site_title: US consumer spending picks up; inflation rises moderately in July
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.5% in July, maintaining momentum from the second quarter and boosting gross domestic product growth to a 3.0% annualized rate. This suggests the economy remains on firmer ground early in the third quarter, potentially arguing against a half-percentage-point interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve next month. Despite concerns over a near-three-year high unemployment rate of 4.3%, inflation remains above the central bank's 2% target, with the personal consumption expenditures price index rising 0.2% last month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoppers carry bags of purchased merchandise at the King of Prussia Mall, United States' largest retail shopping space, in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, U.S., December 8, 2018.  REUTERS/Mark Makela/File Photo

site_title: IHH Healthcare confident Malaysia will remain key medical tourism hub despite headwinds
summary: IHH Healthcare remains optimistic about Malaysia's position as a key medical tourism hub despite headwinds, including the strengthening ringgit and potential competition from Indonesia's healthcare reforms. The group has seen a 50% year-to-date growth in medical tourism revenue in Malaysia and plans to expand its reach by adding new hospitals and beds. In Singapore, IHH Healthcare is developing out-of-hospital transitional care facilities, which are expected to be Ebitda break-even. The group's China clinics are now also Ebitda break-even, following a revamp of operations. IHH Healthcare's management believes the market will remain attractive for future expansion, particularly in Indonesia.

site_title: China's Sinochem plans to exit US shale JV with Exxon: sources
summary: China's Sinochem is planning to sell its 40% stake in a US shale joint venture with ExxonMobil, valued over $2 billion, amid a re-evaluation of its struggling oil exploration and production business. Sinochem hired investment bankers to advise on the sale, which Exxon has the right of first refusal for. The sale would end Sinochem's 11-year involvement in the Permian Basin, a key US shale region, and comes as the company shifts focus to new materials and life sciences.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Men wearing face masks walk past a sign of China National Offshore Oil Corp (CNOOC) outside its headquarters in Beijing, China March 8, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
In 2021, Shell plans to build a biofuels plant at Bukom to help meet its own target of halving emissions by 2030.
ExxonMobil announces FID for mega China petchem project

site_title: Goldman to cut a few hundred jobs in coming weeks in annual cull
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to dismiss a few hundred employees in coming weeks as part of its annual staff reduction, with total cuts expected to be around 3-4% of its workforce. This is in line with the bank's typical approach to keep costs low and make room for new talent. Despite this, Goldman is expected to have more employees at the end of 2024 than it did last year. The move comes after the bank's stock reached an all-time high, rising 32% to surpass $510 per share.

site_title: Sats’ subsidiary proposes to acquire cargo handler in Amsterdam airport
summary: Sats, a subsidiary of the air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services Holland (WFS), is proposing to acquire Menzies World Cargo (Amsterdam) in a deal that will increase warehouse capacity and cargo handling capabilities at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport. The acquisition is pending conditions, including employee advice and a lease agreement. Sats will acquire the loss-making asset for a nominal sum of one euro, with the transaction price determined after pre-completion undertakings. The deal aims to enable WFS to capitalize on its strong local customer relations and service levels, positioning itself for growth over the long term.

images.alt_text: Sats' net profit for the first quarter ended Jun 30 amounted to S$65 million.
Across the broader market, gainers are almost even with losers at 266 to 267, after 848.9 million securities worth S$846.4 million change hands.
Sats Food Services
Ground handler and caterer, Sats, tops the general category of the 2024 Singapore Governance and Transparency Index.
Sats’ institutional catering businesses at several JTC-leased premises located at Pandan Loop would be transferred to Sats Food Hub in Jurong Innovation District under the original plan.

site_title: China considers allowing refinancing on US$5.4 trillion in mortgages
summary: China is considering a plan to allow refinancing of up to $5.4 trillion in mortgages, enabling homeowners to renegotiate terms with their current lenders before January. This move aims to lower borrowing costs, boost consumption, and support the economy amid a housing-led slowdown. Authorities hope to reduce mortgage costs, which have been largely unaffordable for existing homeowners. The plan, if implemented, could cut rates on existing mortgages by a maximum 1 percentage point, saving homeowners about $42 billion, and provide a signal of the central government's support for the economy.

images.alt_text: China’s commercial real estate market is still contending with a huge amount of oversupply. Vacancies are near a two-decade high in some cities while rents continue to plummet.
Unfinished apartment buildings at Phoenix City, a residential project developed by Country Garden Holdings,  Shanghai, China, Jan 17, 2022.

site_title: Strong turnout of over 50,000 runners expected at StanChart Marathon
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon is expected to break records this year, with over 50,000 participants anticipated to take part in the event. As of now, over 37,000 people have signed up, a 40% increase from last year. The event has seen a significant rise in young runners, with a 76% increase in participants aged 18-35, and a 83% increase in female runners within this age group. Overseas participation is also on the rise, with over 9,000 participants from top five markets: Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, China, and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Runners zoom off at the starting point at the 2023 Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon.
Lien Choong Luen, Singapore Athletics Association president receiving the $50,000 cheque from Santoz Kumar, The Ironman Group Singapore general manager.
It is important to do weight-bearing and resistance exercises to maintain muscle mass and function.

site_title: Country Garden delays 2023 annual results again
summary: Country Garden, China's largest property developer, has further delayed the release of its 2023 financial results due to ongoing debt restructuring. The firm had previously delayed the results in March, citing a need for more time to collect information. Trading of its shares remains suspended since April. Country Garden also missed the deadline to publish its first-half 2024 earnings. The company stated it will finalize and publish the 2023 annual results as soon as possible.

site_title: Philippines and Vietnam agree to deepen military and defence ties
summary: The Philippines and Vietnam agreed to deepen military and defence ties, including cooperation on maritime security, amid simmering tension in the South China Sea. Defence Ministers Gilberto Teodoro and Phan Van Giang expressed their commitment to continued interaction and engagements at all levels. The move comes as the two countries and the US have been sparring with China over its actions in the South China Sea, with the Philippines accusing China of aggression and trespassing. Vietnam aims to balance its relations with China while maintaining close ties with the US and other western powers.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr commended the troops for exercising restraint “amidst intense provocation”, and said his country would always exercise its freedoms and rights in line with international law.

site_title: Berita Harian launches news platform for youth on social media
summary: Malay-language newspaper Berita Harian (BH) has launched OMGxBH, a news platform targeting young Malay readers aged 21-34 on social media platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube. The platform features engaging storytelling formats, including images, infographics, and long-form videos, as well as lifestyle content and interviews with inspiring personalities. Since its soft launch in December 2023, the platform has gained over 37,000 followers, exceeding its initial target of 16,500. The platform aims to reach a more youthful audience and is guided by social media data analysis.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim (left), winner of the Young Journalist of the Year award and Wong Pei Ting, winner of the Journalist of the Year award.
SPH bolsters News Tablet offering with Viu promotion, new device

site_title: Thailand’s SCG Packaging buys US$652 million stake in Indonesia’s Fajar Surya
summary: Thailand-based SCG Packaging has acquired an additional $652.4 million stake in Indonesian packaging paper-maker Fajar Surya, increasing its ownership to 99.7%. The acquisition lifts SCG Packaging's stake from 55.24% to 99.7%. Fajar Surya reported revenues of $1.1 billion in 2023, and SCG Packaging aims to expand its operations in Southeast Asia.

site_title: HK tycoon Cheng’s family office appoints son to co-CEO role
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Henry Cheng's family office has appointed his son Christopher as co-CEO of Chow Tai Fook Enterprises, alongside Gilbert Ho, to lead corporate functions and operations. Patrick Tsang, an in-law, will oversee North Asia investment, Americas, Australia, and Europe. Four of Cheng's children now lead key aspects of the family business, with Adrian as CEO of New World Development Co and Sonia serving as a joint vice-chairman for Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group. Henry Cheng remains in charge of the family office and chairman of the companies, amidst a succession saga sparked by his public statement seeking an heir.

site_title: VCs on the ropes in South-east Asia. Here’s how they can bounce back
summary: Southeast Asia's venture capital industry is struggling, with fundraising expected to be down 48% from 2021 levels. Despite raising over $14 billion, the sector faces challenges in providing returns to investors. Traditional VCs focus on established companies, while venture studios, which invest in startups from scratch, offer a more hands-on approach. Studios believe they can better tackle the region's complexities, but collaboration between studios and VCs is crucial. VCs should adapt by reducing fund sizes, being more flexible with investments, and building relationships with ecosystems. Smaller funds can offer more attractive returns without inflated valuations.

images.alt_text: Managers of the fortunes of the world’s ultra-wealthy are searching out private credit funds at a slower pace this year than last, according to the latest data from Preqin.
Big Tech bigwigs such as Bill Gates and Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg were touted as prime examples of founders who did not need higher education to find success.
In this prolonged dry spell, caution is the name of the game.

site_title: Pacific bloc scrubs Taiwan from document after China complaint
summary: China successfully pressured the Pacific Islands Forum to remove a paragraph from a joint declaration, effectively scrubbing Taiwan from the document. The paragraph, which reaffirmed Taiwan's participation in the forum, was deleted after China's special envoy expressed outrage, calling it a "mistake" that "must be corrected." The move is seen as a setback for Taiwan, which has faced increasing pressure from China to be excluded from international bodies and lose its autonomy.

images.alt_text: Wang Yi, the director of the Communist Party's Central Foreign Affairs Commission Office, speaks before talks with White House National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan at Yanqi Lake in Beijing, China, August 27, 2024. Ng Han Guan/Pool via REUTERS
“You know, we’re no different than an insurance company. Taiwan doesn’t give us anything.," said Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.
Pacific Islands countries are projected to expand by 3.5 per cent in 2024 and 3.3 per cent in 2025.

site_title: Biden’s solar tariffs undermine his own climate agenda
summary: US President Joe Biden's solar-panel policies, including high tariffs on imported panels and subsidies for solar plants, are undermining his administration's climate agenda and economic goals. The tariffs, which are expected to surge by up to 286% and increase consumer prices by nearly three times the global average, will likely dampen demand for solar panels. The move is also expected to jeopardize America's clean-energy transition, as it fails to create good jobs and boost domestic production. With China currently producing 80% of the world's silicon, it's unclear how much the US can realistically boost its solar-panel production capacity, and the prospect of higher tariffs could lead to more cancellations of planned installations.

images.alt_text: Imports have tripled since 2022, when President Joe Biden ordered a two-year waiver on the collection of expanded duties for some solar components from South-east Asia, which expired in June.

site_title: Intel rises as report of chipmaker exploring options stokes investor enthusiasm
summary: Intel's shares rose 3% on Friday, driven by a report that the company is exploring options to boost its value, including a potential merger or split. Intel is working with investment bankers and considering separating its main product business from its struggling manufacturing unit. The move aims to address the company's financial struggles, which have seen its market value fall below $100 billion for the first time in three decades. This comes after Intel's disappointing quarterly report and lay-offs, which have impacted 15% of its workforce.

images.alt_text: The employees who were laid off mostly worked on marketing and recruiting for the startup, the report said.
The entry of Apple into OpenAI’s ownership, if confirmed, would come as the company is set to announce its new iPhones on Sept 9 that are expected to optimise AI innovations.

site_title: CapitaLand’s retail, workspace CEO Chris Chong leaves group
summary: CapitaLand's retail, workspace CEO Chris Chong is leaving the group after more than six years, citing a career break. Ervin Yeo, group chief strategy officer, has taken over Chong's portfolio, overseeing CapitaLand's commercial and asset-management business in China and South-east Asia. Under Chong's leadership, CapitaLand was the first mall operator to enter the metaverse with its virtual experience CapitaVerse. Chong's departure follows a successful period for the group, with its commercial management vertical contributing S$185 million to its fee-related business revenue in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: CLI has inked a new third-party management contract for an iconic retail asset in Singapore, said Chris Chong, its chief executive officer of retail and workspace in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Fresh from farm to feast in 36 hours: Malaysia’s durians hit lucrative Chinese market
summary: Malaysia's fresh durians, including popular varieties like Musang King, Black Thorn, D24, and IOI, were successfully transported from Kuala Lumpur to Zhengzhou, China via air cargo charter service. The 15-tonne shipment marked the first portion of a 40-tonne export over three days, targeting major cities like Beijing and Shanghai. The retail price of fresh Musang King in Shenzhen is RM350 per fruit, showcasing a lucrative entry into the Chinese market for Malaysia's top durian exporter.

images.alt_text: Malaysia is not the only country producing Musang King durian but the taste and texture of Malaysian-grown Musang King are distinct due to the suitable climate and soil conditions.
Durian is packed for export at a port in Laem Chabang, Thailand, which is by far the fruit’s biggest exporting country.
FILE PHOTO: A man arranges durians at a market stall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Tencent, NetEase rethink Japan approach as game strategy stalls
summary: Tencent Holdings and NetEase are reevaluating their investments in Japanese game studios after years of spending yielded few successful titles. NetEase has cut nearly all jobs at its Ouka studio in Tokyo, while Tencent is scaling back investments and backing off funding commitments for new games. The move follows a stagnating Chinese market and a mismatch in ambition between Chinese firms and local developers. Despite continued partnerships with prominent Japanese studios, the Chinese game publishers are reassessing their strategy and prioritizing domestic success.

images.alt_text: Black Myth: Wukong, an action-adventure title based on the antics of the fabled Monkey King, garnered more than 1.4 million concurrent players on Steam shortly after its global debut on Tuesday (Aug 20).
Tencent's revenue jumped 8 per cent to 161.1 billion yuan (S$29.7 billion) for the April-to-June period, versus the projected estimate of 161.4 billion yuan.
Tencent in June became one of China’s best-performing stocks.
Alibaba sold US$4.5 billion in debt that can be turned into equity last week, a record for convertibles denominated in dollars by an Asian company.
With the deal, famed franchises like StarCraft, Diablo, Hearthstone and Overwatch will once again be live for players in China.

site_title: US workforce to expand just 0.4% a year in coming decade
summary: The US labor market is projected to grow by 0.4% annually from 2024 to 2033, resulting in 6.7 million additional jobs over the decade. However, the growth rate is slower than the previous decade, driven by slower population growth. The aging population and prevalence of chronic conditions are expected to drive employment growth in healthcare, while declines in younger cohorts are expected to reduce demand for education jobs. The overall labor force participation rate is projected to fall 1.4 percentage points to 61.2% over the decade.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Construction workers stay in the shade of a building while working during hot weather at the construction site of a large office complex in the biotech sector of San Diego, California, U.S., July 2, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Denza D9 review: The luxury world’s silent killer
summary: BYD, a Chinese luxury car brand, is expanding its presence with the Denza D9, a luxury MPV with seven seats, priced at or under S$300,000. The D9 boasts Business Class seats, a massive chrome face, and features like a huge glass roof and optional 14-speaker sound system. With seamless and strong acceleration, the D9 is also remarkably quiet, even for an electric car. BYD's aggressive rollout of new products aims to challenge established luxury marques, with plans to launch 10 new models in the next year.

site_title: Japan to introduce new entry rules for Singaporeans and other visa-exempt tourists
summary: Japan plans to introduce a new screening system, called Jesta, by 2030, requiring visitors from visa-exempt countries, including Singapore, to declare personal information before entry. The system aims to reduce overstaying and will apply to travelers from 71 countries. Visitors will need to declare purpose and destination online, and those at risk of overstaying may be required to obtain a regular visa. The move is part of efforts to manage record-breaking tourist numbers, with 17.78 million visitors in the first half of 2024, exceeding the 2019 pre-pandemic record.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A crowd of tourists are seen at Kiyomizu-dera temple in Kyoto, western Japan March 30, 2023.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: A brighter shade of green
summary: Singapore's aging buildings pose a sustainability challenge, with only 58% of buildings greened as of 2023. Retrofitting these buildings is costly, with some projects requiring millions of dollars for upgrades. However, the Singapore Green Building Council (SGBC) offers a cost-effective approach through Energy Performance Contracting (EPC), which allows building owners to work with accredited firms to implement upgrades and reduce energy costs. Successful EPC projects have resulted in significant energy savings and carbon emissions reductions, demonstrating that older buildings can achieve remarkable sustainability improvements with the right approach.

images.alt_text: Pan Pacific Orchard was purpose-built to global sustainability specifications.
Keppel will develop and operate these projects, which include decarbonisation of power generation, renewable energy, electric mobility and green buildings.
The EENP Awards recognised the efforts of nine companies from various sectors to become energy efficient with Honourable Mentions at the EENP Awards 2023.

site_title: Potential government sales of Bitcoin unnerves crypto market
summary: The US, China, UK, and Ukraine are potential sources of government sales of Bitcoin, which could lead to a $33 billion supply overhang. The US holds approximately 203,220 Bitcoin, followed by China's 190,000, the UK's 61,200, and Ukraine's 46,350. The crypto market is also experiencing waning liquidity, with Bitcoin's seven-day average trading volume declining to 2% after peaking near 5% in March. This has led to choppy price action, with the digital asset dropping 8% so far in August.

images.alt_text: According to investors, Elon Musk deliberately drove up dogecoin’s price more than 36,000 per cent over two years and then let it crash, with he and Tesla often timing trades to Musk’s public statements and activities concerning dogecoin.
Options are listed derivatives that give the holder the right to buy or sell an asset, such as a stock or exchange-traded product, at a predetermined price by a set date.

site_title: Germany’s struggling economy starts to take toll on its banks
summary: Germany's economy is taking a toll on its banks, with risk provisioning by the country's largest lenders rising almost 50% in the first half of the year. Several banks, including DZ Bank, raised risk provisions fourfold compared to the year-earlier period, citing loans to companies and consumers in trouble. Corporate insolvencies in Germany rose 30% in the first half, with several companies, including chemicals manufacturers and battery makers, facing financial difficulties. Experts warn that things may get worse before they get better due to ongoing geopolitical uncertainties and rising borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: A euro sign sculpture stands in front of the European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Jan. 13, 2011. European Central Bank President Jean-Claude Trichet signaled he's prepared to raise interest rates if needed to fight inflation even as leaders struggle to contain the region's sovereign debt crisis. Photographer: Hannelore Foerster/Bloomberg

site_title: Scenario planning, foresight, and the power of imagination: Navigating an uncertain future
summary: Scenario planning, a methodology tailored for uncertain futures, encourages practitioners to challenge assumptions, adapt strategies, and avoid tunnel vision. This approach helps individuals and organizations envision multiple plausible outcomes, fostering resilience against uncertainties. By leveraging imagination, scenario planning differs from traditional forecasting, which relies on historical data. A collaborative effort among strategists is essential in developing robust strategies across various futures, enhancing decision-making in an unpredictable world.

images.alt_text: Smoke billows following Israeli bombardment in Nuseirat in the central Gaza Strip on Aug 11, 2024, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian political group Hamas. Geopolitical tensions are a major risk for investors.
Four scenarios for business from Ukraine conflict

site_title: US: Dow notches record high close after upbeat economic data
summary: US stocks reached record highs on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 41,563.08 points, as upbeat economic data raised expectations for a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September. Consumer spending increased solidly in July, suggesting the economy remains strong, while prices rose moderately. Key stocks including Tesla, Amazon, and Broadcom rose, while Nvidia rebounded from a drop on Thursday. The S&P 500 climbed 1% to end at 5,648.40 points, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.1% to 17,713.62 points.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on August 16, 2024. US stocks edged lower in early trading Friday, as traders looked to lock in gains at the end of a positive week for major Wall Street indices. Around 10 minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1 percent at 40,518.87, and the S&P was 0.1 percent lower at 5,536.08. The Nasdaq slipped 0.2 percent to 17,566.08. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up to record high as inflation data sets stage for ECB rate cut
summary: European shares reached an all-time high, closing above 525 points, as inflation data fell to 2.2% in August, its slowest pace since July 2021. This cemented market expectations for an interest rate cut in September. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained 1.2% in August, marking a second consecutive month of gains, amid hopes for interest rate cuts in both Europe and the US. The strong economic data has helped European stocks bounce back from a massive selloff early in August.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index was up 0.8 per cent at 524.57 points, narrowly missing a fresh record-high close, while Germany’s DAX rose 0.7 per cent to a record high.

site_title: Visits to VEP info counter in Woodlands by appointment only; bookings can be made online
summary: Singapore's new VEP information counter in Woodlands is now open by appointment only, with bookings available online. The move aims to free up staff to handle inquiries, following large crowds since its opening on Aug 19. Motorists without a valid VEP risk being denied entry into Johor or fined up to RM2,000 (S$600). Appointment bookings are open for the next three weeks, and visitors must enter personal info and choose a time slot between 9am and 5pm.

images.alt_text: Announcement of SOPs for Malaysian workers in Singapore postponed to Mar 30
Johor to announce SOPs for Malaysian workers in Singapore
Malaysia VEP enforcement delayed until next year, says Transport Minister

site_title: Court rejects application by David Yong, of Netflix’s Super Rich In Korea, to travel to Japan
summary: Singaporean businessman David Yong, CEO of Evergreen Group Holdings, had his application to travel to Japan for work rejected by a court due to concerns he remains a flight risk. Yong is facing four falsification of account charges involving millions of dollars. He had to access funds in Japan as his Singapore bank accounts are frozen, but the court noted that the business meeting could be held virtually, and another representative could be appointed. Yong is currently out on bail of S$1 million and has to abide by strict bail conditions.

site_title: Flash Coffee taps ex-Foodpanda CEO in turnaround bid
summary: Flash Coffee, a tech-enabled coffee chain, has hired former Foodpanda CEO Jakob Angele as its executive chairman in a bid to hit profitability. The firm, still headquartered in Singapore, liquidated its operations in the city-state last October and sold its Thai business, leaving it with 67 outlets in Indonesia. Angele believes the majority of these stores are Ebitda-positive, indicating the company is going all-in on its remaining market. This turnaround move aims to help Flash Coffee recover from a rough couple of years.

images.alt_text: Flash Coffee is winding up in Taiwan and Singapore and has sold off its business in Thailand to focus on other markets, such as Indonesia.
Flash Coffee at PLQ was closed when BT visited in the late morning on Friday (Oct 13).
The Jurong Point outlet was empty and closed when BT visited on Friday morning, with no sign of the "ON STRIKE" notice shown in a TikTok video.

site_title: Brazil watchdog moves to block access to Elon Musk's X after court order
summary: Brazil's telecommunications regulator suspended access to Elon Musk's X social network due to a court order that required the platform to name a local representative and pay fines. The suspension, which began on Friday, could force X to lose its largest market and further exacerbate the platform's advertising revenue struggles. Musk has argued that the ruling is unjustified censorship, while the judge, Alexandre de Moraes, insists that social media needs hate speech regulations.

site_title: Singtel raises S$1.48 million for students with special needs
summary: Singtel raised S$1.48 million at its annual charity golf event to support students with special needs, surpassing the previous year's record of S$1.28 million. The funds will go to the Singtel Touching Lives Fund, which supports about 1,800 students yearly and has raised over S$57 million since its inception in 2002. The charity event marks a significant milestone in the fund's efforts to provide internships and employment opportunities for students with special needs.

images.alt_text: Students from APSN Chaoyang School showcase their musical talents with a performance of Home by Kit Chan at the appreciation dinner for Singtel's annual charity golf fundraiser.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, August 30th, 2024 (Ep 134)
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, driven by US data and a record Dow on Wall Street. In South-east Asia, insurtech deals surged 4 times to US$2.35 billion in 2023, despite fewer transactions. Additionally, Singapore Airlines (SIA) received foreign direct investment approval for its Air India-Vistara merger.

images.alt_text: Authorities are ramping up a push to reduce mortgage costs after the central bank encouraged such support last year and banks responded with a rare rate cut on outstanding mortgages of first homes.

Singapore Airlines says it now expects the merger to complete by end-2024.

site_title: Uber CEO says seeing ‘double-digit growth’ in South Korea
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi announced the company's double-digit growth in South Korea, citing a 90% market share held by Kakao Taxi. Despite initial challenges, including a ban and suspension of services, Uber launched a joint venture with licensed taxis, leading to month-on-month growth in ridership and driver participation. The company attributes its success to local partnerships and respect for regulations, aiming to build a business in collaboration with local authorities.

images.alt_text: Motorcycle taxi drivers working for online ride-hailing start-ups protest against low tariffs in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 29, 2024. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana
Shopee has helped Sea reach profitability in its recent quarterly earnings report.

The company now aims to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, though the timeline for that remains unclear.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hires 13-year Citigroup veteran in UK wealth push
summary: Deutsche Bank has hired 13-year Citigroup veteran Adam Proctor as a managing director and senior relationship manager to focus on ultra-high-net worth individuals and their personal investment firms in the UK. Proctor, 45, will join the bank in London next month and report to James Whittaker, head of the Frankfurt-based private bank. The hire is part of Deutsche Bank's UK wealth push, which aims to double assets managed for rich families in South-east Asia and the Middle East. The bank has 613 billion euros in assets under management in its private bank.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
Deutsche Bank said it reached agreements with “more than 80 plaintiffs representing almost 60 per cent of the total claims in the litigation” based on a proposal of 31 euros (S$44) per share.

site_title: Geopolitics, disruptions and domestic constraints will challenge growth: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong warned that geopolitical tensions, disruptions, and domestic constraints will challenge the country's economic growth. He identified three key drivers: the global operating environment facing "tremendous pressure", the need to navigate complex trade relationships, and domestic constraints such as an ageing population and low fertility rates. Despite these challenges, Gan emphasized the importance of pushing the frontier on productivity and innovation, expanding trade architecture, and investing in a skilled and agile workforce to drive economic growth.

site_title: Mastercard to get rid of card numbers for online shopping
summary: Mastercard plans to eliminate credit card numbers for online shopping, a decade after introducing a technology that replaces them with tokens. The company is now processing 1 billion transactions weekly and aims to expand this technology to replace security measures like passwords with biometric data. This move aims to combat the rising issue of online payment fraud, expected to exceed $91 billion by 2028. Mastercard will partner with banks and payment providers to replace one-time passwords with tokenized biometric information, a step expected to curb data breaches and fraud.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Mastercard logo is seen on a credit card in this picture illustration August 30, 2017.   REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Issue 114: Mainstreaming ESG-linked pay; climate policy is better together
summary: Singapore-listed companies are seeing a decline in the adoption of ESG-related factors in executive compensation, reversing a trend that began in 2021. Despite a global increase in the use of ESG compensation factors among Asia-Pacific companies, Singapore's listed companies have seen a decrease from 26% in 2021 to 16% in 2023. Policymakers and investors are putting pressure on businesses to hold executives accountable for ESG performance, making it harder to avoid linking compensation to ESG outcomes. A combination of climate policies addressing different facets of the issue is more effective in cutting emissions than standalone policies.

images.alt_text: By aligning with global best practices and setting new benchmarks, the Republic is leading the international discourse on sustainable data centre development.
“We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.
Pacific islands leaders attend the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in Nuku'alofa, Tonga, Aug 26, 2024.

The Taj Mahal amid heavy smog conditions in Agra, India, Nov 23, 2023. Despite an improvement in air quality in South Asia in 2022, the region continues to breathe the world’s most-polluted air, with its residents losing more than 3.5 years of life expectancy on average, the annual Air Quality Life Index warned.

TOPSHOT - This underwater photo taken on June 14, 2024 shows Black Turtle Dive conservation teacher Sandra Rubio (R) and her 14-year-old conservation and citizen science student Nannalin "Fleur" Pornprasertsom (L) surveying bleached corals around Koh Tao island in the southern Thai province of Surat Thani. Coral bleaching has been recorded in over 60 countries since early 2023, threatening reefs that are key to ocean biodiversity and support fishing and tourism industries globally, and that death spiral is everywhere in the waters of the Gulf of Thailand around Koh Tao. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP) / To go with 'THAILAND-OCEANS-CONSERVATION-CORAL,FOCUS' by Sara HUSSEIN

site_title: Markets should beware the normalisation of threats
summary: Stock markets are experiencing a surge, with the Dow Jones reaching a record high, driven by optimism about a "soft landing" for the US economy. However, investors should be cautious as risks are building, including geopolitical threats, a potential Trump victory, and the looming US debt crisis. The normalization of deviance, a phenomenon where investors become accustomed to and ignore risks, is also a concern. As investors should hedge against potential "what if" scenarios, they must also consider the deviant threats they have learned to normalize, including threats to Fed independence.

images.alt_text: It is clear that Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris (right) and her running mate Minnesota governor Tim Walz have dramatically reshaped this year’s race to the White House, flipping within weeks the narrative of the 2024 election.

Smoke billows following Israeli bombardment in Nuseirat in the central Gaza Strip on Aug 11, 2024, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian political group Hamas. Geopolitical tensions are a major risk for investors.
Should Donald Trump win a second term aas US president, investors should expect a strong attempt to renew his flagship 2017 tax cuts and further reduction in corporate taxes.

site_title: Cash-loving investors dig in even as US rate cuts threaten payouts
summary: US investors are staying loyal to cash despite expected interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, which could pull yields down from above 5%. Despite a record $6.24 trillion in US money markets, individual investors are holding onto cash, with 80% of one retiree's portfolio in money markets. The durability of cash as an asset class is a recent shift in the post-Covid investment landscape, driven by its safety and liquidity. Investors are hesitant to move out of cash, fearing volatility in stocks and rich valuations, but may be forced to reconsider if the Federal Reserve cuts rates faster or deeper than expected.

images.alt_text: Proctor, 45, will join Deutsche Bank in London next month as a managing director and senior relationship manager focused on ultra-high-net worth individuals and their personal investment firms.

site_title: Doctor charged in death of Matthew Perry 'incredibly remorseful'
summary: A doctor, Dr. Mark Chavez, has been charged in the death of Matthew Perry due to a ketamine overdose. Chavez, who previously signed an agreement to enter a guilty plea, surrendered his medical license and passport, and was ordered not to practice medicine as part of his bond conditions. Chavez expressed remorse, stating he is "incredibly remorseful" for the situation, and will cooperate fully with the investigation. Another doctor, Dr. Salvador Plasencia, has pleaded not guilty, while the alleged "ketamine queen," Jasveen Sangha, remains at large.

images.alt_text: Alleged evidence discovered in what authorities have dubbed the “Sangha stash.”. Five people who allegedly supplied ketamine to "Friends" star Matthew Perry in a bid to exploit his drug addiction for profit have been charged in relation to his overdose death, US officials said on August 15.
FILE PHOTO: Actor Matthew Perry arrives at the Comedy Awards 2012 in New York City, New York April 28, 2012. REUTERS/Lee Celano/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba wins Beijing’s approval in end to years-long scrutiny
summary: China's antitrust watchdog has approved Alibaba, ending a years-long scrutiny, following the e-commerce leader's improvements in services and fostering competition. Alibaba stopped forcing exclusive arrangements on merchants and improved services for shoppers. The endorsement coincides with Beijing's growing support for private firms and the technology industry, amid a post-Covid economic funk. The antitrust regulator deemed Alibaba's three-year rectification work "effective" and will continue to regulate its operations to ensure compliance.

images.alt_text: The decision by shareholders during its annual general meeting on Thursday will provide a much-needed boost to Alibaba, which has underperformed the market in recent years owing to weak consumption and after a painful crackdown by Beijing on the tech industry.

site_title: Land betterment charge rates cut by 5.4% on average for non-landed residential use
summary: The Singapore government has cut the land betterment charge (LBC) rates for non-landed residential use by 5.4% on average for the next half year, marking the biggest cut since 2019. The rates are up for landed residential, commercial, and hotel/hospital use groups. The reductions reflect a decrease in developers' appetite for the residential market due to overhanging property cooling measures, a high interest rate environment, and rising global geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.
Land betterment charge rates for landed residential use have been left unchanged.
Developers pay a land betterment charge for the right to enhance the use of some sites or to build bigger projects on them.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia officials met to advance talks on Johor deal
summary: Singapore and Malaysia officials met to advance talks on a special economic zone in Johor, discussing topics such as economic sectors, movement of people and goods, ease of doing business, and talent development. The meeting aims to bring mutual benefits through a full-fledged deal, with a potential signing in November. The 11th Malaysia-Singapore Leaders' Retreat is also expected to be held later this year.

site_title: MHA seeks feedback on orders to restrict banking transactions of scam targets
summary: The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) in Singapore is seeking feedback on a proposed Bill that allows police to temporarily restrict the banking transactions of individuals targeted by digital or telecommunication scams. The Protection from Scams Bill will not cover scams with in-person interactions and aims to protect those who refuse to believe they are being scammed. The restriction orders will cover online banking, mobile banking, and credit facilities, and can be issued for 28 days with the option to renew. The MHA hopes the bill will prevent scammers from deceiving victims into applying for credit lines or loans on their behalf.

images.alt_text: If the trend continues, scam losses could exceed $770 million by the end of the year.
The police said they observed an increase in suspicious activity in local bank accounts opened by foreigners.
CPFB advised members who intend to make large withdrawals to plan in advance, and those who intend to withdraw large amounts to do so online over multiple days.

site_title: Lululemon’s US$98 yoga pants face baggier fashions, more rivals
summary: Lululemon lowered its sales and profit outlook for the year due to increased competition and inflation, citing slower sales growth in North America. The company expects sales of up to US$10.48 billion, down from a previous view of US$10.8 billion. Comparable store sales in North America fell 3% in the second quarter, missing analyst expectations, while the company still posted robust growth in mainland China, with comparable sales rising 19%. Lululemon shares rose 4.8% in extended trading after the release.

images.alt_text: T he meteoric rise of dupes is the latest threat facing global retail giants who can’t seem to figure out what Chinese shoppers want.
Hong Kong, which has relaxed visa rules to attract skilled workers, has seen an influx of middle-class residents from mainland China seeking to escape the country's economic slowdown.

site_title: India lifts sugar curbs for ethanol in threat to global supply
summary: India has lifted restrictions on sugar mills and distilleries using sugarcane juice to make ethanol, allowing producers to use cane juice, B-heavy and C-heavy molasses during the 2024-25 year. The move is expected to prolong export curbs and tighten global supply, affecting the world's second-biggest sugar producer. The easing of restrictions will help India meet its target of boosting ethanol in gasoline blends to 20% by November 2025, and shares of sugar millers have jumped following the news.

images.alt_text: India government wants to make sure there is enough sugar for the local market at reasonable prices, and on using more cane to produce ethanol.
The US Department of Agriculture’s Foreign Agricultural Service predicts India wheat imports at 2 million tonnes in the season that began on Apr 1 on steady local demand.

India’s absence from the world sugar market would be likely to increase benchmark prices in New York and London that are already trading around multi-year highs, triggering fears of further inflation on global food markets.

site_title: Australian home prices to keep rising as supply remains tight
summary: Australian home prices are expected to rise an average 6.3% this year, driven by tight supply and robust population growth, despite the highest interest rates in 13 years. The Reserve Bank of Australia's benchmark cash rate has risen to 4.35%, but the low supply of affordable housing and population growth have prevented average house prices from falling sharply. This will make it more difficult for first-time home buyers, with average urban home rents forecast to rise 5-7% over the coming year.

images.alt_text: Figures from property consultant CoreLogic showed prices across the nation climbed 0.5 per cent in July, an increase on unchanged from June.

site_title: Gold drops as dollar, yields firm after US inflation report
summary: Gold prices slipped 1% on Friday, but are set for a monthly gain due to a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September. The US inflation report showed a 0.2% rise in personal consumption expenditures, confirming inflation is no longer a major concern for the Fed. Investors now focus on the upcoming US non-farm payroll report, which may solidify a 50- or 25-basis-point interest rate cut.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 0.1 per cent at US$2,517.91 per ounce, as of 0037 GMT, and was on track to log its second consecutive monthly gain, rising about 3 per cent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 30)
summary: The Land Betterment Charge (LBC) rates for non-landed residential use in Singapore have been cut by an average of 5.4% from September 1, 2024, to February 28, 2025. This change aims to make it more affordable for developers to build projects on certain sites. The LBC is a payment made by developers to enhance the use of sites or build bigger projects on them. The reduction in LBC rates is expected to boost the development of non-landed residential projects in Singapore.

site_title: China factory activity extends slide in August as headwinds rise
summary: China's factory activity contracted for a fourth consecutive month in August, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index declining to 49.1 from 49.4 in July. The economy, which targets a 5% gross domestic product growth this year, faces headwinds from a prolonged property downturn, trade tensions with the US and Europe, and a slowdown in exports. Economists predict China will fall short of its growth target, with the non-manufacturing measure of activity in construction and services showing a slight improvement. The government's efforts to boost sentiment through interest-rate cuts have yet to yield results.

images.alt_text: Authorities are ramping up a push to reduce mortgage costs after the central bank encouraged such support last year and banks responded with a rare rate cut on outstanding mortgages of first homes.
China to continue with low-carbon reforms, energy regulator says
China’s commercial real estate market is still contending with a huge amount of oversupply. Vacancies are near a two-decade high in some cities while rents continue to plummet.
With China’s economic momentum subdued since March amid the real estate downturn and a tight fiscal policy stance, UBS now expects gross domestic product to expand 4.6 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Drug distributors strike US$300 million opioid settlement with US health plans
summary: US drug distributors McKesson, Cardinal Health, and Cencora (formerly AmerisourceBergen) have agreed to pay $300 million to resolve claims from health insurers and benefit plans related to the US opioid epidemic. The settlement covers third-party payers that funded overprescribed pills and treatment for opioid use disorder. The companies did not admit wrongdoing, and the payment is to be distributed among the three companies at a ratio of 38.1% by McKesson, 30.9% by Cardinal, and 31% by Cencora.

images.alt_text: drugs, pills, capsules

site_title: Now an acclaimed restaurateur, he long concealed a secret
summary: Restaurateur Arjav Ezekiel, 36, has revealed his secret: he is an undocumented immigrant who came to the US on a tourist visa with his family at 12. Despite his success as a sommelier and restaurant owner, Ezekiel concealed his immigration status, fearing deportation. He gained protection under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program in 2012, allowing him to work legally. Ezekiel's journey highlights the often-overlooked contributions of undocumented immigrants in the food industry, where they may have played a role in harvesting, pruning, and producing the food we eat.

images.alt_text: Winemaker Esperanza Hernandez poses with a glass of wine in her Old Roots Vineyard in Wellingtonbridge, near Wexford, southern Ireland on July 13, 2024. A tiny outpost in the wine world, Ireland's handful of wine-makers are cautiously eyeing long-term growth potential as climate change warms up its cool climate. And at Ireland's largest vineyard, owner Esperanza Hernandez says "better weather makes it more possible than before to make high-quality wine" even on the sun-starved island. Hernandez's 10-acre (4-hectare) vineyard lies near the village of Wellingtonbridge in the south-eastern coastal county of Wexford, statistically Ireland's sunniest corner. (Photo by Paul Faith / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY BY Peter MURPHY

site_title: Yuan hits strongest in more than a year as flows offset fundamentals
summary: The Chinese yuan has reached its strongest level in over a year, gaining 0.3% to 7.0752 per US dollar, amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut and US dollar weakness. This surge comes as Chinese exporters are expected to sell their US dollar holdings, boosting the yuan. Despite sluggish growth and a slowdown in consumer spending, the currency is seen as supported by recent stimulus measures, with some analysts predicting further appreciation to 7-7.1 per dollar by year-end.

images.alt_text: The yuan isn’t fully convertible as the authorities limit the inflow and outflow of foreign currency to aid their control of the economy.
The PBOC has been walking a fine line of stimulating growth and cooling a government-bond buying spree to limit financial risks in recent months.

site_title: A driven introvert creates his dream home in Paris
summary: Max Gunawan, a driven introvert, has created his dream home in Paris, a 700 sq ft apartment in the historic Place des Vosges square. He designed every detail himself, blending minimalist simplicity with artful whimsy. The apartment features a refined color palette, clever storage solutions, and unique touches like a hidden hallway and a whale sculpture. Gunawan, a product designer, aimed to create a space that would inspire his creativity and provide a sense of calm, reflecting his love for architecture and Japanese design.

images.alt_text: Beatriz Ramo Lopez de Angulo, left, and  Bernd Upmeyer at the tiny apartment they designed in Rotterdam, Netherlands, in July 2024. This Cabanon, which is on the top floor of a 1950s mixed-use building, is 74 square feet, half the size of the inspiration.

site_title: LTA to waive S$10 ERP admin charge for missed payments settled within 5-day grace period
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that from October, it will waive the S$10 administrative charge for missed Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) payments settled within a 5-day grace period. This move aims to reduce costs for businesses and individuals, and is part of the government's efforts to ease regulatory burdens. The change will be facilitated by the On-Board Unit, which will detect and process missed ERP payments directly, and will be implemented as part of the new ERP 2.0 system.

images.alt_text: Owners of new vehicles can finalise OBU installation options – such as where to place the processing unit or whether to have the optional touchscreen display – through relevant authorised distributors or dealers.

The evolution of Singapore's road pricing system (from 12 o'clock, clockwise): A sign signifying the boundary of the Restricted Zone where the Area Licensing Scheme (ALS) was in operation; cars queueing up to buy ALS licences; a monthly ALS disc costing S$60; a motorcyclist signalling he wants to buy a S$1 licence (two fingers mean S$2 and
three, $3); a hut at the entry point into the city where Cisco guards looked out for vehicles without ALS discs; and people forming carpools, which were exempt from ALS charges for 15 years, until 1989.

site_title: DBS consumer banking head Jeremy Soo to succeed UOB’s Susan Hwee as Nets chair
summary: DBS' consumer banking head Jeremy Soo will succeed UOB's Susan Hwee as Nets chairman, effective September 1. Soo has over 30 years of experience in consumer banking and finance, and is known for his advocacy of inclusive banking. He will leverage his expertise to strengthen Nets' leadership in the payments space, while Hwee will head UOB's group retail business, starting September 1.

site_title: China's top airlines post losses, hit by slow international travel and domestic oversupply
summary: China's top airlines, including Air China, China Southern Airlines, and China Eastern Airlines, reported losses in the first half of the year due to slower-than-expected international travel recovery and domestic oversupply. International traffic grew, but at a slower pace than expected, with flights to the US and other destinations held back by low demand. The airlines' losses are attributed to increased competition as aviation capacity returns globally, with domestic flights rising 15% and international flights 23% lower than pre-pandemic levels in July.

images.alt_text: A China Southern Airlines Airbus A321 plane is towed at Changi Airport in Singapore April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: UK house prices fall for first time since April, mortgage lender Nationwide says
summary: UK house prices fell 0.2% in August, their first monthly drop since April, according to Nationwide Building Society. Despite this, annual prices rose 2.4% from August last year, the fastest increase since December 2022. The housing market remains subdued but is expected to strengthen gradually as affordability constraints ease, according to Nationwide chief economist Robert Gardner. The Bank of England's recent interest rate cut may also contribute to a potential rate cut in September.

images.alt_text: Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Britain’s top antitrust enforcer has opened an investigation into eight housebuilders to probe potential information sharing, sharpening scrutiny of a sector that’s failing to deliver enough affordable housing to meet demand. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Prices in London have risen by just 0.2 per cent year on year.

site_title: Tokyo inflation tops expectations, supporting case for BOJ hikes
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to hold its policy steady in September, following Tokyo's inflation rate exceeding expectations at 2.4% in August. This supports the case for further rate hikes as the bank balances economic support and inflation control. Governor Kazuo Ueda has indicated a possible rate hike if price trends align with the bank's projections. The BOJ's decision will be made on September 20.

images.alt_text: A fallen electricity pole following Typhoon Shanshan in Miyazaki, Japan, Aug 29, 2024.

site_title: Gold prices poised for monthly gain; focus on US data
summary: Gold prices are poised for a second consecutive monthly gain, rising about 3% as traders await a potential US interest rate cut in September. Spot gold fell 0.1% to US$2,517.91 per ounce, while US gold futures dropped 0.4% to US$2,551.20. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge, Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) data, is due later today, which may influence the central bank's policy outlook.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.5 per cent to US$2,513.77 per ounce, as of 0250 GMT. Bullion hit a record high of US$2,531.60 on Aug 20 and is up nearly 22 per cent this year so far.

site_title: GIC acquires another logistics facility in Japan
summary: GIC, a Singapore sovereign wealth fund, has acquired a four-floor logistics facility in Yokohama, Japan, for an undisclosed amount. The 126,000 square meter facility, completed in 2022, provides access to the Greater Tokyo region and features a seismic-base isolation system for earthquake resistance. This is GIC's latest acquisition in Japan, following several other logistics assets developed by Daiwa House Industry. GIC expects demand for modern logistics spaces to continue to grow, driven by e-commerce and supply-chain optimization trends.

images.alt_text: GIC is one of the world’s biggest sovereign wealth funds.

The Shiodome City Center rises above the
streets of Tokyo January 8, 2003. Mitsui
Fudosan Co., Japan's biggest developer,
may have to slash rents by more than a fifth
to fill its 43-story property after a merger
of chemicals makers fell through, real estate
brokers familiar with the agreement said.

site_title:
Pressing need for business parks to reposition 
and reinvent their spaces: real estate don
summary: A survey by the National University of Singapore (NUS) found that business parks in Singapore remain relevant and competitive, with 70% of real estate executives agreeing on their relevance. However, the changing work landscape, driven by hybrid work arrangements and technological advancements, may hurt demand for such spaces. The vacancy rate at Changi Business Park has increased, with nearly 40% of unoccupied space, prompting business park operators to reposition and reinvent their spaces to remain attractive.

images.alt_text: Changi Business Park  Photographer: Aparna Nori/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore’s book clubs boom as social media sparks reading renaissance
summary: Singapore's book clubs are booming, with a 58% increase in book club listings on Eventive and a doubling of book-club events on Meetup, according to industry observers. The growth is attributed to social media, which has sparked a reading renaissance among Singaporeans. However, not all retailers have seen a surge in book sales, with some citing changing reading habits and increased competition from online platforms. Despite this, bookstores and libraries are adapting, with some offering book clubs, online resources, and delivery services to make reading more accessible. The National Library Board (NLB) has seen a 20% increase in visitorship to its libraries, while Rakuten Kobo reported a 21% year-on-year increase in reading time among Singaporean readers.

images.alt_text: American cycling brand Specialized started online sales in 2018 then opened their own brick-and-mortar stores in Singapore around two years ago

With Boston Consulting Group’s projection that Asean’s digital economy could treble to US$1 trillion by 2030, there will be opportunities for more data centres with enhanced capabilities to support the flow of data and information.
Strata retail sales down 32.1% in H1 to S$215.5 million; strata office deals take a dip

site_title: Silicon Valley Bank's Chinese partner buys out stake in joint venture
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's Chinese joint venture, SPD Silicon Valley, will become a wholly owned unit of Shanghai Pudong Development Bank after a buyout deal. The bank's name will be changed to Shanghai Innovation Bank. The deal comes after no buyers emerged to acquire SVB's stake following its collapse last year. The National Financial Regulatory Administration's Shanghai branch approved the changes, allowing SPD to hold 100% of the shares and reducing the bank's registered capital to 1 billion yuan.

site_title: Elevating your financial journey with good money habits
summary: A person can achieve lasting financial improvements by developing good money habits, rather than just setting financial goals. According to author James Clear, habits are the key to success, as they are automatic processes that help us get better. Improving by 1% each day can lead to significant gains over time. Key good money habits include saving, protecting, growing, and retiring, which can be achieved by tracking expenses, reviewing insurance coverage, investing, and planning for retirement. By building healthy money habits and leveraging the habit loop, individuals can make informed decisions, handle emergencies, and achieve sustainable financial wellness.

images.alt_text: Is investing your new year's resolution? Take action now
Almost 40% jump in CPF members who topped up savings amid pandemic
Invest early in the build-up to retirement

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on US data after Dow hits record on Wall Street
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday after a record day on Wall Street, driven by strong US data that reassured investors about the world's top economy. The Dow Jones hit a record high, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 also ended on a mixed note. Key inflation figures and the non-farm payrolls report next week will determine the Federal Reserve's next steps on interest rate cuts. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, and others rose, while the yen edged up against the dollar.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumber losers 75 to 37.
The Stoxx 600 index was up 0.8 per cent at 524.57 points, narrowly missing a fresh record-high close, while Germany’s DAX rose 0.7 per cent to a record high.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped by 0.6 per cent to 41,335.05, while the broad-based S&P 500 was flat at 5,591.96 on Thursday.

site_title: Trading in Australian casino firm Star Entertainment halted after damning report
summary: Trading in Australian casino firm Star Entertainment has been halted after a scathing report by the New South Wales Independent Casino Commission found the company's casino operations unsuitable due to a culture allowing serious criminal infiltration. The regulator stated that Star Entertainment had not done enough to rectify this issue, citing concerns over inadequate policing of criminal infiltration and vetting of money sources. This is the latest in a string of watchdog investigations.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past The Star casino, operated by Echo Entertainment Group Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, March 16, 2012. Crown Ltd. last month doubled its stake in rival Echo Entertainment, owner of the only casino in Sydney, and sought regulatory approval to buy more. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: UK's Aviva conspired to dodge India compensation and tax rules, agency says
summary: The Indian Directorate General of GST Intelligence has found that British insurer Aviva breached local regulations by using fake invoices and clandestine cash payments to claim tax credits and evade US$5.2 million in taxes. Aviva's India business paid approximately US$26 million to entities that purportedly provided marketing and training services, but actually funneled funds to insurance distributors. The company faces around US$11 million in penalties, and the investigation is part of a broader probe into over a dozen Indian insurers accused of evading US$610 million in unpaid taxes, interest, and penalties.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Aviva logo on a window at the company's head office in the City of London, Britain, March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: Australian retail sales stagnate as elevated rates take toll
summary: Australian retail sales remained unchanged in July, defying economists' expectations of a 0.3% gain, due to elevated interest rates forcing households to reduce discretionary spending. This marks a three-month stretch of expansion, as interest rates have remained at a 12-year high of 4.35%. The Reserve Bank is expected to leave interest rates unchanged at its next meeting on September 23-24, with some predicting a 70% chance of a rate cut in December due to stubbornly strong inflation.

images.alt_text: The RBA’s goal is to bring consumer prices back within its 2 to 3 per cent target.
Woolworths posted net profit after tax before significant items of A$1.71 billion (S$1.5 billion) for the year ended June, largely in line with A$1.72 billion in the prior year.

Coles reported a 2.1 per cent rise in net profit after tax from continuing operations of A$1.13 billion (S$998 million) for the year ended June 30, beating a Visible Alpha consensus estimate of A$1.08 billion.
Workers in Australia can now “refuse to monitor, read, or respond to” their employers’ attempts to contact them outside work hours - unless that refusal is deemed “unreasonable”.

site_title: Thai central bank chief, finance minister to meet over inflation target as government eyes rate cut
summary: Thailand's central bank chief and finance minister will meet in early September to discuss an inflation target for 2025, amid government efforts to revive the economy. The government has been pushing for a rate cut, citing a flagging economy, while the Bank of Thailand has maintained its benchmark interest rate at a decade-high of 2.50%. A review of the 1-3% inflation target range could raise the chance of a rate cut, with the central bank proposing a target approved by its monetary policy committee.

images.alt_text: Natthapatt Tanboon-ek, chief financial officer at WHA Corp., speaks during the Thailand Focus Forum in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024. The conference runs through today. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg
Thailand in June introduced a 7 per cent value-added tax on imported goods priced at less than 1,500 baht (S$57.5).
Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput speaks during the Thailand Focus Forum in Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 28, 2024.
Thailand, South-east Asia’s second-largest economy is likely to grow between 2.3 per cent and 2.8 per cent this year, Paopoom Rojanasakul said at a business forum.

(FILES) Thailand's then-deputy prime minister Prawit Wongsuwan, speaks to members at a meeting outlining the Palang Pracharath Party's policies ahead of the general election in Bangkok on February 10, 2023. Thailand's parliament said it would investigate senior politician and former army chief Prawit Wongsuwan after he was filmed on August 16, 2024 slapping a reporter as she tried to ask him questions. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Speculative traders turn short dollar as Fed rate cuts loom
summary: Speculative traders have turned bearish on the US dollar for the first time since February, wagering $9.8 billion on a decline, amid expectations of the Federal Reserve's rate cuts in September. The dollar has slumped 1.6% in August, its biggest monthly drop this year, as traders anticipate interest rate reductions. Meanwhile, leveraged funds have taken a bullish stance on the euro and started betting against the Mexican peso, as the euro surges against the weaker US dollar.

images.alt_text: The Chinese yuan is benefitting from expectations of an interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve.
The dollar index was last 0.16 per cent higher at 101.18, still within striking distance of a 13-month low of 100.51 on Tuesday.
The dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of currencies, rose 0.42 per cent to 100.96 on Wednesday, but looked on course for its biggest monthly drop since November 2023.
The dollar slumped as much 0.7 per cent to 143.45 yen, its weakest level since Aug 5, and was last trading down 0.2 per cent.

site_title: S’pore’s climate targets still ‘highly insufficient’, even after clean energy push: Research group
summary: Singapore's climate targets remain "highly insufficient" despite efforts to boost clean energy, according to a report by the Climate Action Tracker (CAT). The country's 2030 emissions target of 60 million tonnes of carbon dioxide is still at a higher level than needed to limit global warming to 1.5°C. While Singapore's clean energy developments, such as its Future Energy Fund and plans to import low-carbon electricity, are promising, more needs to be done to reduce emissions and meet the Paris Agreement goal. The CAT recommends increasing ambition in Singapore's Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) update and implementing a higher carbon tax to create incentives for a low-carbon transition.

images.alt_text: Employment in clean energy businesses – including wind, solar, nuclear and battery storage – rose by 142,000 jobs, or 4.2 per cent last year, up from a rise of 3.9 per cent in 2022.

The Taj Mahal amid heavy smog conditions in Agra, India, Nov 23, 2023. Despite an improvement in air quality in South Asia in 2022, the region continues to breathe the world’s most-polluted air, with its residents losing more than 3.5 years of life expectancy on average, the annual Air Quality Life Index warned.
UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres speaks during the opening of the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum in Nukualofa, Tonga, Aug 26, 2024.

site_title: China’s designer dupes entice frugal shoppers away from labels
summary: China's dupes, or near-facsimiles of luxury brands, are gaining popularity among frugal shoppers, with sales skyrocketing on e-commerce platforms. Local makers sell high-quality products at lower prices, often without logos, reflecting a shift in consumer values. The rise of dupes threatens global retail giants, including Hermes and Lululemon, which may struggle to maintain exclusivity and luxury status in China. As economic confidence falters, Chinese consumers are seeking better value, driving growth for local brands and potentially disrupting the luxury sector. The dupes' popularity may not be sustainable, but for now, they're a significant threat to global brands.

images.alt_text: The lending slowdown is spurring debate over various alarming scenarios for China’s economy.
Fake goods have also migrated to other sites, with dozens of Reddit and Discord users discussing alternative sources.

Italy – home of the most luxury fashion brands – is the clear leader in counterfeit seizures within the European Union, accounting for 63 per cent of detained items in 2022, according to a November EU report.

site_title: Excel e-sports: the ‘Olympics’ of spreadsheets is a fun twist on serious software
summary: Microsoft Excel has evolved into a competitive e-sport, with the Financial Modeling World Cup (FMWC) hosting the annual championship. The event, held in Las Vegas, features "data athletes" competing in "spreadsheet battles" where they solve themed challenges using Excel functions. The championship has gained popularity, with a growing network of local chapters and competitions worldwide. Notable players include Australia's Andrew Ngai, nicknamed "The Annihilator," and Diarmuid Early, known as the "LeBron James of Excel." The event's founder, Andrew Grigolyunovich, aims to increase prize money and attract more athletes, with the goal of making Excel e-sports a mainstream phenomenon.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by the US indices' mixed performance and Europe's main stock index closing higher overnight. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 13.54 points to 3,418.01. Index counter Singtel gained 1.7%, while V2Y Corp rose 18.2%. The three local banks – DBS, UOB, and OCBC – were in the black, with DBS advancing 0.5% and UOB gaining 0.4%.

images.alt_text: GuocoLand posts 58 per cent lower net profit of S$62.8 million for the second half of FY2024.

site_title: Thai July factory output rises for first time in 3 months, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index rose 1.79% in July, beating a forecast fall, marking the first increase in three months. Stronger exports, tourism, and public spending contributed to the growth. This signals a recovery in the industry, according to Krit Chansuwan, deputy director general of the Office of Industrial Economics. The MPI increased 1.79% from a year earlier, reversing a revised annual decline of 1.63% in June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble an EV car inside BYD's first electric vehicle (EV) factory in Southeast Asia, a fast-growing regional EV market where it has become the dominant player, in Rayong, Thailand, July 4, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: Thyssenkrupp crisis deepens as heads of steel unit quit
summary: Thyssenkrupp's steel unit crisis deepened as its CEO Miguel Lopez and supervisory board head Sigmar Gabriel quit amid a management struggle. Gabriel accused Lopez of an "unprecedented campaign" to force out supervisory board members. The unit's chief executive Bernhard Osburg also quit, alongside three other board members. The crisis comes as the steel unit faces higher costs and growing imports of cheaper Asian steel, putting the future of Germany's largest steelmaker at risk.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A crane lifts a steel coil at the storage and distribution facility of German steel maker ThyssenKrupp in Duisburg, Germany, November 16, 2023.     REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
Franklin Templeton-managed Fondul Proprietatea has raised  8.1 billion lei in IPO of Romania’s Hidroelectrica.

site_title: ESR appoints interim chairman amid search for successor
summary: ESR Group has appointed Brett Harold Krause as interim chairman, replacing Jeffrey David Perlman who steps down on September 2 to take the CEO role at Warburg Pincus. Krause, an independent non-executive director since 2019, will serve as interim chairman until a full-time independent chairman is appointed by the first quarter of 2025. Krause's annual director's fee remains unchanged at HK$705,000.

site_title: Another one bites the dust: Jakarta governor darling benched; Malaysia’s digibanks falter
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta governor, Anies Baswedan, is effectively out of the race for the Jakarta governor position after the country's largest political party chose a Cabinet minister instead of him. Malaysia's digital banks, granted licenses in 2022, are not living up to expectations, with only three of the five having begun operations. Meanwhile, Vietnam's renewable energy ambitions were dealt another blow with Equinor exiting the country, and Norwegian state-controlled energy giant Orsted also paused market development activities.

images.alt_text: Former presidential candidate and popular favourite for Jakarta governor in November’s regional elections, Anies Baswedan, is effectively out of the race.

site_title: Nvidia discusses joining OpenAI’s latest funding round
summary: Nvidia is discussing a potential investment in OpenAI's latest funding round, valued at over US$100 billion, to acquire more computing power and fund operating expenses. Nvidia would invest around US$100 million, while Apple and Microsoft are also in talks about participating. The funding round aims to support OpenAI's growth and development of its AI tools, including the popular ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: OpenAI has been in early discussions to raise funding at a valuation at or above US$100 billion since at least December.
Microsoft, Google, Meta, Tesla and Amazon all depend on Nvidia technology to train generative AI models and execute the heavy computing workloads needed to deploy the new technology.

site_title: Google weighs large data centre in Vietnam, source says, in nation’s first by US Big Tech
summary: Google is considering building its first large data centre in Vietnam, motivated by the country's growing digital economy and presence of its domestic and foreign cloud services clients. The investment, estimated to be between $300 million and $650 million, would be a significant move for the South-east Asian nation, which has struggled to attract major overseas capital in data centres due to patchy infrastructure. The data centre could be ready in 2027, according to internal talks, and would be a shot in the arm for Vietnam's expanding digital economy.

images.alt_text: The move is meant to combat rising cases of cybercrime, including online fraud and gambling, as well as cyberbullying and sexual crimes against children.

site_title: Economics tutor jailed five weeks, ordered to pay S$72,770 in penalties for tax evasion
summary: A 51-year-old economics tutor, Quek Ban Tong Edmund, was sentenced to five weeks in jail and ordered to pay S$72,770.79 in penalties for tax evasion. Edmund, the precedent partner of Economics Cafe Learning Centre, underreported sales and profits of his tuition centre and his own income, resulting in $24,256.93 of undercharged income tax. He pleaded guilty to the charges following an audit by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore in 2016.

images.alt_text: David Yong is facing four falsification of account charges involving sums that run into the millions.
Kim Taek Hoon faces more than 20 charges for offences that include cheating and money laundering.

site_title: Japan’s July jobless rate rises to 2.7%, job availability edges up
summary: Japan's jobless rate rose to 2.7% in July, surpassing economists' median forecast of 2.5%. The jobs-to-applicants ratio increased to 1.24 from 1.23 in June. This marks a slight edge in job availability. The unemployment rate was unchanged from June, but the jobs-to-applicants ratio indicates a slight improvement in the job market.

site_title: Singapore stocks join Asian markets in the black; STI adds 1.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% to 3,442.93, driven by positive US economic data. Across the broader market, 1.4 billion shares worth S$2 billion changed hands, with 354 gainers beating 222 losers. Sembcorp Industries led the gains, rising S$0.21 to S$4.93, while DFI Retail Group retreated S$0.02 to US$1.86.

images.alt_text: BT
Under group president and CEO Wong Kim Yin's leadership, Sembcorp posted total returns of 61 per cent in 2023.

site_title: German coalition unlikely to last until September 2025
summary: Germany's fractious three-party coalition under Chancellor Olaf Scholz may not last until the scheduled general election in September 2025, amid high tensions and public disapproval. The coalition between the Social Democratic Party, Greens, and Free Democratic Party faces collapse due to the upcoming east German poll on September 1, which could hit the euro and complicate the European Central Bank's interest-rate decisions. A possible early election could lead to another "grand coalition" between the Christian Democratic Union and the SPD, but this outcome is unlikely to produce regeneration.
