site_title: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate falls to 0.5% in August
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation rate fell to 0.5% in August, down from 2.4% in July, due to a 22.5% drop in electricity costs and downward adjustments to fuel, water, and cooking gas prices. Demand is expected to remain muted ahead of the presidential election on September 21, with analysts citing political and policy uncertainty. Inflation is projected to remain below the central bank's target of 5% for the next seven months.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Colombo main port is seen beyond the main wholesale market, on the day President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is also the island nation's finance minister, presents the annual budget in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 12, 2023.Picture taken November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: China considers allowing refinancing on US$5.4 trillion in mortgages
summary: China is considering allowing refinancing of US$5.4 trillion in mortgages to lower borrowing costs for millions of families and boost consumption. Homeowners would be able to renegotiate terms with their current lenders before January and refinance with a different bank for the first time since the global financial crisis. The move aims to stem a housing-led slowdown in Asia's largest economy, despite potential losses for state-run Chinese banks. Lower mortgage rates could cut costs for homeowners by up to 300 billion yuan, but may squeeze banks' net interest margins by around 5-10 basis points.

images.alt_text: China’s US$17 trillion economy is struggling as a prolonged property downturn weighs on consumers and businesses.
Country Garden defaulted on US$11 billion of offshore bonds late last year.

This aerial photograph taken on August 30, 2023 shows a damaged logo of Chinese real estate developer Vanke at a residential housing complex in Zhengzhou, in China’s central Henan province. (Photo by AFP)
Authorities are ramping up a push to reduce mortgage costs after the central bank encouraged such support last year and banks responded with a rare rate cut on outstanding mortgages of first homes.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after July inflation data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, August 30, following a key inflation report that reiterated price pressures are moderating, fueling bets for an interest-rate cut at the Federal Reserve's September meeting. The S&P 500 rose 0.37%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.77%. These gains come as investors await the Fed's decision on interest rates.

site_title: Vanke reports first half-year loss in more than two decades
summary: Shenzhen-based Vanke, a major Chinese property developer, reported a net loss of 9.85 billion yuan (S$1.8 billion) in the first half of 2024, its first semi-annual loss in over 20 years. The loss is attributed to the ongoing property crisis in China, which has led to reduced homebuyer demand and liquidity stress for the company. Vanke has been raising funds and selling assets to address investor concerns, but the government's supportive measures have yet to materialize. The company's full-year profit was 12.2 billion yuan last year.

site_title: Finance goes to Hollywood
summary: Hollywood films often reflect a populist perspective on financial markets and institutions, reflecting concerns about regulation and the excesses of capitalism. Classics such as "The Wizard of Oz" and "It's a Wonderful Life" portray bank runs and speculation as morally complex issues, while films like "Wall Street" and "The Wolf of Wall Street" depict greed and insider trading as problematic. However, some films like "The Big Short" present short-selling as a necessary check on excessive market exuberance. Despite this, politicians often appeal to populist anger against bankers and speculators, and efforts to improve regulation are often met with resistance from those who benefit from the status quo.

site_title: Taipei former mayor arrested in graft probe
summary: Former Taipei mayor Ko Wen-je was arrested on August 31 as part of a graft probe involving approvals for a property project during his tenure. Ko denies wrongdoing, stating he has no problems. The arrest was made after investigators raided his home and party, and he has temporarily stepped down as party chairman. The scandal has damaged support for Ko and his party, the Taiwan People's Party, ahead of the 2028 presidential election.

site_title: Amazon to hire Covariant founders to expand warehouse automation
summary: Amazon is hiring Covariant's founders as part of an "acquihire" deal to boost its warehouse automation. Amazon will absorb executives and about a quarter of Covariant's staff. The deal also grants Amazon a non-exclusive license to Covariant's robotic foundation models. This move aims to enhance Amazon's warehouse automation capabilities, which have been a leader since its 2012 acquisition of Kiva Systems. Covariant's software is used by several major companies, including Otto Group, Radial, and McKesson. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand Amazon's warehouse automation capabilities.

images.alt_text: OpenAI offices in San Francisco, California. California legislators are set to vote on a bill as soon as this week to broadly regulate how AI is developed and deployed in the state.

site_title: Core inflation in Tokyo rises 2.4% yr/yr in August
summary: Tokyo's core consumer price index rose 2.4% year-over-year in August, exceeding market forecasts of 2.2%. This marks the fourth consecutive month of acceleration, fueling expectations of further interest rate hikes from the Bank of Japan. The increase is attributed to rising wages and service prices, which the central bank projects will keep inflation around 2% in the coming years. The Tokyo inflation figures are considered a leading indicator of nationwide trends, further supporting the BOJ's monetary policy tightening campaign.

images.alt_text: Japan's jobs-to-applicants ratio in July rose to 1.24 from 1.23 in June, labour ministry data showed.

site_title: SIA gets foreign direct investment approval for Air India-Vistara merger
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has received foreign direct investment approval for the merger of Vistara and Air India, with the completion expected by end-2024. The merger, which will result in SIA holding 25.1% of the enlarged entity, is expected to boost the group's presence in India and strengthen its multi-hub strategy. The approval marks the final regulatory hurdle for the proposed merger, following India's antitrust body and Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) approvals in September 2023.

Singapore Airlines says there is no change in SIA's position from the November 2022 announcement.
Singapore Airlines owns 49 per cent of Indian carrier Vistara while Tata Group owns the other 51 per cent. The two companies are in talks about a deepening of their partnership.

site_title: Co-lending makes headway as South-east Asia’s private credit space matures
summary: Private credit managers in South-east Asia are making headway with co-lending offerings, driven by growing demand from investors seeking more control over their investments. Co-lending allows limited partners to lend directly to a single borrower, giving them greater control over deal terms. Market players expect co-lending to catch on as banks consolidate and streamline their lending activities, seeking to diversify their portfolios and tap into private credit. Key players such as DBS and Muzinich & Co are already exploring co-lending opportunities, with some banks setting up segregated mandates to gain exposure to private credit.

site_title: Japan’s July factory output rises 2.8% month-on-month
summary: Japan's factory output rose 2.8% in July from the previous month, exceeding market forecasts for a 3.3% increase. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expects seasonally adjusted output to increase 2.2% in August and contract 3.3% in September.

site_title: Harris rejects ‘flip-flop’ claims in first campaign interview
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris has played down Republican claims she has shifted her stance on key issues, saying her "values had not changed" on immigration and fracking. In a CNN interview with running mate Tim Walz, Harris also proposed appointing a Republican to her cabinet if elected president. Despite criticism from Republicans, including Donald Trump, Harris's campaign is riding a surge of enthusiasm, with a new Fox poll showing increasing support for her in battleground states.

If confirmed, Apple's entry into OpenAI's ownership would come as the startup raises $1 billion in funding to meet technology costs, with Microsoft also participating in the round. The funding would value OpenAI at $100 billion, making it one of the most valuable tech companies in the world.

site_title: Indonesia to reform tourism on tropical island Bali, senior minister says
summary: Indonesia plans to reform tourism on Bali, citing issues such as crime, over-development, and competition for jobs caused by the large number of foreign visitors. Data shows 2.9 million foreign visitors entered Bali through the airport in the first half of the year, accounting for 65% of Indonesia's total foreign arrivals by air. Senior Minister Luhut Pandjaitan announced the plan, stating that Indonesia will deport problematic tourists and limit their entry to preserve local culture and jobs. An audit is to be conducted to improve tourism quality.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s chief investment minister Luhut Pandjaitan said that rich families had approached him to ask if it was possible for Jakarta to adopt a common law system in Bali.

site_title: Typhoon Shanshan barrels up Japan as five reported dead
summary: Typhoon Shanshan hit Japan, causing 5 reported deaths and injuring 81 others, with over 250,000 households left without electricity. The typhoon, one of the strongest to hit Japan in decades, brought torrential rains and transport disruptions. Authorities issued a highest alert in several areas, advising over 5 million people to evacuate, but it's unclear how many did. Power cuts, flooded rivers, and suspended transportation networks affected the region, with major disruptions to flights, trains, and industries.

images.alt_text: A police car drives amid destruction from Typhoon Shanshan in Miyazaki city, Japan August 29, 2024.

site_title: OpenAI, Anthropic sign deals with US government for AI research and testing
summary: OpenAI and Anthropic have signed deals with the US government for AI research, testing, and evaluation of their models. The agreements, facilitated by the US Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute, provide access to major new AI models before and after their public release. Collaborative research will evaluate AI model capabilities and risks, with the aim of defining US leadership in responsible AI development. The agreements follow regulatory scrutiny over AI safety and ethics, with California legislators set to vote on a bill to regulate AI development and deployment in the state.

summary: Character.AI, a chatbot startup, has laid off at least 5% of its staff, primarily from marketing and recruiting roles. The company cited a need to refocus and align roles with its new direction to build personalized AI products. This move comes after signing a deal with Google, which grants the search engine giant a non-exclusive license to Character.AI's large language model technology. The company had previously raised $193 million in venture capital.

site_title: Elon Musk, Tesla win dismissal of lawsuit claiming they rigged dogecoin
summary: US District Judge Alvin Hellerstein dismissed a federal lawsuit against Elon Musk and Tesla, alleging they defrauded investors by hyping dogecoin and conducting insider trading. The lawsuit claimed Musk drove up dogecoin's price over 36,000% and then crashed it, causing billions of dollars in losses. Musk's lawyers argued there was no proof of wrongdoing, including suspicious trading or sales of dogecoin, and that his tweets were "innocuous and often silly." The lawsuit, which originally sought $258 billion, was dismissed with prejudice.

site_title: Déjà vu as Indonesia flirts with election age limits
summary: Indonesia's Constitutional Court rejected a proposed change to the Regional Head Elections Law, which would have lowered the minimum age of candidates from 30 to 30 by inauguration. The move was seen as a potential path for President Joko Widodo's youngest son to run for deputy governor in November's regional elections. The decision sparked protests and led to a weakening of the rupiah, with the Jakarta Stock Exchange Composite Index sinking by about 1%. The change was previously approved by the Supreme Court in May but was later undercut by a legislative panel.

site_title: Europe: Inflation data helps stocks shake off Nvidia results; Delivery Hero surges
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% to a record high, driven by tech stocks after softer inflation data lifted hopes for interest-rate cuts. German inflation eased to 2% in August, while Spain's EU-harmonised inflation slowed to 2.4%. The tech sector jumped 2.2%, with companies like Nvidia, ASM International, and SAP SE gaining. The data strengthened hopes for the European Central Bank to cut rates again in September, offsetting disappointment around Nvidia's quarterly results.

site_title: US: Stocks close mixed but Dow hits new record
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a new record after revised economic data showed the US economy grew at a 3.0% annual rate in the second quarter. The Dow jumped 0.6% to 41,335.05, while the S&P 500 was flat at 5,591.96. The Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2% to 17,516.43, despite a stabilisation in initial jobless claims and consumer spending data showing a boost.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 254.08 points, or 0.62 per cent, at the open to 41,345.50.

site_title: US second quarter growth stronger than estimated
summary: The US economy expanded 3% in the second quarter, exceeding the initial estimate of 2.8%. Stronger-than-expected consumer spending, despite high interest rates, drove the growth. This revision surpasses analyst expectations, which had anticipated no change to the figure. The improved growth rate is a positive sign for the US economy, indicating resilience in the face of economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Shoppers check out at a Costco, the third-largest retailer in the world, behind only Amazon and Walmart, in Anchorage, Alaska, Aug. 16, 2024. More than 100 million people get their groceries (and TVs and gold bars and pet coffins) at Costco, but the retailer is not about what it seems. (Kerry Tasker/The New York Times)
The government's new view follows earlier data showing Japan's economy rebounded to growth in the second quarter on the back of recovering domestic demand.

site_title: Spanish actor’s son jailed for life for grisly Thai island murder
summary: Spanish actor Rodolfo Sancho's 30-year-old son, Daniel Sancho Bronchalo, was sentenced to life in prison for the premeditated murder of Colombian plastic surgeon Edwin Arrieta Arteaga on the Thai island of Koh Phangan last year. The court ordered Bronchalo to pay 4.4 million baht to Arrieta's family. Bronchalo claimed self-defense, but the prosecution proved he had bought knives and plastic bags before the crime. The victim's family accepted the life sentence, with the sister stating, "Let him be left in Thailand so he can take time to think about what he did."

images.alt_text: epa11570472 (FILE) - Spanish chef Daniel Sancho Bronchalo (C) is escorted by Thai police officers as they arrive at a port before going to the court in Koh Samui island, southern Thailand, 07 August 2023 (reissued 29 August 2024). A Thai court on 29 August 2024 sentenced Daniel Sancho Bronchalo, the son of Spanish actor Rodolfo Sancho, to life in prison for the premeditated murder of Colombian plastic surgeon Edwin Arrieta Arteaga on the tourist island of Koh Phangan. Sancho, a 30-year-old Spanish chef, was arrested by Thai police in August 2023 and was accused of killing Arrieta, dismembering his body, and disposing of the remains in a rubbish dump and the sea, according to a police statement.  EPA-EFE/SOMKEAT RUKSAMAN

site_title:
Net foreign selling of Vietnamese stocks may 
ease ahead of potential market upgrade in 2025
summary: Vietnam's stock market has seen net foreign selling of an estimated $3.5 billion since 2023, with a 10-year low proportion of foreign ownership. Despite robust foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows, analysts attribute the selling to concerns over short-term challenges, including geopolitical uncertainty and interest-rate differentials. A potential upgrade of Vietnam's stock market from "frontier" to "emerging" status in 2025 could attract new interest from equity investors, with some predicting up to $25 billion in new investments by 2030. However, analysts also warn of potential volatilities upon the upgrade.

images.alt_text: Head of the ruling Communist Party To Lam is the current Vietnam President.

(FILES) Vietnam's President To Lam waits for the arrival of Japan's former prime minister Yoshihide Suga at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi on July 25, 2024. Vietnam's Communist Party named President To Lam as the country's top leader on August 3, after the death of his predecessor two weeks ago. (Photo by LUONG THAI LINH / POOL / AFP)
The tech and telco sector represents merely 2 per cent of the total number of listed companies on Vietnam's local bourses

Vietnam currently has a frontier status. A classification as an emerging market would open the floodgates to possibly having billions of dollars of foreign capital flow into Vietnamese stocks every year, say analysts.
Investor interest in Vietnam will unlikely suffer a dent, say analysts, even with the resignation of Vo Van Thuong as state president.

site_title: Indian tribunal approves US$8.5 billion Disney, Reliance media assets merger
summary: An Indian tribunal has approved the US$8.5 billion merger of Reliance Industries and Disney's Indian media assets, creating the country's largest entertainment player. The merger was approved subject to concessions, including a commitment to not raise advertising rates unreasonably for streamed cricket matches and the sale of seven to eight non-sports TV channels. The Competition Commission of India had previously expressed concerns about the deal, but the companies' voluntary modifications alleviated these worries. Reliance Industries Chairman Mukesh Ambani welcomed the merger, calling it an "invaluable growth centre" for the company.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, GuocoLand, Tan Chong International, Cordlife, IHH Healthcare
summary: Singapore Airlines' shares fell 0.3% on Friday after receiving approval from India's government for foreign direct investment into its merged entity with Air India. GuocoLand's net profit for the second half of FY2024 dropped 58% to S$62.8 million, while Tan Chong International posted a net loss of HK$35.9 million for the first half. Cordlife's cord-blood banking services will resume on September 15 in a controlled manner, and IHH Healthcare's net profit more than doubled to RM623 million for the second quarter.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q2 net profit more than doubles to RM623 million
summary: IHH Healthcare, a private healthcare group, reported a net profit of RM623 million (S$188 million) for the second quarter of 2024, more than doubling from RM301 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 30% to RM6.1 billion, driven by sustained demand for quality healthcare services and higher patient volume. The company also reported an earnings per share of 7.07 sen, an improvement from 3.43 sen in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: IHH, which is listed on the Malaysian and Singaporean bourses, said it does not comment on market speculation and will update the market if there are any material developments.
Revenue for Q1 hit a new quarterly high. It rose 16 per cent to 6 billion ringgit, from 5.1 billion ringgit a year earlier, crossing the 6 billion ringgit mark for the first time.

Analysts say the increase in salaries to help retain current staff could be less than what these private healthcare players may have to fork out to bring in new nurses and give them the relevant training.
Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital is operated by IHH Healthcare. The healthcare group plans to add more than 15 new clinics and around two to three ambulatory care centres in Singapore.
The dividend policy is revised upwards to no less than 30 per cent of the group’s profit after tax and minority interests, excluding exceptional items, from a ‘no less than 20 per cent’ policy.

Mount Elizabeth Novena hospital is owned by Parkway Holdings, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Malaysian-controlled IHH Healthcare. The group's indirect subsidiary in India is no longer filing for an initial public offering.

site_title: Oil settles up over 1% on worries over supplies from Libya, Iraq
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Thursday due to supply disruptions in Libya and plans to lower output in Iraq, raising concerns of tighter global supplies. Libyan oil production was offline, with about 700,000 barrels per day offline, and exports halted at several ports. Iraq plans to cut its oil output to 3.85-3.9 million barrels per day in September. Expectations of lower US interest rates also supported oil prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Shell Petroleum signage is pictured in Malaysia's southern city of Johor Bahru April 26, 2017.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Brent crude futures settled 90 cents, or 1.13 per cent, lower at US$78.65 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Former president Halimah Yacob joins Sias as chief patron
summary: Former Singapore President Halimah Yacob has been named as the new chief patron of the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), succeeding Tony Tan. Halimah's virtues align with Sias' mission, including protecting individual investors' rights and promoting ethical behavior. She was chosen for her contributions to Singapore's betterment, including her diplomatic efforts and signing of bilateral agreements. Sias founder and president David Gerald welcomed Halimah, stating that her involvement will benefit the organization's mission and the broader community of investors. City Developments' CEO Sherman Kwek has also been appointed as a patron.

images.alt_text: David Gerald, chief executive of Sias, says that minority shareholders of Great Eastern Holdings feel they have to choose between accepting an offer deemed "unfair" or potentially having their money locked up in an unlisted company for a long time.
Sias CEO David Gerald says: “Sustainability reporting can also set a company apart from competitors, especially when it demonstrates leadership in sustainability practices."
David Gerald, founder and chief executive of the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), is asking Chemical Industries to provide a timeline regarding the appointment of a new CEO.
Sias' email was addressed to AEM chief executive Chandran Nair (pictured) and the company's board.
Park Place was only purchased recently at the end of 2021 for US$106 million.

site_title: US pending home sales gauge drops to lowest on record
summary: US pending home sales gauge dropped to the lowest level on record in July, with contract signings falling 5.5% to 70.2. This is the lowest reading since 2001, attributed to high borrowing costs and lean inventory. The National Association of Realtors attributed declining sales to affordability challenges and wait-and-see behavior ahead of the US presidential election. Falling mortgage rates may bring buyers into the market, but high prices and limited inventory continue to deter prospective buyers.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage eased for a fourth week to 6.44 per cent, the longest stretch of declines this year, according to Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA).

site_title: Shell plans wide cuts in oil exploration division, sources say
summary: Shell plans to cut 20% of its oil exploration and development workforce, resulting in hundreds of job losses worldwide, particularly in its British and Dutch offices. The move is part of CEO Wael Sawan's cost-saving drive, following deep cuts in renewable and low-carbon businesses. The restructuring aims to deliver $2-3 billion in structural operating cost reductions by 2025 and focus on profitable businesses, including liquefied natural gas and steady oil production.

images.alt_text: The second phase of development will include up to 450 production wells, new pipeline and road and infrastructure upgrades, Shell says.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren//File Photo
In the longer term, renewable hydrogen from the project could be directly supplied to help lower industrial emissions in the region as customer demand evolves, Shell said.

site_title: Japan raises view of economy for first time in 15 months
summary: Japan's government has upgraded its monthly economic assessment for the first time in 15 months, citing a moderate pace of recovery in the economy. The Cabinet Office reported that consumer spending is recovering, with resilience in spending on goods. The government also revised up its assessment for housing construction for the first time in over two years, citing signs of a recovery in consumption. This marks a positive shift in Japan's economic outlook, following earlier data showing the economy rebounded to growth in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: A police car drives amid destruction from Typhoon Shanshan in Miyazaki city, Japan August 29, 2024.
The Japanese operator of seven-Eleven stores is seeking designation as a “core” company under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act.

site_title: GuocoLand H2 profit falls 58% to S$62.8 million
summary: GuocoLand's net profit for the 2nd half of 2024 fell 58% to S$62.8 million, down from S$148 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 15% to S$752.4 million, from S$882.9 million. Earnings per share decreased to 4.83 Singapore cents, compared to 12.51 Singapore cents last year.

images.alt_text: GuocoLand plans to develop the Upper Thomson site into a residential development with 941 units.
While listed property groups can access debt funding, they should be careful with raising debt and actively explore selling low-yielding investment properties
Will a flurry of possible new condo launches post the Chinese Hungry Ghost month see modest sales?

The state land site for an executive condominium development at Jalan Loyang Besar (pictured) drew XXX bids, a sharp contrast from the private residential site at Margaret Drive, which fetched just XXX bids.

Property developer GuocoLand held a 27 per cent stake in Eco World prior to the divestment.

site_title: Hedge funds may lose billions from Temu owner PDD’s stock crash
summary: Hedge funds may have lost billions from a 30% stock crash of PDD Holdings, the owner of Temu, following downbeat comments from its executives. Global hedge funds held 102.8 million shares of PDD at the end of June, with a 30% fall in shares since then potentially wiping out a combined value of $4 billion. Major investors in PDD include Asia's largest hedge funds and global giants like Appaloosa Management. The unexpected bearish guidance has further dampened sentiment toward Chinese equities, dragging down tech and consumer shares.

images.alt_text: China’s wealthiest person, Nongfu Spring founder Zhong Shanshan, lost some US$3 billion as the beverage giant’s shares fell by a record 10 per cent on Wednesday (Aug 28) in Hong Kong.
Thailand in June introduced a 7 per cent value-added tax on imported goods priced at less than 1,500 baht (S$57.5).
JD.com on Tuesday (Aug 27) outlined plans to repurchase its own stock from September through to August 2027.
China’s less affluent consumers outside of glitzy mega cities drove much of PDD’s success.
Colin Huang is now the fourth-wealthiest person in China with a net worth of US$35.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
PDD reported revenue of 97.06 billion yuan (S$17.8 billion) in the second quarter, compared with analysts’ average estimate of 100 billion yuan.
The booming demand for Sam’s Club made it possible for Walmart to build its own e-commerce app.

site_title: China to continue with low-carbon reforms, energy regulator says
summary: China will continue to phase out fossil fuels and reform its electricity system, with investments totaling US$676 billion in energy transition last year. The country aims to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy and expand green electricity trading. Despite emerging as a global leader in renewable energy, China's power system still relies on coal. The government has reaffirmed its carbon emissions targets, with no plans to change them, but analysts suggest China may need to set more ambitious goals for 2030.

images.alt_text: The overall target, according to the plan announced on Sunday, was for China to put its economy “fully on the green and low-carbon track” by 2035 with declining carbon emissions by that time.

site_title: Nokia mobile networks assets said to draw Samsung interest
summary: Samsung is reportedly showing interest in acquiring Nokia's mobile networks assets, seeking to gain scale in the radio access networks that connect mobile phones to telecom infrastructure. The Finnish company has been exploring options for its mobile networks business, which has struggled to compete with larger rivals, and could be valued at around $10 billion. Nokia's CEO Pekka Lundmark has been trying to turn the company around, focusing on new businesses and diversifying its customer base. The move could attract interest from other rivals, and would mark a significant shift in the telecom equipment sector.

images.alt_text: Nokia and its Swedish rival Ericsson have both been hit by customers buying less telecom equipment.
The acquisition is the largest for Nokia since its biggest-ever deal, the 10.6 billion euros takeover of Alcatel-Lucent completed in 2016.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Nvidia results, economic data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by Nvidia's in-line forecast and robust economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 254.08 points, or 0.62%, to 41,345.50, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The economic data showed the US economy remained strong, fueling expectations of a September interest rate cut.

site_title: Ambani touts AI, bonus shares but stays silent on units’ IPOs
summary: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani announced plans for Reliance Industries to develop cutting-edge artificial intelligence tools, aiming to "democratize" AI for ordinary Indians. The conglomerate plans to set up "gigawatt-scale AI-ready data centers" powered by green energy. Ambani also outlined growth plans for its telecom and retail businesses, which are sector leaders, and expects them to double in revenue and earnings in the next three to four years. However, details on the initial public offerings of its telecom and retail units remained unclear.

images.alt_text: Reliance Industries said its consolidated profit fell to 151.38 billion rupees (S$2.4 billion) in the April-to-June quarter, from 160.11 billion rupees a year earlier.
Disney and Reliance logos are seen in this illustration taken, August 13, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: 1MDB says bid to strike out its US$394 million claim against BSI Bank fails
summary: 1MDB's US$394 million claim against BSI Bank has been denied by Singapore's High Court. The claim alleges BSI facilitated unauthorised transfers and money laundering schemes. The court's decision allows the case to proceed. 1MDB is seeking redress for large-scale financial losses due to the alleged schemes, which are part of a global scandal estimated to have misappropriated US$4.5 billion from Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund.

images.alt_text: Low has been accused of embezzling US$4.5 billion from Malaysia’s 1MDB sovereign wealth fund and remains at large.

site_title: Trust Bank’s deposits more than double to S$3 billion in H1 2024, customer base hits 806,000
summary: Trust Bank's deposits more than doubled to S$3 billion in H1 2024, with a customer base of 806,000. The digital bank aims to break even by end-2025 and targets unmet needs like the emerging affluent segment. Revenue growth is three times last year, with costs inching up 1%. Total customer loans and advances reached S$486 million. Trust+ has gotten off to a "very good start" and customers engage with the bank actively, using credit cards 21 times a month.

images.alt_text: Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO, Trust Bank

site_title: China's CNOOC says fossil fuel crucial for the foreseeable future
summary: China's state-run oil company CNOOC expects fossil fuels to remain a crucial part of the global energy mix, aiming to pump 700-720 million barrels of oil equivalent in 2024, a 3-6% increase. The company also plans to monetize vast gas resources in Guyana and maintain strong domestic gas production growth through 2030. CNOOC targets annual capital expenditure of $22.9-22.9 billion and expects oil prices to remain between $75-85 per barrel for the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Cnooc has invested heavily in the development of China’s offshore oil and gas reserves, as part of a broader push to offset declining output from aging onshore fields.
CNOOC's Lingshui 36-1 gas field, located in the western South China Sea, has been tested to produce over 10 million cubic metres per day of open flow natural gas.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) is seen at its booth during the China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 1, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Euro slips after inflation data, concerns over German politics
summary: The euro slid 0.2% to $1.1098 after inflation data from Germany and Spain led investors to expect the European Central Bank to ease interest rates. The single currency had reached a 13-month high of $1.1201 earlier in the week. Investors are also cautious ahead of German state elections, which could impact the euro's value. Meanwhile, the US dollar index rose 0.16% to 101.18, within striking distance of a 13-month low, as investors await US inflation data and potential rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one dollar banknotes are seen in front of displayed stock graph in this illustration taken February 8, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall slightly
summary: US initial jobless claims fell 2,000 to 231,000 for the week ended Aug 24, retreating from an 11-month high in late July. The decrease is attributed to distortions from temporary motor vehicle plant shutdowns and the impact of Hurricane Beryl. However, re-employment opportunities for laid-off workers are becoming scarce, suggesting the unemployment rate may have remained elevated in August. The Labor Department's benchmark revision estimate of employment growth was overstated, and economists expect the unemployment rate to remain near a three-year high of 4.3% this month.

images.alt_text: Unexpectedly robust consumption – even in the face of high interest rates – has helped to bolster the US economy in recent times.

site_title: UBS appoints former Credit Suisse executive as new China head
summary: UBS appoints former Credit Suisse executive Janice Hu as the new head of its business in China, replacing Eugene Qian who is stepping down for family reasons after over nine years. Hu, currently vice-chair of UBS Securities, will take over from September 16 and report to UBS Apac president Iqbal Khan. Qian will continue working on strategic China initiatives after the Credit Suisse acquisition.

site_title: China will not impose anti-dumping measures on EU brandy, for now
summary: China will not impose provisional tariffs on European Union brandy imports, citing a finding that EU distillers were selling brandy in China at a margin of 30.6-39%. The decision comes as China canvasses EU member states to reject proposed duties of up to 36.3% on Chinese-made electric vehicles. The move is seen as a negotiation tactic, potentially linking EU tariffs on Chinese EVs to Chinese action on EU brandy imports.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photograph taken on February 11, 2016, shows the logo of French distilled beverage company Pernod Ricard during a presentation the group's half-year 2015/16 results at the group's headquarters in Paris. French wine and spirits giant Pernod Ricard reported a 35% drop in annual net profit to 1.48 billion euros on August 29, 2024, a sharp decline attributed to "market normalization" after the post-Covid catch-up and an "uncertain" economic environment. (Photo by ERIC PIERMONT / AFP)

site_title: S$38 set lunch and Italian comfort cooking at La D’Oro
summary: La D'Oro, a former fine-dining restaurant, has rebranded itself as a casual eatery in Singapore. The restaurant offers Italian comfort cooking at an affordable S$38 set lunch, served in upscale surroundings. The menu features dishes such as aglio olio pasta, rocket and gorgonzola salad, and pan-fried tomino cheese, all at a more relaxed price point. This new direction appears to be working well, as the restaurant has successfully transitioned to a casual dining experience.

site_title: Rock band Oasis adds UK dates to reunion tour as fans clamour for tickets
summary: Oasis, the British rock band, has added three UK dates to their reunion tour due to overwhelming fan demand. The band initially announced 14 shows, but the high interest led to the addition of concerts in Manchester, London, and Edinburgh. The pre-sale ballot and general sale for tickets will take place on Saturday. This marks the band's first live performance in 15 years, following their split in 2009. The tour is set to take place in 2025, with the first show scheduled for Cardiff in July.

site_title: Tan Chong sinks into the red in H1 with HK$35.9 million net loss
summary: Tan Chong International, an auto dealer, reported a net loss of HK$35.9 million (S$6 million) for the first half of 2024, down from a net profit of HK$126.9 million in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to underperformance in its automotive division, which faced disappointing car sales and shrinking profit margins. However, its financial services subsidiary and logistics subsidiary showed growth. Tan Chong expects continued headwinds due to geopolitical unrest and shifting consumer demand, but anticipates an improvement in performance for the remainder of the year.

images.alt_text: Tesla's experience centre in Kuala Lumpur. The US-based EV maker had previously in July 2023 committed to set up a country head office and service centres in Selangor.
Tan Chong expects 86% fall in profit after tax for H1 2024 on ‘severe drop in sales’
This is as compared to an audited unrealised loss of HK$222 million for the corresponding period in 2022, said Tan Chong.

site_title: Malaysia Aviation Group to cut flight capacity by 20% this year
summary: Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG) will reduce network capacity by 20% across its airlines this year due to a shortage of planes, labor, and parts. The airline's air operator certificate has also been cut to one year by Malaysia's civil aviation regulator following a probe that found significant technical issues, including a shortage of skilled labor and mechanical parts. This decision aims to prioritize customer experience and ensure timely and reliable delivery of spare parts. The reduction will affect domestic flights and routes in various regions.

images.alt_text: Qantas' underlying profit before tax fell 16 per cent in the year ended June 30 to A$2.08 billion (S$1.82 billion), in line with analyst expectations.
Malaysia Airlines has prepared a mitigation plan that will include an aggressive labour recruitment programme and a larger focus on safety and maintenance.
Japan currently has about 7,100 pilots and the government projects another 1,000 will be needed by 2030 to help meet its target of attracting some 60 million tourists that same year.

site_title: Singapore insurers come under closer MAS watch over reinsurance contracts
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is closely monitoring and auditing reinsurance contracts of insurers in the country, following a global standard-setting body's report highlighting risks associated with cross-border asset-intensive reinsurance. Insurers are required to submit the terms and conditions of their contracts to the MAS, which may lead to audits. The move aims to ensure financial stability and mitigate potential risks, such as jurisdictional and reinsurer-level concentration risks.

images.alt_text: FWD last year partnered Apollo Global Management to offer a product for high-net-worth individuals that allocates a portion of premiums to an Apollo alternatives fund.

site_title: Thailand’s top industrial park developer expects more land sales
summary: Thailand's top industrial park developer, WHA Corp, expects a surge in land sales in the second half of 2024, with a 40% increase from the first half. The company anticipates land sales of 224 hectares, driven by foreign manufacturers and companies, particularly Chinese firms in the automobile, electronics, and electrical appliance industries. This rise in demand is expected to boost WHA's record sales and net income in 2024, as the Thai government offers tax and other incentives to attract new investment.

images.alt_text: An overhead view of Benjakitti Park in Bangkok. While a 99-year leasehold could help in the sale of Thailand’s unsold condominiums, it would also stimulate further investments in the property sector, realtors said.
FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: German inflation plunges to 2% as ECB prepares to cut rates
summary: German inflation has fallen to a 2% reading, the lowest since 2021, as price gains moderate and wage pressures ease. The European Central Bank is preparing to cut interest rates in September, with officials warming to the idea following a report showing significant price pressures easing in Spain. However, policymakers caution that the fight against inflation is not yet won, with underlying price growth remaining strong and concerns over service costs. The ECB has not yet secured a return to its 2% inflation target, and a September rate cut may be subject to debate among policymakers.

images.alt_text: “As long as our disinflation path still converges to a return to 2 per cent inflation at or before the end of 2025, then I’m comfortable with gradually taking our foot off the brake,” Dutch policymaker Knot said.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, August 29, 2024 (Ep 133)
summary: Asian markets declined due to Nvidia's disappointing results. Malaysia's stocks reached a four-year high as foreign investors returned, while Haidilao's restaurant operator, Super Hi, narrowed its Q2 loss on higher revenue. The Economic Development Board (EDB) committed another S$32 million to drive corporate venturing and partnerships with startups.

images.alt_text: Index counters Singtel and Genting Singapore lead trading activity at Thursday's open in terms of volume.
FILE PHOTO: Employee walks past the logo of SK Hynix at its headquarters in Seongnam, South Korea, April 25, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
A Haidilao International hotpot restaurant in Beijing. The total number of Super Hi's Haidilao restaurants expanded to 122 as at end-June, from 115 the year before.

The Singapore Economic Development Board on Thursday (Aug 29) inked agreements with nine partners that will work with selected companies to innovate in growth areas under the Corporate Venture Launchpad 3.0 programme.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust’s non-executive directors get letter of demand from trustee-manager
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager has sent a letter of demand to minority directors Zhang Zhencheng and Zhang Zhongming, demanding they compensate for losses suffered from a failed investor deal. The directors are accused of obstructing the trust's restructuring efforts, including sabotaging debt restructuring and attempting to gain control of the management. The trustee-manager also demands they pay fees for financial adviser services, rental arrears, and compensation for failing to comply with financial control procedures.

images.alt_text: Amendments to the trust deed requires the approval of the bourse operator, said the trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust's initial portfolio. The trustee-manager aims to convene the EGM by end-September.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 29)
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has inked agreements with nine partners to innovate in growth areas under the Corporate Venture Launchpad 3.0 programme, injecting S$32 million over the next two years. Cordlife will resume cord-blood banking services "in a controlled manner" from September 15. Trust Bank has seen a significant increase in deposits to S$3 billion in the first half of 2024, with the bank confident of breaking even by the end of 2025. Meanwhile, Singapore Exchange's head of capital markets Matthew Song is leaving the bourse after a year in the role.

site_title: Retail offering of 99 Speed Mart’s IPO, Malaysia’s largest in seven years, oversubscribed
summary: 99 Speed Mart's retail offering in its IPO has been oversubscribed by 3.04 times, with the company offering up to RM2.36 billion worth of shares. The retail offering, priced at RM1.65 apiece, was fully taken up, while the institutional offering was also fully subscribed. This marks Malaysia's largest IPO in seven years, launched on August 15.

site_title: Preventing dementia: The transformative potential of artificial intelligence
summary: Researchers are exploring the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) in preventing and managing dementia, a growing global health challenge. Recent advancements in integrating AI with MRI technology hold promise for medical professionals to predict dementia risk, assess brain function, and detect cognitive impairment earlier. AI-driven software can identify individuals at high risk for dementia and support clinical decisions regarding prevention and treatment. Functional MRI studies can analyze brain activity, while brain-computer interfaces can decode neural activity into text, offering innovative tools for aiding individuals with communication difficulties due to brain trauma.

images.alt_text: Artificial intelligence can potentially drive the next major revolution in reducing cardiovascular mortality.

site_title: Bank of China Q2 profit falls 6.1%
summary: Bank of China reported a 6.1% fall in net profit in the second quarter, with a net profit of 58.63 billion yuan (S$10.75 billion) in the three months to end-June. This is down from 62.43 billion yuan in the same period last year. The bank's first-half net profit fell 1.24% to 118.6 billion yuan. The net interest margin remained stable at 1.44%, in line with the end of March.

images.alt_text: Bank earnings slated for later this month may be the next test for investors to gauge the health of the sector.

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill cut-off yield falls to 3.13%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill cut-off yield dropped to 3.13%, down from 3.34% in the previous auction. Demand held steady with a total of S$16 billion in applications for S$6.8 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.35. All non-competitive applications totaling S$2.1 billion were allocated, with 0.4% of competitive applications allotted at the cut-off yield. The median yield fell to 3% and average yield to 2.62%, reflecting a decrease in interest rates.

images.alt_text: The latest tranche offers a first-year interest rate of 3.06 per cent and a 10-year average return of 3.1 per cent.

site_title: Nvidia's forecast dampens AI enthusiasm in other tech stocks
summary: Nvidia's stock dropped 2.1% after the company forecast third-quarter gross margins that could miss market estimates and revenue that was largely in line with expectations. The forecast, despite beating Wall Street's estimates for the second quarter, dampened enthusiasm for AI stocks, including Broadcom and Advanced Micro Devices. Investors are concerned about increasing spending by major players in emerging AI technology and regulatory scrutiny, with Nvidia receiving requests for information from US and South Korean regulators. The company's stock remains up 150% this year, but the market's reaction to the earnings report may set the tone for a volatile September.

images.alt_text: Microsoft, Google, Meta, Tesla and Amazon all depend on Nvidia technology to train generative AI models and execute the heavy computing workloads needed to deploy the new technology.

site_title: Tata said to shelve media unit IPO after buying out Temasek stake
summary: Tata Group has shelved plans for an initial public offering (IPO) of its entertainment content distribution platform, Tata Play. The decision comes after the conglomerate bought out minority investors, including Singapore's Temasek Holdings, and withdrew the prospectus filed with the Securities and Exchange Board of India. Tata Play will remain a closely held company as the group seeks to expand the business ahead of any potential listing in the future. Plans for an IPO could still be revived in the future, with Tata potentially seeking a valuation of over $1 billion for the entertainment business.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Staff members work on the production line at Jaguar Land Rover's Halewood factory in Liverpool, Britain, December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble

The country’s second biggest steelmaker by market capitalisation said its consolidated net profit rose to 9.60 billion rupees (S$13.3 million) in the three months ended June 30, up from the 6.11 billion rupees it earned last year.

site_title: Indonesian app-based taxi drivers strike in protest over low pay
summary: Indonesian motorcycle taxi drivers staged a strike in several cities on August 29 to protest low pay, calling on the government to provide special status for their employment terms and for ride-hailing firms like GoTo and Grab to increase their share of earnings from 80% to at least 90%. The strike prompted complaints of slow services, but both companies said their operations were running normally. Drivers claim they work long hours for low wages, with some earning less than Jakarta's minimum wage.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's largest taxi operator sees demand rebound as Covid-19 curbs ease

site_title: England house completions sink to lowest since first lockdown
summary: England's new home completions fell to 31,670 in the first quarter, the lowest since 2020's first Covid lockdown, due to a slowdown in the property market after mortgage rate surges. This slump challenges Prime Minister Keir Starmer's goal of boosting net additional dwellings to 1.5 million in five years. Housing starts were 23,730, down 40% from a year ago, and the data suggests subdued completions at the start of Starmer's premiership. Labour's plans to overhaul the planning system aim to spur a housebuilding boom and drive economic growth.

site_title: Philippines prices US$2.5 billion triple tranche of global bonds
summary: The Philippines has priced a $2.5 billion triple tranche of global bonds at yields 35-32.5 basis points tighter than initial guidance. The 5.5-year bonds have a yield of 4.375%, 10.5-year bonds at 4.750%, and 25-year Sustainability bonds at 5.175%. The government took advantage of moderating benchmark yields driven by softer inflation and a dovish US Federal Reserve to raise funds at affordable costs. This is the second US dollar benchmark bond sale for the Philippines this year, aimed at supporting economic growth and reducing poverty.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, Chairman of the Monetary Board and Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (central bank of the Philippines), speaks during a press conference with Queen Maxima of the Netherlands (not pictured), who is the UN Secretary General's Special Advocate for Inclusive Finance for Development (UNSGSA), in Manila on May 23, 2024. (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)

site_title: Cordlife to resume cord-blood banking service ‘in controlled manner’ from Sep 15
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord-blood bank, will resume its services "in a controlled manner" from September 15, 2024, after a six-month suspension. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has allowed the bank to collect, test, process, and store up to 30 units of new cord blood each month from September 15 to January 13, 2025. The decision comes after Cordlife validated its new cord-blood processing method and implemented a new temperature monitoring system. The bank expects this to have a negative financial impact on its fiscal year ending December 31.

images.alt_text: Cordlife shareholder Nanjing Xinjiekou calls off plans to buy over remaining shares

site_title: Dubai developer says rich Turks, Egyptians helping fuel property boom
summary: Dubai developer Binghatti Properties is planning to build around 12,000 homes across the city over the next two years, driven by an influx of rich buyers fleeing currency instability in Turkey and Egypt. The developer attributes the surge in demand to investors seeking to diversify their wealth and capitalize on Dubai's stable economy. This follows a 20% increase in Turkish and Egyptian buyers, and a 24% rise in home prices in the city year-to-date. The move is seen as a sign that Dubai's real estate market may be breaking free from its boom-and-bust cycles.

images.alt_text: A rendering of Aldar Properties’ office tower near the Dubai International Financial center, in Dubai.

site_title: Singapore shares gain on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 13.44 points to 3,404.47 on Thursday, driven by investors assessing Nvidia's second-quarter revenue growth. The STI outperformed the broader market, where gainers beat losers 264 to 257, with 965.1 million shares worth S$1 billion traded throughout the day.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of SGX signage

site_title: A bachelor’s homely hideout
summary: A small condominium apartment in town, measuring 800 sq ft, was transformed into a loft-like oasis by HEI Architects. The owner, a trained architect, wanted a space to escape everyday life. The firm removed an existing bedroom, creating a spacious living area and open kitchen. The apartment features a monochromatic palette, clever storage details, and textures, including a cantilevering kitchen island and a "cave-like" study area. The design balances visual and experiential balance, using dark wood, fabric, glass, and metal accents to create a raw yet refined space.

images.alt_text: The original living area is now an open kitchen and dining space.

site_title: Singapore Gallery Month: Citywide art celebration throughout September
summary: Singapore is hosting its first-ever month-long art celebration, Singapore Gallery Month, from September, featuring over 99 artists in 36 galleries islandwide. The event includes various activities such as sake tastings, speed dating, yoga flows, sound baths, and exclusive home visits. Global sensation Yayoi Kusama will showcase her solo exhibition at Ota Fine Arts, while homegrown artist Ruben Pang returns with a solo show at Richard Koh Fine Art. The event also coincides with the Singapore F1 season, targeting out-of-town art collectors and providing a broader audience with art appreciation opportunities.

images.alt_text:
hymonth8 - Some of the highlights of Singapore Gallery Month.

Credit : PHOTO: SINGAPORE GALLERY MONTH

site_title: HP falls after cutting profit outlook on printer slowdown
summary: HP Inc. fell 3% in extended trading after cutting its full-year profit outlook due to a continued decline in its printing unit. The company's first revenue gain in two years was overshadowed by a 3% drop in printing unit sales. Despite a 2.4% increase in fiscal third-quarter sales, the printing business is expected to continue declining at least through the end of the year. HP also announced a $10 billion share buyback program and a $3.35-$3.45 per-share profit forecast.

images.alt_text: Geopolitical risks, including possible new PC tariffs or chip-export restrictions by US or European regulators, remain a question mark for the 40-year-old company.
The deal is also being assessed by Britain’s antitrust enforcer, with a decision due on Aug 14.

site_title: Not rich yet? Maybe you need to take bigger risks
summary: Nate Silver's new book "On The Edge: The Art of Risking Everything" explores the world of high-risk-takers in tech and finance, contrasting them with formal knowledge holders. Silver, a statistician and founder of FiveThirtyEight, argues that risk-tolerant individuals can reap significant rewards and that those who are able to counter their own risk-aversion can succeed. He identifies two groups: the "River" - highly risk-tolerant individuals who use quantitative reasoning to make calculated gambles - and the "Village" - those who rely on intuition and tradition. Silver concludes that the world is increasingly dominated by "Riverians," leading to a widening gap between the "haves" and "have-nots."

images.alt_text: Stepping out of the banks’ shadows: Reits could turn the corner soon with lower-rate environment.

site_title: China still committed to ‘stable’ US ties, Xi tells Sullivan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping told US national security adviser Jake Sullivan that China remains committed to stable ties with the US, despite "great changes." The two discussed Taiwan and other flashpoints, including the South China Sea, where China and the Philippines have clashed. Sullivan expressed US concerns about China's support for Russia's defense industrial base and China's "destabilising actions" in the region. Despite tensions, Xi reiterated China's commitment to peaceful development and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

images.alt_text: Wang Yi, the director of the Communist Party's Central Foreign Affairs Commission Office, speaks before talks with White House National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan at Yanqi Lake in Beijing, China, August 27, 2024. Ng Han Guan/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Pope Francis takes climate message to South-east Asia on 12-day trip
summary: Pope Francis embarks on a 12-day, 33,000km trip to Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Timor-Leste, and Singapore, urging global action on climate change and supporting vulnerable communities. Despite health concerns, the 87-year-old Pope aims to demonstrate his leadership strength and continue his appeals on climate change, a priority for the Catholic Church. The trip will include over 40 events, including interfaith meetings and outdoor Mass celebrations, and is seen as a strategic move to expand Catholicism in Asia.

images.alt_text: epa11444717 Faithfuls gather to attend Pope Francis' Angelus prayer during the Solemnity of Saints Peter and Paul in Saint Peter's Square, in Vatican City, 29 June 2024.  EPA-EFE/RICCARDO ANTIMIANI
The case is part of a dispute that spilt into several countries over the Vatican’s 350 million euros investment in a former Harrods warehouse that was proposed for redevelopment.

site_title: New World gets US$1.2 billion offer for Hong Kong mall
summary: New World Development has received a US$1.2 billion offer from Chinese state-owned company CR Longdation to purchase its Hong Kong shopping mall, K11 Art Mall, generating HK$40 million in monthly rental income. The sale would help New World reduce its high debt levels and leverage, currently the highest among peers. The transaction is part of the company's efforts to offload non-core assets, which has been a strategy to trim leverage over the past few years.

site_title: Court rules South Korea climate goals ‘unconstitutional’ in case brought by children and teens
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court ruled that the country's climate goals are unconstitutional, handing a victory to young environmental activists. The ruling, brought by children and teenagers, claimed that South Korea's legally binding climate commitments were insufficient and unmet, violating their constitutionally guaranteed human rights. The court found that the government's limited climate targets "violates the Constitution as it does not sufficiently protect the basic rights of the people." As a result, Seoul will revise its climate goals, with the National Assembly and government required to present greenhouse gas reduction goals considering the rights of future generations.

images.alt_text: Over 12 days, Pope Francis will travel nearly 33,000 km to visit Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, East Timor and Singapore. It is the longest trip yet by the pontiff, who now regularly uses a wheelchair due to knee and back pain.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billow from Belchatow Power Station, Europe's largest coal-fired power plant powered by lignite, operated by Polish utility PGE, in Rogowiec, Poland, November 22, 2023. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/File Photo

site_title: Waitress-turned-CEO at Haidilao operator Super Hi to soup up hotpot chain’s presence in S-E Asia
summary: Super Hi International, the operator of Haidilao hotpot restaurants, has appointed Yang Lijuan as its new CEO. Yang, a former Haidilao waitress and executive, aims to improve guest satisfaction, strengthen guest connections, and boost operational efficiency. Under her leadership, the company has seen a 12.5% increase in total revenue and a 12.3% increase in revenue from Haidilao restaurant operations in the second quarter. The company has also expanded its presence in South-east Asia, opening five new restaurants, including its maiden entry into the Philippines and east Malaysia. Despite a narrow net loss of US$126,000 in the second quarter, Yang's efforts appear to be paying off, with the company's "concerted efforts to improve performance" yielding tangible results.

images.alt_text: Tai Er is a sauerkraut fish brand that owns six restaurants in Singapore, including one at 313@somerset.
Five Singapore companies made their Nasdaq debuts in the first half year.
Haidilao operates 119 self-operated restaurants in 13 countries across four countries as at March end.

site_title: Toyota sales overcome US woes for first growth in six months
summary: Toyota's global sales rose 0.7% to 924,918 units in July, marking the first growth in six months, driven by strong demand in Europe and Japan. However, US sales were hindered by recalls of the Grand Highlander and Lexus TX, despite robust demand for sports utility vehicles in India. Worldwide output increased 0.6% to 923,658 units.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is pictured at the 43rd Bangkok International Motor Show, in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Nippon Steel to make additional investment in US Steel’s mills
summary: Nippon Steel has committed to spending at least $1.4 billion on maintenance and capital investments in US Steel's existing facilities as part of its pending $14.9 billion acquisition. This includes $1 billion to increase high-grade steel capacity at Mon Valley Works in Pennsylvania and $0.3 billion to upgrade facilities at Gary Works in Indiana. The investments are subject to regulatory approvals and are expected to extend the production life of US Steel's facilities. The acquisition deal is expected to close in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: China has suspended its system for approving new steel plants.
Manufacturers from EVs to electric utility equipment have asked for the higher tariff rates to be reduced, delayed or abandoned, and for potential exclusions to be greatly expanded.
China’s huge steel sector has been plagued by overcapacity at the time demand has fallen in part because of the protracted property crisis.

site_title: SGX’s head of capital markets Matthew Song leaving bourse: sources
summary: SGX's head of capital markets, Matthew Song, is leaving the bourse later this year, following a year in the role after a revamp. Song, who previously worked at HSBC Holdings and Deutsche Bank, led teams covering corporate and buy-side clients. His departure comes as Singapore tries to revive its stock market, which has been in a slump. The city-state has set up a task force to tackle poor liquidity and low new listings, with revenue from cash equities accounting for less than 30% of total revenue.

images.alt_text: In light of these developments, SGX notes that its Tokyo Overnight Average Futures topped 532 lots.

site_title: HSBC’s wealth head to exit bank after missing out on CEO job
summary: HSBC's wealth head Nuno Matos is leaving the bank after missing out on the CEO job, which was given to Georges Elhedery. Matos, 56, will step down after nine years at the bank and be replaced by Barry O'Byrne. The move comes after a series of management changes, including the departure of group chief human resources officer Elaine Arden and group chief operating officer John Hinshaw. Matos was seen as a strong candidate for the CEO role, but Elhedery's experience and background led to his appointment.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
Greg Hingston, new chief executive officer of Great Eastern

site_title: Powerful Typhoon Shanshan slams into southern Japan
summary: Typhoon Shanshan made landfall in southern Japan on Thursday, bringing powerful winds and torrential rains that injured dozens and caused widespread damage. The storm, packing gusts up to 252 km/h, made landfall on the main island of Kyushu, prompting authorities to issue their highest alert level and advising hundreds of thousands of people to evacuate. The coastal city of Miyazaki reported 26 injuries, including some from a tornado, with 124 incidents of damage to buildings. The typhoon's slow movement is expected to bring more rain, with the Japan Meteorological Office warning of a "disaster due to heavy rain" in western Japan.

images.alt_text: A handout image taken from the Japan Meteorological Agency's satellite shows Typhoon Shanshan moving closer the Japan's Amami island area, Aug 27, 2024.

site_title: South Korean president proposes pension fund reform
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol has proposed pension fund reform to address the country's looming demographic crisis and unsustainable pension system. With a birth rate below the replacement rate and a rapidly aging population, the pension fund is expected to deplete by 2055. The reforms aim to create a sustainable system providing intergenerational fairness and income security, with President Yoon seeking to extend credit benefits to individuals who have children or complete military service.

images.alt_text: Trade is a pillar of South Korea’s economy as the nation lacks natural resources and relies on global supply chains for basic necessities and raw materials.

Oh I-se, vet and CEO of Sky Animal Medical Group, carrying goldendoodle Mozzi before using the 'X Caliber' software to help pin point x-ray abnormalities in the dog, Yongin, South Korea, July 2, 2024.
South KOrea home housing Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Sri Lanka president defends IMF bailout in campaign launch
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe has defended the International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout, stating that the country had no option but to agree to the $2.9 billion package requiring tough austerity measures. The bailout was negotiated last year to address an unprecedented economic crisis that led to food and fuel shortages and triggered street protests. Wickremesinghe has vowed to implement the required reforms or risk a repeat of the struggles.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's President and independent presidential candidate Ranil Wickremesinghe (C) attends the launch of his election manifesto, in Colombo on August 29, 2024. Cash-strapped Sri Lanka had no option but agree to an IMF bailout that required tough austerity measures, Wickremesinghe said on August 29 unveiling a manifesto for his re-election bid. (Photo by Ishara S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: EU new car sales flat in July as battery-electric slumps: industry body ACEA
summary: EU new car sales rose 0.2% in July, but battery-electric vehicles continued to lose market share, with a 37% decline in Germany and a 10.8% drop in sales of battery electric cars. Electrified vehicles accounted for 50.9% of new passenger car registrations, while hybrid-electric car sales jumped 25.7%. Car registrations at three largest carmakers fell by 2.2%, 5.2%, and 1.7% respectively.

images.alt_text: A Tesla electric vehicle charges at a station in Nivelles, on August 26, 2024. (Photo by ERIC LALMAND / Belga / AFP) / Belgium OUT

site_title: Elon Musk’s free speech absolutism is supremely flawed
summary: Elon Musk's free speech absolutism is being challenged as his social media platform X fails to uphold the liberal ideal of a free market in ideas. The battle of ideas, meant to lead to the triumph of truth over falsehood, is instead weakened by sensational tweets and polarizing content. Research shows that 45% of coronavirus-related tweets were likely sent by robots, spreading division and misinformation. The article argues that Musk's platform prioritizes engagement over truth, and that a more nuanced approach to balancing freedom with responsibility is needed, including regulation and accountability measures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of X, formerly known as Twitter, attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition centre in Paris, France, June 16, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid Fed rate-cut hopes; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 16.45 points to 3,809.27, driven by hopes of a Federal Reserve interest-rate cut amid mild US inflation data. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the top gainer, up 2.2%, while Sats lost 1.6%. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also closed higher, with analysts predicting a "buy" call on Oiltek due to a strong order book and demand for sustainable aviation fuel.

images.alt_text: Declines in the local stocks were despite positive sentiment regarding Singapore’s full-year growth for 2024, which economists predict will climb significantly.

site_title: 🦁 Is investing in the Straits Times Index alone enough?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has been criticized for its sluggish performance, with some investors questioning whether investing in it alone is enough. The index, which tracks 30 Singapore-listed companies, is heavily weighted towards the finance and insurance sectors, with three local banks (DBS, OCBC, and UOB) making up around half of the index. In comparison, the S&P 500 index has outperformed the STI, with a 12.52% return over the past decade compared to the STI's 3.81% return. Experts argue that diversifying into international markets, such as the US, can provide better growth opportunities and mitigate currency risk.

site_title: OpenAI nears funding round at more than US$100 billion valuation
summary: OpenAI is nears funding at a valuation of more than US$100 billion in a round led by Thrive Capital, with the company seeking fresh capital to support computing power and operating expenses. The financing would create one of the world's most valuable venture-backed startups, underscoring growing demand for generative artificial intelligence software. This move comes after OpenAI's success with its chatbot, ChatGPT, and follows an arms race among larger tech firms integrating AI technology across their products and funding other promising startups.

images.alt_text: The proposal would mandate safety testing for many of the most advanced AI models that cost more than US$100 million to develop or those that require a defined amount of computing power.
India has tried to keep pace with the global AI frenzy in the nearly two years since ChatGPT launched, but chatbots have often been limited by a lack of data on many of the country’s languages.
AI startups such as OpenAI are increasingly hiring business leaders with experience at the larger tech companies as they scale and compete with their peers.
OpenAI launched its AI-powered search engine SearchGPT in July, with real-time access to information from the internet, into a territory long dominated by Google.
The capability is new for the OpenAI flagship model – fine-tuning has not previously been available on GPT-4o or its predecessor GPT-4.
The earlier timing is Google’s latest bid to keep up with rivals in injecting AI features into its consumer-facing products and comes ahead of Apple’s planned launch of a new iPhone in September.
