site_title: Gold prices firm with US inflation data in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to US$2,513.77 per ounce, as investors await US inflation data and expect a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The dollar weakened, making gold more appealing, while benchmark 10-year Treasury yields decreased. Gold is up nearly 22% this year, with a record high of US$2,531.60 reached on August 20. Market analysts predict a 25-basis-point or 50-bp rate cut by the Fed, but note that positioning risks the near-term outlook.

images.alt_text: Two hundred and fifty gram gold bars arranged at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers in London, U.K., on Thursday, March 17, 2022. Gold rose for a second day as investors weigh the trajectory of the Federal Reserve’s rates tightening cycle against risks to growth from the war in Ukraine. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title:
Singapore property players more optimistic in 
Q2 on expected interest rate cuts: NUS poll
summary: Singapore property players are more optimistic in Q2, with 73.1% citing a slowdown in the global economy as the top risk. Despite this, market sentiments remain cautiously positive, with the Current Sentiment Index at 4.8 and Future Sentiment Index at 5.1. Developers expect a moderately or substantially higher number of units to be launched in the next six months, with 56.2% of respondents. The Composite Sentiment Index remains below the neutral score of 5, reflecting conservative market views due to ongoing uncertainties.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in the global economy remains the top risk that might adversely affect market sentiment in the next six months, a survey by Ireus has found.

site_title: Time for corporate bankers to shift from transactions to trust
summary: Corporate clients are increasingly demanding a more strategic relationship with their bankers, shifting from transactional to advisory roles. Research shows that overall satisfaction with commercial banks is slipping globally, with only 9% of respondents expressing "very satisfaction" in a 2023 survey. To respond to these heightened expectations, banks must revitalize their approach to relationship management, providing strategic advisory and insights beyond banking products. This requires a cultural shift, training, and a deeper understanding of clients' businesses, including future endeavors.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Financial Centre with banks DBS, HSBC and Standard Chartered, as seen from the SkyPark Observation Deck at Marina Bay Sands on Sep 8, 2023.
Global financial firms are seeking to reduce expenses amid a deal drought.

site_title: Asean members’ complementarity creates opportunities for collaboration: DPM Gan
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the importance of Asean's complementarity in creating opportunities for collaboration and integration. He highlighted the region's potential for growth, with a combined GDP of $3.6 trillion and expected to reach $4.5 trillion by 2030. The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone deal is expected to be signed by November, and businesses will be involved in the design of various governmental frameworks. Gan stressed the need for intra-Asean collaboration and trade, as well as bilateral agreements, to strengthen the region's economic future.

images.alt_text: Teo Siong Seng, chairman of JS-SEZ Singapore Business Working Group, notes the SEZ to be a potential game-changer for both Singapore and Malaysia, leveraging the two sides' complementary strengths.
The rupiah is on course to erase all its losses for the year against the US dollar, following in the footsteps of its regional peers: the Singapore dollar, the ringgit and the baht.
Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stresses the importance of the 10 Asean member states maintaining their openness amid the global trade tensions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Prudential, PEC
summary: Prudential's new business profit fell 1% to US$1.47 billion for the first half, attributed to high base effects in many markets last year. PEC's net profit surged 176% to S$10.8 million for the second half, driven by a rise in overseas projects and maintenance works. PEC's board proposed ordinary and special dividends.

site_title: Europe: Insurance, chemical stocks keep Stoxx 600 at over one-month high
summary: The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% to 520.6 points on Wednesday, reaching its highest level since July. Gains were driven by the chemicals sector, which surged 1.4% with companies like Givaudan, Symrise AG, and Covestro up over 3%. This followed a report that ADNOC has completed due diligence on Covestro's planned bid. The move helped Germany's DAX rise 0.5% to its highest since May.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s share price closed down 2.1 per cent ahead of its earnings results.

site_title: UBS lowers China growth forecasts on deeper property downturn
summary: UBS lowered its forecast for China's growth, expecting 4.6% expansion in 2024 and 4% in 2025, down from previous estimates of 4.9% and 4.6%. The bank cites a deeper-than-expected property market slump, with China's housing slump showing little sign of reversing despite policy easing since 2022. Weaker property activities are expected to drag on the overall economy, including household consumption, with new home starts expected to bottom out in mid-2026.

site_title: How the Fed will help Singapore Reits outshine banks
summary: The US Federal Reserve's upcoming monetary easing is expected to benefit Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), which have been struggling due to high interest rates. In contrast, the country's three major banks have been performing well, distributing higher payouts to investors. As interest rates ease, REITs are expected to see increased rental income and potentially higher dividend distributions, with some analysts predicting a 2.9% increase in dividend payouts next year. This shift could help REITs overtake banks in terms of performance.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphae Bostic said he will want to see confirmation from the monthly jobs report and two inflation reports due before the Fed’s Sept 17-18 meeting that the economic trends are continuing.
The Powell pivot – named after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell – could be relatively more positive for equity markets in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: Asia: Tech weighs down markets after Nvidia results
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday after chip maker Nvidia's earnings beat expectations but failed to satisfy investors, sparking concerns about the outlook for artificial intelligence. Nvidia's share price fell 8% in after-hours trading, and the company's growth in sales was slower than expected. The disappointing results, combined with snags in the company's new technology line, weighed on broader markets, with tech firms taking a hit. This sent Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul, into the red, with the Stoxx 600 index reaching a one-month high in Europe despite concerns about US interest rates.

images.alt_text: Index counters Singtel and Genting Singapore lead trading activity at Thursday's open in terms of volume.
The  Stoxx 600 index was up 0.3 per cent to 520.6 points on Wednesday.
Nvidia’s share price closed down 2.1 per cent ahead of its earnings results.

site_title: Harris barnstorms battleground Georgia as US campaign sprint starts
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris is campaigning across southern Georgia, trying to harness a surge of enthusiasm and put the swing state back in play in November's election against Donald Trump. Since replacing Joe Biden as the Democratic presidential nominee five weeks ago, the party has begun to hope it could win the state again. Harris and running mate Tim Walz are traveling through southern parts of Georgia on a two-day bus tour, focusing on Black and working-class voters, and Harris is now targeting the four "Sun Belt" states of Georgia, Arizona, Nevada, and North Carolina as a way to give her multiple ways to win the overall Electoral College vote.

site_title: Qantas profit falls on cost of fixing damaged reputation
summary: Qantas reported a 16% decline in underlying profit before tax to A$2.08 billion in the year ended June 30, in line with analyst expectations. The airline attributed the drop to increased investments in repairing its reputation and lower air fares. Capital expenditure is expected to jump to A$3.9 billion, driven by a fleet overhaul. CEO Vanessa Hudson acknowledged the challenges facing the airline, stating that restoring trust and pride in Qantas is her priority. Despite this, bookings and travel demand remain stable.

site_title: Trump entourage accused of shoving staff at hallowed US military cemetery
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's entourage was accused of shoving staff at Arlington National Cemetery during a visit to pay respects to US service members killed in the 2021 Kabul bombing. The incident occurred despite a ban on filming and photography in the area. Trump's campaign disputed the claim, with his co-manager saying a "despicable individual" blocked their team, while relatives of victims later approved the presence of Trump's media team. The incident adds to Trump's controversies over his relationship with the military.

site_title: AI chip giant Nvidia beats expectations, but shares take hit
summary: Nvidia reported quarterly sales of $30 billion, beating expectations, but its share price fell 4% after hours trading. Despite the growth, investors are concerned that the AI frenzy may be normalizing, leading to slower growth. The company's forecast of $32.5 billion in revenue for the next quarter also disappointed some analysts. Nvidia's CEO, Jensen Huang, assured investors that the new generation Blackwell line of technology will ship to clients in the coming months, maintaining strong sales.

Nvidia’s share price closed down 2.1 per cent ahead of its earnings results.

site_title: Swifties harness their power for Kamala Harris
summary: Taylor Swift's fans, known as Swifties, have launched a fundraising effort for Democratic presidential hopeful Kamala Harris, raising over $140,000 as of Wednesday. The group, "Swifties for Kamala," held a virtual meeting featuring celebrities like Carole King and Senators Elizabeth Warren and Kirsten Gillibrand, and encourages fans to register to vote and support progressive candidates. The effort aims to "turn Swiftie power into political power" and is not affiliated with Swift herself, who has endorsed progressive causes in the past.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Nvidia slips before results
summary: US stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% at 41,091.42, and the S&P 500 down 0.6% at 5,592.18. Nvidia's share price fell 2.1% ahead of its earnings results, with traders anticipating a possible slowdown in growth, which could be negative for technology stocks. The Nasdaq Composite closed down 1.1% at 17,556.03.

site_title: Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway hits US$1 trillion market value
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, briefly surpassed the $1 trillion market value, becoming the first non-tech firm to achieve this milestone alongside tech giants like Apple and Nvidia. The company's rally this year has outpaced the S&P 500's gains, with Berkshire gaining 30% in 2024. Buffett, 94, has transformed the company from a small textile firm into one of the world's most valuable firms through his long-term investment approach. Berkshire's cash reserves stood at $276.9 billion, which has been invested in government bonds.

images.alt_text: The string of sales signals Warren Buffett’s (above) biggest pullback from an investment that long served as a stamp of approval on the leadership of Bank of America chief executive officer Brian Moynihan.

Taipei-listed iPhone assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry and chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing slid about 10 per cent each.

site_title: UK’s richest face prospect of sharp Labour tax hikes on wealth
summary: The UK's Labour government is expected to implement sharp tax hikes on wealth, following a report from the Institute for Public Policy Research that suggests reducing regional economic inequalities. The proposed tax increases would impact high-net-worth individuals, particularly those with inherited assets and capital gains. The Fabian Society has also called for reduced tax relief on pension contributions. Prime Minister Keir Starmer's government is under pressure to balance economic growth with wealth creation, while facing intense lobbying from industries that may be affected by the tax hikes.

site_title: Telegram boss Durov charged, banned from leaving France
summary: Telegram founder Pavel Durov has been charged in France on several counts of failing to curb extremist and illegal content on the messaging app. He was granted conditional release after four days under arrest, but faces restrictions, including reporting to a police station twice a week. The charges include alleged crimes involving an organized group, refusal to share documents, and dissemination of child pornography. Durov's lawyer claims the charges are "absurd" and that Telegram complies with European rules. The case has sparked controversy, with supporters seeing Durov as a freedom of speech champion and detractors as a menace who allowed Telegram to get out of control.

images.alt_text: The arrest of Telegram CEO Pavel Durov shows social media platforms can be forced to take responsibility for the content they carry.

Telegram founder Pavel Durov is accused of failing to curb the spread of illegal content on Telegram, which has over 900 million users.
Pavel Durov, CEO and co-founder of Telegram, is under investigation into alleged offences including fraud, drug trafficking, cyberbullying, organised crime and promotion of terrorism.
Telegram co-founder Pavel Durov was detained at Le Bourget on Saturday on suspicion of failing to take steps to prevent criminal use of Telegram, according to AFP.

site_title: CrowdStrike cuts forecasts as Windows outage weighs on new deals
summary: Cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike cut its annual revenue and profit forecasts due to a July global outage caused by a faulty software update. The outage affected 8.5 million Microsoft Windows devices and delayed some deals. Despite a reputational hit, analysts expect the company's dominant position to remain unchanged, and growth is expected to reaccelerate in the back half of next year. CrowdStrike now expects annual revenue of $3.89-3.90 billion, down from prior estimates of $3.98-4.01 billion.

images.alt_text: The conference marks the first big step by Microsoft to address the issues that affected nearly 8.5 million Windows devices on Jul 19, disrupting operations across industries ranging from major airlines to banks and healthcare.

site_title: Federal Reserve official says it is ‘time to move’ on rate cuts, but wants to be sure
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic expressed a desire to cut interest rates, citing lower inflation and rising unemployment. However, he wants confirmation from upcoming economic reports before making a decision at the Fed's Sept 17-18 meeting. Bostic emphasized that a premature rate cut followed by a subsequent rate hike would be detrimental to the Fed's credibility. His comments suggest that a rate cut may be possible, but a final decision depends on the economic trends presented in the monthly jobs report and inflation reports.

The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage eased for a fourth week to 6.44 per cent, the longest stretch of declines this year, according to Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA).

site_title: Audit quality fight turns nasty
summary: US audit firms, including PwC, are resisting a proposed rule requiring external oversight of quality control, sparking concerns about the integrity of capital markets. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) agreed on the rule, which would mandate a body with an outside member to oversee quality control in each of the largest firms. PwC and other big firms are trying to kill the rule at the last minute, raising eyebrows among some investor groups who see independent board members as crucial to trust in public markets.

images.alt_text: Divided along party lines, the five-member US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) voted 3-2 to approve a rule change adopted in June by the US Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB).

site_title: EDB commits another S$32 million to drive corporate venturing, partnerships with startups
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has committed an additional S$32 million over two years to its Corporate Venture Launchpad 3.0 programme, which supports innovation in growth areas through partnerships with startups. This is a 60% increase from the S$20 million committed in the previous edition. The programme has already supported 24 companies in launching 14 new ventures since its launch in 2021. EDB aims to make it easier for Singapore-based companies to form partnerships with startups, driving corporate venturing and innovation.

site_title: China proposes new curbs on grain imports to boost local prices
summary: China is proposing new curbs on grain imports to boost local prices, aiming to ease domestic oversupply and bolster prices ahead of a forecast bumper harvest. The country, the world's largest buyer of barley and sorghum, is summoning top importers to limit purchases, which could deal a blow to farmers in top exporters such as Australia and the US. The measures, which would likely impact arrivals from November, are part of Beijing's efforts to manage global price fluctuations and support local growers.

images.alt_text: Durian is packed for export at a port in Laem Chabang, Thailand, which is by far the fruit’s biggest exporting country.

COFCO has a 2025 target for a zero-deforestation soybean supply chain in ecologically sensitive areas in Latin America, including the Amazon, and has plans for sustainable palm oil and coffee supply chains.
The additive in question is known as ractopamine, which is used by livestock producers to boost muscle growth and improve feed efficiency in pigs and beef cattle.
Prices in China have risen as Beijing stepped up stockpiling of grain for state reserves to support the market in the runup to the planting of the new crop.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% after US crude stocks draw; Libya supply risks limit losses
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Wednesday, settling at US$78.65 a barrel for Brent crude and US$74.52 for US West Texas Intermediate crude. A smaller-than-expected draw in US crude stockpiles and concerns over Chinese demand weighed on prices, but supply risks in Libya and the Middle East limited losses. The US crude inventories dropped by 846,000 barrels, and refining activity rose during the week. Ongoing geopolitical risks, including the potential loss of Libyan oil output and the Israel-Gaza conflict, also contributed to the price declines.

images.alt_text: Opec+ has stressed on several occasions – most recently on Aug 1 – that hikes can be “paused or reversed” as necessary, and in recent weeks the market outlook has deteriorated amid faltering economic growth in key consumer China.
The oil giant’s global production is expected to reach 4.3 million barrels a day this year, the highest in more than a decade.
Brent futures fell US$1.88, or 2.3 per cent, to settle at US$79.55 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell US$1.89, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$75.53 on Tuesday.

site_title: Fed rate cuts have mixed impact on stocks, so don’t get carried away
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to deliver an interest rate cut next month, which could positively impact equity markets in Singapore and South-east Asia. Strategists predict positive movements in the market, driven by the expected increase in liquidity as money moves out of US money market funds. However, past trading patterns show mixed results from rate cuts, and valuations remain a concern. Domestic tailwinds include increases in civil servant salaries and fiscal strategies in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand, but the biggest risk to equity prices is an escalation of the tariff war between China and developed markets.

site_title: US companies return to currency options to hedge election, macro risks
summary: US companies are turning to foreign exchange options to hedge against potential currency volatility sparked by the upcoming US presidential election and diverging central bank interest-rate policies. With currency swings less pronounced than in 2020-2022, option hedges are cheaper, with 90% of surveyed companies planning to buy more options. Companies are taking policy risks seriously, particularly the November election, and are using options to protect their cash flow, with 48% of companies hedging their currency exposure in the second quarter.

site_title:
Empty office glut in China supercharges hotel group 
Hilton’s expansion plans
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings is expanding in China by converting empty office buildings into hotels amid the country's real estate crisis. The company plans to add around 100 hotels to its network in China over the next few years, with nearly 900 locations in the pipeline. About 25% of these hotels will be developed using empty office space, known as "adaptive reuse," which has more than tripled in China since the pandemic. Despite China's property crunch, the country's hotel boom continues, with a record 3,815 hotels planned or under construction, and Hilton sees an opportunity to capitalize on the rising middle class and untapped spend.

site_title: US, China trade warnings during tense visit
summary: US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan warned China against stoking regional tensions during a meeting in Beijing, amid security rows with American allies Japan and the Philippines. Chinese top diplomat Wang Yi cautioned Washington against supporting the Philippines in the South China Sea, stating that the US should not undermine China's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The meeting aimed to smooth over relations after China's recent actions in the disputed region, with Sullivan reaffirming the US commitment to defending its Indo-Pacific allies.

site_title: Singapore must not let trend of ‘excessive’ individualism, populism affect local politics: Chee Hong Tat
summary: Singapore Minister Chee Hong Tat warns against the influence of excessive individualism, populism, and short-termism in local politics, which could hinder the country's ability to formulate sound economic policies. He emphasizes three key government roles: ensuring adequate public services, supporting people in adjusting to shocks, and planning ahead for future investments. Chee stresses the importance of pragmatism and not being ideologically-driven, and notes that Singapore's approach balances market solutions with targeted government intervention when necessary.

“Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.

site_title: No better time than now to invest in Asean
summary: Asean is poised to become a significant investment destination due to its growing digital ecosystem, green economy, and potential as a super-connector hub. Boston Consulting Group projects the region's digital economy to treble to $1 trillion by 2030, creating opportunities for enhanced data centers. Standard Chartered Bank's head of banking says Asean serves as a base for expanding overseas. The region's exports are forecast to grow at a 6.7% CAGR, and foreign direct investments have risen 40% since 2019, outpacing the global trend.

images.alt_text: Among the Asean nations that have set net-zero goals, Singapore and Vietnam have made the most progress in reducing greenhouse gas emissions over the past year.
Foreign direct investments continue to love South-east Asia, said Edward Lee, the bank's chief economist and head of foreign exchange for Asean and South Asia.

site_title: Archaeologists in high demand in Italy thanks to EU funds
summary: Italy is experiencing a high demand for archaeologists due to a construction boom fueled by EU post-Covid recovery funds. The country's National Association of Archaeologists (ANA) reports that clients struggle to find professionals, with the sector facing low pay and job insecurity. The demand is attributed to the significant investment in the construction sector, with 59% of Italy's EU post-Covid recovery funds allocated to the industry. The ANA is set to release a report on the issue, highlighting the need for a more solid base for the profession to prosper in the future.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of an ongoing archaeological excavation below San Casciano dei Bagni, Italy, June 16, 2023, that revealed an extraordinary discovery. A trove of well preserved bronze statues, mostly dating from the second century B.C. to the first century A.D., were discovered under layers of mud in what had been a sacred pool of thermo-mineral water. (Gianni Cipriano/The New York Times)
The excavation has also turned up hundreds of artifacts that, though still being studied, have already shed new insight on life near the Vatican across centuries of Roman history.

site_title: As regional M&As spike, Singapore’s business valuation body sees benefit of standardised practices across countries
summary: Singapore's business valuation body, the Institute of Valuers and Appraisers (IVAS), aims to standardize valuation practices across South-east Asia through its Chartered Valuer and Appraiser (CVA) program. The program, launched in 2016, has 281 CVA charter holders from 12 markets in Asia-Pacific. IVAS plans to expand the program to other regional markets, with council chair Lie Kok Keong aiming to grow the number of CVA charter holders to 1,000 by 2027. The goal is to provide a trustworthy hallmark of business valuation and enable businesses to conduct transactions in the region more efficiently.

Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah delivered the keynote address at the IVAS-IVSC Business Valuation Conference 2024 virtually.

site_title: US Fed sets large bank capital levels after stress tests, eases on Goldman’s level
summary: The US Federal Reserve set capital levels for large banks, including Goldman Sachs, after annual stress tests in June. The Fed lowered Goldman Sachs' extra capital level from 6.4% to 6.2% after the firm requested a reconsideration of the finding. The central bank added that it adjusted the treatment of some nonrecurring historical expenses under the exam, which led to the change. The new levels, effective October 1, largely mirror the initial findings, and the Fed will explore refinements to its internal stress test models and data reporting processes.
