site_title: Starmer, Scholz seek reset in British-EU ties with bilateral treaty
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz have agreed on a bilateral treaty to mend UK-EU ties, with the aim of a "reset" by the end of the year. The proposed accord includes a defence agreement and deeper links on science, technology, and trade. Starmer called the treaty a "once-in-a-generation chance" to aid the reset, while Scholz welcomed the UK's desire for a "reset" and expressed willingness to accept it. The move comes as Starmer faces early challenges to his premiership, including anti-immigration riots and the war in Ukraine.

site_title: TikTok sued in UK by content moderator alleging toxic workplace
summary: TikTok is being sued in the UK by a content moderator, Olivia Anton Altamirano, alleging a toxic work environment and disability discrimination due to her multiple sclerosis. Altamirano claims she was given impossible targets and discriminated against, leading to stress, anxiety, and pregnancy complications. A judge allowed the case to proceed, stating it has "reasonable prospects of success." The case adds to TikTok's ongoing legal issues in the US, where it faces a possible ban. Altamirano seeks compensation for injury to feelings and health insurance.

images.alt_text: TikTok made commitments to remove the programme from the 27-country bloc and not to launch “any other programme which would circumvent the withdrawal”, the European Commission said.

site_title: BlackRock to auction Amazon aggregator once valued at US$1 billion
summary: BlackRock has initiated an auction for German startup SellerX, a company once valued at US$1 billion, due to a soured loan. The loan, initially extended to SellerX in 2021, was increased after the company acquired fellow aggregator Elevate Brands. BlackRock and Victory Park Capital are seeking a buyer for the company, which has struggled to recover from the pandemic-era e-commerce boom. The auction, scheduled for September 17, is a rare move by creditors to seize control of a company.

images.alt_text: BlackRock close to buying 299-unit Citadines Raffles Place for S$300 million

The US$10 trillion asset manager is focused on “building up our suite of blended finance instruments” as well as public-private partnerships, says Heidi Yip, BlackRock’s head of sustainable and transition solutions for South-east Asia.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat at open ahead of Nvidia results
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday ahead of Nvidia's earnings report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average at 41,250.17. The S&P 500 fell 1.29 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 16.02 points. Investors are watching Nvidia's performance to gauge the sustainability of the recent tech-driven bull market rally.

site_title: US clean energy jobs growth rate double that of overall jobs, report says
summary: US clean energy jobs grew 142,000, or 4.2%, in 2023, more than double the overall US job growth rate of 2%. This surge was driven by legislation passed in 2022, including the CHIPS Act and Inflation Reduction Act. Unionization rates in clean energy reached 12.4%, surpassing the overall energy industry for the first time.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People shop at a supermarket in Montebello, California, on May 15, 2024. The US Federal Reserve's favored inflation measure eased further in June, according to government data published on July 26, 2024. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index eased to an annual rate of 2.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said in a statement, down slightly from 2.6 percent a month earlier. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)
A series high 4.4 per cent of respondents said they expected to lose their job, versus 3.9 per cent in the survey a year ago.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 233,000 for the week ended Aug 3, the Labor Department said.
The latest US jobs report, which showed a material slowdown in hiring and an unexpected pickup in joblessness, heightened these concerns.
FILE PHOTO: An employee hiring sign with a QR code is seen in a window of a business in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., April 7, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Paris Paralympics open in blaze of hope and inclusivity
summary: The 2024 Paralympics opened in Paris with a colourful ceremony, marking 11 days of competition in the city. French President Emmanuel Macron declared the Games open, calling for an "inclusion revolution." The ceremony featured performances by French singer Lucky Love and Paralympic athletes, and highlighted the event's focus on inclusivity and disability rights. Over 4,400 competitors from 168 delegations will compete in various sports, with China and Ukraine sending strong teams. The Games aim to restore disability issues to the global agenda and promote a more inclusive world.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken and released by OIS/IOC on August 28, 2024, shows (from LtoR) France's paralympic torchbearers, Nantenin Keita, Alexis Hanquinquant join Charles-Antoine Kaoukou, Fabien Lamirault and Elodie Lorandi holding the flame in front of the Paris 2024 Paralympic Games cauldron during the Paris 2024 Paralympic Games Opening Ceremony at the Jardin des Tuileries (Tuileries Garden) in Paris. (Photo by Adrian DENNIS / OIS/IOC / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / OIS/IOC   " - NO MARKETING NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS

The Eiffel tower and Beach Volleyball court at sunset during a Women's Bronze Medal match between Team Australia and Team Switzerland during the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris, on Friday, Aug. 9, 2024. Uncompromising French ambition has marked the Olympics, a miracle of detailed planning and execution at a cost of about $4.8 billion. (Daniel Berehulak /The New York Times)
A balloon carrying the lit Olympic cauldron flies at Jardin des Tuileries during the opening ceremony of the 2024 Paris Olympics, Paris, France, July 26, 2024.
The Singapore contingent aboard a boat on the river Seine during the opening ceremony of the Paris 2024 Olympics, Paris, France, July 26, 2024.
BREAK THE RECORD!
Paris 2024 is designed for sustainability from the start. Apart from the purpose-built Athletes’ Village and Aquatic Centre, 95 per cent of the infrastructure is either existing or temporary.

site_title: Chinese electric car maker BYD posts 33% profit rise
summary: Chinese electric car maker BYD reported a 32.8% rise in second-quarter net profit to 9.1 billion yuan, driven by a 25.9% increase in revenue to 176.2 billion yuan. The company has taken a significant lead in the electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle sector, leveraging its vertical integration strategy. BYD is expected to unseat Tesla as the largest EV vendor this year, with a 17.7% share of the global market.

images.alt_text: BYD has a factory up and running in Thailand, and more manufacturing capacity being built in Hungary, Brazil and Turkey.
The company has been investing heavily in developing its own advanced driver-assistance system (Adas) by hiring thousands of engineers since last year.
For the Chinese automaker, the cathode project offers a foothold in a country with the world’s biggest reserves of lithium.
Saic has been subjected to an extra 36.3 per cent tariff on the EVs it sells in Europe.
Chinese electric vehicles make up a big slice of the Latin American market, with 51 per cent of all sales.
Mexico’s federal government is keeping Chinese automakers at arm’s length by refusing to offer incentives such as low-cost public land or tax cuts for investment in EV production.
Denza models at a shopping mall in Beijing, China.
BYD, China’s top-selling car brand, is pressing on with its expansion in Europe.
BYD aims to introduce additional models, including both battery-electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, to the market at a later date.
BYD has emerged as the top-selling EV brand in both Singapore and Thailand.

site_title: US mortgage rates drop again to lowest level since April 2023
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to 6.44% for the fourth week, the longest stretch of declines this year, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This rate is the lowest since April 2023, leading to a modest increase in home-purchase applications. The decline in mortgage rates is attributed to falling Treasury yields, which are expected to decrease further as the Federal Reserve may start cutting interest rates in September. This move is seen as a response to the central bank's July meeting minutes indicating a case for reducing rates.

site_title: Evonik ramps up animal-feed protein production with new plant expansion
summary: Evonik, a German chemicals giant, has expanded its methionine facility on Jurong Island in Singapore, increasing production capacity by 40,000 tonnes to 340,000 tonnes per year. This brings the facility to become the largest methionine facility in the world, with a 40% market share. The expansion is part of Evonik's efforts to remain competitive in the global market and its commitment to sustainability. The move is expected to contribute to Singapore's growth in the energy and chemicals sector, with the country aiming to increase sustainable product output by 1.5 times by 2030.

images.alt_text: Evonik to make more animal feed ingredients here
Specialty chemicals giant Evonik trains sights on Asia, sustainability growth

site_title: Oil traders remain split on whether Opec+ will revive supplies as planned
summary: Oil traders remain divided on whether Opec+ will revive supplies as planned, with 12 predicting a hike of 543,000 barrels a day in October and 11 expecting a delay. The group's market outlook has deteriorated due to faltering economic growth in key consumer China, but some delegates believe the hikes can be paused or reversed if necessary. A prolonged shutdown in Libya could ease the path for fellow members to open the taps, and analysts at Citigroup and others doubt the alliance will increase supplies as scheduled.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell US$1.88, or 2.3 per cent, to settle at US$79.55 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell US$1.89, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$75.53 on Tuesday.

site_title: What across-the-board tariffs could mean for the global economy
summary: US presidential nominee Donald Trump proposes a 10% tariff on all US imports, which economists warn could severely damage global trade. This universal tariff would affect China with a 50-60% tariff and the rest of the world with a 10% surcharge. Similar to the 1971 Nixon administration's 10% surcharge, Trump's plan lacks a specific goal and timetable, increasing the likelihood of a devastating trade war with retaliatory measures from other countries, potentially leading to recession and higher inflation.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers from EVs to electric utility equipment have asked for the higher tariff rates to be reduced, delayed or abandoned, and for potential exclusions to be greatly expanded.
Jake Sullivan’s trip comes months before the US presidential election in November

site_title: Geneva pair convicted by Swiss court over US$1.8 billion 1MDB fraud
summary: A Swiss court has convicted two Geneva businessmen, Tarek Obaid and Patrick Mahony, of fraud and money laundering in a US$1.8 billion scam targeting Malaysia's 1MDB economic development fund. Obaid received a seven-year prison sentence, while Mahony was sentenced to six years. The convictions are a win for Swiss prosecutors seeking to demonstrate their commitment to combating white-collar crime, and come after a 2022 conviction of Credit Suisse in a related case.

site_title: Malaysia’s Starbucks operator hurt by anti-Israel boycott
summary: Berjaya Food, the operator of Starbucks in Malaysia, reported a net loss of RM38.2 million (S$11.5 million) for the third quarter, reversing a profit from the same period last year, due to lower consumer sentiment on the Middle East conflict. Sales fell by more than half, attributed to boycotts of US fast food brands in Asia and the Middle East. This is part of a larger full-year loss of RM91.5 million and a 35% drop in revenue for the company.

site_title: PEC’s H2 net profit jumps 176% to S$10.8 million
summary: Singapore-based engineering company PEC reported a net profit of S$10.8 million in the second half of its 2024 fiscal year, a 176% increase from the previous year. Revenue fell 15% to S$204 million, while earnings per share improved to 4.3 Singapore cents. The company attributed its better performance to increased project and maintenance works from overseas. However, it warned that the shift towards clean energy and sustainability may impact Singapore's traditional refining and petrochemical hub, with intensified competition and a diminishing pipeline of projects.

images.alt_text: PEC is cautiously optimistic about prospects for projects works and maintenance in the energy, chemicals and storage terminals sectors over the medium term

site_title: Demand falls for latest Singapore Savings Bond with 10-year average return of 3.1%
summary: The latest Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) tranche received S$829.4 million in applications, down from S$969 million in the August tranche, with a 10-year average return of 3.1%. The lower demand is attributed to yields slipping below 3%, following expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate cut. This is in line with Fed chief Jerome Powell's signals of a potential rate cut in September, as inflation rates fall towards the central bank's 2% target.

images.alt_text: The latest tranche offered a first-year interest rate of 3.26 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 3.3 per cent.

site_title: Future of cinema clouded by uncertainty, Venice jury chief Huppert says
summary: French actress Isabelle Huppert expresses concerns about the future of cinema, citing its weakened state in recent years due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite box office sales recovering slightly in 2023, they remain 15% below average returns from 2017-2019. Huppert, who runs two art house cinemas in Paris, aims to help cinema "keep going for as long as possible" through the Venice Film Festival, which she calls a vital "ecosystem" promoting film-making values.

images.alt_text: The 81st Venice Film Festival Jury member Isabelle Huppert poses during a photocall on the day of the opening ceremony of the 81st Venice Film Festival, Venice, Italy, August 28, 2024. REUTERS/Louisa Gouliamaki

site_title: Art across the island
summary: Singapore Gallery Month, an islandwide event, features 99 artists in over 30 galleries until September. The inaugural event includes Yayoi Kusama's solo at Ota Fine Arts, Ruben Pang's solo at Richard Koh Fine Art, and a group show of female artists from the South-east Asian diaspora. The event also includes special art tours, collector home visits, and a sake appreciation event. This expansion aims to increase art appreciation among locals, with various galleries and art enthusiasts participating.

site_title: Nvidia’s earnings will test the S&P 500’s US$4 trillion recovery
summary: Nvidia's upcoming earnings are expected to significantly impact the S&P 500, potentially shifting the US$4 trillion benchmark by nearly 10% in either direction, affecting US$300 billion in market capitalization. As the second-largest company in the S&P 500 and a major influence on various equity indexes, Nvidia's results will be closely watched, with traders anticipating potential wild swings in its stock price.

images.alt_text: The results from Nvidia, whose chips are widely seen as the gold standard in artificial intelligence, also have big implications for the broader market.

site_title: US dollar rebounds, traders seek clarity on US rate path
summary: The US dollar rebounded 0.42% to 100.96 on Wednesday, its largest monthly gain since November 2023, as traders awaited economic data that could influence the US Federal Reserve's September policy meeting. The dollar index is on course for its biggest monthly drop since 2023, amid concerns over a potential US recession and hawkish signals from the Bank of Japan. Investors expect the Fed to begin cutting interest rates next month, with markets pricing in a 35% chance of a 50-basis point cut, and await the release of key economic data, including US GDP and inflation figures.

images.alt_text: Sterling 20 pound banknotes pass through an automated currency counting machine in this arranged photograph inside a Travelex store, operated by Travelex Holdings Ltd., in London, U.K., on Friday, Sept. 12, 2014. The pound, already suffering its worst month in more than a year, has the potential to tumble 10 percent should the Scots vote for independence from the U.K., according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg
The dollar slumped as much 0.7 per cent to 143.45 yen, its weakest level since Aug 5, and was last trading down 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Saudi Arabia signals ambition to host Olympic Games
summary: Saudi Arabia has signaled its ambition to host the Olympic Games, following its successful bids for the Asian Winter Games in 2029 and the potential to host the FIFA World Cup in 2034. The country's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has prioritized sports, entertainment, and tourism as part of his economic overhaul, aiming to diversify the economy away from oil. Prince Faisal Bandar Sultan Al Saud, chairman of the Saudi Esports Federation, expressed the country's interest in hosting the Olympics, but emphasized that it will be a "logical step" when the time is right.

images.alt_text: The Public Investment Fund (PIF) tower in Riyadh.

site_title: China’s two richest people lose billions in consumer stock rout
summary: China's two richest individuals, Zhong Shanshan of Nongfu Spring and Colin Huang of PDD Holdings, saw their fortunes decline by a combined $17.1 billion as their shares plummeted. Nongfu Spring's shares fell 10% in Hong Kong, wiping out $3 billion from Zhong's wealth, while PDD Holdings' shares fell the most in company history, erasing $14.1 billion from Colin's wealth. The losses underscore deepening investor concerns over China's economy, Asia's largest.

images.alt_text: Nongfu’s revenue from its packaged drinking water products fell by 18 per cent over the first half, with the segment’s proportion of total revenue dropping to about 39 per cent, from around 48 per cent last year.
Zhong Shanshan, chairman of Hangzhou-based Nongfu Spring, has lost US$13 billion so far in 2024, according to the Bloomberg billionaires Index, with a fortune of US$54.8 billion.
China’s less affluent consumers outside of glitzy mega cities drove much of PDD’s success.
Colin Huang is now the fourth-wealthiest person in China with a net worth of US$35.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Reliance, Disney India’s US$8.5 billion merger wins antitrust nod
summary: India's antitrust regulator approved the US$8.5 billion merger of Walt Disney and Reliance Industries, creating a behemoth in the country's fast-growing entertainment market. Reliance, led by billionaire Mukesh Ambani, will control over 60% of the combined unit, with Disney holding 37%. The merger, announced in February, was subject to voluntary modifications, and the regulator has given its approval. The deal cements Ambani's dominant position in the sector and secures cricket broadcast rights in India.

images.alt_text: Disney and Reliance logos are seen in this illustration taken, August 13, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Adani Enterprises’ debut public bond sale to see strong demand, bankers say
summary: Adani Enterprises is set to raise up to $124.2 million through its debut public bond sale, with yields considered attractive by bankers. The issue, scheduled to open for subscription on September 4, is expected to be fully subscribed within the first couple of days, with the company offering higher yields and a greenshoe option. The bonds, ranging from two to five years, will pay annual coupons of 9.25-9.9% and have options for direct coupon payment or quarterly interest payments. The issue is rated A+ by CareEdge and is seen as a rebound for the company after a tumultuous period.

images.alt_text: The Dharavi slum, about three-quarters of the size of New York’s Central Park, stand in contrast to India’s development boom.
Adani’s empire has been growing at a breakneck pace in the past five years, often by piling on more debt.
Adani Enterprises is looking to launch a US$1 billion share sale by mid-September.
While Sebi has yet to make a case against the Adani Group, the regulator had sent Adani officials and Hindenburg notices seeking further information on suspected regulatory violations
The offering of existing shares will mark Adani Enterprises’ return to equity markets after the flagship company scrapped a US$2.5 billion share sale in February last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 28)
summary: Key developments include new valuation guidelines for intangible assets, a 81% decline in Prudential's H1 profit to US$182 million, and KTL Global's former CEO serving an eight-month jail sentence for false trading. Additionally, Keppel Infrastructure Trust closed a private placement at S$0.438 per unit, and the Singapore government-backed Singapore Savings Bond received a total of S$829.4 million in applications.

images.alt_text: Justin Gabbani, chief executive officer (Investment Management) at Lendlease.

site_title: Hyundai to double hybrid lineup; unveils US$3 billion buyback
summary: Hyundai plans to double its hybrid car lineup to 14 models, including large and luxury vehicles, as demand for pure electric vehicles slows. The company will also invest US$3 billion in a share buyback and commit to a minimum annual dividend of 10,000 won per share. Despite keeping its EV sales target at 2 million units by 2030, Hyundai aims to target a total shareholder return of 35% from 2025 to 2027.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai factory, to be located just southeast of the capital city of Bangkok, will start production in 2026, according to a BOI statement.

site_title: Canada’s biggest bank RBC beats profit on smaller bad loan provisions
summary: Canada's largest bank, RBC, exceeded analyst expectations with a quarterly profit, thanks to a smaller-than-expected bad loan provision and a 17% rise in earnings from its personal and commercial banking segment. The bank's acquisition of HSBC's domestic operations and rise in net interest income also contributed to the results. RBC's market capitalization remains unchanged despite the strategic actions, including rejigging upper ranks and changing reporting segments, which included absorbing 780,000 clients and a C$71 billion loan book.

images.alt_text: Royal Bank of Canada's adjusted profit comes in at C$4.07 billion, or C$2.85 per share, for the three months ended Jan 31.

site_title: Cybercrime and sabotage cost German firms 267 billion euros in past year
summary: German companies have faced significant cybercrime and sabotage costs, totaling 267 billion euros in the past year. A survey by Bitkom found 70% of targeted companies attributed attacks to organized crime, with 81% reporting data theft. 90% expect more cyberattacks in the next year, and only 37% have an emergency plan to react to security incidents. The threat situation for the German economy is worsening, prompting companies to increase their IT budget for digital security to 17%, but they still need to improve their preparedness.

site_title: Meituan’s sales beat estimates on strong food delivery demand
summary: Meituan reported a revenue of 82.3 billion yuan (S$15 billion) for the June quarter, beating estimates. The company's core food delivery business expanded, driving a positive signal to investors. This outperformance stands out during a dismal earnings season for Chinese consumer-oriented companies. Meituan's shares have risen 25% this year, suggesting it's coping with emerging rivals and expanding internationally, with a focus on lower-cost delivery programs and membership perks.

images.alt_text: Meituan’s shares have surged more than 90 per cent from a late-January low.
The global expansion is emblematic of a push by Chinese companies to seek growth abroad as competition at home intensifies.Source: Bloomberg

Meituan, which operates an app providing services as varied as bike-sharing, ticket-booking and maps, reported revenue in the three months to Mar 31 of 73.3 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion), against 58.62 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.

site_title: Dubai, Abu Dhabi ranked best spots for globetrotting executives
summary: Dubai and Abu Dhabi have been ranked as the best spots for globetrotting executives, according to a research by Savills. The cities' strong air connectivity, modern infrastructure, and high quality of life make them attractive to senior hybrid workers in the finance and consultancy sectors. Many executives are drawn to warm coastal cities with easily accessible airports, as European companies encourage more employees to return to their desks. Despite rising rental prices, the affordability of prime rental properties remains a crucial factor in deciding where to move next.

images.alt_text: Global cumulative data-centre demand is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 11 per cent by 2032, Mubadala said.
Abu Dhabi has seen banks, hedge funds, family offices, venture capital firms and crypto traders rushing to the UAE’s capital in recent years as they tap into a wealthy market.
A rendering of Aldar Properties’ office tower near the Dubai International Financial center, in Dubai.
The figure marked an eight per cent increase from 41.6 million passengers in the same period of 2023, heading towards a new annual all-time high, Dubai Airports said.
From L-R: Ryan Gwee, founder and chairman, Aleta Planet; Al Ketbi, founder and chairman, National Pulse
Last year, Dubai ranked first globally for the number of home sales above US$10 million, selling nearly 80 per cent more such properties than second-placed London.

site_title: Lego CEO wants to copy Fortnite success with more game deals
summary: Lego CEO Niels B Christiansen aims to replicate the success of its Fortnite partnership with new digital deals. The company has seen a 26% increase in operating profit and 14% growth in consumer sales, outperforming rivals Hasbro and Mattel. Lego Fortnite, introduced in December, has reached 83 million players and will continue to expand with new updates and physical products, including miniature figures. Christiansen believes the digital world is crucial for the brand's long-term relevance and plans to increase partnerships and licence agreements.

images.alt_text: Lego owner, the Kirkbi group’s net income rose to 11.3 billion kroner (S$2.2 billion) in 2023.
Lego has expanded its position as the world’s No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4 per cent in 2023 when the overall market contracted about 7 per cent.

site_title: Chinese EV makers outpace Tesla in South-east Asia’s electric car race
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, led by BYD, have surged to over 70% of South-east Asia's EV sales in 2024, surpassing Tesla. BYD is the top-selling EV brand in Singapore and Thailand, while Chinese brands such as Wuling Air have experienced strong sales growth in Indonesia. Tesla's sales in the region have dropped to around 4% due to intensifying competition, with the company pausing plans to build a factory in Thailand. Chinese EV makers' dominance is attributed to more affordable offerings, local production, and market understanding, leaving Tesla to adjust its strategy to regain ground.

images.alt_text: The BYD sign at a dealership in Singapore.

site_title: Telegram’s hands-off approach to content faces a reckoning
summary: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov's arrest in France marks a turning point for the social media platform, as governments push for greater accountability from companies hosting content. Telegram's hands-off approach to content moderation has allowed abuse, including child sexual-abuse material, drug trafficking, and money laundering, to proliferate. The charges against Durov highlight the need for social media giants to take responsibility for the content on their platforms. France's move is part of a broader shift in regulation, with the European Union and UK set to introduce stricter laws on social media harms in the coming year.

images.alt_text: Pavel Durov’s arrest has caused a firestorm, turning him into a folk hero among those concerned about free speech and government censorship, especially as scrutiny of online content has increased globally
Telegram founder Pavel Durov is accused of failing to curb the spread of illegal content on Telegram, which has over 900 million users.

Pavel Durov, whose fortune was estimated by Forbes at US$15.5 billion, has said that some governments had sought to pressure him but the app should remain a “neutral platform” and not a “player in geopolitics”.
Telegram surpasses WhatsApp to become Russia's top messenger: Megafon

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, August 28, 2024 (Ep 132)
summary: Prudential reported a 1% drop in new business profit to US$1.47 billion in the first half of 2024, despite an 81% tumble in profit to US$182 million. Meanwhile, Malaysia's Starbucks operator, KTL Global, suffered losses due to an anti-Israel boycott, and its former CEO was sentenced to eight months in jail for false trading. The Singapore shares also fell 0.1% on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: XXXXX
Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta stocks all dropped on Wednesday.
Prudential attributes the lower net profit to changes in short-term fluctuations from movements in interest rates.
Berjaya Food, which operates the Starbucks coffee chain in Malaysia, reported a net loss of RM38.2 million (S$11.5 million) for the three months that ended in June.
Tan Kheng Yeow held significant quantities of KTL shares and knew that his net worth would increase along with the share price, says MAS and SPF.

site_title: China’s credit market sees first floating rate bond since 2020
summary: China's credit market has seen its first floating-rate corporate bond in over four years, with Shanghai Lingang Economic Development Group issuing a one-billion yuan note with a 20-year tenor. The bond offers an option for investors to hedge against rising interest rates, with a coupon rate of 2.66% that will reset every five years. This move comes as China's corporate debt markets have been affected by the central bank's efforts to cool down a bond rally, with yields jumping 18 basis points this month.

images.alt_text: The Oriental Pearl Tower, center left, Shanghai World Financial Center, center, and the Shanghai Tower, center right, stand among other buildings in the Lujiazui Financial District along the Pudong riverside in this aerial photograph taken above Shanghai, China, on Monday, April 2, 2018. China's sprawling local government financing system needs "crucial" reforms to increase consumption, build prosperity and encourage economic rebalancing, the International Monetary Fund said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia’s largest party backs minister for Jakarta governor, sidelining favourite
summary: Indonesia's Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP) nominated Cabinet secretary Pramono Anung as its candidate for Jakarta governor, sidelining the early favourite Anies Baswedan. The decision follows a week of protests and outcry over President Joko "Jokowi" Widodo's efforts to consolidate power. Anies, a popular former governor, had an eight-point lead in recent surveys, but PDIP chose Pramono due to his extensive experience. The nomination effectively ends Anies' chances of running, leaving a coalition of 13 government-aligned parties with Ridwan Kamil as their candidate.

images.alt_text: “We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.

Protesters climb on a fence at the parliament in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024. Indonesian lawmakers adjourned parliament as thousands protested proposed electoral changes seen as favoring the alliance of President Joko Widodo and his successor, Prabowo Subianto. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Bahlil Lahadalia, the newly appointed energy minister and the president’s right-hand man, was chosen as party leader at the annual congress of Golkar.

site_title: Great Eastern group CEO Khor Hock Seng to retire; Greg Hingston to take the helm from Nov 1
summary: Great Eastern Group's CEO, Khor Hock Seng, will retire on October 31, and Greg Hingston will take over as CEO from November 1. Hingston, 52, has 20 years of experience in Hong Kong, including 18 years at HSBC, where he led the life insurance business. The company's nominating committee and board selected Hingston after a rigorous process, citing his global market expertise and ability to lead a large team. Hingston's experience is expected to be beneficial in growing and expanding the insurer's business beyond its core markets.

images.alt_text: The local bourse needs to offer investors a choice of listed enities with strong businesses and sizeable free floats.
Existing GEH shareholders who have yet to accept OCBC’s offer can still do so, as the bank and its concert parties hold more than 90 per cent of the insurer’s shares.

Helen Wong, group chief executive of OCBC, says that the lender continues to work on its "One Group" strategy to achieve greater synergies with GEH and minimise leakage of the economic value generated.
Great
Patient investors should not fear holding shares in Great Eastern Holdings even though the shares are suspended from trading.
OCBC had in May made a a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$1.4 billion for the remaining 11.56 per cent stake in Great Eastern that it did not already own.

site_title: Seven & i seeking protection tests Japan’s appetite for reform
summary: Seven & i Holdings, the Japanese operator of seven-Eleven stores, is seeking government protection by designating itself as a "core" company under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act, which would require prior notification to the government of any purchase of its shares above 10%. This move suggests Japan may not be ready for big cross-border mergers, with a successful designation potentially killing Couche-Tard's proposed $38 billion buyout of Seven & i. The decision is a high-profile test of whether corporate Japan will evolve, with policymakers recognizing the need for change to improve governance and promote healthy economic metabolism.

images.alt_text: A 7-Eleven convenience store, operated by Seven & i Holdings Co., in Kawasaki, Japan, on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024. Circle K operator Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. made a proposal to take over much larger rival and 7-Eleven owner Seven & i Holdings Co., in what would be the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese company. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Seven & i grew from small beginnings, tracing its origins to the small family-owned Yokado Clothing Store that first opened in Tokyo in 1920.
The company’s empire now spans 85,000 convenience stores, petrol stations and retail outlets worldwide.
Seven & i’s effort to invoke governmental oversight of Couche-Tard’s proposal reflects the retailer’s wariness towards the approach.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as investors await Nvidia results; STI declines 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% or 7.44 points to 3,391.03 on Wednesday, amid mixed regional performance. Investors await Nvidia's earnings release, which analysts consider a key indicator for the artificial intelligence sector. Losers beat gainers 295 to 226, with top losers including Genting Singapore and top gainer Thai Beverage.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta stocks all dropped on Wednesday.
India has become one of the busiest venues globally for IPOs this year.

site_title: MBS bans ex-top executive, now working for RWS, from premises for alleged poaching of high-rollers
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) has banned two executives, Andrew MacDonald and Louise Ng, from its premises for allegedly attempting to poach high-rollers from the casino. MacDonald, a former MBS executive, was issued a persona non grata notice after several visits to the property in July, while Ng, also a former MBS executive, was banned due to similar allegations. The ban was seen as an unprecedented move, with experts describing it as a rare business decision by a casino operator.

images.alt_text: MBS' revenue from hotel rooms grew 29.9 per cent to US$126 million in Q1 from US$97 million a year ago.
An artist's impression of the planned Waterfront development luxury hotel on Sentosa.

site_title: Betting on Chinese demand, Hong Kong developers turn to rental market
summary: Hong Kong developers are shifting their focus to the rental market to combat a prolonged property downturn, driven by surging demand from mainland Chinese professionals and students. Rents of private homes rose to their highest level in nearly five years in July, while home prices dropped 22%. Developers like Henderson Land and Chevalier International are putting units up for rent instead of sale, with monthly rents ranging from HK$14,000 to HK$19,000. The surge in rental demand is attributed to the government's talent attraction schemes, which have attracted 140,000 mainland Chinese students and professionals to the city.

images.alt_text: The prices have tumbled 25.4 per cent from their 2021 peak, hitting the lowest since September 2016.
Hong Kong, which has relaxed visa rules to attract skilled workers, has seen an influx of middle-class residents from mainland China seeking to escape the country's economic slowdown.
CMG20240610-HoPY01/何炳耀/Stock photo: Generic pic of Hong Kong. [Hong Kong] . Photos taken on 4/6/2024. Caption: 太平山頂,山頂, 旅客. The Peak, Victoria Peak
Malaysia’s ringgit at one point saw its best single-day rally since 2015, and outperformed all emerging-market peers on Monday.
The recent improved pricing in New World’s bonds helped to lower its new issue funding costs compared to the start of the year.
8 Purves Road, located in Wan Chai’s Jardine’s Lookout area.

site_title: Thailand steps up regulation of Chinese goods as cheap imports roil economy
summary: Thailand introduces a task force to enforce regulations on cheap Chinese imports, amid warnings of a "tsunami" of cheap goods threatening the manufacturing sector. The task force, comprising 28 government agencies, will review and revise regulations to prevent the distribution of illegal goods. The move comes after the Thai economy experienced a 2.01% decline in factory output for the first half of 2024 and nearly 2,000 factory closures in the last year. The government is also reviewing its tax laws, including a 7% value-added tax on imported goods priced at less than 1,500 baht, introduced in June.

images.alt_text: The influx of Chinese products has added to challenges facing Thailand’s stuttering economy with recorded growth of just 1.5 per cent in the first quarter and saw nearly 2,000 factory closures in the past year.

site_title: KTL Global’s former CEO to serve eight months’ jail for false trading
summary: Tan Kheng Yeow, former CEO of KTL Global, has begun serving an 8-month jail sentence for conspiring with another individual to create a false appearance of active trading in the company's shares. The actions aimed to increase the company's share price, which was below the minimum price required by the Singapore Exchange in 2014. Tan also held significant shares and knew his net worth would increase with the price rise.

images.alt_text: KTL Global says independent review may take 3-5 months; shares to remain suspended
KTL Global's ex-CEO charged with cheating and false trading
Vibrant's CEO Khua Kian Keong was sentenced to 13-months jail after assaulting the former chairman of KTL Global, Tan Tock Han.

site_title: Bicycle sales on bumpy terrain as Covid cycling craze screeches to a halt
summary: Singapore's bicycle sales have plummeted by 30-70% since the Covid-19 pandemic, with retailers struggling to move unsold inventory. The slump mirrors a global cycling downturn, with major brands reporting lower sales and profits. Retailers have been forced to slash prices and offer one-for-one deals to clear stock, while manufacturers are trying to offload old inventory to distributors. Some retailers have closed stores, while others have consolidated their physical footprint. However, many are cautiously optimistic that demand will eventually normalize, with businesses with established customer bases and repair services likely to survive.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2017 by Htay Aung, Anywheel provides first-mile and last-mile transportation options.
Mounting challenges for bike retailers amid surge in demand

site_title: Bank of America to lead US$1.83 billion leveraged loan for Carrier unit deal
summary: Bank of America has committed to a US$1.83 billion leveraged loan for Lone Star Funds' purchase of Carrier Global's commercial and residential fire unit, part of a US$3 billion deal. This is expected to increase acquisition financings involving lower-rated companies in the coming months. Meanwhile, collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) have surged 70% this year, driven by a need for new-money deals amid market dominance by repricings and refinancings.

site_title: News outlet Today to merge with CNA, will become digital weekend magazine from October
summary: Today, Singapore's online news publication, will merge with CNA to become a digital long-form weekend magazine starting October 1. The move aims to grow CNA's digital traffic and deepen engagement, particularly on weekends. Mediacorp's editor-in-chief Walter Fernandez attributed the decision to worldwide news fatigue and algorithm changes that reduce news discoverability. All Today staff will be offered roles in CNA, either in the new magazine or other teams.

site_title: Regulator cuts Malaysia Airlines’ air operator certificate duration after probe
summary: Malaysia's Civil Aviation Authority has cut Malaysia Airlines' air operator certificate duration from three years to one year following a probe into technical issues, including safety and maintenance issues. The airline's parent, Malaysia Aviation Group, has prepared a mitigation plan, including an aggressive labour recruitment programme and reducing third-party maintenance services. The plan aims to address issues such as a shortage of skilled workers and mechanical components. Regulators will conduct an annual audit if the air operator certificate is to be renewed.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Aviation Group managing director Izham Ismail said the biggest lesson learnt from Covid-19 pandemic is “never put all your eggs in one basket.”
The Malaysian flag carrier will reroute flights to avoid airspace over parts of the Middle East, requiring more fuel and spurring the need to lighten its load.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip as traders await US data, Nvidia release
summary: Asia's stock markets dropped on Wednesday as traders await US data and Nvidia's earnings report, which could impact demand for artificial intelligence. Despite a rebound in markets and lower interest rates, traders remain cautious ahead of key economic indicators, including non-farm payrolls figures. Nvidia's earnings report, which could indicate sector performance, is due after US market close.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index edged 0.2 per cent higher to 518.88 points on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat at 41,250.50 on Tuesday.
XXXXX

site_title: Nongfu shares slump to lowest since debut as profit growth slows
summary: Nongfu Spring, China's top bottled water producer, saw its share price slump to its lowest point since 2020 after posting the slowest half-year profit growth in four years. Revenue from packaged drinking water products fell 18% due to a price war and public relations challenges, including online criticism of founder Zhong Shanshan. Net income rose 8% to 6.24 billion yuan, but the company's market share has been impacted, with the share price dropping 12.9% on Wednesday and 33% this year.

images.alt_text: Zhong Shanshan, chairman of Hangzhou-based Nongfu Spring, has lost US$13 billion so far in 2024, according to the Bloomberg billionaires Index, with a fortune of US$54.8 billion.

site_title: Warren Buffett reaps almost US$1 billion from sale of more BofA shares
summary: Warren Buffett sold an additional $982 million of Bank of America (BofA) stock, trimming Berkshire Hathaway's stake by nearly 13% since mid-July. The sales generated $5.4 billion in proceeds, as the conglomerate shrinks its investment in the second-largest US bank. Berkshire still holds 903.8 million shares worth $35.9 billion, making it BofA's largest shareholder. The sales signal Buffett's pullback from his long-held investment in BofA, which began in 2011 and was seen as a stamp of approval on CEO Brian Moynihan's leadership.

site_title: UBS sees growth in all Asia regions
summary: UBS reports growth in all Asia regions for the first time in two years, with 13 markets posting revenue increases in the second quarter. Australia and Singapore led the way, driven by progress in integrating Credit Suisse. New regional president Iqbal Khan attributes UBS' success to teamwork and commitment to growth, with the bank aiming to dominate global wealth management. Khan's posting is seen as a test for his successor, CEO Sergio Ermotti, as UBS continues to navigate geopolitical tensions and economic challenges in the region.

images.alt_text: Edmund Koh, president of Asia-Pacific at UBS Group AG, during a Bloomberg Television interview on the sidelines of the UBS Asian Investor Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, May 28, 2024. Koh signaled that most of the bank's job cuts in the region are over as it nears the official completion of its historic merger with Credit Suisse Group AG. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

FILE PHOTO: Iqbal Khan, CEO International Wealth Management of Swiss bank Credit Suisse attends the company's annual shareholder meeting in Zurich, Switzerland April 26, 2019.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia weighs bringing back GST to boost finances
summary: Malaysia's government is considering reinstating the goods and services tax (GST) to boost finances, with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's Cabinet discussing the option. The move comes as the country aims to cut its budget deficit and phase out broad subsidies, including those for popular petrol. However, reinstating GST is a politically sensitive issue, given its predecessor's downfall in elections. The OECD recommends reintroducing GST at a low rate and compensating low-income households, while industry groups suggest a 4% rate.

site_title: Warren Buffett sells more Bank of America shares, reaping US$982 million
summary: Warren Buffett's conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, sold an additional $982 million of Bank of America stock, reducing its stake by nearly 13%. This is part of a series of sales since mid-July, generating $5.4 billion in proceeds. The shares, which were trading near $5 in 2011, have slid 10% to $39.67, following a 31% gain this year. Berkshire remains the bank's largest shareholder, holding 903.8 million shares worth $35.9 billion. Buffett has not publicly explained his reasoning for the sales, which signal a pullback from his long-held investment in Bank of America.

site_title: Australian inflation cools, RBA set to retain hawkish bias
summary: Australian inflation cooled in July, with the consumer price index rising 3.5% from a year earlier, down from 3.8% and just above economists' estimates. The trimmed mean core measure also decreased to 3.8% from 4.1% a month earlier. Despite the slight upside miss, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is unlikely to change its hawkish stance, and markets are still pricing in a rate cut in December. The RBA's goal is to bring consumer prices back within its 2-3% target, with forecasts showing core CPI only returning to the target in late 2025.

images.alt_text: Universities have repeatedly warned that any moves to limit foreign students could damage the lucrative tertiary education industry.
Workers in Australia can now “refuse to monitor, read, or respond to” their employers’ attempts to contact them outside work hours - unless that refusal is deemed “unreasonable”.
Australia’s economy is dominated by services industries and activity in the sector has remained expansionary in the seven months to August.

site_title: Apple eyes bigger slice of India’s streaming market with Airtel deal
summary: Apple is partnering with Indian telecom firm Airtel to bundle its streaming services, including Apple TV+, with premium plans, offering them to Airtel's 300 million subscribers for free. The move aims to expand Apple's audience in India's $28 billion entertainment market, where competition is tight due to an impending US$8.5 billion merger of Reliance and Walt Disney. The deal does not disclose a value or costs, but could give Apple access to thousands of price-sensitive consumers.

images.alt_text: Layoffs are unusual at Apple, though the company has made other recent cuts.
The iPhone 16 will have larger screens on its Pro models and new camera features, such as a dedicated button for taking photos.

Apple could ultimately lose billions of dollars because of the Google case if the judge bans the search juggernaut from paying the iPhone maker and others to be the default search engine on their devices.
The new launches come as Apple forecasts more gains, betting on AI to attract buyers.
The change comes as Apple loosens its grip on devices in the EU due to the bloc’s landmark new digital rules.

site_title: Thai economy has not reached full potential: deputy finance minister
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow between 2.3% and 2.8% this year, according to Deputy Finance Minister Paopoom Rojanasakul. The country's growth rate has not reached its full potential due to global geopolitical tensions, financial market volatilities, and domestic factors such as the political situation and budget delays. Despite these challenges, the Thai economy is showing signs of recovery, with the April-June quarter growth rate beating analysts' expectations. New investment is needed to maintain competitiveness, and the government is confident in the economy's resilience.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Thailand's then-deputy prime minister Prawit Wongsuwan, speaks to members at a meeting outlining the Palang Pracharath Party's policies ahead of the general election in Bangkok on February 10, 2023. Thailand's parliament said it would investigate senior politician and former army chief Prawit Wongsuwan after he was filmed on August 16, 2024 slapping a reporter as she tried to ask him questions. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Exports, a key driver of Thailand, rose 15.2 per cent in July from a year earlier, the biggest increase since March 2022.
Houses and streets submerged by flood water in the northern province of Phrae, about 540 km from Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 26, 2024.

site_title: Prudential’s H1 new business profit falls 1% to US$1.47 billion
summary: Prudential's new business profit fell 1% to US$1.47 billion for the first half of 2024, attributed to high base effects in 2023. Excluding interest rate impacts, new business profit increased 8%. The insurer reported a 81% decline in net profit to US$182 million, mainly due to short-term fluctuations. Adjusted operating profit rose 6% to US$1.54 billion, while annualized premium equivalent (APE) sales increased 3% to US$3.1 billion. Despite a decline in Hong Kong and mainland China, Prudential remains optimistic about growth prospects in Asia and Africa.

images.alt_text: Angel Ng will join Prudential's group executive committee starting from Oct 1.
Pankaj Banerjee will assume the role on Sep 30, says Prudential.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices drop faster in July
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.9% in July from June, marking the third consecutive month of decline. The prices have fallen 25.4% from their 2021 peak, the lowest since September 2016. The decline is attributed to potential buyers waiting for rate cut signals and a weak market outlook. Realtors expect prices to continue softening until banks cut interest rates, expected to happen late this year or early next year. The decline is also linked to higher mortgage rates, talent outflow, and the lifting of property purchase curbs in February.

site_title: Market darling Abercrombie & Fitch to make a full comeback to Hong Kong
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch is set to reopen its flagship store in Hong Kong after an 8-year absence, with the company renting two large stores in prime locations. The 7,000-square-foot space in Hysan Place and the 10,000-square-foot store in New Town Plaza will be among the retailer's largest in the city. Abercrombie is betting on Hong Kong's stronger spending power compared to mainland China, amid falling property prices. The company's return to Hong Kong follows a successful turnaround story, with its stock price soaring over 236% in the past year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Abercrombie & Fitch products are seen at their store at the Woodbury Common Premium Outlets in Central Valley, New York, U.S., February 15, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Donald Trump faces revised US indictment in election subversion case
summary: US Special Counsel Jack Smith's team has obtained a revised federal indictment against Donald Trump, focusing on his role as a political candidate seeking re-election, rather than as president at the time. The indictment, like the initial one, accuses Trump of a conspiracy to block the certification of his 2020 election defeat to Joe Biden. The revised indictment lays out the same four charges brought against Trump last year. The decision comes after the US Supreme Court ruled that former presidents have broad immunity from criminal prosecution.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks behind bulletproof glass during a campaign rally at the North Carolina Aviation Museum & Hall of Fame in Asheboro, North Carolina, August 21, 2024. (Photo by Peter Zay / AFP)

site_title: Saudi’s sovereign wealth fund refinances US$15 billion loan
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund (PIF), has refinanced a US$15 billion loan with a group of banks, replacing a 2021 agreement. The three-year loan has an option to extend by two more years and is part of the fund's efforts to diversify the Saudi economy and boost annual investment to US$70 billion. The PIF has tapped bond investors twice this year, raising US$7 billion, and will rely on asset transfers, retained earnings, and borrowing to fund its investments.

images.alt_text: Riyadh Air is seeking to build its network and challenge regional incumbents Emirates and Qatar Airways.
The fund is a key vehicle for his efforts to reshape the Saudi economy and wean it off a reliance on oil sales.
The investment comprises US$100 million worth of convertible debentures, giving PIF the option to trade the investment for stocks in Chaoshang, and US$400 million in a five-year loan.

site_title: BOJ deputy governor sees rate hike justified if outlook realised
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Ryozo Himino stated that the central bank will raise interest rates if inflation aligns with its outlook, maintaining its stance despite market turmoil. Himino's comments suggest another rate hike by January, but also cautioned against rushing into a move amid unstable financial markets. The yen weakened slightly after the speech, trading at 144.3 against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: The yen’s rebound comes as a relief for the BOJ, which has been under political pressure to stem its falls that hurt consumption by inflating imported food and fuel costs.
Economists expect the Bank of Japan to increase borrowing costs again by December.

Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the market volatility seen in early August was due to rising fears of a US recession, stoked by the country’s weak economic data, while the BOJ’s interest rate hike in July led to a sharp reversal of “one-sided yen falls”.
Japanese workers in Tokyo, Japan, near Tokyo Station on 21 May 2013.

site_title: Soaring insurance costs could ‘end’ affordable housing in US, developers warn
summary: US developers and non-profit organizations building affordable housing face a growing crisis due to skyrocketing insurance costs, which are forcing them to sell units or shut down projects. Rising premiums, driven by more frequent and severe storms, are making it impossible for insurers to write policies for many developments. This threatens to exacerbate the affordable housing crisis, as the US housing market needs up to 6 million more affordable units. The problem is most severe in coastal states, where severe weather has become more frequent, and could potentially "end affordable housing development as we know it," according to industry leaders.

images.alt_text: House price inflation is likely to moderate further in the months ahead, as new housing supply has surged to levels last seen in early 2008.

site_title: Lego to replace oil in its bricks with pricier renewable plastic
summary: Lego plans to replace oil-based plastic in its bricks with renewable and recycled plastic by 2032, after testing over 600 materials. The company aims to reduce oil content to 30% by 2026 and increase production of certified renewable resin to 50% by 2026. This move comes amid a surplus of cheap virgin plastic and follows similar efforts by rival toy maker Hasbro and Mattel to use more sustainable materials. Lego's CEO says the company is willing to pay up to 70% more for certified renewable resin to support manufacturers in boosting production.

images.alt_text: A view of a Lego figure on display inside their headquarters in Billund, Denmark, April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Jacob Gronholt Pedersen

site_title: Apple cuts jobs in digital services groups as priorities shift
summary: Apple has cut around 100 jobs in its services group, a rare move for the company, as part of a shift in priorities. The layoffs, affecting some engineering roles, primarily targeted the Apple Books app and Apple News teams. The move is seen as a response to changing market conditions and priorities, with the company focusing on other areas. The affected employees were informed on Tuesday, August 27, by senior vice president Eddy Cue. This is the first significant layoffs in Apple's services group, following recent cuts.

site_title: Thai central bank says growth outlook below potential
summary: The Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput expressed concerns about Thailand's economic growth, stating it's below potential. The central bank expects the country's economy to grow 2.6% this year and 3% in 2025, with uneven recovery and structural factors holding back growth. Governor Suthiwartnarueput noted the policy interest rate of 2.5% is among the lowest globally and urged for a higher long-term growth rate to increase living standards and welfare. The central bank is prepared to adjust interest rates if the outlook changes and is keeping a close eye on credit quality.

images.alt_text: Thailand, South-east Asia’s second-largest economy is likely to grow between 2.3 per cent and 2.8 per cent this year, Paopoom Rojanasakul said at a business forum.

(FILES) Thailand's then-deputy prime minister Prawit Wongsuwan, speaks to members at a meeting outlining the Palang Pracharath Party's policies ahead of the general election in Bangkok on February 10, 2023. Thailand's parliament said it would investigate senior politician and former army chief Prawit Wongsuwan after he was filmed on August 16, 2024 slapping a reporter as she tried to ask him questions. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Exports, a key driver of Thailand, rose 15.2 per cent in July from a year earlier, the biggest increase since March 2022.
Houses and streets submerged by flood water in the northern province of Phrae, about 540 km from Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 26, 2024.
South-east Asia’s second-largest economy expects overall investment applications to reach 800 billion baht for 2024.
Thailand's jobless rate rose to 1.07 per cent in the April-June quarter from 1.01 per cent in the previous three months.

site_title: South Asia air pollution fell in 2022, but remains major killer: report
summary: South Asia saw a 18% decline in air pollution in 2022, driven by favourable weather conditions, according to the annual Air Quality Life Index report. Despite this improvement, the region still breathes the world's most-polluted air, with residents losing 3.5 years of life expectancy on average. Globally, most countries lack pollution standards or fail to meet them, and air pollution remains a significant health threat. China, however, has made significant strides in reducing air pollution, with a 41% decrease since 2013, but still faces challenges in achieving safe air quality.

images.alt_text: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres speaks during the opening of the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum in Nukualofa, Tonga, Aug 26, 2024.
“We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.
Pacific islands leaders attend the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in Nuku'alofa, Tonga, Aug 26, 2024.

An industrial park in Shanxi Province in the heart of China’s coal country, Oct 22, 2021. Research shows that bans on coal-fired power plants or combustion engine cars do not result in major emissions reductions when implemented alone.

site_title: Citigroup sees more Asia dealmaking activity in coming quarters
summary: Citigroup expects increased dealmaking activity in the Asia-Pacific region, driven by booming markets in India, Taiwan, and Japan, and a strong pipeline of transactions from China. The bank's head of investment banking in Asia-Pacific, Jan Metzger, notes that the underlying economic activity and innovation in Asia are at an all-time high. To prepare for the potential uptick, Citigroup plans to increase headcount in selective markets and sectors, particularly in Japan and India, and is positive on the healthcare, technology, and consumer sectors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks in front of a Citibank branch in Mumbai November 20, 2008.  REUTERS/Arko Datta/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba’s connect membership may be a boon for overseas stocks
summary: Alibaba Group Holding may gain connect membership, allowing qualified institutional investors to own shares via the Stock Connect, potentially unleashing up to $3.2 billion in cash across global markets. This inclusion is expected to boost foreign equities, particularly US and Japanese stocks, which have outperformed Chinese stocks this year. Analysts predict a gradual phase-out of holdings via redemptions and subscriptions, taking three years to fully utilize the freed-up quota.

images.alt_text: The decision by shareholders during its annual general meeting on Thursday will provide a much-needed boost to Alibaba, which has underperformed the market in recent years owing to weak consumption and after a painful crackdown by Beijing on the tech industry.
The company first hatched the plan for an upgrade to a primary listing in Hong Kong two years ago amid heightened tensions with the US.
Investors worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share back from PDD Holdings and JD.com in China will compress margins.

site_title: Momentum gauge signals risk to South-east Asia currency rally
summary: A regional gauge's Relative Strength Index has breached 80, indicating a risk to the South-east Asia currency rally. The index, which measures momentum, has risen above levels considered overbought, following a 4% jump in regional currencies in August, their best monthly performance since 2015. Analysts expect investor enthusiasm to fade as the Federal Reserve policy pivot is delayed, potentially leading to a consolidation in Asian currencies. Some currencies, like the Philippine peso and Indonesian rupiah, may still rise further, but gains may be limited.

images.alt_text: The ringgit movement remained volatile in the first six months due to persistent strength of the US dollar

site_title: Trump’s latest NFT sale depicts him as superhero, motorcyclist
summary: US former president Donald Trump is offering a new collection of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) featuring images of himself as a superhero, boxer, and motorcyclist, selling for $99 each. The collection includes exclusive "trading cards" and physical items, such as a piece of Trump's presidential debate suit. Sales come as NFTs continue to be weak, despite a recent surge in interest. Trump has highlighted crypto as part of his platform, with Bitcoin mining support and opposition to central bank digital currency.

images.alt_text: P2E games are a subcategory of Web3 games that leverage blockchain technology to create secure, tradable tokens. The number of games launched, the increase in market capitalisation and the rise in daily active users in recent months all point to the recovery in the Web3 gaming market.
This month Google searches for NFTs hit their lowest level since 2021, when the tokens began to enter the mainstream, according to Google Trends.
While NFTs and NFT platforms have so far rarely been used for acts like terrorist financing, they can be used to launder proceeds from crimes, said the report by the US Treasury Department.
Dolce & Gabbana allegedly told consumers that buying the DGFamily NFTs would grant them access to various digital rewards, physical products and exclusive events.
BAYC is the all-time best-selling NFT collection on OpenSea, conducting roughly US$2.9 billion in sales volume, according to the NFT marketplace.

site_title: Social media platform X back up after brief outage, Downdetector shows
summary: Social media platform X experienced a brief outage lasting less than an hour, with over 36,500 reports at its peak. Outage tracking website Downdetector showed significantly fewer reports by 11:46 pm ET, indicating the platform was back up. The cause of the outage is unknown, and X did not comment on the incident.

site_title: Frasers Property turns focus to industrial and logistics sectors on limited supply, regional growth
summary: Frasers Property is shifting its focus to the industrial and logistics sectors, driven by limited supply and regional growth. The group's assets in these sectors have increased by 80% to S$11.7 billion over the last five years. According to Reini Otter, CEO of Frasers Property Industrial, the company has diversified its investments outside residential and hospitality sectors, aiming to capitalize on high-performing asset classes.

images.alt_text: Frasers Property has seen strong industrial and logistics leasing conditions across Australia and Europe.

site_title: What’re your brand and technology worth? New valuation guidelines being developed for intangible assets
summary: Singapore's Institute of Valuers and Appraisers (IVAS) is developing new guidelines for valuing intangible assets such as brand value, intellectual property, and technology. The guidelines, co-developed with international organizations, aim to provide consistency and comparability in valuing intangible assets. The guidelines are expected to be released in the first half of 2025, with public feedback sought. The move follows the growing value of intangible assets, which were worth US$61.9 trillion globally in 2023. The guidelines are expected to enhance credibility and reliability in valuation reports.

images.alt_text: Improving intangible asset disclosures can lead to better investment decisions, said Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah.

site_title: Meta shuttering augmented reality studio amid pivot to AI
summary: Meta Platforms is shutting down its augmented reality (AR) studio, Meta Spark, to focus on investments in artificial intelligence (AI). The studio, which allowed developers to create digital filters for Facebook, Instagram, and Messenger, will close on January 14, 2025. Despite struggling with AR products, Meta is prioritizing AI, with a planned $40 billion investment this year. The company will still offer in-house AR effects and shift resources to new form factors like glasses.

site_title: Verdict due in Swiss trial over US$1.8 billion Malaysian 1MDB fund ‘scam’
summary: The Swiss Federal Criminal Court is set to deliver a verdict in the trial of PetroSaudi chief executive Tarek Obaid and director Patrick Mahony over their alleged involvement in a $1.8 billion embezzlement from the Malaysian sovereign wealth fund 1MDB. Prosecutors sought 10-year and 9-year sentences, respectively, for the two men, who are accused of orchestrating a vast embezzlement with Jho Low, an advisor to former Malaysian prime minister Najib Razak. The verdict is seen as significant in the ongoing international investigation into the 1MDB scandal.

images.alt_text: Low has been accused of embezzling US$4.5 billion from Malaysia’s 1MDB sovereign wealth fund and remains at large.

In a judicial review application filed on April 1, former Malaysian PM Najib Razak said an “addendum order” issued by the former king had accompanied a pardons board’s decision in February to halve his 12-year jail sentence for graft in the multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal.
aJho Low also agreed to cooperate in the transfer to Malaysia of certain other assets located in Hong Kong, Switzerland and Singapore that are linked to 1MDB funds.
To date, US authorities have recovered and returned about US$1.4 billion in funds misappropriated from 1MDB to Malaysia, the US embassy said in a statement issued late on Thursday.
Malaysian state fund 1MDB named a UK-based law firm in the civil lawsuit filed May 7 at the Kuala Lumpur High court.

site_title: China’s BYD aims to get half of auto sales from global markets
summary: China's BYD aims to capture nearly half of its total sales from global markets in the future, driven by investments in production facilities in Europe, Asia, and South America to skirt trade barriers. The company expects 500,000 overseas sales this year, up from 270,000 in the first seven months, with a goal of selling 3.6 million fully electric and plug-in hybrid cars in 2024, mostly in its home market. BYD's expansion plans are seen as a response to punitive tariffs imposed on Chinese electric vehicles in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: The company has been investing heavily in developing its own advanced driver-assistance system (Adas) by hiring thousands of engineers since last year.
For the Chinese automaker, the cathode project offers a foothold in a country with the world’s biggest reserves of lithium.
Mexico’s federal government is keeping Chinese automakers at arm’s length by refusing to offer incentives such as low-cost public land or tax cuts for investment in EV production.
Denza models at a shopping mall in Beijing, China.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust closes private placement at S$0.438 apiece
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has closed a private placement with 456.6 million new units issued at S$0.438 apiece, a 6% discount to its VWAP. The placement, which was 2.5 times subscribed, raises approximately S$200 million. Proceeds will be used to partially repay a S$391.8 million term loan, with S$5.4 million allocated for fees and expenses. The new units will be listed on SGX on September 5.

images.alt_text: Keppel Merlimau Cogen power plant has completed its capital restructuring with a sustainability linked loan.
Ron Sim is a substantial shareholder of mm2 Asia, holding 228,402,950 shares or about 5.5 per cent of the existing issued and paid-up share capital.

site_title: Japan braces for Typhoon Shanshan, heavy rain and strong winds forecast
summary: Typhoon Shanshan is forecast to strike Japan's southwestern Kyushu island over the next few days, prompting airlines and railways to cancel services. The Japan Meteorological Agency has warned of strong winds, high waves, and high tides, with maximum caution required. Airlines ANA Holdings and Japan Airlines have cancelled flights, and some Shinkansen bullet train services are expected to be cancelled. The typhoon is expected to approach Japan's central and eastern regions, including Tokyo, around the weekend. The Japan Meteorological Agency may issue a special warning to Kagoshima prefecture.

images.alt_text: Houses and streets submerged by flood water in the northern province of Phrae, about 540 km from Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 26, 2024.
UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres speaks during the opening of the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum in Nukualofa, Tonga, Aug 26, 2024.

As at March 2024, 15 per cent of Australian households were experiencing home insurance affordability stress, which is defined as having premiums that cost more than four weeks’ of their incomes, the report from the Actuaries Institute found.
