site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Wing Tai, Lum Chang
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust raised about S$200 million through a private placement, issuing 456.6 million new units at S$0.438 apiece. Wing Tai reported a widened net loss of S$99.2 million for the second half, while Lum Chang swung back into the black with a S$3.7 million net profit.

site_title: Indonesia sells longest-ever 40-year bond as easing pivot nears
summary: Indonesia sold a record 40-year rupiah-denominated bond worth 3 trillion rupiah (S$252 million) at an annual coupon of 6.875%. The move is seen as a response to looming interest-rate cuts, making longer-tenor debt more attractive to investors. The sale is expected to deepen Indonesia's domestic financial markets and meet demand from pension funds and insurers for long-term investments. Bank Indonesia has signaled potential rate cuts by the fourth quarter of 2024, further boosting demand for longer-tenor debt.

images.alt_text: Under the policy, the government covers the cost of value-added tax on up to two billion rupiah of the price of an eligible landed house or apartment purchase.
Output of the tropical oil this year is expected to be flat or as much as 5 per cent lower than in 2023.
“We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.
The development of the two fields will create a new production hub called the Northern Hub, Italy's Eni said.

site_title: New centre for trade associations will identify needs, provide tailored guidance, strengthen secretariats
summary: A new Trade Association Committee (Tacom) Transformation Centre has been launched in Singapore to support trade associations and chambers. The centre will analyze specific needs, provide tailored guidance, and enhance secretariats' capabilities. With the support of Enterprise Singapore, the centre will focus on smaller members and provide resources and training for trade association secretariat staff. The centre aims to empower trade associations to tackle challenges through collaboration and shared resources, ultimately benefiting Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Europe: Travel, banking stocks lift shares with data in focus
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% to 518.88 points on Tuesday, driven by gains in the travel and banking sectors. Banco Santander rose 2.5% after launching a 1.525 billion euro share buyback program, while Ryanair and easyJet gained 4.6% and 6.9%, respectively. Despite a 0.1% decline in Germany's GDP, the Stoxx 600 index edged higher. Investors are cautious ahead of key economic data, including the European Union inflation print and inflation data from the US, and rate decisions in September.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat at 41,250.50 on Tuesday.

site_title: Gold holds ground near record high as rate-cut bets build
summary: Gold prices remained near a record high, holding steady at $2,524.88 per ounce, driven by anticipation of imminent US rate cuts and safe-haven demand amid the Middle East crisis. The Chicago and New York Federal Reserve banks' boards of directors voted in favor of lowering the discount rate, further fueling rate-cut optimism. Meanwhile, US consumer confidence rose to a six-month high, and investors await the Personal Consumption Expenditures data.

site_title: Nomura is hiring wealth managers after years of staff overhaul
summary: Nomura Holdings is hiring wealth managers as its domestic retail business, a consistent performer, continues to grow. The company has overhauled its staff and business model to focus on managing the assets of rich households, shifting away from generating commissions from securities transactions. Wealth management head Go Sugiyama aims to expand recurring assets under management to 35 trillion yen by 2031. The company has seen a doubling in job applications from mid-career retail bankers and is open to making acquisitions to boost its wealth operations.

images.alt_text: Nomura’s call comes after rising interest in Indonesian and Malaysian stocks among foreign investors, with both markets poised to see a second straight month of inflows.

“Clearly, since the interest has shifted to Japan… clients who used to be fair to all the banks may now prioritise talking to Nomura to see how Japan is doing,” said Kenji Teshima, representative director and CEO of Nomura Asia Pacific Holdings.
The results show the progress Nomura has made in shifting toward a fees-based profit model in order to secure more consistent revenue that is less subject to market swings.
Costs remain elevated in the wholesale business, prompting the company to look for growth in other areas such as trust banking and investment management.

site_title: Seven & i seeks government protection after US$38 billion approach
summary: Seven & i Holdings is seeking Japanese government protection after a US$38 billion buyout proposal from Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. The Japanese operator of 7-Eleven stores is applying to be designated as a "core" company under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act, which would require prior notification of any purchase of its shares above 10%. This move reflects the retailer's wariness towards the proposal, which could potentially block the deal. The outcome of the application is uncertain, but if successful, it would be the largest takeover of a Japanese company.

images.alt_text: A 7-Eleven convenience store, operated by Seven & i Holdings Co., in Kawasaki, Japan, on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024. Circle K operator Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. made a proposal to take over much larger rival and 7-Eleven owner Seven & i Holdings Co., in what would be the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese company. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Seven & i grew from small beginnings, tracing its origins to the small family-owned Yokado Clothing Store that first opened in Tokyo in 1920.
The company’s empire now spans 85,000 convenience stores, petrol stations and retail outlets worldwide.
The plan is part of a large-scale restructuring that involves selling off lower-performing supermarket assets.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% lower at 3,396.82 on Wednesday, despite overnight gains in global markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw losers outnumber gainers 51 to 48, with Thai Beverage gaining 2.9% and Keppel Infrastructure Trust losing 4.3%. Banking stocks were mixed, while US stocks ended higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.2%. The market awaits an earnings report from Nvidia and economic data in Europe later this week.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's private placement will raise about S$200 million, says its trustee-manager.

site_title: Nasdaq seeks SEC approval for Bitcoin index options
summary: Nasdaq is seeking SEC approval to launch Bitcoin index options, which would allow institutional investors and traders to hedge their exposure to the cryptocurrency. The options would track the CME CF Bitcoin Real-Time Index and offer a cheaper alternative to trading individual Bitcoin ETFs. The move aims to normalize Bitcoin options, which have been delayed due to SEC comments on underlying ETFs. Approval would provide a new way for investors to amplify their exposure to Bitcoin, following the withdrawal of recent ETF options applications.

images.alt_text: Plutus Lending, doing business as Abra, agreed to settle with the SEC without admitting or denying the agency’s allegations.
The US Securities and Exchange Commission is accusing crypto platform Kraken of operating an unregistered securities exchange.
Licensing crypto exchanges is a cornerstone in Hong Kong’s Web3 agenda that was first proposed in 2022.

site_title: Booming India primary market lures funds from pricey stocks
summary: India's primary market has attracted global funds, with $6.6 billion in net buying through IPOs, preferential allotments, and large investor sales in 2024, the highest since 2021. In contrast, $3.6 billion was pulled from local shares, driven by high valuations of Indian secondary-market stocks at 24 times 12-month forward earnings. The country is poised for over $10 billion in IPOs in the second half of the year, including Hyundai Motor's. This trend is driven by the allure of early exposure to Indian companies through the primary route, with long-only funds from the US and Europe increasing their interest.

images.alt_text: People monitor market news outside the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, Jan. 22, 2008. India's Finance Minister P. Chidambaram urged investors to "stay calm'' after the Sensex had its biggest fall in almost 16 years. It has now slumped more than 20 percent from its closing peak on Jan. 8. Photographer: Adeel Halim/Bloomberg

site_title: Pilot shortage threatens Japan’s goal of 60 million tourists
summary: Japan's tourism industry faces a severe pilot shortage, with the country needing an additional 1,000 pilots by 2030 to meet its target of 60 million tourists. Currently, Japan has around 7,100 pilots, and airlines are struggling to find and hire new talent. The government is considering measures to attract foreign pilots, including converting their licenses to Japanese ones at a faster and cheaper rate. However, opposition from local unions and lower salaries compared to international airlines are major obstacles. If the shortage is not addressed, it could impact Japan's tourism revenue and ability to meet its target.

images.alt_text: Japan's CPI, which excludes fresh food items, rose 2.7 per cent from a year earlier after rising 2.6 per cent in June.
Japan’s economy expanded in the second quarter, rebounding from a slump at the start of the year thanks to rises in consumption and capital spending.
Exports gained 10.3 per cent from a year ago, accelerating from 5.4 per cent in the previous month, Japan's Ministry of Finance reported.

Japan's core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the six to nine months ahead, rose in June by 2.1 per cent from the previous month, Cabinet Office data showed.

site_title: Australia’s Fortescue beats dividend payout view, shares rise
summary: Australia's Fortescue reported a rise in annual profit, boosted by higher iron ore shipments, and announced a larger-than-expected final dividend, sending its shares higher. The company's underlying net profit after tax was US$5.7 billion, slightly below expectations, but it maintained its dividend payout ratio at 70% and approved the acceleration of two hydrogen projects. Fortescue's shares rose as much as 1.72% to A$18.95, their highest since August 1, as the company capitalizes on higher iron ore prices to finance its green energy business expansion.

images.alt_text: The memorandum of understanding includes exploring construction and deployment of green ammonia-fuelled vessels owned either by Cosco or jointly owned by both companies to transport iron ore and other minerals, to reduce carbon emissions in the China-Australia iron ore green shipping corridor.

FILE PHOTO: An autonomous truck readies to pick up a load of iron ore at Australia's Fortescue Metals Group (FMG) Chichester Hub, which includes the Christmas Creek iron ore mine, in the Pilbara region, located southeast of the coastal town of Port Hedland in Western Australia, November 29, 2018. Picture taken November 29, 2018.  REUTERS/Melanie Burton/File Photo

site_title: Sky-high rents have Mumbai residents living on the edge
summary: Mumbai, India's financial capital, is plagued by dangerously dilapidated buildings, with over 13,000 structures requiring continuous repair to prevent collapse. Nearly 850 buildings are deemed "dangerous and dilapidated" and not recommended for repair, posing a risk to hundreds of thousands of residents. Despite high rents, many tenants refuse to leave, citing affordability and lack of alternative housing options. Authorities have issued warnings and orders for evacuation, but residents often ignore them, leading to tragic consequences, such as the recent collapse of a four-storey building that killed one person and injured four.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Labourers construct a structure amidst shanties in Dharavi, one of Asia's largest slums, in Mumbai, India, August 1, 2023. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File Photo

site_title: China Evergrande’s EV arm warns of bigger first-half loss on impairment provisions
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle reported a consolidated net loss of about 20.25 billion yuan (S$3.7 billion) for the six months ended June 30, compared to a loss of 6.87 billion yuan in the same period last year. The EV unit expects a bigger loss due to increased provisions for impairments, totaling around 16.74 billion yuan. The company is in talks with a potential buyer and is scheduled to report its half-year earnings on August 30.

images.alt_text: The possibility of Evergrande’s offshore creditors recouping funds through subsidiaries adds another chapter to the downfall of what was once China’s biggest property conglomerate.
More than 30 publicly listed firms based in mainland China, including state-owned giants Bank of China and PetroChina, have dropped PwC as their auditor this year.
Evergrande is in the process of being liquidated in Hong Kong, where it’s listed, and the latest court development opens up the possibility that a similar fate awaits the developer in mainland China.

FILE PHOTO: A partially removed company logo of China Evergrande Group is seen on the facade of its headquarters, near a traffic light in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China January 10, 2022. REUTERS/David Kirton/File Photo

The Evergrande unit, Guangzhou Kailong Real Estate, was ordered by an arbitration court to pay Vanward the investment sum and an annual interest of 10 per cent, as well as an arbitration fee of more than 1.4 million yuan.

site_title: EU faces legal challenge over 'grossly inadequate' climate goals
summary: EU climate goals deemed "grossly inadequate" by green activists. A lawsuit has been filed against the European Union, claiming the bloc's targets for emissions from agriculture, waste, and transport are insufficient to meet the 1.5-Degree Celsius limit set by the 2015 Paris climate accords. Climate activists are seeking a 65% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, with a possible ruling expected in 2026.

images.alt_text: People crowd a beach during a hot day in Valencia, Spain, Aug 11, 2024. High temperatures, exceeding 40 deg C in some parts of Spain, are being recorded in a new heatwave, the fourth of the summer.

site_title: CNN’s Dana Bash to interview Harris and Walz on Thursday
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris will appear on CNN alongside her running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, for a joint interview on Thursday in Georgia. The interview, conducted by CNN anchor Dana Bash, marks Harris' first major interview since becoming the presumptive Democratic nominee for president five weeks ago. Harris' allies say she is being strategic about her media rollout, while critics, including former President Donald Trump, accuse her of avoiding scrutiny. The interview comes ahead of upcoming debates, including a vice-presidential debate on October 1.

images.alt_text: Harris’ entrance into the presidential race a month ago upended the Trump campaign’s strategy.
Democratic presidential nominee and US Vice-President Kamala Harris waves after speaking at the Democratic National Convention (DNC) in Chicago, Illinois, Aug 22, 2024.
Republican presidential nominee and former US President Donald Trump speaks during a visit at the frontier with Mexico in Hereford, Cochise County, Arizona, Aug 22, 2024.
The NFT sale is happening while sales of nonfungible tokens continue to be weak.

Supporters of former President Donald Trump climb the walls of the US Capitol in Washington, United States, Jan 6, 2021. US District Judge Timothy Kelly sentenced Michael Sparks, the first rioter to enter the US Capitol that day, to 53 months in prison and a US$2,000 fine.

site_title: First rioter to enter US Capitol sentenced to 53 months
summary: US District Judge Timothy Kelly sentenced Michael Sparks, 46, to 53 months in prison for being the first rioter to enter the US Capitol on January 6, 2021. Sparks, a factory supervisor, was convicted of civil disorder and disorderly conduct. The sentence was the second longest handed down so far, following Enrique Tarrio's 22-year sentence for seditious conspiracy. Nearly 1,500 people have been charged in connection with the Capitol attack, which left at least five dead and 140 police officers injured.

images.alt_text: District Judge Aileen Cannon, a Trump appointee, dismissed the documents case last month on the grounds that special counsel Jack Smith was unlawfully appointed, usurping the role of US Congress.
Manufacturers from EVs to electric utility equipment have asked for the higher tariff rates to be reduced, delayed or abandoned, and for potential exclusions to be greatly expanded.

US Vice-President and 2024 Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris‘s campaign appears to have energised large and small donors alike - a turnaround from the uncertain period after a disastrous Biden debate performance in June, when major donors reportedly halted fundraising.
When wages increase faster than inflation, the cost of grocery items relative to wages declines over time.
Robert F Kennedy Jr abandons his campaign on Friday and joins former President Donald Trump.
Harris’ entrance into the presidential race a month ago upended the Trump campaign’s strategy.
Steve Bannon, 70, is serving a four-month sentence for defying a congressional subpoena.
Meta has blocked the WhatsApp accounts after users reported the activity as suspicious.

site_title: Tokyo-Yokohama still world’s top science-tech cluster: UN
summary: Tokyo-Yokohama remains the world's largest science and technology cluster in 2024, according to the UN's World Intellectual Property Organization. Shenzhen-Hong Kong-Guangzhou took second place, while Beijing overtook Seoul to grab third. China led the world in patent filings, followed by the US, and clusters in middle-income economies experienced the strongest growth. The top two clusters combined account for almost one of every five patent applications filed globally, driven by Japan's Mitsubishi Electric and China's Huawei.

images.alt_text: The studio, called Meta Spark, allows developers to make digital filters that are overlaid onto videos in the company’s Facebook, Instagram and Messenger apps.
Shopee has helped Sea reach profitability in its recent quarterly earnings report.
The company has been investing heavily in developing its own advanced driver-assistance system (Adas) by hiring thousands of engineers since last year.
China has suspended its system for approving new steel plants.
FILE PHOTO: IBM logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks make small gains ahead of Nvidia results
summary: US stocks made small gains on Tuesday ahead of Nvidia's earnings report, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.2% to 5,625.80 and 17,754.82, respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained flat at 41,250.50. Investors are watching Nvidia's results as a gauge of the tech and AI sectors' health, with some expecting a rate cut from the Federal Reserve. US central bank chief Jerome Powell's comments last week that interest rate cuts were necessary have also boosted markets.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on August 16, 2024. US stocks edged lower in early trading Friday, as traders looked to lock in gains at the end of a positive week for major Wall Street indices. Around 10 minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1 percent at 40,518.87, and the S&P was 0.1 percent lower at 5,536.08. The Nasdaq slipped 0.2 percent to 17,566.08. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Oasis hometown abuzz after reunion tour announced
summary: Oasis, the legendary British rock band, has announced a worldwide reunion tour for next year, sparking excitement among fans in their hometown of Manchester. The 14-gig tour, including four shows at Heaton Park in Manchester, comes 15 years after the band's split. Fans, including 82-year-old Ralph Clare, 45-year-old Michelle Locke, and 24-year-old Ryan Quinn, are overjoyed by the news, with many expressing hope that the siblings' newfound truce will last. The reunion is seen as a positive development for the band's music and its enduring influence on Manchester.

images.alt_text: Elvis Presley's jewellery and pill bottle are displayed ahead of Artefacts of Hollywood & Music sale by GWS Auctions, in New York City on August 31.
A fan of Taylor Swift using the 'Swiftie Steps' a mural created by the British artist Frank Styles, outside Wembley Stadium in London on Aug 15, ahead of the five concerts she played at the stadium.

site_title: UK homes for sale hit seven-year high as market gains momentum
summary: The UK property market has seen a surge in listings, with 33 properties on average per estate agent, a 14% increase from last year. This marks the highest level in seven years, driven by a recovering economy and growing consumer confidence. With mortgage costs easing and living standards rising, sellers are becoming more confident, and buyer demand is rebounding to a six-month high, according to Zoopla. This boost in supply is expected to lift sales this year, but also keep prices in check, providing relief for those struggling to get onto the housing ladder.

images.alt_text: UK households are facing a mix of cost pressures triggered by higher interest rates and a cost-of-living squeeze.
By 2040, this former World War II airfield will be transformed into a thriving town with 10,000 homes and about 25,000 residents.

Blackstone has been betting heavily on residential property as the world’s largest alternative-asset manager anticipates a supply shortage and seeks to invest in real estate with shorter leases that allow it to capture rising rents more quickly.
Bellway said buyer confidence was improving after a drop in mortgage rates.

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% on economic worries, technical decline
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Tuesday due to economic worries, particularly in the US and China, which may reduce demand for energy. Brent futures dropped $1.88 to $79.55 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell $1.89 to $75.53. Analysts attribute the decline to a normal correction after a 7% surge in the prior three days. Concerns about the US labor market and recession also led to a boost in interest rate expectations, which could boost economic growth and oil demand.

images.alt_text: Beijing has pushed its state-owned oil giants to invest heavily in production to help the nation meet energy security goals.
Brent crude futures closed US$2.41, or 3.05 per cent, at US$81.43 a barrel, while US crude futures settled US$2.59, or 3.5 per cent, higher at US$77.42 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: US house prices fall on monthly basis in June
summary: US house prices fell 0.1% in June, marking the smallest annual increase in nearly a year. The decline was attributed to higher mortgage rates and a surge in new housing supply, which has reached levels last seen in early 2008. Existing homes inventory has also risen to its highest level in nearly four years. While an outright decline in house prices is unlikely, lower mortgage rates may boost demand and moderate further house price inflation in the months ahead.

site_title: Big agenda for Europe’s two most powerful politicians
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer met in Washington, DC, on August 28, 2024, to discuss critical issues such as the Ukraine war, transatlantic alliance, and ties with China. The meeting comes as the EU faces a critical period and Scholz and Starmer are expected to have significant influence in shaping regional issues. The key issue of UK-EU cooperation post-Brexit is also on the agenda, with the UK government seeking to rebuild trust with European allies. A potential new UK-EU security pact and improved trading deal are also on the table, with negotiations likely to be complex and contentious.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer (centre) at a wind turbine factory in the north of England, in July, where he announced his government's plans to develop green energy.

site_title: ExxonMobil seeks to sell conventional Permian assets for US$1 billion
summary: ExxonMobil is seeking to sell a package of conventional oil assets in the Permian Basin for approximately $1 billion. The assets, which produce small but stable amounts of oil, are part of the company's strategy to focus on growing shale production. ExxonMobil's global production is expected to reach 4.3 million barrels a day this year, the highest in over a decade, following its $60 billion purchase of Pioneer Natural Resources earlier this year. The sale's value is highly dependent on oil prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ExxonMobil logo is seen in this illustration taken, October 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title:
Celebrating excellence in annual reports 
to inspire the journey ahead
summary: The Singapore Corporate Awards recognize companies that excel in transparent and comprehensive annual reports. Introduced in 1974, the Best Annual Report Award promotes excellence in corporate reporting, focusing on social and environmental sustainability. This year's winners stand out for their clarity, depth of analysis, and strategic insights, showcasing a strong balance of innovation, financial transparency, and stakeholder engagement. The awards also recognize sustainability reporting practices, with a new Distinction in Sustainability Reporting award introduced in 2024. Companies that adopt transparent and responsible practices can enhance their long-term value and stakeholder trust.

images.alt_text: Winners of the Best Managed Board at the SCA 2024. From left: Lim See Wah, CEO of Hyphens Pharma International; Euleen Goh, immediate past chair of Sats; and Stephen Ho, executive director and CEO of Hong Leong Asia.

site_title: Nvidia results could spur record US$300 billion swing in shares, options show
summary: Nvidia's upcoming earnings report is expected to spark a record US$300 billion swing in its shares, with traders anticipating a 9.8% move, according to options pricing data. This would translate to a US$305 billion swing, dwarfing the market capitalization of 95% of S&P 500 constituents. The stock has been a significant contributor to the S&P 500's 18% year-to-date gain, with traders prioritizing the potential for a large upside move over a large drop, reflecting their "fear of missing out" on the company's growth.

images.alt_text: nvidia Photographer: I-Hwa Cheng/Bloomberg
Traders are pricing in a swing of around 10.3 per cent in Nvidia’s shares the day after the company reports earnings.
Nvidia shares have surged 17 per cent in the past four sessions.
Nvidia’s approval of Samsung’s latest HBM chips comes amid soaring demand for sophisticated GPUs created by the generative AI boom that Nvidia and other makers of AI chipsets are struggling to meet.

Samsung and Nvidia have yet to sign a supply deal for the approved eight-layer HBM3E chips but will do so soon, the sources said, adding that they expect supplies would start by the fourth quarter of 2024.

site_title: Australia’s Woolworths posts flat annual profit
summary: Australia's Woolworths, the country's largest supermarket chain, reported a net profit after tax of A$1.71 billion (S$1.5 billion) for the year ended June, in line with the prior year. The company declared a special dividend but warned that customers remain cautious amid heightened cost-of-living pressures and intense competition. Woolworths has been struggling with declining performance in key divisions and inflation-induced margin pressures, prompting price cuts and cost savings measures to adapt to evolving consumer trends.

images.alt_text: Coles reported a 2.1 per cent rise in net profit after tax from continuing operations of A$1.13 billion (S$998 million) for the year ended June 30, beating a Visible Alpha consensus estimate of A$1.08 billion.
Above: A Woolworths supermarket in Sydney. Woolworths is set to report its annual results on Wednesday (Aug 28), and Coles, the day before.
The supermarkets will face fines of up to 10 per cent of annual turnover for breaches of the code which mainly covers dealings with suppliers.
Woolworths and rival Coles face an inquiry next month amid claims that top grocers were inflating profit margins, worsening living costs for Australians.

site_title: Walmart takes on Amazon by adding pre-owned watches, collectibles to marketplace
summary: Walmart is expanding its online marketplace to include pre-owned watches, collectibles, and high-end beauty products, aiming to attract more customers and drive growth. The move follows a 22% increase in US online sales and rising weekly active customers. The marketplace, which has seen a 30% sales increase for four consecutive quarters, will also offer related services such as advertising and fulfillment. Walmart's strategy contrasts with Amazon's, which sells a wider range of products, including pre-owned items and collectibles.

site_title: Big Tech wants AI to be regulated. Why do they oppose a California AI bill?
summary: California lawmakers are set to vote on a bill regulating artificial intelligence (AI) development and deployment, despite opposition from tech giants. The bill, SB 1047, would mandate safety testing for advanced AI models, require a kill switch to turn off models if they malfunction, and give the state attorney general the power to sue non-compliant developers. Tech companies, including Meta and Google, have expressed concerns that the bill could hinder innovation and drive developers from the state. The bill has won support from some tech firms, including Elon Musk, but its passage remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: AI (Artificial Intelligence) letters and robot hand miniature in this illustration, taken June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Blackstone said to seek A$5.5 billion loan for AirTrunk bid
summary: Blackstone is seeking a $5.5 billion loan to back its bid for Australian data centre operator AirTrunk. The financing will consist of a $2 billion term loan and a $3.5 billion revolving credit facility. Blackstone is competing with a separate consortium, and AirTrunk's owners are seeking around $20 billion in the sale. The deal is one of Asia Pacific's largest digital infrastructure deals in 2024, driven by growing demand for cloud services amid an artificial intelligence boom.

images.alt_text: AirTrunk’s chief executive officer Robin Khuda says: “The level of growth we are seeing right now is something we have not seen in 10 years.”

site_title: Ferrari set to extend record-breaking gains, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Ferrari is expected to extend its record-breaking gains as Morgan Stanley analysts attribute the company's outperformance to "fierce brand loyalty" and low exposure to China. The Italian luxury carmaker has seen its shares rally 43% this year, outperforming European peers and luxury brands. Ferrari's new factory in Italy will build its first all-electric super-car and hybrid models, and analysts have raised their price target to $520, implying a further 6% upside. The company's low reliance on China and high repeat customer percentage have contributed to its success.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Ferrari is seen in the headquarters as CEO Benedetto Vigna unveils the company's new long term strategy, in Maranello, Italy, June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Flavio Lo Scalzo/File Photo

site_title: Preparing Singapore against turmoil
summary: Conflicts in Europe and the Middle East continue to escalate, with violent protests erupting in countries like Britain along racial and religious lines. The Palestinian cause remains a foundation for angst among ordinary Arabs and Muslims worldwide, with incendiary calls for retaliation and revenge on social media. Singapore, not exempt from the transmission of such sentiments, has a history of such incidents, including the 1974 Laju incident where bombs exploded at the Pulau Bukom oil refinery. To prevent social tensions from boiling over, fostering better understanding among people is essential, and efforts such as inter-faith dialogues, harmony circles, and the arts can play a role. Companies and the wealthy must also invest in society to help all segments cope and find opportunities, rather than relying solely on government measures.

images.alt_text: The Capitol building in Washington, DC. If the trust, respect and deference that some nations still give to America is eroded, it would be worse for the US than perhaps any policy change.
Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto (left) and vice-president-elect Gibran Rakabuming Raka at a meeting in Jakarta on Apr 24. Both sides now have to find a way to work together.

site_title: Elvis Presley jewellery up for sale at celebrity artefacts auction
summary: Elvis Presley's jewellery, including a microphone, pill bottle, and gold rings, is up for sale at the Artefacts of Hollywood & Music auction in New York City. The auction, featuring over 400 rare collectibles, also includes items from Prince, Aaliyah, and Beach Boy Brian Wilson. Estimated to sell for $35,000 to $60,000, the Presley items are expected to draw strong interest due to their emotional connections and rarity. The online auction will take place on August 31 and will be livestreamed.

images.alt_text: Graceland, the former home of rock ’n’ roll legend Elvis Presley.

site_title: Marketing to the Max is not for free
summary: Celebrity endorsements can positively impact brand perceptions and purchasing decisions, known as the "positive halo effect." Multimillion-dollar endorsement contracts exist with brands like American Express, Louis Vuitton, and Nike. However, a low-profile company, Leung Kai Fook Medical Company, took a unique approach by congratulating Maximilian Maeder, a bronze medalist at the Paris Olympics, without a prior sponsorship arrangement. This strategy suggests that subtle, genuine expressions of support can be just as effective as more overt endorsement deals.

images.alt_text: Maximilian’s podium finish in the men’s formula kite at the Olympics on Aug 9 is no surprise given his track record in recent years
When local bank DBS chose top Indian badminton players to bear its logo, this sparked social media discussions on whether they should have backed Singapore players such as Loh Kean Yew instead.

site_title: JD.com unveils US$5 billion share buyback as China concerns grow
summary: JD.com plans to repurchase up to $5 billion of its shares from September 2024 to August 2027 to appease investors concerned about a worsening Chinese consumer downturn. The move comes after Walmart sold its stake in JD, and PDD Holdings, a rival e-commerce firm, delivered a gloomy outlook, highlighting the economic malaise affecting the retail industry in China. This is the latest in a series of red flags, including Din Tai Fung's outlet closures and Starbucks' 14% decline in Chinese revenue, amid concerns about the Chinese economy.

site_title: Market’s contrasting reactions to Grab’s and Sea’s financials show that growth alone is not enough
summary: Southeast Asian tech giants Grab and Sea recently released their second-quarter financial results, with Sea's shares surging 23.7% due to its return to profitability and revised e-commerce guidance. In contrast, Grab's shares fell 3.9% after missing analyst estimates and narrowing losses. Both companies highlighted macroeconomic tailwinds, but investors are now seeking more than just growth, with Sea's advertising segment expected to benefit in the coming quarters. Grab's focus on affordable offerings and expansion into financial services is also underway, but its profitability remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Grab and Trans-cab have decided not to proceed with the proposed acquisition, and informed the competition watchdog on Jul 22.
The improved loss, however, missed estimates of a US$43.4 million loss in a poll of 8 analysts by Bloomberg.
Forrest Li, chief executive of Sea.

Shopee has been raising fees much quicker than before – twice this year for many of its core markets in South-east Asia including Indonesia and Philippines, said Simon Torring, co-founder of e-commerce research firm Cube Asia.

site_title: US consumer confidence rises in August
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 103.3 in August, but job views weakened, with 32.8% of consumers believing jobs are plentiful, down from 33.4% in July. Economists expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in response to labor market concerns. Consumer inflation expectations dropped to 4.9%, the lowest since March 2020.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People shop at a supermarket in Montebello, California, on May 15, 2024. The US Federal Reserve's favored inflation measure eased further in June, according to government data published on July 26, 2024. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index eased to an annual rate of 2.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said in a statement, down slightly from 2.6 percent a month earlier. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

Business spending on equipment notched double-digit growth in the second quarter, with spending on goods largely holding up despite 525 basis points worth of interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve in 2022 and 2023.

site_title: New mpox strain is changing fast; African scientists are ‘working blind’ to respond
summary: A new strain of mpox, known as clade Ib, has emerged, prompting a global health emergency declaration by the World Health Organization. The virus is changing rapidly, with unknowns about its severity, transmission, and mutation patterns. In Africa, over 18,000 suspected cases and 615 deaths have been reported this year, with the majority of clade Ib cases among adults, particularly in South Kivu, Congo. The lack of funding and equipment hinders the response, and the virus can spread through human contact and potentially through sex. Researchers call for urgent research and access to diagnostic tests to track the outbreak and develop effective strategies.

images.alt_text: A health worker assesses a suspected case of mpox at the Munigi mpox treatment center in North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo. photographer: Arlette Bashizi/Bloomberg

The WHO has declared mpox a global public health emergency after an outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo spread to neighbouring countries and a new form of the virus, clade Ib, triggered concerns about the speed of transmission.
There have been more than 15,000 cases of mpox in Congo this year, and at least 550 deaths.
Two vaccines, made by Denmark’s Bavarian Nordic and Japan’s KM Biologics, are already approved by regulators around the world, including the United States and Japan.
A health worker discusses treatments with patients at the Munigi mpox treatment center in Nyiragongo territory, North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo.
MOH said that close contacts will be offered vaccination to reduce the risk of mpox infection.
Clade 1b has triggered global concern due to the ease with which it spreads.

site_title: Lum Chang swings back to black with S$3.7 million H2 net profit
summary: Lum Chang, a Singapore-based construction company, reported a net profit of S$3.7 million for the second half of its 2024 fiscal year, reversing a net loss of S$29.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 36% to S$267.8 million, driven by improved construction activity and new projects. The company expects challenging operational conditions due to a competitive tendering environment and high material costs.

images.alt_text: Former transport minister S. Iswaran arrived with his team of lawyers at the Supreme Court building on May 8, 2024
The Land Transport Authority says it has not awarded any contract to Lum Chang Building Contractors since 2019.
Lum Chang said that the pandemic has led to higher materials, labour and subcontractor costs.
The 19-storey hotel will be located on Orchard Road, and is expected to have 246 rooms with ancillary facilities.
Lum Chang unit disposes interest in UK serviced residence block

site_title: Portability of Integrated Shield Plans could exacerbate rising premiums
summary: The portability of Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) in Singapore may exacerbate rising premiums. A study by the Singapore Actuarial Society (SAS) suggests that more generous portability terms, such as coverage for all pre-existing conditions, could lead to higher premiums. Industry experts argue that the "as charged" benefit design, which drives overconsumption of healthcare, is a major contributor to the trend of rising premiums. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is set to complete its study on IP portability within the year, but some experts believe that the industry should focus on other levers to dampen claims and costs, rather than portability, to keep premiums sustainable and affordable.

images.alt_text: How essential are Integrated Shield plans (IPs) and riders?
The government has raised concerns about "overly generous insurance policy design" which lead to bigger bills and higher premiums. Around 2% of seniors have given up their Integrated Shield plans.
Changes in portability rules for Integrated Shield plans and riders will need to be thoroughly analysed in terms of intended and unintended impacts on all stakeholders.
Raffles Medical's hospital division remains strong, growing its profit after tax by 65 per cent for H1 FY2024.

site_title: How keeping an investment journal can make you a better investor
summary: Keeping an investment journal can significantly improve decision-making, emotional management, and tracking investment progress. By documenting investment decisions and strategies, individuals can refine their approach, avoid emotional mistakes, and learn from past errors. This practice helps investors stay objective, rational, and accountable, ultimately leading to better investment outcomes and a more disciplined investment strategy.

images.alt_text: Investing without making mistakes is like trying to surf the ocean waves without getting wet –it’s just not realistic.
It is not unusual for the stock market to weather periods of intense volatility. Learning how to manage unpredictability is key to investing success.

site_title: Wing Tai H2 net loss widens to S$99.2 million
summary: Wing Tai Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a widened net loss of S$99.2 million in the second half of its 2024 fiscal year, nearly doubling its losses from the same period last year. Revenue fell by 67% to S$71.5 million due to lower contributions from its development properties. The company attributed the losses to impairment losses on its development properties and fair value losses on its investment properties in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in the Causeway Bay area of Hong Kong. The city's property market has been struggling.
River Valley Green parcel is seen in the background.
River Valley Green (Parcel A), on the confirmed list of the first-half 2024 Government Land Sales Programmej, can yield about 380 private housing units.
BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee asks: Might the government relook having housing sites with long-stay serviced apartments or consider ways to boost developers’ appetite for housing plots?
Wing Tai is issuing new notes under its S$1 billion multicurrency debt programme.
Wing Tai represents fashion brands including Uniqlo in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore shares add to gains on Tuesday; STI ticks up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,398.47 on Tuesday, with 264 advancers outnumbering 249 decliners. The benchmark index led by Thai Beverage's 3% gain, while Jardine Matheson fell 1.8%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also saw gains. The gains were influenced by geopolitical movements, with investors digesting trade relations between China and the West.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Sony hikes PlayStation 5 price in Japan citing cost volatility
summary: Sony is increasing the price of its PlayStation 5 in Japan by 19% to nearly 80,000 yen, citing the impact of global economic fluctuations. The price hike comes despite slowing PS5 sales and expectations of a mid-cycle console refresh. This move follows Sony's recent price increases on TVs, headphones, and cameras, and Microsoft's price hike on Xbox consoles. Analysts predict Sony's games division profit may reach a new high in the fiscal year to March, driven by strong first-party titles and potential price hikes on PlayStation network services.

site_title: China’s Xpeng prices new budget EV at US$16,813
summary: China's electric vehicle maker Xpeng priced its budget sub-brand MONA at US$16,813, targeting the mainstream segment of China's largest auto market. The MONA M03 electric hatchback coupe will compete with other EVs priced between 100,000-150,000 yuan. Two versions will be available: an entry-level model and the M03 Max with advanced autonomous driving technology, priced from US$21,866. Deliveries of the M03 Max will start early next year, aiming to achieve a better economy of scale and break even.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen’s Chinese partner is in the initial stages of selecting a site in the European Union as part of its future plan to localise production, CEO He Xiaopeng says.
XPeng has seen its expansion plans temporarily throttled by the European Commission’s move to impose tariffs on electric vehicles made in China.
Pre-sales of the Land Aircraft Carrier are due to start in the final quarter of 2024 in China, the company says.

site_title: Philippine president defends massive operation to arrest celebrity pastor
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. defended the deployment of 2,000 police officers to arrest self-proclaimed pastor Apollo Quiboloy, accused of sex trafficking and child abuse, who is hiding in a compound owned by his church. Quiboloy denies wrongdoing and has millions of followers in the Philippines. The operation was criticized by former President Rodrigo Duterte and his daughter, Vice President Sara Duterte, who accused police of rights violations and abuse of power. The arrest is part of a court order to apprehend Quiboloy, who is also on the US Federal Bureau of Investigation's most wanted list.

images.alt_text: epa11565411 Anti-riot police block supporters of religious leader Apollo Quiboloy as they stage a protest rally outside the Kingdom of Jesus Christ (KOJC) compound in Davao city, Davao del Sur province, about 1,500 kilometers south of Manila, Philippines, 26 August 2024. The Philippine National Police (PNP) are searching the 30-hectare Kingdom of Jesus Christ (KOJC) compound to arrest KOJC leader Pastor Apollo Quiboloy, who claims he is the ‘Son of God’. Quiboloy and five other KOJC members are facing charges of child abuse and human trafficking.  EPA-EFE/CERILO EBRANO

site_title: China’s July net gold imports via HK rise for first time since March
summary: China's gold imports via Hong Kong rose 17% in July, the first increase since March, with 25.659 tonnes imported. Total gold imports were up 6% at 31.457 tonnes. China's central bank paused gold purchases in May, but several banks received new import quotas. Analysts say the uptick in imports may be a knee-jerk reaction to revive demand, but industry officials expect gold demand to increase as economic uncertainty boosts investment flows, despite record-high prices.

images.alt_text: Gold is historically reputed for its stability as a favoured hedge against geopolitical and economic risks.
A revival of demand in China, the world’s top consumer of the precious metal, could further support the rally in global gold prices, which hit a record high last week.
Gold’s resilience throughout the current rate-hike cycle highlights that numerous factors are capable of impacting movements in the gold price, particularly over the short term.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, August 27, 2024 (Ep 131)
summary: Asian stocks fluctuated on Tuesday, with PDD's US$55 billion stock crash sending a warning on the Chinese economy. South-east Asian currencies reached fresh highs against the US dollar following a speech by Powell, with strength expected to last till the year-end.

images.alt_text: Silverlake Axis is the most actively traded counter of the morning.
Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul Singapore, Sydney, Wellington and Taipei stocks all slipped on Tuesday.
China’s less affluent consumers outside of glitzy mega cities drove much of PDD’s success.
The rupiah is on course to erase all its losses for the year against the US dollar, following in the footsteps of its regional peers: the Singapore dollar, the ringgit and the baht.

site_title: Party of Thailand's new PM drops military-backed party from coalition government
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai Party has dropped the Palang Pracharat Party from its coalition government, signaling a rift in the alliance. The decision comes after Palang Pracharat's leader, Prawit Wongsuwon, failed to attend a parliamentary vote to approve new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra. Despite losing seats, Pheu Thai's coalition is expected to have over 300 of 500 parliamentary seats, and the party plans to team up with the Democrat Party. Pheu Thai's decision is seen as a move to distance itself from the military-backed Palang Pracharat Party, which has been involved in coups against Pheu Thai's predecessor.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Thailand's then-deputy prime minister Prawit Wongsuwan, speaks to members at a meeting outlining the Palang Pracharath Party's policies ahead of the general election in Bangkok on February 10, 2023. Thailand's parliament said it would investigate senior politician and former army chief Prawit Wongsuwan after he was filmed on August 16, 2024 slapping a reporter as she tried to ask him questions. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: OCBC moves to recover over S$6 million owed on mortgages for assets linked to money laundering case
summary: OCBC has filed claims in the High Court to recover over S$6 million owed on mortgages for assets linked to the S$3 billion money laundering case. The bank is seeking funds from Xu Haika and Wu Yamei, who purchased units at South Beach Residences, as well as Lin Baoying and Su Yongcan, who bought units in the same development. The bank is also seeking to repossess the properties and has previously recovered over S$20 million from the sale of a Sentosa property and shophouses in Chinatown.

images.alt_text: The plot of land (left, covered by sound barrier) at 69 Ocean Drive in Sentosa Cove which is up for sale, pictured on April 15, 2024.

site_title: US says escorting Philippine ships in South China Sea an option
summary: The US has offered to escort Philippine vessels during resupply missions in the South China Sea, amid recurring confrontations with Chinese ships. This comes after recent clashes, including a collision near Sabina Shoal. The US has repeatedly assured the Philippines of its "ironclad" commitment to defend its ally under the 1951 treaty. However, Washington's direct involvement could risk intensifying tensions with Beijing, which has said the US has no right to interfere in the maritime dispute. The Philippines will rely on itself for missions, but may seek cooperation with other nations like the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: epa11554758 A handout photo made available by the Philippine Coast Guard shows the damaged ship BRP Cape Engano following a collision with a Chinese coast guard vessel near Sabina Shoal in disputed waters of the South China Sea, 19 August 2024. National Task Force for the West Philippine Sea (NTF-WPS) spokesperson Jonathan Malaya announced that the Philippine Coast Guard patrol ships 'BRP Bagacay' and 'BRP Cape Engano' were damaged after being subjected to unlawful and aggressive maneuvers by Chinese Coast Guard ships while en route for a resupply mission to the Spratys islands in South China Sea.  EPA-EFE/Philippine Coast Guard HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Pound hits more than two-year high, US dollar back under pressure
summary: The pound has reached its highest level since March 2022, closing at US$1.32195, as investors shift away from the US dollar amid expectations of a pause in rising oil prices and upcoming US rate cuts. The dollar index settled at 100.88, just off a one-year low. The euro was also up against the dollar, while the Canadian dollar and Swiss franc gained. Markets expect a rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September, with some predicting a 50-basis-point cut.

images.alt_text: The dollar slumped as much 0.7 per cent to 143.45 yen, its weakest level since Aug 5, and was last trading down 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Panama Canal eases limits that caused global shipping bottleneck
summary: The Panama Canal has lifted restrictions that caused a global shipping bottleneck due to severe drought, allowing 36 vessels a day to transit after recent rains lifted water levels. The canal will increase its draft to 50 feet and expects rains to continue through November, further lifting water levels. It may need to implement seasonal draft restrictions in 2025, but aims to avoid daily transit restrictions. The authority is studying a proposal to open long-term reservation slots for time-sensitive users and is considering building a dam to boost its water supply.

site_title: UK retail sales fall for 3rd month, CBI says
summary: UK retail sales have fallen for the third consecutive month, with the Confederation of British Industry (CBI) reporting a -27 sales balance in August, a less severe decline than in July. Retailers predict another weak month in September, citing poor weather and a squeeze on household spending power. The CBI also reported decreased investment and hiring plans, with a gauge of sales expectations at -17. Shop prices fell in annual terms in August for the first time since October 2021, adding to the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Workers in the claim would be entitled to back pay for up to six years before they brought the action and for the time since, a total estimated to be more than £30 million (S$51.6 million).
Shop prices fell by 0.3 per cent in August compared with the same month in 2023, after a 0.2 per cent increase in July.

The Confederation of British Industry’s monthly net balance of new orders rose in August to -22 from -32 in July, marking two years of straight negative readings.

A strong performance in the second quarter meant the UK enjoyed the best growth in the Group of Seven nations in the first half of 2024, outstripping the US and well ahead of other European countries.

site_title: Pakistan eyes US$4 billion from Middle Eastern banks to plug financing gap
summary: Pakistan aims to raise up to $4 billion from Middle Eastern banks to fill a financing gap, Governor Jameel Ahmad said in an interview. The country is also in the advanced stages of securing $2 billion in external financing for a $7 billion IMF bailout program. Recent interest rate cuts have helped slow inflation to 11.1% in July, and the current account remains under control. The central bank's focus will shift from monetary policy to growth and job creation, with the mandate to ensure price and financial stability.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, to curb soaring inflation.

site_title: Massive fires to hurt sugar output in top supplier Brazil
summary: Massive fires in Brazil's sugarcane fields have affected 60,000 hectares of crop area, potentially impacting global sugar supply and prices. The fires, which included as many as 2,000 outbreaks over the weekend, also damaged sprouting cane. Industry experts predict the consequences could be more severe than a major frost in 2021, with prices potentially rising due to reduced supply.

images.alt_text: India government wants to make sure there is enough sugar for the local market at reasonable prices, and on using more cane to produce ethanol.
StoneX has projected that global sugar production exceed total demand by 3.9 million tonnes, up from 3.4 million tonnes seen in February.
Thai millers have produced 4.9 million tonnes of the sweetener from about 49.6 million tonnes of cane crushed since the season started on Dec 10.

site_title: Vietnam party chief Lam relinquishes presidency amid reshuffle
summary: Vietnam's Communist Party chief, To Lam, will relinquish his role as president amid a reshuffle following the death of his predecessor, Nguyen Phu Trong. The National Assembly accepted the resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Le Minh Khai for violating anti-corruption rules, and Lam will step away from the presidency later this year. The reshuffle aims to create stability ahead of the party's congress in 2026, with a "four pillars" structure separating leaders holding key positions of government.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is targeting 6.5 per cent GDP growth this year.
The nomination comes two weeks after the death of General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam’s most powerful leader in decades.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 27)
summary: Lendlease and Warburg Pincus acquired a S$1.6 billion portfolio of industrial assets in Singapore from entities related to Blackstone and Lim Chap Huat, Soilbuild's executive chairman. Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is reviewing the local equity market, prioritizing new listings, liquidity, and regulatory framework. The MAS also announced that Singapore's re-employment support will begin in April 2025 for involuntarily unemployed workers with a previous average monthly salary of up to S$5,000.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on caution ahead of Nvidia results, economic data
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Tuesday, August 27, 2024, due to caution ahead of Nvidia's results and economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 54.24 points, or 0.13%, to 41,186.28. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 opening 13.95 points, or 0.25%, lower, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 70.24 points, or 0.40%. The market remains cautious ahead of the economic data and Nvidia's quarterly results.

site_title: Toyota and BMW to upgrade fuel cell alliance, Nikkei Asia says
summary: Toyota and BMW are set to upgrade their partnership in fuel cell vehicles, with a memorandum of understanding to be signed next week. The two automakers have been working together for several years to offer a zero-emission mobility solution. An official announcement is expected on September 5. The partnership aims to advance fuel cell technology, although both companies declined to comment on the details of the agreement.

site_title: Starmer signals pain and ‘unpopular decisions’ to fix Britain
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer warned that his government will have to take "unpopular decisions" to fix Britain's problems, including "painful" taxes on the wealthy and spending cuts. In a speech, Starmer said that the country's economic and societal issues, inherited from the previous Conservative government, would only worsen before getting better. He promised to rebuild British society, but acknowledged that short-term pain would be necessary for long-term gains, stating "things will get worse before we get better."

images.alt_text: The retail sector has been hit hard by the squeeze on the spending power of many households while poor weather in recent months has also hurt sales.

The S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers’ Index leapt to 55.3 – the highest since May 2022 – from 52.2 in June.

site_title: A fresh approach to assess macroeconomic risk
summary: A new framework for assessing macroeconomic risk is proposed by Philipp Carlsson-Szlezak and Paul Swartz, reframing good macro analysis as a process for developing better judgment about the economic environment, rather than specific forecasts. The authors suggest that a healthy scepticism and willingness to practise economic eclecticism are necessary to assess true macro risk, focusing on the broad picture and trends rather than doom-mongering. The framework assesses risks in three core areas: the real economy, the financial setting, and the global environment, providing an alternative perspective to traditional macro thinking and offering insights for investment professionals.

images.alt_text: Regardless of the asset class, it is important that investing is based on the fundamental of value-creation, and not speculation or activism.
Doubts over the possibility of securing an Israel-Hamas ceasefire grow. There is also the looming possibility of a wider regional war.

site_title: Malaysia must be ready to hike rates to curb prices, OECD says
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has warned Malaysia that it may need to hike interest rates to curb prices, citing significant risks in the country's inflation trajectory. The OECD notes that Malaysia's inflation has stabilised around 2% but is vulnerable to second-round effects from higher energy prices, particularly with the planned removal of subsidies. The report advises the country to be prepared for potential monetary policy tightening, unlike its peers in the region.

images.alt_text: IFC has invested in three projects in Malaysia since it set up an office in the country last year.

site_title: Sony, India’s Zee settle dispute over scrapped US$10 billion merger
summary: Zee Entertainment Enterprises and Sony's Indian unit have agreed to withdraw all claims against each other related to their failed $10 billion merger. The companies scrapped the deal in January due to Zee's failure to meet financial terms. Zee had initially sought to force the deal through at India's national company tribunal but withdrew its application in April to pursue claims in arbitration at the Singapore International Arbitration Center. As part of the non-cash settlement, both parties will have no continuing obligations or liabilities to each other.

images.alt_text: Sony and Zee logos are seen in this illustration taken January 30, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: What Shein’s supply chain says about the future of Chinese manufacturing
summary: Shein, a Chinese-founded fast-fashion startup, is facing labor shortages in its supply chain as the country's working-age population ages and young workers opt for lower-paid service sector jobs. Despite paying workers between $1,280 and $2,000 monthly, Shein's low prices are attributed to labor costs rising in China. The company is exploring alternative manufacturing destinations, including Brazil and Turkey, but faces challenges in maintaining efficiency. China's demographic crisis poses a significant risk to its manufacturing sector, with some factory managers expressing concerns about hiring skilled workers and investing in automation.

images.alt_text: Shein is now grappling with EU rules designed to clamp down on illegal and harmful content online.
Shein, which is planning to go public in Britain, taps a network of largely China-based suppliers which take small initial orders and scale up based on demand.

site_title: SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support starts April 2025, for locals with previous wage of S$5,000 and below
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme will start in April 2025, providing up to S$6,000 over six months to involuntarily unemployed workers with a previous average monthly salary of S$5,000 or below. The scheme is initially restricted to Singaporean citizens aged 21 and above, but will be extended to permanent residents in 2026. The support will taper off after three years, and workers will not be eligible again. This marks a "paradigm shift" for the government, according to Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.

images.alt_text: To receive support under the new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, workers must go for training, career coaching and job-matching services.

Associate Professor Walter Theseira, a labour economist from the Singapore University of Social Sciences, said: “The scheme by quantum is targeted more at lower income workers, as the payout amounts are quite low by international standards for replacement-income type schemes for middle income workers.”

site_title: Malaysia’s Muhyiddin charged with sedition over remark against king
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin was charged with sedition over a comment he made about the former king, potentially facing up to three years in jail and a maximum RM5,000 fine. The charge is a fresh blow to Muhyiddin's Perikatan Nasional bloc, which lost a by-election in Kelantan on August 17. Muhyiddin has also faced accusations of money-laundering and abuse of power, and his pro-Malay coalition has been losing ground following a switch of allegiance by six lawmakers.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands’ charity festival celebrates 10th anniversary, raises S$4.6 million
summary: Marina Bay Sands' charity festival, now in its 10th year, raised S$4.6 million from its Aug 23-25 event at Event Plaza. The festival, featuring local performances and food stalls, has raised over S$39 million since 2013. The funds will support various charities.

images.alt_text: The Sands Innovative Arts Fund is part of MBS’ community engagement programme, Sands Cares, of which support for the arts is a key pillar.
Nicholas Ionides, MBS’ vice-president of communications and corporate affairs, with a senior at the reunion lunch organised by MBS and Care Corner.

site_title: ECB can gradually cut rates but jury still out on September, Knot says
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Klaas Knot expressed cautious optimism about a potential interest rate cut in September, citing a disinflation path converging to 2% inflation by the end of 2025. However, Knot emphasized that a decision will depend on full data and information, and a more definitive stance will be taken in subsequent meetings. Markets have already priced in a cut for September and at least one more move later this year, with inflation rising to 2.6% in July.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank (ECB) board member Klaas Knot appears at a Dutch parliamentary hearing in The Hague, Netherlands September 23, 2019 REUTERS/Eva Plevier/File Photo

site_title: How a ‘Cash++’ portfolio with Asian bonds puts you in good stead
summary: A "Cash++" portfolio with Asian bonds offers above-inflation returns without excessive risk, making it an attractive option for investors. With interest rates expected to ease globally, Singapore's core inflation is forecasted to average 3-4% in 2024 and 2-3% in 2025. To achieve real returns, investors need yields above 3%. A Cash++ portfolio can include three bond solutions: cash-plus, Asian investment-grade, and Asian high-yield bonds. These offer gradual increases in yield and risk, making them suitable for novice investors and those seeking diversification. A sample portfolio with S$100,000 can deliver roughly S$4,600 per annum.

images.alt_text: The Powell pivot – named after Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell – could be relatively more positive for equity markets in Singapore and South-east Asia.

site_title: Warburg, Lendlease buy S$1.6 billion in industrial assets from Blackstone-Soilbuild private Reit
summary: Lendlease and US private equity giant Warburg Pincus have acquired a S$1.6 billion portfolio of industrial assets in Singapore from Blackstone and Lim Chap Huat's Soilbuild Group. The assets, totaling 4.5 million square feet, include business parks and high-tech industrial facilities leased to blue-chip companies in life sciences, technology, and logistics sectors. The acquisition underscores the growing interest in industrial real estate, particularly in the life sciences and R&D market in Asia-Pacific, with investors seeking stable income returns.

images.alt_text: Soilbuild Reit trust scheme court order granted; delisting expected April 14

site_title: Japanese scramble to buy rice as shortages bite
summary: Japan is experiencing a rice shortage due to a combination of factors, including hot weather, water shortages, and increased demand from foreign tourists. The government has warned against panic buying, citing that only half of the usual amount of rice can be procured this summer. Some supermarkets have rationed rice and emptied shelves, with customers limited to buying one bag per person per day. The government assures that the supply shortage will be resolved as a new harvesting season begins, with 40% of the crop available by the end of September.

images.alt_text: Top exporter India’s 5 per cent broken parboiled variety was quoted at US$539-to-US$545 per tonne, down from last week’s US$543-to-US$551.
Farmers prepare for paddy seeding in a rice field in Chainat province, Thailand, August 31, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Microsoft to buy solar power from Singapore public buildings
summary: Microsoft has agreed to buy all the renewable energy exported to the grid from the SolarNova 8 project in Singapore, owned by EDP Renewables. The project, the largest solar project in Singapore, will generate enough energy to power hundreds of public housing and government-owned buildings. This deal aims to help Microsoft inch closer to its climate goals, following a 30% increase in emissions last year. Microsoft will purchase 100% of the energy exported to the grid from the SolarNova 8 project.

site_title: Santander starts a 1.525 billion euro share buyback programme
summary: Santander, the eurozone's second-largest lender, launched a 1.525 billion euro share buyback program as part of its 50% underlying profit target. The buyback program, which started on August 27 and will last until January 3, is part of the bank's distribution policy split between cash dividends and share buybacks. Following the announcement, Santander's shares rose 1.7% to 4.40 euros. The bank booked a record net profit of 6.06 billion euros in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: The job cuts come even as Santander expands its investment bank in the US, with some 200 hires over the past year or so.

site_title: Thai exports post fastest growth in 28 months in July
summary: Thai exports posted their fastest growth in 28 months in July, rising 15.2% from a year earlier, surpassing forecasts. The increase was driven by strong demand in key markets such as the US and China. Imports rose 13.1% in July, leading to a trade deficit of $1.37 billion. Despite this, the commerce ministry maintained its forecast for a small increase in shipments in 2024, with exports expected to grow 1-2%.

images.alt_text: Houses and streets submerged by flood water in the northern province of Phrae, about 540 km from Bangkok, Thailand, Aug 26, 2024.
South-east Asia’s second-largest economy expects overall investment applications to reach 800 billion baht for 2024.
Thailand's jobless rate rose to 1.07 per cent in the April-June quarter from 1.01 per cent in the previous three months.
The Bank of Thailand has left its key interest rate unchanged for a fifth straight meeting on Aug 21.

Thailand's new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, known by her nickname "Ung Ing" and daughter of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, takes part in a press conference in Bangkok on August 16, 2024. site_title: Indonesia reinstates full tax break for property purchases until December
summary: Indonesia has reinstated a full tax break on property purchases worth up to 5 billion rupiah (S$420,454) until December 2024. The government will cover the cost of value-added tax on up to 2 billion rupiah of the purchase price of eligible landed houses or apartments. This move aims to support the purchasing power of the middle class, which has been declining due to the ongoing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. The policy change is expected to boost demand in the property market.

site_title: France's Macron back to square one as left plans protests over political crisis
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron is facing a political crisis as left-wing parties, including Socialists and Greens, refuse to participate in talks to form a government. Macron slammed the door on a potential leftist government, stating it would be immediately removed from power by other lawmakers. The president has embarked on another round of talks with party leaders, but a hung parliament and opposition refusal to form a coalition leave him back to square one. Protests are planned by left-wing supporters.

images.alt_text: France's President Emmanuel Macron has invited the heads of the parties and parliamentary groups represented in the National Assembly for talks with the aim of building the widest and most stable possible majority in the lower house.

site_title: Man in Singapore accused of buying 28,000 gold bars worth over S$1.5 billion with ill-gotten gains
summary: A 63-year-old South Korean man, Kim Taek Hoon, faces over 20 charges for alleged cheating and money laundering in Singapore. He is accused of receiving over S$1.5 billion from South Korea and Japan between 2014 and 2017, using the funds to buy nearly 28,000 gold bars. Kim allegedly concealed the gold bars in shipments of tools, evading customs declarations. He could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to S$500,000 for money laundering charges and up to three years for cheating charges.

images.alt_text: Former Philippines mayor Alice Guo is said to have arrived in Singapore on July 21, after fleeing the archipelago while facing a Senate hearing.

site_title: Asian investors seek higher returns in private markets
summary: Asian investors are shifting their focus to private markets, with global private investor allocation expected to rise from $4 trillion in 2023 to $13 trillion by 2032. To navigate declining returns in public markets, investors are prioritizing diversification, risk management, and income generation in private alternatives, such as data centres, private credit, and global equities. Despite barriers like limited access to private markets and lower risk tolerance, fund selectors are optimistic about the outlook for these asset classes, with 76% of Asian fund buyers underexposed to private markets.

images.alt_text: Justin Gabbani, chief executive officer (Investment Management) at Lendlease.
SeaTown is a wholly owned subsidiary of Temasek’s asset management group, Seviora Holdings.

site_title: South Korean authorities eye budget bump with funds for chips, K-pop
summary: South Korea's government plans to increase its 2025 budget by 3.2% to 677.4 trillion won, the largest increase since 2021. The proposal includes 6.2 trillion won in low-interest loans for semiconductor and battery development, as well as a 2.9 trillion fund for K-pop and nuclear-energy projects. The budget aims to boost economic growth to 2.2% despite slowing momentum in chip exports and a 2.1% GDP growth forecast by the Bank of Korea. The government also plans to support aging demographics and national security with increased spending on parental-leave allowances, mortgage regulations, and advanced weaponry.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Korea held the benchmark interest rate at 3.50 per cent, a decision expected by 38 out of 40 economists surveyed by Reuters.

South Korea relies heavily on imports of energy and raw materials to assemble products destined for shipment overseas.

site_title: Singapore climbs to 13th place in global real estate transparency index
summary: Singapore has risen to 13th place in the JLL Global Real Estate Transparency Index, moving up one spot from last year. The city-state's highly transparent market, driven by its focus on sustainability and digital services, ranks second in Asia after Japan. The UK remains at the top, followed by France and the US. Singapore's advancements are attributed to its Real Estate Industry Transformation Map, which aims to transform the property industry to be future-ready. The index shows increased transparency across most markets, with Asia recording the strongest average transparency improvements since 2022.

site_title: Hilleman-Bharat Biotech partnership brings new oral cholera vaccine to market
summary: Hilleman Laboratories and Bharat Biotech have launched Hillchol, a single-strain oral cholera vaccine, which significantly reduces production costs. The vaccine has been approved for licensure by Bharat Biotech in India and is expected to benefit up to 500 million people in low- and middle-income countries over the next five years. With a lower cost, Hillchol aims to expand access to the vaccine, particularly in areas with increasing cholera outbreaks.

images.alt_text: Some of the major investments secured by Singapore in 2022 came from the manufacturing industry.
DPM Heng Swee Keat, who spoke at the launch event at SGInnovate’s office on Friday, says talent is a critical resource for innovation, especially in deep tech where very specific expertise is needed.

site_title: SpaceX delays launch of first-ever private spacewalk mission
summary: SpaceX has delayed the launch of its Polaris Dawn mission, initially scheduled for August 27, due to a ground-side helium leak. The mission, carrying four private astronauts, including billionaire Jared Isaacman and two SpaceX engineers, aims to perform the world's first commercial spacewalk. The crew will also break spaceflight records, including the farthest humans have flown into space, and conduct research on the effects of space radiation on the human body. The new launch window is set for no earlier than August 28.

site_title: UK banks brace for a lending boom on Labour’s housebuilding goals
summary: The UK's Labour government has announced plans to stimulate growth by increasing homebuilding, prompting banks to prepare for a lending boom. Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner has promised to make it easier for developers to build on the green belt and restore mandatory local housing targets. Banks such as OakNorth Bank and Shawbrook Bank expect an increase in demand for housebuilding loans, driven by the certainty of a pro-building government. The government's plans aim to address the UK's housing shortage, which has been exacerbated by years of missed targets from the previous government.
