site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Tuesday; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.01% to 3,395.75. The market followed Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments signaling a potential September rate cut. Silverlake Axis was the top-traded counter, gaining 21.7% after receiving a voluntary offer to go private. Genting Singapore fell 0.6% and DBS rose 0.2%, while OCBC and UOB were mixed. The US stock market also closed mixed, with the Dow Jones up 0.2% and the Nasdaq down 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Thomson Medical's net profit for H2 is down 2.5 per cent year on year despite higher revenue.

site_title: Chinese embrace icy DIY drinks as competition with cafes heats up
summary: Chinese consumers are embracing DIY ice cups as a cost-effective alternative to cafes, with pre-packaged cups and ingredients flying off shelves. The trend, fueled by a record-breaking heat wave and social media cred, has propelled the popularity of ice cups, with over 13,000 recent posts on Xiaohongshu. Convenience stores, including those offering branded ice cups, are competing with coffee shops, which have seen a decline in sales. The DIY trend adds to the pressure on coffee shops, with some chains opening over 10,000 stores to attract consumers, and others offering competitive coupons and discounts.

images.alt_text: Colin Huang is now the fourth-wealthiest person in China with a net worth of US$35.2 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Thomson Medical, Silverlake Axis, RE&S
summary: Thomson Medical reported a net profit of S$13.4 million for the second half of 2024, down 2.5% year-over-year despite higher revenue. Silverlake Axis received a voluntary offer to go private at S$0.36 per share. RE&S will delist its shares around Oct 17 after its successful privatization offer. Keppel Infrastructure Trust halted trading to raise S$200 million by placing new units.

site_title: Inflation is fading, statistically and politically
summary: US inflation is fading, both statistically and politically, according to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks at the Jackson Hole symposium. Powell noted the decline in the US inflation rate since its peak in 2022, which is good news for Democrats. This development has significant implications, as inflation has been a major issue for the party in recent years. As a result, Powell's speech suggests that inflation is becoming less of a political issue, benefiting the Democratic Party ahead of the upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: A television station displays Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaking at the Kansas City Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole Economic Policy Symposium on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024. Powell said the time has come for the Federal Reserve to cut its key policy rate, affirming expectations that officials will begin lowering borrowing costs next month and making clear his intention to prevent further cooling in the labor market. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Germany confirms economy shrank in Q2
summary: Germany's economy shrank 0.1% in Q2, its second quarter contraction, due to sluggish private consumption and industrial investments. This marks the only major advanced economy to shrink in 2023, with a 4.1% plunge in machinery and equipment investments. Household consumption and exports also fell, as the country battled high inflation, an industrial slowdown, and cooling export demand. The German government expects a modest 0.3% expansion this year, lagging behind the eurozone's 0.8% growth.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People cross a street in front the headquarters building of the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on June 5, 2024, one day before annual ECB press conference on Eurozone monetary policy. The number of ECB staff suffering from burnout has risen steadily in recent years to reach nearly four in ten, according to an internal study seen by AFP on July 11, 2024. The number of employees at the European Central Bank reporting burnout has gone up from 29.7 percent in 2016 to 33.2 percent in 2021, before reaching 38.9 percent in 2024, according to the study commissioned by ECB staff representatives and conducted by the Psy@work consultancy. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: British rock band Oasis to reunite with 2025 tour
summary: British rock band Oasis announced a reunion tour in 2025, 15 years after their initial split. The band, comprising brothers Noel and Liam Gallagher, will perform 14 live shows in various cities, including Cardiff, Manchester, London, Edinburgh, and Dublin. The tour marks the 30th anniversary of their second album "(What's the Story) Morning Glory?", which included hit singles "Don't Look Back in Anger" and "Wonderwall". Tickets will go on sale on Saturday, with the first show scheduled for July 4, 2025.

site_title: Thailand braces for more rain after floods, landslide kill 22
summary: Thailand braces for more tropical rainstorms after 22 people died in flash floods and landslides over the past week, affecting over 33,000 households in 13 provinces since August 16. The flooding has receded, but about 10,000 households remain affected. A tropical depression is expected to bring more rain to northern, northeastern, and southern provinces through Wednesday. The current situation is expected to be less severe than the 2011 disaster, with a higher water dam capacity and a less severe storm forecast. Former leader Thaksin Shinawatra is visiting affected areas.

Thailand's jobless rate rose to 1.07 per cent in the April-June quarter from 1.01 per cent in the previous three months.
The Bank of Thailand has left its key interest rate unchanged for a fifth straight meeting on Aug 21.

site_title: Private homes: Will land bidding and new home buying be subdued?
summary: Sales at new condo launches hovering around 20% plus could spell trouble for developers, with potential financing costs and clawback fees if sales don't meet targets. Condo resale volumes jumped 32% in July, but private home sales excluding executive condos were 44% less than last year. Housing land bids may remain subdued, except for EC plots, which saw a strong response. Reits are expected to see a turn in the second half of the year with interest rate cuts, but investors should remain cautious of underlying fundamentals.

While the market continues to see a steady flow of headline deals, more signs of distress are also surfacing, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Developers are pricing more risk into their land bids or are staying away completely, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Thousands of workers at UK retailer Next win equal pay case
summary: A UK tribunal has ruled in favor of over 3,500 current and former Next employees, winning a six-year battle for equal pay. The ruling finds Next failed to show that lower pay rates for sales consultants, predominantly women, were not sex discrimination. Workers are entitled to back pay of over £30 million, with the ruling expected to encourage similar cases at other companies. The tribunal's decision highlights the need for equal pay legislation to address discriminatory practices.

site_title: New listings, liquidity, regulatory framework, governance among priorities for MAS review of equities market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up an Equities Market Review Group to recommend measures for the development of local equity markets. The group, chaired by Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat, has identified priority areas as new listings, liquidity, regulatory framework, and governance. Recommendations will be announced in phases to facilitate prompt rollout. The review aims to improve the overall health and competitiveness of Singapore's equity market.

site_title: Aviation regulators press for global efforts to tackle turbulence
summary: Aviation regulators are pressing for global efforts to tackle turbulence, citing recent incidents that have led to injuries and fatalities. Countries such as Japan, Korea, and Singapore are seeking to add turbulence as a category in the International Civil Aviation Organization's (ICAO) 2026 Global Aviation Safety Plan. Turbulence is the leading cause of accidents, accounting for 40% of all accidents involving large aircraft in scheduled commercial operations. Regulators aim to improve real-time coordination of weather and turbulence data sharing across borders to reduce the risk of turbulence-related incidents.

At least seven people were injured Monday during the flight prompting an emergency landing in Brazil, the airline said. site_title: Top White House official due in Beijing as China faces off against US allies
summary: US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan is set to meet China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Beijing, amid tense security rows with US allies Japan and the Philippines. China has been accused of violating Japan's airspace and being a major disruptor in South-east Asia. Sullivan will discuss the South China Sea, Taiwan, and China's support for Russia with Wang, while emphasizing the US commitment to managing competition responsibly and preventing conflict. The trip comes ahead of US elections in November and follows four previous meetings between Sullivan and Wang over the last year and a half.

site_title: Rothschild to boost India ECM, debt businesses as deals heat up
summary: Rothschild plans to expand its equity capital markets (ECM) advisory business in India, with a focus on initial public offerings (IPOs), debt advisory services, and mergers and acquisitions (M&A) advisory. The firm aims to double its existing team in India and pool resources from London, Dubai, and Singapore. India's dealmaking activity has gained momentum, with $6.4 billion raised through IPOs this year, driven by multinational companies seeking to unlock value from local operations. Rothschild also plans to start a debt advisory business to support Indian companies raising debt for growth.

images.alt_text: The firm has shrunk in North America in recent months as deal volume fell.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust proposes private placement to raise at least S$200 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) proposes a private placement to raise at least S$200 million, with proceeds used to partially repay a S$391.8 million term loan facility for the acquisition of Australia's Ventura Motors. About 96.6% of the proceeds will go towards repaying the loan, while S$5.4 million will be used for fees and expenses. The remaining proceeds will be used to repay existing debts. The placement is expected to close on August 28 with an issue price to be announced.

site_title: BYD to use Huawei’s advanced autonomous driving system in off-road EVs
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle giant, has signed an agreement with Huawei to use its advanced autonomous driving system, Qiankun intelligent driving system, in its off-road Fangchengbao EVs. The Bao 8 SUV under the Fangchengbao lineup will be the first BYD model to feature Huawei's system and is expected to go on sale later this year. This partnership aims to boost BYD's premium brand sales and improve profitability, as its premium brands of Denza, Fangchengbao, and Yangwang account for only 5% of its total sales.

site_title: UN’s Guterres issues ‘global SOS’ over fast-rising Pacific ocean
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has issued a "global SOS" over the rapid rise of the Pacific Ocean, warning of a worldwide catastrophe threatening Pacific islands. Research shows the region's seas are rising 15 cm in 30 years, nearly three times the global average. Low-lying islands, such as Tuvalu, face almost complete destruction within 30 years, while other sites, like Kiribati and Cook Islands, are rising at a similar rate to the global average. Guterres calls for urgent action to reduce emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change on Pacific island nations.

site_title: Silverlake Axis jumps 23.3% on privatisation offer
summary: Silverlake Axis' share price surged 23.3% to S$0.37 after the company announced a voluntary unconditional offer to privatize at S$0.36 in cash per share, following a trading halt on Monday. Shareholders can also opt for a combination of cash and a new redeemable preference share. The company's controlling shareholder, Zezz FundQ, is offering to buy out the shares at a valuation of about S$234.5 million.

The enterprise technology company says that Silverlake’s independent directors are of the view that the proposal should be explored in line with the company’s longer-term expansion and growth.
Andrew Tan, CEO of Silverlake Axis, would relinquish his role in January 2025.

site_title: ‘A box of surprises’: A Rotterdam flat that’s only 74 sq ft
summary: Beatriz Ramo López de Angulo and Bernd Upmeyer, a Spanish and German-born architect couple, designed a 74-square-foot apartment in Rotterdam as a tribute to Le Corbusier's 1952 Cabanon, a 144-square-foot tiny house. The Rotterdam apartment features four distinct areas with luxurious materials and finishes, including a saffron "living room," a chartreuse sleeping loft, a sky-blue shower room, and a black marble spa. The couple's goal was to maximize space, not reduce it, and create a sense of greater space despite the tiny size.

images.alt_text: Beatriz Ramo L—pez de Angulo, left, and  Bernd Upmeyer the tiny apartment they designed in Rotterdam, Netherlands, in July 2024. This Cabanon, which is on the top floor of a 1950s mixed-use building, is 74 square feet, half the size of the inspiration. (Ossip van Duivenbode/The New York Times)
The original living area is now an open kitchen and dining space.

site_title: Skydance set to seal Paramount merger after Bronfman drops out
summary: Skydance Media, led by producer David Ellison, is set to acquire Paramount Global after Seagram heir Edgar Bronfman Jr dropped out of the bidding process. The deal, expected to be completed in the first half of 2025, aims to provide a fresh start for the beleaguered studio, which is struggling with debt and declining audiences. Paramount had agreed to a merger with Skydance in 2024, but Bronfman's group had submitted a $6 billion proposal, challenging Skydance's offer of over $8 billion.

images.alt_text: Potential buyers may be better positioned after the US presidential election in November, when the outlook on the regulatory environment is expected to be more clear.
Edgar Bronfman is also looking to team Paramount up with a company that can take it to a higher level in terms of licensing its many brands for consumer products.
Bronfman is expected to argue that his proposal is superior because it will result in less dilution for Paramount’s non-Redstone shareholders.
Paramount agreed to combine with Skydance last month.
Paramount, which owns networks like CBS, MTV and Comedy Central, aims to reduce annual costs by US$500 million and return to profitable growth ahead of its merger with David Ellison’s Skydance Media.

site_title: Indonesian palm oil output set to fall on dry weather, old trees
summary: Indonesia's palm oil output is expected to fall 0-5% this year due to dry weather and aging trees, which may tighten global supply and keep prices elevated. The country, the world's top palm oil producer, is forecast to produce 52-53 million tonnes, a 3-5% decrease from last year. Drought and low rainfall have caused trees to produce fewer fruit bunches, and many plantations are over 25 years old, requiring replenishment to boost output. This may impact the global supply of palm oil, used in various products, and keep prices stable.

images.alt_text: “We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.
The plan raised objections from conservation groups fearful for the welfare of the orangutans that are critically endangered.
The world’s biggest palm oil maker currently has a mandatory 35 per cent blend of palm oil-based fuel in biodiesel .

site_title: Apple to hold ‘Glowtime’ iPhone 16 launch event on Sep 9
summary: Apple will hold a launch event for the iPhone 16 on September 9, featuring larger screens on Pro models, new camera features, and Apple Intelligence, a suite of AI features available on all new iPhone models. The event will also showcase revamped AirPods, a new Apple Watch, and a plastic-made Watch SE. The announcement comes ahead of the iPhone's expected release around September 20, with a potential boost in sales when Apple Intelligence is released in the iOS 18.1 operating system in October.

images.alt_text: Apple could ultimately lose billions of dollars because of the Google case if the judge bans the search juggernaut from paying the iPhone maker and others to be the default search engine on their devices.
The new launches come as Apple forecasts more gains, betting on AI to attract buyers.
The change comes as Apple loosens its grip on devices in the EU due to the bloc’s landmark new digital rules.

Brian Rakowski, vice president of product management for Pixel at Alphabet Inc., during the Made By Google launch event in Mountain View, California, US, on Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024. Alphabet Inc.'s Google is rolling out upgraded smartphones, watches and earbuds, aiming to take on Apple Inc. and Samsung Electronics Co. and offer more ways to use artificial intelligence. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
The shift into robotics is part of a broader effort to boost sales and capitalise on Apple Intelligence, a suite of AI technology that’s coming to the iPhone, iPad and Mac this year.

site_title: PDD’s US$55 billion stock crash sends warning on Chinese economy
summary: PDD Holdings, the parent company of e-commerce platform Temu, reported a 29% stock crash, wiping out $55 billion in market value, due to a gloomy outlook on the Chinese economy. The company's revenue missed estimates, and CEO Chen Lei stated that revenue and profits will "inevitably" decline as economic growth slows. This warning comes amidst a series of red flags about the Chinese economy, including weakened consumer demand, intense price wars, and a decline in job and salary growth. The company's stock plunge marks a significant shift in investor sentiment, highlighting concerns about China's consumer market.

images.alt_text: Temu logo is seen in this illustration taken August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: China’s budget spending drops as land sales see record fall
summary: China's budget spending declined 2% in the first seven months of the year, with land sales revenue from local governments plummeting 40% year-over-year. The decrease in land-related expenditure and total revenue led to a broader fiscal gap of 3.8 trillion yuan. Economists urge Beijing to add stimulus to support the US$17 trillion economy, citing a severe housing downturn and gloomy job market. Calls for a higher deficit ceiling are growing, with some proposing using government bonds to fund subsidies for less well-off households and address local debt risks.

images.alt_text: A revival of demand in China, the world’s top consumer of the precious metal, could further support the rally in global gold prices, which hit a record high last week.

People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)
Long-term relief for the consumer is unlikely so long as China’s real estate slump squeezes household budgets.

site_title: BYD says fate of lithium project is in hands of Chile government
summary: Chinese automaker BYD says the timing of its lithium project in Chile remains uncertain as negotiations with the Chilean government continue. BYD was granted preferential prices for lithium carbonate in April 2023, but terms are yet to be settled, with production expected to be delayed. The project, which aims to make lithium iron phosphate for cathodes, would give BYD a foothold in the world's largest lithium reserves. BYD executive vice-president Stella Li stated that the project's start is now in the hands of the Chilean government, with the company seeking a "good deal."

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat after rally, oil dips but Middle East worries linger
summary: Asian markets retreated on Tuesday, following a lackluster day on Wall Street, as traders took a breather after a recent rally fueled by bets on a US interest rate cut. Oil prices eased from a surge caused by Middle East tensions, but geopolitical concerns continued to weigh on sentiment. The Fed's interest rate cut cycle is expected to be the focus, with key data points and labour market conditions to be watched for any signs of a deterioration in growth and employment.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index was flat at 518.05 at 1600 GMT on Monday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.2 per cent higher at 41,240.52 on Monday.
Silverlake Axis is the most actively traded counter of the morning.

site_title: PetroChina’s strong drilling leads to record first half
summary: PetroChina posted record earnings for the first half of 2024, driven by high drilling output and strong oil prices, which averaged over $83 a barrel. The company's net income rose to 88.6 billion yuan, offsetting a weaker fuel market due to China's sputtering economy and growing electrification of the transport fleet. PetroChina also announced a six billion yuan acquisition of its parent company's electricity unit to jumpstart its clean energy transition and plans to add 30 gigawatts of renewable generation by 2024.

images.alt_text: A PetroChina Co. gas station in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, Aug. 25, 2024. PetroChina is scheduled to release earnings results on Aug. 26. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia says tech firms must comply with its laws amid backlash over social media licensing
summary: Malaysia's Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil has stated that major tech companies must comply with local laws to operate in the country, amid a proposed regulation requiring social media platforms to obtain a license. The Asia Internet Coalition, representing tech giants Google, Meta, and X, has called for a pause on the plan, citing lack of clarity. The government has confirmed it will discuss the regulations with industry groups but has no plans to delay implementation, aimed at tackling rising cybercrime, with the deadline set for January 1, 2025.

images.alt_text: As the US election approaches, Meta expects Russia-backed online deception campaigns to attack political candidates who support Ukraine.
Meta’s move to sunset CrowdTangle also comes amid relaxed content moderation policies and information integrity efforts across social media platforms.
Gen Z is often considered the first generation that grew up with social media.

site_title: S-Reit DPUs weighed down by higher interest rates in H1, but tide to turn in H2
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) saw their distributions and distribution per unit (DPU) decline in the first half of 2024 due to higher interest rates and financing costs. However, positive rental reversions, particularly in the retail sector, helped lift their performance. Analysts expect interest rate cuts to materialize in the second half of 2024, turning the tide for S-Reits. Key sectors such as retail, office, and warehouse are expected to see robust growth momentum, while the hotel sector may experience softer demand.

site_title: Australia caps foreign students in bid to curb migration
summary: Australia will cap foreign students at 270,000 in 2025, with 145,000 for universities and 95,000 for skills training. The move is part of a migration crackdown, aiming to ease concerns over high post-Covid numbers and a housing squeeze. Universities warn that limiting foreign students could damage the lucrative tertiary education industry, potentially leading to 14,000 job losses and A$4.3 billion in economic costs.

images.alt_text: Workers in Australia can now “refuse to monitor, read, or respond to” their employers’ attempts to contact them outside work hours - unless that refusal is deemed “unreasonable”.
Australia’s economy is dominated by services industries and activity in the sector has remained expansionary in the seven months to August.

site_title: Cordlife shareholder Nanjing Xinjiekou calls off plans to buy over remaining shares
summary: Substantial shareholder Nanjing Xinjiekou has called off plans to buy over remaining shares of Cordlife due to risks not aligned with its investment criteria and business strategy. Despite this, Nanjing Xinjiekou remains committed to supporting Cordlife's navigation through challenges and rehabilitation. The decision comes amid ongoing investigations and a suspension of new cord blood collection and processing, resulting in a net loss of S$12.4 million for Cordlife.

images.alt_text: The Association for the Advancement of Blood & Biotherapies has also withdrawn Cordlife’s AABB accreditation for cord blood activities – collection, processing, storage and distribution.
Cordlife says it will disclose more details when it announces its unaudited first half results on or before Aug 14.
Cordlife shares were up 2.8 per cent or S$0.004 to S$0.147 at Monday’s close.
Cordlife has been in the spotlight after it was revealed last November that seven of Cordlife’s 22 storage tanks were exposed to temperatures above acceptable limits.
Cordlife previously said that negative publicity from compromised cord blood samples incident in Singapore affected its fortunes in other markets.
SAC Capital said it was “furthering the discussions” with Nanjing Xinjiekou on the potential offer’s terms.
Cordlife Group reports a net loss of S$11.6 million for the three months ended Mar 31, reversing a net profit of S$1.2 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

site_title: Opposition leader and WP chief Pritam Singh seeks High Court trial over alleged lies to Parliament
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh is seeking a High Court trial for alleged lies to Parliament, citing the case of former transport minister S Iswaran. Singh faces two charges of lying to a parliamentary committee in November 2021 over Raeesah Khan's allegations. He argues that a High Court judge would be better suited to hear the case, citing the unique nature of the allegations and the potential for a more impartial trial. The case is scheduled to take place between Oct 14 and Nov 13, with Deputy Principal District Judge Luke Tan presiding.

images.alt_text: The upcoming general election, due by November 2025, will be Pritam Singh’s second at the helm.
Leader of the Opposition and Workers’ Party chief Pritam Singh is under a police probe in relation to a controversy involving former MP Raeesah Khan lying in Parliament.

site_title: Gold drifts near record high amid Fed rate-cut optimism, geopolitical woes
summary: Gold prices held steady near record highs on Tuesday, supported by safe-haven demand amid rising geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September. Spot gold was flat at $2,515.83 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.2% to $2,551.20. The Fed's San Francisco president, Mary Daly, said the time is upon us to cut interest rates, with a 70% chance of a 25-basis-point reduction. A low interest rate environment boosts gold's appeal as a non-yielding hedge against economic risks.

images.alt_text: A low interest rate environment tends to boost non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: China’s industrial profits climb even as warning signs flash
summary: China's industrial profits rose 4.1% in July, the fastest pace in five months, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This growth follows a 3.6% increase in the previous month, with total profits for the first seven months of 2024 reaching 4.1 trillion yuan. Despite this, weak domestic demand raises concerns about the sustainability of this resilience.

site_title: LG Electronics weighs India IPO to help chase US$75 billion goal
summary: LG Electronics is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its India business to help achieve its goal of reaching US$75 billion in electronics revenue by 2030. CEO William Cho has set a target of growing the electronics business to 100 trillion won annually by 2030, with a focus on enterprise clients and new businesses such as heating and air-conditioning. An IPO in India would coincide with the country's booming stock market, which has seen 189 companies aiming to raise US$5.6 billion this year.

site_title: BHP annual profit rises 2%, says open to higher debt for acquisitions
summary: BHP Group reported a 2% increase in annual underlying profit, driven by record iron ore output and resilient average realized prices, offsetting weak coal prices and the sale of two coal mines. The company is comfortable raising its debt target for potential acquisitions, citing its net operating cash flow of $20.7 billion. BHP's net debt stands at $9.1 billion, within its target range of $5 billion and $15 billion. The company walked away from a $49 billion deal for Anglo American earlier this year.

site_title: Temu owner’s founder loses spot as China’s richest person after 18 days
summary: Colin Huang, founder of e-commerce giant Temu, has lost his spot as China's richest person after just two weeks, with a net worth of $35.2 billion. A slump in PDD Holdings' shares, the parent company of Temu, caused his fortune to drop by $14.1 billion, his largest one-day loss ever. The decline comes after the company reported missed quarterly revenue estimates and warned of slowing sales growth, citing intense competition and external uncertainties.

images.alt_text: PDD reported revenue of 97.06 billion yuan (S$17.8 billion) in the second quarter, compared with analysts’ average estimate of 100 billion yuan.

Colin Huang, 44, has become China’s richest person, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. With a US$48.6 billion fortune, he displaces Zhong Shanshan, the country’s bottled-water king who has held the top spot since April 2021.

site_title: ‘Hard to imagine’ no September rate cut, says Fed official
summary: US Federal Reserve official San Francisco Fed president Mary Daly said it's "hard to imagine" the Fed not cutting interest rates in September, signaling a likely rate cut amid a cooling US labour market. Daly's comments follow Fed chair Jerome Powell's statement that the time has come to start cutting rates, setting the stage for a September rate decision. The Fed's benchmark lending rate has been at a 23-year high, but policymakers believe the dual mandate to control inflation and unemployment has come into better balance, paving the way for a first cut.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s two-year battle against inflation saw rates rise to a quarter-of-a-century high without any appreciable job-market fallout.

site_title: Macron denies Telegram founder’s arrest ‘political’
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron denied any political link to the arrest of Telegram founder Pavel Durov, stating that Durov's arrest was part of an ongoing judicial investigation and not a political decision. Durov, 39, is accused of failing to curb the spread of illegal content on Telegram, which has over 900 million users. He was arrested at a Paris airport and his detention has been extended until Wednesday. Telegram has rejected the accusations, saying Durov has "nothing to hide" and abides by EU laws.

images.alt_text: Pavel Durov, CEO and co-founder of Telegram, is under investigation into alleged offences including fraud, drug trafficking, cyberbullying, organised crime and promotion of terrorism.

Pavel Durov, whose fortune was estimated by Forbes at US$15.5 billion, has said that some governments had sought to pressure him but the app should remain a “neutral platform” and not a “player in geopolitics”.

site_title: Europe: Chip stocks slip, keeping shares muted ahead of data-heavy week
summary: Europe's stock market remained flat on Monday, with the Stoxx 600 index at 518.05, ahead of key economic data releases this week that may influence monetary policy. Semiconductor stocks, particularly those of Nvidia, declined due to second-quarter results. The technology sector led the decline, down 1% as investors await data on EU inflation and other economic indicators. Investors expect a possible 25 basis point rate cut from the European Central Bank on September 12.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.2 per cent higher at 41,240.52 on Monday.

site_title: Australia’s Guzman y Gomez profit beats forecast in first earnings since IPO
summary: Australia's Guzman y Gomez reported a 71% increase in pro forma net profit after tax to A$5.7 million for the 12 months ended June 30, exceeding its prospectus forecast. Full-year global network sales jumped 26% to A$959.7 million, driven by comparable restaurant sales and network expansion. The company's stock has climbed over 60% since its IPO on June 20. Same-store sales growth in the first seven weeks of the current financial year topped expectations at 7.4%.

site_title: Special counsel urges appeals court to revive Trump documents case
summary: Special counsel Jack Smith is urging an appeals court to revive the classified documents case against former US president Donald Trump, which was dismissed by a Trump appointee judge. Trump allegedly kept classified documents at his Mar-a-Lago home, thwarting efforts to retrieve them. Smith argued that the district court's decision to dismiss the case is at odds with a long-standing tradition of special-counsel appointments and could raise questions about hundreds of other appointments in the Executive Branch. Trump faces 31 counts of "willful retention of national defense information" and other charges, with the case unlikely to be resolved before the November presidential election.

site_title: How Telegram’s founder went from Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to wanted man
summary: Pavel Durov, founder of Telegram, was arrested in France on August 24 as part of an investigation into criminal activity on the platform. Durov, who has been known for his anti-establishment views and commitment to free speech, has faced criticism for Telegram's lax moderation policies, which have attracted terrorists, extremists, and other illicit content. The arrest has sparked a firestorm, with Elon Musk and Edward Snowden among those defending Durov. Telegram claims to abide by EU laws and has denied any wrongdoing. Durov's arrest has raised questions about the intersection of tech and freedom of speech, and the consequences for users of platforms that prioritize security over content moderation.

images.alt_text: Telegram founder Pavel Durov is accused of failing to curb the spread of illegal content on Telegram, which has over 900 million users.

Telegram co-founder Pavel Durov was detained at Le Bourget on Saturday on suspicion of failing to take steps to prevent criminal use of Telegram, according to AFP.

site_title: Rothschild plans to shut Chicago office, move staff to New York
summary: Rothschild is planning to shut its Chicago office and transfer staff to New York, as the firm shrinks its North American footprint amid declining deal volume. The move follows the closure of the Miami office earlier this year. Rothschild will have three US offices left, with New York, Los Angeles, and Boston. The firm's head of Canada left earlier this year, further contributing to the North American contraction.

site_title: Australia’s Coles beats annual profit view on strong supermarket sales
summary: Coles, Australia's second-largest grocer, reported a 2.1% rise in net profit after tax to A$1.13 billion for the year ended June 30, beating analysts' estimates. Strong sales at its supermarkets and improved inventory management drove the profit, with revenue from sales rising 4.3% to A$39.04 billion. The company bolstered its competitive position through private-label offerings and ecommerce sales, and reported a 3.7% increase in supermarkets sales in the first eight weeks of fiscal 2025.

images.alt_text: Above: A Woolworths supermarket in Sydney. Woolworths is set to report its annual results on Wednesday (Aug 28), and Coles, the day before.

site_title: China’s Xpeng aims to manufacture EVs in Europe to blunt tariffs
summary: China's Xpeng aims to manufacture electric vehicles (EVs) in Europe to mitigate the impact of import tariffs, which could reach 36.3% for China-made EVs. The company plans to select a site in the European Union and set up a large-scale data centre to support its intelligent driving features. Xpeng's CEO, He Xiaopeng, stated that localizing production will not impact the company's global plans and that some profits will be reduced due to higher levies. This move follows other Chinese EV makers, such as BYD and Geely, in seeking to minimize the impact of tariffs on their European operations.

images.alt_text: XPeng has seen its expansion plans temporarily throttled by the European Commission’s move to impose tariffs on electric vehicles made in China.
Xpeng has six EVs on the market and is looking to launch “a large number of new models and facelift versions” in the next three years.
Xpeng said it expects to hand over between 29,000 and 32,000 vehicles, an increase of about 25 to 37.9 per cent from the previous year.

site_title: WHO seeks US$135 million as it launches global mpox response plan
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has launched a global response plan to contain the mpox outbreak, which has killed hundreds and infected thousands in Central Africa. The organization is seeking $135 million to fund the plan, which will cover the first six months and focus on improving surveillance, diagnostics, and response strategies. The funds will also help countries plan for animal-to-human transmission and secure vaccines. The WHO has been working to address the shortage of vaccines in Africa, where the disease is endemic, and has hosted talks to develop a pandemic treaty for equitable access to vaccines and treatments.

images.alt_text: The WHO has declared mpox a global public health emergency after an outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo spread to neighbouring countries and a new form of the virus, clade Ib, triggered concerns about the speed of transmission.
There have been more than 15,000 cases of mpox in Congo this year, and at least 550 deaths.

site_title: Temasek’s SeaTown raises over US$1.3 billion for private credit fund
summary: Temasek's SeaTown has raised over US$1.3 billion for its private credit fund, exceeding the total commitments of its predecessor fund. This brings SeaTown's private credit strategy to over US$2.5 billion in assets under management. The fund aims for a mid-teens net return and a double-digit distribution yield to investors. SeaTown is a wholly owned subsidiary of Temasek's asset management group, Seviora Holdings.

images.alt_text: Temasek Logo in the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.
Temasek indirectly owns SeaTown through its asset management group Seviora Holdings.
The fund receives support from existing investors such as Temasek and Temasek Trust.
Carsome Automall in Selangor has a capacity to showcase over 200 cars.

The lifting of Covid-19 restrictions was expected to lead to a decline in the popularity of telehealth services such as Doctor Anywhere's remote Covid testing offering (pictured). This has not turned out to be the case.

site_title: UK shop prices dip for first time in nearly 3 years: survey
summary: UK shop prices have fallen for the first time in nearly 3 years, according to a survey. In August, prices dropped 0.3% compared to the same month in 2023, after a 0.2% increase in July. Non-food goods prices fell 1.5% and food prices rose 2.0%, marking the smallest rise since November 2021. This decline is attributed to summer sales of clothes and household goods.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer (centre) at a wind turbine factory in the north of England, in July, where he announced his government's plans to develop green energy.
The GfK Consumer Confidence Index, Britain’s longest-running gauge of economic morale among members of the public, was steady in August at -13, matching July’s 34-month high.

Official data last week showed British pay grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly two years during the second quarter of 2024 and there was a surprise drop in unemployment, albeit on a survey that is undergoing a major overhaul.
The figures may signal a turning point for official data and other surveys, which have shown that vacancies across the economy have continued to decline.

Rightmove, which says it advertises property for more than nine of every 10 estate agents in the United Kingdom, said buyer enquiries in August were 19 per cent higher than a year earlier, compared with an 11 per cent annual increase in July.

site_title: Crypto firm Abra settles with SEC over unregistered securities
summary: Crypto firm Abra has settled with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) without admitting or denying allegations of selling unregistered securities to consumers and operating as an unregistered investment company. Abra agreed to pay civil penalties, which have yet to be determined, after it was accused of exercising discretion in investments to deliver high yields and operating as an unregistered investment company for two years. The settlement resolves allegations that nearly $500 million in securities were sold to US investors without complying with registration laws.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The seal of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is seen at its headquarters in Washington, D.C., U.S., May 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Singapore and India add semiconductors, air connectivity to high-level ministerial discussions
summary: Singapore and India have added advanced manufacturing and semiconductors, as well as aviation and maritime connectivity, to their high-level ministerial discussions. The second India-Singapore Ministerial Roundtable concluded on August 26, setting the stage for an upcoming official visit to Singapore by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The meeting aimed to enhance bilateral cooperation in areas such as digitalization, the green economy, and skills development, with opportunities for collaboration in sectors like semiconductors and aviation. The two countries have agreed to facilitate investments in renewable energy and standardize rules for a regional instant payments system.

images.alt_text: Both the medical technology and pharmaceuticals segments in the biomedical manufacturing cluster mark declines in July.

site_title: SGX RegCo orders Halcyon Agri to delist
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered Halcyon Agri to delist due to its failure to restore a public float of at least 10% of issued shares. The company was given until August to meet the requirement but failed to do so. As a result, Halcyon Agri must make an exit offer to shareholders, which must be fair and reasonable, and include a cash alternative. The company has one month to provide a proposal for the exit offer.

images.alt_text: Halcyon Agri has narrowed its H1 2024 losses on increased sales to 901,780 metric tonnes of rubber.
Halcyon Agri posted a 20.5 per cent increase in revenue to US$592.9 million in the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2024.
Li Xuetao has relinquished the executive director and CEO positions at Halcyon Agri.
Halcyon rubber processing factory in Palembang, Indonesia. The group reported a widening net loss to US$24.9 million for H2 2023. PHOTO: HALCYON AGRI

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as another Fed official backs rate cuts
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% at 41,240.52, while the S&P 500 fell 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite lost 0.9%. Federal Reserve policymaker Mary Daly expressed support for starting interest rate cuts, saying it's "hard to imagine" not cutting rates in September. This follows comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell, signaling the time has come to adjust monetary policy. Tech stocks declined, with Nvidia and Broadcom finishing the day down 2.3% and 4% respectively.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on August 16, 2024. US stocks edged lower in early trading Friday, as traders looked to lock in gains at the end of a positive week for major Wall Street indices. Around 10 minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1 percent at 40,518.87, and the S&P was 0.1 percent lower at 5,536.08. The Nasdaq slipped 0.2 percent to 17,566.08. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: With Fed’s shift to job market risks done, policy now has to catch up
summary: The Federal Reserve's two-year battle against inflation has ended, with interest rates reaching a quarter-century high without significant job-market fallout. After shifting focus to combating inflation, the Fed now needs to catch up with monetary policy by protecting the job market. Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole conference highlighted the need for a policy shift, which may occur at a slower pace than the rapid rate increases seen in the past. The Fed's next move will be crucial in balancing inflation and job-market concerns.

images.alt_text: The yen’s rebound comes as a relief for the BOJ, which has been under political pressure to stem its falls that hurt consumption by inflating imported food and fuel costs.
Minutes of the Fed’s July meeting show “the vast majority” of participants observe that it would be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting in September.
Gold will continue to grind higher ahead of the September Federal Reserve meeting, says New York-based independent metals trader Tai Wong.

“The upside risks to inflation have diminished. And the downside risks to employment have increased,” Powell said in a highly anticipated speech to the Kansas City Fed’s annual economic conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

site_title: Oil climbs 3% as Libya output cuts further supply concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Monday as Libya's production cuts further fueled supply concerns amid escalating Middle East tensions. Brent crude futures closed at $81.43 a barrel and US crude futures settled at $77.42 a barrel. Libya's eastern-based government announced the closure of all oil fields, while a NOC subsidiary warned of a complete halt to production due to unspecified "protests and pressures." Analysts fear a further drop in Libyan oil production could lead to a risk of production falling to zero, exacerbating market concerns.

images.alt_text: Petronas abandoned its investment due to mounting costs brought about by a broken pipeline that ships two-thirds of South Sudan’s crude through neighbouring Sudan, which has been at war for more than a year.
“We are at B35 now and we will accelerate to B40, B50,” Indonesia president-elect Prabowo Subianto said.
Brent crude futures climbed 37 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$79.39 a barrel by 2300 GMT while US crude futures were at US$75.19 a barrel, up 36 cents, or 0.5 per cent on Monday.

site_title: US core capital goods orders dip in July
summary: US core capital goods orders excluding aircraft dipped 0.1% in July, lower than forecast, following a revised 0.5% increase in June. This suggests a loss of momentum in business spending on equipment into the third quarter. Despite double-digit growth in the second quarter, spending on goods largely held up despite interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. Economists expect the Fed to cut interest rates next month, with a 25 basis points reduction anticipated.

site_title: Value creation in banking ecosystems goes beyond transactional partnerships: DBS’ P’ing Lim
summary: DBS' P'ing Lim, head of ecosystem and cross-border transfers, emphasizes the importance of creating value for every player in a banking ecosystem. She notes that partnerships go beyond transactional relationships and should benefit all parties involved. Lim's role involves integrating banking services into customers' lives, and she aims to make financial services accessible to everyone, regardless of their background or wealth level. She highlights the need for strategic partnerships and the use of alternative data to underwrite customers and offer financing.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings saw fees from wealth management jump 37 per cent to S$518 million, faster than the growth from lending income.
Piyush Gupta expects DBS’ total income growth for this year to be a high single digit, even after factoring in rate cuts, based on the strong run it has had in the first half of the year.
Tan Su Shan, DBS’ group head of institutional banking and newly appointed deputy CEO, will take over the helm from CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025.

site_title: Reining in the cost of unwanted calories, sugar and salt
summary: Singapore is extending its Nutri-Grade labelling system to four more product groups, aiming to increase transparency on sodium and saturated fat levels in packaged foods. The move aims to encourage healthier choices among consumers, with over two-thirds of pre-packaged drinks now graded A or B. However, experts suggest that additional measures may be needed to improve overall diet quality, and mandatory nutrition labelling for all packaged food items could be considered to provide more detailed information to consumers.

images.alt_text: Some beverage manufacturers have reformulated their existing drink recipes and rolled out zero and low sugar options for sale ahead of time.

site_title: South-east Asian currencies hit fresh highs against US dollar post-Powell speech; strength set to last till year-end
summary: South-east Asian currencies, including the ringgit, Singapore dollar, baht, and rupiah, have reached fresh highs against the US dollar following US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's dovish remarks, which solidified market expectations of a September rate cut. The currencies are expected to maintain their strength into the year-end, with economists predicting a gradual strengthening trend. The rupiah is on track to erase its losses for the year, while the ringgit could close the year as one of the region's strongest performers, with some analysts forecasting a range of 4.4 to 4.45 per US dollar.

images.alt_text: The rupiah currency weakened on Tuesday (April 16) to its lowest point in four years against the US dollar.
Ringgit, despite depreciating 0.55 per cent for the past 5 days, is not the worst performing currency in the Asia region.

The Indonesian rupiah has strengthened on the back of favourable domestic conditions and global sentiment. Economists expect further relief for Asean currencies after the US Federal Reserve cuts rates in September.
The city-state’s stock market is also a big beneficiary of a strong local currency.

site_title: Paramount explores sale of 12 local TV stations
summary: Paramount Global is exploring the sale of 12 local TV stations, including independent stations in New York, Philadelphia, and other markets, for $500 million to $1 billion. The move is part of the company's asset disposals to raise cash amid the ongoing takeover saga. Potential buyers may be better positioned after the US presidential election in November, when the regulatory environment is expected to be clearer. Deliberations are at a preliminary stage, and any deal could take several months to materialize.

images.alt_text: Edgar Bronfman is also looking to team Paramount up with a company that can take it to a higher level in terms of licensing its many brands for consumer products.
Bronfman is expected to argue that his proposal is superior because it will result in less dilution for Paramount’s non-Redstone shareholders.
Paramount agreed to combine with Skydance last month.
Paramount, which owns networks like CBS, MTV and Comedy Central, aims to reduce annual costs by US$500 million and return to profitable growth ahead of its merger with David Ellison’s Skydance Media.

site_title: Telehealth abuse may go beyond MaNaDr clinic; more can be done to weed out errant doctors
summary: A Singaporean health ministry has found evidence of telehealth provider MaNaDr Clinic engaging in "clinically and ethically inappropriate practices" after discovering over 100,000 one-minute or less teleconsultations in a sampled month, resulting in numerous medical certificates issued to patients. The ministry has ordered MaNaDr to stop providing teleconsultations until further notice. Experts say that such short consultations are not feasible and that more stringent regulations and data analytics are needed to prevent similar cases of misconduct in the telehealth industry.

images.alt_text: Private pods at Doctor Anywhere's new health screening facility, DA Orchard MedSuites.
Leaveism is characterised by using leave for MC, working while on leave, and taking work home.

site_title: Tech giants urge Malaysia to pause plan for social media platform licences
summary: Tech giants, including Google, Meta, and X, urge Malaysia to pause its plan to require social media platforms with over 8 million users to apply for a licence by January 1, 2025, citing the "unworkable" licensing regime and lack of clarity. The Asia Internet Coalition, which includes Apple, Amazon, and Grab, expressed concern that the regulations could stifle innovation and harm Malaysia's growing digital economy. The group requested a pause to allow for further public consultations and assessment of the plan's implications.

site_title: Thomson Medical’s H2 net profit dips 2.5% to S$13.4 million
summary: Thomson Medical Group reported a 2.5% dip in H2 net profit to S$13.4 million, driven by a 6.6% increase in revenue to S$183 million. The healthcare provider cited demographic shifts and evolving needs as reasons for the sector's resilience despite economic volatility. Revenue growth was partially offset by project termination and lower patient loads. The company expects to leverage opportunities in Southeast Asia, focusing on complex procedures and expanding its doctor network.

images.alt_text: Embryo storage area at Thomson Fertility Centre.  Thomson Medical notes a 70 per cent increase in the number of IVF cycles done in Singapore over the last 10 years.
The centre is located at FV Hospital in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, and is owned by Thomson Medical.
There is a need for diverse housing options for seniors, says Bernie Poh, chief executive officer of Allium Healthcare.

Analysts say the increase in salaries to help retain current staff could be less than what these private healthcare players may have to fork out to bring in new nurses and give them the relevant training.
This is the third time Thomson Medical has submitted an application to SGX seeking a grace period to restore its public float.

site_title: Qatar strikes another 15-year LNG supply deal with Kuwait
summary: Qatar has agreed to a 15-year LNG supply deal with Kuwait, starting in January 2025, with deliveries of 3 million tons per annum. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, will help Kuwait meet rising power generation demand, particularly during summer months when air conditioning systems consume large amounts of gas. The agreement may include LNG from Qatar's North Field expansion project and existing output, playing a pivotal role in electricity generation in Kuwait.

images.alt_text: QatarEnergy CEO and Qatar's Minister of Energy Saad al-Kaabi said he sees a big future demand for LNG and Qatar would continue to assess its gas reservoirs for possible future growth.

site_title: Canada to hit China with tariffs on electric vehicles, steel
summary: Canada will impose a 100% levy on electric vehicles made in China, effective October 1, and a 25% levy on steel and aluminium, effective October 15. The move aims to protect domestic manufacturers and workers, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau citing unfair advantages given to Chinese companies. The tariffs will also include certain hybrid passenger automobiles, trucks, buses, and delivery vans. The government will review the levies within a year and has launched a 30-day consultation on other sectors, including batteries and critical minerals.

images.alt_text: The Commission said it still believed Chinese EV production has benefited from extensive subsidies and proposed duties of up to 36.3 per cent on auto companies.

site_title: Rallying the family as the cornerstone of the refreshed Singaporean dream
summary: Singapore's population policy, highlighted during Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's National Day Rally, focuses on creating a family-friendly environment with enhanced parental leave, affordable childcare, and financial support for large families. The country's low fertility rate, below 1.0, poses a demographic challenge, prompting a shift in policy. Immigration remains a national imperative to balance population growth. The government aims to make Singapore an attractive proposition for immigrants while ensuring a strong foundation for the country's future. Changes in mindsets, including promoting shared parental leave and greater equality in marriage, are also essential to addressing ultra-low fertility rates.

images.alt_text: Government funding of parental leave may not fully address operational concerns, say businesses
“Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.
New parents of Singaporean children will get an extra 10 weeks of government-paid leave to share between themselves from Apr 1, 2026.
Women are stereotyped as better-equipped to take on care-giving duties, while men feel the pressure to be breadwinners.

site_title: China’s PDD Holdings misses quarterly revenue estimates
summary: China's PDD Holdings missed quarterly revenue estimates, reporting 97.06 billion yuan (S$17.8 billion) in the second quarter, below analysts' average estimate of 100 billion yuan. The company attributed the decline to reduced consumer spending, a fragile economy, and high unemployment rates. Pinduoduo's shares fell 15% in pre-market trading, while the company's chairman and co-CEO, Chen Lei, vowed to invest heavily in trust and safety and improve the merchant ecosystem, accepting short-term sacrifices for long-term growth.

images.alt_text: The dispute coincides with an aggressive expansion that’s taken the Temu brand around the world.
Total sales across e-commerce platforms were down 7 per cent from the previous year, at 742.8 billion yuan.

The festival, named after the Jun 18 founding date of e-commerce provider JD.com but embraced by all platforms, is China’s second-biggest annual sales event after Singles Day in November and is seen as a key test of household consumption.
Temu, a division of PDD Holdings, has been advertising and discounting heavily to lure customers, who order products directly from China and typically wait a week or more to receive them.

site_title: Pay gap between bosses and ordinary workers widens in Switzerland
summary: The pay gap between top managers and ordinary workers in Switzerland has widened to its highest level since 2019, with top managers earning an average of 143 times more than their lowest-paid employees. The country's largest bank, UBS, had the largest differential, followed by drug maker Novartis and foodmaker Nestle. The Swiss pay gap is attributed to stagnant real wages and rising costs of living, with Unia economist Noemie Zurlinden stating that it cannot be justified that CEOs earn so much more than ordinary workers, and a better redistribution of economic gains is necessary.

images.alt_text: Aside from a slowdown in wage gains, the ECB’s inflation outlook needs corporate profit margins to absorb some of the rise in labour costs and productivity to improve.

Official data last week showed British pay grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly two years during the second quarter of 2024 and there was a surprise drop in unemployment, albeit on a survey that is undergoing a major overhaul.

The median pay for a FTSE-100 company CEO rose 2.2 per cent to £4.19 million last year, think tank the High Pay Centre said, though it added CEO pay growth had slowed compared with the previous two years.

site_title: A little bit of France in Little India
summary: French restaurant Allo, located on Desker Road in Little India, Singapore, has transformed the area's seedy past into a culinary gem. Opened in 2021, Allo offers modern chic French-inspired dishes at affordable prices, with a focus on using fresh ingredients. The restaurant's owner and head chef, Andrew Seah, aimed to bring French cuisine to the heartlands, and his sous chef, Prince Koshinder, has risen through the ranks from dishwasher to culinary star. Allo's success has proven that good food can conquer location, and the restaurant is poised for future growth.

images.alt_text: Snack chain Old Chang Kee has outlets in Malaysia, Indonesia, Australia and Britain.

Haig Road Putu Piring fifth-generation owner Aisha Hashim with her husband Nizam Iskandar (left); Everyday Tour Company chief executive officer Yeo Pei Shyuan (centre);  YeoMama Batik founder Desleen Yeo (right)
Tai Er is a sauerkraut fish brand that owns six restaurants in Singapore, including one at 313@somerset.
Founded in 2011 by entrepreneur Arrif Ziaudeen, Chope enables diners to make online reservations for restaurants .

site_title: Vietnam replaces more top figures, to elect new president in October
summary: Vietnam's parliament has approved a major reshuffle of senior positions, including the appointment of three new deputy prime ministers, a new environment minister, and a new justice minister. The move paves the way for the election of a new state president in October, following weeks of speculation about when and if current state president To Lam would relinquish the position. This marks the third top-level change in less than two years, amidst a sweeping anti-corruption campaign in the Communist-run country.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Vietnam's President To Lam waits for the arrival of Japan's former prime minister Yoshihide Suga at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi on July 25, 2024. Vietnam's Communist Party named President To Lam as the country's top leader on August 3, after the death of his predecessor two weeks ago. (Photo by LUONG THAI LINH / POOL / AFP)

site_title: US dollar drops against yen but broadly stable after last week's decline
summary: The US dollar declined 0.7% to 143.45 yen, its weakest level since August 5, but remained broadly stable against most other currencies after the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cuts. Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech hinted at a shift in policy, prompting traders to adjust bets on rate cuts. The dollar index edged up to 100.82, while the euro and sterling strengthened slightly, and the yen rose against the Swiss franc.

images.alt_text: For the week, the Canadian dollar was up 1.2 per cent, its biggest weekly advance since December.
Sterling rose 0.21 per cent to US$1.3129, its highest since July 2023. Should it squeeze past the US$1.3143 hit then, the British currency would be at its highest since April 2022.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open higher on increased Sept rate cut bets, Nvidia results on tap
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 25.76 points, or 0.06%, to 41,200.84, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 5.05 points, or 0.09%, at 5,639.66. Markets are focused on Nvidia's earnings report and a key inflation report due later this week, amidst geopolitical tensions in the Middle East. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Durov has 'nothing to hide', says Telegram after France arrest
summary: Pavel Durov, CEO of Telegram, has been detained in France for a second day over alleged offenses including fraud, drug trafficking, and promotion of terrorism. Durov, 39, has denied having anything to hide and claims Telegram abides by EU laws. His detention was extended beyond the initial 96-hour period, and he could be remanded in custody or released. Russian President Vladimir Putin's involvement in Azerbaijan on the same day Durov was arrested has raised questions about potential connections. Fellow tech mogul Elon Musk has defended Durov, calling for his release, while US whistleblower Edward Snowden condemned the arrest as an assault on human rights.

images.alt_text: Pavel Durov, whose fortune was estimated by Forbes at US$15.5 billion, has said that some governments had sought to pressure him but the app should remain a “neutral platform” and not a “player in geopolitics”.

site_title: Last day of trading for RE&S on Aug 30
summary: RE&S Holdings, a Singapore-based food and beverage operator, will cease trading on Aug 30 and be delisted around Oct 17 following its successful privatization offer. The company's shareholders approved the acquisition by Relish Investments, a subsidiary of Southern Capital Group, with 99.98% of votes in favor. Shareholders can opt for a cash payout of S$0.36 or a combination of cash and new shares in the special-purpose vehicle. Trading will be suspended from Sep 2.

site_title: Sven-Goran Eriksson: Urbane Swede who became England’s first foreign boss, dead at 76
summary: Sven-Goran Eriksson, the first foreign manager of England, has died at 76. A successful club manager with titles at Benfica, Lazio, and Manchester City, Eriksson's England teams reached the World Cup quarter-finals in 2002 and 2006, but ultimately failed to progress. His relaxed approach was criticized, particularly in the 2002 World Cup, and he stepped down after five years, citing tabloid scandals and pressure to deliver. Despite controversy, Eriksson is remembered for his empathetic and urbane management style, which earned the loyalty of his players.

images.alt_text: Brehme's goal in the 1990 Fifa World Cup final sealed victory for West Germany over Argentina.

site_title: Germany to donate 100,000 mpox vaccine doses to combat outbreak in Africa
summary: Germany plans to donate 100,000 mpox vaccine doses to combat the outbreak in Africa, particularly in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Burundi, and neighboring countries. The move comes after the World Health Organization declared mpox a global public health emergency due to the spread of a new virus clade Ib. Germany will provide flexible financial resources to the WHO and support its partners in Africa through the GAVI vaccination alliance. The country aims to quickly deliver the vaccines to affected areas.

site_title: Japan’s maverick Kono enters race for next PM
summary: Taro Kono, Japan's digital transformation minister, announced his candidacy for the country's prime minister position, citing his experience in foreign affairs and desire to "help steer the world." He joins ex-defence minister Shigeru Ishiba and former economic security minister Takayuki Kobayashi in the race, which will take place in a key vote next month. Kono's unorthodox style and support for progressive policies have earned him a reputation as a maverick, but he now faces a crowded field and declining public support.

images.alt_text: Shigeru Ishiba will run in Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party leadership election on Sep 27.
The decision follows current Prime Minister Fumio Kishida’s bombshell announcement last week that he won’t seek re-election, after polls showed plummeting approval ratings for his government.

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas sues South Sudan over abandoned oil fields
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas has sued South Sudan over the alleged seizure of its oil fields and assets worth $1.25 billion. Petronas abandoned its investment in the country due to mounting costs caused by a broken pipeline due to the ongoing war in neighboring Sudan. The dispute escalates concerns over human rights abuses and large-scale oil exploitation in South Sudan.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has an abundance of deep saline aquifer reservoirs which presents an opportunity for the development of a CCS hub in South-east Asia.

“The decision was made following a two-year period of divestment initiatives in alignment with Petronas’ long-term investment strategy amid the changing industry environment and accelerated energy transition,” the firm said.
Petronas, whose sole shareholder is the federal government, now has to make concessions.
Petronas has a 25 per cent stake in the LNG Canada plant in Kitimat, British Columbia, on the west coast of Canada.

site_title: UK’s Starmer drives domestic agenda amid global flux
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to deliver his first major speech as PM, amid a volatile international context, particularly with the US presidential election looming. Starmer faces significant domestic challenges, including the aftermath of UK riots, and must navigate a complex relationship with the US under a potential Donald Trump presidency. The UK's international influence is at risk, with Trump's "America First" agenda potentially undermining core UK interests. Meanwhile, Starmer aims to push ahead with his domestic agenda, including reforms to the planning system and the creation of a state-owned green energy company, in an effort to redefine the UK's polity and economy by the 2030s.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping during a meeting on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit in Astana, Kazakhstan July 3, 2024. Sputnik/Pavel Volkov/Pool via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Making gold an essential asset class for portfolios
summary: Gold's unique risk-return characteristics make it a resilient asset class, maintaining real value across diverse macroeconomic landscapes and market disruptions. Over two centuries, gold has withstood inflation, deflation, revolutions, technological evolution, conflicts, and pandemics. Unlike other commodities, gold has limited industrial application and sensitivity to economic activity, making it a reliable hedge against market, macroeconomic, and geopolitical disruptions. With central banks' record net purchases and emerging market buyers, gold's price surge is driven by a shift towards a less accommodative monetary policy regime and increasing government debt worldwide.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee shows gold bullions at Degussa shop in Singapore June 16, 2017. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
A low interest rate environment tends to boost non-yielding bullion’s appeal.

site_title: Can Singapore balance its ambitious AI goals with sustainability?
summary: Singapore is balancing its ambitious AI goals with sustainability by setting a global standard for sustainable data centre development through its Green Data Centre Roadmap. The nation aims to treble its data centre capacity while ensuring high sustainability standards, which is crucial for its position as the leading data centre hub in South-east Asia. Singapore's data centres must meet current needs while being flexible and scalable to accommodate future advancements without compromising energy efficiency, with the government fostering an environment conducive to innovation in sustainable technology through supportive policies.

images.alt_text: CMG20240513-Darwis01 陈渊庄/ 马华卿/ Green Data Centre Roadmap [STTelemedia 1 Loyang Close] Tim Rosenfield, Co-CEO and CoFounder of Sustainable Metal Cloud, in their sustainable AI factory showcasing their product of utilising liquid based (oil) to create the sustainable data centre.

site_title: Din Tai Fung to close 14 China outlets amid weak consumer spending
summary: Taiwanese dumpling chain Din Tai Fung will close 14 stores in mainland China by October 31 due to a business license expiration and disagreement over renewal. The move is attributed to weak consumer spending, with per capita expenditure of 150 yuan (S$27.5) being unsustainable in a market where high-end restaurants offer buffet deals and fast food chains promote cheap deals. This decision follows other restaurants, including fine-dining establishments and Starbucks, scaling back operations in China due to slumping consumer sentiment.

site_title: Millennium shuts 2 trading pods in Asia, managers to leave
summary: Millennium, a global hedge fund, has shut down two index-rebalancing trading pods in Asia, led by portfolio managers Shao Ying and Zachary Corones, who are also leaving the company. The decision comes amid market volatility triggered by a weakening US economic outlook and tighter Japanese monetary policy. The move is part of Millennium's strategy to manage trading risk and post steady returns, even in times of market swings. The assets under management and performance details of the two pods are not immediately clear.

images.alt_text: epa11556314 People walk past a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 20 August 2024. The Nikkei Stock Average gained 674.30 points, or 1.80 percent, to close at 38,062.92.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

The slew of details offers a rare glimpse into deal negotiations between hedge funds, which have become more frequent as industry giants get bigger and seek external firms to run their cash and optimize costs.
The firm’s average trade count jumped 50 per cent last month compared to the second quarter, while volumes surged 83 per cent.

site_title: Man sentenced to four weeks’ jail for false trading in KOP shares
summary: A Singapore court has sentenced Tay Ming Hin, a 17th largest shareholder of Catalist-listed KOP, to four weeks' imprisonment for false trading in the company's shares. Tay bought KOP shares between 2018 and 2019 to artificially inflate the share price, avoiding margin calls in his margin trading accounts. His actions caused the share price to be higher than it would have been on 79 occasions. The conviction was the result of a joint investigation between the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department usually jointly investigate market misconduct offences.
MAS says: “The convictions gave MAS reason to believe that Mr Hoi will not perform financial advisory services honestly.”

site_title: China’s gold demand expected to rebound as economic jitters spur buying
summary: China's gold demand is expected to rebound in coming months as economic uncertainty and concerns about currency weakness drive investment flows. Industry officials say Chinese buyers are adjusting to higher prices, with investment demand picking up again, and discounts narrowing. The rally in global gold prices, which hit a record high last week, could be further supported by China's revival of demand. Gold prices have surged 22% this year, driven by factors such as interest rate cuts, geopolitical tension, and investor buying.

images.alt_text: Gold’s resilience throughout the current rate-hike cycle highlights that numerous factors are capable of impacting movements in the gold price, particularly over the short term.
A low interest rate environment tends to boost non-yielding bullion’s appeal.
