site_title: Apple defence bolstered by Google monopoly ruling in US case
summary: A US federal judge mostly sided with antitrust enforcers in a Google antitrust case, ruling Google's search business is an illegal monopoly. However, the judge threw out a claim that Google thwarted competition by failing to offer key features for rivals' ads. The ruling could bolster Apple's defence in its own antitrust case against the US Justice Department, which claims Apple hampered the development of third-party apps and devices. The judge's decision may not directly impact Apple's case, but could provide a boost to its defence.

images.alt_text: The new launches come as Apple forecasts more gains, betting on AI to attract buyers.
Meta told employees at its Reality Labs division to stop work on the premium mixed-reality headset this week after a product review meeting.
The change comes as Apple loosens its grip on devices in the EU due to the bloc’s landmark new digital rules.

site_title: Top Australian supermarkets’ FY24 earnings expected to show challenging outlook
summary: Australia's top supermarkets, Woolworths and Coles, are expected to report challenging earnings due to a cost-of-living crisis. Consumers are cutting back on spending, with consumers trading down on food items and eating at home more often, leading to reduced sales and profit margins. Analysts predict Coles will fare better than Woolworths, with Coles' underlying earnings margin expected to expand, while Woolworths' is expected to contract. The results will be released on August 27 and 28, respectively, and are closely watched as barometers of the wider economy.

images.alt_text: A man walks through an aisle at a Woolworths Group Ltd. grocery store in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Woolworths is scheduled to release earnings results on Aug. 23. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The supermarkets will face fines of up to 10 per cent of annual turnover for breaches of the code which mainly covers dealings with suppliers.
Woolworths lands rare blow on Coles in Australian grocery price war
Woolworth's bond risk surges as supermarket competition spikes

site_title: IBM to shut China R&D in move affecting 1,000 staff
summary: IBM is shutting its China research division, affecting over 1,000 employees, in a move to focus on serving private enterprises and select multinationals in China. This decision is part of a broader trend of US companies scaling back their ambitions in China due to economic downturn, regulatory scrutiny, and a drive to replace foreign technology. IBM plans to move its Chinese R&D functions to offices elsewhere, including Bangalore, India. This move is seen as part of the growing trend of companies distancing themselves from China amid heightened tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Reits climb post-Jackson Hole speech; STI gains 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by renewed optimism over potential US rate cuts, as indicated by Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments at Jackson Hole. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 8.04 points to 3,396.03, with Reits leading the gainers. The largest gainer was Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, which rose 3%. US stocks are expected to cut rates in September, but Powell noted that data-dependent cuts.

images.alt_text: At the September Fed gathering, officials will also issue a fresh set of economic projections and indicate where they anticipate their policy rate will be at the end of each year through 2026.

Over the long run, the stock market tends to rise because the arc of the economy and the ability of corporations to extract profits both trend upward. But you can count on facing sharp economic and market declines at unpredictable moments.
Minutes of the Fed’s July meeting show “the vast majority” of participants observe that it would be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting in September.

site_title: Dutch hit Uber with 290 million euro fine over driver data
summary: The Dutch data protection watchdog fined Uber 290 million euros for failing to protect driver information, including taxi licenses, location data, and payment details. The regulator stated that Uber's transfers of personal data to US servers were a "serious violation" of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Uber collected sensitive information of European drivers, including criminal and medical data, and failed to use transfer tools, resulting in insufficient data protection. Uber plans to appeal the fine, calling it "flawed" and "extraordinarily unjustified".

images.alt_text: On an adjusted basis, Uber reported core earnings of US$1.60 billion, beating estimates of US$1.51 billion.
Under the multiyear partnership, Uber and BYD will offer drivers lower vehicle pricing and financing.

site_title: From pop-star to policy wonk? Vibes are over, time now for the issues
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris concluded the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, highlighting her personal background and policies. She vowed to achieve change and opportunity for Americans, while also promising not to "go back" to the past. However, critics argue that Harris needs to provide more policy specifics on issues like trade policy, foreign policy, and economic decisions. Her proposed tax cuts and handling of the war in Ukraine and Israel-Hamas conflict remain unclear. Harris has a track record of progressive stances on trade and has repudiated Trump's tariffs, but her approach to tariffs on Chinese goods is expected to be more strategic and targeted.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President and 2024 Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris‘s campaign appears to have energised large and small donors alike - a turnaround from the uncertain period after a disastrous Biden debate performance in June, when major donors reportedly halted fundraising.

Kamala Harris' economic proposals will be the priorities for her first 100 days in the White House, should she be elected president.
Republican presidential nominee and former US President Donald Trump speaks during a visit at the frontier with Mexico in Hereford, Cochise County, Arizona, Aug 22, 2024.

site_title: Leadership takes Centurion from small-cap to mid-cap at the Singapore Corporate Awards , Singapore Corporate Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Centurion Corporation's shares surged to an all-time high after submitting its application to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company aims to become the first property developer to list on the exchange through its Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) structure. Centurion's Reit will focus on acquiring and managing industrial properties in Singapore. The listing is expected to provide the company with access to new capital and enhance its visibility in the market. The submission has received regulatory approval, paving the way for Centurion's Reit to begin trading on the SGX.

site_title: DBS continues to partner ITE in mentorship programme to empower students
summary: DBS Bank has concluded its annual mentorship programme with the Institute of Technical Education (ITE), empowering 245 DBS mentors and 280 ITE students over five months. The programme, launched in 2019, aims to develop essential skills, build confidence, and achieve career goals. Feedback from mentors and mentees has enabled the programme's growth, with plans to deepen DBS' partnership with ITE in the next five to 10 years. The programme's expansion to include mental health topics and its positive impact on mentors have been highlighted, with many mentees reporting increased confidence and motivation.

images.alt_text: Han Kwee Juan (centre), acting chief information officer and Singapore country head, DBS, interacting with participants at the digital literacy workshop
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (left) and  Ambassador Hong Jin-wook (2nd from left) of the Republic of Korea interacting with beneficiaries from Rainbow Centre.

site_title: Norway sovereign wealth fund commits 900 million euros to renewable energy fund
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management (NBIM), has committed 900 million euros to Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners' (CIP) fifth flagship fund, CI V. The fund invests in offshore and onshore wind, solar farms, grid, and distribution, among other renewable energy assets. This investment will provide further opportunities for NBIM to invest in clean energy and support local growth and jobs. The investment will be equally split among North America, Western Europe, and developed countries in the Asia Pacific region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo

site_title: Thailand warns against severe floods that killed 22
summary: Thailand is warning of severe floods that have killed 22 people and injured 19, with 30,000 households affected. The floods, caused by monsoon rains, have also led to a mudslide on Phuket that killed 13 people, including a Russian couple and nine migrant workers from Myanmar. Rescuers are battling to free three workers trapped in a collapsed tunnel in Nakhon Ratchasima. Severe flooding persists in five northern provinces, with a high risk of waters rising in areas near the Chao Phraya River, including the capital Bangkok.

site_title: Condo resale volumes surge 32.2% in July; CCR posts biggest price increase at 2.8%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale volumes surged 32.2% in July, with 1,075 units resold, representing a 21.7% year-over-year increase. Prices rose 0.8% month-over-month and 5.5% from July 2023, with the Core Central Region (CCR) posting the biggest price increase at 2.8%. Analysts attribute the surge to a lower base from the school holiday season and increased demand from HDB upgraders. The upward trend is expected to continue, driven by declining supply and robust demand for resale condos.

images.alt_text: Condo rental volumes are 11.4 per cent higher year on year.
More than half of the resale flats transactions were from non-mature estates.

site_title: Jumbo listings set to boost Japan’s market as sentiment recovers
summary: Japan's stock market is expected to benefit from two jumbo initial public offerings (IPOs), with Tokyo Metro and Kioxia Holdings set to raise around $3.2 billion and $500 million, respectively. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average has rebounded over 20% from its intraday low, driven by improving sentiment and corporate governance reforms. The IPOs come as new share sales in Japan have raised only $1.45 billion this year, down 40% from the same period in 2023.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 26)
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 1.8% year on year in July, reversing from June's 4.3% decline, according to Economic Development Board (EDB) data. This growth was driven by an improvement in the electronics sector. In contrast, the medical technology and pharmaceuticals segments in the biomedical manufacturing cluster marked declines in July.

images.alt_text: Interior of the new Leica Microsystems Singapore manufacturing facility at 15 Tukang Innovation Drive.

site_title: Making a difference via social and sustainability bonds
summary: Investors in social and sustainability bonds can expect stable returns despite global uncertainty, with issuance volumes remaining steady at around $436.9 billion in 2022 and 2023. These bonds raise money for projects benefiting individuals and societies, including access to healthcare, education, and affordable housing, as well as environmental initiatives. Despite interest rate volatility, issuers' conviction in the format has remained, with the European Union Platform for Sustainable Finance publishing a draft social taxonomy to assess the degree of "social-ness" of social bonds.

images.alt_text: Opportunities in Asia include companies in renewable energy, electric vehicles and the corresponding value chain and manufacturers adopting more sustainable practices.

site_title: To whom it may concern: America and Europe need each other
summary: US-Europe relations are crucial for the continent's security and well-being, with the US being a unique and valuable asset to Europe. The transatlantic alliance faces three strategic challenges: handling China, paying defence bills, and upholding Western values. Europe's lack of consultation on China issues, inefficient defence spending, and inconsistent human rights standards are major concerns. The US presidential election outcome will not produce easy solutions, but recommitting to Western values and a coordinated approach to security challenges could help maintain the alliance. Ultimately, Europe needs the US more than ever, and the US needs Europe to be responsible for its security.

images.alt_text: Soldiers of the Eurocorps carrying the EU flag near the headquarters of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.  The writer says that even if Trump fails to win a second term, Europe should invest more in its security to boost capability and self-sufficiency.

site_title: India markets regulator pull up Paytm founder, director on IPO breaches, Moneycontrol reports
summary: India's markets regulator has issued show-cause notices to Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma and other board members over alleged misrepresentation of facts during the firm's 2021 IPO. The regulator questions whether Sharma was accurately classified as an employee, not a large shareholder, who can influence company decisions. This classification issue may have breached SEBI rules. The notices are related to alleged breaches of IPO regulations and will be investigated further.

site_title: PBOC starts bank stress tests to avoid stampede out of bonds
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has initiated stress tests with financial institutions to assess their ability to handle market volatility in Chinese bonds. The tests aim to prevent a "stampede" in long-term government bonds, which could lead to a liquidity crisis and threaten financial stability. The PBOC has been taking measures to cool sentiment, including having state banks sell bonds and gathering financial institutions for meetings, resulting in a collapse in government bond trading. The goal is to ensure banks can cope with large drops in bond prices and maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: Measures such as selling from state banks to drive up yields and repeated regulatory checks on some investors have kept traders on edge and dampened trading activities.
The yuan has erased much of the year’s losses against the US dollar in recent weeks as the latter retreated amid expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts next month.
Investor attention has increasingly focused on the seven-day repo rate to assess monetary policy direction.
The PBOC will strengthen efforts to effectively implement monetary and financial policies that have been introduced this year.

site_title: Sinopec's 1H profit up 2.6% on record output despite slumping product demand
summary: Sinopec, the world's largest oil refiner, reported a 2.6% increase in net profit to 37.1 billion yuan (S$6.78 billion) for the first half of the year, driven by record oil and gas production despite slumping domestic demand for refined fuel and petrochemicals. The company's oil and gas production reached a record high of 257.66 million barrels of oil equivalent, with natural gas production rising 6% to 700.57 billion cubic feet.

images.alt_text: The contract is for Sinopec Oilfield Service to procure and construct the third-phase of the Master Gas System in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: PBOC holds policy rate steady after warning on bond rally
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) held its one-year policy loan rate steady at 2.3% as it seeks to balance stimulating growth with cooling a government-bond buying spree. The central bank withdrew 101 billion yuan from the banking system, indicating a cautious approach to supporting the economy. Economists predict further PBOC easing by year-end, particularly as the Federal Reserve is expected to start rate-cutting in September. The PBOC also injected 471 billion yuan of short-term cash via reverse repurchase agreements to maintain liquidity.

images.alt_text: A stellar rally in Chinese bonds has stalled amid measures to cool sentiment including having state banks sell some bonds and gathering financial institutions for meetings.
Measures such as selling from state banks to drive up yields and repeated regulatory checks on some investors have kept traders on edge and dampened trading activities.
The yuan has erased much of the year’s losses against the US dollar in recent weeks as the latter retreated amid expectations of Federal Reserve rate cuts next month.
Investor attention has increasingly focused on the seven-day repo rate to assess monetary policy direction.

site_title: Saudi perfume maker’s US$188 million IPO sells out in hours
summary: Saudi Arabia-based perfume maker Al Majed for Oud's initial public offering (IPO) of 7.5 million shares sold out in hours, raising up to $188 million. Institutional investors fully subscribed to the $188 million price range of 90-94 riyals per share. The offer period for retail investors will run until September 15. This is part of Saudi Arabia's active equity capital markets, which have seen several IPOs this year, including Saudi Aramco's $12 billion secondary offering.

images.alt_text: The fund is a key vehicle for his efforts to reshape the Saudi economy and wean it off a reliance on oil sales.

Saudi Arabia has taken several steps in recent years to attract foreign investment, including issuing visas specifically for investors, creating special economic zones with lower tax rates, and introducing new laws related to civil transactions and bankruptcy.

site_title: Cheap AI voice bots are suddenly everywhere in India
summary: India is witnessing a surge in the use of AI voice bots, with several startups developing technology that can interact with customers using spoken voice rather than just text. The voice bots are priced at a rupee per minute and have been developed with data from 10 native Indian languages. Companies like Samsung-backed Gnani AI, CoRover AI, and Haloocom Technologies are already deploying voice bots in various applications, including customer service, banking, and train booking. The technology has the potential to reach a billion people in India and may also appeal to users in other countries, with some startups already eyeing international markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening at 3,401.33, driven by expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut next month. Gainers outnumbered losers 127 to 28, with 72.9 million securities worth S$78.3 million changing hands. Notably, Genting Singapore rose 0.6% after a strong trading session. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Revenue rose as hotel occupancy increased year-on-year, from a low base in the first half of 2023.

site_title: China’s Didi in talks to sell smart auto assets to state-backed NavInfo’s unit: sources
summary: China's Didi Global is in talks to sell its smart driving and cockpit assets to state-backed NavInfo's unit, AutoAi, in exchange for a stake in the provider. The deal, valued at approximately 500 million yuan (S$91.5 million), will help Didi focus on its core business after a regulatory crackdown. This sale marks a significant retreat from the ultra-competitive electric vehicle market, following the sale of its EV development business to Xpeng last year. The deal's details are expected to be announced in the coming days.

images.alt_text: The company now aims to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, though the timeline for that remains unclear.
DIDI Global said sales increased to 49.1 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) in the first three months of the year.
Didi’s revenue in Q4 2023 rose 55 per cent from a year earlier, suggesting the company is progressing in its endeavour to reclaim market share lost since 2021.
Andi, the joint venture between DiDi Autonomous Driving and GAC Aion, will roll out a crossover electric sports utility vehicle (SUV) as its inaugural model and will produce the first batch in 2025.

site_title: Japan’s startup index outperforms Topix by most since April
summary: Japan's startup equity gauge, the Tokyo Stock Exchange Growth Market 250 Index, rose 3.4% over the past month, outperforming the broader Topix Index, which declined 1.7%. The smaller index benefits from yen strength, as domestic tech startups and companies with domestic revenues tend to thrive. Investors are shifting focus to small and mid-cap stocks, with some caution remaining on interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Silverlake Axis receives privatisation offer with S$0.36 per share cash option
summary: A group led by Silverlake Axis chairman Goh Peng Ooi has made a voluntary unconditional offer to take the enterprise technology company private at S$0.36 per share, or a combination of S$0.30 per share in cash and one new redeemable preference share. The offer aims to provide shareholders with an opportunity to exit their investment due to low trading liquidity. The offeror expects a cash outlay of approximately S$234.5 million, representing a premium of 28.1% over Silverlake Axis' volume-weighted average price per share.

Silverlake Axis CEO Andrew Tan, who will be stepping down in January 2025. The group's revenue for the first half of FY2024 rose by 1 per cent.

site_title: China robots conference spotlights the changing face of humanoids
summary: China's robotics industry is advancing with the development of humanoid robots, backed by President Xi Jinping's policy of "new productive forces" in technology. Companies like Wisson Technology showcased cheaper and innovative parts, such as 3D-printed plastics, to power robots. However, executives warn that product reliability remains a challenge, with defect rates affecting production volumes. Premier Li Qiang emphasized the importance of the robot industry, highlighting its potential for technical innovation and high-end manufacturing strength, and called for efforts to maintain supply chain stability and progress on the international stage.

site_title: Strong corporate governance is key as companies navigate uncertain times, Singapore Corporate Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The 19th Singapore Corporate Awards recognized outstanding companies and leaders in the country. Winners included listed companies such as DBS Group, United Overseas Bank, and Singapore Exchange. DBS Group took home the top award for Outstanding Company of the Year. Other notable winners included Jardine Matheson Holdings, OCBC Bank, and the leaders of these companies. The awards ceremony honored companies that demonstrated excellence in business, innovation, and leadership. The recognition aims to promote and celebrate the achievements of Singapore's corporate sector, fostering a culture of excellence and entrepreneurship in the country.

site_title: Bitcoin flirts with US$65,000 on Powell pivot, streak of ETF flows
summary: Bitcoin surged 1.2% to $65,030 on Monday, its first time above $65,000 in three weeks, amid signs that the Federal Reserve is set to cut benchmark rates. The largest digital asset advanced 7.4% last week, its sharpest increase since mid-July. A $252 million net inflow into US spot-Bitcoin ETFs on Friday, fueled by Fed Chair Jerome Powell's indication of a potential rate cut, contributed to the price hike. A potential September rate cut may boost Bitcoin, according to industry analysts.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has fallen about 9 per cent in August, lagging a gain of almost 1 per cent in MSCI’s world share index as well as a jump in gold to all-time highs.

site_title: Australia gives millions of workers ‘right to disconnect’
summary: Australia has given millions of workers the legal right to "disconnect" from work outside of hours, allowing them to refuse unreasonable out-of-hours contact from employers. The law, enacted in February, applies to medium-sized and large companies, with smaller companies to be covered from 2025. Unions have welcomed the legislation, saying it helps workers achieve a better work-life balance. However, industry groups have expressed concerns, citing confusion and potential uncertainty for employers and employees.

images.alt_text: Australia’s moderating inflation and an uptick in unemployment is reinforcing bets that the RBA to start reducing rates as soon as this year.

site_title: Subdued bidding for housing sites will persist if sales at new condo launches are tepid
summary: Singapore's housing market is expected to remain subdued due to tepid sales at new condo launches. Developers are cautious in bidding for housing sites, with modest take-up rates at launch spelling trouble. This can lead to higher financing costs, clawback on Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), and reduced profit margins. The Government Land Sales (GLS) programme's confirmed list for H2 includes sites that can collectively yield about 5,050 private homes, drawing healthy participation from developers is crucial to meet demand. Policymakers may need to consider relaxing property cooling measures to boost private housing demand, but careful messaging is required to address the sensitive topic of housing.

site_title: US industry seeks easing of steep Biden-Harris China tariff hikes
summary: The Biden-Harris administration is expected to announce final implementation plans for steep tariff increases on Chinese imports, with some tariffs potentially being reduced, delayed, or abandoned. US industry, including electric vehicle and utility equipment manufacturers, has asked for the higher tariff rates to be eased, citing concerns over increased costs and potential disruptions to supplies. The decision comes amid escalating US-China tensions and a presidential election, with some companies urging the administration to extend tariffs on Chinese steel and other strategic goods.

site_title: Big polluters urged to pay as key Pacific summit opens in Tonga
summary: Pacific islands leaders are pushing for countries to pay for climate-related damage, with Tuvalu declaring "if you pollute, you should pay." At the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in Tonga, leaders are also seeking a homegrown climate adaptation fund and to speed the transition away from oil, gas, and other polluting fuel sources. The US and Australia are expected to play key roles in the discussions, with the US aiming to co-host the COP31 climate conference alongside Pacific neighbors in 2026. The summit also addresses security concerns, including China's growing influence in the region and the New Caledonia crisis.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output returns to growth with 1.8% rise in July, as electronics sector improves
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 1.8% year-over-year in July, reversing the 4.3% decline in June, according to the Economic Development Board (EDB). The electronics sector, led by a 2.8% rise in the computer peripherals and data storage segment, drove the growth. The biomedical manufacturing cluster, however, continued to decline, with output falling 17.4% year-over-year. The improved performance suggests a manufacturing recovery, with economists expecting further growth in the second half of the year.

summary: The 19th Singapore Corporate Awards honored outstanding companies and leaders in the country. Winners included companies such as DBS Group, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. DBS Group took home the top award for Bank of the Year, while OCBC Bank won the award for Best Digital Bank. site_title: German business outlook at lowest since February on weak economy
summary: Germany's business outlook has hit its lowest level since February, according to the Ifo institute, due to an anticipated jump in consumer spending failing to materialize. The expectations gauge dropped to 86.8 in August from a revised 87, and a barometer of current conditions also declined. Ifo president Clemens Fuest stated that the German economy is falling into crisis, with expectations worsening in both manufacturing and services.

site_title: ‘From brown to green’: With Wong at the helm, Sembcorp reaps dividends from sustainability push, Singapore Corporate Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A unit of Sembcorp, a Singapore-based energy company, has delayed the acquisition of a 49 MW hydropower asset in Vietnam. The project, valued at approximately $70 million, was initially scheduled to be completed by 2025. However, the delay is attributed to unforeseen technical issues and regulatory hurdles. Sembcorp has not provided a revised timeline for the project's completion. The company's management is working to resolve the issues, and the acquisition is expected to proceed once the technical and regulatory challenges are addressed. Further updates on the project's status are not available at this time.

site_title: World Bank forecasts Vietnam 2024 GDP growth at 6.1%, warns on bad loans
summary: The World Bank has forecast Vietnam's 2024 GDP growth at 6.1%, lower than the country's target of 6.5%. The forecast warns that banks' asset quality remains a concern, despite expected external recovery and increased public investment. The bank notes that domestic demand is set to firm up in the second half of 2024 as investor and consumer sentiment improves, driven by export growth and a real estate recovery.

site_title: New Zealand to push through law to reverse ban on oil and gas exploration
summary: New Zealand plans to pass a law by the end of the year to reverse a 2018 ban on offshore oil and gas exploration, amid severe energy shortages and rising prices. The ban will be lifted to attract investment to the country's oil and gas sector, with the government also making it easier and cheaper to consent, build and maintain renewable power generation. Energy Minister Simeon Brown cited a 12.5% decline in natural gas production and a nationwide energy shortage as justification for the move.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Marsden Point Oil Refinery, in Northland, New Zealand January 12, 2023. REUTERS/Lucy Craymer/File Photo

site_title: Diversification pays off for CSE Global CEO Lim Boon Kheng , Singapore Corporate Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The 19th Singapore Corporate Awards recognized and honored top companies and leaders in Singapore. The awards ceremony, held on June 29, 2023, acknowledged excellence in various categories, including CEO of the Year, Company of the Year, and Innovation Award. Winners included listed companies such as DBS Group, OCBC Bank, and Singtel. The event aimed to celebrate outstanding achievements and contributions to the Singapore business community. The awards are presented by Corporate Awards, a leading awards organization in Asia, and are considered a prestigious recognition of corporate excellence in Singapore.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Shangri-La Asia, Sembcorp, MPACT, Starhill Global Reit, Oxley, Creative Tech
summary: Shangri-La Asia reported a 28.1% decline in net profit to US$94.5 million for the first half-year, attributed to higher operating costs and a year-on-year decrease in non-operating gains. Sembcorp Industries resumed operations of its power plant in Mandalay, Myanmar, without expecting a significant impact on earnings. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half.

arstatista - Shangri-La Singapore's swimming pool 


Source: Shangri-La Singapore

site_title: Thailand approves Western Digital’s 23.5 billion baht investment project
summary: Thailand has approved a 23.5 billion baht (S$899 million) investment project by Western Digital to expand hard disk production, boosting the Thai economy with 200 billion baht in annual exports and 10,000 new jobs. This investment follows a 16 billion baht expansion by rival Seagate last year, and contributes to Thailand's overall investment applications reaching 800 billion baht for 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Western Digital office building is shown in Irvine, California, U.S., January 24, 2017.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: China economists see weak demand despite expected interest rate cuts
summary: China economists are becoming increasingly pessimistic about the country's domestic demand, with forecasts for annual growth in fixed-asset investment and retail sales being lowered to 4.2% and 4% respectively. Despite expected interest rate cuts, inflation forecasts are also being trimmed, with consumer prices projected to rise 0.5% this year. The challenges for Beijing in stimulating the economy to achieve its 5% growth target are highlighted, with policymakers facing a weak growth momentum and a persisting property slump.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley cut its global oil demand growth forecast for this year to 1.1 million barrels per day (mbpd) from 1.2 mbpd.
People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)

President Xi Jinping gets a lot of economic advice. Beijing is urged – or admonished – to boost consumer spending, rein in exports, curb overcapacity, and clean up local-government debt.

site_title: Indonesia’s incoming leader hopes to implement 50% palm-based biodiesel in 2025
summary: Indonesia's president-elect Prabowo Subianto aims to implement 50% palm oil-based biodiesel by early 2025, cutting fuel imports by $20 billion annually. The move, part of his administration's efforts to reduce fossil fuel emissions, will require biodiesel producers to improve product quality and install new equipment. The industry may need six months to meet the new standards, and the implementation could impact Indonesia's palm oil exports, which have grown 7.6% annually since 2019.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Indonesia's Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto speaks at the second plenary session of the 19th Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore June 11, 2022. REUTERS/Caroline Chia

The plan raised objections from conservation groups fearful for the welfare of the orangutans that are critically endangered.

site_title: Thai employment falls 0.4% yoy in Q2
summary: Thailand's employment rate dropped 0.4% in Q2, reaching 1.07% jobless rate, a rise from 1.01% in the previous quarter. This decline was attributed to lower farm jobs. The drop follows a 0.1% year-on-year decrease in the previous quarter.

site_title: Takeover battle for Taiwan bank heats up with CTBC offer
summary: Taiwan's CTBC Financial Holding has made a US$4 billion offer to acquire a controlling stake in Shin Kong Financial Holding, creating the island's largest financial holding company by assets. The bid surpasses a proposed stock swap offer from rival suitor Taishin Financial Holding. The deal would be the first financial holding transaction in Taiwan since 2022 and would cap a dramatic week for Taiwanese banks seeking to diversify the economy.

images.alt_text: ctbc bank Photographer: Gabriela Bhaskar/Bloomberg
The growth plan underscores how Singapore and its neighbours are benefiting as US-China tensions prompt companies to diversify investments and manufacturing.

site_title: Gold edges higher as Fed backs September easing
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,516.09 per ounce as US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's dovish remarks solidified expectations of an interest rate cut next month. The US dollar hovered near its lowest level in eight months, making gold cheaper for other currency holders. Powell's comments have fully priced in a 64% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut and 36% chance of a 50-basis-point reduction. This boost in gold prices comes as a low interest rate environment tends to increase the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee shows gold bullions at Degussa shop in Singapore June 16, 2017. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Gold will continue to grind higher ahead of the September Federal Reserve meeting, says New York-based independent metals trader Tai Wong.

site_title: China says it’ll raise Taiwan, tariffs with visiting Biden aide
summary: China plans to raise issues related to Taiwan and tariffs during US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan's visit, amid ongoing tensions between the two nations. Beijing will focus on "serious concerns" and "arbitrary measures" taken by the US, including tariffs and unilateral sanctions. Sullivan's trip, scheduled for Tuesday to Thursday, comes months before the US presidential election in November and aims to maintain dialogue despite friction. The US will reiterate its positions on Taiwan and the South China Sea, and Sullivan will not speak for the next administration.

images.alt_text: People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)

site_title: Harris raises US$540 million since launching her presidential campaign
summary: US Vice-President and 2024 Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris has raised US$540 million in little over a month since launching her campaign, surpassing a record for any campaign in history. The funds, which include donations from first-time contributors and joint fundraising committees, have helped energize large and small donors and mobilized a "virtual army of volunteers." Harris's campaign now trails Donald Trump in the polls, but she has erased his previous polling leads and outraised him in key battleground states.

images.alt_text: When wages increase faster than inflation, the cost of grocery items relative to wages declines over time.
Robert F Kennedy Jr abandons his campaign on Friday and joins former President Donald Trump.

site_title: TechCreate Solution Partners with IDEMIA Secure Transactions to Elevate Digital Payments in Cambodia
summary: TechCreate Solution has partnered with IDEMIA Secure Transactions to revolutionize digital payments in Cambodia, advancing financial inclusion and cutting-edge payment solutions. The partnership enables several leading banks to offer sophisticated digital payment options via Google Pay and Host Card Emulation (HCE) wallets for Android users. This collaboration drives digital transformation, enhances financial inclusion, and sets new standards for payment convenience and security, marking a significant milestone in Cambodia's financial technology landscape.

site_title: There are over 170,000 possible Starbucks drinks orders – and it’s killing the company
summary: Starbucks faces difficulties due to the vast number of possible drink combinations, estimated to be over 170,000, and even higher estimates of 300 billion. This complexity has led to increased employee turnover and a struggle to maintain optimal staffing levels. Former CEO Laxman Narasimhan was replaced by Brian Niccol, who aims to simplify the menu and streamline operations. The company is adopting strategies similar to those of Pizza Hut, adding new items and simplifying processes to appeal to a younger crowd and reduce complexity.

images.alt_text: Nestle's Latin America head Laurent Freixe will take over as the company's CEO from Sept 1.
Haidilao International began its international expansion 12 years ago with an outlet in Singapore. It has since added 11 more in the city-state.
FILE PHOTO: A Starbucks drink is seen on a table in New York's Times Square April 21, 2010.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton (UNITED STATES - Tags: FOOD BUSINESS)/File Photo

site_title: First Rolex Rainbow Daytona could fetch US$3.5 million at Nov 8 auction
summary: The first-ever Rolex "Rainbow" Daytona chronograph watch from the 1990s is set to be auctioned off in Geneva on November 8, with a potential sale price of over $3.5 million. The watch features a unique multi-colored sapphire gem-set pattern around its bezel and is believed to be the first of its kind. Only a few Rolex collectors were aware of its existence, making it a rare and significant find. The sale comes at a challenging time for the luxury watch industry, but rare and unique models remain in demand.

images.alt_text: The drop in sales and cuts in production are rippling through the industry in Switzerland.

Rows of second hand luxury watches, including brands by Rolex, Tag Heuer, Maurice Lacroix, Graham, Tudor, Omega, Cartier, Jaeger LeCoultre, and Porsche, are seen in the window display of a store in the Swiss capital of Bern, in Switzerland, on Tuesday, June 30, 2015. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras’s decision to call what is effectively a public vote on Greece’s euro-area membership is also a blow for Switzerland, where the currency’s appreciation is pushing the economy toward a recession. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil climbs on Middle East escalation fears, US rate cut expectations
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures climbing 0.5% to $79.39 a barrel and US crude futures up 0.5% to $75.19 a barrel. The gains were driven by fears of a regional conflagration in the Middle East, including the Gaza conflict, which could disrupt oil supplies. The US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate cuts also boosted the outlook for global economic growth and fuel demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An oil pump is seen operating in the Permian Basin near Midland, Texas, U.S. on May 3, 2017. REUTERS/Ernest Scheyder/File Photo
Morgan Stanley cut its global oil demand growth forecast for this year to 1.1 million barrels per day (mbpd) from 1.2 mbpd.

site_title: Singapore dollar trades around 10-year high on policy outlook
summary: Singapore's currency reached a 10-year high against the US dollar, trading around 1.30 USD, due to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's hawkish policy outlook and the Federal Reserve's expected interest-rate cuts. The Singapore dollar has gained 1.5% this year, the second-best performer in Asia. The government upgraded its growth forecast to 2-3% and an expanding economy may support further currency gains.

site_title: Nomura cuts Chinese stocks to fund Indonesia, Malaysia switch
summary: Nomura analysts have upgraded Malaysian and Indonesian stocks to overweight from neutral, recommending investors pare Chinese equity holdings to fund the two markets, which are poised for a second straight month of inflows. The decision comes after rising interest in Indonesian and Malaysian stocks among foreign investors, driven by expected US interest rate cuts and China's faltering equity markets. Nomura's strategists also upgraded Taiwanese equities last year, which have seen significant gains this year.

images.alt_text: “Clearly, since the interest has shifted to Japan… clients who used to be fair to all the banks may now prioritise talking to Nomura to see how Japan is doing,” said Kenji Teshima, representative director and CEO of Nomura Asia Pacific Holdings.
The results show the progress Nomura has made in shifting toward a fees-based profit model in order to secure more consistent revenue that is less subject to market swings.
The IPO comes amid heightened capital markets activity in India, where stock markets are trading near a record high
Costs remain elevated in the wholesale business, prompting the company to look for growth in other areas such as trust banking and investment management.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s dovish shift a mixed blessing for Bank of Japan rate hike plan
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may face mixed signals from the US Federal Reserve's dovish shift, which could provide relief for the BOJ's weak yen but complicate its efforts to raise interest rates. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled a continued rate hike path despite market turmoil, while Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicated an imminent policy easing. The yen's rebound is a relief for the BOJ, but domestic politics and economic uncertainty may hinder its ability to implement bold rate hikes.

images.alt_text: At the September Fed gathering, officials will also issue a fresh set of economic projections and indicate where they anticipate their policy rate will be at the end of each year through 2026.
Economists expect the Bank of Japan to increase borrowing costs again by December.

Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the market volatility seen in early August was due to rising fears of a US recession, stoked by the country’s weak economic data, while the BOJ’s interest rate hike in July led to a sharp reversal of “one-sided yen falls”.
Japan's CPI, which excludes fresh food items, rose 2.7 per cent from a year earlier after rising 2.6 per cent in June.
Market strategists have warned that the yen carry trade unwinding may have further room to run. There may still be significant risks present for global investors caught on the wrong side.

site_title: Singtel, Hitachi to collaborate on data centres in Japan
summary: Singtel and Hitachi have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to develop data centers across Japan and potentially the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership aims to create power-efficient methodologies for enterprises to achieve sustainability goals. Hitachi will explore using Singtel's GPU-as-a-service for its internal AI applications and workloads, while Singtel's Digital InfraCo will collaborate with Hitachi to co-create enterprise-grade applications. The partnership opens up new opportunities in Japan's expanding data center market and aligns with Singtel's efforts to bring its collective expertise to help enterprises innovate and transform through the cloud and AI.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Singtel’s Digital InfraCo chief Bill Chang with Toshiaki Tokunaga, executive vice president and executive officer at Hitachi at the MOU signing ceremony.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Is a soft or hard landing for the US economy better for your investments? (Ep 181)
summary: The US economy is experiencing whiplash, with the Fed poised to cut interest rates. Experts weigh in on whether a soft or hard landing would be better for investments. Charu Chanana, head of FX Strategy and global market strategist at Saxo, discusses that a soft landing could lift investor sentiment, but a hard landing could lead to a stock slump. The conversation also touches on the importance of timing in portfolio rebalancing.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 288 to 266 after 920.2 million securities worth S$1.1 billion were traded.
Markets were already rattled by downbeat earnings updates from Amazon and Intel and Thursday’s softer-than-expected US factory activity survey and the monthly US non-farm payrolls report.

site_title: Australia pension fund to acquire state’s Powerco stake: report
summary: Australian Retirement Trust (ART) is set to acquire a majority stake in New Zealand energy distributor Powerco, increasing its ownership to 58%. ART will acquire a 33% stake, with Dexus Group retaining a 42% holding. The deal is expected to be finalized this week and may value Powerco at NZ$3.5 billion. Powerco supplies electricity and gas to over 900,000 customers across New Zealand's North Island.

site_title: Londoners are increasingly buying houses miles away from the capital
summary: Londoners are increasingly buying homes outside the capital, with the average person moving 63km away from London, a record 10km further than in 2019. This trend is driven by higher interest rates and a cost-of-living squeeze, with over 25% of households trading a London home for one outside the capital moving more than 161km away. First-time buyers are also seeking more affordable areas closer to London, with 48% of homes sold in the capital purchased by first-time buyers in the first half of 2024, up from 28% a decade ago.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Buildings in the City of London are seen alongside Victorian residential housing in South London, Britain, August 1, 2023. REUTERS/ Susannah Ireland/File Photo

site_title: ‘Deadpool’ still has a pulse, again leading North American box office
summary: "Deadpool & Wolverine" has topped the North American box office for the fourth time, earning an estimated $18.3 million over the weekend, bringing its total US ticket sales to $577.2 million domestically and $634 million internationally. The film's success is attributed to its strong cast, including Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, and its performance as a highlight of the summer season, according to analyst David Gross.

images.alt_text: Edgar Bronfman is also looking to team Paramount up with a company that can take it to a higher level in terms of licensing its many brands for consumer products.
The Venice Film Festival opens on Wednesday (Aug 28) and runs through Sep 7.

Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.

site_title: Yuan carry trade can prosper even after yen version collapsed
summary: The yuan carry trade, a strategy that involves borrowing yuan to buy higher-yielding assets, is expected to be more resilient than the yen carry trade, which crashed after Japan's currency surged. China's central bank has kept monetary policy dovish, supporting the yuan carry trade. This version of the strategy involves exporters and multinationals, and is less affected by shocks, with a recent trade returning 0.5% this quarter. Analysts predict that investors will continue to bet on the Mexican peso and Brazilian real against the yuan and yen due to China's struggling economy and softer US dollar backdrop.

images.alt_text: For the week, the Canadian dollar was up 1.2 per cent, its biggest weekly advance since December.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit sees opportunities in favourable supply-demand environment
summary: Keppel DC Reit's assets under management have grown by almost four times since its inception, reaching S$3.7 billion as of 2023. CEO Loh Hwee Long is bullish on Singapore and Japan, citing a favourable supply-demand environment for data centres, with both locations having limited capacity and high demand. The Reit will focus on securing good-quality deals in these markets to benefit its unitholders.

images.alt_text: Loh Hwee Long CEO, Keppel DC REIT Management

site_title: Greater awareness and government support are birthing an IVF boom
summary: IVF services in Singapore and South-east Asia are experiencing a boom due to growing awareness and government support to boost low birth rates. Private healthcare providers like Thomson Medical Group and Virtus Health are expanding their services, with Thomson Medical seeing a 70% increase in IVF cycles over the last 10 years. The trend is expected to continue, with companies exploring mergers and acquisitions to cater to the growing demand. Governments are also promoting fertility health, with Singapore introducing policies to support new parents and increase paid leave.

images.alt_text: The number of IVF treatments performed in the US has more than doubled in the past decade, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

OUE Healthcare's chief executive and executive director Yet Kum Meng is bullish on the healthcare industry’s outlook, given the sector’s lower susceptibility to economic cycles and the non-discretionary nature of healthcare expenses.

site_title: New Boeing CEO faces hard choices after Nasa snubs Starliner for SpaceX
summary: Boeing's new CEO, Kelly Ortberg, faces a critical decision regarding the company's struggling Starliner space program after NASA announced it will not send astronauts home from the space station on the faulty spacecraft. NASA will instead use SpaceX's spacecraft. Ortberg's leadership will determine whether Boeing continues the Starliner program, which has faced numerous setbacks and delays, or exits the human spaceflight initiative due to financial constraints. The decision could cost Boeing around $400 million and impact its legacy in space.

images.alt_text: Nasa astronauts Barry “Butch” Wilmore and Sunita “Suni” Williams have been living on the ISS since Jun 6, when Boeing’s Starliner docked with the orbiting laboratory.

site_title: Asia’s top performing bonds show RBA is shouting into the void
summary: Australia's top-performing bonds have surged 3% over the past month, outperforming regional and US Treasuries, as investors doubt the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) hawkish stance on interest rates. The RBA's cash rate is at a 12-year high, and moderating inflation and rising unemployment have led traders to expect a rate cut as soon as this year. The Bank of England, Riksbank, and Reserve Bank of New Zealand have all cut rates recently, prompting the RBA to follow suit.

images.alt_text: One difference is that the RBA raised rates at a slower pace than peers and its benchmark is about 1 percentage point less than some of them.
Michele Bullock has expressed a willingness to be patient as she seeks to slow inflation without choking off economic growth.
Bond investors are shrugging off a relatively hawkish stance from the RBA, at least compared to peers.

Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

site_title: British Airways, Air France suspend Tel Aviv flights over conflict risk
summary: British Airways and Air France have suspended flights to and from Tel Aviv, citing the risk of conflict in the region. The suspensions follow clashes between Israel and Lebanon's Iran-backed Hezbollah group, with Israel launching air strikes against Hezbollah and the group delivering a drone and rocket barrage across the border. Both airlines will reassess security situations before resuming services, with British Airways suspending flights until Wednesday and Air France suspending flights to Tel Aviv and Beirut until Monday.

site_title: Telegram says it abides by EU laws after CEO detained in France
summary: Telegram CEO Pavel Durov was detained in France on Saturday on suspicion of failing to prevent criminal use of the messaging app, according to Agence France-Presse. Durov, a 39-year-old billionaire co-founder, has denied any wrongdoing, stating that Telegram abides by European laws, including the Digital Services Act. The arrest was extended by 24 hours, and Russia's embassy in Paris has demanded that French authorities ensure Durov's rights are protected. Durov's detention has sparked concerns about the platform's content moderation policies and its use in criminal activities.

images.alt_text: Pavel Durov, whose fortune was estimated by Forbes at US$15.5 billion, has said that some governments had sought to pressure him but the app should remain a “neutral platform” and not a “player in geopolitics”.
E-commerce players will be required to verify users who advertise or post about sales of goods and services using government-issued records, among other measures.

site_title: Fierce competition, narrow offerings stymie Malaysia’s digibank sector
summary: Malaysia's digital banking sector is facing significant challenges due to fierce competition and limited offerings. Only three of the five licensed digital banks have begun operations, with the other two yet to launch. Analysts attribute the slow progress to well-capitalized conventional banks rapidly advancing in digitization, creating a competitive market for newcomers. The sector's trust concerns also hinder growth, with GXBank, the first digital bank to launch, being the only exception. The industry's future remains uncertain, with limited opportunities for new entrants to gain traction.

site_title: UOB’s FDI advisory unit sets job creation as a KPI
summary: Singapore's UOB has set a goal to help create one million jobs through its foreign direct investment (FDI) advisory unit, with a focus on creating high-quality jobs. Since its inception in 2011, the unit has supported over 4,500 firms and created around 200,000 jobs since 2020. The unit works closely with local partners and government agencies to design talent strategies for businesses expanding in Asia. UOB's FDI advisory unit aims to be a trusted adviser to companies, offering a one-stop shop for services such as market-entry support, know-how, and risk management.

site_title: Long-term prospects of gold are shining bright
summary: Gold prices are expected to rise due to geopolitical uncertainty, central bank demand, and anticipated interest rate cuts. The yellow metal has remained stable at around $2,500 per ounce, with prices potentially reaching $2,700 by mid-2025 and $3,000 thereafter. Safe haven demand and buying from emerging market and Asian central banks, such as China, are driving the upward trend. The expected Fed rate cuts will further boost gold demand, reducing the opportunity cost of investing in gold and leading to renewed institutional buying. Gold is seen as a strong portfolio diversifier of risk, providing a calm oasis in volatile markets.

images.alt_text: Gold will continue to grind higher ahead of the September Federal Reserve meeting, says New York-based independent metals trader Tai Wong.

By focusing on higher-yielding private credit opportunities,  Blackstone Private Credit Fund and Hamilton Lane’s Senior Credit Opportunities Fund have been able to offer investors attractive investment options.
The mood in the Bitcoin market has been gloomy of late: the digital asset is nursing losses for August and has struggled to hold above the US$60,000 level.

site_title: Shifting property winds
summary: The Singapore government has reduced the loan-to-value ratio for HDB loans from 80% to 75% to "help cool the market and encourage prudent borrowing." This move comes amid a surge in HDB flat prices, with resale prices rising 2.3% in the second quarter, the fastest rate since Q3 2022. Cooling measures have only slowed price appreciation, not reversed it, and property developers are becoming more cautious. This may impact property-related stocks, with real estate investment trusts (Reits) expected to benefit from a potential rate cut and subsequent increase in borrowing.

images.alt_text: The global semiconductor industry, which had slumped last year, is on the mend, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.

The slumping property market, combined with a weak stock market, is hitting household wealth, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.

site_title: Edgar Bronfman’s Paramount plans include partnership with big tech
summary: Edgar Bronfman Jr. is planning to partner Paramount Global with a big tech company, such as Amazon or Apple, to improve its streaming-TV business. Bronfman, who recently submitted a $6 billion bid to buy Paramount, believes the company needs more specific skills in customer acquisition and ad sales. He also aims to license Paramount's brands for consumer products through a partnership. Bronfman faces a rival bid from independent film producer David Ellison, who plans to invest $8 billion in Paramount. A special committee will decide on Bronfman's proposal on August 28.

images.alt_text: Bronfman is expected to argue that his proposal is superior because it will result in less dilution for Paramount’s non-Redstone shareholders.
Paramount agreed to combine with Skydance last month.
Paramount, which owns networks like CBS, MTV and Comedy Central, aims to reduce annual costs by US$500 million and return to profitable growth ahead of its merger with David Ellison’s Skydance Media.

site_title: WealthBT: Integrated Shield plans: When do premium rises cross the line? (Ep 41)
summary: Integrated Shield plan premiums are set to rise in September, prompting questions about whether to downgrade or switch insurers. To save on premiums, consider downgrading or switching to a different insurer. The Ministry of Health's data on lifetime premiums can also guide insurer choices. Reviewing and adjusting premiums can help protect and grow wealth, but it's essential to weigh the costs and benefits of different options.

site_title: In election season, the stock market can be fickle. So be patient
summary: The US stock market has rallied after a brief downturn, with many Wall Street strategists now betting on good times to come due to subdued inflation, strong corporate earnings, and a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. However, the market's high prices on historical basis raise concerns about overvaluation, and potential risks include prolonged political uncertainty, idiosyncratic factors, and global conflicts. Historically, the market has tended to rally once the outcome of an election seems a sure thing, but investors should remain patient and diversify their portfolios to navigate the market's fickle nature.

images.alt_text: Partly because of politics, specific sectors and fixed-income instruments have been fluctuating. The Trump trade has been attributed to small moves in bond yields and in expectations of changes in transactions, from mergers and acquisitions to the exchange rate of the US dollar

site_title: The relevance of a real estate agent is on the table
summary: A recent change in real estate commissions nationwide has led to some individuals, like Joanne Cleaver, selling their homes without using a real estate agent, potentially saving thousands in fees. However, this shift has raised concerns about the potential for buyers to encounter unaddressed issues with the property, such as hidden problems or title and wire fraud. Real estate professionals warn that buyers may face financial burdens and difficulties navigating complex regulations and paperwork.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: EUR/USD expected to see continued upward momentum
summary: The EUR/USD pair has shown resilience, gradually recovering and forming higher lows, indicating a bullish bias. A recent breakout above the upper trendline of a symmetrical triangle near 1.10 level suggests continued upward momentum. This breakout, part of a larger consolidation phase since early 2023, signals the end of the consolidation phase and the beginning of a new bullish leg, potentially shifting the trend after a prolonged period of consolidation.

images.alt_text: The US currency marked a 17-day low versus the yen after Fed chair Jerome Powell greenlights September rate cuts.

site_title:
Canadian dollar climbs to 4-month high 
on ‘surprisingly dovish’ Powell remarks
summary: The Canadian dollar reached a four-month high against the US dollar after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled interest rate cuts. The currency rose 1.2% for the week, its largest weekly advance since December, due to Powell's "surprisingly dovish" remarks. Retail sales in Canada rebounded in July, while manufacturing sales rose 1.1%. The Bank of Canada has already begun cutting rates, and Canadian government bond yields moved lower.

images.alt_text: The US currency marked a 17-day low versus the yen after Fed chair Jerome Powell greenlights September rate cuts.

site_title: Economists push back on Harris price gouging plan
summary: Economists are criticizing Kamala Harris' proposed price gouging policy, which aims to ban price gouging on food and groceries. The policy could hurt consumers if it leads to reduced competition and higher prices. When wages increase faster than inflation, the cost of groceries relative to wages declines over time, making the policy counterintuitive. Analysts argue that the policy is uncompetitive and could ultimately benefit corporations rather than consumers.

images.alt_text: “The upside risks to inflation have diminished. And the downside risks to employment have increased,” Powell said in a highly anticipated speech to the Kansas City Fed’s annual economic conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
At the September Fed gathering, officials will also issue a fresh set of economic projections and indicate where they anticipate their policy rate will be at the end of each year through 2026.

site_title: Britain targets trade deals with India, Gulf states but the US remains notable absentee
summary: The UK's new Secretary of State for Business and Trade, Jonathan Reynolds, is set to unveil the government's international trade strategy and agenda in September. The plan includes restarting trade talks with India and Gulf states, but notably, the US remains an absent participant. Reynolds emphasized that free trade agreements are not the only means to drive economic growth, and the government will also publish a trade strategy aligned with its industrial strategy to boost jobs and deliver growth.

images.alt_text: A strong performance in the second quarter meant the UK enjoyed the best growth in the Group of Seven nations in the first half of 2024, outstripping the US and well ahead of other European countries.
The GfK Consumer Confidence Index, Britain’s longest-running gauge of economic morale among members of the public, was steady in August at -13, matching July’s 34-month high.

Russian President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping during a meeting on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit in Astana, Kazakhstan July 3, 2024. The change will allow the Citigroup’s so-called material risk takers to now earn a bonus that’s as much as six times their base salary.

site_title: Good connections at Rotterdam but Wilmar faces green constraints at Europe’s busiest port
summary: Wilmar International, a Singapore-listed agribusiness, faces challenges in Europe due to stricter green regulations. Despite being near Europe's busiest port, Rotterdam, Wilmar's growth is hampered by the EU Regulation on Deforestation Free Products, which requires due diligence on palm oil production. The company's European revenue reached US$2.36 billion in 2023, but the new regulation increases administrative burden and may deter other traders from participating in the European market. Meanwhile, Singapore-owned Eagletainer Logistics Europe, which transports petrochemicals and oleochemicals, is optimistic about its prospects in Europe and has invested in a young fleet of ISO tank containers to comply with environmental regulations.

Singapore's marine and offshore players can adapt to take part in constructing critical components in the wind energy value chain, such as offshore substations, support vessels, and mooring products.
Singapore Aerospace Manufacturing's facility in Bad Tolz, Germany makes parts for the aerospace industry.

site_title: China EV maker’s tepid reply to EU proves costly in tariff spat
summary: China's state-owned automaker, SAIC Motor, has been hit with a 36.3% tariff on its electric vehicles sold in Europe, more than twice the tariff imposed on BYD, which pays 17% on top of existing customs duties. The European Union imposed the tariffs due to SAIC's "highly deficient" responses to the EU's investigation, citing concerns over the company's security and lack of access to supplier data. The incident highlights the challenges Chinese companies face in navigating Western business and political domains, with experts attributing the issue to a lack of engagement with EU civil society and regulatory systems.

images.alt_text: MG Motor vehicles, a brand of Chinese state-owned carmaker SAIC, are seen reflected in the glass of a car showroom in Santander, Spain, 2024. REUTERS/Vincent West

site_title: Tying executive pay to ESG: Singapore listcos see strategic role
summary: Singapore-listed companies such as Singtel, CapitaLand Investment, Keppel, and Sembcorp Industries are incorporating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) key performance indicators (KPIs) into top executives' remuneration plans. ESG targets cover climate change, digital inclusion, talent diversity, and reputation, and are designed to be challenging yet realistic. While linking remuneration to ESG factors can boost sustainability efforts, concerns exist about easy-to-achieve metrics and the need for transparency in the choice of KPIs and their alignment with business strategy.

images.alt_text: (Photo: RENDY ARYANTO/VVS.sg)

site_title: Soilbuild Construction Group, WeavInsight recognised for balancing profit and purpose
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group and WeavInsight have been recognized for balancing profit and purpose. Soilbuild Construction Group, a sustainable construction engineering company, aims to contribute to people, society, and the environment while achieving financial success. WeavInsight, a small enterprise, uses analytics and data to improve resilience to climate change and create social impact through education. This recognition highlights the importance of balancing corporate goals with social responsibility and environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: 21 Carpenter used to be the location of Chye Hua Seng Wee Kee, a remittance house that was founded in 1936 by philanthropist Lee Wee Nam and his brothers.

site_title: South-east Asia insurtech deals jump over 4 times to US$2.35 billion in 2023 despite fewer transactions: EY
summary: Insurtech deals in South-east Asia surged to US$2.35 billion in 2023, a four-fold increase from 2022, despite fewer transactions. Japanese insurer Sumitomo Life's acquisition of Singapore Life (Singlife) and Singapore-based Bolttech's series B round drove the majority of deal value. Investors prefer established insurtech companies with a proven track record, and those driving digital transformation are also in high demand. The market is expected to rebound, with a focus on category leaders and regional expansion, according to EY.

images.alt_text: The EY company logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, April 16 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls

site_title: China’s tightening rules put foreign high-frequency futures traders in limbo
summary: China's tightening rules on high-frequency futures trading have significantly increased costs for foreign firms, rendering their algorithmic strategies less profitable. Some firms, including those from big-name foreign companies, set up goods trading companies to evade restrictions on overseas investment, but have been caught in a regulatory gray area. New rules disqualifying high-frequency traders from commission rebates and increasing fees have led to a decline in profits, with some firms considering alternative markets like India. Only one foreign high-frequency institution-backed firm successfully registered as a private fund manager, but its registration was later revoked due to non-compliance.

site_title: Telegram messaging app CEO Durov arrested in France
summary: Russian-French billionaire Pavel Durov, CEO of Telegram, has been arrested by French authorities while traveling on his private jet. He faces possible indictment over a preliminary investigation into Telegram's lack of moderators, allowing criminal activity to go on undeterred on the platform. Durov has denied any wrongdoing and stated that Telegram should remain a "neutral platform" and not a "player in geopolitics". The Russian Embassy in Paris has demanded Durov's release, calling France's actions a "dictatorship".

images.alt_text: “We can create the first real power app that can both serve as a communication system, but also as a bank account,” Tether chief executive officer Paolo Ardoino says.

site_title: China says it is ‘strongly dissatisfied’ with fresh US sanctions
summary: China expressed strong dissatisfaction and opposition to the US's imposition of sweeping sanctions on 400 individuals and companies aiding Russia's war in Ukraine, including several Chinese firms. The sanctions target companies involved in shipping microelectronics and machine tools to Russia. China's commerce ministry described the move as "typical unilateral sanctions" that disrupt international trade and threaten global industrial and supply chains. The US has repeatedly warned China about its support for Russia's defense industry, branding Beijing a "decisive enabler" of the war.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping during a meeting on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit in Astana, Kazakhstan July 3, 2024. Sputnik/Pavel Volkov/Pool via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Hizbollah launches missiles at Israel, prompting airstrikes on Lebanon
summary: Hizbollah launched hundreds of rockets and drones at Israel, prompting Israel to strike Lebanon with around 100 jets, in one of the biggest clashes in over 10 months of border warfare. The conflict, which began in parallel with the war in Gaza, risks escalating into a regional conflagration involving Hizbollah's backer Iran and Israel's main ally the US. Israel's military said it foiled a larger attack and intercepted drones launched against a strategic target, while Hizbollah claimed it launched its drones as planned. The United Nations called for an immediate ceasefire, and the US offered support for Israel's right to defend itself.

images.alt_text: Despite the cooling in economic growth, the Bank of Israel is unlikely to cut borrowing costs at its next rate decision in 10 days.

site_title: Australian homeowners struggling to afford insurance as climate risks grow: report
summary: Australia is experiencing a growing crisis of home insurance affordability, with 15% of households facing premiums exceeding four weeks' income, affecting 1.61 million households. Climate-related risks and high construction costs are driving up insurance costs, fueling inflation. The report estimates that 5% of households with home loans are experiencing extreme affordability stress, with A$57 billion in outstanding mortgage loans at risk. The situation is expected to worsen due to increased climate risks, posing a problem for lenders, regulators, and governments.

images.alt_text: A view of the Commonwealth Bank building facade in the Sydney Central Business District, in Sydney, Australia, May 14, 2024. REUTERS/Jaimi Joy

site_title: Isetan Singapore to stop trading on Aug 29 after court sanctions privatisation scheme
summary: Isetan Singapore's last day of trading for its shares will be Aug 28, and trading will be suspended from 9 am on Aug 29, after the court sanctioned a scheme of arrangement allowing Japan's Isetan Mitsukoshi to take Isetan Singapore private. The consideration for the acquisition is S$7.20 per share, a 37.4% premium over the counter's highest closing market price of S$5.24 in the past five years. The transfer books and register of members will close on Sep 5 to determine the entitlements of target shareholders.

site_title: Whaling: why the practice will not go away
summary: Japan continues to hunt whales, despite international condemnation, and plans to expand its list to include fin whales. The country's whaling industry has resumed commercial hunts after quitting the International Whaling Commission moratorium in 2019. However, scientific evidence supporting Japan's "scientific research" whaling claims is thin, and experts argue that non-invasive research methods using advanced technology can provide more accurate data. The moratorium has allowed whale populations to recover, but hunting remains a threat, and whales also face other dangers such as ship collisions and climate change.

site_title: Director acquisitions rebound after earnings reporting season
summary: Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks from Aug 16 to Aug 22, with S$184.7 million of net institutional inflow. Twenty-three primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$16.6 million. CapitaLand Investment led the buyback consideration, buying 3.4 million shares. Leading net institutional inflow were DBS, Singapore Exchange, Sats, UOB, Jardine Cycle & Carriage, and others. Conversely, leading net institutional outflow were Genting Singapore, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and others. More than 60 director interests and substantial shareholdings were filed for over 30 primary-listed stocks, with 20 acquisitions and nine disposals by directors, and seven acquisitions and five disposals by substantial shareholders.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks over the four trading sessions spanning Thursday (Aug 8) to Wednesday’s close.

site_title: Philippines says China fired flares at its South China Sea plane
summary: The Philippines accused China of firing flares at one of its aircraft, a Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources plane, during a maritime domain awareness flight near Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea on Aug 19. China claimed the BFAR plane entered its airspace and undertook "necessary countermeasures" on Aug 22. The incident is part of a series of tense confrontations between the two countries, sparking fears of armed conflict that could draw in the US. Manila urged Beijing to "immediately cease all provocative and dangerous actions."

site_title: How wonky US payroll revisions became controversial
summary: The US Bureau of Labour Statistics (BLS) reported a significant downward revision to the number of jobs created from March 2023 to March 2024, with 818,000 fewer jobs than initially estimated. This is the largest revision in 15 years, primarily affecting white-collar sectors. Former President Donald Trump has accused the Biden administration of "defrauding the people" due to the revision. However, the adjustment is part of a long-standing effort to achieve a more accurate labor market picture.

More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives. site_title: Major central banks now aligned as Powell signals Fed cuts ahead
summary: Major central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Bank of England, are signaling a shift towards lowering interest rates in the coming months, marking the end of an era of high borrowing costs. Fed Chair Jerome Powell indicated the US central bank will lower rates when officials meet in September, while European Central Bank officials also expressed support for further rate cuts. The move aims to address emerging concerns over labor markets and growth, replacing inflation as the primary threat for policymakers.
