site_title: US Treasuries not the safe bet they once were, research says
summary: US Treasuries are no longer considered the "safe haven" securities they once were, according to new research. During the COVID-19 pandemic, investors marked down Treasury securities, similar to bonds from other countries, rather than driving up their value. This shift in investor behavior raises questions about the "exorbitant privilege" the US government enjoys in borrowing globally. The researchers found that large-scale asset purchases by central banks to respond to government spending increases have undesirable public finance implications, including destroying value for taxpayers and subsidizing bondholders.

images.alt_text: “The upside risks to inflation have diminished. And the downside risks to employment have increased,” Powell said in a highly anticipated speech to the Kansas City Fed’s annual economic conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
The futures market anticipated Fed rate cuts at mid-month that were forecast to reach close to 3.25 per cent by end-2025.
Against the backdrop of a strong stock market performance in 2024, softer-than-expected July jobs and ISM data have sparked fears that a US recession is imminent.

site_title: Meta cancels plans for high-end mixed-reality headset, the Information reports
summary: Meta has canceled plans for a high-end mixed-reality headset, internally code-named La Jolla, which was set to compete with Apple's Vision Pro. The device, featuring ultrahigh-resolution micro OLED screens, was scheduled for release in 2027. The decision comes after a product review meeting, where employees were told to stop work on the device. Meta's Reality Labs division, responsible for Quest headsets, has incurred billions in losses, but CEO Mark Zuckerberg remains optimistic about virtual and mixed reality technologies.

images.alt_text: The new proposal ensures that all the Facebook Marketplace advertisers’ data will not be used to improve the ecommerce platform, without having to opt in or out.
Meta’s move to sunset CrowdTangle also comes amid relaxed content moderation policies and information integrity efforts across social media platforms.
A Meta spokesperson says the company removes false ads from its platforms when it learns about them and works with local authorities to battle scammers.

site_title: US new home sales rise more than expected in July
summary: US new home sales surged 10.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 739,000 units in July, beating expectations. The increase was driven by a drop in mortgage rates, which boosted demand and offered evidence of the housing market's recovery. Sales pace for June was revised higher to 668,000 units, and sales rose 5.6% year-over-year in July. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate fell to 6.46%, its lowest since May 2023, amid expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September.

images.alt_text: The average for a 30-year, fixed loan was 6.46 per cent, down from 6.49 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said.
Home sales rose 1.3 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.95 million units, the National Association of Realtors (NAR) said.
US united states housing Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg
Prices for existing single-family houses in the San Jose-Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area rose 11.6 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier to US$2.08 million.

site_title: Shangri-La Asia posts 28.1% fall in H1 net profit on higher operating costs
summary: Shangri-La Asia reported a 28.1% decline in H1 net profit to US$94.5 million, despite a 4.3% revenue rise to US$1.05 billion. Higher operating costs and a decrease in non-operating gains contributed to the decline. Hotel occupancy increased year-over-year, with revenue rising in Sri Lanka and mainland China. The company plans to expand its footprint, particularly in mainland China, and has launched new properties, including a dual-brand hotel. An interim dividend of HK$0.05 per share was declared.

images.alt_text: The combined effects of rebounding travel activities, relaxed pandemic related restrictions, and pent-up consumer demand catalysed the revenue growth during the period, said Shangri-La Asia.
Shangri-La Singapore is one of the group's hotels.

site_title: WHO says partners can start talks to buy mpox vaccines before its approval
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has allowed partners like Gavi and Unicef to start buying mpox vaccines before their approval, aiming to accelerate inoculations in Africa amid a growing outbreak. Two vaccines, approved by regulators worldwide, will receive an emergency license in September. The decision comes as the WHO faces a tight deadline to grant approval, and vaccine manufacturers require immediate orders to produce more shots this year. This move aims to prevent lower-income countries from missing out on vaccines, a concern raised during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: A health worker discusses treatments with patients at the Munigi mpox treatment center in Nyiragongo territory, North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as spotlight turns to Powell
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 rising 31.8 points, or 0.57%, to 5,602.49, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 153.4 points, or 0.87%, to 17,772.727. Investors looked to Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium for clues on rate cuts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 166.3 points, or 0.41%, to 40,879.12.

site_title: Creative posts deeper H2 loss of S$6.8 million despite higher revenue
summary: Creative Technology posted a net loss of US$6.8 million for its second half, despite a 12% revenue increase to US$31 million. Foreign exchange losses, mainly due to euro and yen depreciation, contributed to the loss. The company narrowed its full-year net loss by 35% to US$10.8 million and achieved a higher gross profit margin of 30% due to newly launched products. The market remains challenging, and the company plans to consolidate and lower costs to reach profitability sooner.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Creative Technology posted a 13-per-cent increase in revenue to US$31.8 million on the launch of new products.
Creative founder and former chief executive Sim Wong Hoo who died in January this year.

site_title: Morgan Stanley cuts 2024 oil demand growth outlook on China factors
summary: Morgan Stanley reduced its global oil demand growth forecast for 2024 to 1.1 million barrels per day due to China's slower economic growth, increased electric vehicle usage, and a rise in liquefied natural gas-powered trucks. The bank lowered its Brent price forecasts, predicting an average of US$80 per barrel in the fourth quarter of 2024, down from US$85 previously. This change aligns with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' recent cut in oil demand growth forecasts, citing softness in China.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.17, or 1.54 per cent, to US$77.22 a barrel on Thursday.
Brent futures for October delivery fell 46 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel on Tuesday.
Brent crude futures settled at US$77.66 a barrel on Monday, dropping US$2.02, or 2.5 per cent.
Although the WTI oil price recently found support at a double bottom of US$72.50 per barrel in early August, it has faced resistance near the US$80 per barrel level.

site_title: SAS cabin crew go on strike in Norway, more strike action next week
summary: SAS cabin crew in Norway went on strike on Friday, affecting a limited number of flights, after wage talks broke down. The strike, involving around 120 employees, is expected to rise to 800 staff by August 30, potentially causing mass cancellations. Norway's government-appointed mediator was unable to bridge the divide between the two sides, with the airline citing a need to minimize disruptions to its traffic program. The strike is over demands for better salaries and working conditions, with union leaders stating that SAS cabin crew are paid 15-30% less than counterparts at rival carriers.

images.alt_text: Passengers are seen at BA check-in desks at Heathrow Airport, following the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), London, Britain January 15, 2021. REUTERS/Matthew Childs

site_title: Equinor halts Vietnam offshore wind plans, to close Hanoi office
summary: Equinor, a Norwegian state-controlled energy giant, has cancelled plans to invest in Vietnam's offshore wind sector due to regulatory headwinds and the country's delayed reforms. The company will close its office in Hanoi, marking the first time it has exited an international office focused on offshore wind development. Vietnam aims to install six gigawatt of offshore wind capacity by 2030, but regulatory hurdles and political turbulence have slowed progress. The move is a setback for Vietnam's green power ambitions, following a similar pause by Danish company Orsted last year.

images.alt_text: Photovoltaic panels and battery energy storage systems will be installed across more than 320,000 square meters of ready-built factory roofs at London Business Park in Vietnam's northern province of Thai Binh.

site_title: HSBC to double UK wealth business as banks target 'mass affluent'
summary: HSBC aims to double its UK wealth business assets under management to £100 billion within the next five years, targeting the 'mass affluent' market. The bank plans to hire more advisors to drive growth, leveraging its global reach and international connectivity. With a global asset management business worth US$712 billion, HSBC aims to become a top five player in Britain, joining rivals in the push for fee income from the UK's affluent segment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An aircraft flies past the HSBC headquarters building in the Canary Wharf financial district in east London February 15, 2015.   REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: China bond trading collapses amid PBOC crackdown on record rally
summary: China's efforts to curb a record bond rally have stalled, resulting in a collapse in trading activity. Trading in the 10-year government bond has decreased by 90% over the last two weeks, with average daily volume plummeting. Measures such as selling from state banks and regulatory checks have kept traders on edge. The benchmark yield rose to 2.15% on Friday, while China's finance ministry sold 10-year bonds at record-low yields. Officials have expressed concerns over a slowing economy and the impact on the market, warning against halting trading completely.

images.alt_text: People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)
Bank earnings slated for later this month may be the next test for investors to gauge the health of the sector.

site_title: Sri Lanka flags civil service pay hike ahead of vote
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe's office announced a plan to increase civil servant salaries by 25-50% and boost pensions, starting January, as the country prepares for presidential polls in September. The move aims to address the pressing need for public sector pay hikes, despite the country's ongoing economic crisis and US$46 billion foreign debt default. The plan has received approval from the cabinet and treasury, and Wickremesinghe is seeking a mandate for his efforts to repair the nation's finances.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Colombo main port is seen beyond the main wholesale market, on the day President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is also the island nation's finance minister, presents the annual budget in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 12, 2023.Picture taken November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte
Incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe (top), opposition leader Sajith Premadasa and Marxist-leaning parliamentarian Anura Kumara Dissanayake are seen as frontrunners.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust manager appoints Gerry Chan as deputy CEO
summary: CapitaLand China Trust's manager has appointed Gerry Chan as deputy CEO, effective September 1, 2024. Chan will assist the chief executive in managing all aspects of the trust's business and is currently the managing director of Reit investments at CapitaLand Ascott Trust's manager. The appointment was made in a bourse filing on August 23, 2024.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Private credit loses ground in fight for family office money
summary: Family offices, which manage the fortunes of the world's ultra-wealthy, are slowing down their investments in private credit funds, a key asset class that has grown into a $1.7 trillion industry. According to Preqin, family office searches for private credit funds decreased to 11% this year, down from 18% last year. This trend is attributed to concerns about lower returns as interest rates are expected to cut, and the potential for higher borrowing costs to weigh on future gains. Meanwhile, family offices are shifting their investments towards private equity, real estate, and other asset classes that offer higher potential payouts.

images.alt_text: Adani’s empire has been growing at a breakneck pace in the past five years, often by piling on more debt.
Abu Dhabi has seen banks, hedge funds, family offices, venture capital firms and crypto traders rushing to the UAE’s capital in recent years as they tap into a wealthy market.
Hong Kong has introduced a slew of tax and residency incentives to attract more money management firms, including family offices.
Global lives and global portfolios mean ultra high net worth individuals need a wealth manager who understands their increasingly broad and complex set of needs.
Some 35 per cent of global family offices said they will allocate more assets to Asia-Pacific in the next five years.

site_title: Some economists eye policy easing in October after core inflation slows more than expected in July
summary: Singapore's core inflation slowed to a two-year low in July, reaching 2.5%, below economists' median estimate of 2.9%. This has led some private-sector economists to predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may ease monetary policy settings as early as October. Economists expect core inflation to subside towards the 2% handle in 2025, with some forecasting a slight easing of monetary policy in October, while others believe it may not happen until January's meeting.

images.alt_text: July’s headline inflation is just a nudge lower than the median forecast of 2.5 per cent by private-sector economists polled by Bloomberg.
Friday's monetary policy statement prompted DBS to lower its headline and core inflation forecasts.

site_title: Sembcorp resumes operations of Myanmar power plant
summary: SEMBCorp Industries has resumed operations of its Myingyan Independent Power Plant in Mandalay, Myanmar, after a temporary suspension due to conflicts in the area. The company stated that the situation is now deemed safe for personnel to return. This decision is expected to have minimal impact on the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2024.

site_title: Issue 113: Keppel, ADB team up on energy projects; shifting the focus of Indonesia’s coal phase-out
summary: Keppel and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) have partnered to explore $800 million in energy transition and environmental sustainability opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region. The deal aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 1 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent per year. The partnership will focus on decarbonizing power generation, renewable energy, and green buildings in Indonesia, where a coal phase-out program is underway. The initiative could unlock $300 billion in potential growth for Keppel, but challenges include commercially sound terms and scaling up blended finance.

images.alt_text: Gaia – the largest wooden building in Asia. Nanyang Technological University (NTU) is home to Asia’s largest wooden building, which is also a zero-energy structure that consumes as much energy as it produces.
The project, which will include an array of panels, batteries and, eventually, a cable linking Australia with Singapore, is backed by tech billionaire and green activist Mike Cannon-Brookes.
As at end-June, DBS is the only Singapore banked to be selected by the PBOC for the programme.
Sembcorp says it will produce competitively priced green ammonia in India.
Malaysia has an abundance of deep saline aquifer reservoirs which presents an opportunity for the development of a CCS hub in South-east Asia.

site_title: Infineon to pay more than expected in Qimonda settlement
summary: Infineon has agreed to pay 753.5 million euros (S$1.1 billion) to settle a decade-long dispute over insolvent former unit Qimonda, exceeding initial estimates. The settlement will impact earnings and cash flow from discontinued operations, but Infineon has sufficient funds for dividends and investments. The conclusion of insolvency proceedings is expected in 2025, with substantial dividends for Qimonda creditors.

images.alt_text: The new plant will focus on making power semiconductors that can help with decarbonisation in automotive, industrial and data centre fields.
Infineon reported revenue of 3.7 billion euros for the April-to-June period, falling short of the 3.8-billion-euro forecast in a company-provided consensus and down 9 per cent on the year.
Infineon CEO Jochen Hanebeck said that many end markets were developing weakly due to the economic situation, and customers and distributors continue to reduce semiconductor inventory levels.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit obtains S$50 million sustainability-linked loan
summary: Starhill Global Reit has secured a S$50 million sustainability-linked loan from UOB to finance general corporate funding requirements, including green certification for its portfolio of companies. The five-year loan, drawn from Dec 31, 2024, is not expected to impact the Reit's gearing. The loan will be used to support capital expenditure and attain green certification.

site_title: Vanke to show extent of property crisis that’s bruising Chinese banks
summary: Chinese developer Vanke expects a first-half net loss of 7-9 billion yuan due to a shortage of liquidity and surplus of unbuilt homes, forcing it to resort to discounts to boost cash flow. This follows a 20% slump in new home residential sales in July. The country's rescue package has done little to stem the property sector's decline, with Vanke's announcement painting a pessimistic picture of the sector's outlook. The surplus of unbuilt homes and liquidity shortage have plagued developers, with China Overseas Land & Investment likely to report similar results.

site_title: Government to focus on helping seniors, tackling cost of living, with support in Budget 2025: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's government will focus on helping seniors and tackling the cost of living in Budget 2025, said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. Addressing seniors' longer-term care and housing needs will be a priority, as well as targeted support for larger families with more young children. The government will review and determine the most adequate support measures, considering factors such as inflation and income indicators. The goal is to provide a "fair shot" in life, while encouraging hard work and family uplift, underpinned by a renewed social compact and refreshed Singapore dream.

images.alt_text: In introducing 10 extra weeks of shared parental leave, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong made no reference to the usual economic and existential fears surrounding population issues.

Singaporeans, PM Wong reiterated at the rally, want a more compassionate and inclusive society even as it continues to seek economic growth. Realising these new ambitions would require a “major reset” both in policies and people’s attitudes.
“Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.
The Prime Minister delivers his maiden National Day Rally speech.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 23)
summary: OK Lim's two-storey bungalow in Tanglin Hill has sold for S$39.2 million, or S$2,507 per square foot, on a 15,636 sq ft freehold land area. Meanwhile, protests in Indonesia over a controversial election Bill have raised investor unease, while NASDAQ-listed MoneyHero made a non-binding offer of US$8 million to acquire MoneySmart. Singapore shares rose 0.4% after data showed moderating inflation in July.

images.alt_text: “While there are signs of a more positive employment outlook with some businesses seeking to expand hiring and raise wages, a sizeable proportion of businesses continue to be cautious about the future," says SBF CEO Kok Ping Soon.

site_title:
London luxury-home market looks 
to rich Americans to save it
summary: The London luxury-home market is experiencing a surge in demand from rich Americans, driven by political and social challenges in the US, a strong dollar, and concerns over gun violence. According to a survey by LonRes, US buyers now make up 6.1% of London's luxury market, a 50% increase from last year. This trend is expected to continue, with some brokers citing the presidential election, gun violence, and tax considerations as factors. The US is the only international source of higher year-on-year demand this summer, with luxury brokers relying on Americans as their primary client base.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A row of residential houses is seen with the financial district in the distance in South London, Britain, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia’s Umno vows to resume fight for jailed Najib’s freedom
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, Umno, reaffirmed its commitment to defend jailed ex-prime minister Najib Razak, despite a recent court dismissal of his bid to serve his corruption sentence at home. Umno president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi stated that the party's fight to free Najib has never ended, amid concerns that any further reprieve could erode Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's credibility. This stance puts Umno at odds with Anwar's anti-graft crusade, which relies on public support to stay in power.

site_title: Chinese developer Longfor plans further debt reductions this year
summary: Longfor Group, a Chinese private property developer, plans to further reduce its debt by making early repayments this year, totaling six billion yuan on bonds due in 2025. The company has fared better than peers due to its focus on larger cities, which have seen stronger sales. Longfor lowered its short-term debt by 5.2 billion yuan during the first half of the year, bringing its total debt down to 187.4 billion yuan. The move aims to increase cash flow and reduce debt.

images.alt_text: Fitch downgraded Longfor to ‘BB+’ from ‘BBB-’, which was the last notch for the investment-grade ratings, adding a negative outlook.

site_title: Japan’s core inflation accelerates to 2.7% in July, matches forecast
summary: Japan's core inflation accelerated to 2.7% in July, matching forecasts, for the third straight month. The Bank of Japan's core consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.7% from a year earlier, exceeding the central bank's 2% target for the 28th consecutive month. The BOJ is expected to consider further interest rate hikes, which led to a surge in the yen and a decline in Tokyo stocks.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure on the trading floor at the Nomura Securities Co. headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan. 11, 2024. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.8% to the highest level in about 34 years on Thursday. Photographer: Nao Sano/Bloomberg
Market strategists have warned that the yen carry trade unwinding may have further room to run. There may still be significant risks present for global investors caught on the wrong side.
Japan’s economy expanded in the second quarter, rebounding from a slump at the start of the year thanks to rises in consumption and capital spending.

epa11283791 Foreign visitors walk through the Shibuya crossing in Tokyo, Japan, 17 April 2024. The Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) announced that the estimated number of foreign visitors to Japan in March was 3,081,600. It is the first time the number of visitors exceeded 3 million in a single month, setting a new record.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
The town’s struggle with unruly tourists made international headlines as record numbers of tourists headed to Japan over the summer, creating some opposition among locals.
Seven & i grew from small beginnings, tracing its origins to the small family-owned Yokado Clothing Store that first opened in Tokyo in 1920.

site_title:
China vows to accelerate buying unsold homes 
for public housing
summary: China's housing regulator vows to accelerate the purchase of unsold apartments and turn them into affordable housing to cushion the record property slump. The government will also push forward renting and selling public housing units as soon as possible. This effort aims to implement a new housing model and put a floor under the prolonged property crisis, which has dragged down the job market, consumption, and household wealth.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand China Trust's distributable income has risen slightly in its latest financial results.
People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)
The possibility of Evergrande’s offshore creditors recouping funds through subsidiaries adds another chapter to the downfall of what was once China’s biggest property conglomerate.
More than 30 publicly listed firms based in mainland China, including state-owned giants Bank of China and PetroChina, have dropped PwC as their auditor this year.

Women at an antenatal course in Yichun, China, Aug 21, 2024. China is rapidly running out of mothers. The number of women of reproductive age, defined by the United Nations as 15-to-49, is set to drop by more than two-thirds to under 100 million by the end of the century.
Sephora has expanded to some 300 stores since entering China in 2005.
Kaisa expects a net loss of 8.8 billion yuan to 9.8 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion to S$1.8 billion) for the half year ended June 30.

site_title: Easing inflation bolsters stocks; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Friday, August 23, as moderating inflation data bolstered the market. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 14.41 points to 3,387.99. Top gainers included Sats and Thai Beverage, while Seatrium was the biggest loser. The core consumer price index (CPI) recorded its second consecutive month of deceleration at 2.5%, below market forecasts, paving the way for potential monetary policy easing in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: The coming year will be defined by interest rate cuts, almost everywhere.
In a press conference following his first National Day Rally speech, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said that the cost of living is a common concern cited by Singaporeans whom he has met on the ground.
July’s headline inflation is just a nudge lower than the median forecast of 2.5 per cent by private-sector economists polled by Bloomberg.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei and Seoul stocks slipped while Wellington and Jakarta edged up on Friday.

site_title: China pauses steel capacity swap programme, which will limit expansion
summary: China has paused its steel capacity swap program, which aims to curb overcapacity in the sector, due to "new challenges" facing the industry. The suspension, effective from August 23, will limit the expansion of steel capacity in the long term. The move follows a temporary halt in January 2020 and a revised regulations in June 2021. Analysts predict the suspension will speed up the elimination of "zombie" capacity but may not be enough to phase out excess capacity, emphasizing the need for stronger government enforcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers wearing face masks following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak load steel products for export to a cargo ship at a port in Lianyungang, Jiangsu province, China May 27, 2020. China Daily via REUTERS/File Photo
Baosteel will also reduce the financing collateral principal for the joint venture to nearly US$1.1 billion from US$1.3 billion.

site_title: Australia's CBA cuts interest rates on some home loans for new borrowers
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has cut interest rates on some home loans for new borrowers, with variable mortgage rates decreasing by 25 basis points to 6.89% for those with a 20% deposit. The rate cuts reflect growing competition in the mortgage market amid decade-high interest rates and inflation above the central bank's target range. This move is expected to boost borrowing power for new customers, but contrasts with recent warnings from the Reserve Bank of Australia governor that a rate cut before Christmas is unlikely.

site_title: Why America’s tech giants have grown bigger and stronger
summary: The combined value of the US' top tech giants has more than tripled since 2019, reaching $11.8 trillion. This surpasses the combined value of the next 25 largest firms, including big oil, pharma, finance, and retail. Notable growth includes Apple, now exceeding $3 trillion in value alone, while Nvidia's value has skyrocketed to over $3 trillion. The dominance of these tech giants has led to a widening gap between them and smaller companies, making it increasingly difficult for others to compete.

images.alt_text: Most major governments tend to shoot first and ask questions later in dealing with tech behemoths, the writer says.
Creative destruction? Once upon a time, venture capitalists refused to fund anybody who didnt promise to break things.
Services incumbents will escape destruction from tech disruption

site_title: Singapore’s core inflation eases more than expected in July; headline inflation maintains pace
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to 2.5% in July, lower than the 2.9% recorded in June, while headline inflation remained steady at 2.4%. Private transport costs rose, but were offset by lower accommodation inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained its core inflation forecast range at 2.5-3.5% for 2024. Economists expect core inflation to be lower on average in 2024 due to contained imported price pressures, but may return to around 2% sooner than anticipated.

images.alt_text: An elderly man selecting some vegetables at the NTUC FairPrice supermarket on 18 Jan, 2024.

site_title: The global central bank is alive and well
summary: Central banks worldwide are expected to cut interest rates in the coming year, with the Federal Reserve's upcoming decision anticipated to be followed by similar moves from other major central banks, including the European Central Bank and the Bank of England. While some argue for divergence in monetary policies, economists suggest that the global trend will be synchronized rate cuts, with the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and China already easing rates. The divergence camp may be nostalgic for the rare joint actions taken during the 2008 crisis, but the underlying theme is that global central banks are still aligned in their efforts to combat inflation and support economic growth.

images.alt_text: A view of the Commonwealth Bank building facade in the Sydney Central Business District, in Sydney, Australia, May 14, 2024. REUTERS/Jaimi Joy

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will likely signal - but not explicitly say - that the Fed is looking to start to cut interest rates sooner rather than later, and it’s most likely going to be in September,
The policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in the 5.25 to 5.50 per cent range on July 31, but opened the door to a cut at the Sept 17-18 meeting.

site_title: Harris accepts historic nomination to start US election sprint
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris formally accepted the Democratic presidential nomination on August 22, marking a historic step towards the November 5 election. Harris, 59, must now convince voters she's more than just a younger, capable alternative to President Joe Biden and Donald Trump. In her speech, she pledged to unite Americans, lead and listen, and fight for the American people, contrasting her agenda with Trump's focus on personal gain. Harris outlined plans to prioritize the middle class, protect reproductive and civil rights, and boost economic opportunities, aiming to build a winning electoral coalition.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential nominee and former US President Donald Trump speaks during a visit at the frontier with Mexico in Hereford, Cochise County, Arizona, Aug 22, 2024.

Vice-presidential candidate Tim Walz brought his plain-speaking style and small-town values to the national stage, joined by a litany of political luminaries and star entertainers on the third night of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

In her speech Harris plans to tell the story of who she is and of her plans to help the middle class with cuts in prices on groceries and housing and in taxes and to advance personal freedoms including abortion rights, aides and advisers said.
Kamala Harris' economic proposals will be the priorities for her first 100 days in the White House, should she be elected president.

Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks behind bulletproof glass during a campaign rally at the North Carolina Aviation Museum & Hall of Fame in Asheboro, North Carolina, Aug 21, 2024.

Former US President Barack Obama, speaking on the second day of the Democratic National Convention (DNC), had the attendees at the United Centre in Chicago, Illinois, on their feet time and again; Aug 20, 2024.

It is clear that Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris (right) and her running mate Minnesota governor Tim Walz have dramatically reshaped this year’s race to the White House, flipping within weeks the narrative of the 2024 election.
Former US President Barack Obama speaks during the Democratic National Convention (DNC) at the United Centre in Chicago, Illinois, Aug 20, 2024.
A merchandise booth at the opening night of the Democratic National Convention (DNC) at the United Centre in Chicago, Illinois, Aug 19, 2024.

In a CBS opinion poll released this week, 56 per cent of women surveyed said they would vote for Harris, while 44 per cent backed Trump, a Republican. Conversely, 54 per cent of men surveyed backed Trump, while 45 per cent said they would vote for Harris.

site_title: Protests over controversial Bill batter Indonesia’s markets, trigger investor unease
summary: Indonesia's markets have been rattled by mass protests over a controversial election bill, sparking investor unease ahead of the country's leadership change in October and regional polls in November. The protests, which have fueled concerns about dynastic politics, have led to a decline in the rupiah and equities. The country's central bank has kept interest rates steady, but analysts warn of a widening current account deficit and potential economic instability. The protests have also highlighted the potential risks of prolonged uncertainty during the transition period, with some experts warning that policies implemented during this time may not be upheld by the incoming government.

images.alt_text: A protester yells at police officers outside the parliament in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024. Thousands of police have been deployed near Indonesia’s parliament, amid growing anger over plans for electoral changes that would effectively favor the alliance of President Joko Widodo and his incoming successor, Prabowo Subianto. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Anil Ambani banned from Indian securities market for 5 years
summary: Anil Ambani, chairman of Reliance Group, has been banned from the Indian securities market for 5 years and fined 250 million rupees (S$3.89 million) by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) for orchestrating a scheme to "siphon off" funds from Reliance Home Finance. The regulator alleged that Ambani structured loans to credit-unworthy borrowers, resulting in substantial losses to the company and its stakeholders. The ban also applies to 24 others, including executives of Reliance Group and other unlisted companies connected to Ambani.

images.alt_text: Mukesh Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries Ltd., at India Mobile Congress 2022 in New Delhi, India, on Saturday, Oct. 1, 2022. Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, announced the launch of 5G services in India during the event on Oct. 1. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: #vanlife in Malaysia: A lifestyle choice for some, an act of desperation for others
summary: Malaysians are embracing the #vanlife trend, living in their vehicles for various reasons, including travel with pets and exploring rural areas. However, reality is not always as Instagram-worthy as it seems, with challenges such as regulations, safety concerns, and limited amenities. Some individuals, like Yap Yoong Ching, are willing to spend significant amounts on modifying their vehicles to create a comfortable living space. The #vanlife trend is also driving interest in recreational vehicles (RVs) in Malaysia, with sales expected to reach US$36.9 million by 2026, according to market research.

images.alt_text: Malaysian King Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar has a collection of at least 300 luxury cars.
Motorhomes come of age as Europe relaxes lockdowns

site_title: Malaysia seen pausing rate through 2024 as inflation risks fade
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to maintain its benchmark interest rate at 3% for the rest of 2024 due to lower-than-expected inflation. Analysts have downgraded their inflation forecasts, citing muted impact from higher diesel prices and government intervention measures. The central bank maintained its full-year inflation forecast range of 2-3.5%, with consumer prices unlikely to exceed 3% in 2024. Factors influencing inflation in 2025 include RON95 subsidy reforms, global commodity and food prices, and potential demand upsides from partial pension fund withdrawals.

site_title: Gold edges higher ahead of Powell’s speech, but set for weekly fall
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,488.59 per ounce ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole, Wyoming, but are set for a weekly loss. The dollar index rebounded, making gold less attractive, and benchmark US 10-year yields rose. Investors await Powell's comments on a potential September rate cut, which has been largely priced in. Gold futures gained 0.29% to $2,524.00.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,511.80 per ounce.
The policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in the 5.25 to 5.50 per cent range on July 31, but opened the door to a cut at the Sept 17-18 meeting.

site_title: Lack of mpox shots is disaster for those most hit, WHO aide says
summary: The World Health Organization's African advisory group chair, Helen Rees, warns that the lack of mpox vaccines in affected African countries is a disaster, particularly for those most hit, as it limits containment of the outbreak. The WHO has been working to secure vaccines, and some will be available in the Democratic Republic of Congo by the end of next week. Rees notes that vaccines not only protect individuals but also stop transmission, and that communities have historically accepted vaccines during Ebola outbreaks. The WHO is pushing for a pandemic treaty to ensure equitable access to vaccines and diagnostics.

images.alt_text: MOH said that close contacts will be offered vaccination to reduce the risk of mpox infection.
Clade 1b has triggered global concern due to the ease with which it spreads.
WHO declared mpox a global public health emergency on Aug 14, the second time in two years.
Unlike the mpox-causing virus that spread globally in 2022, the newer strain is more dangerous, with a case fatality rate over 3 per cent.

site_title: First Sponsor seeks to raise S$283.8 million in convertible perps issue
summary: First Sponsor Group plans to raise S$283.8 million through a renounceable and non-underwritten rights issue of perpetual convertible capital securities. The perps will be issued at S$1.08 each, representing a 0.5% discount to the volume-weighted average price of shares traded prior to the announcement. Net proceeds will be used to fund expansion plans, strengthen financial position, and repay borrowings. The Series 3 convertible securities will have a 4.85% distribution rate and may be redeemed at any time on or after six months from the issue date.

images.alt_text: Le Meridien Frankfurt Hotel, owned by First Sponsor Group in a joint venture with City Dveelopments and Tai Tak Estates. First Sponsor has declared a final dividend of S$0.032 per share for H2 FY2023.

Artist's impression of First Sponsor's Star of East River project in Dongguan, China. Pre-sales for the group’s China projects remained muted in the six months due to weak market sentiment.

site_title: Thai PM says economy needs a boost, to adjust handout scheme
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra announced plans to adjust the country's flagship handout scheme worth up to 500 billion baht to stimulate the economy, which has lagged peers. The "digital wallet" scheme, aimed at 50 million Thais, was initially planned for the fourth quarter under the previous government. Paetongtarn stated that the economy needs stimulation and that people will suffer for longer if adjustments are not made. The scheme's future is uncertain, pending the formation of her Cabinet and resubmission to Parliament.

images.alt_text: Thailand's new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, known by her nickname "Ung Ing" and daughter of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, takes part in a press conference in Bangkok on August 16, 2024. Thai lawmakers on August 16 appointed the 37-year-old daughter of billionaire Thaksin Shinawatra as prime minister, elevating a third member of the influential but divisive clan to the nation's top job. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Alibaba to upgrade Hong Kong listing amid profit drop
summary: Alibaba has decided to upgrade its Hong Kong-listed shares to primary status, allowing China's investors to potentially invest billions of dollars in the company. The decision, made by shareholders during the annual general meeting, aims to boost the firm, which has underperformed the market due to weak consumption and regulatory crackdowns. The conversion could pave the way for Alibaba to enter a cross-border scheme, opening it up to China's over 200 million investors and potentially attracting US$19.5 billion in capital inflows in the first six months.

images.alt_text: The booming demand for Sam’s Club made it possible for Walmart to build its own e-commerce app.

Investors worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share back from PDD Holdings and JD.com in China will compress margins.

Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.

site_title: Apple to let iPhone users in Europe delete its App Store
summary: Apple will allow iPhone and iPad users in the European Union to delete the App Store or its Safari browser, starting this fall. This change comes as the company complies with the EU's landmark Digital Markets Act, which requires tech giants to offer users more choices and promote competition. Users will be able to manage default settings for browsers, messaging, phone calls, and other features. Apple will also authorise developers to implement alternative browser engines after meeting specific criteria and committing to ongoing privacy and security requirements.

images.alt_text: The shift into robotics is part of a broader effort to boost sales and capitalise on Apple Intelligence, a suite of AI technology that’s coming to the iPhone, iPad and Mac this year.
Apple takes a cut of all payments made via the iPhone.

Hon Hai has set itself the goal of securing 40 per cent of the global AI server market, relying on its close relationships with many of the world’s biggest tech companies and depth of manufacturing expertise.

site_title: OK Lim’s Tanglin Hill bungalow sells for S$39.2 million
summary: OK Lim's two-storey freehold bungalow in Tanglin Hill has been sold for S$39.2 million, or S$2,507 per square foot, to the children of Mapletree Investments CEO Hiew Yoon Khong. The 8,110 sq ft bungalow features five bedrooms and a pool, and is located in the Ridley Park Good Class Bungalow area. The sale price works out to S$2,507 per square foot on the freehold land area of 15,636 sq ft, a record for the area.

site_title: MoneySmart rejects MoneyHero’s S$8 million acquisition offer
summary: MoneySmart, a Singapore-based personal finance company, has rejected a non-binding offer of US$8 million from NASDAQ-listed fintech company MoneyHero to acquire it. The board of MoneySmart deemed the offer "neither serious nor credible" and stated it will not be entertained, citing a lack of prior discussions and divergence in strategy and financial outlook between the two companies. MoneyHero had made the offer after laying off 80 employees in July to cut costs and improve financial profitability.

images.alt_text: Dhruv Arora, founder and chief executive of Syfe, founded the company in 2019, with the aim of making investing more accessible.
Revolut said on Friday it had “signed agreements with a group of leading technology investors to provide liquidity to employees through a secondary share sale at a US$45 billion valuation.”

site_title: High food prices in India threaten overall inflation outlook, say rate panel members
summary: India's headline inflation remains above the central bank's 4% target due to persistent food price inflation, forcing the monetary policy committee to maintain a restrictive stance. Retail inflation fell to 3.54% in July, but core inflation continues to hover around record lows. The Reserve Bank of India kept interest rates unchanged, with four out of six members voting in favor, as global market volatility prompts other central banks to ease policy.

site_title: Trump threatens tariffs on countries that don’t accept migrants
summary: Former US President Donald Trump threatened large tariffs on countries that don't accept deported migrants, suggesting his immigration and trade policy could become intertwined if he returns to the White House. Trump made the statement during a visit to the US-Mexico border, intensifying his attacks on Vice-President Kamala Harris' handling of illegal immigration. He has pledged to complete the construction of a wall along the border and carry out the largest deportation effort in US history, amid a surge in undocumented immigrants entering major cities.

images.alt_text: Vice-presidential candidate Tim Walz brought his plain-speaking style and small-town values to the national stage, joined by a litany of political luminaries and star entertainers on the third night of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

Kamala Harris' economic proposals will be the priorities for her first 100 days in the White House, should she be elected president.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda signals readiness to raise rates if growth, inflation on track
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled readiness to raise interest rates if the economy and prices align with forecasts, while keeping a close eye on market developments. The recent market volatility was attributed to rising fears of a US recession, not the BOJ's interest rate hike in July. Ueda stated the central bank would remain vigilant to market moves and their impact on forecasts, with no change to its stance on adjusting monetary easing if economic and price developments align with expectations.

site_title: UK consumer confidence matches almost 3-year high in August
summary: UK consumer confidence remained steady in August at a 34-month high of -13, matching July's reading, according to a survey by GfK. The improvement in sentiment was driven by better outlooks for personal finances and major purchases, partly due to a recent interest rate cut. Business surveys suggest the economy is on track for solid growth in the second half of 2024. However, the gauge of past economic sentiment cooled, and economists predict only one more interest rate cut this year, likely in November.

Official data last week showed British pay grew at its slowest annual pace in nearly two years during the second quarter of 2024 and there was a surprise drop in unemployment, albeit on a survey that is undergoing a major overhaul.
The figures may signal a turning point for official data and other surveys, which have shown that vacancies across the economy have continued to decline.

Rightmove, which says it advertises property for more than nine of every 10 estate agents in the United Kingdom, said buyer enquiries in August were 19 per cent higher than a year earlier, compared with an 11 per cent annual increase in July.

A strong performance in the second quarter meant the UK enjoyed the best growth in the Group of Seven nations in the first half of 2024, outstripping the US and well ahead of other European countries.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee: Requisitionists’ proposed internal manager directors must obtain MAS approval
summary: The trustee of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has stated that the proposed candidates for the internal manager directorship must obtain approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) before an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) can be convened. The candidates, nominated by requisitionists, must meet regulatory criteria, including being competent, honest, and having integrity. The trustee has asked the requisitionists to amend their resolutions and apply for MAS approval to enable the EGM to be held as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

Sabana Growth Internalisation Committee urges unitholders to vote for the resolutions in favour of the internalisation.

site_title: US Federal Reserve chair expected to signal support for rate cuts
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is expected to signal support for cutting interest rates ahead of the September rate decision, according to an expert. Powell's keynote speech at the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium may indicate the Fed is considering rate cuts sooner rather than later. The Fed's benchmark lending rate is currently at a 23-year high, cooling demand in the US economy ahead of the presidential elections. The move could help alleviate inflation concerns and boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: The average for a 30-year, fixed loan was 6.46 per cent, down from 6.49 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said.

Average prices charged for goods and services rose at the slowest rate since January and are now at levels that S&P Global viewed as consistent with the Federal Reserve’s 2 per cent inflation target.

site_title: Australian regulator increases capital add-on requirement for ANZ to A$750 million
summary: The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority has increased the capital add-on requirement for ANZ Group to A$750 million, reflecting escalating concerns about the bank's risk management practices. This follows a 2019 mandate of A$500 million operational risk capital add-on due to inadequacies in its risk governance framework. The move comes amid a tumultuous period for ANZ, which recently suspended several traders from its markets division amid allegations of misconduct related to suspected misrepresentation in government bond trades. The regulator's action underscores persistent concerns about ANZ's risk management practices.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday after US, Europe indices close mixed overnight
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Friday, August 23, following a mixed overnight performance in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index rose 0.03 points to 3,373.61, with healthcare services provider Medtecs International gaining 5.6% and Singtel rising 0.3%. US tech shares led stocks lower, while Europe's main stock index climbed, driven by healthcare and retail stocks.

images.alt_text: Marco Polo Marine's gross profit rose 2.6 per cent to S$14.6 million for the third quarter ended Jun 30, 2024.

site_title: Far East Orchard establishes inaugural private fund to invest in UK purpose-built student accommodation
summary: Far East Orchard has established its first private fund, the FE UK Student Accommodation Development Fund, with a target aggregate commitment of £100 million. The fund will invest in purpose-built student accommodation in the UK, with a first closing of £70 million. The company's PBSA portfolio has 92% reservations for the academic year starting September 2024, driven by strong demand. This marks a natural progression for the group into fee-based investment management, aiming to grow recurring income and reduce balance sheet exposure.

images.alt_text: Far East Orchard's purpose-built student accommodation portfolio in the UK is the key driving force behind the group's revenue and net profit growth in FY2023.

site_title: Oil prices settle US$1 up on hopes of a Fed rate cut next month
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures increasing US$1.17 to US$77.22 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gaining US$1.08 to US$73.01 a barrel. The price rebound was driven by expectations of a US interest rate cut next month, which could slow economic activity and boost demand for oil. The US dollar has also fallen, making oil cheaper for buyers using other currencies.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for October delivery fell 46 cents, or 0.6 per cent, to settle at US$77.20 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Changi and Seletar airports to start temperature, visual screening to detect mpox cases
summary: Singapore's Changi and Seletar airports will implement temperature and visual screening for travellers and crew on flights from mpox-affected areas starting Aug 23. The screenings will also be done at sea checkpoints for ships arriving from such areas. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has advised travellers to adhere to health advisories and will offer vaccinations to close contacts to reduce the risk of mpox infection.

Mpox has tended to present at first through fever, muscle aches, fatigue, headache, the swelling of lymph nodes and other flu-like symptoms.
A new form of the virus has triggered global concern as it seems to spread easily though routine close contact.

site_title: Vietnam’s move to source renewables directly a big boost to energy independence
summary: Vietnam's new regulations on direct power purchase agreements (DPPA) for renewable energy are expected to boost the country's energy independence and attract more global high-tech firms. The move will enable industrial parks to source renewable energy directly, reducing reliance on the national grid. Over 320,000 square meters of factory roofs in the northern province of Thai Binh will be equipped with photovoltaic panels and battery energy storage systems. Industry players see significant potential, but caution that clearer guidance from authorities is needed to overcome hurdles.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Marco Polo Marine, Sabana Reit, CapitaLand India Trust, Far East Orchard
summary: Marco Polo Marine's gross profit rose 2.6% to S$14.6 million for the third quarter, despite a 4.6% decline in revenue. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's trustee clarified that new directors must meet regulatory requirements before convening an extraordinary general meeting. CapitaLand India Trust priced S$150 million notes at 3.7% per annum. Far East Orchard established its first private fund, completing its first closing of £70 million, and investing in UK student accommodation.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on rate cut hopes, healthcare sector hits record high
summary: Europe's main stock index rose 0.4% on Thursday, reaching its highest level this month, driven by gains in the healthcare and retail sectors. The Stoxx 600 index rose for the second day, with healthcare stocks such as Novo Nordisk and Siegfried Holding advancing. Investors are hopeful of interest rate cuts by major central banks, including the Fed and ECB, which could boost risk assets globally.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4 per cent to 40,712.78 on Thursday.

site_title: The role of culture in being a liveable and distinctive city
summary: Singapore is converging with international thinking that a city is liveable and loveable when it evokes intangibles like memory, identity, history, and culture beyond traditional physical measures. The city's vibrant cultural precincts, such as Kampong Gelam and Little India, reflect its multicultural identity and capture memories. Data from the National Arts Council and National Heritage Board shows that arts and culture contribute to building a liveable and distinctive city, with 72% of Singaporeans feeling a greater sense of belonging through arts and culture. The government has committed to enhancing living environments through arts and culture initiatives, with plans like the Our SG Arts Plan and Our SG Heritage Plan 2.0.

images.alt_text: It has been well-established that using gross domestic product, which values goods and services produced in an economy, as a metric to measure quality of life is woefully inadequate.

site_title: Investors should avoid a new generation of rip-off ETFs
summary: New generation of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) may pose a risk to financial stability due to their complex designs and lack of transparency. Some ETFs, such as "defined-outcome funds" and "semi-transparent" vehicles, offer investors protection from market losses but at a significant cost. These funds can lead to overpaying for volatility protection and create a mismatch in liquidity. The issuance of private-market ETFs, which bundle unlisted assets into tradable ETFs, may further exacerbate these issues. Experts warn that these new forms of ETFs could turn John Bogle's concerns about their potential misuse into a reality.

site_title: GM’s Cruise recalls nearly 1,200 robotaxis to close US probe
summary: General Motors' Cruise unit has agreed to recall nearly 1,200 robotaxis due to hard braking issues, the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) announced. The recall follows an investigation into 7,632 incidents involving Cruise's automated driving system, which was linked to 10 crashes, including four resulting in injuries. Cruise agreed to the recall, despite disagreeing with the NHTSA's conclusion that a recall was necessary. The incident marks a significant step for Cruise as it works to reassure regulators and resume robotaxi operations.

images.alt_text: Cruise has been working to rebuild the business by overhauling top management with a new chief executive officer and by mending relationships with regulators

site_title: US: Stocks fall as market weighs expected Fed pivot
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as the market weighed expectations for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4% to 40,712.78, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.9% and 1.7% respectively. Tech shares led the decline, with chip companies like Nvidia and Intel falling 3.7% and 6.1%. The expectation of a potential interest rate cut has boosted market sentiment, with futures markets betting on a quarter-point reduction.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip with Wall Street ahead of Powell, yen rises
summary: Asian stocks slipped on Friday ahead of Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's speech, as investors awaited a possible interest rate cut. The dollar weakened amid speculation about the size of the expected cut. Tokyo's central bank head appeared before lawmakers, sparking concerns about the yen's value. The yen rose after the Bank of Japan indicated a possible rate hike. Despite a US economic slowdown, markets remain uncertain about Powell's speech, with some expecting a smaller rate cut than anticipated.

site_title: Combining climate measures key to slashing emissions: study
summary: A new study published in Science found that implementing climate measures such as taxes or subsidies alone is not effective in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The study analyzed 25 years of public policies in 41 countries and identified only 63 successful climate policies that led to an average emission reduction of 19%. Successful policies were found to be implemented in conjunction with tax or price incentives, such as in the UK's coal-fired power generation and Norway's car phase-out plan. The researchers hope their work will inform climate roadmaps and help countries meet the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting warming to 1.5°C.

site_title: Europe office demand rises on boost from banks and insurers
summary: European office space take-up rose 9% in the second quarter, driven by the finance and insurance sector and return-to-work mandates. The finance sector accounted for 25% of leasing activity, with the City of London seeing a 34% share. Office attendance is increasing, with three-quarters of companies adopting minimum attendance policies. However, businesses are shrinking their footprints, and a lack of suitable stock is prompting tenants to renew existing leases. European office investment transactions totaled 14.1 billion euros in the first six months, down 21% year-on-year due to high interest rates.

site_title: US mortgage rates drop to a 2024 low as buyers await Fed cuts
summary: US mortgage rates have dropped to a 2024 low of 6.46%, down from 6.49% last week, according to Freddie Mac. This decrease has increased purchasing power for homebuyers and boosted sales of previously owned US homes, which rose in July for the first time in five months. Experts expect further interest-rate reductions by the Federal Reserve to stimulate the sluggish market, but warn that policymakers must time the cuts carefully to avoid triggering unemployment.

The US housing market has been starting to benefit from an expectation that the Federal Reserve will cut its benchmark interest rate at its meeting in September.
Prices for existing single-family houses in the San Jose-Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area rose 11.6 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier to US$2.08 million.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as prospects of September rate cut grow
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday as investors anticipated a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September. The Dow Jones rose 41.7 points, or 0.10%, to 40,932.23, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. The optimism comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's Jackson Hole meeting this week, where policymakers are expected to provide insight into their monetary policy stance.

site_title: Water-energy efficiencies: Catalyst to semiconductor sustainability
summary: The semiconductor industry, a trillion-dollar market by 2030, faces a significant challenge in reconciling its water and energy consumption with climate targets set by South-east Asian countries, aiming for carbon neutrality by 2050. To drive sustainability, manufacturers must focus on the water-energy nexus, targeting energy-intensive water processes rather than just traditional energy reduction. A three-pronged approach, including a mindset shift, measurement-based analysis, and digital solutions, can help achieve water and energy efficiencies, minimizing operational costs and aligning with environmentally responsible supply chains.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of a worker in the clean room processing Wafer-level packaging (WLP) at the Singapore semiconductor firm, STATS ChipPAC office in Yishun on April 12, 2023. WLP is a process where packaging components are attached to an integrated circuit (IC) before the wafer– on which the IC is fabricated.
After integrated circuits are fabricated on a wafer, it is cut into small pieces known as die that form the basis of a chip.

site_title: Nestle replaces CEO Schneider with company veteran Freixe
summary: Nestle replaces CEO Mark Schneider with company veteran Laurent Freixe, who will take over as CEO on September 1. The move comes after Nestle lowered its sales growth outlook for 2024 due to slowed price increases. Freixe, who has led the company's European zone and Latin America region, is seen as a "perfect fit" for the role, with Nestle chairman Paul Bulcke praising his strategic acumen and market expertise. The change is effective September 1, with Freixe also nominated for the board of directors at Nestle's 2025 annual general meeting.

site_title: US existing home sales rise more than expected in July
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.3% in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.95 million units, exceeding expectations, as improving supply and declining mortgage rates offered hope for a rebound. Home prices increased 4.2% from a year earlier, while inventory rose 0.8% to 1.33 million units. The median existing home price reached $422,600. Despite the modest gain, home sales remain sluggish, and entry-level homes remain in short supply.

images.alt_text: The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) refinancing index jumped 34.5 per cent to a more than two-year high of 889.3.
Prices for existing single-family houses in the San Jose-Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area rose 11.6 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier to US$2.08 million.
Housing has been one of the main contributors to post-pandemic inflation, and further improvement in rental supply should help bring headline rates lower.
The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped 27 basis points in the week ended Aug 2, to 6.55 per cent, the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) said.

site_title: Sri Lanka court convicts president over vote delay
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe was found guilty by the country's top court of "unlawful conduct" for delaying local council elections in March 2023, which were seen as a referendum on his handling of the economy. The judgement carries no immediate legal consequences due to Wickremesinghe's immunity while in office. The court ordered the independent election commission to hold the local polls as soon as possible without disrupting the upcoming presidential vote, set for September 21.

images.alt_text: Incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe (top), opposition leader Sajith Premadasa and Marxist-leaning parliamentarian Anura Kumara Dissanayake are seen as frontrunners.

site_title: Thailand confirms mpox case is clade 1b, second outside of Africa
summary: Thailand has confirmed a second case of mpox outside of Africa, a 66-year-old European man who arrived in the country last week from an unspecified African country. The case is of the clade 1b strain, which has triggered global concern due to its ease of spread through routine close contact. This is the first case of clade 1b in Thailand, and the individual is likely infected from an endemic country.

images.alt_text: Test tubes labelled "Mpox virus positive" are seen in this illustration taken August 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Laboratory tests are under way to confirm the strain, but officials believe it to be from Clade 1.
WHO declared mpox a global public health emergency on Aug 14, the second time in two years.
Unlike the mpox-causing virus that spread globally in 2022, the newer strain is more dangerous, with a case fatality rate over 3 per cent.
Mpox has tended to present at first through fever, muscle aches, fatigue, headache, the swelling of lymph nodes and other flu-like symptoms.
A new form of the virus has triggered global concern as it seems to spread easily though routine close contact.

The meeting will be attended by members of an alliance of health experts who oversaw the global response to Covid-19 and include global health agencies such as the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance.

site_title: China’s real estate woes weigh down S-Reits, but retail sector could be bright spot
summary: China's real estate woes continue to weigh down Singapore-listed S-Reits, with many seeing downward pressure on valuations in the coming quarters. However, the retail sector in China is showing positive signs with rental reversions starting to turn positive amid a recovery in consumer spending, offering a potential bright spot. Despite this, market analysts expect a challenging period for the sector.

site_title: Body of British tech entrepreneur Lynch retrieved from yacht, source says
summary: British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, 59, was retrieved from the wreck of his luxury yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily during a violent storm. Lynch was celebrating his recent acquittal in a major US fraud trial when the yacht disappeared. The bodies of 5 others who vanished were recovered, but Lynch's 18-year-old daughter Hannah and others remain unaccounted for. Authorities are investigating the disaster, which has been described as baffling by naval marine experts, and have questioned passengers and witnesses. The yacht's manufacturer claims it was "one of the safest boats in the world" but blames a chain of human mistakes for the sinking.

images.alt_text: Rescue personnel in the area where the luxury yacht Bayesian sank, off the coast of Sicily.

Mr Jonathan Bloomer, Group Chief Executive
of Prudential Plc.
FILE PHOTO: British entrepreneur Mike Lynch leaves the High Court in London, Britain March 25, 2019. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: India may let foreign investors raise capital in rupees to invest overseas
summary: India may allow foreign investors to raise capital in rupees for investments in select countries of "strategic interest" to India, simplifying its foreign direct investment and overseas investment rules. The move aims to boost the international use of the Indian rupee as a currency for overseas investments, reducing reliance on the US dollar. The plan, proposed by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, will require amendments to the Foreign Exchange Management Act. The government plans to enable investments in rupees on a country-to-country basis, promoting Indian rupees as a currency for international trade.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A private money trader counts Indian Rupee currency notes at a shop in Mumbai August 1, 2013. REUTERS/Vivek Prakash/File Photo

site_title: Soaring to new heights
summary: Omega has released a limited-edition Seamaster Diver 300M watch to celebrate its role as Official Timekeeper at the 37th America's Cup in Barcelona. The 42mm stainless steel watch features a blue ceramic bezel, laser-engraved waves on the dial, and an America's Cup trophy counterweight on the central seconds hand. This design combines dive watch technology with regatta-inspired features, highlighting Omega's official partnership with the prestigious sailing event. The limited-edition watch is a unique tribute to Omega's involvement in the America's Cup.

images.alt_text: A classy smoked bronze dial takes centrestage in this Royal Oak Offshore summer novelty.

site_title: Ping An profit rises as market recovery bolsters returns
summary: Ping An Insurance reported a 7% increase in profit for the first half of 2024, reaching 74.6 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion), driven by a stock-market recovery that bolstered investment returns. Operating profit dropped 0.6% due to stripping out short-term investment volatility and one-time items. The company's new business value benefited from improved margins in life policies and increased sales of protection-type products, following a 0.9% gain in China's CSI 300 Index.

site_title: US business activity edges lower; pricing power ebbs further
summary: US business activity declined to a 4-month low in August, with the manufacturing sector experiencing its 8-month low, according to S&P Global's flash US Composite PMI Output Index. The services sector showed a slight increase, but not enough to offset the decline. Average prices charged for goods and services rose at the slowest rate since January, consistent with the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. This suggests inflation may stay on a downward trend over the coming months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Solar panels are built at the QCells solar energy manufacturing factory in Dalton, Georgia, U.S., March 2, 2023. REUTERS/Megan Varner//File Photo

The policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in the 5.25 to 5.50 per cent range on July 31, but opened the door to a cut at the Sept 17-18 meeting.

Harris vice-presidential pick Tim Walz 
rallies Democratic convention
summary: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, chosen by Kamala Harris as her running mate, rallied the Democratic National Convention with a speech emphasizing small-town values and a commitment to human rights. Walz vowed to defeat Republican Donald Trump in the November election, criticizing Trump's policies as favoring the wealthy and most extreme. The convention featured appearances by Oprah Winfrey, Bill Clinton, and Stevie Wonder, with some Republicans joining Democrats in supporting the Harris-Walz ticket. Polls show Harris leading Trump in several key states, and the convention concluded with a focus on issues such as healthcare, housing, and social justice.

images.alt_text: Kamala Harris' economic proposals will be the priorities for her first 100 days in the White House, should she be elected president.

site_title: US jobless claims rise in latest week
summary: US jobless claims rose 4,000 to a seasonally adjusted 232,000 for the week ended Aug 17, according to the Labor Department. This data suggests a gradual cooling of the labor market, alleviating concerns of rapid deterioration. Layoffs remain low, with hiring slowing due to firms scaling back hiring and immigration-induced labor supply. The Federal Reserve is closely watching the labor market, with interest rate hikes curbing demand, and is expected to begin a rate-cutting cycle at its next policy meeting on Sept 17-18.

images.alt_text: The policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in the 5.25 to 5.50 per cent range on July 31, but opened the door to a cut at the Sept 17-18 meeting.

site_title: From ‘Bidenomics’ to ‘Harrisnomics’: Adding a touch of populism
summary: Kamala Harris' economic proposals have been criticized by The Washington Post's editorial board, labeling them as "populist gimmicks" that failed to provide a substantial plan for managing the economy. Harris' agenda, which will be a priority in her first 100 days in the White House, marks a departure from the policies of the Biden administration. The Post's criticism highlights a potential shift in Harris' economic stance, sparking debate about her presidential campaign's direction.

images.alt_text: It is clear that Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris (right) and her running mate Minnesota governor Tim Walz have dramatically reshaped this year’s race to the White House, flipping within weeks the narrative of the 2024 election.

Harris is riding a historic whirlwind into the convention: her campaign has broken fundraising records, packed arenas with supporters, and turned opinion polls in some battleground states in Democrats’ favour.

Kamala Harris’ economic platform closely mirrors that of President Joe Biden and aims to appeal to the middle class. Her campaign will pay special attention to what plays well with voters in battleground states, with less than 90 days from the presidential election, advisers said.

Residential buildings in New York, US, on Friday, July 12, 2024. President Joe Biden is calling on Congress to pass a form of national rent control for some 20 million apartment units nationwide, a dramatic federal intervention in the housing market on behalf of current tenants. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Federal Reserve's legal status is complicated, but there's no fundamental constitutional principle saying that elected officials must keep their hands off the money supply.
Pollsters and strategists from both major US parties warn that the "sugar high" of Harris' initial surge will wear off.

site_title: Eurozone wage growth slows, boosts case for another ECB cut
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) inflation outlook is boosted by a slowdown in eurozone wage growth, easing concerns about the need for further interest rate cuts. Second-quarter negotiated pay rose 3.6% from last year, down from 4.7% in the previous quarter, in line with estimates. The ECB's decision to lower interest rates next month is expected, with officials citing the need for corporate profit margins to absorb labor costs and improve productivity. The ECB's inflation target of 2% by end-2025 remains a challenge, with policymakers cautious about making further cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bank employee counts pound notes at Kasikornbank in Bangkok, Thailand, October 12, 2010.  REUTERS/Sukree Sukplang/File Photo
In Germany, negotiated wages including additional benefits rose 3.1 per cent in the second quarter – half the pace recorded in the preceding three-month period.
HCOB’s preliminary composite Purchasing Managers’ Index, compiled by S&P Global, bounced to 51.2 this month from July’s 50.2, moving away from the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction.

Commercial property prices have fallen sharply due to higher borrowing costs and poor demand as firms adjust to post-pandemic realities, with the ECB estimating that prices may have dropped by close to a tenth last year alone.
FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble campers at Knaus-Tabbert AG factory in Jandelsbrunn near Passau, Germany, March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo
