site_title: CapitaLand India Trust prices S$150 million notes at 3.7%
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has priced S$150 million notes at 3.7% per annum, with interest payable semi-annually. The notes are expected to be rated "BBB-" by Fitch Ratings and will be used to refinance existing borrowings or repay loans. The net proceeds will also be used to finance business activities and general working capital. The notes are expected to be issued on Aug 30 and listed on the Singapore Exchange on Sep 2.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine Q3 gross profit up 2.6% on favourable supply-demand environment
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a 2.6% increase in gross profit to S$14.6 million in Q3 2024, despite a 4.6% decline in revenue to S$34.9 million. The company's shipyard segment was limited by a fully utilised dry dock, preventing third-party jobs. A favourable supply-demand environment boosted charter rates for its Offshore Support Vessels, but the company faces a delayed delivery of its Commissioning Service Operation Vessel, potentially triggering liquidated damages. Despite this, Marco Polo Marine remains positive on its outlook for the OSV market.

images.alt_text: Good corporate governance and a consistent track record, as well as paying dividends, are also important factors to look out for.
The results translate to an earnings per share of 0.29 Singapore cents.
A lack of investment in the oil and gas sector after the oil price crash of 2016 has resulted in muted supply of vessels despite strong demand amid buoyant oil prices.

site_title: Singapore’s fine-dining scene in dire straits; more closures expected before year end
summary: Singapore's fine-dining scene is experiencing a downturn, with several high-end restaurants set to close by the end of the year. One-Michelin-starred Sommer and two-Michelin-starred Cloudstreet are among the closures, citing poor market conditions and increasing cost-consciousness among consumers. This trend follows recent closures of La Dame de Pic, Braci, and Table65, with restaurateurs attributing the decline to the non-renewal of leases and a shift in consumer preferences. The industry is expected to continue experiencing a "purge" of underperforming establishments.

images.alt_text: One Michelin-starred Basque Kitchen by Aitor closed its premises on May 28.
The interiors of Cloudstreet restaurant.
Pan Pacific Orchard was purpose-built to global sustainability specifications.

site_title: Scam victims in Singapore lost S$385.6 million in first half of 2024 as number of cases hits high of 26,587
summary: Singapore's scam victims lost a record S$385.6 million in the first half of 2024, with 26,587 cases reported, a 16.3% increase from the same period in 2023. The majority of victims (74.2%) were young adults and adults under 50, with investment scams being the most common type. The police prevented over S$204 million in potential losses and took down 2,700 scam-tainted accounts and suspicious advertisements. A new ScamShield App, equipped with AI, can identify and alert users to potential scam threats across WhatsApp, Telegram, and web links.

images.alt_text: The police said they observed an increase in suspicious activity in local bank accounts opened by foreigners.
According to Google, aggregators and telcos will verify a company’s legal identity and sender ID against Singapore’s SMS Sender ID Registry to ensure that messages are only sent by legitimate brands.
By using AI, we can elevate defence and protection mechanisms for consumers and financial institutions,
E-commerce players will be required to verify users who advertise or post about sales of goods and services using government-issued records, among other measures.

site_title: UK factory orders fall again but by less than in July, CBI survey shows
summary: UK factory orders fell again in August, but at a less severe pace than in July, according to a survey. The Confederation of British Industry's monthly net balance of new orders rose to -22 from -32 in July, marking two years of straight negative readings. Output fell for the first time since March, but manufacturers remain confident that output will tick up over the autumn, despite a sustained recovery remaining uncertain.

images.alt_text: File photo: A member of staff works on a car production at the Morgan Motor Company factory in Malvern, Britain, May 12, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Boyers/File photo

site_title: Pound at new 13-month high; euro slips on softer data
summary: The pound rose 0.21% to a new 13-month high against the US dollar at US$1.3129, driven by softer eurozone data and slowing wage growth. The euro slipped 0.1% to US$1.1137. The pound's rise, coupled with the dollar's weakness, supports the case for interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank. Markets now price in more rate cuts from the Fed by year-end than from the ECB or Bank of England, with traders anticipating a 50 basis point cut at the Fed's September meeting.

images.alt_text: The dollar index fell to its lowest since the end of December overnight at 101.30 but was last up 0.12 per cent at 101.51.

site_title: Redoing the tiny apartment
summary: A small HDB flat in Singapore was redesigned by Open Studio to maximize space. The original layout was reconfigured to create an open kitchen and dining area, a monolith pod for the living room, and a compact bedroom with a walk-in wardrobe. The "dead space" corridor was eliminated to create a more fluid spatial layout, making the home feel larger. The redesign showcases that floor area does not directly equate to liveability, and innovative solutions can be used to create a comfortable and functional living space.

site_title: Chanel buys minority stake in cutting-edge Swiss watchmaker MB&F
summary: Chanel has acquired a 25% minority stake in Swiss watchmaker MB&F, providing financial security to the 19-year-old brand amid an industry-wide downturn in demand for expensive timepieces. The deal boosts Chanel's standing in the high horology industry, known for its cutting-edge designs and innovative watch movements. MB&F's founder, Maximilian Büsser, stated that the stake sale ensures the brand's long-term future, citing a favorable context and a prime management team. The partnership aims to bring stability to the brand and capitalize on the high-end watch market.

images.alt_text: British actress Keira Knightley wears the Graphic Line necklace in white gold, platinum, diamonds, sapphire, rubies and onyx, and rings in white gold, platinum, diamonds, sapphires and onyx.

site_title: Billionaire Adani to revamp family offices, hire auditors and CEO to boost oversight
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani plans to revamp his family offices, hiring auditors from a top global firm and a CEO to boost oversight and transparency. The move comes after a tumultuous period last year, following allegations of corporate malfeasance by Hindenburg Research. The new team will oversee the founders' shareholding, prepare financial reports, and provide additional disclosures. The family offices will be fully operational from April 2025, with a structure that may undergo changes in the meantime.

images.alt_text: Adani Enterprises is looking to launch a US$1 billion share sale by mid-September.
While Sebi has yet to make a case against the Adani Group, the regulator had sent Adani officials and Hindenburg notices seeking further information on suspected regulatory violations
The offering of existing shares will mark Adani Enterprises’ return to equity markets after the flagship company scrapped a US$2.5 billion share sale in February last year.

site_title: Thailand's Thaksin backs party's US$14.5 billion handout plan
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra has expressed support for his daughter Paetongtarn's party's US$14.5 billion handout plan, which aims to stimulate the economy. The plan, which involves distributing 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais via a smartphone app, is expected to continue under the incoming government. Thaksin's comments come as the plan has faced criticism from experts and the central bank due to the country's ballooning household debt. The plan's implementation has been uncertain since the previous finance minister's dismissal.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra greets his supporters after landing at Bangkok's Don Mueang airport on August 22, 2023. Thailand's attorney general on April 10, 2024 postponed until May a decision over whether to indict ex-leader Thaksin Shinawatra in a royal insult case. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 22)
summary: Singapore businesses show mixed views on the economy, with 40% planning to expand hiring despite 27% expecting an improvement in the domestic economy. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) annual manpower and wage survey also found that 29% of companies plan to raise wages in the next year. Additionally, platform worker protections will kick in from January 2025, and AIA Singapore's new business value rose 27% in the first half of the year to US$219 million.

site_title:
Investors cautious as regional markets 
close mixed; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended down 0.01% on Thursday, August 22, 2024, after investors became cautious ahead of US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's speech, where a rate cut is expected. Despite a mixed regional market, the STI beat losers 372 to 190, with 1.1 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB declined 0.6%, 0.5%, and 0.4% respectively, while Seatrium led the gainers with a 4.9% rise.

site_title: Singapore Night Festival revisits your childhood dreams
summary: The Singapore Night Festival revisits childhood memories with a nostalgic theme, celebrating the city's past amusement parks from the 1950s to 1970s. The festival features installations and attractions, including a vintage carousel, traditional game stalls, and nostalgia-themed food and beverage stalls. The event is themed "The Art of Play," inspired by Singapore's earliest schools, and runs from Aug 23 to Sep 7 across the Bras Basah-Bugis district.

site_title: Inflows of Singapore unit trust funds jump 88.9% in Q2: Morningstar
summary: Singapore unit trust funds experienced a 88.9% surge in inflows during Q2, reaching S$261.2 million. The average return for CPFIS funds was 3.1% in Q2, down from 4.9% in Q1. Over the past year, CPFIS funds averaged a 9.7% positive return. Higher yields from the funds were the main draw, but sustainability of the trend is uncertain.

site_title: Indonesian protests hit markets, spur rethink of law changes
summary: Thousands of protesters in Indonesia have clashed with police, forcing lawmakers to pause legislation that would have undercut a Constitutional Court ruling on electoral changes. The proposed changes, seen as favoring President Joko Widodo's and his successor Prabowo Subianto's alliance, have sparked widespread protests, with demonstrators burning tires and throwing stones at police. Lawmakers have agreed to reconsider the changes, and the government has vowed to abide by the Constitutional Court's decision. The protests have led to a sharp drop in the rupiah and stocks, raising uncertainty for the business sector and potentially leading to a larger student protest.

images.alt_text: Bahlil Lahadalia, the newly appointed energy minister and the president’s right-hand man, was chosen as party leader at the annual congress of Golkar.

site_title: China’s WeRide delays US IPO just as deadline nears
summary: WeRide, a Chinese autonomous vehicle company, has delayed its US initial public offering (IPO) days before its regulatory approval is set to expire. The company, which was seeking up to $440 million, is still preparing for the IPO and is working to complete documentation for US securities regulators. The delay comes as the US is preparing to widen its confrontation with China over autonomous vehicles. WeRide's IPO would be the first company to see its Chinese regulatory approval lapse during bookbuilding, and it's unclear whether the company will need to reapply for approval or request an extension.

site_title: 🧳 More Singaporean jobseekers set their sights abroad
summary: More Singaporean jobseekers are turning to foreign job opportunities amid uncertainty. According to recent trends, Gen Z individuals are looking to redefine traditional management roles and prioritize skills over corporate jargon. To increase job prospects, Gen Zs are focusing on acquiring skills such as adaptability and creativity. The rise of remote work and the job market's evolving nature are driving Singaporean jobseekers to explore international job opportunities, reflecting the changing needs and aspirations of the younger generation.

images.alt_text: The moves by companies to temper entry-level hiring have fuelled the competition for internship seekers.
Singapore is also no longer a place where foreign talent can start or develop their careers, the way it used to be about a decade ago.

site_title: Baidu reports flat Q2 revenue as China’s economic slowdown hits ad spending
summary: Baidu reports flat Q2 revenue as China's economic slowdown hits ad spending, with net income falling 8% to 7.4 billion yuan. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about its AI position, citing its leading AI platform and 600 million daily requests. Baidu CEO Robin Li expects fierce competition in the next two to three years, but remains confident in the long-term growth of its AI business. The company's online marketing business fell 2% to 19.2 billion yuan, reflecting the slowing Chinese economy.

images.alt_text: More than 500 electric robotaxis built by Baidu currently ply the city’s streets, with plans for an additional 1,000 to be deployed by year-end.
Autonomous driving and machine learning have been core tenets in Baidu’s broader ambitions to expand within the AI sector.
Apollo has started manned test in 11 Chinese cities, and is conducting unmanned auto driving test in Beijing,
Baidu reported revenue of 31.51 billion yuan (S$5.9 billion) for the three months ended Mar 31.

site_title: Vintage Wine Estates wins approval to sell brands to Foley firm
summary: Vintage Wine Estates, a bankrupt California-based vintner, has won court approval to sell five wine brands, including Bar Dog and Cherry Pie, to Foley Family Wines for $15 million. The sale is subject to better offers, with an auction to be held in September if competing bids are received. The company has secured buyers for "almost all of the major assets," according to its representative. This sale is part of Vintage Wine Estates' Chapter 11 protection from creditors, with other stalking horse bids expected in the coming weeks.

Amazon has invested $6.2 billion in its AWS Asia Pacific (Malaysia) Region. Singapore's platform worker protections will kick in from January 2025, with additional cash support for CPF contributions. Meanwhile, Myanmar households are struggling due to the currency tumbling to a record low.

site_title: Timepieces inspired by sea and space
summary: Luxury watch brands IWC, Omega, and Konstantin Chaykin unveiled new timepieces inspired by sea and space. IWC's Polaris Dawn chronograph supports space exploration under the Polaris Program, with a 44.5mm white ceramic case and dark blue lacquered dial. Omega's Seamaster Diver 300M America's Cup celebrates the boat race theme, with a blue ceramic bezel and America's Cup tributes. Konstantin Chaykin's Stargazer features ultra-complex watch movements, anthropomorphic design, and a space exploration theme, priced on application.

site_title: Maximum CPF daily withdrawal limit to be lowered from S$200,000 to S$50,000 as anti-scam measure
summary: The Central Provident Fund Board (CPFB) will lower the maximum daily withdrawal limit from S$200,000 to S$50,000 starting September 25 to combat scams targeting CPF members. Members who plan to make large withdrawals are advised to plan in advance and consider making online withdrawals over multiple days. The move follows a record-high 26,500 reported scams and at least S$385.6 million lost in the first half of 2024, with most victims authorizing withdrawals that were then transferred out of their accounts.

site_title: AIA Singapore’s value of new business rises 27% in H1 to US$219 million
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 27% increase in value of new business (VONB) to US$219 million in the first half of 2024, driven by strong performances across all distribution channels and higher sales of long-term savings products. Annualised new premiums rose 57% to US$417 million, while operating profit after tax increased 2% to US$343 million. The insurer also launched a wealth centre targeting high-net-worth clients and expanded its agency force, with new recruits up 19%.

images.alt_text: AIA’s VONB, which gauges expected profits from new premiums and is a key barometer for future growth, came in at US$1.33 billion in the three months ending March 31 compared with US$1.05 billion a year ago.
Located at Six Battery Road, the AIA Wealth Centre is a one-stop hub offering wealth management services beyond traditional wealth preservation and accumulation consultation.
Changes in portability rules for Integrated Shield plans and riders will need to be thoroughly analysed in terms of intended and unintended impacts on all stakeholders.

site_title: Kamala Harris to cap Democratic convention with historic speech
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris will deliver a historic speech at the Democratic National Convention, accepting the party's presidential nomination and outlining her plans to help the middle class with cuts in prices on groceries and housing, and advancing personal freedoms such as abortion rights. Harris, the first Black, South Asian woman to be nominated for president, has tightened the race against Republican Donald Trump, raising $500 million in the past month and narrowing the gap in national polls.

images.alt_text: U.S. Vice President and Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris attends a campaign rally in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, U.S. August 20, 2024.  REUTERS/Marco Bello

site_title: China banks become surprise winners of frenzied hunt for yield
summary: Chinese banks have become market darlings as investors seek high dividend-yielding assets amidst economic malaise and a clouded investment outlook. The sector has surged 19% this year, outperforming the broader benchmark, with shares of big four state-owned banks reaching record highs. Analysts attribute the rally to rising risk-adverse funds, state support, and low valuations, but warn of potential risks, including over-investment and declining margins. Bank earnings later this month may be the next test for investors to gauge the sector's health.

images.alt_text: Long-term relief for the consumer is unlikely so long as China’s real estate slump squeezes household budgets.
China’s top leaders already signalled a more supportive stance towards growth at a recent Politburo meeting by vowing to shift their focus to consumption.

site_title: UK recruiter Hays annual profit drops 47% on extended hiring periods
summary: Hays, a UK recruiter, reported a 47% drop in annual profit to £105.1 million due to extended hiring periods caused by low confidence levels among jobseekers and employers. The company, which employs 11,000 people across 33 countries, has been closing offices, adjusting headcount, and shutting unprofitable businesses. Despite the decline, Hays' CEO Dirk Hahn stated that the company will achieve £30 million in annual cost savings by FY27.

site_title: The yen carry trade and the importance of sound risk management
summary: Global investors caught on the wrong side of the yen carry trade are still reeling from its dramatic unwinding, which has resulted in billions of dollars in losses. The trade, which involved borrowing yen at low interest rates to invest in riskier assets, saw investors lose confidence in July when the Bank of Japan raised interest rates and the US Federal Reserve signaled a rate cut. The sudden shift in market sentiment led to a sharp correction, with the Nikkei experiencing its worst day since 1987. Market strategists warn that the unwinding may have further room to run, highlighting the importance of sound risk management for investors.

images.alt_text: As a core investment principle, recognising that the best opportunities are not always short-term in nature is crucial.
Whether market conviction around the recession narrative gains momentum depends entirely on the reaction function of the US Federal Reserve.

Investors often sell their stocks when they are expensive. They move into cash hoping to buy the stocks back when they become cheap again. But it may be a very long wait. Meanwhile, expensive stocks continue to outperform.
By the close on Monday, the Nikkei index had wiped out 113 trillion yen (S$1 trillion) of that peak market value.

site_title: Budget carrier AirAsia gets US$443 million private credit funding
summary: AirAsia Bhd secured a US$443 million private credit funding, with Ares Management and Indies Capital Partners providing US$200 million for aircraft refurbishment and aircraft lessors providing US$243 million to refinance lease liabilities. The funding will be used to refurbish planes grounded during the pandemic and expand medium to long-haul network to Europe and West Coast North America. This deal marks the growing popularity of private credit in Asia, offering higher, floating rates of return compared to mainstream lending.

images.alt_text: The global aviation industry has been transformed as the post-pandemic reopening unleashed a wave of pent-up travel demand that’s sent ticket prices surging faster than inflation in many parts of the world.
For AirAsia Bhd’s acquisition, AirAsia Group will not need to pay any purchase price as Capital A will transfer the debt it owes to AirAsia Bhd.
The listing will allow CAPI to access the world’s most extensive and liquid capital markets, and enhance Capital A’s international credibility and presence, Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at 3-week high; focus on central bankers' comments
summary: Japan's Nikkei index rose 0.68% to a three-week high of 38,211.01, recovering from its 12.4% drop on August 5. The Nikkei has bounced back 23% from its low on August 5, but remains below its July peak. Foreign investors exited Japanese cash equities worth 47.9 billion yen. The Nikkei's gain was driven by Uniqlo-brand owner Fast Retailing and Silicon wafer maker Shin-Etsu Chemical, while SoftBank Group fell 1.25%. Central bankers' comments, including Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda's remarks, are expected to shape the market's focus this week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Media members observe the stock quotation board at the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: German business activity contracts in August, PMI shows
summary: German business activity contracted for a second consecutive month in August, with the HCOB German flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 48.5 from 49.1 in July. The manufacturing sector index dropped to 42.1, while the services sector index eased to 51.4, indicating a downturn in the economy. Analysts expect the economy to continue contracting, with some predicting a recession in Germany.

images.alt_text: In Germany, negotiated wages including additional benefits rose 3.1 per cent in the second quarter – half the pace recorded in the preceding three-month period.
Output increased 1.4 per cent from May, surpassing the one per cent median estimate in a Bloomberg survey of analysts.
Driving factors for the rise in Germany's factory orders included the automotive industry, while sectors manufacturing fabricated metal products and other transport equipment also contributed.

site_title: Xiaomi will swallow EV losses to join Tesla in the big leagues
summary: Xiaomi is investing heavily in its electric vehicle (EV) business, prioritizing growth over profits, with a goal to become one of the world's top five carmakers in 15-20 years. The company reported a 25% revenue growth in its EV business since its launch in March, with a net loss of 1.8 billion yuan in the second quarter. Xiaomi plans to expand its EV lineup, develop more models, and sell globally, with a target of delivering 120,000 EVs by 2024 and 300,000 by 2025.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi started shipping its SU7 EVs in early April after announcing it would price its models competitively against Tesla’s offerings.
Xiaomi has entered the auto market in March with its base model SU7 costing 215,900 yuan.
FILE PHOTO: People check new products of Xiaomi ahead of the 2023 Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain February 26, 2023. REUTERS/Nacho Doce/File Photo
Xiaomi’s base model SU7 is about US$4,000 cheaper than the base model of Tesla’s Model 3 in China.

site_title: Hong Kong Airlines eyes used Boeing 787s in long-haul reboot
summary: Hong Kong Airlines plans to relaunch long-haul flights to North America in 2025 with at least three used Boeing 787 Dreamliner jets. The airline, which nearly bankrupted in 2022 after a contentious debt restructuring, aims to restart flights to Vancouver, Toronto, Los Angeles, and Seattle. Hong Kong Airlines also plans to temporarily resume long-haul flights to Australia's Gold Coast next year. The move is expected to boost Boeing's US planemaker, as the airline will be its first new operator of the 787 widebody.

site_title: Hong Kong crypto exchanges face challenges to get full licences
summary: Hong Kong's push for a digital-asset hub faces challenges as 11 crypto exchanges struggle to achieve full licenses after receiving initial approvals. The Securities and Futures Commission found unsatisfactory practices, including over-reliance on a few executives to oversee client assets and inadequate cybercrime protection. The firms must address these concerns to meet the licensing requirements, which are a cornerstone of Hong Kong's Web3 agenda. The outcome is uncertain, threatening the city's status as a digital-asset hub.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority permits retail crypto trading on a limited basis, following efforts to turn the city into a digital asset hub.
Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to become a digital asset hub after rolling out a dedicated regulatory regime last year.

site_title:
Eurozone business activity gets boost from 
Olympics, PMI shows
summary: The Eurozone's business activity showed a surprise boost in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.2, beating expectations. However, the strength may be temporary, with French services activity driven by the Olympic Games, and German business activity contracting for the second consecutive month. The European Central Bank may remain cautious due to rising price pressures, and the ECB's decision to ease policy further may be delayed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People buy fruit and vegetables in a street market in Rome, Italy, August 11, 2016. Picture taken August 11, 2016. REUTERS/Max Rossi

Commercial property prices have fallen sharply due to higher borrowing costs and poor demand as firms adjust to post-pandemic realities, with the ECB estimating that prices may have dropped by close to a tenth last year alone.

Price growth in the 20 countries that share the euro accelerated to 2.6 per cent in July from 2.5 per cent in June according to Eurostat’s flash estimate.
Eurozone gross domestic product rose 0.3 per cent in the three months through June, sustaining the same pace as it did at the start of the year.
Manufacturing remained mired in a downturn, with the index tumbling to 42.1 from 43.2 in July.

site_title: Stocks to watch: StarHub, LHN
summary: StarHub has appointed Han Kwee Juan, DBS Singapore group executive and country head, as its independent director effective September 1. He will also join the risk and sustainability committee. Meanwhile, LHN Group secured 250 new keys across two projects, taking its total to 2,784 keys under management, and secured 28 new facilities management contracts.

site_title: Walmart’s doing so well in China it doesn’t need JD.com anymore
summary: Walmart is exiting a long-time partnership in China due to its strong operations and sales growth. The US retailer's Sam's Club is driving double-digit sales growth, with half of its China sales being digital. This has allowed Walmart to build its own e-commerce app, a rarity in China, where major Western retailers rely on local platforms like Alibaba's Taobao and Tmall. The success of Sam's Club's membership model has also been copied by competitors, further solidifying Walmart's position as the largest hypermarket operator in China.

images.alt_text: A Sam’s Club discount warehouse chain store in Shenzhen. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The consumer environment in general is worsening and growth is evaporating given the economic uncertainty.
A Walmart store in Secaucus, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Walmart is revamping more than 800 store locations and adding high-end products. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
A Walmart store in Secaucus, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Walmart is revamping more than 800 store locations and adding high-end products. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

Walmart has been making moves to shrink its workforce over the past year and had said in April last year that it expects about 65 per cent of its stores to be serviced by automation by the end of its fiscal year 2026.

site_title: Gold holds near record high as Fed minutes fuel rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices remain near record highs, holding steady at US$2,511.80 per ounce, as traders await US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech for insights on a potential September interest rate cut. Minutes from the Fed's July meeting showed officials are inclined towards a rate cut, with a 62% chance of a 25bps cut, according to the CME FedWatch tool. The Fed's decision will influence the Jackson Hole Economic Symposium and affect gold prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,514.79 per ounce.

site_title: Tampines executive condominium site for 560 units put up for sale
summary: A 560-unit executive condominium site in Tampines Street 95 has been put up for sale, with a tender closing on October 24. The site, which spans 22,488.9 square meters, is expected to attract at least four bids, ranging between S$650 and S$750 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale of the site could set a new record land rate for EC plots, following the recent sale of a nearby site for S$729 per square foot. The Tampines site is part of a mature estate with a large pool of potential buyers looking to upgrade to an EC, and market watchers expect it to sell well.

images.alt_text: An EC site in Pasir Ris fetched a record-high land price for ECs or S$557 million or S$729 psf ppr.

The state land site for an executive condominium development at Jalan Loyang Besar (pictured) drew XXX bids, a sharp contrast from the private residential site at Margaret Drive, which fetched just XXX bids.

site_title: Amazon to invest US$6.2 billion in Malaysia through 2038
summary: Amazon has announced plans to invest US$6.2 billion in Malaysia through 2038, with its new Asia-Pacific (Malaysia) Region expected to contribute US$12.1 billion to the country's GDP and create over 3,500 jobs annually. The region, which includes three zones, will provide developers and organizations with enhanced cloud infrastructure options, enabling the use of AI and machine learning technologies. The investment is part of AWS's commitment to upskilling Malaysia's workforce and achieving net-zero carbon across its operations by 2040.

images.alt_text: The Philippines’ gambling sector is the third largest in Asia, next in size only to Macau and Singapore.
FlightAware said more than 21,000 flights were slowed globally, and travel disruptions were expected to stretch into the coming days.
Amazon’s AWS data centres are spread across dozens of regions, serving as a kind of engine room to the online world.

site_title: Bank of Korea signals rate cuts as inflation, growth slow
summary: The Bank of Korea held its benchmark interest rate at 3.50% as expected, but signaled readiness to ease policy as inflation and growth eased. The decision, which was anticipated by 38 out of 40 economists, suggests a potential rate cut at the October meeting, following a slowdown in price pressures and growth. The Bank of Korea will examine the timing of rate cuts while maintaining a restrictive monetary policy stance.

images.alt_text: South KOrea home housing Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
South Korea relies heavily on imports of energy and raw materials to assemble products destined for shipment overseas.
Apartment prices in the Seoul area rose 0.32 per cent last week, the biggest weekly gain since September 2018.

site_title: South Korean pet care goes high-tech with AI diagnostics
summary: South Korea is embracing AI in pet care with the introduction of "X Caliber," an AI-powered software that diagnoses X-ray abnormalities in animals in seconds. Developed by SK Telecom, the software has a 86% disease detection rate and is helping veterinarians pinpoint issues quickly and accurately. The technology is also being used in veterinary hospitals in the US, Australia, and Southeast Asia to address a shortage of trained staff. The move is part of South Korea's broader push into AI healthcare, with plans to expand into additional domains.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is one of the few big companies that break out AI contributions in their quarterly earnings, as most firms are yet to see a big boost from AI investments.

site_title: Chinese EV maker BYD eyes state incentives for Mexico plant
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD is reviewing incentives from three Mexican states to locate a manufacturing plant. The company, which has previously stated it was not targeting the US market, aims to produce 150,000 units in its first stage and up to 500,000 units in subsequent years. BYD's Mexico director general, Jorge Vallejo, said the company is evaluating fiscal, land, and management incentives, but did not name the states offering them. The plant will serve the Mexican market and is expected to be centrally located in the country, with a goal of identifying the location by year-end.

images.alt_text: Denza models at a shopping mall in Beijing, China.
BYD aims to introduce additional models, including both battery-electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, to the market at a later date.
Separately on Wednesday, BYD announced a partnership with Uber Technologies to put 100,000 EVs onto the ride-hailing company’s platform.

site_title: Binance hiring 1,000 as compliance spending tops US$200 million
summary: Binance is hiring 1,000 people, with a focus on compliance roles, as the company's annual spending to meet regulatory requirements tops $200 million. CEO Richard Teng, a former regulator, aims to have a 700-strong compliance workforce by the end of 2024. The hiring spree follows a rebound in crypto prices and trading volumes, and comes after Binance agreed to a $4.3 billion penalty for allowing criminals and terror groups to use the exchange. The company faces years of compliance monitoring by US agencies.

images.alt_text: Richard Teng Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: Didi turns profitable as ride-hailing arm grows ahead of IPO
summary: Didi Global, China's leading ride-hailing provider, has turned profitable in the June quarter with a net profit of 1.4 billion yuan (S$256 million). Revenue climbed 4.1% to 50.9 billion yuan, driven by a record number of ride-hailing transactions. The company's shares rose 2.3% following the earnings report, and it now aims to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, although the timeline remains unclear. Didi's business has recovered from a tough few years, following a fine and delisting from the New York stock exchange in 2022.

site_title: Senior Thai politician to face probe for slapping reporter
summary: Thai politician Prawit Wongsuwan is facing a probe after being filmed slapping a reporter, Duangthip Yiamphop, as she attempted to ask him questions about the new prime minister. The incident occurred on August 16 and was captured on video. The Thai parliament has launched an investigation, and Prawit could potentially face suspension or a lifetime ban if found guilty of a serious ethical violation. The Thai Journalists' Association has condemned Prawit's actions, calling them threatening and harassing.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Thailand's then-deputy prime minister Prawit Wongsuwan, speaks to members at a meeting outlining the Palang Pracharath Party's policies ahead of the general election in Bangkok on February 10, 2023. Thailand's parliament said it would investigate senior politician and former army chief Prawit Wongsuwan after he was filmed on August 16, 2024 slapping a reporter as she tried to ask him questions. site_title: Second-biggest diamond ever is found in mine in Botswana
summary: A 2,492-carat diamond, the second-largest stone ever discovered, has been found in Botswana's Karowe mine by Canada's Lucara Diamond. The massive stone, discovered using x-ray technology, is yet to be thoroughly assessed for gem quality. The find is a significant boost for Lucara, even if the diamond is not of gem quality. The recovery of such a large stone demonstrates the effectiveness of Lucara's approach to diamond recovery, according to CEO William Lamb.

site_title: More businesses plan to raise hiring in the next year, despite expectations for the economy remaining mixed: SBF poll
summary: According to a Singapore Business Federation (SBF) poll, 40% of companies plan to expand hiring in the next 12 months, despite only 27% expecting the domestic economy to improve. Businesses are cautious about higher manpower costs and limited local talent, with rising costs and work pass woes being top challenges. Fewer companies plan to cut headcount, and those who do cite decline in business activity, economic uncertainty, and cost management as reasons. The survey also found that more companies are planning to increase investment in staff training, flexible work arrangements, and redeployment of staff.

site_title: Blackstone nears purchase of Hyatt Clearwater Beach in Florida
summary: Blackstone is in talks to acquire the Hyatt Regency Clearwater Beach Resort and Spa in Florida for around $200 million. The alternative asset manager is discussing a purchase from Westmont Hospitality Group, which acquired the property for $121 million in 2016. The proposed transaction comes as hotel demand normalizes after a post-COVID recovery, with similar deals in Florida and other markets. A transaction has not been finalized, and terms could change or talks could collapse.

site_title: China’s slowing economy sparks calls to raise deficit ceiling
summary: China's slowing economy has sparked calls to raise the country's deficit ceiling, allowing the central government to borrow more to boost growth. Despite cutting interest rates, the housing market remains stagnant and job creation is slow. Economists, including Zhang Ming, a deputy director at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, recommend doubling or tripling this year's special sovereign bonds to subsidize consumers and alleviate local government debt risks. They also suggest increasing the deficit ceiling to 3% of gross domestic product to give the Ministry of Finance more policy flexibility.

images.alt_text: People walk at a shopping mall in Beijing on August 12, 2024. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP)

Women at an antenatal course in Yichun, China, Aug 21, 2024. China is rapidly running out of mothers. The number of women of reproductive age, defined by the United Nations as 15-to-49, is set to drop by more than two-thirds to under 100 million by the end of the century.

site_title: Australia’s services activity rises, costs gain in rates worry
summary: Australia's private sector business activity rose at the fastest pace in three months, driven by expansionary services sectors and rising employment and input costs. The services activity index rose to 52.2 in August, while the composite purchasing managers' index (PMI) advanced to 51.4. This suggests monetary policy may not be tight enough to dampen price and demand pressures, with inflationary risks remaining. The Reserve Bank of Australia may still need to raise interest rates further before easing measures can be implemented.

The index measuring whether it was a good time to buy major household items bounced 0.6 per cent, but remains historically low at 82.6.

site_title: China Evergrande subsidiary dealings raise prospects for offshore creditors
summary: China Evergrande's offshore creditors may increase their chances of recovering funds through subsidiaries, as they can prove the property developer lent money to onshore restructured businesses. Experts say this avenue could lead to higher seniority for creditors, potentially recouping up to US$23 billion in liabilities. However, recovery will be challenging, with a lengthy and complex process, and may clash with onshore creditors pursuing the same assets. The Hong Kong ruling designating offshore shareholders as shareholders of onshore assets is not automatically recognized in mainland China.

site_title: Japan’s August factory activity declines slow: survey
summary: Japan's factory activity declined in August, but at a slower pace than in the previous month, according to a business survey. The service sector, however, expanded, indicating upbeat conditions in some industries. Rising price pressures and labor constraints remain concerns for Japanese firms, particularly in the service sector. The manufacturing PMI rose to 49.5 in August from 49.1 in July. The economy expanded in the second quarter, rebounding from a slump at the start of the year due to rises in consumption and capital spending.

images.alt_text: Exports gained 10.3 per cent from a year ago, accelerating from 5.4 per cent in the previous month, Japan's Ministry of Finance reported.

Japan's core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the six to nine months ahead, rose in June by 2.1 per cent from the previous month, Cabinet Office data showed.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggles to track Wall Street up after US jobs, Fed minutes
summary: Asia's stocks struggled to follow Wall Street's gains on Thursday after softer-than-expected US jobs data and minutes from the Federal Reserve's July meeting showed officials open to an interest rate cut. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney rose, while Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, and Taipei fell. Investors expect the Fed to begin unwinding its monetary tightening campaign, with some predicting a 50 basis point cut in September. The next Fed chief Jerome Powell's speech in Jackson Hole is expected to provide further clarity on the central bank's plans.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3 per cent higher on Wednesday, having snapped a five-day winning streak on Tuesday, with all the major regional bourses logging gains.

site_title: PwC expects six-month ban in China for Evergrande audit: report
summary: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) China's audit unit expects a six-month ban from the Chinese government, starting as early as September, due to its audit of failed property giant China Evergrande Group. The ban, potentially accompanied by a large fine, would restrict PwC from signing off on financial results and IPOs. This would be the toughest action taken by a Big Four firm against Chinese regulators. Over 30 Chinese listed firms, including state-owned giants, have dropped PwC as their auditor this year following scrutiny over its role in an alleged accounting fraud at Evergrande.

images.alt_text: pwc Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore’s platform worker protections kick in from Jan 2025; more cash support for CPF contributions
summary: Singapore's platform worker protections, aimed at improving financial security for ride-hailing and on-demand delivery workers, will kick in from January 1, 2025. The government will fully foot the rise in workers' Central Provident Fund (CPF) payments in 2025, 75% in 2026, and taper off to cease in 2029. Platform workers will be allowed to join union-like bodies, and companies must provide work injury compensation and contribute to CPF savings schemes. The government has also enhanced its CPF transition support scheme for low-wage platform workers.

site_title: Malaysian bonds set to gain most in EM Asia from Treasury rally
summary: Malaysian bonds are expected to gain the most in EM Asia from a Treasury rally amid bets on the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cuts. The 30-day correlation between EM Asia bonds and 10-year US yields has risen to 0.29, with Malaysian bonds having the highest correlation of 0.53 in the region. This suggests Malaysian bonds will outperform peers as investors seek safe-haven assets. The rally is driven by expectations of the Fed's interest-rate cuts, which are expected to boost yields and make Malaysian bonds more attractive.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's stock market is leading peers in South-east Asia with a 12 per cent advance this year, while the number of initial public offerings have surged. More gains await if Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim is able cut more subsidies and reduce the fiscal deficit, investors said.
In the first quarter of 2024, Malaysia's year-on-year growth came in at a stronger-than-expected 4.2 per cent on higher household spending and a turnaround in exports.
Malaysia wants to establish at least 10 local companies in design and advanced packaging for semiconductor chips, with revenues between $210 million to $1 billion, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.3% lower at 3,364.53, following overnight gains in global markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell despite 23.9 million securities changing hands. Key losers included Genting Singapore (-1.2%), CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (-0.5%), and banking stocks such as DBS (-0.3%) and UOB (-0.2%). Global markets await the Federal Reserve's address on Friday, with stocks rising in Europe and the US.

images.alt_text: Han Kwee Juan will become StarHub's independent director from Sep 1.

site_title: Ola Electric shares surge 82% post-debut to hit US$7 billion value
summary: Ola Electric's shares surged 82% post-debut, reaching a market capitalization of over $7 billion, making it India's biggest IPO in two years. The company's founder, Bhavish Aggarwal, achieved his target valuation sooner than expected due to strong investor demand. This surge is attributed to investors' confidence in India's electric vehicle (EV) story and the country's growing appetite for new technology businesses. Ola's stellar debut comes after a rally in other Indian tech companies, with shares of Zomato and PB Fintech more than doubling this year.

site_title: United Food says it will be delisted for failing to address issues raised in auditor’s report
summary: United Food Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to its failure to address concerns raised by auditors KPMG in an August 5 special report. Despite providing supplemental information, SGX RegCo found the issues unaddressed, including "unusual" cash transactions and potential contraventions of SGX listing rules. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since September 2021, and it also failed to meet criteria to exit the watch list, leading to the delisting decision.

images.alt_text: KPMG says United Holdings and its directors has potentially breached several listing rules involving the group's proposed acquisition announced in 2017, among others.

Thilan Wickramasinghe, head of research for Singapore at Maybank Securities, said that while individual corporate strategies should be assessed based on their own merits, a higher debt ratio typically leads to higher risks for companies.

site_title: Where are the SMEs in Singapore’s AI story?
summary: Only 4% of Singapore's SMEs have adopted artificial intelligence (AI) or machine learning, despite 95% having adopted digital tools. SMEs face obstacles in integrating AI due to complexity, uncertainty, and lack of clear use cases. To overcome these challenges, SMEs should prioritize practical applications, leverage built-in solutions, and tap into government support. By doing so, SMEs can enhance customer experiences, drive operational efficiency, and grow revenue, ultimately positioning themselves for growth and success in a challenging business landscape.

images.alt_text: While Singapore has made good progress in supporting enterprises to use technologies over the past 30 years, “much more” can be done, said Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information Tan Kiat How.
Areas where SMEs can adopt AI include marketing and customer engagement, says Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

From left: Yeo Hiang Meng, FMAS president; Andy Hoon, FMAS vice president; Tan Tong Hai, chairman of the Nanyang Polytechnic Board of Governors; Albert Lim, director of Nanyang Polytechnic's School of Design & Media; and Esther Ho, Nanyang Polytechnic's deputy principal of lifelong learning and enterprise services.

site_title: BT Podcasts: Discretionary portfolio management will grow your wealth
summary: A recent podcast from BT discusses discretionary portfolio management as a way to grow wealth. The podcast emphasizes the importance of seeking professional advice before making investment decisions. Key takeaways include understanding one's financial goals and risk tolerance, diversifying investments, and regularly reviewing and adjusting portfolios. By adopting a discretionary approach to portfolio management, individuals can potentially increase their wealth over time.

site_title: Temasek’s 10-year yuan bonds yield 2.75%; its 30-year bonds pay out 3.1%
summary: Temasek, a state investor, issued 1 billion 10-year and 1.7 billion 30-year offshore Chinese yuan bonds with yields of 2.75% and 3.1% respectively. The bonds will be used to fund Temasek and its investment holding companies, and have been rated "Aaa" and "AAA" by Moody's and S&P Global Ratings. This is Temasek's first offshore Chinese yuan bond issuance of the year, following previous placements in February and March.

images.alt_text: Temasek launches dual tranche offering of 10-year and 30-year offshore Chinese yuan bonds
Temasek branding during a news conference in Singapore on July 9.Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: Elon Musk’s Neuralink says second trial implant went well, no thread retraction issue
summary: Elon Musk's Neuralink has successfully completed a second trial implant, with patient Alex showing no issues with thread retraction. Unlike the first patient, Noland Arbaugh, who experienced thread retraction, Alex's implant has stabilized. Neuralink implemented measures to prevent similar issues, including reducing brain motion during surgery and limiting the gap between the implant and the brain. The device has allowed Alex to play video games, browse the internet, and move a cursor on a laptop, demonstrating its potential to help people with spinal cord injuries.

images.alt_text: Neuralink is in the process of testing its device, which is intended to help people with spinal cord injuries.
In upcoming surgeries, Neuralink will make some changes to try to mitigate the issue of its electrode threads retracting from brain tissue,

The Chinese government’s announcement is a signal that it intends to accelerate the development of similar technologies to rival western competitors like Neuralink after mostly concentrating its efforts thus far in academic research settings.
Neuralink is seeking to implant its device in more human subjects.

site_title: LHN secures 250 more co-living keys in Q3
summary: LHN Limited secured 250 new co-living keys in Q3 FY2024, bringing its total to 2,784 keys across Singapore and overseas projects. The company also added 16 new car parks to its management portfolio, increasing its car park management to 94 lots in Singapore. Occupancy rates remained above 90% across its industrial, commercial, and co-living spaces. This expansion is attributed to the company's proactive capital recycling initiatives and positioning for sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Coliwoo, LHN's co-living brand, is expected to drive the company's residential business.

site_title: China premier meets Putin, vows more cooperation with Russia
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang met with Russian President Vladimir Putin, reaffirming their countries' commitment to cooperation and stability. China has become Russia's main trading partner since the 2022 invasion of Ukraine, and the two leaders discussed exploring new opportunities in scientific and technological innovations, industrial development, and consolidating their partnership in traditional areas. Li emphasized the benefits of their partnership for regional and global peace, stability, and prosperity.

images.alt_text: Long-term relief for the consumer is unlikely so long as China’s real estate slump squeezes household budgets.
President Xi Jinping gets a lot of economic advice. Beijing is urged – or admonished – to boost consumer spending, rein in exports, curb overcapacity, and clean up local-government debt.
China’s top leaders already signalled a more supportive stance towards growth at a recent Politburo meeting by vowing to shift their focus to consumption.

site_title: Beauty retailer Sephora cuts China jobs as market slumps
summary: Sephora, a beauty retailer owned by LVMH, is cutting 120 jobs in China, equivalent to less than 3% of its workforce, due to a slump in the country's property market and consumer confidence. The move comes as consumers reduce spending on high-end perfumes and makeup. Sephora has around 350 stores in China and sells products online, but has not performed well in the country. The cut is part of a restructuring effort to ensure long-term sustainable growth in China.

images.alt_text: Top Swiss brand Rolex has served as the official timekeeping sponsor of Formula one since 2013, its signature green and gold adverts becoming commonplace at F1 tracks.

Sales at LVMH, owner of labels Louis Vuitton, Tiffany and Hennessy, grew to 20.98 billion euros (S$30.6 billion), a 1 per cent rise on an organic basis, which strips out currency effects and acquisitions.
The investigation into suppliers for LVMH’s second-largest fashion label shows potential worker exploitation in the US$1.6 trillion global luxury goods industry.

site_title: Microsoft rejigs reporting on business units, offers clarity on AI benefits
summary: Microsoft has restructured its quarterly earnings report to provide clearer insights into its AI contributions. The company has moved search and news advertising revenue under the Azure cloud-computing unit and will now report AI and speech technology services revenue under its productivity business, which includes the Office suite. This change aims to align the reporting structure with its business management. The move is seen as a step towards offering investors a clearer picture on the benefits of AI investments.

images.alt_text: Microsoft's report follows recent statements by senior US Intelligence officials that they’d seen Iran ramp up use of clandestine social media accounts with the aim to use them to try to sow political discord in the United States.

Big Tech firms such as Microsoft are a dominant force in the US and global equity markets, and play a role in driving the future of the global economy.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange sees 9% profit gain on rising trading
summary: Hong Kong Exchange & Clearing (HKEX) reported a 9% profit gain in the second quarter, driven by a 47% increase in trading flows from mainland China. Core revenue rose 7% and investment income jumped 37%. The surge in trading is attributed to mainland Chinese investors seeking diversification amid market turbulence in Shanghai and Shenzhen. HKEX's CEO, Bonnie Chan, attributed the growth to its role as a "super connector" and a pick-up in initial public offerings.

site_title: PropertyBT: Get to grips with the HDB resale market (Ep 34)
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore has seen strong performance, with prices nudging up further in July. Experts discuss the factors driving this trend, including private home downgraders and a spike in million-dollar deals. The possibility of a price correction is also considered, with some speculating that the BTO eligibility criteria should be expanded to alleviate pressure on resale units.

images.alt_text: Extending generous aid to buyers of HDB homes can help fuel inflation of HDB resale and private home prices.
Amid rising HDB resale flat prices, let more people be eligible to buy more affordably priced BTO units.
More than half of the resale flats transactions were from non-mature estates.

site_title: Americans say it takes US$2.5 million to be considered wealthy
summary: Americans now believe it takes a net worth of $2.5 million to be considered wealthy, a 14% increase from last year, according to the Charles Schwab Modern Wealth survey. The perception of wealth varies by age, with baby boomers defining it as $2.8 million and millennials at $2.2 million. The survey also found that 10% of Americans are already considered wealthy, while 22% believe they are on track to be wealthy in the future.

site_title: Philippine ex-mayor linked to Chinese crime rings fled to Singapore in July: Filipino authorities
summary: Philippine ex-mayor Alice Guo, linked to Chinese crime rings, fled to Singapore in July after facing a Senate hearing. Guo, who was removed from office for grave misconduct, is accused of ties to a money laundering syndicate and human trafficking activities. She allegedly met her parents in Singapore and left for Indonesia on August 18. Philippine authorities have issued an immigration lookout bulletin order, but Guo is not considered a person of interest in the S$3 billion money laundering case. Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr vowed to expose those responsible for her escape, promising "heads will roll."

images.alt_text: Over the course of 2021, Wang Qiming helped to forge documents from Indonesian companies and other paperwork to mask the source of deposits into Citibank accounts, the charge sheets alleged.
Malaysian national Besmond Huan Yu Kang, 22, was arrested for his suspected involvement in money laundering activities using Singapore bank accounts.
Liew Yik Kit, who was the personal driver to Cambodian national Su Binghai, was handed two charges on Aug 15.
The biggest money laundering probe in Singapore saw about $3 billion in cash and assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders.
The Bill will introduce several proposals to improve the processes involved in dealing with seized properties including those linked to money laundering.

site_title: China’s fresh urbanisation push may thwart ‘birth-friendly society’ goal
summary: China's "birth-friendly society" initiative, aimed at increasing fertility rates, may be hindered by the country's rapid urbanization push. The number of women of reproductive age is expected to drop by over two-thirds to under 100 million by the end of the century, largely due to high housing costs, limited space, and expensive education in cities. Experts argue that improving rural living standards could have a more sustainable impact on economic growth and birth rates. China's urbanization rate is lower than that of Japan and South Korea, offering potential room for maneuver, but addressing the root causes of low fertility rates, such as stress and limited family planning options, is crucial.

images.alt_text: Women learn knowledge of taking care of mothers and newborn babies in a neighborhood committee in Yichun, in central China's Jiangxi province on August 21, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Trump holds first outdoor rally since attempted assassination
summary: Donald Trump held his first outdoor campaign event since an assassination attempt, speaking behind bulletproof glass at a rally in North Carolina. The Republican candidate criticized Democratic opponent Kamala Harris, calling her the "most radical left person" to run for the White House. Trump claimed that millions of jobs will "vanish overnight" if Harris wins in November, and warned that her victory would lead to the loss of life savings. The event took place at the North Carolina Aviation Museum & Hall of Fame in Asheboro, North Carolina.

Harris is riding a historic whirlwind into the convention: her campaign has broken fundraising records, packed arenas with supporters, and turned opinion polls in some battleground states in Democrats’ favour.

site_title: China’s beef demand poised for smallest growth in a decade, USDA says
summary: China's beef consumption is expected to rise by 0.25% in 2025, marking the smallest growth in a decade, due to economic headwinds. The country is forecast to consume 11.712 million tons of beef next year. Simultaneously, China's pork consumption is predicted to fall 2% in 2025, largely due to shifts in dietary habits and negative economic factors. The USDA's Foreign Agricultural Service attributes these trends to the country's slowing economy and its impact on the hotel, restaurant, and retail industries.

site_title: Zomato to buy Paytm’s movie ticketing business for US$244 million
summary: Zomato agreed to buy Paytm's movie and events ticketing business for 20.5 billion rupees (S$319 million) in cash, expanding into adjacent areas beyond food delivery. This deal will help Zomato capitalize on its success and increase revenue. For Paytm, the sale will sharpen its focus on core businesses, including payments and financial services, to broaden its merchant base and increase revenue. The entertainment ticketing business generated nearly three billion rupees in sales and 290 million rupees in adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization in the fiscal year to March 2024.

site_title: Geely says EU tariffs would have big impact as earnings climb
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed Chinese automaker, warns that proposed EU tariffs on its electric vehicles could significantly impact sales in the European market. The company, which owns brands such as Volvo, Lotus, and Zeekr, sees the tariffs, which could reach 19.3%, as a major blow. Despite this, Geely has reported a 575% rise in net income to 10.6 billion yuan for the first half of 2024, driven by strong sales of plug-in hybrids and electric vehicles.

Zeekr’s upgraded lithium iron phosphate battery.

site_title: SGX-listed agri-commodity players post resilient earnings despite dent from forex losses and higher rates
summary: SINGAPORE-listed agri-commodity players posted resilient earnings despite foreign exchange losses and elevated interest rates. Crude palm oil prices remain under pressure due to competition from alternative edible oils, uncertainties over import demand, and expected supply shocks from the La Nina event. Analysts expect CPO prices to remain firm in the near term, with some predicting a slight decline to RM3,700 per tonne by end-2024. Agribusiness giants like Wilmar International and First Resources registered earnings growth, while others like Kencana Agri and Bumitama Agri saw weaker results due to forex losses and lower revenue.

site_title: Deutsche Bank strikes deal with Postbank ex-shareholders
summary: Deutsche Bank reached agreements with over 80 former shareholders of Postbank, representing 60% of total claims, in a dispute over the 2010 takeover. The deal, valued at 31 euros (S$44) per share, will cost 45% of the 1.3 billion euros set aside for the litigation. The settlement is expected to have a positive impact on Deutsche Bank's third-quarter operating profit, estimated at 430 million euros. The litigation provision contributed to Deutsche Bank's first quarterly loss in four years in the second quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: Any settlement would mark a significant development in years-long litigation that has cast a shadow over Deutsche Bank and recently forced it to set aside 1.3 billion euros (S$1.88 billion) ahead of any possible payout.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Deutsche Bank is seen in Brussels, Belgium December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Deutsche Bank's net loss attributable to shareholders was 143 million euros in the second quarter.

site_title: US home-purchase applications slide to lowest since February
summary: US home-purchase applications slid to the lowest level since February, falling 5.2% to 130.6, amid high home prices despite more favorable mortgage rates. Refinancing applications also tumbled after reaching a two-year high. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate eased to 6.5%, still the lowest since May last year, but high home prices have pushed housing affordability to its lowest level in decades, despite expected easier Fed monetary policy.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly higher with payrolls revisions, Fed minutes on tap
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, August 21, driven by revised payrolls data and Federal Reserve minutes. The S&P 500 rose 6.0 points, or 0.11%, to 5,603.09, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 23.6 points, or 0.13%, to 17,840.51. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 46.1 points, or 0.11%, to 40,881.03, amid investor anticipation of the updated data and policy meeting minutes.

site_title: Cristiano Ronaldo launches YouTube channel
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo has launched his YouTube channel, which gained 1.69 million subscribers within two hours of posting his first video. The 39-year-old footballer, who plays for Saudi Arabian club Al Nassr, has a massive social media following, with 112.5 million followers on X, 170 million on Facebook, and 636 million on Instagram. Ronaldo announced the launch on his social media accounts, inviting fans to subscribe to his new channel.

site_title: Federal Reserve steaming towards September rate cut, minutes from meeting show
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates in September, with a "vast majority" of officials indicating a likely rate cut. The Fed's policy-setting committee left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in July, but minutes from the meeting showed some policymakers would have been willing to reduce borrowing costs. Financial markets expect a full percentage point worth of rate cuts by the end of the year, citing the cooling of inflationary pressures and a rise in joblessness. The Fed's concerns about the job market may be underpinned by the US Labor Department's estimate of 818,000 fewer payroll jobs in March.

site_title: Here’s what private equity may be getting right
summary: Private equity (PE) groups may be getting it right in their approach to company boards. PE-controlled boards are more hands-on, have relevant expertise, and are bolder and more innovative. This could be the reason behind EQT's recent offer for loss-making PropertyGuru Group, which may be undervalued by the public market. PropertyGuru's $1.78 billion valuation after its 2022 merger with Bridgetown 2 Holdings suggests potential that may only be accessible through PE ownership.

site_title: Temasek mulling exit from Schneider Electric India venture
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investment company, is considering an exit from its joint venture with Schneider Electric in India. The company has been discussing options, including selling its minority stake to Schneider or another party, or going public through an initial public offering. Schneider Electric acquired a 65% stake in the Indian business in 2020, with Temasek holding the remaining 35%. The potential exit has raised questions about the future of the joint venture and Temasek's strategic priorities.

images.alt_text: Temasek branding during a news conference in Singapore on July 9.Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks rise after dovish Fed minutes
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday following dovish Federal Reserve meeting minutes that indicated a "vast majority" of policymakers support a September interest rate cut. Futures markets now see a slightly greater chance of a 0.50 percentage point cut, but analysts remain divided on the likelihood of a "soft landing" that avoids a US recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gained 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6%.

images.alt_text: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, June 28, 2024. Wall Street traders sent stocks toward fresh all-time highs as signs of inflation cooling reinforced bets the Federal Reserve will be able to start cutting interest rates this year. site_title: US payrolls likely to be 818,000 lower after preliminary revision
summary: US job growth was likely less robust in the year through March than previously reported, with payrolls revised down by 818,000 for the 12 months. This represents a decline of around 68,000 jobs per month, with economists largely anticipating a decline. The revised figures are due early next year and may be influenced by factors such as business closures and unauthorized immigrant worker counts. The benchmark revision aims to provide a more accurate picture of the labor market, which may be cooling faster than initially reported.

site_title: StarHub appoints DBS executive Han Kwee Juan as independent director
summary: StarHub appoints DBS executive Han Kwee Juan as an independent director, effective September 1, 2024. Han, who previously served as DBS' group head of strategy and planning from 2019 to 2023, will also join the telco's risk and sustainability committee. He will undergo training on the roles and responsibilities of a director, despite having no prior experience as a director of another listed issuer.

Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Artificial intelligence is losing hype
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is losing hype, with Western firms' share prices dropping by 15% as investors question the technology's limitations. Despite significant investments, only 4.8% of American companies use AI, down from 5.4% earlier this year. The "hype cycle" theory, popularized by Gartner, suggests that AI will follow a similar pattern of euphoria, disillusionment, and eventual mainstream adoption. However, the Economist's analysis suggests that the cycle is a rarity, with only a fifth of breakthrough technologies experiencing the full cycle. The future of AI remains uncertain, and its success depends on proving its benefits to the real economy.

images.alt_text: Generative artificial intelligence could transform life as we know it.
Generative artificial intelligence could hurt or help businesses.

site_title: In a rout no one’s safe, ESG-compliant or not
summary: Major stock markets worldwide plummeted on August 5 due to weak US jobs data, disappointing Big Tech earnings, and rate hikes by the Bank of Japan. ESG-compliant investors shouldn't be spooked by short-term portfolio performance, as ESG indices mostly tracked their vanilla benchmarks during this period. However, investors who believe structural ESG-related risks will continue to increase may see the recent sell-off as an opportunity to pick up ESG value. ESG risks and opportunities are typically assessed over longer-term periods, and ESG is not a material factor in every market correction.

images.alt_text: As at end-June, DBS is the only Singapore banked to be selected by the PBOC for the programme.

site_title: Starbucks banks on pumpkin spice latte to reverse sales slump
summary: Starbucks is relying on the return of its pumpkin spice latte, a fan-favourite autumn beverage, to reverse two quarters of same-store sales declines. The product will be available for the 21st straight year starting August 22. The company is also introducing new apple-based beverages, including a iced apple non-dairy cream chai, to boost sales. The move comes after the ousting of its CEO and follows a strategy to focus on seasonal offerings to drive customer traffic back into stores.

site_title: Tether to launch stablecoin pegged to UAE’s dirham
summary: Tether, a cryptocurrency company, plans to launch a new stablecoin pegged to the United Arab Emirates dirham (AED), the country's currency. The move aims to tap into demand for the Gulf currency and offer alternatives to the US dollar. The stablecoin will be fully backed by liquid UAE-based reserves and is expected to be launched in collaboration with Phoenix Group and Green Acorn Investment. The UAE is seeking to become a global hub for the crypto industry, with regulators having already enabled cryptocurrency payments in areas like real estate and school fees.

Tether's investment plan highlights the growing financial clout and ambition of the issuer of the world’s largest stablecoin, a type of cryptocurrency designed to track a real-world asset one-to-one.

site_title: Court of Appeal upholds dismissal of Winson’s claim against OCBC and StanChart
summary: The Court of Appeal upheld the High Court's decision to dismiss Winson Oil Trading's US$60.9 million claim against OCBC and Standard Chartered over payment disputes related to collapsed oil trader Hin Leong Trading in 2020. The court ruled that Winson's claim was dismissed due to the "fraud exception" for letters of credit, citing Winson's recklessness in ignoring red flags and using forged bills of lading. The Supreme Court's upper division reaffirmed this decision, dismissing Winson's appeals.

site_title: Europe: Auto leads shares higher, Fed minutes in focus
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, led by automobile stocks, snapping a five-day winning streak. The Stoxx 600 index advanced, with basic resources and healthcare also gaining. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's July meeting minutes, expected to reinforce a dovish stance. The US Labor Department reported fewer jobs added than expected, highlighting concerns about the jobs market. Key individual stocks included Demant's 2% rise after Morgan Stanley upgraded its rating, and Moncler's 2% gain after Bernstein upgraded it to "outperform".

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, August 12, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate at 2.50%
summary: The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee held its one-day repurchase rate at 2.50% for a fifth consecutive meeting, as expected. This decision is seen as a sign that a rate cut is unlikely until the second quarter of 2025. The rate has remained steady since September 2023, following a 200 basis point increase over eight meetings from August 2022. The decision comes amidst fiscal policy uncertainty and a sluggish economy, with the median forecast of economists predicting a rate cut will not occur until then.

images.alt_text: Thailand, South-east Asia’s second-largest economy, grew 2.3 per cent in the April-June quarter from a year earlier, accelerating from the 1.6 per cent growth in the prior quarter.

site_title: Where have all the fine diners gone?
summary: Fine dining in Singapore is experiencing a decline, with Michelin-starred restaurants struggling to retain loyal customers due to high costs, changing tastes, and the allure of exotic destinations. Travel to countries like Tokyo, Bali, and Bangkok has led to a shift in dining preferences, with locals opting for cheaper and more exotic options overseas. The saturated dining scene has rendered a Michelin star or top restaurant guide placement no longer a guarantee of success, leaving high-end restaurants to adapt to changing consumer habits.

site_title: Two election narratives colliding: Harris’ future hope vs Trump’s dark present
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz have dramatically reshaped the 2024 US presidential election narrative, flipping the story within weeks. Harris now leads Trump by four points in Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, and is in a statistical dead heat in Arizona and Georgia. The Harris-Walz ticket's optimism about the future and emphasis on diversity and progress are drawing enthusiastic crowds and raising large sums of money. In contrast, Trump's narrative is dark and foreboding, emphasizing decline and pessimism, which may not resonate with voters in a time of economic uncertainty and growing polarization.

images.alt_text: Former US President Barack Obama speaks during the Democratic National Convention (DNC) at the United Centre in Chicago, Illinois, Aug 20, 2024.

In a CBS opinion poll released this week, 56 per cent of women surveyed said they would vote for Harris, while 44 per cent backed Trump, a Republican. Conversely, 54 per cent of men surveyed backed Trump, while 45 per cent said they would vote for Harris.
