site_title: GDS seeking RM10 billion in loans for Malaysia expansion
summary: GDS Holdings is seeking up to RM10 billion (S$3 billion) in loans to build out its data centre operations in Malaysia, with the goal of expanding into the Asian market. The Shanghai-based company is also considering an initial public offering of its Malaysian unit, which was established in 2022. Malaysia's growing demand for data centres, driven by the need for artificial intelligence development and services, is expected to increase by 25% annually through 2028.

images.alt_text: GDS says it had been reviewing options on the capital needs of its international business, including the possibility of raising capital for its international business from private equity investors.

site_title: China Sino-Ocean’s offshore debt revamp plan gets 30% creditor support: sources
summary: China state-backed property developer Sino-Ocean Group's offshore debt restructuring plan has garnered support from less than 30% of creditors, according to sources. The company is facing a liquidation hearing next month and has proposed repaying existing debt with new loans and notes worth US$2.2 billion. However, the majority of creditors, mostly banks, have expressed dissatisfaction with the plan, prompting a counter proposal from the ad hoc bondholder group to suggest more new equity issuance and lower debt terms.

images.alt_text: Sino-Ocean’s problems are part of the debt crisis that has beset China’s beleaguered property sector.

site_title: US dollar hits year low versus euro as traders await data and Powell
summary: The US dollar hit a year-low against the euro, falling to 101.30 overnight before recovering to 101.51, as investors await revised US employment data and a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The euro rose to its highest level since December at $1.1132, while the dollar index climbed 0.12% to 101.51. Analysts attribute the dollar's decline to concerns about the economy and the potential for a downward revision of US job numbers, which could lead to another risk-off episode.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, August 21, 2024 (Ep 127)
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday, with JD.com leading losses in China tech stocks following Walmart's $3.74 billion stake sale. In contrast, India's Ola Electric shares surged 80% since its IPO. Sats rose 11% after reporting a profit for Q1, swinging back into the black.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was among the big losers as tech firms took a hit, with e-commerce titan JD.com tumbling more than 11 per cent after a Bloomberg report said Walmart planned to unload US$3.7 billion of shares in the firm at a discount.
The consumer environment in general is worsening and growth is evaporating given the economic uncertainty.
Sats' net profit for the first quarter ended Jun 30 amounted to S$65 million.

site_title: Sats leads gains amid market rally; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks registered a 7-day winning streak on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.1% to 3,373.76. The market rally was led by Sats, which rose 11.5% after its first-quarter earnings lifted investor sentiment, and analysts raised its target price to S$4.10. Meanwhile, Venture Corporation fell 0.8% and local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS closed in the red.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong was among the big losers as tech firms took a hit, with e-commerce titan JD.com tumbling more than 11 per cent after a Bloomberg report said Walmart planned to unload US$3.7 billion of shares in the firm at a discount.
Market updates for Wednesday.
Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 313 to 231 after 904.2 million securities worth S$968.9 million changed hands.

site_title: China opens anti-subsidy probe into EU dairy imports in push back against EV tariffs
summary: China has launched an anti-subsidy investigation into EU dairy imports, focusing on various types of cheeses, milks, and creams, amid rising tensions with the EU over electric vehicle tariffs. The move comes after the EU revised its proposed duties on Chinese EVs to 36.3%, prompting China's commerce ministry to vow to take measures to protect its firms. The investigation, prompted by a complaint from China's dairy industry, will examine 20 subsidy schemes from across the EU.

images.alt_text: The Tesla logo is seen through a charging station outside a store of the electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China January 4, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo
The Commission said it still believed Chinese EV production has benefited from extensive subsidies and proposed duties of up to 36.3 per cent on auto companies.
Many of China’s biodiesel producers are privately run small plants employing scores of workers processing waste oil collected from millions of Chinese restaurants.
BYD, China’s top-selling car brand, is pressing on with its expansion in Europe.
In July, the EU slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 per cent on Chinese EVs after its executive arm concluded in an investigation that they were unfairly undermining European rivals.
China is both the largest producer and the world’s biggest market for EVs, yet the manufacturers mostly rely on foreign companies for the multiple chips that modern high-end cars require.
Xi Jinping (right) has sought to portray himself as a neutral arbiter on the world stage capable of brokering agreements such as last year’s accord between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.

site_title: Hong Kong’s bourse reports 3% drop in H1 profits, Q2 activities pick up
summary: Hong Kong's bourse operator, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX), reported a 3% drop in first-half profits to HK$6.13 billion, despite core revenue remaining flat compared to last year. Quarterly income from April to June rose 9% to HK$3.16 billion. Despite sluggish trading and subdued listing activities, HKEX remains cautiously optimistic about the year's outlook, citing increases in trading and clearing fees from higher volumes across markets.

site_title: Ford cancels fully electric sport utility vehicle
summary: Ford has cancelled plans for a fully electric sport utility vehicle, expected to cost around $1.9 billion, as part of its recalibrated electrification strategy. The decision follows a slowdown in EV demand and a need to better compete with lower-cost Chinese competitors. Ford will instead focus on producing a new fully electric commercial van in 2026 and two new electric pickups in 2027, with a goal of delivering EVs priced on par with traditional vehicles and turning a profit within a year. CEO Jim Farley is confident in the plan, which includes boosting battery production in the US to qualify for manufacturing tax credits.

images.alt_text: The company has held some vehicles for longer than expected to ensure quality, Lawler says.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 21)
summary: Temasek Financial (I) launches a dual tranche offering of 10-year and 30-year offshore Chinese yuan bonds under its guaranteed global medium term note programme. This move is part of Temasek's efforts to diversify its funding sources and tap into the growing Chinese yuan market. The offering is expected to provide Temasek with access to a larger pool of capital, enabling it to support its investments and business operations.

images.alt_text:
Generic picture of HDB blocks in Bishan.

ST PHOTO : SHINTARO TAY

site_title: China’s Didi Global swings to profit in second quarter
summary: China's largest ride-hailing company, Didi Global, reported a net profit of 1.4 billion yuan (S$256.5 million) in the second quarter, reversing a 300 million yuan loss a year earlier. Revenue rose 4.1% to 50.9 billion yuan. The company has been recovering from a regulatory crackdown in 2021 and a 2022 fine over data security violations. Co-founder Jean Liu stepped down from her roles earlier this year, but remains a "permanent partner." Didi's ride-hailing orders reached 971 million trips in June, a 27.3% increase from the same month last year.

images.alt_text: DIDI Global said sales increased to 49.1 billion yuan (S$9.1 billion) in the first three months of the year.
Didi’s revenue in Q4 2023 rose 55 per cent from a year earlier, suggesting the company is progressing in its endeavour to reclaim market share lost since 2021.

site_title: China goes ape over culture-boosting ‘Black Myth: Wukong’ video game
summary: China's state media has praised the country's first AAA video game, "Black Myth: Wukong", for its cultural significance and potential to attract global players. The game, based on a Ming dynasty epic, has been played by 2.2 million concurrent players on Steam and has sparked interest from Western players in learning about Chinese culture. Analysts see this as a milestone for China's gaming sector and a sign of the country's growing recognition of its intellectual property as a valuable export.

images.alt_text: Black Myth: Wukong, an action-adventure title based on the antics of the fabled Monkey King, garnered more than 1.4 million concurrent players on Steam shortly after its global debut on Tuesday (Aug 20).
The industry is expected to generate more than US$180 billion in revenue this year and attract more than 3.4 billion players.

site_title: Temasek launches dual tranche offering of 10-year and 30-year offshore Chinese yuan bonds
summary: Temasek has launched a dual tranche offering of 10-year and 30-year offshore Chinese yuan bonds under its US$25 billion guaranteed global medium-term note programme. The issuance aims to fund Temasek and its investment holding companies. Moody's and S&P Global Ratings have assigned Temasek's proposed offshore Chinese yuan notes a credit rating of "Aaa" and "AAA", respectively, reflecting the company's strong fundamental credit quality and conservative financial profile.

images.alt_text: Many of the tech shares held by Temasek have started to recover this week and it’s unclear how it invested since Jun 30.

site_title: Australia approves world’s ‘largest’ solar hub that will export energy to Singapore
summary: Australia has approved a massive US$24 billion solar and battery farm project, SunCable, which will power three million homes and export energy to Singapore. The project, backed by tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes, includes an array of panels, batteries, and a cable linking Australia with Singapore. Energy production is expected to begin in 2030, providing four gigawatts of energy for domestic use and two gigawatts for Singapore. The project aims to reduce Australia's reliance on fossil fuels and meet its net zero targets by 2050.

site_title: KKR, Hulic bid US$2 billion for GIC’s central Tokyo skyscraper
summary: KKR and Hulic, a Japanese real estate unit of KKR, have made a US$2 billion bid to acquire Shiodome City Center, a 43-storey office tower in Tokyo's central business district. The building, owned by Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, was initially put on the market in mid-2023 but the sale has dragged on due to an anchor tenant replacement and being taken off the market. The KKR-Hulic offer is the sole bid for the building, with ongoing discussions and potential capital partners joining the bid.

site_title: ‘Rotten-tail kids’: China’s rising youth unemployment breeds new working class
summary: China's jobless rate for 16-24-year-olds exceeded 20% for the first time, affecting 100 million youth. This has led to a new working class of "rotten-tail kids," forced to accept low-paying jobs or rely on parents' pensions. The labor market is depressed due to COVID-19 disruptions and regulatory crackdowns. A record number of college graduates are seeking jobs in a stagnant market, exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Job seekers crowd a job fair at Liberation Square in Shijiazhuang, Hebei province, China February 25, 2018. Picture taken February 25, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: China bans risky trusts from selling wealth products for LGFVs
summary: China's National Financial Regulatory Administration (NFRA) has banned some lower-rated trust firms from selling wealth products backed by local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) amid concerns of potential defaults. The move aims to curb growing financial risks, following a prolonged property slump and economic slowdown. The ban is part of the NFRA's efforts to defuse interconnected financial risks, which have seen rising risks in the trust and LGFV sectors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.
Chinese residents, unimpressed with falling deposit rates at banks, are pouring their savings into higher-yielding wealth and money-market funds offered by asset management firms.
The average coupon in April on new debt fell to just 2.83 per cent – the lowest level in data going back to 1999.
China’s nominal GDP growth rate of 4.2 per cent in the first quarter was considerably below the real growth rate, mainly dragged down by weak prices.

site_title: Xiaomi Q2 revenue beats estimate, reveals auto unit sales
summary: Xiaomi reported higher-than-expected revenue for the second quarter, with revenue rising 32% to 88.9 billion yuan. The company's auto business unit generated 6.2 billion yuan in revenue, beating analyst estimates, despite operating at a loss. Xiaomi delivered 27,307 electric vehicles in Q2, with a gross profit margin of 15.4%. The company aims to reach its target of delivering 120,000 EVs by year-end.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi has entered the auto market in March with its base model SU7 costing 215,900 yuan.
Huawei’s sales were driven by continued demand for its new 5G products, which covers the technology, media and telecom industry.
FILE PHOTO: People check new products of Xiaomi ahead of the 2023 Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain February 26, 2023. REUTERS/Nacho Doce/File Photo
Xiaomi’s base model SU7 is about US$4,000 cheaper than the base model of Tesla’s Model 3 in China.
Xiaomi's first electric vehicle SU7 is displayed at a showroom of a newly opened Xiaomi store in Beijing, China March 25, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Crowded Bitcoin derivatives bets spur warning of ‘short squeeze’
summary: The Bitcoin derivatives market is warning of a potential "short squeeze" due to the lowest seven-day average annualised funding rate since March 2023. The rate, which gauges bullish or bearish speculation, has averaged negative levels over the past week, indicating aggressive shorting. This setup could lead to a sharp rally in Bitcoin, as fast-money traders close out bearish bets. The market has been gloomy, with Bitcoin nursing losses for August and struggling to hold above the $60,000 level, and a global stock gauge has rebounded to a record high.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has fallen about 9 per cent in August, lagging a gain of almost 1 per cent in MSCI’s world share index as well as a jump in gold to all-time highs.

site_title: The new wave of climate claptrap
summary: Climate change misinformation continues to spread, despite increasingly evident problems. Powerful heatwaves, wildfires, and coral bleaching events have struck every continent, with at least 10 countries recording daily temperatures above 50 degrees Celsius. Climate change ideologues claim there's no need to tackle the issue, but experts warn that decades of failing to reduce carbon emissions mean drastic action is necessary to avoid irreversible changes. Notable examples of climate claptrap include Elon Musk's downplaying of climate risk and the Project 2025 blueprint, which advocates for dismantling the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

images.alt_text: Experts say climate change doubled the likelihood of floods in southern Brazil and worsened the intense rains caused by El Nino.
Trumpism is the result of Republican climate denial
People at the downtown Riverwalk during an unusually warm winter day on Feb 27 in Chicago. The city was then hit with severe thunderstorms that night, bringing hail and reported tornadoes.

site_title: FPT consortium commences work on US$173 million AI centre in southern Vietnam
summary: FPT, Vietnam's largest tech firm, has commenced construction on a US$173 million AI centre in southern Binh Dinh province, part of its US$200 million AI factory plan announced in April. The 93.24-hectare project includes an AI centre for research, software production, digital transformation, and cybersecurity, as well as an education zone and supporting urban zone. FPT, valued at US$7.7 billion, aims to tap into the growing AI sector and expand its services, which already exceeded US$2 billion in revenue last year.

site_title: Bank Indonesia keeps rates steady as expected
summary: Bank Indonesia kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 6.25% as expected, aligning with market forecasts. Governor Perry Warjiyo signaled a dovish outlook, hinting at further easing while remaining cautious about external risks, including potential US rate cuts and high Treasury yields. The rupiah has strengthened by 5% against the dollar this month, bolstered by growing expectations of a US policy rate cut, and Indonesia's economy is forecast to grow between 4.7 and 5.5% this year.

images.alt_text: On Friday, the rupiah fell as much as 0.31 per cent to 16,295 per dollar, its weakest since July 9.

Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo said the decision would ensure inflation remained within the target range in 2024 and 2025, while the short-term policy focus was directed at strengthening the rupiah currency and attracting inflows.

Indonesian Central Bank governor Perry Warjiyo says at this moment there is no need to raise BI rate, adding that the foreign exchange intervention and the use of rupiah-denominated certificates known as SRBI were enough as inflation would stay low until the end of the year.
Bank Indonesia assures the market it will continue its efforts to stabilise the rupiah, which has weakened to its lowest level in four years.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Mubadala adds to data centre bets with Yondr deal
summary: Mubadala Investment, Abu Dhabi's US$302 billion wealth fund, has invested in London-based data centre developer Yondr Group, supporting growth in a sector expected to see a compound annual growth rate of 11% by 2032. The deal marks Mubadala's latest foray into the data centre market, which is critical to supporting the expanding digital economy. Yondr has contracted and reserved 878 megawatts of capacity.

site_title: Thailand reports suspected case of new mpox strain
summary: Thailand has reported a suspected case of the new, more deadly mpox strain, Clade 1b, which has caused a surge in cases in Africa. A European traveler who visited an African country before arriving in Thailand has been quarantined after laboratory tests confirmed the presence of the virus. The patient is believed to be infected with Clade 1b, which causes death in about 3.6% of cases, with children more at risk. The World Health Organization has declared Clade 1b a global public health emergency.

images.alt_text: WHO declared mpox a global public health emergency on Aug 14, the second time in two years.
Unlike the mpox-causing virus that spread globally in 2022, the newer strain is more dangerous, with a case fatality rate over 3 per cent.
Mpox has tended to present at first through fever, muscle aches, fatigue, headache, the swelling of lymph nodes and other flu-like symptoms.
A new form of the virus has triggered global concern as it seems to spread easily though routine close contact.

site_title: Singapore to remain open amid concerns over US protectionism: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of Singapore remaining open amidst growing US protectionism concerns. He highlighted the significance of the US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement, which has led to a tripling of trade between the two countries from $83 billion to $207 billion in 2021. Heng stressed the need for Asean member states to maintain their openness, citing the example of the US-Vietnam trade relationship, and called for upgrades to regional agreements, such as the Digital Economy Framework Agreement, to facilitate seamless digital trade and data flow.

images.alt_text: DPM Heng says transformation efforts have helped  Singapore maintain its position among the world’s most competitive economies.
The World Cities Summit is a biennial event for government leaders and industry experts around the world to share knowledge and forge partnerships.
Singapore is a regional data centre hub, with over 70 data centres.

site_title: Taylor Swift ends European leg of Eras tour with surprise-packed show
summary: Taylor Swift ended her European leg of the Eras tour with a surprise-packed show at Wembley Stadium in London, featuring a guest appearance by Florence Welch and the debut of ballad "So Long, London," which fans believe is about her relationship with Joe Alwyn. The show was part of Swift's critically acclaimed tour, which has surpassed $1 billion in revenue and has been praised by critics. The tour will continue in the US in October and end in Vancouver, Canada, in December.

images.alt_text: On Sunday, Donald Trump shared screenshots of posts with manipulated images - including some that an expert said appeared to be AI-generated - suggesting that the pop star and her fans, popularly known as Swifties, support his campaign.

site_title: Sembcorp inks in-principle agreement to export green ammonia to Japan
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed an in-principle agreement with Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha to export green ammonia from India to Japan. The agreement comes after the company, along with Kyushu Electric Power and Sojitz, signed a heads of terms deal in June for green ammonia offtake. Sembcorp will produce competitively priced green ammonia in India, with the goal of producing 200,000 tonnes per annum. The agreement does not expect to have a material impact on Sembcorp's earnings.

images.alt_text: The vast majority of the hydrogen that is used now is “grey” – made from natural gas, oil or coal, and which produces huge volumes of carbon dioxide in the process.

The memorandum of understanding includes exploring construction and deployment of green ammonia-fuelled vessels owned either by Cosco or jointly owned by both companies to transport iron ore and other minerals, to reduce carbon emissions in the China-Australia iron ore green shipping corridor.

site_title: Japan sees record visitors for second straight month on weak yen
summary: Japan has set a record for the second consecutive month with over 21 million foreign visitors through July, surpassing the annual record of 31.9 million in 2019. The weak yen and summer holidays fueled the tourism boom, with 3.29 million foreign visitors for business and leisure, an all-time high for any month. School holidays in East Asia and Europe contributed to significant increases, particularly from these regions, with 19 out of 23 markets tracked by the Japan National Tourism Organization setting new records for July arrivals.

site_title: Indonesia’s Golkar party picks influential Jokowi loyalist as leader
summary: Indonesia's Golkar party has appointed Bahlil Lahadalia, a loyalist of President Joko Widodo, as its new leader. The move is seen as a way for Widodo to maintain influence after he steps down in October. Lahadalia, who is the newly appointed energy minister, was chosen without opposition and gave a veiled warning to party members to stay in line. The appointment could give Widodo a significant bargaining power in the upcoming government, particularly as his successor Prabowo consolidates power.

images.alt_text: Indonesian president Joko Widodo (centre), president-elect Prabowo Subianto (left) and house speaker Puan Maharani leave parliament in Jakarta, Indonesia, Aug 16, 2024. Widodo will hand over the reins to Prabowo in October, departing with sky-high approval ratings over an economic track record that delivered consistent growth coming out of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: After yacht sinks, experts say Mediterranean growing more dangerous
summary: A luxury yacht, the Bayesian, sank off the coast of Sicily, killing one person and leaving six missing after a storm. Climate experts say global warming is making violent storms more frequent in the Mediterranean, which is becoming a more dangerous sea to sail in. The unusually high sea surface temperature around Sicily contributed to the storm, and experienced skippers note increased unpredictability and critical situations with little warning. The Mediterranean is becoming more like the Caribbean, with areas to steer clear of during certain times of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Rescue personnel work in the area where a luxury yacht sank, off the coast of Porticello, near the Sicilian city of Palermo, Italy, August 20, 2024. REUTERS/Guglielmo Mangiapane/File Photo

site_title: New skills recognition initiatives for built environment and infrastructure sectors, HR professionals
summary: Singapore has launched two skills recognition initiatives for the built environment and infrastructure sectors, and HR professionals. The Institution of Engineers, Singapore, partners with Singapore Polytechnic to establish an assessment centre for the Chartered Engineering Technologist certification through workplace learning. Meanwhile, the Institute for Human Resource Professionals rolled out two new role badges in workplace learning, allowing HR professionals to obtain badges through formal education and on-the-job pathways.

images.alt_text: A general view shows vessels docked next to stacks of containers at Pulau Brani port terminal in Singapore on July 3, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

From left: Dilys Boey, CEO of Workforce Singapore; Jedrick Tan, CEO of Fei Siong FastFood (Popeyes PLK Singapore); Gloria Arlini, COO and country lead of Generation Singapore; Lim Min Han, head of consulting at Ensign InfoSecurity; and Lee Su Shyan, Associate News Editor of The Business Times.
For SkillsFuture to succeed, individuals, industries and institutions have to step up into their roles, said Education Minister Chan Chun Sing.

site_title: Obama casts Harris as the inheritor of the movement he created
summary: Former US President Barack Obama cast Vice-President Kamala Harris as the inheritor of his 2008 movement, saying her candidacy has rekindled hope for Democrats. In a speech at the Democratic National Convention, Obama praised Harris' policies, including her efforts to cap insulin costs and lower healthcare costs. He also criticized former President Donald Trump, accusing him of spreading "ugly, misogynistic, racist lies" as a substitute for real ideas. Obama warned that defeating Trump will be a "tight race" and that it will take "far more" to win, highlighting the challenges ahead for the Democratic Party.

images.alt_text: Former US President Barack Obama speaks during the Democratic National Convention (DNC) at the United Centre in Chicago, Illinois, Aug 20, 2024.

It is clear that Democratic presidential candidate Kamala Harris (right) and her running mate Minnesota governor Tim Walz have dramatically reshaped this year’s race to the White House, flipping within weeks the narrative of the 2024 election.

site_title: Commercial vehicle COEs up 1.8% at S$72,400, passenger car premiums steady
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums ended mixed in the second round of bidding in August, with commercial vehicle and open categories seeing increases, while passenger car categories remained steady. Commercial vehicle COE premiums rose 1.8% to S$72,400, while the open category increased 0.7% to S$106,001. In contrast, passenger car categories A and B saw no change, with Category B seeing a 0.2% decrease to S$105,889. The motorcycle category saw the largest drop, 3%, to S$9,310.

images.alt_text: De-registrations, which feed the Certificate of Entitlement quota, are expected to rise significantly from 2026 onwards.
The quota for the commercial vehicle category increased the most, by 5.4 per cent.
EVs and petrol-electric hybrids were the most common new car types registered in Singapore in the first half of 2024.
The rise in Certificate of Entitlement premiums in August may be due to new China EV brands Xpeng and Zeekr, spurring purchases.
Xiaomi’s SU7 debuts at an industry event in Shanghai on May 10.
More are keeping their cars beyond 10 years as new car prices remain high.

site_title: UK borrows more than expected in July, underlining challenge for Reeves
summary: The UK government has borrowed £3.101 billion in July, exceeding expectations and underscoring the financial challenges for new finance minister Rachel Reeves. Rising social benefits, driven by inflation, and government wage increases are key drivers of increased spending. Public debt, excluding state-owned banks, stands at £2.75 trillion, or 99.4% of GDP. The government is on track for an overspend of £22 billion against budget plans this financial year, prompting concerns about tax increases in the upcoming budget.

images.alt_text: Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.

site_title: Myanmar households crippled as currency tumbles to record low
summary: Myanmar's currency, the kyat, has plummeted to a record low of 7,500 to the dollar in the black market, causing widespread poverty and crippling households. The kyat's depreciation has led to a surge in prices of essentials such as food and medicine, with some households paying up to 40,000 kyat ($11.94) per week for groceries. The junta's attempts to stabilize the currency have been met with resistance, and the country's economic woes continue to worsen, with poverty rates reaching a six-year high.

images.alt_text: Military personnel stand guard as hundreds of refugees crossed over the river frontier between Myanmar and Thailand on Friday following the fall of a strategic border town to rebels fighting Myanmar's military junta, in Mae Sot, Tak province, Thailand, April 13, 2024. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Myanmar's looming energy crunch is a result of underinvestments, as investors pulled out from the country amid the upheaval.

site_title: China’s PBOC dials back support for yuan as currency steadies
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has set its daily reference rate for the yuan at 7.1307 per US dollar, the smallest gap since June 2023. This move suggests the PBOC is loosening its grip on the managed currency. The yuan has erased most of its losses against the US dollar in recent weeks due to the Federal Reserve's expected rate cuts next month and a strategy unwind by traders. The move indicates the PBOC is allowing the yuan to stabilize and potentially strengthen.

images.alt_text: Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen in a counting machine while a clerk counts them at a branch of a commercial bank in Beijing, China, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Investor attention has increasingly focused on the seven-day repo rate to assess monetary policy direction.
The PBOC will strengthen efforts to effectively implement monetary and financial policies that have been introduced this year.
Traders in China rushed back into buying bonds after a report showed bank loans to the real economy contracted for the first time in 19 years.
The PBOC in recent weeks began an overhaul that could allow it to operate more such as global peers and influence market borrowing costs more effectively.

site_title: Bank of Korea expected to extend hold on property concerns
summary: The Bank of Korea is expected to hold its benchmark interest rate at 3.5% for a 13th consecutive time, according to 21 of 22 economists surveyed. The decision aims to maintain financial stability amid concerns about household debt and a surge in mortgage loans. Inflation has cooled, but housing demand is rising due to a shortage of homes, prompting policymakers to wait for tighter macroprudential measures on mortgage lending to take hold. The decision extends the bank's policy holding pattern, the longest since 2008.

images.alt_text: South KOrea home housing Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
Apartment prices in the Seoul area rose 0.32 per cent last week, the biggest weekly gain since September 2018.

site_title: XPeng projects lower-than-expected Q3 revenue on stiff competition
summary: Chinese EV firm XPeng forecasts lower-than-expected Q3 revenue due to stiff competition and decreased demand for its aging electric vehicle lineup. Despite this, the company expects to deliver 41,000 to 45,000 vehicles in the third quarter, slightly above last year's 40,008 units. XPeng plans to refresh its model lineup with new EVs in the next three years to boost sales. The company's Hong Kong-listed shares fell 2.7% on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Xpeng has six EVs on the market and is looking to launch “a large number of new models and facelift versions” in the next three years.
Pre-sales of the Land Aircraft Carrier are due to start in the final quarter of 2024 in China, the company says.
The tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU’s 27 member states.
Xpeng said it expects to hand over between 29,000 and 32,000 vehicles, an increase of about 25 to 37.9 per cent from the previous year.

site_title: More than 300 OCBC bank accounts linked to scammers frozen by police, S$1.8 million seized
summary: The Singapore police, in collaboration with OCBC Bank, have frozen over 300 bank accounts linked to scam-related activities and seized more than S$1.8 million. The joint operation, conducted from May to August, aimed to identify and weed out money mules. The accounts, primarily opened by foreigners, were used to receive scam proceeds and hide illicit fund sources. The police urge Singaporeans to reject suspicious money-making requests and report scams to authorities.

images.alt_text: By using AI, we can elevate defence and protection mechanisms for consumers and financial institutions,
E-commerce players will be required to verify users who advertise or post about sales of goods and services using government-issued records, among other measures.

Warren Buffett, chairman and chief executive officer of Berkshire Hathaway., during the company's annual meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, in 2022. Berkshire Hathaway delivered about 20.5 per cent annually from 1965 to 2018.

site_title: ‘Yes she can’: Obama says US ready for a Harris presidency
summary: Former US President Barack Obama expressed his support for Vice-President Kamala Harris, stating she is "ready for the job" and will fight for Americans. Obama called Harris "someone who sees you and hears you and will get up every single day and fight for you," echoing his own "Yes we can" campaign slogan. Harris is polling strongly, and Democrats believe she can defeat Republican nominee Donald Trump. Obama's endorsement comes as the Democratic National Convention is underway, with Biden and other party leaders highlighting Harris's qualities and her potential to break the "highest, hardest glass ceiling" in the country.

site_title: Could the Fed end quantitative tightening in the weeks ahead?
summary: The US Federal Reserve may end quantitative tightening in the weeks ahead due to market turmoil and struggling Treasury auctions. Futures markets anticipate Fed rate cuts at mid-month, with some predicting a 3.25% interest rate by end-2025. The Fed has already begun to signal its intention to roll back quantitative tightening, and a pause in its balance sheet shrinkage could be imminent. This move could be a response to the large auction tails and reverse repo balances, which have increased pressure on the US Treasury to ease pressure in bond auctions.

site_title: DBS launches 500 million yuan green loan facility for Envision Energy to develop wind turbine farm in China
summary: DBS, a South-east Asian bank, has launched a 500 million yuan (S$92 million) green loan facility for Envision Energy to develop a 100-megawatt wind turbine farm in China. The project is expected to generate 270 gigawatt hours of renewable energy, powering 90,000 households and reducing annual carbon emissions by 212,600 tonnes. This is the first transaction in the People's Bank of China's carbon emission reduction facility programme by a South-east Asian bank, supporting China's goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060.

site_title: 7-Eleven deal talk reflects allure of Japan’s convenience stores
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard, a Canadian convenience store chain, has made a preliminary proposal to buy out Seven & i Holdings, the parent company of 7-Eleven, for billions of dollars. The deal would give Couche-Tard control of the global 7-Eleven chain, which operates 85,000 convenience stores, petrol stations, and retail outlets across Asia, North America, and Europe. The acquisition would transform Seven & i into a five trillion yen global retailer, and could breathe new life into the small-store shopping experience. The deal's success would depend on national political sentiment in Japan and antitrust regulators in the US.

site_title: Netflix upfront ad commitments surge as NFL games, Squid Game boost appeal

The cheaper ad-supported plan now has 40 million global monthly active users. This growth comes as the company faces saturation in US subscriber growth and seeks to offset the costs of creating original content. site_title: Singapore, Japan to deepen cooperation on carbon capture and storage technologies
summary: Singapore and Japan signed a memorandum of cooperation to deepen their collaboration on carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies. The agreement aims to expedite the adoption of CCS processes in the region by exchanging best practices and pooling expertise and resources. CCS is considered a key measure in global climate mitigation efforts, with both the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and the International Energy Agency acknowledging its importance in achieving net-zero emissions by mid-century. The partnership is part of the Asia Zero Emission Community initiative, which aims to facilitate regional collaboration on energy transition pathways.

site_title: With tourists away, Mount Fuji barrier taken down in Japan
summary: A barrier erected in Japan's Fujikawaguchiko town to deter unruly tourists from taking photos of Mount Fuji has been taken down, succeeding in discouraging problematic visitors. The barrier, installed in May, was lowered ahead of a typhoon and will not be reinstated. The move aims to address issues caused by large numbers of mostly foreign tourists, which had become a concern for local residents. The town's decision marks a temporary solution to mitigate the impact of record-breaking tourism numbers over the summer.

site_title: Hyatt to buy Standard International for up to US$335 million
summary: Hyatt Hotels has agreed to buy Standard International for up to $335 million, acquiring 21 properties and a pipeline of over 30 new projects. The deal, valued at $150 million, includes brands such as the Standard, Bunkhouse Hotels, and Peri Hotels, and will be led by Amar Lalvani, executive chairman of Standard International. This acquisition marks Hyatt's shift towards an asset-light business model, following the sale of properties like the Hyatt Regency Orlando. The deal is expected to support the profitability of Hyatt's hotels through vibrant food and beverage suites.

site_title: Chipmaker Texas Instruments expects free cash flow to jump in 2026
summary: Texas Instruments (TI) expects free cash flow to jump in 2026, driven by increased demand and reduced capital spending. The company has been expanding its 300mm production capacity to prevent chip shortages and address future demand. TI's free cash flow per share is expected to be between $8 and $12 in 2026, a significant increase from a 77% decline in 2023. site_title: China auto body says EU draft on tariffs for Chinese EVs brings ‘enormous risks’
summary: China's auto body, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers, opposes the European Union's draft on tariffs for Chinese electric vehicles, citing "enormous risks and uncertainty" for China's operations and investment in the EU. The proposed duties of up to 36.3% on auto companies are seen as damaging to the EU automotive industry, increasing local employment opportunities, and hindering green and sustainable development. The association believes Chinese EV production has benefited from extensive subsidies, and the high tariffs will have a "serious adverse impact" on the EU industry.

summary: Microchip Technology reported a cyber incident disrupting certain operations, citing an "unauthorised party" that affected servers and business operations. The incident occurred on Saturday, leading to reduced manufacturing facility operations and impacted order fulfillment. Shares dropped about 2% in extended trading. This incident adds to the company's struggles with slowing orders for chips as clients work through excess inventory built up during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK employer pay awards soften in three months to July: Brightmine survey
summary: British pay awards granted by employers fell to 4.5% in the three months to July, the smallest rise since April, according to a survey by Brightmine. This decline chimes with Bank of England forecasts for slowing wage growth. Pay deals are likely to slow further into 2025, with employers reacting to the falling inflation environment by implementing lower pay awards. The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development has predicted a 3% pay rise over the coming year, while the Bank of England expects a 4.1% rise.

Tech firms, including JD.com, were hit hard, with JD.com plummeting 11% after a report said Walmart planned to sell $3.7 billion of its shares at a discount. site_title: Are you prepared for the next bear market?
summary: A bear market is inevitable, with eight occurring in the last 50 years, averaging every six years. The recent market downturn, triggered by war, inflation, and recession concerns, is a warning sign. Central banks' efforts to dial back liquidity may be too late, as inflation remains high and economic growth slows. Investors should prepare by knowing the companies they invest in, monitoring valuations, and differentiating between market pessimism and company fundamentals. Instead of viewing bear markets as a threat to wealth, they offer opportunities to buy shares at cheaper prices, making them a punctuation mark in a rising market.

site_title: Petronas taps Adnoc, Storegga to evaluate carbon capture, storage in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas has partnered with Adnoc and UK-based Storegga to evaluate carbon dioxide emissions storage in the country. The deal aims to develop a carbon capture and storage (CCS) hub in the Penyu basin, targeting at least 5 million tonnes of CO2 capture and storage capacity by 2030. Malaysia's deep saline aquifer reservoirs present an opportunity for CCS development in South-east Asia. Activities under the agreement are scheduled to begin later this year, with the goal of creating a CCS hub in the region.

site_title: Hot stock: Sats rises 11% after swinging back into the black for Q1
summary: Sats, an in-flight caterer and ground handler, reported a net profit of S$65 million for Q1 2025, swinging back into the black after a loss of S$29.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 15.5% to S$1.4 billion, up from S$1.2 billion. Sats shares rose 11.2% to a high of S$3.58 after the announcement, with a married deal recorded at S$3.545. The company's turnaround is seen as a positive development for investors.

South Korea's semiconductor industry, home to two of the world's biggest memory-chip makers, is benefiting from global demand for AI development, particularly to the US and other developed nations. site_title: Cake Group slashes more jobs despite end of founders’ feud
summary: CAKE Group, a Singapore-based crypto platform, is set to undergo another round of layoffs and company-wide restructuring, similar to its 30% job cut in November 2023. CEO Julian Hosp acknowledged the move, stating it's necessary to reduce costs despite the company's revenue growth. summary: Gold prices took a breather after reaching an all-time high on Tuesday, trading flat at $2,514.79 per ounce. The US dollar hit a seven-month low, making non-yielding bullion less expensive, and geopolitical tensions are expected to support gold prices. summary: Walmart is seeking up to $3.74 billion by selling its 144.5 million JD.com shares in a $24.85 to $25.85 price range, ending an 8-year partnership plagued by economic uncertainty and intense competition. The sale comes as JD.com's Hong Kong-listed shares fell 11% and the company faces a property crisis, market volatility, and uncertain job prospects in China. Walmart is refining its strategy in the world's second-largest economy, where retail is dominated by online platforms like Alibaba Group Holding and PDD Holdings.

summary: The US is set to impose hefty tariffs on solar panels produced in South-east Asia, particularly in China, as it accuses these firms of skirting US import levies on their home market. At least three Chinese solar companies, including Longi and Trina, have scaled back operations in Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. The US International Trade Commission has passed an initial vote determining manufacturers are being harmed by cheap imports from the region. This move could jeopardize South-east Asia's booming solar industry and undermine Washington's decarbonisation efforts, with over three-quarters of its solar product imports coming from the region.

summary: A large supply-chain security initiative is being implemented, focusing on fostering relationships among suppliers, partners, customers, and regulatory bodies to maintain trust through transparency. The initiative, modeled after Schneider Electric's approach, aims to address the growing cyber threats in operational technology (OT) systems, with financial losses expected to reach $81 billion globally by 2026. Industry leaders and government authorities are uniting through public-private partnerships to tackle supply-chain cybersecurity challenges, with the US Department of Energy's Cyber Testing for Resilient Industrial Control Systems programme exemplifying this collaboration.

site_title: No need to rush for masks, mpox is not the new Covid-19: Experts
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared mpox a global public health emergency on August 14, amid a surge in cases and deaths, mostly among children, in the Democratic Republic of Congo and neighboring countries. Experts say there's no need for panic buying or mask-wearing, as mpox spreads primarily through close contact, not respiratory droplets. Highly effective vaccines are available, and infected individuals can notify their contacts for post-exposure vaccination. The risk is low for the general public, and experts advise staying updated if traveling to areas with ongoing outbreaks and avoiding unnecessary direct contact with strangers or animals.

site_title: OpenAI to let companies customise its most powerful AI model
summary: OpenAI is releasing a new feature allowing corporate customers to customize its most powerful AI model, GPT-4o, by fine-tuning it with their own company data. The move aims to make it easier for businesses to use the AI model, which has been a key area of competition for startups. Fine-tuning allows AI models to be trained on specific tasks or subject areas, and the new capability will initially be available for text-based data. The feature is expected to roll out on August 20, following a one-hour to two-hour training process.

The trade balance turned back to a deficit of 621.8 billion yen due to a 16.6% increase in imports. The recovery in overseas shipments is expected to provide relief for the Bank of Japan, which has been monitoring the economy closely. summary: Asian families are increasingly institutionalizing the management of their private wealth to mitigate risks associated with intra-family conflicts and ensure long-term security and prosperity. summary: Netflix shares hit their first record in nearly three years, rising 1.5% on Tuesday, following a significant increase in upfront ad sales commitments and a 150% rise in advertising revenue compared to 2023. site_title: Kamala Harris proposes raising corporate tax rate to 28%
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris proposes raising the corporate tax rate to 28% from 21% if she wins the November election against Donald Trump. The move aims to increase revenue and reduce the US deficit by $1 trillion over a decade. Harris' campaign has broken fundraising records and turned opinion polls in some battleground states in favor of Democrats. The proposal, part of Harris' "opportunity economy" plan, also includes tax cuts for most Americans and affordable housing initiatives.

site_title: Divisive US election deepens gender ‘chasm’ in voting patterns
summary: A recent CBS opinion poll reveals a significant voting divergence between women and men in the US presidential election, with 56% of women supporting Democrat Kamala Harris and 44% backing Republican Donald Trump, compared to 54% of men backing Trump and 45% supporting Harris. Analysts say the "chasm" between genders is a stark departure from previous elections, with some predicting it could lead to "divorces" between supporters of opposing candidates. The poll's findings highlight the evolving state of reproductive rights and Trump's focus on masculinity, which may be resonating with some voters.

site_title: Harnessing almost 90 years of experience in navigating intergenerational wealth transfer
summary: A significant intergenerational wealth transfer is expected in Asia, with 70,000 high-net-worth individuals set to transfer $2.5 trillion by the end of the decade. site_title: US judge strikes down Biden administration ban on worker ‘noncompete’ agreements
summary: A US federal judge has struck down a Biden administration ban on worker 'noncompete' agreements, ruling that the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) does not have the authority to adopt broad rules. The ban, set to take effect on September 4, aimed to address unfair restraints on competition and suppress workers' wages and mobility. Judge Ada Brown found that the FTC lacked evidence to justify a sweeping prohibition on noncompete agreements, rendering the rule arbitrary and capricious.

The Swiss bank believes the region's growing economies and wealthy population will drive demand for onshore services, with 7.8% annual growth expected in the Asia-Pacific region over the next five years. Banks are advised to offer innovative products and services to garner more deposits, addressing the growing credit-deposit gap. The RBI's caution comes as young Indians increasingly turn to alternative markets, attracting deposits away from traditional banking channels.

summary: Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay up to $1.7 billion for heart-tech firm V-Wave, bolstering its development efforts to treat heart failure. The deal includes a $600 million upfront payment and potential additional payments of up to $1.1 billion. V-Wave's implanted interatrial shunt device received breakthrough status from the US FDA in 2019 and has the potential to be the first of its kind to market. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of 2024 and may dilute J&J's adjusted earnings per share by 24 cents in 2024 and 6 cents in 2025.

site_title: UK competition watchdog accepts Meta's changes to advertising data rules

The changes ensure that Facebook Marketplace advertisers' data won't be used to improve the ecommerce platform without opting in or out. This move follows Meta's original commitment to limit data usage, addressing concerns over customer privacy.

site_title: US dollar hits 7-month low before Powell, Swedish krona volatile after rate cut

Meanwhile, Sweden's krona fell 0.33% to 10.27 after the Riksbank cut rates and signaled potential policy easing. The move is seen as a response to price pressures, which could impact the US monetary easing cycle and global currency markets.

summary: Maria Branyas, the world's oldest person at 117, has died peacefully in her sleep in a Spanish nursing home. Born in the US in 1907, she lived through two world wars and a civil war. She holds the record for the oldest verified person to have lived, surpassing Frenchwoman Jeanne Louise Calment, who died at 122 years old in 1997.

site_title: Tesla to get lower EU tariff on its Chinese-made EVs
summary: The European Union has reduced its planned extra tariff on Tesla electric vehicles imported from China by over half, from 20.8% to 9%. This change follows an investigation into alleged Chinese subsidies, which Tesla cooperated with. The EU still believes Chinese EV production benefited from extensive subsidies, proposing duties of up to 36.3%. China has vowed to take measures to protect its firms, and the EU's decision may lead to retaliation. The reduced tariff applies to Tesla and other companies that cooperated with the investigation, while some Chinese firms in joint ventures with EU automakers may be eligible for lower duties.

site_title: Thai central bank may face more rate-cut pressure from new PM
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to keep its policy rate at a decade high as the economy shows signs of growth, despite new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's pledge to lift the nation out of an "economic crisis." The BOT may face pressure to cut rates due to the new government's doubts about a $14 billion cash stimulus. Economists predict the pressure will continue as long as the economy remains sluggish, with some forecasting a possible rate cut. The central bank's autonomy and independence are also under scrutiny, given Paetongtarn's family history of clashing with the bank.

images.alt_text: While inflation, at 0.83 per cent in July, remained below the BOT’s target range of 1 to 3 per cent, governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput said the current interest rate is appropriate and there is no need to cut despite the government’s repeated calls to lower it.
“SMEs are the heart and important force of the country,” Bank of Thailand governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput said.

site_title: Asia girds for mpox cases after Sweden finds dangerous strain
summary: Asia is preparing for a potential outbreak of the mutated monkeypox virus, known as the 1B strain, which has a case fatality rate over 3% and may transmit the virus several days before symptoms appear. China, India, Indonesia, and Malaysia have increased surveillance and testing for travelers and individuals showing symptoms. The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency earlier this month, and cases have been reported in countries including Pakistan, the Philippines, and Sweden.

site_title: Lilly's weight-loss drug cuts diabetes risk in overweight patients
summary: Lilly's weight-loss drug Zepbound has shown a 94% reduction in the risk of progression to type 2 diabetes in overweight or obese pre-diabetic adults after three years of weekly injections. In a trial involving 1,032 adults, patients who received Zepbound injections had a significantly lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared to those on a placebo. The results demonstrate the drug's effectiveness in preventing diabetes progression and could have significant implications for patients at risk of developing the condition.

images.alt_text: Tirzepatide is the active ingredient in Eli Lilly’s diabetes drug Mounjaro and weight-loss drug Zepbound.

site_title: HSBC said to explore sale of South Africa units to focus on Asia
summary: HSBC is exploring the sale of its South African businesses as it focuses on expanding its presence in Asia, amid efforts to cut costs and complexity under new CEO Georges Elhedery. The South African branch and securities unit have attracted interest from regional banks, China, and the UAE. A sale would see HSBC largely exit sub-Saharan Africa, following the recent sale of its retail and business banking units in Mauritius. The move is part of HSBC's strategy to simplify its global banking business and prepare for a world with interest-rate cuts.

site_title: Tencent-backed ‘Wukong’ makes game history in first-day rush
summary: A Tencent-backed Chinese game, Black Myth: Wukong, achieved a record-breaking 1.4 million concurrent players on Steam within hours of its launch, surpassing other popular titles like Cyberpunk 2077 and Elden Ring. This milestone may signal China's gaming industry is maturing, with the game's developer, Game Science, receiving significant investment and support from Tencent. The game's success could encourage more local AAA game development for PC and console, and may also encourage Chinese regulators to be more supportive of export games.

images.alt_text: Tencent is exploring ways to offer in-app transactions via Apple’s iOS payment system.
Tencent's revenue jumped 8 per cent to 161.1 billion yuan (S$29.7 billion) for the April-to-June period, versus the projected estimate of 161.4 billion yuan.
Large Chinese tech companies have conspicuously turned to buybacks this year to enhance shareholder return given their lacklustre sales growth.

site_title: BlackRock close to buying 299-unit Citadines Raffles Place for S$300 million
summary: BlackRock is close to acquiring the 299-unit Citadines Raffles Place serviced residences in Singapore for approximately S$300 million, or around S$1 million per unit. The asset, located within the 51-storey CapitaSpring building, has a 56.5-year remaining lease. The sale is part of BlackRock's expansion into the Singapore hospitality market, following a previous acquisition of a serviced apartment block near Novena for S$100 million.

site_title: Indian rupee misses on Asia currency rally on RBI’s watch
summary: The Indian rupee has failed to capitalize on the Asian currency rally, instead edging lower against the dollar in August. The rupee remains one of the least volatile currencies globally due to the Reserve Bank of India's tight grip. In contrast, the Indonesian rupiah and Malaysian ringgit have surged over 4% in August, driven by bets on the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cuts. This underperformance is a turnaround from the rupee's strong performance in the first half of 2024, when it was the region's best performer.

site_title: Shifting approaches: From asset allocation to the whole portfolio advisory
summary: Bank of Singapore adopts a 'whole portfolio advisory' approach to meet evolving client needs. The approach goes beyond asset allocation, incorporating strategies to recover losses, reduce leverage costs, and select suitable solutions for legacy planning. According to Vivienne Chia, global head of the Investment Solutions Group, this shift is necessary due to increasingly complex markets and changing expectations from wealthy individuals and families. A Wealth-X report predicts $18.3 trillion of collective wealth will be transferred to the next generation by 2030, with Asia accounting for $2.5 trillion of this transfer.

site_title: 'We heart Joe': tearful Democrats hail Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden delivered an emotional farewell speech at the Democratic National Convention, marking the end of his presidency. Thousands of Democrats gathered at the United Center in Chicago, waving "We heart Joe" banners and chanting his name as he took the stage with his family. The speech was a cathartic moment, with Biden thanking his party for their support and urging voters to back his successor, Kamala Harris. Despite lingering bitterness over his decision to step down, Biden was met with widespread adoration, with many in the audience visibly moved to tears.

images.alt_text: The 81-year-old Biden is expected to say that Harris – America’s first female, Black and South Asian vice president – is the best person to finish the job he started of protecting American democracy from Republican rival Donald Trump.

site_title: India, Malaysia look to reset ties hit after Delhi's Kashmir move
summary: India and Malaysia are seeking to reset ties after a deterioration in relations in 2019, sparked by remarks by Malaysia's then-Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad against India's decision to remove Kashmir's autonomy. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim have agreed to boost cooperation in areas like semiconductor, financial technology, and defense production. Malaysia will reinvigorate relations with India in all fields, with Modi stating that the two countries will work together to promote mutual interests and benefit.

images.alt_text: India was a leading source of sugar, rice, and onions for Malaysia, which itself is the second-largest exporter of palm oil to India, after Indonesia.

site_title: ‘America, I gave my best to you,’ Biden tells DNC
summary: US President Joe Biden delivered a nearly hour-long speech at the 2024 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, passing the torch of leadership to Vice-President Kamala Harris. The crowd erupted in a sustained standing ovation and chanted "Thank you, Joe" as Biden credited himself for saving democracy and claimed his best for the nation. He expressed gratitude for the support of the American people over 50 years of public service.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden's final bow marked at long last the passing of the torch for a politician who has been in the public eye for more than half a century.

site_title: SGX FX adds MUFG as liquidity provider
summary: SGX FX has added Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) as a liquidity provider to its eFX trading solutions platform for global buyside institutions. The partnership aims to deepen liquidity to the platform's client base, with MUFG's extensive banking roots and robust client base expected to reduce transaction costs. This move follows a 47% growth in SGX's over-the-counter FX average daily volume to US$111 billion and a 36% increase in its currency futures daily average volume to about 204,000 contracts in FY2024.

site_title: HDB, condo rents rise in July; condo leasing volumes surge 35.1%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo rental volumes surged 35.1% in July, with 8,133 units rented, a 11.4% increase from last year and 3.8% higher than the five-year average. Condo rents rose 0.9% from June, while HDB rents increased 1.4% from June. These numbers reflect a strong demand for condominium rentals in Singapore, with condo leasing volumes reaching a 11.4% year-on-year high.

site_title: China weighs letting local governments issue bonds to buy homes
summary: China is considering allowing local governments to issue special bonds to buy unsold homes, a move aimed at easing the housing glut and boosting developers' finances. The proposal, which would allow local governments to fund home purchases with proceeds restricted to infrastructure and environmental projects, comes as the country's real estate crisis deepens. Despite previous rescue packages failing to prop up the market, policymakers are growing increasingly urgent to address the issue, but analysts warn that the expected return from turning unsold homes into affordable housing may not justify the cost of funding.

site_title: China plans ‘bigger, stronger’ social security fund to aid ageing society
summary: China plans to strengthen its social security fund, increasing its 2.88 trillion yuan (S$531.7 billion) to support its rapidly ageing population. Over the next decade, 300 million Chinese will retire, equivalent to the entire US population. The fund aims to improve elderly care and expand investments in the domestic capital market, scientific innovation, and technological productivity. The move aims to stabilize public expectations and ensure the fund's "bigger and stronger" future.

site_title: About 10% of buyers with HDB loan may be affected by new measures to cool market
summary: Singapore's government lowered the loan-to-value ratio for HDB loans from 80% to 75% to cool the resale market. This change is expected to affect around 1 in 10 homebuyers who borrow 75% or more of their flat price, resulting in a median of S$20,000 to S$60,000 more in costs. The move aims to dampen demand at the higher end of the market and stabilize the rest of the resale market. The vast majority of homebuyers with HDB loans will not be affected, and the government has also increased the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant to help first-time buyers.

site_title: Huawei’s smart car unit valued at 115 billion yuan after investment
summary: Huawei's smart car unit, Yinwang Smart Technology, has been valued at 115 billion yuan (S$21.1 billion) after an investment by state-owned carmaker Chongqing Changan Automobile and battery maker CATL. The investment is part of Huawei's push into the electric vehicle market, which China is promoting as a new pillar of economic growth. The move comes as Huawei faces US-China trade tensions and restrictions on its access to advanced semiconductors and 5G network equipment. This investment is expected to diversify Huawei's business and provide a platform for automotive technology development.

site_title: US firms warn against ‘unprecedented’ Hong Kong cyber rules
summary: US firms have warned that proposed Hong Kong cyber regulations could grant the government "unprecedented" access to their computer systems, threatening the city's digital economy. The Asia Internet Coalition, including Amazon, Google, and Meta, has criticized the rules, which would allow authorities to connect to critical computer systems and install programs, potentially harming users and tech investment. The Hong Kong government has defended the bill as necessary for protecting the economy, public safety, and national security, and is likely to be enacted by the end of the year.

site_title: The stakes are high for Powell and the Fed at Jackson Hole
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is set to address the Jackson Hole conference, a key event for central bankers, academics, and media. The stakes are high for Powell to regain control of the policy narrative amid economic uncertainty and financial volatility. He must clearly communicate the Fed's goals, policy destination, and how it will achieve a new equilibrium policy rate, rebuild credibility, and restore international standing. A clear and transparent speech is crucial to prevent renewed market volatility and protect the Fed's reputation.

site_title: Food supply chain startup DiMuto secures US$5.9 million funding from Seeds Capital, SGInnovate
summary: Singapore-based food supply chain startup DiMuto has secured US$5.9 million in Series A funding, led by The Yield Lab Asia Pacific, to bolster expansion into key markets such as Latin America and the US. The fresh funds will enhance DiMuto's digital ecosystem and support its growth trajectory, with plans to broaden its marketplace arm and venture into greenhouse-based agriculture and climate-adaptive varietal development.

images.alt_text: Local vegetable and seafood production as a proportion of consumption has been slipping over the past three years, though hen shell production has grown.
Peptobiotics intends to use its fresh funds to produce larger commercial volumes.

site_title: Tighter HDB loan limit will cool resale flat prices; choice units should still see firm demand
summary: The Singapore government has implemented a new loan-to-value (LTV) limit for HDB loans, reducing the maximum LTV from 80% to 75% effective August 20, 2024. This move aims to cool the resale flat market, where prices have been rising faster than private home prices. Strong demand for choice HDB resale homes is expected to continue, driven by buyers such as those who cannot afford BTO units or prefer specific locations. The measure is seen as a pre-emptive move to prevent market overheating, and its impact is expected to be largely limited to those who borrow up to the LTV limit or aim to maximize loan quantum and duration.

site_title: Top Thai opposition party seeks to rein in Constitutional Court’s power after political upheaval
summary: Thailand's People's Party, the country's largest opposition party, plans to introduce legislation to curb the Constitutional Court's power. The party's leader, Natthaphong Ruengpanyawut, aims to make it harder for the court to dissolve parties and lessen penalties for politicians. This move comes after the court dissolved the most-popular party and ousted the prime minister, sparking fresh upheaval. Ruengpanyawut claims the court's power is "detached from the people" and undermines elected institutions, seeking to end "lawfare" and protect democratic institutions.

images.alt_text: The disbandment of the 2023 election winner is the latest setback for Thailand’s major political parties, which remain embroiled in a tumultuous two-decade battle for power with an influential nexus of conservatives, old money families and royalist generals.

site_title: Centrist voters are political orphans
summary: Centrist voters in the US are facing a challenge as the competition between the Republican and Democratic parties has become a zero-sum game, leaving little room for pragmatic choices. The Republican Party has shifted to a Trumpist agenda, embracing anti-democratic sentiments and protectionism, while the Democratic Party has moved towards a progressive wing focused on identity politics and free market skepticism. As a result, moderate and centrist voters are being left behind, with many expected to stay home on election day due to the lack of practical solutions and ideological agendas.

images.alt_text: America’s allies around the world have to prepare themselves for a US that is less willing to serve in the global role of the “indispensable nation”.

site_title: The very public problem of rising HDB prices
summary: Singapore's government has further tightened loan-to-value limits for HDB resale market, capping it at 75% to curb price hikes. Despite efforts to keep public housing affordable, prices of HDB flats above $1 million continue to rise, with official data showing 2% of transactions reached this milestone in the last 1.5 years. Analysts warn that low-yielding investment assets and heavy debt may be irrational, and property groups should divest and reduce gearing. Meanwhile, developers are seizing opportunities to expand margins, with City Developments Ltd posting a 32% increase in first-half profit.

site_title: Australian landlord Dexus says net loss doubles and flags another weak year, shares plunge
summary: Australian property giant Dexus reported a net loss more than doubling to A$1.5 billion, with its shares plummeting 9% due to weak commercial property market performance. The company attributed the decline to high interest rates, which have hit cap rates and increased debt-servicing costs. Dexus' A$14.8 billion portfolio shrank 12.9% in value, and its adjusted funds from operations fell 7% to A$516.3 million. The company flagged lower-than-expected earnings for next year, citing a thin buyer pool and selective investors.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s Bloomer among those missing after yacht sinks
summary: Morgan Stanley International chairman Jonathan Bloomer, 70, and British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch are among those confirmed missing after a luxury yacht, Bayesian, sank off the coast of Sicily due to a tornado. At least one person died, and six are still missing. Bloomer, a 50-year finance veteran, has worked at Morgan Stanley since 2018 and was a friend of Lynch, who was a witness in a long-running legal battle. Italian authorities are investigating the incident.

site_title: Mpox surge raises fear of spread before patients show symptoms
summary: A fast-spreading mpox outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo is raising concerns that the disease may be spreading before symptoms appear, with infected individuals potentially transmitting the virus to others even before showing flu-like symptoms. The new subvariant, clade I, has infected 17,794 cases and 535 deaths in Congo this year, with most fatal cases among children under five. The true number of cases is likely higher due to difficulty in accessing health services in the region, and the speed of the outbreak's spread requires prompt action to contain it and prevent future pandemics.

site_title: BOJ highlights rising wage pressure from structural job market changes
summary: The Bank of Japan has released research papers highlighting rising wage pressure in Japan's labour market due to structural changes. Labour shortages, a dwindling pool of female and elderly workers, and rising job hoppers are driving firms to hike permanent workers' pay. This trend is expected to keep upward pressure on wages, replacing raw material costs as the main driver of inflation. As a result, companies are adjusting their price-setting behaviour, leading to rising service-sector prices, and the central bank may need to raise interest rates to control inflation.

images.alt_text: Japanese workers' real cash earnings climbed 1.1 per cent in June from a year earlier, turning positive for the first time since March of 2022, the labour ministry reported on Tuesday.

site_title: PwC loses major client Bank of China amid regulatory probe
summary: PwC has lost its largest mainland China-listed client, Bank of China (BOC), to rival EY amid a regulatory investigation into its work on troubled property developer China Evergrande Group. BOC had planned to reappoint PwC as its auditor for 2024, but instead will appoint EY for shareholder approval. This decision follows an exodus of clients, with at least 50 Chinese firms dropping PwC as their auditor or cancelling plans to hire the firm.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate ahead of key earnings and Powell
summary: Asian markets rose 1.7% on Tuesday, led by Tokyo's rally, as investors await Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's speech this week, which may signal an interest rate cut. Expectations of a rate cut have surged, with some predicting 25-50 basis point cuts in September. Recent US data showing a slowing economy and inflation have fueled optimism, and a slew of earnings reports from US retailers this week will provide further insight into consumer confidence.

summary: Chinese banks maintained benchmark lending rates unchanged for August, keeping one-year and five-year loan prime rates at 3.35% and 3.85%, respectively. The decision reflects a balancing act by the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to support growth while ensuring financial institution health, amid a subdued economic outlook. The central bank governor signaled caution, avoiding "drastic" measures, and may ease policies further as the US Federal Reserve prepares to cut interest rates next month.
