site_title: Bronfman makes US$4.3 billion bid for control of Paramount Global
summary: EDGAR Bronfman Jr has made a $4.3 billion bid to take control of Paramount Global, surpassing an existing offer from Skydance Media. Bronfman plans to buy National Amusements, the Redstone family holding company, for $1.75 billion and invest $1.5 billion to reduce debt. He argues that his proposal will result in less dilution for Paramount's non-Redstone shareholders, making his offer superior.

images.alt_text: Paramount agreed to combine with Skydance last month.
Paramount, which owns networks like CBS, MTV and Comedy Central, aims to reduce annual costs by US$500 million and return to profitable growth ahead of its merger with David Ellison’s Skydance Media.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on May 04, 2022 US actor Tom Cruise arrives in a helicopter to the world premiere of "Top Gun: Maverick!" aboard the USS Midway in San Diego, California. - Boycotted by A-listers and studios last year, the Golden Globes will attempt to rebuild their reputation as one of Hollywood's top award shows with organizers unveiling this year's nominees on December 12, 2022. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which organizes the film and television awards, has scrambled to reform itself since long-harbored criticisms of the group's practices went public in early 2021. Tinseltown completely distanced itself from the Globes last January over voters' lack of diversity, alleged corruption and lack of professionalism, and the show took place behind closed doors. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)
Paramount has argued that the fund’s demand for information filed in April is now outdated as the terms of the Skydance deal have evolved.

site_title: Gold holds ground above US$2,500 on weaker dollar; markets await Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices held above the US$2,500 mark on Tuesday, boosted by a weaker US dollar and falling Treasury yields. The US dollar fell to a seven-month low, making gold more appealing for overseas buyers. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields also slipped. Traders await the release of the Federal Reserve's minutes for further cues on interest rate cuts, with a 75.5% chance of a 25-basis-point cut.

images.alt_text: Prices had surged to an all-time high of US$2,509.65 on Friday.

site_title: China’s gold imports tumble again as record prices deter buyers
summary: China's gold imports fell 24% in July to 44.6 tonnes, the lowest in over two years, due to record prices and a weak economy. This decline follows a 58% drop in June, as Chinese buyers pull back on gold purchases. The drop affects demand, which has been crucial for the gold price surge above $2,500 an ounce. The slowdown could make further gains difficult, as the country's central bank paused its buying program and the premium paid on gold in Shanghai turned to a discount.

site_title:
The British Museum is trying to recover 
gems as well as its reputation
summary: The British Museum is working to recover 1,500 missing artefacts, a year after a curator was fired for stealing gems and selling them online. An eight-person team, led by Thomas Harrison, is searching for the items online, in public auctions, and in other museums' collections. So far, 634 items have been secured, leaving over 850 missing, with around 100 gems expected to be returned in the next year. The team faces challenges, including poor museum records and a lack of photographs, but has made progress, including the recent recovery of a purple gem engraved with the goddess Venus.

images.alt_text: epa11547609 Recovered jewels and pieces from a burglary are on display at the Historic Green Vault (Gruenes Gewoelbe) in Dresden, Germany, 13 August 2024. Jewels that had been stolen during a burglary into Dresden's Historic Green Vault on 25 November 2019 were presented to media representatives on 13 August 2024. Despite continued seizure by the district court, it is now possible to display the jewels again in their original place.  EPA-EFE/CLEMENS BILAN
Artefacts dating back to the Chalcolithic and Bronze Age period are seen at the Cyprus Museum in Nicosia, Cyprus.

site_title: Saudi fund said to eye Boeing, Airbus jets for new cargo airline
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is in exploratory talks to acquire Boeing 777 and Airbus A350 freighters for a new cargo airline, Riyadh Air, which aims to challenge regional incumbents Emirates and Qatar Airways. The move is part of Saudi Arabia's push to diversify its economy and turn the kingdom into a logistics hub. The talks are at an early stage, with no final decisions made, and the fund may delay or scrap the plans. This would be part of a broader effort to reduce the country's reliance on oil sales.

images.alt_text: The fund is a key vehicle for his efforts to reshape the Saudi economy and wean it off a reliance on oil sales.
Aramco posted second-quarter net income of 109.01 billion riyals (S$38.6 billion) in the three months to Jun 30, beating a company-provided median estimate from 15 analysts of US$27.7 billion.
Logo of of the Saudi BinLaden Group on their headquarters in Jeddah 20 September 2001.      AFP PHOTO/Mahmoud MAHMOUD (Photo by MAHMOUD MAHMOUD / AFP)

site_title: Paramount likely to extend ‘go shop’ period if Bronfman bids
summary: Paramount Global is likely to extend its "go shop" period for a potential takeover bid if Edgar Bronfman Jr makes an offer before Wednesday night. The deadline for rival bids, set for August 21, may be extended to September 5 if a superior offer is received. This comes after Paramount agreed to combine with Skydance Media last month, with a 45-day "go shop" period. Bronfman, a media investor, is expected to make an offer for Paramount in the next 24 hours.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of Paramount Studios's water tank in Los Angeles, California, U.S., September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Nintendo museum to open in Japan on Oct 2
summary: Nintendo will open its first museum in Kyoto, Japan on October 2, featuring vintage games and interactive exhibits, including a shoot-em-up with Super Mario characters. The museum is located inside a renovated 1969 factory and includes a giant controller and ancient Japanese poems. Tickets, costing 3,300 yen (S$29.60) for adults, went on sale on August 20. The museum marks part of Nintendo's efforts to widen its revenue stream and follows the opening of Super Nintendo World in Osaka in 2021.

images.alt_text: The industry is expected to generate more than US$180 billion in revenue this year and attract more than 3.4 billion players.
Nintendo sold just 2.1 million units of the Switch, which is in its eighth year, during the quarter but maintained its full-year sales forecast for 13.5 million units.
Tencent is among the best performers in the global game sector this year, with its Hong Kong-listed shares outpacing gains in peers from NetEase to Nintendo.
Each new chapter of Zelda is eagerly awaited by fans – the franchise has racked up well over 140 million sales since it began in 1986.
The move signals greater interest from Nintendo to bring in content to bolster the offerings from its in-house creative studios.

site_title:
Overseas funds return 
to Indonesian bonds 
on dovish Fed bets
summary: Overseas investors are pouring into Indonesia's bonds, driven by bets on the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate cuts and the country's robust growth. The country's benchmark 10-year security yield has fallen to 6.69%, its lowest level since April, while the rupiah has strengthened 4.6% against the US dollar. This influx of foreign capital has helped push down borrowing costs for the government and erased the year's net outflows from the debt market.

images.alt_text: Indonesian president Joko Widodo (centre), president-elect Prabowo Subianto (left) and house speaker Puan Maharani leave parliament in Jakarta, Indonesia, Aug 16, 2024. Widodo will hand over the reins to Prabowo in October, departing with sky-high approval ratings over an economic track record that delivered consistent growth coming out of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Expenditure in the proposed 2025 budget, which was jointly prepared by Widodo’s (right) ministers and Prabowo’s economic team, is almost 6 per cent higher than this year’s forecast.
Widodo (left) talks to Prabowo after delivering his final state address on Friday; Widodo has been laying the groundwork for a seamless transition by supporting initiatives championed by Prabowo.
Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, wearing the traditional Betawi attire, delivers his annual state of the nation address at the parliament building in Jakarta on Aug 16, 2024.

site_title: Oil falls by more than US$2 a barrel on Gaza ceasefire talks and weak Chinese economy
summary: Oil prices dropped by more than US$2 a barrel on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$77.66 a barrel, due to expectations of successful Middle Eastern peace talks reducing supply risks and concerns about a weak Chinese economy. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged a ceasefire deal in Gaza, while China's economic problems, including falling new home prices, pressured oil prices. Despite this, supply risks from the Middle East and Russia-Ukraine war continue to underpin the market.

images.alt_text: Although the WTI oil price recently found support at a double bottom of US$72.50 per barrel in early August, it has faced resistance near the US$80 per barrel level.

site_title: New Zealand promises banking shake-up after watchdog finds the sector lacks competition
summary: New Zealand's government has promised a shake-up of its banking sector after a report by the country's watchdog found that the four largest lenders, all owned by Australian banks, lack competition. The Commerce Commission recommended boosting capital for state-owned Kiwibank, lowering barriers to entry, and ensuring open banking by June 2026. The government aims to increase competition and improve consumer choice in the sector, with potential reforms including increasing Kiwibank's capital and promoting more Australian banks to enter the market.

images.alt_text: The nation’s banks have defied analysts who have widely expected a drop in earnings as a result of fierce mortgage competition. I

Australia’s largest banks are contending with expectations that interest rates will begin to fall before the end of this year, even as many consumers and businesses curb spending.
For BT use
Mortgage payments past their due date for 90 or more days rose 5 basis points to 84 bps for ANZ’s Australian housing loans, the lender said in a limited quarterly trading update.

site_title: 7-Eleven billionaire heirs would see big payday from shock offer
summary: Billionaire family heirs behind Seven & i Holdings, owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, could see a massive payday if they support a non-binding buyout proposal from Canadian company Alimentation Couche-Tard. The proposal would be the largest foreign takeover of a Japanese company. The Ito clan's 8.1% stake in Seven & i is worth US$3.1 billion, and the company's market value has jumped 23% after the proposal. However, it's unclear if the Ito clan supports the deal, and a successful takeover would mark a rare exit by a billionaire family in Japan.

images.alt_text: The Seven & I Holdings Co. logo displayed atop the Ito-Yokado supermarket Tsunashima store in Yokohama, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, on Wednesday, April 10, 2024. Seven & i fell after the company said there were “no facts to support” reports that it plans to list or sell part of its supermarket unit Ito-Yokado, which has been under pressure to restructure in the face of intensifying competition from discount stores and online retailers. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg
The plan is part of a large-scale restructuring that involves selling off lower-performing supermarket assets.

site_title: China makes 220 billion yuan nuclear push with record approvals
summary: China has approved 11 new nuclear reactors across five sites, totaling a record 220 billion yuan investment, as the government prioritizes atomic energy to reduce emissions. The country is expected to surpass France and the US as the world's leading nuclear power generator by 2030. With 56 reactors currently in operation, China is already building more than any other nation, with a combined capacity of 5% of total electricity demand. The new projects include high-temperature gas-cooled reactors with advanced safety features, using mostly Chinese-made components.

images.alt_text: Singapore inked a 30-year deal with the US on Jul 31 to study SMRs and other advanced nuclear power technologies

US scientists achieved net energy gain in a fusion reaction for the second time in July 2023, producing a higher yield than its initial fusion ignition breakthrough seven months prior at the National Ignition Facility in California.

site_title: Japfa to buy back 183.3 million shares at S$0.355 apiece
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, proposed buying back up to 183.3 million shares at S$0.355 apiece, representing a 6% premium over the last traded price. The offer is not expected to impact the company's working capital requirements and gearing levels. Japfa's shares were trading below its net asset value of S$0.52, and the buyback will commit S$65.1 million, funded through internal resources or external borrowings.

images.alt_text: Japfa chief executive officer Tan Yong Nang noted cost reduction initiatives proved effective for the poultry and swine operations in Vietnam.

site_title: The MAS and CAD naughty list
summary:
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) have been investigating various cases of market misconduct in Singapore. These cases include insider trading, bribery, and false trading. Some notable cases include:

- Regency Steel Asia's chairman, Gui Boon Sui, was fined S$350,000 for conducting false and unauthorized trading.
- JPMorgan Chase Bank paid a S$2.4 million civil penalty for failing to prevent and detect misconduct by its relationship managers.
- EuroSports Global's Wong Chow Lin and Gillian Isabel Siow were charged with false trading of the company's shares.
- Nech Capital's former representative, Pan Qi, was issued a five-year prohibition order for conducting a fraudulent business operation.
- Memiontec's husband-and-wife co-founders were arrested and released on bail for potential offenses under the Securities and Futures Act.
- Tay Joo Heng was fined S$70,000 for insider trading in GS Holdings.
- Seatrium is under investigation for potential bribery offenses related to a decade-old case in Brazil.
- Cordlife's directors and former group CEO were arrested and released on bail for alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations.
- Tay Ming Hin was sentenced to four weeks' jail for false trading in KOP's shares.
- Tan Kheng Yeow was serving an eight-month jail sentence for false trading of KTL Global's shares.
- Chong Yew Mun Alan was served a five-year prohibition order by the MAS for false trading of Koyo International's shares.
- Lim Yong Sim was convicted and sentenced to a fine of S$420,000 for false trading under the SFA.

images.alt_text: Tay and Soegiharto were arrested after attending interviews on Aug 14.
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Liew Yik Kit, who was the personal driver to Cambodian national Su Binghai, was handed two charges on Aug 15.
The biggest money laundering probe in Singapore saw about $3 billion in cash and assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders.

site_title: ANZ logs slight rise in overdue home loan payments
summary: ANZ Group reported a slight rise in overdue home loan payments, with mortgage payments past due for 90 or more days increasing 5 basis points to 84 bps in the June quarter. Sticky inflation and high borrowing costs have impaired household ability to repay, despite ANZ's core capital ratio remaining at 13.3% as of June end. This trend is attributed to banks facing reduced margins in a high interest rate environment, with ANZ also facing regulatory scrutiny over suspected bond trade allegations.

site_title: Japan ruling party to choose next PM on Sep 27: media
summary: Japan's ruling party will select a new leader, and likely next prime minister, on September 27. The decision follows Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's announcement that he won't seek re-election due to plummeting approval ratings. Kishida's approval ratings slid in response to rising prices and scandals. The internal committee has set September 12 as the start of campaigning, with a vote two weeks later. Several candidates, including former defence minister Shigeru Ishiba and potential female prime minister candidates, are reportedly vying for the leadership.

images.alt_text: News about Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's resignation flashed on public screens in Tokyo; August 14,  2024.
FILE PHOTO: Shigeru Ishiba, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Makiko Yamazaki/File Photo
Fumio Kishida’s decision to quit will trigger a contest to replace him as party boss, and by extension as the leader of the world’s fourth-biggest economy.
Governor Kazuo Ueda last week repeatedly stressed the BOJ decided to increase rates based on economic and inflation data showing that developments were in line with previous expectations.
Japan’s Prime Minister Fumio Kishida delivers a speech during the closing ceremony of the Asia Business Summit in Tokyo on July 5, 2024. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, attending a joint press conference with Japan's Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa, says US alliances are all “defensive in nature”.
The hike in minimum pay follows significant wage gains achieved by workers in wage negotiations earlier this year.

site_title: Keppel, ADB, EnterpriseSG to explore US$800 million of energy and environmental projects
summary: Keppel, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and Enterprise Singapore have signed a memorandum of understanding to explore US$800 million in energy-transition and environmental-sustainability projects in South-east Asia from 2025 to 2030. The projects, including decarbonisation of power generation, renewable energy, and green buildings, aim to abate at least 1 million tonnes of CO2 per year. Keppel will develop and operate these projects, leveraging ADB's concessionary financing and EnterpriseSG's deal-matching capabilities.

images.alt_text: From left: Thitipong Jurapornsiridee, chairman of board of directors, CHPP; Worawat Pitayasiri, president and CEO, GPSC; Cindy Lim, CEO of Keppel’s infrastructure division; Lim Yong Wei, general manager (EaaS), Keppel’s infrastructure division.

site_title: US orders Boeing 787 inspections after Latam plane plunge
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has ordered inspections of pilot seats on hundreds of Boeing 787 planes after a March incident where a Latam Airlines plane suddenly plunged, injuring 50 passengers. The FAA is requiring 158 US-registered 787 models and 737 planes worldwide to inspect for "uncommanded horizontal movement" of the captain and first officer's seats, which can lead to rapid descents and serious injuries. Four additional incidents have been reported, with three attributed to loose switch caps and two under investigation.

images.alt_text: The rapid ramp-up of international flights by Chinese airlines has reduced the SIA group’s market share on these routes.

The Boeing Co. logo on the company's stand during the opening day of the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, UK, on Monday, July 22, 2024. The aviation summit is typically a platform for planemakers to rack up multibillion-dollar deals. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
File photo of passengers at Narita airport. One runway at Narita airport has been closed due to the emergency landing of a cargo plane, public broadcaster NHK reported on Tuesday.
The SIA plane was carrying 276 passengers and crew members, local media said.
Boeing’s factory processes have been under the microscope of regulators and safety inspectors since the accident.
Cathay already has 48 A350s in its fleet and operates 43 older generation A330s.
Boeing’s senior vice-president for quality Elizabeth Lund said the planemaker is working on design changes that it hopes to implement within the year and then to retrofit across the fleet.
National Transportation Safety Board chair Jennifer Homendy attends a NTSB hearing on the Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 MAX door accident at NTSB headquarters in Washington.

site_title: ECB’s Rehn says growth risks bolster case for September cut
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Olli Rehn says the recent increase in negative growth risks in the euro area has reinforced the case for a rate cut at the next ECB monetary policy meeting in September, provided that disinflation is on track. Rehn notes that inflation's path to the ECB's 2% medium-term goal is likely to be "bumpy" this year, and the economy is facing uncertainty due to trade wars and conflicts. Markets are pricing in at least two more rate reductions this year, ahead of the September policy meeting.

images.alt_text: Commercial property prices have fallen sharply due to higher borrowing costs and poor demand as firms adjust to post-pandemic realities, with the ECB estimating that prices may have dropped by close to a tenth last year alone.

Some 55 per cent of lenders now take climate and environmental risks into account when building so-called provisioning overlays, up from 16 per cent in findings last year, says the European Central Bank.
The European Central Bank's president expects economic recovery to be supported by consumption, driven by the strengthening of real incomes.

Inflation this year could average 2.4 per cent, in line with the survey’s prediction three months ago and could then slow to 2 per cent next year, as predicted earlier, both below the ECB’s own in-house projections.

site_title: Chinese property developer Kaisa, bondholders agree to restructure offshore debt
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group has agreed to restructure its offshore debt with a key group of bondholders, swapping existing debt into new notes and shares. The restructuring plan covers $12 billion in offshore bonds and other debts, and includes the issuance of senior notes and mandatory convertible bonds with interest rates ranging from 5% to 6.25%. The move is seen as a step towards deleveraging and enhancing liquidity for the company, which defaulted on US dollar bonds in 2015.

images.alt_text: Kaisa reported total liabilities of 226 billion yuan (S$42.4 billion) as of the end of last year.
Kaisa, with about US$13 billion of offshore borrowings subject to restructuring, carries one of the largest debt loads in the industry.
Kaisa, with about US$13 billion of offshore borrowings subject to restructuring, carries one of the largest debt loads in the industry.
The Center skyscraper in Hong Kong. On a visit by Bloomberg News reporters in April, ceiling panels were missing in places, with long electric wires hanging from the gaps on some floors.
The turn in the trajectory of new-home sales may offer some relief for China’s economy, which is on track to undershoot the government's official 5 per cent growth target for this year.
A growing list of Chinese property developers are facing liquidation lawsuits filed by creditors, including Country Garden.
Beijing is lowering the minimum down-payment ratio for buying a home to 20 per cent from 30 per cent, and for some second home buyers to 35 per cent from 40 per cent

site_title: South Koreans expect hotter home prices with central bank set to meet
summary: South Korean apartment prices rose 0.32% last week, the largest gain since September 2018, according to a Bank of Korea survey. Expectations for home prices climbed to 118 in August, a third consecutive rise. The central bank is expected to keep its policy settings on hold, with economists predicting a benchmark interest rate of 3.5% when the board meets on Thursday. The government has also announced measures to boost housing supply in Seoul to cool apartment price growth. Most economists expect a policy pivot to October, not August.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund’s returns boosted by global markets rally
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund (PIF), reported annualized returns of 8.7% in 2023, driven by local investments and gains on its international portfolio, surpassing its previous year's 8% return. The fund's assets under management grew to $760 billion, with international assets reaching $204 billion. The PIF's performance was boosted by a 24% rally in global markets, particularly the S&P 500 Index. The fund's externally managed assets fell to 15% from 17% and its profit swung to $25 billion from a loss of $11 billion the previous year.

images.alt_text: The investment comprises US$100 million worth of convertible debentures, giving PIF the option to trade the investment for stocks in Chaoshang, and US$400 million in a five-year loan.
The US$925 billion Saudi wealth fund has listed several of its portfolio companies in recent years and is becoming an active debt issuer.
The investment comprises US$100 million worth of convertible debentures, giving PIF the option to trade the investment for stocks in Chaoshang, and US$400 million in a five-year loan.

site_title: Australia central bank signals rates will stay at 12-year high for ‘extended period’
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has signaled that interest rates will remain at a 12-year high of 4.35% for an "extended period" to ensure inflation returns to its target band of 2-3% next year. The board discussed further tightening but decided to keep rates steady, citing the need for a "somewhat greater-than-usual weight" on data flow. This decision contrasts with neighboring countries that have reduced rates, and the RBA is under pressure to balance inflation with labor market gains.

images.alt_text: Michele Bullock has expressed a willingness to be patient as she seeks to slow inflation without choking off economic growth.
Bond investors are shrugging off a relatively hawkish stance from the RBA, at least compared to peers.

Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock, in a speech in her home town of Armidale, New South Wales, reiterated that the board was vigilant to the upside risk of inflation, days after the bank decided to hold rates steady.

site_title: GuocoLand bags S$847.1 million green facility to develop Upper Thomson site
summary: GuocoLand secures S$847.1 million in green financing to develop a 99-year leasehold residential site at Upper Thomson, Singapore, with 941 units slated for launch in 2025. The development will be built on a 32,023.7 square metre site, with a portion of the former Seletar Institute to be conserved. This brings GuocoLand's total green financing to over S$3.7 billion, and the project is expected to achieve a Green Mark Platinum (Super Low Energy) certification.

images.alt_text: CMG20220730-ThongKH01唐家鸿/NDP Preview2 [Ritz Carlton Hotel] Archival shot/tags: Guocoland.

site_title: Cocoa climbs as traders focus on crop prospects in West Africa
summary: Cocoa futures in New York rose 7.2% to their highest price since late July, driven by traders' focus on West African crop prospects. Despite recent forecasts of beneficial rains, weather risks and challenges for farmers persist, threatening historically expensive beans. The near-term weather outlook is mixed, with some areas receiving light to moderate rain and others experiencing drier conditions. This has led to a range of reactions from farmers, with some expressing relief at the return of rains, while others face difficulties accessing plantations.

images.alt_text: Chocolate companies have already warned margins could come under pressure in the second half of the year as they purchase beans at higher prices following this year’s rally.
Prices have roughly doubled this year as poor harvests in West Africa fuelled a historic shortage.
Nestle’s factory in York churns out 200,000 KitKat bars every hour.

Big buyers, such as Hershey and Mondelez, buy and sell cocoa on global exchanges, where they trade physical beans as well as futures contracts that can require them to take a delivery of beans at a future date.

site_title: GoPro to cut 15% of workforce in restructuring push
summary: GoPro is cutting 15% of its workforce, approximately 139 jobs, as part of a restructuring plan to reduce operating expenses. The layoffs are expected to begin in the third quarter and be completed by the end of 2024, with the company expecting charges of $5-7 million and cash expenses of $1-6 million. The move comes after the company reported a 22.7% decline in revenue and a 5% increase in operating expenses in the second quarter.

site_title: Vintage car sales get ‘freezer burn’ as collectors value patience
summary: Vintage car sales dropped 8% to $371 million in Monterey, California, at overcrowded auctions, with half of the vehicles failing to meet low price estimates. Top sellers included a 1955 Ferrari 410 Sport Spider ($12.9 million) and a 1960 Ferrari 250 GT SWB Spider ($17 million). The market is experiencing a shift, with younger collectors prioritizing usability over rarity, and sell-through rates for blue-chip vehicles (valued at $1 million+) dropped to 52% from 63% in 2023. Experts caution that the market is not in a catastrophic state, but rather undergoing a correction, with smart investors taking a long-term view.

images.alt_text: A view of BMW's factory in Shenyang. The recalls, effective immediately, are for models produced from 2003 to 2017, says China’s State Administration for Market Regulation.
“The car carrier industry has enjoyed exceptionally good times for a couple of years actually and we still are,” said Andreas Enger, the chief executive officer of Höegh Autoliners.

A Volkswagen ID.4 electric vehicle (EV) at a Rivian charging station in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024. Volkswagen AG is taking another swing in its long struggle to catch up with Tesla Inc., plowing $5 billion into a tie-up with the US company's closest would-be rival, Rivian Automotive Inc. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally with fresh advances
summary: US stocks extended their rally on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.6% to 40,896.53, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 1.0% and 1.4% respectively. The rally follows encouraging US economic data and comes ahead of key earnings reports from retailers and central bank commentary, including Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks at the Jackson Hole gathering. Individual stocks such as AMD and General Motors also saw gains.

images.alt_text: epa11549029 Stock prices are listed on a screen as seen through the window at the Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, New York, USA, 14 August 2024. US stocks, including Dow Jones Industrial Average, went up on 14 August after the release of US inflation data. The Consumer Price Index cooled to 2.9 percent in July 2024, down from 3 percent in June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on 14 August.  EPA-EFE/SARAH YENESEL

site_title: Australia's 'vulnerable' Sydney faces hotter days, rising seas
summary: Sydney, Australia is at risk of extreme heat and rising seas unless emissions are reduced, a government climate report warned. By 2050, the city could be 1.8°C warmer, and by 2090, around double that. Sea levels could rise by 56cm, and regional towns away from the coast are likely to experience sweltering temperatures. Authorities are considering measures to "future-proof" communities, including shaded heat refuges and climate-resilient infrastructure. The report comes as Australia faces its hottest year on record and extreme heat is linked to hospitalizations and deaths.

images.alt_text: The hot weather has not thinned crowds at popular beach and resort destinations such as Terengganu in Malaysia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Japfa
summary: Keppel inked a memorandum of understanding with the Asian Development Bank and Enterprise Singapore to explore US$800 million in energy transition and environmental sustainability opportunities in the Asia-Pacific. Japfa announced a share buyback of up to 183.3 million shares, or 9% of its shares in issue, at S$0.355 apiece.

site_title: BT Podcasts: Unpacking the PM’s first National Day Rally speech
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong delivered his first National Day Rally speech, emphasizing security, social connections, and dynamism. The speech highlighted new policy announcements, including reinforcing the social compact, enhancing family support, and adjusting parental leave. Long-term infrastructural developments, such as the Kallang Alive Master Plan, were also discussed. The conversation reflected on the government's proactive approach to addressing employment challenges through schemes like SkillsFuture JobSeeker, and how PM Wong's delivery linked policy directions to the Forward Singapore roadmap.

site_title: Europe: Shares notch broad-based gains; defence stocks lag
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.6% higher on Monday, reaching a three-week high, driven by retail and basic resources stocks. The pan-European index has notched its biggest weekly gain in three months. Defence stocks fell after a report that the German finance ministry would not approve additional Ukraine military aid due to budget constraints. Investors are gearing up for a data-heavy week, with a focus on US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole for clues on potential rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent higher at 40,896.53 on Monday.

site_title: Property downturn creating best opportunity in decades, Andy Gloor says
summary: Chicago's commercial real estate market is experiencing its best opportunity in decades, according to Sterling Bay CEO Andy Gloor. With vacancy rates reaching 23.1% in the central business district, Gloor sees a contrarian move for investors to acquire properties, citing the Federal Reserve's expected rate cut. This downturn has attracted investors, such as Prime Group, who bought the former Cboe Global Markets headquarters for half its pre-pandemic value. Gloor believes a rate cut of at least 50 basis points in September could be a "green shoot" for the market, encouraging investment in urban areas.

site_title: Singapore shares inch up at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.1% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 4.32 points to 3,359.88. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 81 to 24, with actively traded counters such as Soilbuild Construction and Mapletree Logistics Trust rising 6.1% and 1.6%, respectively. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also increased. The gains follow overnight gains in global markets, which await US retailers' earnings and central bank commentary.

images.alt_text: ST20240625_202434953939 pixgeneric Azmi Athni/ SGX logo on June 25. Tags: SGX; finance; investment; money; finance; Singapore; ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI
Keppel inks a memorandum of understanding with Asian Development Bank and Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Trump shares doctored images showing Taylor Swift support
summary: Former US President Donald Trump shared manipulated images on his social media site Truth Social, suggesting that Taylor Swift and her fans, known as Swifties, support his presidential campaign. The images, including one of Swift in an Uncle Sam outfit, appear to be AI-generated. An expert described the combination of real and fake imagery as "particularly devious." Trump's post drew online mockery and scorn from Swifties, who called for Swift to take legal action. Swift has not publicly endorsed any presidential candidate yet, but her massive popularity and influence could make her support valuable in the upcoming US presidential election.

images.alt_text: The 81-year-old Biden is expected to say that Harris – America’s first female, Black and South Asian vice president – is the best person to finish the job he started of protecting American democracy from Republican rival Donald Trump.
From a market perspective, Trump’s policies could initially favour US assets and the USD.
Pollsters and strategists from both major US parties warn that the "sugar high" of Harris' initial surge will wear off.
Donald Trump often pivots to personal insults, questioning Kamala Harris’s intelligence, attacking her racial identity and branding her a “communist.”

US President Joe Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris, the Democratic presidential nominee, raise their clasped hands during a campaign event at Prince George's Community College in Largo, Maryland, Aug 15, 2024.

The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index eased to an annual rate of 2.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said in a statement, down slightly from 2.6 percent a month earlier. Residential buildings in New York, US, on Friday, July 12, 2024.
