The former president’s holdings in Trump Media & Technology Group, worth US$2.7 billion and accounting for more than half of his US$5.3 billion net worth.
Crypto4Harris is part of a growing effort by Democrats and others in the crypto industry to push nonpartisanship rather than hitch their wagon to Republican nominee Donald Trump.

site_title: India might need more cautious monetary policy to stem food price rise spillover
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) expects India's inflation to rise and stay above its medium-term target of 4% this quarter and next due to high food prices, which account for nearly half of retail inflation. The RBI blames "repeated climatic shocks of rising intensity" for the stubbornly high food prices, warning that a cautious monetary policy approach is warranted if food price pressures persist and threaten to spill over into generalised price inflation.

images.alt_text: India’s merchandise exports stood at US$33.98 billion in July, while imports were US$57.48 billion.

site_title: ‘Not overly generous’ jobseeker support will mainly help the lower-income: observers
summary: Singapore's new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme will provide up to S$6,000 in total, over six months, to help involuntarily unemployed workers. However, observers say the amount is not overly generous, particularly for middle-income and mature workers, who may need additional support. The scheme requires jobseekers to participate in accredited programs and demonstrate active job search efforts. While some praise the initiative as providing meaningful assistance, others call for more help for middle-income workers and clarification on eligibility criteria. The six-month duration cap aims to avoid moral hazard and encourage job seekers to find employment.

images.alt_text: To receive support under the new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, workers must go for training, career coaching and job-matching services.

site_title: New Zealand house prices fall 1.4% in July: Reinz
summary: New Zealand's house prices dropped 1.4% seasonally adjusted in July, the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand reported. Despite this, sales numbers increased 6.4% from June and 5.4% from July 2023. High interest rates have been a major factor in the decline, but analysts predict a relatively solid increase in values in 2025 as interest rates are expected to decrease.

images.alt_text: New Zealand housing market Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: US adds most power generation in 21 years as AI demand surges
summary: US power generation capacity surged in the first half of 2024, with a 20.2-gigawatt increase, the highest recorded since 2003. This growth is driven by rising electricity demand from data centres and artificial intelligence, with solar power expected to account for nearly 60% of planned capacity for the rest of the year. New solar projects will drive gains, but the need for power has slowed the retirement of coal- and gas-fired power plants, with a 45% decrease in retirement rates compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Welcome to the end of the biggest commodity boom
summary: The world's iron ore market is experiencing a significant downturn, ending the biggest commodity boom in history. Iron ore prices have fallen 55% from their all-time high of nearly US$220 a tonne in 2021, currently trading below US$100 a tonne. China, the world's largest steel producer, is driving the decline as it shifts its economic model to services, reducing demand for steel and iron ore. New mines in Australia and Africa will further exacerbate the oversupply, pushing prices down to rebalance the market, potentially to US$50 a tonne, and forcing high-cost miners to cut output.

images.alt_text: Money managers piled a combined net-short position of almost 153,000 futures and options across 20 raw-material markets in the week ended last Tuesday (Aug 6), according to US Commodity Futures Trade Commission data compiled by Bloomberg.

This file photo taken on February 21, 2023 shows the company logo adorning the side of the BHP global headquarters in Melbourne. Mining giant BHP reported an 86 percent slump in half-year net profit on February 20, 2024, hit by a write-down of its nickel assets and costs related to a 2015 Brazilian mining disaster. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)
Rio, BHP and Fortescue Metals produce almost two-thirds of the world’s seaborne iron ore from Western Australia, and margins remain enviable.

site_title: US talk show host Phil Donahue dead at 88
summary: Phil Donahue, a pioneering US talk show host, has died at 88 after a long illness. Donahue's groundbreaking show, The Phil Donahue Show, launched in 1967 and featured audience participation, earning him numerous Emmy Awards. He was the first on daytime US television to tackle controversial issues, and his format was later adopted by hosts like Oprah Winfrey. Donahue received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Joe Biden in May. He was married to actress Marlo Thomas for 44 years.

images.alt_text: French actor Alain Delon at the Cannes Film Festival in May 2019, where he was awarded an honorary Palme d'Or.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat with focus on Jackson Hole
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, August 19, after their best week of the year, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 11.1 points to 40,670.83. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole for rate-cut indications. The S&P 500 rose 3.0 points to 5,557.23, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 18.0 points to 17,649.74.

site_title: Ex-Citi, Julius Baer bankers charged in money laundering case were stars in the race for China’s rich
summary: Two former bankers, Wang Qiming and Liu Kai, were criminally charged for allegedly facilitating the movement of illicit funds in Singapore's largest-ever money laundering case. Wang Qiming, a former Citibank executive, and Liu Kai, a former Julius Baer executive, forged documents to mask the source of deposits into Citibank accounts and were stars in the race for China's rich clients. The charges raise questions about how sophisticated banks vet their customers and screen their employees. This is the first time financial professionals linked to the scandal have been charged.

images.alt_text: Malaysian national Besmond Huan Yu Kang, 22, was arrested for his suspected involvement in money laundering activities using Singapore bank accounts.
Loh fled the country in 2020 and was arrested in 2022.
Liew Yik Kit, who was the personal driver to Cambodian national Su Binghai, was handed two charges on Aug 15.
The biggest money laundering probe in Singapore saw about $3 billion in cash and assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders.
The Bill will introduce several proposals to improve the processes involved in dealing with seized properties including those linked to money laundering.

site_title: US workers more glum on compensation and work prospects, New York Fed says
summary: US workers are becoming increasingly dissatisfied with their employment compensation and work prospects, according to a survey by the New York Federal Reserve. A series high 4.4% of respondents expect to lose their job, up from 3.9% last year. Satisfaction with wages, non-wage benefits, and promotion opportunities also decreased, with 56.7% of respondents satisfied with pay in July, down from 59.9% last year.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 233,000 for the week ended Aug 3, the Labor Department said.
The latest US jobs report, which showed a material slowdown in hiring and an unexpected pickup in joblessness, heightened these concerns.
FILE PHOTO: An employee hiring sign with a QR code is seen in a window of a business in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., April 7, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz
Intel said it would cut more than 15 per cent of its workforce, some 17,500 people, as the chipmaker pursues a turnaround focused on its money-losing manufacturing business.

Job seekers speak with prospective employers during a City of Los Angeles career fair offering to fill vacancies in more than 30 classifications of jobs on November 2, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. The US Bureau of Labour Statistics will release on November 3 the October jobs report amid expectations employment remains quite healthy. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Biden to pass torch to Harris in bittersweet convention farewell
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to deliver a bittersweet farewell address at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, passing the torch to Vice President Kamala Harris as the party's nominee for the November election. Biden, 81, will praise Harris as the best person to finish the job of protecting American democracy from Republican rival Donald Trump. Harris will briefly appear with Biden on stage, and First Lady Jill Biden will also speak. The event comes after Biden's withdrawal from the race and Harris's ascent, and is seen as a symbol of unity among Democrats.

images.alt_text: From a market perspective, Trump’s policies could initially favour US assets and the USD.

site_title: Trump says he may end EV tax credit; is open to naming Elon Musk as an adviser
summary: Donald Trump, a Republican presidential candidate, expressed openness to ending the US$7,500 tax credit for electric vehicle purchases and potentially naming Tesla CEO Elon Musk to an advisory role. Trump stated that tax credits are not beneficial and would consider reversing Treasury Department rules or repealing the credit if elected. Musk has publicly endorsed Trump in the US presidential race, and Trump praised his intelligence, saying he would consider him for a Cabinet or advisory position.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. President Donald Trump gestures as he speaks during a campaign rally in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, U.S. August 17, 2024. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon

site_title: Beyond upskilling: Helping Singapore’s maritime workers acquire the right mix of skills
summary: Singapore's government has introduced new upskilling measures, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups and training allowances, to help the workforce acquire industry-relevant skills amid technological disruptions and sustainability imperatives. A systematic approach to developing skill sets is emphasized, with a focus on digital skills, domain skills, and soft skills. The maritime industry, a key sector, has formed the Tripartite Advisory Panel to deliberate on future-ready workforce development, recommending a framework to build skills in domain, digital, and soft skills. The government has also set up a Joint Office for Talent and Skills to coordinate efforts and partner with institutes of higher learning to strengthen the curriculum and develop continuing education courses.

images.alt_text: With the right response from employers across the private sector, the support that the Singapore government provides around upskilling will work as a phenomenal catalyst.

The ST-BT Budget Roundtable 2024 was moderated by ST associate editor Vikram Khanna (left), with panellists (L to R) UOB senior economist Alvin Liew; Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah; Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Ang Yuit; and NTUC deputy secretary-general Desmond Tan.
The SkillsFuture Credit will now have two tiers. At age 25, Singaporeans will receive a base tier of S$500 that does not expire. This can be used for a wide range of over 28,000 approved courses.

site_title: Government tightens HDB loan limits to tame resale market, extends more support to lower- to middle-income first-time buyers
summary: The Singapore government has implemented new measures to cool the HDB resale market, including lowering the loan-to-value ratio for HDB loans from 80% to 75% and extending more aid to first-time buyers through enhanced CPF housing grants. The revised grants will provide up to $230,000 in housing support for eligible first-time families and up to $115,000 for eligible singles. The measures aim to make housing more affordable for lower- to middle-income first-time home buyers and encourage prudent borrowing.

images.alt_text: “Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.
More than half of the resale flats transactions were from non-mature estates.
Some 61 per cent of homebuyers surveyed agree that the Housing Development Board’s Build-To-Order flats remain an affordable option.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has asked the Ministry of National Development to see what more can be done for singles.

site_title: UK tech tycoon Lynch among missing after yacht sinks off Sicily
summary: UK tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, 59, is among the missing after a luxury yacht, the Bayesian, sank off the coast of Sicily, Italy. Lynch is best known for selling Autonomy Corp to Hewlett Packard for over $11 billion in 2011. One person has died, and six others, including four UK nationals, are missing. Lynch's wife, Angela Bacares, was among those rescued. Italy's coast guard is leading search and rescue operations, which have recovered 15 people, including 12 guests and 3 crew. The cause of the sinking is unknown.

site_title: Global context for 2024 US race is different to 1968
summary: Pro-Palestine protesters marched in Chicago ahead of the Democratic National Convention, echoing the 1968 riots in the same city. However, the foreign policy context is different this time, with the US no longer involved in the Vietnam War. President Joe Biden's decision not to seek re-election and the absence of major conflicts are notable differences from the tumultuous 1968 election. The 2024 convention is taking place during a distinct era of global politics, with companies shifting focus from Vietnam to other issues.

images.alt_text: Pollsters and strategists from both major US parties warn that the "sugar high" of Harris' initial surge will wear off.

US President Joe Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris, the Democratic presidential nominee, raise their clasped hands during a campaign event at Prince George's Community College in Largo, Maryland, Aug 15, 2024.

site_title: Latest semiconductor results show that the sector is still stumbling
summary: The global semiconductor industry is showing signs of recovery, with the world's largest independent chipmaker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, reporting 45% revenue growth in July. However, several manufacturing companies that serve the technology industry delivered disappointing results, including AEM Holdings, which saw its earnings decline 95% to S$895,000. The sector's recovery is expected to be patchy, with smaller players delivering better results than larger ones. Despite this, the industry's overall sales increased 18.3% year-over-year to US$149.9 billion in Q2 2024, and electronics exports rose 15.7% in July.

images.alt_text: AEM CEO Amy Leong says she will share her plans for the company in November this year.

site_title: Thaksin faces royal insult charge as Thai court begins trial
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra appeared in court on Monday, August 19, as the trial of a royal insult case against him began. Thaksin, 75, faces up to 15 years in prison for comments he made in 2015 criticizing the monarchy. He received a royal amnesty just days earlier, allowing him to walk free, but is still barred from traveling. Thaksin denies the charges and has submitted evidence, including a list of 14 witnesses, to the court. The trial is set to take place in seven hearings next year.

images.alt_text: epa11554812 Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra arrives to face charges of insulting the monarchy at the Criminal Court in Bangkok, Thailand, 19 August 2024. The Criminal Court has released former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra on bail after he was indicted over lese-majeste crime charges allegedly for defaming the monarchy in his comments during an interview with a South Korean newspaper on 21 May 2015.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
The BOT has held the one-day repurchase rate at 2.5 per cent since the fourth quarter even as inflation remained way below the 1 to 3 per cent target.

site_title: GM lays off over 1,000 salaried software, services employees
summary: General Motors (GM) is laying off over 1,000 salaried software and services employees worldwide. The job cuts, which include roughly 600 jobs in the US, are not due to cost-cutting measures but rather a review of operations following the departure of executive vice president Mike Abbott in March. The layoffs come as GM prioritizes investments with the greatest impact as it builds its future, with about half of the cuts occurring in the US.

site_title: Icahn settles with US SEC over alleged disclosure failures
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn has settled with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over allegations of failing to disclose pledging majority of his firm's securities for personal margin loans. Icahn agreed to pay $2 million in penalties and did not admit or deny the allegations. The SEC found failures to disclose margin loans but did not substantiate more serious allegations of a "Ponzi-like" scheme. Icahn claimed Hindenburg Research's allegations were "scurrilous and unsupported" and had sparked the SEC probe, which allowed him to put the allegations to rest.

images.alt_text: Carl Icahn has a long history of investing in the gambling sector, owning casinos from Atlantic City to Las Vegas.

site_title: Are you really prepared for retirement?
summary: A former army officer and financial advisor warns that retirement planning goes beyond financial readiness, citing the tragic story of Pam Hixon, who struggled with purpose and depression after retiring at 60. Experts recommend a "dry run" of post-work life by taking a sabbatical or career break to live as close as possible to the planned retirement lifestyle, and making life decisions before financial ones. This allows individuals to assess their desired lifestyle, location, and activities, and make necessary adjustments to their financial plan.

images.alt_text: From a market perspective, Trump’s policies could initially favour US assets and the USD.

site_title: Yen rises sharply; euro hits highest this year
summary: The US dollar fell to a seven-month low of 102.15 against a basket of major currencies, while the yen rose sharply to its highest this year at 146.32, and the euro reached its strongest level at US$1.1051. The dollar's decline is attributed to traders' expectations of dovish signals from the Federal Reserve meeting minutes and chair Jerome Powell's speech, which may indicate interest rate cuts in the US. Analysts expect the Fed to cut interest rates by 25 basis points in September, supporting a stronger dollar in the short term.

images.alt_text: The dollar fell 1.04 per cent against the Japanese yen to 147.75.

The gold spot price rose to a record high of US$2,509.41 an ounce as investors snapped up the haven investment in the face of an increasingly likely US interest rate cut in September and heightened geopolitical risks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 19)
summary: Singapore consumers remain optimistic about the local economy, with 68% expressing confidence. However, a survey found that over half of consumers lack financial preparedness, with the youth being the most underprepared. Meanwhile, a report by Forrester predicts the global digital economy will reach $16.5 trillion by 2028, capturing 17% of global GDP. In other news, property groups are advised to sell low-yielding investment properties and debt remains accessible for Singapore-listed property groups.

site_title: Estee Lauder sees bleak 2025 results; CEO Fabrizio Freda to retire
summary: Estee Lauder forecasts 2025 profit and sales below estimates due to a slowing global beauty market, particularly in China. CEO Fabrizio Freda, who joined the company in 2008, is retiring. The company expects a 1-2% sales rise, compared to an analyst estimate of a 6.43% rise. Estee is considering internal and external candidates for CEO succession. Freda will continue to lead until a successor is appointed. The company's adjusted quarterly net sales rose to $3.87 billion.

images.alt_text: “I’m very committed to take this company through the recovery,” says Estée Lauder's CEO Fabrizio Freda.

site_title: AMD to acquire server builder ZT Systems for US$4.9 billion in cash and stock
summary: AMD plans to acquire server maker ZT Systems for US$4.9 billion in cash and stock, aiming to expand its portfolio of artificial intelligence chips and hardware to battle Nvidia. The acquisition, expected to close in the first half of 2025, will allow AMD to test and roll out its AI GPUs at scale, with CEO Lisa Su stating that "AI systems are our number one strategic priority." AMD will retain about 1,000 ZT Systems engineers and sell the server manufacturing business once the deal closes.

images.alt_text: AMD benefits from large cloud operators buying the company’s AI and other chips.
Intel revealed the details of the Gaudi 3 AI chip in April and has positioned it as a considerably cheaper and viable alternative to Nvidia’s H100 chips.
Nvidia sees the rise of generative AI as a new industrial revolution and expects to play a major role as the technology shifts to personal computers, the CEO says.
The chip will feature more memory and faster data throughput, the company said. MI350 will follow in 2025 and the MI400 model a year after that.

site_title: Pakistan ex-PM Imran Khan applies to be Oxford chancellor
summary: Pakistan's former Prime Minister Imran Khan has applied to become the chancellor of the University of Oxford, a prestigious British institution. Khan graduated from Oxford in 1975 and now seeks the position, one year into his prison sentence on various charges. The application scrutiny process will begin, according to Khan's party spokesman.

images.alt_text: Khan, 71, had been sentenced to 10 years in prison by a lower court on charges of making public a classified cable sent to Islamabad by Pakistan’s ambassador in Washington in 2022.

site_title: Money laundering syndicate based in JB busted by Singapore and Malaysia police
summary: Singapore and Malaysian police have busted a money laundering syndicate based in Johor Bahru, arresting 12 Malaysian nationals for their suspected involvement in laundering ill-gotten gains from scams using Singapore bank accounts. Besmond Huan Yu Kang, 22, was extradited to Singapore and charged for his role in the syndicate, which allegedly exploited Singapore's financial system to launder scam proceeds. The syndicate is seen as a key player in the illicit movement of funds, and authorities vow to continue collaborating to detect and deter such transnational syndicates.

site_title: Government funding of parental leave may not fully address operational concerns, say businesses
summary: Singapore is introducing a new parental leave policy, providing 10 weeks of government-paid leave to be shared by new parents, on top of existing entitlements. The policy aims to support work-life balance, but industry associations, such as the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme), warn that it may not fully address operational concerns, particularly for small businesses with leaner teams and smaller budgets. SMEs may struggle to adjust to the changes, which could impact business continuity, staffing, and project timelines. The government is expected to consider extending pay coverage for returning employees to mitigate these challenges.

images.alt_text: In introducing 10 extra weeks of shared parental leave, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong made no reference to the usual economic and existential fears surrounding population issues.

Singaporeans, PM Wong reiterated at the rally, want a more compassionate and inclusive society even as it continues to seek economic growth. Realising these new ambitions would require a “major reset” both in policies and people’s attitudes.
“Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.
New parents of Singaporean children will get an extra 10 weeks of government-paid leave to share between themselves from Apr 1, 2026.

site_title: Can China’s tech giants do without consumers?
summary: China's tech giants, including Alibaba and JD.com, failed to boost consumer spending despite aggressive price-cutting and marketing campaigns during the 618 shopping festival. Despite strong profit growth from Tencent's gaming unit, the broader economy remains struggling, with a prolonged housing slump and high youth unemployment. To counter this, companies may need to focus on innovation and alternative revenue streams, such as artificial intelligence and international expansion, as domestic conditions remain uncertain.

images.alt_text: JD.com’s second-quarter profit rose 73.7 per cent to 9.36 yuan per share, excluding items, compared with estimates of 6.07 yuan.
Investors worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share back from PDD Holdings and JD.com in China will compress margins.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an Ant Group logo at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, August 19, 2024 (Ep 125)
summary: Asia currencies reached a seven-month high due to a 'Goldilocks' US economic scenario, where growth is steady but not too fast. Meanwhile, Yoma fell 17% after denying involvement in online scams that funded a real estate project. Thailand's Ratanarak Group acquired Jardine Cycle's Siam City stake for $354 million.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 58 to 32 after 16 million securities worth S$41.6 million change hands.
Hong Kong piled on more than one per cent, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Sydney, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta, though Seoul, Singapore and Wellington dipped on Monday.
News agency The Irrawaddy reports that Yoma's former executive chairman, Serge Pun, is facing two additional charges.

The proposed sale of SCCC is “consistent with Jardine C&C’s strategy to evolve its portfolio in line with its long-term growth and sustainability objectives,” said the automotive retailer in a bourse filing on Friday (Aug 16).

site_title: Sliding Bitcoin struggling to harness rebound in global risk appetite
summary: Bitcoin has fallen about 9% in August, lagging the MSCI world share index's 1% gain and gold's all-time highs. The largest digital asset has dropped about 10% in the month, partly due to the US government's seizure of $12 billion worth of crypto. Blockchain data shows the US moved $600 million of confiscated Bitcoin to a Coinbase wallet. Analysts expect the price to rebound, but the funding rate for Bitcoin perpetual futures on Binance is at its most negative since 2022, signaling dwindling interest from speculators.

images.alt_text: Traders view the recent volatility in digital assets as the product of macro-economic factors as well as forced selling by crypto speculators.
The rout marks the first major stress test for digital assets since a group of spot-Bitcoin and Ether (ETFs debuted in the US in January and July, respectively.
ETFs that invest directly in Bitcoin have had four straight days of outflows, totalling roughly US$423 million.
Bitcoin has been buffeted by a range of factors since hitting a record of US$73,798 in March.

site_title: Soft landing bets for US economy lift investor sentiment; STI up 0.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,355.56, driven by expectations of a soft landing for the US economy, with US inflation easing favourably. Markets gained confidence in a September rate cut, boosted by Federal Reserve members' comments. The broader market saw gainers beat losers 288 to 266, with 920.2 million securities worth S$1.1 billion traded.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
Mia Pei

site_title: Rallying the nation with hope, not fear
summary: In his first National Day Rally, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized hope over fear in addressing Singapore's population issues, reframing policy announcements to focus on supporting parenthood and reskilling. He introduced 10 extra weeks of government-paid shared parental leave and extended a training allowance to part-time courses, acknowledging that these are personal choices and the government's role is to create a more family-friendly environment. Wong also highlighted the need for a renewed social compact where every Singaporean feels there is hope, as a defense against real threats, in an effort to ensure concrete opportunities and support.

images.alt_text: A father with his child at Toa Payoh central, 13 February  2024. parents, parenting, family

site_title: Thai central bank to hold rates until Q2 2025, political turmoil risks early cut
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) has decided to keep interest rates unchanged until Q2 2025 to balance growth with inflation control, despite the government's repeated calls to lower them. Inflation remains below the target range of 1-3% at 0.83% in July. The decision comes amid growing political uncertainty following the dismissal of Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin. The BOT will remain in a wait-and-watch mode to assess the impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput speaks during his first briefing on the economy and monetary policy after taking office in Bangkok, Thailand October 20, 2020. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Jardine C&C, Yoma, Memiontec
summary: Keppel has signed a memorandum of understanding with ACEN and GenZero to explore the origination and utilization of transition credits to retire a coal-fired power plant in the Philippines. Jardine C&C has proposed selling its 25.5% stake in Siam City Cement for S$458.7 million. Yoma Strategic has clarified that no investigations are underway regarding a former executive chairman's alleged use of criminal proceeds. Memiontec co-founders have been released on bail after being interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Australia’s Lendlease reports A$1.5 billion loss amid strategy shift, regulatory delays
summary: Australia's Lendlease reported a full-year loss of A$1.5 billion due to a strategy shift and regulatory delays. The company plans to retreat from its overseas construction business, freeing up up to A$4.5 billion in capital. This move comes after the Australian competition regulator delayed the sale of community projects, impacting core earnings. Lendlease has already divested its US construction business and sold A$1.9 billion in assets as part of its targeted A$2.8 billion by June 2025.

images.alt_text: Lendlease Group aims to lower its cost base, with an annual target of A$125 million pre-tax savings, and also return capital to its shareholders via a A$500 million share buyback programme.
Google still plans to work with developers and capital partners to move the projects forward.
Lendlease has "quite a good pipeline" and its primary focus is what is has, says Asia CEO Justin Gabbani. "If you look historically at Lendlease, we've been quite selective about what we pursue."
Lendlease is also pushing for an industry-wide data-sharing platform for the secure exchange of digitised, verified Scope 3 emissions data across value chains.

site_title: China court accepts liquidation hearing against Evergrande unit
summary: A mainland Chinese court accepted a liquidation application against a China Evergrande Group unit, Guangzhou Kailong Real Estate, triggering a formal legal process that may lead to liquidation of the defaulted developer in its main base of operations. The Intermediate People's Court of Guangzhou City accepted the application on August 9, with a creditors meeting scheduled for November 14. This development increases pressure on Evergrande to restructure or face liquidation.

site_title: China and Vietnam sign 14 deals from rail to crocodiles after leaders meet
summary: China and Vietnam signed 14 documents after Chinese President Xi Jinping met Vietnam's new leader To Lam in Beijing, strengthening bilateral ties and trade cooperation. The agreements include cross-border railways, transport infrastructure development, and defence and security ties. Lam sought soft loans and technology to upgrade Vietnam's transport infrastructure, while Xi pledged to import more Vietnamese farm produce. The two countries aim to deepen their strategic partnership and enhance connectivity, including railways and highways, to boost trade and investment.

images.alt_text: Long-term relief for the consumer is unlikely so long as China’s real estate slump squeezes household budgets.
President Xi Jinping gets a lot of economic advice. Beijing is urged – or admonished – to boost consumer spending, rein in exports, curb overcapacity, and clean up local-government debt.

Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.
China’s top leaders already signalled a more supportive stance towards growth at a recent Politburo meeting by vowing to shift their focus to consumption.

site_title: Malaysia’s reNIKOLA to invest over US$240 million in compressed biomethane gas projects in Indonesia
summary: Malaysia's reNIKOLA Holdings plans to invest over US$240 million in 40 compressed biomethane gas projects in Indonesia, aiming to develop a combined capacity of 100 megawatts. The projects will be developed in partnership with Perkebunan Nusantara IV, a division of Indonesia's state-owned agricultural enterprise. The investment supports Indonesia's goal of achieving a 26% renewable energy mix by 2030, and aligns with reNIKOLA's expansion plans to reach a 1 gigawatt-peak capacity.

site_title:
Package deals make a comeback 
as sun seekers count the cost
summary: Tourists are turning to package holidays in Europe as soaring hotel and flight prices revive demand for all-inclusive deals. The trend, which began last year, has accelerated this summer, the busiest for travel since the pandemic. Travelers are attracted to fixed-price packages with no unexpected add-on costs and easier redress when things go wrong, particularly during the cost-of-living crisis and disruptions. This shift is bolstering the balance sheets of some travel companies.

images.alt_text: Tourists enjoy the weather at Malagueta beach, on a hot summer day, in Malaga, Spain, August 14, 2024. REUTERS/Jon Nazca

site_title: Uber-backed e-scooter startup Lime enters Japan after South Korea exit
summary: Uber-backed e-scooter startup Lime launched its service in Tokyo's densely populated neighborhoods, entering Japan's growing e-scooter market. Lime, which has a global fleet of 200,000 e-bikes and scooters, now has around 200 electric scooters and 40 recharging ports in Tokyo. The company's entry is a sign of Japan's belated acceptance of the sharing economy, following years of dialogue between regulators and local governments. Lime aims to grow slowly and earn trust with local regulators, and its modified e-scooters meet Japan's regulations, including helmet and licence requirements for e-scooter users.

site_title: India PM Modi to visit Ukraine, weeks after rebuking Putin in Moscow
summary: India Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to visit Ukraine, weeks after his trip to Moscow, where he rebuked President Vladimir Putin over a strike on a children's hospital. The visit aims to control damage from the Moscow trip and reinforce India's position that the conflict should be resolved through dialogue and diplomacy. Modi also plans to visit Poland, and his visit coincides with efforts by the US and NATO to bolster Ukraine and counter Russia. The visit is seen as a step to strengthen India-Ukraine ties and potentially mediate between Russia and Ukraine.

images.alt_text: epa11469927 Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks during a joint press conference with Austria's chancellor in Vienna, Austria, 10 July 2024. It is the first visit by an Indian head of government to Austria in more than 40 years.  EPA-EFE/MAX SLOVENCIK

site_title: Siemens unit consortium bags $400 million Cross Island Line power supply contract from LTA
summary: Siemens Mobility, leading a consortium with Concord Corporation, has secured a $400 million contract from the Land Transport Authority to design, supply, install, test, and commission a power supply system for Singapore's eighth MRT line, the Cross Island Line. The system will be fully automated and driverless ready, optimizing lifecycle costs and providing a safe and reliable commute for passengers. Construction is expected to be completed by 2030.

images.alt_text: Passenger service of CRL’s second phase is targeted to commence in 2032.
An artist's impression of the future West Coast station on the Cross Island Line.
LTA awards S$526m civil contract for Bright Hill interchange on Cross Island Line Phase 1

site_title: Property groups should sell low-yielding investment properties, go slow in raising debt
summary: Singapore-listed property groups can access debt funding at relatively competitive interest rates. However, due to low yields on investment properties, they may consider selling such assets and instead focusing on housing development opportunities. Low-yielding properties may not provide sufficient returns, especially if debt costs do not decrease. In contrast, housing development can offer more promising margins, driven by declining land costs and growing demand for private homes. Property groups may need to reassess their strategies to boost returns, potentially by selling low-yielding investment properties and prioritizing housing development.

images.alt_text: Singapore dollar notes in 2, 5, 10 and 50 denomination.

site_title: Canada's Couche-Tard makes preliminary bid for Japanese retail giant Seven & i
summary: Canada's Couche-Tard has made a preliminary bid for Japanese retail giant Seven & i, the largest ever buyout of a Japanese firm by an overseas company. Seven & i has formed a special committee to review the proposal, but no decision has been made. The deal, if successful, would value Seven & i at $50.3 billion. The talks are at an early stage, with Couche-Tard valued at roughly $58 billion. This move comes as Seven & i faces pressure from activist investors to sell underperforming assets and focus on its global convenience store business.

images.alt_text: Seven & i will likely announce its plan to list Ito-Yokado, a major general merchandise store chain, on Wednesday, when it is set to announce its financial result.

site_title: Biden dropping out: Is it a game changer?
summary: US President Joe Biden has dropped out of the re-election bid, endorsing Vice-President Kamala Harris, sending ripples through financial markets. Investors are now gauging the impact on Donald Trump's chances of reclaiming the White House. A Trump presidency could initially favor US assets and the US dollar, but risks from unilateral executive actions and heightened protectionism remain. A Republican sweep of the White House and Congress could lead to significant policy changes, including deregulation and tax cuts, but also widen the fiscal deficit and increase market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Former U.S. President Donald Trump holds up a piece of art, showing moments after his recent assassination attempt, during a campaign event in Atlanta, Georgia, US, on Saturday, Aug. 3, 2024. Trump said he is willing to debate Vice President Kamala Harris on Fox News on Sept. 4 in Pennsylvania, although it wasn't clear if the Democratic nominee had been consulted on the terms of the proposal. Photographer: Dustin Chambers/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s biodiesel producers seek new outlets as hefty EU tariffs bite
summary: China's biodiesel producers, primarily privately-run small plants, are seeking new outlets for their exports amid EU tariffs that have reduced demand and prices. The EU imposed provisional anti-dumping duties of 12.8-36.4% on Chinese biodiesel, worth $2.3 billion last year. Exports to the EU have fallen 51% since mid-2023, and some producers are exploring the marine fuel market in China and Singapore. Larger producers are also planning to build sustainable aviation fuel plants and scouting for new clients outside the EU bloc.

images.alt_text: BYD, China’s top-selling car brand, is pressing on with its expansion in Europe.
In July, the EU slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 per cent on Chinese EVs after its executive arm concluded in an investigation that they were unfairly undermining European rivals.
China is both the largest producer and the world’s biggest market for EVs, yet the manufacturers mostly rely on foreign companies for the multiple chips that modern high-end cars require.
Xi Jinping (right) has sought to portray himself as a neutral arbiter on the world stage capable of brokering agreements such as last year’s accord between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.

site_title: MAS issues 9-year prohibition order against ex-OCBC representative for misconduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a 9-year prohibition order against Hoi Wei Kit, a former OCBC representative, for misconduct. Hoi was convicted of cheating and other charges in 2022 and sentenced to 30 months' imprisonment. He was barred from providing financial advisory services and taking part in the management of any financial advisory firm. The MAS stated that the convictions showed Hoi would not perform financial advisory services honestly, leading to the prohibition order.

images.alt_text:
ST20220719-202264388695-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
MAS Building at 10 Shenton Way on July 19, 2022.
Singapore's financial sector went from strength to strength, buoyed by broad-based growth but inflationary pressures, wobbly global growth and global tightening monetary policies have weighed on the central bank's fiscal performance.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Tuesday (July 19) announced at its annual review that it clocked a net loss of $7.4 billion for the financial year ended March 31, 2022 - the first time in nine years. The loss came from lower investment gains, a large negative foreign exchange translation effect, and higher interest expenses.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Japan, Tokyo governments target 700 billion yen valuation for Tokyo Metro in IPO: sources
summary: Japan's national and Tokyo governments are seeking a 700 billion yen valuation for Tokyo Metro, aiming to list the subway operator in October, potentially raising 350 billion yen in its largest IPO in six years. The valuation, if achieved, would surpass Kokusai Electric's 2023 IPO and SoftBank's 2018 listing. The company, which operates 195 km of lines carrying 6.5 million daily passengers, reported a 2/3 jump in net profit to 46 billion yen in the financial year ended March 2024.

images.alt_text: Japan's core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the six to nine months ahead, rose in June by 2.1 per cent from the previous month, Cabinet Office data showed.
FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

People look at the city's skyline from the Bunkyo Civic Center Observation Deck in Tokyo, Japan, Aug 14, 2024. Typhoon Ampil is set late on Thursday to skirt the Tokyo region - home to almost 40 million people - and then churn up the Pacific coast on Friday and Saturday.
News about Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's resignation flashed on public screens in Tokyo; August 14,  2024.

Currency markets have been rocked by a sharp rally in the yen since July that has prompted – and been driven by – an unwinding of a highly popular investment strategy called the carry trade and contributed to a slide in stocks.

Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda attends a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on April 26, 2024. The Bank of Japan kept its ultra-low interest rates unchanged on April 26 and stopped short of signalling another hike, pushing the yen to a fresh 34-year low against the dollar. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Philippines detects first mpox case this year, yet to determine strain
summary: The Philippines has reported its first mpox case this year, a 33-year-old male with no travel history, according to the Department of Health. The patient is awaiting test results to determine the strain. This case is the 10th laboratory-confirmed case in the country, with symptoms including fever and a rash. The World Health Organization has declared mpox a global public health emergency, citing its easy spread through close contact. The outbreak has been reported in several countries, including Sweden, Pakistan, and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Health Organization (WHO) logo is seen near its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Two-thirds of Singapore consumers optimistic about local economy, but over half lack financial preparedness: survey
summary: Singapore consumers are more optimistic about the local economy, with 68% expressing confidence, a 20 percentage point surge from last year. However, two-thirds of consumers lack financial preparedness, particularly Gen Zs aged 18-25 who are underprepared in insurance and legacy planning. The UOB Asean Consumer Sentiment Study found that a significant majority of Singapore consumers are not taking adequate steps to secure their financial future.

images.alt_text: On a seasonally adjusted, quarterly basis, Singapore's economy contracted/expanded x per cent in Q2.
Year-on-year GDP growth, at 2.9 per cent in Q2, beat economists' median estimate.
Malaysia’s economy grew more than expected in the second quarter of 2024, exceeding the 5.8 per cent advance estimates made by the Department of Statistics Malaysia.

site_title: Busiest US ports absorb import surge nearing pandemic-era frenzy
summary: The US' busiest ports, Los Angeles and Long Beach, are experiencing a surge in import volumes nearing pandemic-era highs. Despite worries about a cooling economy, the ports' third-strongest month ever in July was driven by retailers stocking up ahead of US tariffs on Chinese goods and a possible strike by American dockworkers. Capacity constraints are rising, but ports are maintaining efficient operations, with some gauges of capacity constraints starting to increase. A potential strike by longshoremen could lead to a cargo backlog taking up to a year to clear, and companies are racing to beat the imposition of more tariffs on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: Maersk, LR and Core Power will assess the regulatory feasibility and frameworks that would be needed for a container ship using a fourth-generation nuclear reactor to undertake cargo operations in Europe.

Maersk, viewed as a barometer of world trade, said global container demand increased about 7 per cent year on year in the first half of the year, boosted by robust demand from Europe, emerging markets and strong Chinese exports.
“The car carrier industry has enjoyed exceptionally good times for a couple of years actually and we still are,” said Andreas Enger, the chief executive officer of Höegh Autoliners.
Maersk now sees underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of US$9 billion to US$11 billion this year, compared with a previous forecast of US$7 billion to US$9 billion.

FILE PHOTO: Containers are seen on the Maersk's Triple-E giant container ship Majestic Maersk, one of the world's largest container ships, next to cranes at the APM Terminals in the port of Algeciras, Spain January 20, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

site_title: New Zealand population growth slows further on economic weakness
summary: New Zealand's population growth slowed further in the second quarter, increasing by 7,000 to 5,338,500, the weakest pace since 2022. Net immigration declined to 2,000, the lowest quarterly read since mid-2022, due to a sluggish economy and record numbers of citizens seeking overseas job opportunities, particularly in Australia. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand attributed the decline in immigration to cooling inflation pressures, expecting net arrivals of working-age people to slow to 31,000 this year.

site_title: Indonesia’s outgoing leader gives Cabinet jobs to loyalists of successor Prabowo
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has appointed new Cabinet ministers with close ties to his successor Prabowo Subianto, two months ahead of his departure. Widodo handed over Cabinet jobs to Prabowo loyalists in a move aimed at smoothing the transition of power. The appointments include Prabowo as Defence Minister, as well as new ministers for energy, investment, and law, and heads of three agencies. The move is seen as a quid-pro-quo, ensuring Widodo maintains influence after a decade in charge.

images.alt_text: A coal power plant is seen along the north coast of Jakarta on July 4, 2024.
Expenditure in the proposed 2025 budget, which was jointly prepared by Widodo’s (right) ministers and Prabowo’s economic team, is almost 6 per cent higher than this year’s forecast.
Widodo (left) talks to Prabowo after delivering his final state address on Friday; Widodo has been laying the groundwork for a seamless transition by supporting initiatives championed by Prabowo.
Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, wearing the traditional Betawi attire, delivers his annual state of the nation address at the parliament building in Jakarta on Aug 16, 2024.

The Purbaleunyi Toll Road running parallel to the HSR. Constructed in 1989, it forms part of the existing highway network linking Jakarta and Bandung. The HSR has cut the 3.5-hour drive to a train ride of less than an hour.

site_title: Asia: Markets get week off to largely positive start
summary: Asian markets started the week on a positive note, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and several other markets rising. Investors are focused on a speech by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, who is expected to discuss possible interest rate cuts. The US economy is seen as avoiding recession, with Wall Street indexes near record highs. Oil prices were steady, while gold prices broke above $2,500. Tensions between Israel and Hamas remain a concern, with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken meeting with Israeli leaders to try to broker a ceasefire.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 58 to 32 after 16 million securities worth S$41.6 million change hands.

site_title: Ericsson reaches deal to sell US firm to Koch unit
summary: Ericsson has agreed to sell its US call-routing business Iconectiv to a private investment arm of Koch for $1 billion. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2025 and result in one-time earnings of $8.8 billion. Ericsson aims to generate $1.3 billion in cash after taxes and other liabilities. The sale is part of the company's efforts to cut costs and improve margins in a challenging telecom equipment market.

site_title: Stay focused on business goals when going digital, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 applications have opened, offering a platform for innovative and growing businesses to be recognized. The awards, now in its 10th edition, will celebrate outstanding achievements in various categories such as innovation, sustainability, and growth. Applications are open until June 30, 2025. The winners will be announced at a ceremony in July 2025, with the event expected to attract business leaders and entrepreneurs from across the globe. The awards aim to promote and support emerging businesses, providing a unique opportunity for them to gain recognition and network with industry peers.

site_title: UK job vacancies increase for first time this year, Adzuna says
summary: The UK job vacancies increased by 1.1% in July to 862,043, according to Adzuna, signaling a potential turning point in the labour market. This rise in vacancies, coupled with an increase in job seekers, makes it the most competitive market for hiring since May 2021. The data may indicate that the economy is gaining strength, contrary to recent official data showing declining vacancies and easing wage growth.

images.alt_text: A strong performance in the second quarter meant the UK enjoyed the best growth in the Group of Seven nations in the first half of 2024, outstripping the US and well ahead of other European countries.

epa10993033 People walk along Oxford Street as they do their Black Friday shopping and enjoy the decorations in London, Britain, 24 November 2023. The Black Friday global sales event sees the UK retailers increasing their Black Friday discounts in 2023 but customers face ongoing concerns about the cost of living.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN
In June alone, Britain’s level of gross domestic product was unchanged compared with a year earlier, when it was 0.7 per cent higher.

site_title: Thailand's Ratanarak Group buys out Jardine Cycle's Siam City stake for US$354 million
summary: Thailand's Ratanarak Group has acquired Singapore-based Jardine Cycle & Carriage's 25.54% stake in Siam City Cement for US$353.97 million, increasing its controlling shareholder, Sunrise Equity, to a 71.88% stake in the cement maker. The deal values Siam City Cement at 47.68 billion baht (S$1.81 billion). This move further solidifies the Ratanarak Group's presence in Thailand's cement industry, led by the family's substantial holdings in various firms.

images.alt_text: 豪华汽车品牌马赛地在本地设立亚洲第一个“马赛地中心”）（Mercedes-Benz Center）。这个展销中心把马赛地业务集中在同一个屋檐下，顾客往后将获得销售、维修、保养方面等一站式服务。坐落在亚历山大路的马赛地中心由 戴姆勒克莱斯勒（DaimlerChrysler）汽车集团和授权代理商怡和合发（JardineCycle & Carriage）合作设立。

site_title: Thailand growth quickens even as US$14 billion stimulus hangs
summary: Thailand's economy expanded at its fastest pace in five quarters, with a 2.3% growth in the three months through June, driven by tourism and exports. However, a leadership change and uncertainty over a $14 billion stimulus plan cast a cloud over the outlook. The Bank of Thailand is expected to keep its policy rate steady, the highest since 2013, amidst concerns over the economy's growth and the impact of the stimulus plan. The country's super-long bonds have gained in value due to rising tariffs and a political crisis.

images.alt_text: "As head of the government I will work with parliament with an open heart, open to all ideas to help develop the country," Paetongtarn Shinawatra says.
The economy likely grew 2.1 per cent in the second quarter from a year ago, according to a median estimate of economists ahead of the announcement on Monday.
Stocks prices displayed on an electronic stock board are photographed with a zoom effect in Bangkok, Thailand. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: As demand grows, OUE Healthcare looks to beef up regional offerings
summary: OUE Healthcare, a Catalist-listed healthcare group, aims to strengthen its presence in Singapore and China's premium private healthcare market. The company has acquired a 26.2% stake in Healthway Medical and is expanding its services, including general practitioners and secondary care services. Yet Kum Meng, CEO, is bullish on the healthcare industry's outlook, citing Asia's growing demand for healthcare services. The group plans to open two new hospitals in Changshu and Shenzhen, and is focusing on differentiating itself from China's robust public healthcare system. Despite a net loss of S$3.8 million in the first half of 2024, the company remains optimistic about its future growth.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
OUE Healthcare's hospital in Changshu, China.

site_title: Foxconn chief defends hiring practices after report married women rejected in India
summary: Foxconn's chairman, Liu Young, defended the company's hiring practices after a Reuters report found that married women were systematically excluded from iPhone assembly jobs in India. Despite acknowledging some lapses in hiring practices in 2022, Foxconn "vigorously refutes allegations of employment discrimination." The Indian government ordered an investigation into the matter, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has called for a detailed report. Foxconn employs 33,360 women, including 2,750 married women, at its main India iPhone factory.

images.alt_text: Hon Hai has set itself the goal of securing 40 per cent of the global AI server market, relying on its close relationships with many of the world’s biggest tech companies and depth of manufacturing expertise.
FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past the logo of Foxconn outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan November 9, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
According to the investment certificate, the two projects will complete construction in July, 2026.
Foxconn has invested more than US$3.2 billion in Vietnam since fist entering the South-east Asian country in the 2000s.

site_title: India pledges US$3.5 million to help developing nations with trade
summary: India has pledged $3.5 million to help developing nations promote trade and build capacity, aiming to avoid debt traps. The plan, proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will focus on human-centric, multi-dimensional programs with technology sharing and concessional finance. The initiative will be presented to the UN's Summit of Future in New York, following a virtual summit attended by representatives from 18 countries, including Bangladesh, Ethiopia, and Chile. The move is seen as India's attempt to position itself as a leader of the Global South and counter China's influence in the region.

images.alt_text: epa11469927 Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks during a joint press conference with Austria's chancellor in Vienna, Austria, 10 July 2024. It is the first visit by an Indian head of government to Austria in more than 40 years.  EPA-EFE/MAX SLOVENCIK
India conducted inspections, sampling and testing of mixed spice blends after Hong Kong suspended sales of some blends of the MDH and Everest brands in April.

Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, during the nation's Independence Day ceremony at Red Fort in New Delhi. He again called for a replacement of India’s religion-based laws with a uniform civil code, a move that’s been opposed by some minority groups.
India’s merchandise exports stood at US$33.98 billion in July, while imports were US$57.48 billion.

site_title: X says it is closing operations in Brazil due to judge’s content orders
summary: Media platform X, owned by Elon Musk, is closing its operations in Brazil "effective immediately" due to "censorship orders" by Brazilian judge Alexandre de Moraes. The orders allegedly threaten X representative Rachel Nova Conceicao with arrest if the platform doesn't comply with taking down content. X claims the orders are a result of secret threats, and the platform remains available to users in Brazil.

images.alt_text: X had recently started “irreversibly feeding” the personal data of more than 60 million European users into its Grok AI technology, “without ever informing them or asking for their consent”, according to the European Centre for Digital Rights, also known as Noyb.
The lawsuit is the latest in a series of legal actions taken against Elon Musk.
A number of advertisers left Twitter following Musk’s takeover amid concerns about the level of content moderation under the new ownership and Musk’s own controversial musings on the site.

site_title: Beijing says Chinese, Philippine ships ‘collided’ in disputed South China Sea
summary: China's coast guard says Philippine ships "collided" with a Chinese vessel near a disputed shoal in the South China Sea, with Beijing accusing the Philippine Coast Guard of "illegally entering" the area. Footage appears to show the incident, with one ship allegedly running into the side of the Chinese vessel before moving on. The Philippine Coast Guard denies any incidents, and analysts say the clash could escalate tensions in the region, with the US potentially becoming involved. Beijing continues to press its claims to the South China Sea despite an international tribunal ruling that its assertion has no legal basis.

images.alt_text: epa11554758 A handout photo made available by the Philippine Coast Guard shows the damaged ship BRP Cape Engano following a collision with a Chinese coast guard vessel near Sabina Shoal in disputed waters of the South China Sea, 19 August 2024. National Task Force for the West Philippine Sea (NTF-WPS) spokesperson Jonathan Malaya announced that the Philippine Coast Guard patrol ships 'BRP Bagacay' and 'BRP Cape Engano' were damaged after being subjected to unlawful and aggressive maneuvers by Chinese Coast Guard ships while en route for a resupply mission to the Spratys islands in South China Sea.  EPA-EFE/Philippine Coast Guard HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Asia currencies hit seven-month high on ‘Goldilocks’ US scenario
summary: Asian currencies reached a seven-month high due to improved US recession concerns, bets on US Federal Reserve rate cuts, and a strong domestic backdrop. The Bloomberg Asia Dollar Index gained 0.6% as the ringgit rose 1.5% to its strongest level since February 2023. The South Korean won and Malaysian ringgit led regional gains, while the Thai baht rose after the appointment of a new prime minister. Goldman Sachs economists lowered the probability of a US recession to 20% and predicted a 25-basis-point interest rate cut by the Fed in September.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian rupiah has strengthened on the back of favourable domestic conditions and global sentiment. Economists expect further relief for Asean currencies after the US Federal Reserve cuts rates in September.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Do ILPs have a place in your portfolio? (Ep 180)
summary: Investment-linked insurance policies (ILPs) have been a staple in the insurance industry since the early 1990s. However, their popularity has waxed and waned over the years due to concerns about their performance. In a recent podcast, CEO of Providend Christopher Tan and chief agency officer of Income Insurance Tan Chuan How discussed the current state of ILPs. Despite still facing negativity, ILPs have a place in a diversified portfolio, offering a unique asset class with potential for long-term growth. Experts recommend considering ILPs as part of a broader investment strategy.

images.alt_text: Dealing with high costs in the world’s costliest city can be challenging.

site_title: Australia fears A$3 billion hit from China slowdown
summary: Australia's economy may face a multibillion-dollar hit due to China's slowdown and falling iron ore prices. The nation's iron ore exports, accounting for 18% of its total exports, have dropped by 30% since the start of the year. This could reduce tax receipts by around A$3 billion over the next three to four years, according to Treasurer Jim Chalmers. The Australian mining sector, heavily reliant on China, has already seen a 20% decline in shares since the start of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An autonomous truck readies to pick up a load of iron ore at Australia's Fortescue Metals Group (FMG) Chichester Hub, which includes the Christmas Creek iron ore mine, in the Pilbara region, located southeast of the coastal town of Port Hedland in Western Australia, November 29, 2018. Picture taken November 29, 2018.  REUTERS/Melanie Burton/File Photo

site_title: Chinese copper exports fall from record as local demand rebounds
summary: Chinese copper exports dropped 40% in July from a record high in June, falling to 140,940 tonnes, as domestic buyers took advantage of the metal's price retreat. This is despite a 43% increase in exports over the first seven months of 2024 compared to the previous year. The rally in international prices led to a surge in overseas warehouses tracked by the LME, providing a rare window for Chinese exports.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Copper rods are seen at Truong Phu cable factory in northern Hai Duong province, outside Hanoi, Vietnam, August 11, 2017. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: Pacific International Lines adds 5 LNG dual-fuel container vessels to fleet
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) has ordered five liquefied natural gas (LNG) dual-fuel container vessels, part of its fleet renewal strategy focused on larger and more eco-friendly vessel types. The vessels, each with a capacity of 13,000 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEU), are expected to be delivered from end-2026 and will contribute to PIL's decarbonisation goal of net-zero emissions by 2050. The new vessels will incorporate energy-saving features and digital technologies to automate tasks, supporting PIL's transport of temperature-controlled products.

site_title: Gold holds near record high on US rate cut optimism
summary: Gold prices held near a record high, edging 0.2% lower to US$2,501.19 per ounce, amid rising expectations of a US interest rate cut next month. The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut rates on Sep 18, with traders pricing in a 75.5% chance of a 25 basis point cut. A low interest rate environment boosts gold's appeal, with Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago president Austan Goolsbee stating the US economy is not overheating.

images.alt_text: Spot bullion climbed as much as 2.2 per cent last Friday (Aug 16), exceeding the previous record set last month.

site_title: UK estate agents report more buyer interest after BOE rate cut
summary: UK estate agents report a 19% increase in buyer enquiries in August compared to the same period last year, with Rightmove citing the Bank of England's interest rate cut as a positive factor. Mortgage rates have fallen to 4.80% from 5.82% a year ago, and financial markets expect at least one further rate cut this year. Asking prices for newly advertised properties are 0.8% higher than a year earlier, and prices in June were 2.7% higher than last year, the joint-biggest increase since March 2023.

images.alt_text: By 2040, this former World War II airfield will be transformed into a thriving town with 10,000 homes and about 25,000 residents.
FILE PHOTO: A row of residential houses is seen with the financial district in the distance in South London, Britain, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

A strong performance in the second quarter meant the UK enjoyed the best growth in the Group of Seven nations in the first half of 2024, outstripping the US and well ahead of other European countries.
Regular pay has been growing at roughly double the pace the BOE thinks is compatible with keeping inflation at its 2 per cent target over the medium term.

Floodwater from the rivers Avon and Severn surrounds Tewkesbury Abbey in the aftermath of Storm Henk in Tewkesbury, Britain, Jan 8, 2024. Increased flooding from overflowing rivers and blocked drains is causing insurers to pull back from offering coverage, particularly for commercial properties and residential landlords, according to industry representatives.

The median pay for a FTSE-100 company CEO rose 2.2 per cent to £4.19 million last year, think tank the High Pay Centre said, though it added CEO pay growth had slowed compared with the previous two years.
Permanent hiring extended a nearly two-year downturn although the drop was less marked than a month earlier, and pay increases were weaker than in June.

site_title: Australia’s Westpac profit rises as margin pressure shows signs of easing
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking reported a profit of A$1.8 billion in the June quarter, beating expectations as margin pressure eased and mortgage lending grew. The nation's largest banks face declining interest rates, with consumers and businesses cutting spending. CEO Peter King stated that the cost of living and high interest rates remain a challenge, while businesses face cost pressures and lower demand. Despite this, Westpac's mortgage lending growth offset these challenges, providing a glimmer of hope for the bank's performance.

site_title: F is for fake: investors on why founders cry Ivy League
summary: A growing trend in the South-east Asian startup scene involves founders fabricating educational credentials, with several cases reported, including a Singaporean AI startup founder claiming a Stanford University doctorate and a CEO of a waste management startup claiming a master's degree from the University of California at Berkeley. Investors acknowledge the "fake it till you make it" culture but stress that due diligence procedures, such as verifying educational backgrounds, are crucial. However, some investors admit that they often focus on financial performance and may not thoroughly verify founders' credentials. The ecosystem is maturing, with some investors calling for a shift in mindset, but concerns about bad behavior persist.

images.alt_text: Before implementing AI, organisations need to first evaluate its readiness and intended usage as part of their longer-term overall strategy.
The number of IVF treatments performed in the US has more than doubled in the past decade, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.1% or 37.16 points to 3,352.89. The broader market saw 58 gainers outperforming 32 losers, with 16 million securities worth S$41.6 million changing hands. The rally follows Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's National Day Rally speech on Sunday.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: UOB Malaysia on track to better 2023’s record profit this year, says CEO
summary: UOB Malaysia is on track to surpass its record profit of RM1.9 billion in 2023, with CEO Ng Wei Wei attributing the growth to top-line growth, cost management, and strategic investment in key sectors such as industrials, energy, and the digital economy. The bank's retail segment has seen a consistent rise in new current and savings accounts, and wholesale banking is expected to grow by 16% by 2026. UOB Malaysia aims to increase its customer base to 2 million by 2026 and boost its return on equity to 12-14% by the same year.

images.alt_text: Offshoring is always an option because of the high cost in Singapore, although UOB is also mindful of the quality of labour supply, said CFO Lee Wai Fai.
Generative artificial intelligence is driving the growth of green data centres in this region, while the electric vehicle boom is propelling the industrials sectors, said Lim.
Net interest income falls 1 per cent on year, to S$2.4 billion, due to a moderation in net interest margin.

site_title: Memiontec husband and wife co-founders out on bail amid CAD, MAS probe
summary: Memiontec co-founders Tay Kiat Seng and Soelistyo Dewi Soegiharto, who were arrested by the Commercial Affairs Department and Monetary Authority of Singapore, have been released on bail. The investigation, related to potential use of manipulative and deceptive devices, is ongoing and may not lead to formal charges. Memiontec's nominating committee has assessed the pair as suitable to remain as directors, and no immediate measures are needed to safeguard against internal control risks. The company will provide updates on the investigations as material developments occur.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo issues Trade with Caution alert on Memiontec Holdings
Memiontec says unaware of reason for unusual stock price movements
Singapore firms helping to fuel Indonesia's tech sector's growth

site_title: Japan’s June machinery orders rise 2.1% m/m, more than expected
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 2.1% in June from the previous month, exceeding economists' expectations of a 1.1% increase. However, on a year-on-year basis, core orders dropped 1.7%, lower than the forecasted 1.8% growth. This mixed data may indicate a shift in Japan's capital spending patterns, potentially affecting the country's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks machinery at a factory in Higashiosaka, Japan June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Sakura Murakami/File Photo

site_title: NTU’s wooden building of the future has a mould problem
summary: Singapore's Nanyang Technological University (NTU) is experiencing issues with mould growth in its wooden building, Gaia, which is Asia's largest wooden structure and a zero-energy building. Constructed from sustainably harvested timber beams and panels, the 450,000 sq. ft. building was designed to consume as much energy as it produces. However, the spruce wood used in the building is prone to mould growth due to high humidity, and experts warn that similar issues can arise in other tropical climates. Despite the problems, NTU has developed maintenance plans to address the issue, and experts suggest that mass timber can be a sustainable option when designed for specific climates.

images.alt_text: Dual key HDB flats present an option for owners to reconfigure their homes for rental.
The suburban Outside Central Region continues to lead in condo and private apartment sales, accounting for 77.8 per cent of sales in July.
Some 61 per cent of homebuyers surveyed agree that the Housing Development Board’s Build-To-Order flats remain an affordable option.

site_title: Fed’s Daly says it is time to consider adjusting borrowing costs: FT
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Mary Daly suggests adjusting borrowing costs, currently ranging from 5.25% to 5.5%, amid uncertainty over the July jobs report, which may signal a slowdown or real weakness in the labor market. Daly cautions that preventing a downturn is "extremely important" and notes that inflation is likely headed toward the 2% goal, but warns that gradualism is not weak, and a more rapid pace of interest rate changes could be detrimental.

site_title: Clean-energy projects in Indonesia’s coal regions could attract US$9.4 billion in investments: report
summary: Indonesia's coal-producing regions could see a significant boost in clean-energy investments, potentially creating 50,000 jobs and attracting US$4.3 billion in investment, according to a report by Ember Climate. The report suggests that converting existing coal plants to renewable energy could prevent 18 million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions. However, the report also notes that new coal plants currently in the pipeline face high risks of being "stranded" due to declining demand and increasing competition from solar power. This could lead to job losses and economic impacts in the region.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has pledged to boost the proportion of renewables in its energy mix and foreign lenders have promised to provide funding.
Methane remains in the atmosphere for only about a decade, but it has a warming effect 28 times greater than carbon dioxide over a 100-year timescale.
Joko Widodo’s decade in power: Infrastructure, economic and welfare gains amid governance hurdles
FILE PHOTO: A heavy machinery unload coal from barges into trucks to be distributed, at the Karya Citra Nusantara port in North Jakarta, Indonesia, January 13, 2022.
Indonesia plans to add almost 2 gigawatts of new rooftop solar capacity by the end of 2025.

site_title: Semicon still stumbling
summary: The global semiconductor industry is on the mend, with global sales reaching $149.9 billion in Q2 2024, a 6.5% increase from the previous quarter. However, Singapore-listed companies that serve the technology industry are still struggling, with AEM Holdings and UMS Holdings reporting disappointing earnings results. Despite this, smaller players such as Frencken Group and Grand Venture Technology are showing signs of recovery. The industry's recovery is expected to continue, with analysts predicting a 50% increase in earnings for H2 2024.

images.alt_text: With the right moves, Dyna-Mac Holdings could become a stock to watch, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
The slumping property market, combined with a weak stock market, is hitting household wealth, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Once upon a time, slower growth in China would have worried economists, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.

site_title: Djokovic blasts ‘embarrassing’ lack of video replays in tennis
summary: Novak Djokovic criticized the lack of video replays in tennis, calling it "embarrassing" after a disputed point in the Cincinnati Masters. The Olympic champion and 24-time Grand Slam title winner believes players should have access to video reviews to ensure fair calls. Djokovic's comments come after Coco Gauff also expressed frustration with a lack of video replays, which she feels is unfair and frustrating for players.

site_title: Mike Tyson says Jake Paul will ‘run like a thief’ in the ring
summary: Former heavyweight boxing champion Mike Tyson expressed confidence in his upcoming fight against YouTuber and professional boxer Jake Paul, stating that he will "run like a thief" in the ring. Tyson, 58, had an ulcer flare-up that forced a postponement of their original July 20 match, but is now fit and ready for the November 15 fight at AT&T Stadium in Texas. Tyson has a 50-6 record with 44 knockouts, while Paul has a 10-1 record. Tyson described Paul as "not a real fighter" and predicted a quick knockout.
