Botswana won its first Olympic gold ever when Letsile Tebogo beat out his rivals in the men's 200m final of the athletics event at Stade de France, Paris, on August 8, 2024.

site_title: Israel’s GDP growth slows as wartime exports, investments cool
summary: Israel's GDP growth slowed to 1.2% in the second quarter, missing expectations of 5.9%. This marks a rebound from a 17.3% surge in the prior quarter, but still fell short of initial expectations. The slowdown is attributed to cooling wartime exports and investments. Meanwhile, inflation rose to 3.2% annually, indicating a continued rise in prices. The data suggests a slowdown in Israel's economic recovery from the war against Hamas.

images.alt_text: Fitch maintained Israel’s outlook at “negative” and forecast the country’s debt to “remain on an upward trend beyond 2025” if higher military spending and economic uncertainties continue.

site_title: Gold tops US$2,500 for first time on outlook for lower rates
summary: Gold has reached a record high of US$2,500 an ounce for the first time, driven by optimism over the US Federal Reserve cutting interest rates and bolstered by mounting expectations of monetary easing. The precious metal is up over 20% this year, fueled by rising geopolitical risks and large purchases by central banks. Analysts predict further price gains, with some forecasting a rise to US$2,700 in the coming quarters. The Fed's decision to cut rates is expected to have a positive impact on gold, which pays no interest.

images.alt_text: The gold spot price rose to a record high of US$2,509.41 an ounce as investors snapped up the haven investment in the face of an increasingly likely US interest rate cut in September and heightened geopolitical risks.

site_title: Shinawatra heiress takes office as PM, vows to boost economy
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of former billionaire ex-premier Thaksin, took office on August 18, vowing to boost the country's sluggish economy. At 37, she is the kingdom's youngest ever PM, succeeding a government sacked by the Constitutional Court. Shinawatra, leading a coalition government, called on all Thais to work together to revive the economy, which has struggled to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. Her father's influence is expected, but she insists she is independent and has her own ideas and goals.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn, 37, secured the support of at least 251 lawmakers midway through the voting in the 500-member House of Representatives.

Thailand's new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra  will hope to avoid the fate of her father and aunt, whose terms as PM both ended with the army seizing power in a tussle between the family and Thailand’s pro-royalist, pro-military elite fought over more than 20 years.
The economy likely grew 2.1 per cent in the second quarter from a year ago, according to a median estimate of economists ahead of the announcement on Monday.

site_title: WTI expected to show continued weakness
summary: The WTI oil price broke a four-day gain streak on August 13, edging lower due to concerns over oil demand growth following the OPEC's reduced forecast. The price found support at a double bottom of US$72.50 per barrel in early August but faces resistance near US$80 per barrel. Technical indicators suggest decreasing momentum, with lower highs and lows since April, and the long-term trend exhibits weakness. This decrease in momentum is likely to show continued weakness in the WTI oil price.

site_title: Spanish fashion group Mango adds Hong Kong shop with rent 60% off peak: sources
summary: Spanish fashion group Mango has opened a 19,000-square-foot store in Hong Kong's Central district with a rent of about HK$1.2 million (S$202,500) per month, 60% lower than the premises' peak rent in 2014. The move comes as global brands return to the city, lured by lower rents and a strengthened local economy. Hong Kong's relaxed visa rules have attracted middle-class residents from mainland China, boosting local spending and reinvigorating its appeal to global brands.

images.alt_text: If the selling persists, China may see the first annual outflow from its stock market since 2016.

site_title: Starbucks is sued again for alleged stealing concept for coffee-flavoured lipstick
summary: Balmuccino, a company led by a sister-in-law of TV doctor Mehmet Oz, has sued Starbucks for the third time, alleging the coffee chain stole its concept for coffee-flavored lip balms. Balmuccino claims it pitched its idea to Starbucks in 2018 and provided prototypes, but the company launched its "S'mores Frappuccino Sip Kit" in 2019 without compensation. Balmuccino is seeking unspecified damages and argues the lawsuit is not too late due to New York's statutes of limitation laws. Starbucks has no immediate comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: Brian Niccol, the new CEO of Starbucks, will not be required to move to Seattle, where the company is based, even though he will be spending much of his time there.
Starbucks will award Niccol stock grants worth US$75 million to replace unvested awards he will leave behind at Chipotle Mexican Grill.
Fresh leadership is now brewing at Starbucks.

(FILES) Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol walks across the 14th hole during the Pro Am event prior to the Memorial Tournament presented by Workday at Muirfield Village Golf Club on June 05, 2024 in Dublin, Ohio. Starbucks said on August 13, 2024, that Niccol would be the coffee chain's new CEO, just over a year after current boss Laxman Narasimhan took over the role. Narasimhan steps down as chief executive and as a member of the Starbucks board "with immediate effect," said the company in a statement. (Photo by Dylan Buell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: CEO change at DBS unfolding at an uncertain time
summary: DBS Group reported record earnings in 2022 and 2023, driven by a 70 basis point expansion in net interest margins. Piyush Gupta, who led DBS since 2009, is set to retire as CEO. His departure comes at an uncertain time, with a profitability-boosting surge in interest rates expected to end. The less richly priced shares of DBS' peers may offer better risk-adjusted returns, considering the changing market landscape.

images.alt_text: Signage at a DBS Group Holdings Ltd. bank branch in Singapore, on Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. DBS Group is scheduled to report earnings results on Aug. 7. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Near 12% of India’s tested spice samples fail quality, safety standards
summary: India's Food Safety and Standards Authority found nearly 12% of tested spice samples from popular brands MDH and Everest failed quality and safety standards. The tests were conducted after Hong Kong suspended sales of the brands in April over pesticide contamination concerns. Britain has since tightened controls on Indian spice imports, while several other countries are investigating issues related to the brands. MDH and Everest claim their products are safe for consumption, but the agency has taken action against non-conforming samples, citing penalty provisions under Indian law.

images.alt_text: The company, part of billionaire Sajjan Jindal’s steel-to-energy JSW Group, will issue new shares worth up to 20 billion rupees, and existing shareholders are set to sell shares of up to 20 billion rupees, draft papers show.
The Reserve Bank of India has been intensifying its scrutiny of rapidly-growing consumer finance services, including P2P lending, to prevent systemic risks and protect consumer interest.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report provides a roundup of the week's tanker and dry bulk market (Aug 16, 2024). The capesize market saw a strong start, with rates increasing in the Pacific and Atlantic. However, the end of the week saw a shift in sentiment, with a noticeable drop in activity and decreased fixing levels. The Panamax market continued to decline, while the VLCC market improved, with rates rising in the Atlantic and Middle East. The rest of the market saw mixed activity, with some sectors experiencing gains and others remaining flat.

images.alt_text: Japan will divert some liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargoes to Europe after requests from the United States and the European Union, the industry minister said on Wednesday, a step that aligns the country with the West as tensions flare with Russia.

site_title: National Day Rally: New parents get extra 10 weeks of paid leave, to share; mandatory paternity leave rises to four weeks
summary: Singapore's government has announced new parental leave policies, starting from April 1, 2026. New parents of Singaporean children will receive a total of 30 weeks of paid parental leave, with 10 weeks to be shared between both parents. Mandatory paternity leave has increased to four weeks, and employers must grant this leave. The new scheme will be implemented in phases, with six weeks of shared leave for parents of babies born in 2025 and the full 10-week entitlement for those born in 2026.

site_title: Malaysia announces adopt-an-orangutan plan for palm oil importers
summary: Malaysia's Plantations and Commodities Minister Johari Abdul Ghani has announced a revised "adopt-an-orangutan" plan for palm oil importers, allowing them to adopt orangutans but keeping them in the country. The plan aims to halt deforestation and preserve forests, with funds raised from adoptions going to non-governmental organizations and the Sabah government to monitor forested areas. Conservation groups have raised objections, citing concerns for the welfare of critically endangered orangutans, with the population estimated to be less than 105,000 on the island of Borneo.

images.alt_text: A female Bornean orangutan eats fruits while her offspring sits on her shoulder at a rehabilitation centre in Sepilok, Malaysia August 17, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Dover Park Hospice raises S$1.1 million for patients in need of palliative care
summary: Dover Park Hospice in Singapore has raised S$1.1 million at its annual Sunflower Charity Gala, supporting its programmes and services for inpatients, home-care patients, and day-care clients. The funds will aid those with per-capita income below S$1,200. The hospice aims to increase its home palliative care capacity by 200 clients by end-2025, driven by Singapore's ageing population, expected to reach 21% by 2026.

images.alt_text: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (left) and  Ambassador Hong Jin-wook (2nd from left) of the Republic of Korea interacting with beneficiaries from Rainbow Centre.

site_title: National Day Rally: Balancing between a ‘reset’ and policy continuity
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a "major reset" in policies and people's attitudes to achieve a more compassionate and inclusive society while pursuing economic growth. This balancing act will be crucial, as Singaporeans expect a more compassionate and inclusive society. Wong's stance reflects the aspirations of Singaporeans, who want a society that combines economic growth with social welfare.

images.alt_text: “Realising our new ambitions will require a major reset," said Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in his first National Day Rally speech.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has asked the Ministry of National Development to see what more can be done for singles.
Lawrence Wong also acknowledged concerns that SMEs may have about higher business costs, noting that the government will simplify compliance and regulatory processes to help reduce costs.
New parents of Singaporean children will get an extra 10 weeks of government-paid leave to share between themselves from Apr 1, 2026.
To receive support under the new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, workers must go for training, career coaching and job-matching services.

site_title: French actor Alain Delon dies aged 88: French media
summary: French actor Alain Delon, known for his roles in films like "Rocco and His Brothers" and "Le Samourai," has died at 88. Delon's acting career spanned over six decades, but he struggled with personal demons, including shady underworld connections and a troubled personal life. He was openly acknowledged his friendships with Mafia figures and was known for his outspoken views, including his support for the far-right National Front. In his final years, Delon was under legal protection due to concerns over his health and well-being. He was awarded an honorary Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival in 2019 before his death.

images.alt_text: (FILES) French actor Alain Delon poses during a photocall before being awarded with an Honorary Palme d'Or at the 72nd edition of the Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, southern France, on May 19, 2019. French film legend Alain Delon has died at the age of 88, his three children told AFP in a statement on August 18, 2024, following a battle with ill health. (Photo by CHRISTOPHE SIMON / AFP)

(FILES) A photo taken on May 26, 1979 shows French actor Alain Delon during the filming of "Le toubib" directed by Pierre Granier Deferre, in Sissonne, central France. French film legend Alain Delon has died at the age of 88, his three children told AFP in a statement on August 18, 2024, following a battle with ill health. (Photo by JEAN MEUNIER / AFP)

site_title:
Greenback softens, yen set for weekly 
fall as US recession worries fade
summary: The US dollar fell 1.04% against the Japanese yen to 147.75, its biggest weekly decline since June, as traders took profits and investors assessed the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cut expectations. Disappointing US housing figures and easing recession worries supported the yen's rally. The dollar index fell 0.48% to 102.54, with odds of a 25-bps interest-rate cut now at 25.5%. Sterling rose 0.6% against the dollar, and the euro added 0.36% to 1.1012, as risk-sensitive currencies rallied amid improved economic outlooks.

site_title: Global bond traders are getting too complacent about inflation
summary: Global bond traders are building up protection against future inflation spikes, despite recent easing of price growth. Fund managers are amassing positions to cushion fixed-income returns in case of an inflation shock. Wall Street strategists recommend taking advantage of declining market-based inflation gauges to build up protection on the cheap. This move comes despite benign inflation readings and interest-rate cuts, which have sent benchmark bond yields sharply lower.

images.alt_text: Commuters cross London Bridge on their way to work at the City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 12, 2024. The Bank of England is looking carefully at labor market data to determine the strength of inflationary forces lingering in the economy. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Hilton CEO nears billionaire ranks again, with company’s shares jumping 90% since 2020
summary: Hilton CEO Christopher Nassetta's shares have jumped 90% since 2020, nearing billionaire status, thanks to the company's asset-light business model that generates revenue from hotels owned by other companies. Under Nassetta's leadership, Hilton has transformed from a hotel owner to a brand-licensing and technology-profit company, weathering the Covid-19 pandemic and global travel cycles. The company's recent success has helped it expand its room network and loyalty members, but faces new challenges as demand growth slows, with rival Marriott cutting its outlook for 2024.

site_title: Latest ‘Alien’ movie scares up big crowds in North American theatres
summary: The latest 'Alien' movie, "Alien: Romulus," has topped the weekend box office in North American theatres, earning an estimated US$41.5 million. This marks the franchise's continued ability to scare up sizeable audiences, according to analysts. The film's excellent opening is attributed to its late-episode horror sequel status, with industry watcher Exhibitor Relations praising the result as "excellent".

images.alt_text: Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.

site_title: Chinese stock investors lose a key indicator to gauge sentiment
summary: China's stock exchanges will stop releasing daily data on overseas fund flows starting August 19, depriving investors of a key sentiment indicator. This change comes as foreign funds have steadily withdrawn from the market, taking the year-to-date tally to negative. The absence of data will force investors to rely on quarterly reports from the central bank and lagging indicators of foreign holdings, which may not accurately reflect current market sentiment. China's stock market may see its first annual outflow since 2016 if selling persists.

site_title: National Day Rally: More cost-of-living support will be given ‘when necessary’
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that the government will provide more cost-of-living support when necessary to cope with inflation. He reassured senior citizens that they will receive continued support, citing earlier healthcare packages. For small and medium-sized enterprises, the government will simplify compliance and regulatory processes to reduce costs. PM Wong also highlighted initiatives to nurture future Singaporean leaders, including a new Singapore College of Islamic Studies and changes to bilingual education policy.

images.alt_text: “We cannot control global prices, but we can and we have shielded Singaporeans from the worst effects of global inflation by keeping the Singapore dollar strong," said PM Wong.

site_title: Investors timing the market see biggest hit on sector funds
summary: Wealth advisers warn against timing the market, as investors who sell during volatility often miss out on rebounds. A new Morningstar report found that average investors lose up to 2.6% in annual gains by straying from a buy-and-hold strategy in certain US mutual funds and ETFs. The report cautions that attempting to time the market can result in missed opportunities, emphasizing the importance of patience and sticking to a long-term strategy.

images.alt_text: Money market fund investors need to consider two powerful factors — inflation and short-term interest rates. The trend for both is clearly downward.

site_title: National Day Rally: New jobseeker support of up to S$6,000 in total, over a period of up to six months
summary: Singapore's government has announced a new re-employment support scheme, SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support, which provides up to S$6,000 in total to lower and middle-income workers who lose their jobs due to retrenchment or company closure. To receive support, workers must undergo training, career coaching, and job-matching services. The scheme aims to help workers "pull themselves up" and stay competitive in a rapidly changing job market, while also ensuring a business-friendly environment to support economic development.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong gave a preview of his NDR speech during his Aug 8 National Day Message.
The committee will look into how to lower costs for businesses, Minister for Transport Chee Hong Tat told reporters.

The re-employment support scheme, which was announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in his National Day Rally speech in 2023, will help retrenched workers get back on their feet.

site_title: SIA leads buyback consideration; Multi-Chem CEO trims stake
summary: Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks from Aug 8 to Aug 14, with S$31.5 million of net institutional inflow. SIA led buyback consideration with 1.5 million shares at S$5.90 per share, while Digital Core Reit Management acquired units of Digital Core Reit Trust. The buyback consideration also included 18 primary-listed companies, with a total consideration of S$22.5 million.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title:
With Kamala Harris at the helm, Democrats 
meet with new hope and some old worries
summary: Vice-President Kamala Harris is leading the Democratic Party into the 2024 US presidential election, riding a wave of enthusiasm and fundraising records. With less than 80 days to go until Election Day, Harris faces a historic opportunity to become the nation's first female president, but also struggles to address simmering divisions among Democrats on issues like the economy and Israel-Hamas war. Pollsters warn that her initial surge will wear off, but Harris has already redrawn an electoral map in her favor, leading or tying with Republican candidate Donald Trump in six of seven swing states.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump often pivots to personal insults, questioning Kamala Harris’s intelligence, attacking her racial identity and branding her a “communist.”

US President Joe Biden and Vice-President Kamala Harris, the Democratic presidential nominee, raise their clasped hands during a campaign event at Prince George's Community College in Largo, Maryland, Aug 15, 2024.

site_title: From burnout to brilliance: Empowering middle managers helps workplace culture
summary: Middle managers play a critical role in shaping workplace culture, driving engagement and performance, and safeguarding employee mental health and well-being. Mercer's Global Talent Trends report reveals that 8 in 10 Asian employees are burnt out, emphasizing the need for organizations to prioritize employee well-being. Effective middle managers can balance competing priorities and foster a supportive culture, ultimately benefiting both employees and the organization.

images.alt_text: Overloading employees with excessive overtime because they excel can create a vicious cycle. The more work they handle, the more is expected of them.
Cutting middle management can backfire by leading to uncertainty.

site_title: The end of fabulous money market rates is near
summary: Money market fund investors face a shift as inflation and short-term interest rates are expected to decline, potentially reducing returns. Despite a stable period, investors should consider alternative options, such as bonds or stocks, for long-term growth. The average yield on money market funds is around 5.1%, but rates are likely to drop due to the US Federal Reserve's anticipated rate cuts. Investors should re-evaluate their needs and consider locking in high rates now, then reassessing their portfolios for the future.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, July 31, 2024. Federal Reserve officials held interest rates at the highest level in more than two decades but signaled they are moving closer to lowering borrowing costs amid easing inflation and a cooling labor market. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: National Day Rally: BTO priority to be extended to singles and their parents buying flats to live together or near one another
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that from mid-2025, singles and their parents who want to live near or with one another will receive priority for Build-to-Order (BTO) public flats, expanding the current priority to married couples and their parents. The move aims to make flats more affordable by increasing supply and is part of the government's efforts to address housing concerns. The Ministry of National Development will provide more details soon.

images.alt_text: Will there be more refinements to Singapore's world class public housing at this year's NDR?
More moves on the housing front can be considered to address Singapore's baby woes.

site_title: Porsche agrees to provide capital in battery maker’s restructuring deal
summary: German battery maker Varta has reached a restructuring agreement with creditors, including Porsche, to reduce debt from 485 million euros to 200 million euros. Porsche will secure access to high-performance batteries for its hybrid and electric sports cars, while Michael Tojner and Porsche will become new owners, providing a capital injection of 60 million euros. The agreement also includes a majority stake in Varta's V4Drive Battery division for Porsche, with plans to keep manufacturing sites in Germany and implement "moderate" job cuts.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has vowed to ditch some existing electric car policies if he returns to office, and to extend tariffs on Chinese EV imports to as much as 200 per cent.

site_title: Goldman cuts US recession risk following retail sales, jobs data
summary: Goldman Sachs lowered the US recession risk to 20% from 25% due to strong retail sales and jobless claims data. The economists also expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by 25 basis points at the September policy meeting, with a possible 50-bp move if a downside jobs surprise occurs. The data shows the US economy is resilient, with retail sales increasing in July by the most since early 2023 and the fewest applications for unemployment benefits since early July.

site_title: Businesses, rights defenders decry Pakistan Internet slowdown
summary: Pakistan's government is throttling the internet and social media, slowing it by up to 40% since July, while testing new controls to crush dissent. Digital rights experts believe the state is installing a national firewall to increase surveillance and censor political dissent, particularly against the opposition party led by jailed leader Imran Khan. The move is seen as a threat to the country's economic recovery, with business leaders warning it could cost the IT sector up to $300 million. Analysts say the main target is Khan's party, which is boosted by a young, tech-savvy voter base.

images.alt_text: The energy sector has become an acute pain point as Pakistan grapples with chronic economic crisis.

site_title: UK economy heads for slowdown after ‘Goldilocks’ first half
summary: The UK economy is experiencing a "Goldilocks moment" with slowing inflation, rising employment, and healthy growth. It outperformed the US and other European countries in the first half of 2024, with the best growth among G7 nations. Official data showed a strong second quarter, with workers hired at the quickest pace since November, reducing the jobless rate and inflation rising less than expected. However, the economy's fragile recovery is at risk due to constraints on the workforce and productivity.

images.alt_text: Doubts over the possibility of securing an Israel-Hamas ceasefire grow. There is also the looming possibility of a wider regional war.
Regular pay has been growing at roughly double the pace the BOE thinks is compatible with keeping inflation at its 2 per cent target over the medium term.

Floodwater from the rivers Avon and Severn surrounds Tewkesbury Abbey in the aftermath of Storm Henk in Tewkesbury, Britain, Jan 8, 2024. Increased flooding from overflowing rivers and blocked drains is causing insurers to pull back from offering coverage, particularly for commercial properties and residential landlords, according to industry representatives.

The median pay for a FTSE-100 company CEO rose 2.2 per cent to £4.19 million last year, think tank the High Pay Centre said, though it added CEO pay growth had slowed compared with the previous two years.
The king praised British police and emergency services “for all they are doing to restore peace in those areas that have been affected by violent disorder”.
Permanent hiring extended a nearly two-year downturn although the drop was less marked than a month earlier, and pay increases were weaker than in June.

site_title: Informal caregiving for seniors valued at S$1.28 billion annually: Duke-NUS study
summary: A new study by Duke-NUS Medical School estimates that informal caregiving for seniors in Singapore is valued at S$1.28 billion annually, equivalent to 11% of the government's healthcare expenditure. This amount is spent by caregivers aged 21 and older, providing unpaid help to seniors aged 75 and above. The study aims to provide insights for policies to better support caregivers, who often face challenges such as time commitment and social exclusion. Companies are now acknowledging caregivers' efforts through joint events and initiatives, highlighting the need for practical tools and supportive communities to empower informal caregivers.

images.alt_text: From left: Dr Mervyn Koh, medical director, Dover Park Hospice; Dr Kwa Chong Teck, co-chairman Dover Park Hospice Fundraising Sub-committee; Associate Professor Jeremy Lim, chairman, Dover Park Hospice; Rahayu Mahzam, Minister of State for Health as well as Digital Development and Information; Dr Liew Li Lian, chief executive, Dover Park Hospice; Atiqah Tanty, director of nursing, Dover Park Hospice; Dr Karen Soh, co-chairman, Dover Park Hospice Fundraising Sub-committee at the Sunflower Charity Gala 2024.

site_title: US judge delays launch of sports streaming venture from Disney, media
summary: A US judge has temporarily blocked the launch of Venu Sports, a new sports streaming service backed by Walt Disney, Fox, and Warner Bros Discovery. The service aimed to capture younger sports fans, but a rival streaming service, FuboTV, sued the media companies, accusing them of antitrust practices. The judge found it likely that FuboTV's claims would succeed, and issued the injunction. The media companies had planned to launch Venu Sports this fall.

images.alt_text: Alvarez says he is forever marked by the series’ early chapters as a kid growing up in Uruguay.
The merged company will also have lucrative rights worth billions of US dollars for the broadcast of cricket, raising pricing power fears and its grip over advertisers.
Disney is forging ahead with the ambitious plans despite a slowdown in its parks business tied to weaker consumer trends.
Disney’s plans could build on the recent success of films like 'Inside Out 2' and the company’s television business.

site_title: Harris woos voters with price-cutting plans
summary: Kamala Harris unveiled an economic blueprint in North Carolina, promising to cut costs for Americans and combat inflation. The plan includes tax breaks for families with children, support for first-time homebuyers, and help accessing government-subsidized health care. Harris also called for a federal ban on "price-gouging" by food companies. The proposals aim to distance her from President Joe Biden's unpopular management of price surges, as the Democratic National Convention approaches.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People shop at a supermarket in Montebello, California, on May 15, 2024. The US Federal Reserve's favored inflation measure eased further in June, according to government data published on July 26, 2024. site_title: How to mitigate resentment in your team
summary: Leaders can mitigate resentment in their team by creating incentives for cooperation and providing opportunities to build trust and positive feelings. Research suggests that people become less cooperative when they expect others to be uncooperative, but co-dependency creates reciprocity. By framing tasks as organizational necessities and providing achievable goals, leaders can encourage team members to rely on each other and reduce resentment. This approach, known as intergroup contact theory, has been applied to workplace relationships and can lead to increased trust and goodwill, making it more likely for conflicts to be resolved.

images.alt_text: Top sprinters such as Noah Lyles repeatedly perform the same precise movements, such as starts, acceleration drills, and core and strength training exercises including squats and deadlifts.

site_title: National Day Rally: ‘Major reset’ of policies, mindsets needed to realise Singapore’s new ambitions
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced a "major reset" of policies and mindsets in his first National Day Rally speech. Key changes include a 10-week paid parental leave scheme for both mothers and fathers, increased support for large families, and a new SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme with temporary financial assistance and training requirements. Other initiatives include enhanced housing support for singles and lower-income couples, education policy changes, and investments in infrastructure projects. The goal is to realise the ambitions of the fourth-generation leadership's Forward Singapore exercise, embracing lifelong learning and a "refreshed Singapore dream" where Singaporeans can thrive and flourish.

ST20240818_202468000681/ndr18/Jason Quah

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong speaking at the National Day Rally at ITE College Central on Aug 18, 2024. ST PHOTO: JASON QUAH

site_title: Optimising your workout to boost your mood
summary: Exercise can boost mood and reduce stress by releasing a complex cocktail of "feel-good" chemicals, including endocannabinoids, dopamine, serotonin, and oxytocin. To maximize the mood-boosting effects, experts recommend getting your heart rate up for at least 30 minutes, sustaining moderate aerobic activity for 20-30 minutes, and exercising regularly for at least three weeks to develop a dopamine reward system. Social exercise, such as working out with friends or in groups, can also amplify the oxytocin boost, while mixing up exercise types, such as aerobic, resistance, and mindfulness practices, can release different mood-enhancing chemicals and prime the brain for greater rewards.

images.alt_text: For more experienced athletes, heart rate zone training can help improve speed and endurance.
Physical activity improves cognitive and mental health in all sorts of ways.
There are a few tools that can trick our brain into lacing up and heading out.
Can moving the body heal the mind?

site_title: UK fintech firm Revolut valued at US$45 billion after secondary share sale
summary: UK fintech firm Revolut has been valued at $45 billion after a secondary share sale, cementing its position as the most valuable private technology company in Europe. The company, founded in 2015, has seen significant growth, with revenues almost doubling to £1.8 billion last year and a profit of £344 million. Revolut has gained 12 million new customers in the past year, taking its total to 38 million, and has since grown to 45 million. The funding round was led by Coatue, D1 Capital Partners, and existing investor Tiger Global.

images.alt_text: Revolut, which has waited more than three years for the licence amid regulatory caution, has over nine million UK customers, around one-fifth of its global total.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as gold hits fresh record
summary: US stocks rose 0.2% on Friday, ending a positive week, as gold hit a record high. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 40,659.76, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also finished 0.2% higher. Bullish investors snapped up gold amid rising confidence in a September rate cut and weakening US dollar, despite geopolitical risks. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and comments from officials will be closely watched on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 06: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 06, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up slightly up in the three major indexes a day after the Dow Jones and the S & P 500 had their worst day of trading since 2022, amid a global market sell-off centered around fears of a U.S. recession. site_title: In pursuit of a higher quality of life
summary: Singapore's new Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizes the need to move beyond material success in measuring quality of life, citing the inadequacy of using gross domestic product as a metric. According to Forward Singapore's public engagement, the modern Singapore Dream now prioritizes fulfillment, meaning, and purpose. Identifying non-market or intangible indicators, such as optimal population size and green spaces, has policy implications, including reevaluating considerations beyond economic growth. This shift aims to better understand and improve the quality of life for the populace.

images.alt_text: Vital for growth measures to include environmental damage

site_title: Saudi Arabia to reduce big spending on oil sector, Goldman says
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to reduce big spending on the oil sector, allocating 73% of its investments into non-oil sectors by 2030, according to Goldman Sachs Group. This shift aims to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on crude sales. The kingdom's oil sector investments are expected to shrink by $40 billion between 2024 and 2028, with natural gas continuing to contribute to the country's economic development.

images.alt_text: Opec in a monthly report said world oil demand will rise by 2.11 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2024, down from growth of 2.25 million bpd expected last month.
Saudi Arabia is the second-largest crude supplier to China, world’s top oil importer and the biggest contributor to global demand growth.

site_title: Malaysia’s ruling party wrests seat in boost for Anwar Ibrahim
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, Barisan Nasional, won a seat in an opposition-controlled state, boosting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's coalition. The victory comes as Anwar looks to implement unpopular reforms, including ending blanket petrol subsidies. The win follows the announcement of a RM10 billion salary increase for the civil service and a second consecutive quarter of economic growth exceeding estimates. This swing of support is seen as a significant boost for Anwar, who is expected to undertake key financial reforms to strengthen the country's finances.

site_title: Gold hits record high as global markets rise
summary: Gold prices hit a record high of $2,509.41 an ounce as investors sought refuge from potential US interest rate cuts and heightened geopolitical risks. Global stock markets rose, with the Nikkei 225 jumping 3.6% in Asian trading, while oil prices tumbled 1.7% due to weak Chinese demand expectations and ongoing tensions in the Middle East. The dollar weakened, and bond yields dropped amid expectations of US rate cuts, pushing gold prices higher.

images.alt_text: A low interest rate environment tends to boost non-yielding bullion’s appeal.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.2 per cent higher at 40,659.76 on Friday.

site_title: US office market shows bottoming signs: Moody’s Analytics
summary: US office property values have slumped since the Covid-19 pandemic, but Moody's Analytics reports signs of a market bottom. Sales volume has stopped falling, and large properties are being resold below prior deal values. This suggests a significant increase in price discovery and a potential end to the price decline. While "significant pain" remains, owners and lenders can now evaluate potential losses, a necessary step for the market to recover. A bottom in office pricing may be nearing.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan provided a senior mortgage for One High Line, while Tyko was behind the mezzanine financing.

Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, tumbled 14.1 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 851,000 units last month, says the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau.

site_title: Whoosh-ing through Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's high-speed railway, Whoosh, has been a success since its launch in October 2023, with over 4 million passengers served as of July. The train, reaching 350 km/h, has contributed $7.1 billion to Jakarta's GDP from 2019-2023. Its daily record of 24,135 passengers during school holidays highlights its popularity. The railway is seen as a lasting legacy of President Joko Widodo's presidency, showcasing Indonesia's growth and development.

site_title: When an old soul embraces modern twists
summary: 28 HongKong Street, a Singaporean craft cocktail bar, has unveiled a new menu inspired by tattoo designs. The bar's head bartender, Tamaryn Cooper, aimed to create cocktails that would resonate with the younger generation of bartenders. Four local artists designed three tattoos each, which inspired 12 new cocktail creations, including the Burung Bathikan, a twist on the classic Pisco Sour, and the River City Paloma, which combines flavors of the Bloody Mary and Paloma. The bar's unique blend of modern techniques and traditional methods is reflected in its menu, which also features classic cocktails.

images.alt_text: Jellyfish Martini incorporates the invasive jellyfish species in a dry martini, creating a natural oceany freshness.
Dry Boney is a savoury tomato cocktail served in an elegantly tall glass, reflecting Tamba’s own figure.
Silver Bullet embodies what in Atlas' beverage director Yana Keller's mind an ideal martini: almost frozen, served straight out of the freezer in a frozen pony glass.
Retrospect, a variation of the classic Bamboo cocktail, uses rice vodka to bring out the nuttiness in sherry.

site_title: Indonesia’s HSR as a lasting legacy of Widodo’s presidency
summary: Indonesia's high-speed railway (HSR), Whoosh, has been launched, marking a lasting legacy of President Joko Widodo's presidency. The US$7.3 billion project, co-funded by China, has cut travel time from 3.5 hours to under an hour. The HSR's potential benefits can be amplified by adopting a holistic master-planning approach to the region's diverse transportation links. The project's economic viability and social impact have been called into question, but it has brought national pride and visibility to Indonesia, with plans for a pan-Asian railway network and potential future extensions to Surabaya.

images.alt_text: “It is a symbol of our modernisation in the public transport, seamlessly connecting with other modes of transportation.” says Indonesia's President Joko Widodo.
Indonesia's US$7.3 billion HSR project has been viewed by observers as a big step towards Asean’s push for seamless integration and connectivity in the region.

site_title: Ketamine Queen: the alleged dealer charged over Matthew Perry’s death
summary: Five people, including alleged "Ketamine Queen" Jasveen Sangha, have been charged in connection with the overdose death of actor Matthew Perry in October 2023. Sangha, 41, is accused of selling Perry ketamine from her North Hollywood drug emporium, where investigators found thousands of dollars in profits. Prosecutors claim she exploited Perry's addiction for profit, selling him doses in unmarked vials and even offering ketamine lollipops. If convicted, Sangha could face life in prison.

site_title: Britain stops export of WWII code breaker Alan Turing's wartime papers
summary: Britain has temporarily halted the export of Alan Turing's unpublished papers from the "Delilah" project, a portable encryption system developed during WWII. The papers, valued at £397,680, date from 1943-1945 and offer unique insights into Turing's work. The UK government has placed an export bar on the papers to allow a UK institution to purchase them, ensuring they remain part of the country's national story and can be studied and appreciated.

images.alt_text: New British £50 note with WWII codebreaker Turing enters circulation

site_title: Oil falls 2% to end volatile week, focus on China demand concerns
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 2% on Friday, ending a volatile week, as investors tempered expectations of demand growth from top oil importer China. Brent crude futures settled at $79.68 per barrel, down $1.36, or 1.7%, following data showing China's economy lost momentum in July. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) also cut its forecast for this year's oil demand growth, citing weak demand in China. Oil prices may lack direction until the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates at its September meeting.

images.alt_text: US crude oil stockpiles rose by 1.4 million barrels in the week ended Aug 9.

site_title: India's JSW Cement files for 40-billion-rupee public listing
summary: India's JSW Cement files for a 40-billion-rupee public listing, aiming to tap the country's booming stock market and strong demand for building materials. The company will issue new shares worth up to 20 billion rupees and existing shareholders will sell shares of up to 20 billion rupees. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to finance a proposed cement unit and trim outstanding borrowings. This is the group's second IPO in recent times, following its port-operating arm's listing last year. The IPO is expected to garner interest from long-term investors amid expected infrastructure spending.

images.alt_text: The company has been incurring losses and negative cash flows from operations since inception, according to its listing document.
India's JSW Steel considering bid for Gupta's British business: sources

site_title: Fortnite publisher Epic Games debuts mobile storefront after years in court
summary: Epic Games, the publisher of Fortnite, has launched a mobile storefront after four years of legal battles with Apple and Google over their app store practices. CEO Tim Sweeney expects the mobile versions of Fortnite, Rocket League, and Fall Guys to attract 100 million new installs by the end of the year. The company will charge a 12% fee on mobile transactions and offers free games to draw in users, aiming to bypass the high fees charged by Apple and Google.

images.alt_text: The firm’s marketplace, the Epic Games Store, will also be coming to Android worldwide and iOS in the EU.

site_title: Zirkzee an instant hero as Man Utd beat Fulham in Premier League opener
summary: Manchester United beat Fulham 1-0 in the Premier League opener, with Joshua Zirkzee scoring the winning goal in his debut. The Dutch international came on in the final 30 minutes and poked in Alejandro Garnacho's cross in the 87th minute. Zirkzee said it was an "amazing feeling" to score his first goal for the club, and manager Erik ten Hag praised his team for a strong start despite missing key players due to injury or match fitness. The win gives Ten Hag a much-needed start to the season.

summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been impacted by recent events, including an assassination attempt and the withdrawal of Joe Biden, which has shifted the focus to younger candidate Kamala Harris. Trump, 78, is now the oldest presidential nominee in history and is struggling to regain momentum. His campaign managers are urging him to focus on issues like immigration and inflation, but he repeatedly pivots to personal attacks on Harris, which may not play well with undecided swing voters. Trump's team is desperate to find a new campaign narrative, with some advisors describing him as "frightened, cornered, and angry."

site_title: In the age of AI, will leaders be technocrats or humanists?
summary: Leaders in the age of AI must strike a balance between technical expertise and humanistic priorities to harness the benefits of AI while protecting privacy and ethics. To achieve this balance, organisations need to evaluate their readiness and intended usage of AI as part of their overall strategy. Upskilling initiatives should focus on blending technical skills with human-centric perspectives, and future leaders will need to be aware of the benefits and implications of AI adoption to make informed decisions. A balanced leadership team that combines technical talent with AI translators and human values is crucial for successful AI deployment.

site_title: US single-family housing starts tumble in July
summary: US single-family housing starts dropped 14.1% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 851,000 units in July, according to the Commerce Department's Census Bureau. This marks the fifth consecutive month of decline, as higher mortgage rates and house prices deter prospective buyers. Despite a recent retreat in mortgage rates, a surge in new housing inventory could limit any rebound in housing starts. Homebuilder sentiment also fell to an eight-month low in August, citing challenging housing affordability conditions. Permits for future construction slipped 0.1% to 938,000 units in July.

images.alt_text: Nationwide, there have been six deals at US$100 million or above this year through the end of July, just three shy of a record set in 2021.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 clocks best week in 3 months on rate optimism
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% on Friday, reaching its two-week high and logging its best week since May 6, driven by upbeat risk sentiment following positive US data. The index rose 2.4% for the week, with the automobile sector leading gains. Markets will focus on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole next week, which may influence interest rate decisions. Despite potential volatility, investors may consider European equities as they wait for clarity on US election uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, August 12, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Software firm AvePoint said to weigh second listing in Singapore
summary: AvePoint, a US infrastructure software firm, is considering a second listing in Singapore, potentially raising capital for its investors in South-east Asia. The company, which counts Singapore's 65 Equity Partners among its investors, is working with advisers on a possible listing that could take place in the next 12 months. AvePoint's shares have risen 34% in New York this year, giving the company a market value of over $2 billion, and the firm has a significant presence in Singapore, including a $100 million investment in a research and development hub.

images.alt_text: Avepoint chief executive Jiang Tianyi believes that a Spac offers more certainty around the amount of capital raised for the company, but more can be done to improve the Spac framework.

site_title: UK's Heathrow border officers plan four-day strike at the end of August
summary: Heathrow Airport border officers plan a four-day strike from Aug 31 to Sep 3, affecting hundreds of thousands of holidaymakers. The strike, involving 650 PCS union members, is over changes to terms and conditions, including new inflexible rosters. The PCS union claims the changes will cause "serious disruption" to travelers, but the airport has previously managed strikes without major issues. The strike will coincide with the end of the school summer holidays, a peak travel period for the airport.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A British Airways aircraft parks next to an EasyJet plane at Cointrin airport in Geneva, Switzerland June 24, 2021.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Ultra-luxury home sales in the US are on pace to set a new record
summary: US ultra-luxury home sales are on pace to set a new record, with six deals at $100 million or above through the end of July, just three shy of the 2021 record. A $115 million purchase in June, followed by a nearby penthouse sale for $135 million, marked a turning point for New York's ultra-luxury market. Billionaires' wealth boom is driving major home purchases, and agents are optimistic about other top listings. With four months remaining, home sales of $100 million or more are expected to break the previous record.

images.alt_text: Dubai has seen a surge in demand for property over the past couple years, aided by an influx of a people from around the world.

site_title: US consumer sentiment increases for first time in five months
summary: US consumer sentiment increased for the first time in five months, rising to 67.8 in August from 66.4 in July, according to the University of Michigan. The rise was driven by more optimistic expectations about finances and a decrease in inflation concerns, as President Joe Biden's decision not to seek re-election boosted confidence among Democrats. Despite this, consumers remain cautious due to a higher cost of living, cooler hiring, and elevated borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: General view of metal cutting machines inside Gent Machine Co.'s 55-employee factory in Cleveland, Ohio, U.S., May 26, 2021. REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel
FILE PHOTO: Workers walk by a 737 Max aircraft on the production line at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson

site_title: Nelson Loh jailed 15 years, 9 months for forgery, cheating, money laundering
summary: Nelson Loh, former director of Novena Global Healthcare Group, has been sentenced to 15 years and 9 months in prison for forgery, cheating, and money laundering. Loh, along with another ex-employee Michael Wong Soon Yuh, submitted forged financial statements to obtain loans from six banks, resulting in the disbursement of around S$68 million. The illicit proceeds were transferred to local and overseas entities, with US$630,000 used to finance a trade transaction. Both men were convicted and sentenced to prison terms for their roles in the scheme.

images.alt_text: According to court records, Nelson Loh is expected to plead guilty on July 1 before Deputy Principal District Judge Luke Tan.
Nelson Loh allegedly forged financial statements of Novena Global Healthcare Group in 2019.

Lee Chai Hoon was formerly married to Loh, the co-founder of Novena Global Healthcare Group who has been charged with forging financial statements of the company and used them to obtain bank loans amounting to S$18 million.
DBS wins bankruptcy bid on Nelson Loh in relation to S$14m loan
Terence Loh lodges police report over 'improper transfers' of S$5m

site_title: Bayer wins US legal victory against Roundup cancer claims
summary: Bayer has won a US appeals court decision, shielding the company from a lawsuit by a Pennsylvania landscaper claiming Roundup weed killer causes cancer. The 3rd US Circuit Court of Appeals rejected plaintiff David Schaffner's claim that Monsanto violated state law by failing to put a cancer warning on the label for Roundup. Bayer shares rose 13.2% in Germany, with optimism the decision could eliminate much of its remaining Roundup-related liabilities. The decision maintains Bayer's stance that Roundup and its active ingredient glyphosate are safe.

images.alt_text: Bayer said the group revenue reached 11.1 billion euros (S$16.1 billion) in the second quarter.

site_title: Macron to meet party heads next Friday before naming premier
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron will meet with party heads on Aug 23 to discuss forming a government after snap elections. Macron aims to build a wide and stable majority, potentially relying on parties across the ideological spectrum. He has invited the heads of parties represented in the National Assembly for talks, with the goal of naming a new prime minister. Macron's new government will likely resemble a "cohabitation" between the president and prime minister from rival parties, and he has suggested teaming up with the centre-right Republican Right.

images.alt_text: epa11065643 FILE - French Minister for National Education and Youth, Gabriel Attal attending a European Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council in Brussels, Belgium, 23 November 2023 (reissued 09 January 2024). French President Emmanuel Macron has appointed Gabriel Attal as France's next prime minister, in a government reshuffle 09 January 2024.  EPA-EFE/OLIVIER HOSLET

site_title: Making sense of market movements
summary: Markets experienced a tumultuous start to August, with big sell-offs followed by large bouncebacks, amidst a backdrop of resilient economic data and inflation trending down. Investors should consider the following in the third quarter: interest rate cuts are possible, with markets pricing in four cuts in 2024; deploying cash into bonds could be beneficial as yields are expected to decrease, but current bond yields remain high; and certain markets, such as small-mid caps and dividend stocks, offer attractive opportunities despite being undervalued. Being diversified and selective is crucial to investment outcomes in the short to medium term.

images.alt_text: Investors often sell their stocks when they are expensive. They move into cash hoping to buy the stocks back when they become cheap again. But it may be a very long wait. Meanwhile, expensive stocks continue to outperform.

site_title: Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-flu combo vaccine misses on trial goal
summary: Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid-flu combination vaccine failed to show at least equal effectiveness in generating an immune response against the influenza B strain in a final-stage trial. The vaccine performed better with influenza A and Covid. The companies are exploring tweaks to boost its effectiveness against influenza B, which may set back their efforts by at least two years. This setback complicates Pfizer's efforts to offset declining sales of its Covid vaccine and puts them at a disadvantage compared to Moderna, which recently reported positive results with a Covid-flu combination vaccine.

images.alt_text: BioNTech reported a second-quarter net loss of 807.8 million euros (S$1.2 billion), versus a loss of 190.4 million a year earlier.
FILE PHOTO: Pfizer company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: CEOs are running companies from afar even as workers return to office
summary: CEOs are increasingly running companies from afar, with some executives like Starbucks' new CEO Brian Niccol and Victoria's Secret's new CEO Hillary Super allowed to commute frequently from their homes in California and New York, respectively. This trend contrasts with the return-to-office mandate for many corporate employees. Companies like Starbucks and Victoria's Secret are accommodating their top leaders' preferences, with some using corporate planes and covering travel expenses, while others, like Boeing, are basing their CEOs near production facilities. This shift highlights the evolving nature of work and the flexibility being offered to top executives.

images.alt_text: Starbucks will award Niccol stock grants worth US$75 million to replace unvested awards he will leave behind at Chipotle Mexican Grill.

site_title: The rich can’t sell their art, so they’re borrowing against it
summary: Wealthy art owners can tap into their collections for cash without selling prized possessions through a new market of art lending. This practice allows clients to draw on lines of credit, paying back as they can. The trend is growing due to slower art sales, with the May New York auction season experiencing a 23% decline in value. Affluent individuals, such as a client who used art to buy a sports franchise, are using art loans to secure liquidity, contributing to the market's growth.

images.alt_text: K Contemporary turned a wall piece by textile artist Anne von Freyburg into a bedspread, stationed two human-like sculptures by Viktor Freso on the terrace, and hung a painting by Marc Dennis over the toilet.  “I love taking artwork out of that idea of the white cube,” gallery owner Doug Kacena says.

site_title: Jardine C&C to sell entire 25.5% stake in Siam City Cement for 12.2 billion baht
summary: Jardine Cycle and Carriage (Jardine C&C) has agreed to sell its 25.5% stake in Siam City Cement (SCCC) for 12.2 billion baht, with the cash proceeds used for internal funding requirements. The sale is consistent with Jardine C&C's strategy to evolve its portfolio. The transaction is expected to be completed on August 19, 2024, and is not expected to have a material impact on Jardine C&C's net tangible assets or underlying earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Contributions from the group’s regional interests, which include automotive dealer Cycle & Carriage, stood at US$25 million, down 13 per cent from last year.
Cycle & Carriage has obtained licensing rights to install GoStations in Singapore.
Witt has been group managing director of Jardine Matheson Holdings since 2020, as well as managing director of DFI Retail, Hongkong Land and Mandarin Oriental.

site_title: Housing starts in Canada unexpectedly jump to 13-month high
summary: Canada's housing starts surged to a 13-month high in July, rising 15.7% from the previous month to 279,509 units, exceeding economists' expectations. The increase was driven by multi-unit buildings, particularly in Ontario, where starts rose 59%. While construction momentum is picking up, housing affordability remains a concern, with the country needing to build at least 3.5 million additional units by 2030 to restore affordability.

images.alt_text:
toronto - A condo building under construction in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, Jan. 5, 2024. Toronto's housing market sprung to life in December with sales surging the most in eight months as lower prices and borrowing costs lured back buyers. Photographer: Galit Rodan/Bloomberg
