site_title: US to award chipmaker Texas Instruments up to US$1.6 billion under Chips Act
summary: The US government has signed a preliminary agreement with Texas Instruments to provide up to $1.6 billion in funding under the Chips Act to support the company's planned investment of over $18 billion in building three new facilities in the US. The facilities, located in Texas and Utah, are expected to generate over 2,000 manufacturing jobs and significantly boost domestic production capacity of foundational chips. The funding aims to reduce US reliance on China for older-generation semiconductors and support national security applications.

images.alt_text: Some analysts believe Texas Instruments is unlikely to steer away from its capital investment strategy.

site_title: WHO, partners meet to avoid Covid failures on fair medical access for mpox
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is hosting an emergency meeting to discuss fair global access to tests, treatments, and vaccines for mpox. The meeting, attended by health experts and global health agencies, aims to prevent Covid-19-style failures in equal access to medical treatments. The gathering follows the spread of mpox in parts of Africa and beyond, with the goal of ensuring equal access to medical resources for the viral infection.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Health Organization (WHO) logo is seen near its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: JPMorgan leads nearly US$1.2 billion financing for New York towers
summary: JPMorgan Chase has led nearly $1.2 billion in financing for the luxury towers on Manhattan's west side, known as One High Line. The senior mortgage was provided by JPMorgan, while Tyko Capital, backed by Elliott Investment Management, provided mezzanine financing. The refinancing was arranged by Walker & Dunlop and secures over $800 million in sales for the project. Demand for New York condos remains solid, with median sale prices up 3.4% in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Banks have lately been selling more bonds that transfer credit risk to investors, allowing them to book a lighter capital charge on their assets.

site_title: China youth unemployment jumps to 17.1% in July
summary: China's youth unemployment rate jumped to 17.1% in July, the first increase in five months, as an influx of graduates entered the labor market amid a struggling economy. The rate is more than three times the overall unemployment rate and reflects a structural mismatch between graduates seeking white-collar jobs and factories struggling to hire. The National Bureau of Statistics attributes the rise to the graduation season, with 11.8 million graduates entering the job market this year. The government has pledged to prioritize youth employment and job creation.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open after strong run, weak housing starts data
summary: Wall Street slipped at the open on Friday, August 16, 2024, after a weak US housing starts report. The Dow Jones fell 34.2 points, or 0.08%, to 40,528.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 12.7 points, or 0.23%, and the Nasdaq Composite down 78.1 points, or 0.44%. The decline follows six-straight sessions of gains for the S&P 500.

site_title: GSK wins latest US litigation over Zantac drug saga
summary: GSK wins US litigation over its Zantac heartburn medication, which was withdrawn in 2019 due to alleged cancer risks. A Florida court ruled that there is no consistent evidence that ranitidine increases cancer risk. The verdict is consistent with scientific consensus, and GSK welcomes the outcome.

images.alt_text: Zantac was a once-popular antacid that has drawn a flurry of US personal-injury lawsuits alleging it causes cancer.

site_title: EV maker Rivian halts production of Amazon delivery vans amid parts shortage
summary: Rivian, an electric vehicle manufacturer, has halted production of its commercial delivery vans for Amazon due to a parts shortage. This halt is the latest in a series of supply chain challenges faced by the company, which has struggled with significant production issues over the past two years. The production shortage will not affect other Rivian vehicles, including the R1S and R1T models. Rivian expects to recover all missed production and previously maintained its production forecast for the current quarter. Amazon has ordered 100,000 electric delivery vans from Rivian.

site_title: BlackRock says blended finance at ‘turning point’ as deals grow
summary: BlackRock, a US$10 trillion asset manager, says the market for blended finance has reached a "turning point" as deals combining private and public funding grow. The firm aims to build up its suite of blended finance instruments and public-private partnerships, which can help lower risks for private investors in emerging markets. Blended finance was developed to address climate change and has seen a five-year high of US$15 billion in deals last year. As climate catastrophes grow, adaptation finance is becoming increasingly important, with BlackRock actively seeking investor interest in adaptation-aligned assets.

images.alt_text: Access to private markets via exchange-traded funds has the potential to open the closed-off world to investors of all stripes. It could also channel fresh cash into an asset class struggling to keep the boom alive after years of breakneck expansion.

site_title: Poland to bid for Summer Olympics in 2040 or 2044
summary: Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk announced on August 16 that the country will bid to host the Summer Olympics in 2040 or 2044, following a statement by President Andrzej Duda last year. Tusk dedicated the decision to young Poles, citing the International Olympic Committee's realistic prospects for these years. Poland's bid aims to build on the country's existing sports infrastructure and showcase its potential as a host nation.

images.alt_text:
Paris 2024 Olympics - Ceremonies - Paris 2024 Closing Ceremony - Stade de France, Saint-Denis, France - August 11, 2024.
A general view as singer Yseult performs performs during the closing ceremony. REUTERS/Andy Chua

site_title: Taiwan cuts 2024 GDP growth forecast amid weaker exports
summary: Taiwan's statistics agency has cut its 2024 GDP growth forecast to 3.90% due to weaker-than-expected exports. Exports are now predicted to grow 8.71% this year, down from a previous forecast of 10.06%. This is despite an AI boom boosting demand for tech products. The revised forecast is a slight slowdown from the May forecast of 3.94%.

site_title: Klarna CEO touts ‘solid’ US sales as fintech targets listing
summary: Klarna CEO Sebastian Siemiatkowski stated that US sales are "solid" and expect revenue to reach $1 billion "pretty soon" as the fintech doubles down on its US business. Despite concerns about consumers pulling back on spending due to high prices and borrowing costs, US retail sales accelerated in July, and Klarna is expanding its retail-banking services in the US and Europe. The company is preparing for an initial public offering in the US and aims to shave down payment costs and improve its cost of funding.

images.alt_text: Klarna, a Stockholm-based fintech, increased the value of goods sold by 14 per cent year on year in the second quarter.

site_title: ACEN, GenZero and Keppel collaborate on pioneering initiative for early coal plant retirement
summary: ACEN, GenZero, and Keppel have signed a memorandum of understanding to explore the retirement of a coal-fired power plant in the Philippines, potentially preventing up to 19 million tonnes of carbon emissions. The initiative, if completed, will be one of the first converted coal-fired plants to generate transition credits. The project aims to facilitate earlier retirement of the plant, with key stakeholders including the Philippines' Department of Environment and Natural Resources and Singapore's Ministry of Sustainability and the Environment.

images.alt_text: Several parts of Asia suffered extreme heat in 2024. Extreme weather is among the most signficant environmental risks over the next decade.
MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures
CAAS says such registry will align with internationally recognised sustainability standards.
Chia Der Jiun, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, speaking at the launch of the Singapore Sustainable Finance Association on January 24, 2024.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: India cenbank tightens rules for peer-to-peer lending platforms
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has tightened norms for peer-to-peer (P2P) lending platforms, amid concerns over systemic risks and consumer protection. The revised rules prohibit P2P platforms from assuming credit risk, providing credit enhancement or guarantee, and cross-selling insurance products. Platforms must also disclose losses borne by lenders and refrain from promoting P2P lending as an investment product. The revised norms, effective immediately, aim to prevent rule violations and misleading sales practices that were previously reported by Reuters.

images.alt_text: It is important for monetary policy to stay the course in bringing inflation down towards its 4 per cent medium term target, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das said.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant weighs buying health-care platform Haodf
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, is in discussions to acquire Chinese online health-care platform Haodf.com to integrate its technology with online consultations with doctors. The fintech company is seeking new avenues of growth after a business overhaul in March, following a 10% profit fall due to regulatory crackdowns. Ant has invested heavily in AI services, including a video generation startup and large language model technology. The acquisition is preliminary and could be subject to change, but would bolster Ant's AI services in healthcare.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an Ant Group logo at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun

site_title: With a bed and cinema, Smart’s #5 is a bet on something big
summary: Smart's new model, the #5, is a large, boxy sport utility vehicle designed for outdoor enthusiasts, featuring a bed, cinema, and off-road capabilities. The car's rugged design and accessories, such as a roof rack and foldable ladder, cater to camping and adventure seekers. The #5 is Smart's largest car and marks a significant departure from the brand's typical micro urban cars, highlighting the company's expansion into new markets and its growing capabilities.

images.alt_text: The #3’s instant acceleration making the #3 feel irrepressibly zippy.

site_title: India's Kashmir to vote in polls from Sept 18, five years after Modi ended its autonomy
summary: India will hold provincial elections in the Kashmir region from September 18, the first regional polls in a decade and five years after New Delhi scrapped the region's special autonomy. Nearly 9 million people are registered to vote for the 90-member legislative assembly. The decision follows a Supreme Court order rejecting petitions challenging the revocation of Kashmir's special status and setting a deadline for the polls. The elections aim to boost the local economy, which has seen tourism boom since the region's autonomy was revoked.

images.alt_text: Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, during the nation's Independence Day ceremony at Red Fort in New Delhi. He again called for a replacement of India’s religion-based laws with a uniform civil code, a move that’s been opposed by some minority groups.

site_title: Top Chinese chip gear maker sues Pentagon to void sanctions
summary: Advanced Micro-Fabrication Equipment (Amec), a top Chinese chip gear maker, has sued the US Pentagon to void sanctions imposed by the Pentagon, citing harm to its business and reputation. Amec, a supplier to major tech firms including Huawei and Taiwan Semiconductor, claims its leadership is predominantly American and that the designation was "wrong and groundless." The company is seeking to be removed from the Section 1260H list, which bars business with American firms linked to China's military.

images.alt_text: This latest round of talks comes amid heightened trade tensions between the US and China, with Washington raising concerns over China’s export-oriented industrial policy.
Fentanyl overdoses have surged to become the leading cause of death for Americans between the ages of 18 and 45 and over 107,000 Americans died from drug overdoses in 2023.
The new restrictions are likely to be unveiled as soon as late August.
The US also plans to add about 120 Chinese entities to its restricted trade list.

site_title: Issue 112: ESG indices fall in line amid sell-off; banks likely to miss climate goals
summary: Major ESG indices tracked their vanilla benchmarks closely during a recent global equities sell-off, with the exception of the ACWI Asia Pacific ex-Japan ESG Leaders index, which outperformed its counterpart. Despite this, ESG performance did not correlate with share price movement in Singapore banks and real estate investment trusts. The sell-off may be an opportunity for investors to pick up ESG value if they believe structural ESG-related risks will continue to increase. Meanwhile, a study found that major banks are not on track to achieve already inadequate climate goals, with many lacking targets in high-emitting sectors and providing financing to these sectors.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Generative artificial intelligence is driving the growth of green data centres in this region, while the electric vehicle boom is propelling the industrials sectors, said Lim.
A Trump victory in the US presidential election, especially alongside Republican gains in Congress, will fuel a push to limit many tax incentives that are helping propel electric vehicle sales.
Peninsular Malaysia had 1.7GW of installed solar power capacity in 2021, according to the report
Indonesia has pledged to boost the proportion of renewables in its energy mix and foreign lenders have promised to provide funding.
Hydrogen could supply up to half of Singapore’s power needs by 2050

site_title: Evergrande onshore unit's administrator seeks details from creditors ahead of meeting
summary: Evergrande's onshore unit, Guangzhou Kailong Real Estate, has entered bankruptcy and liquidation proceedings, with a liquidation group appointed as administrator. A creditor meeting is set for November 14. The administrator, Vanward, has asked creditors to declare debts owed to them by November 7. This comes after a Hong Kong court ordered the offshore holding company to be liquidated due to unpaid debt. The bankruptcy does not affect Hengda Real Estate, Evergrande's flagship property entity in mainland China, which claims normal operations will continue.

images.alt_text: The Evergrande unit, Guangzhou Kailong Real Estate, was ordered by an arbitration court to pay Vanward the investment sum and an annual interest of 10 per cent, as well as an arbitration fee of more than 1.4 million yuan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 16)
summary: Singapore's NODX (Non-Oil and Non-Manufacturing Exports) jumped 12.2% on a seasonally adjusted monthly basis. Key exports surged 15.7% in July, reversing the June drop. NY-listed PropertyGuru will be delisted in a $1.1 billion acquisition by EQT Private Capital Asia. SingPost recorded a 105.2% higher Q1 operating profit of $24.4 million. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's first National Day Rally speech on Sunday is expected to have heightened political significance as a pre-general election rally.

site_title: Number of loans to female entrepreneurs rises over 30% after launch of SME programme in April: OCBC
summary: OCBC's SME programme for women entrepreneurs saw a 30% increase in loans extended in the two months following its launch in April, with a 20% increase for male-owned businesses. The programme offers financing of up to S$100,000 with waived processing fees, educational workshops, and networking opportunities. The initiative aims to accelerate the growth of women-led SMEs, with plans to roll out in Malaysia by the end of the year and Hong Kong by mid-2025.

images.alt_text: From left: Sharon Lim, chairperson and former chief executive officer of 3D fashion design platform Browzwear, Linus Goh, OCBC head of global commercial banking and Didi Gan, founder of medical technology start-up N&E Innovations.

site_title: PwC fined US$19 million over LCF audit failures
summary: PwC, a "Big Four" auditor, was fined US$19.3 million for failing to alert regulators to potential fraudulent activity at London Capital & Finance (LCF), a UK investment firm that collapsed in 2016. The firm encountered "significant issues" during its audit and suspected LCF might be involved in fraudulent activity, but failed to report its concerns to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). The FCA attributed the failure to a senior LCF individual's aggressive behavior and the firm's provision of inaccurate information.

images.alt_text: PwC has been in the spotlight for its role in Evergrande’s accounting, after Chinese authorities launched an investigation into one of the biggest financial frauds in history.
A slew of luxury residential units are hitting the market as rich local families have been caught up by a debt crunch.

site_title: Nanyang Poly students help HDB enterprises refresh offerings, go digital
summary: Nanyang Polytechnic has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Federation of Merchants' Associations to develop digital solutions for heartland enterprises, aiming to rejuvenate neighbourhood town centres and encourage businesses to adopt innovative practices. The partnership, set to last three years, will co-develop workshops and training programs for heartland enterprises, with a focus on placemaking, business innovation, and digital transformation. The move follows a successful Heartland Innovation Challenge, where students collaborated with 15 heartland enterprises to develop innovative solutions, with the top prize going to a family-owned picture frame business that developed a website and augmented reality technology to attract younger customers.

images.alt_text: Businesses eligible for the Heartland Enterprise Placemaking Grant can get funding of up to S$10,000 per project for community engagement activities. PHOTO: ST FILE

site_title: Indonesia's 2025 deficit at 2.53% of GDP in proposed budget
summary: Indonesia's 2025 budget proposes a deficit of 2.53% of GDP, with total expenditure expected to be 6% higher than this year's forecast. The government aims to allocate 3,613.1 trillion rupiah for spending, including 71 trillion rupiah for free school meals and 400.3 trillion rupiah for infrastructure projects. The budget targets 5.2% GDP growth, exceeding the 3% deficit limit and sparking concerns about Prabowo's economic team's expansionary fiscal policy and higher debt levels.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, wearing the traditional Betawi attire, delivers his annual state of the nation address at the parliament building in Jakarta on Aug 16, 2024.

site_title: Hong Kong Q2 GDP expands 3.3% on year
summary: Hong Kong's economy expanded by 3.3% in the second quarter of 2024, exceeding expectations, according to the government. The growth is attributed to a 2.7% expansion in the first quarter. The economy is expected to continue growing, despite uncertainties from geopolitical tensions and global economic factors. The total number of cities participating in a scheme allowing Chinese residents to travel to Hong Kong independently has increased to 59, aiming to boost the economy.

images.alt_text: A view of Victoria Harbour.

site_title: What is Mpox, how does it spread and is there a vaccine? All you need to know
summary: A mutated strain of mpox, a cousin of smallpox, has been detected in at least six African countries, prompting a global health emergency declaration by the World Health Organization. The disease, which has a 3-6% fatality rate, typically starts with flu-like symptoms and can spread through close contact. A vaccine is available, and treatment mainly focuses on relieving symptoms. The current outbreak, which has affected over 60% of known fatal cases under 5, is being fueled by its spread through sexual contact and is complicated by stigma and shame surrounding the disease.

images.alt_text: A laboratory nurse takes a sample from a child suspected of having Mpox at a treatment centre in Munigi, Democratic Republic of Congo, July 19, 2024.

site_title: BMW, venture to recall over 1.3 million cars in China due to airbag risks, regulator says
summary: BMW is recalling over 1.36 million cars in China due to potential risks with the Takata airbag. The recall, effective immediately, affects models produced from 2003 to 2017. BMW Brilliance Automotive will recall 598,496 China-made cars, while BMW China Automobile Trading will recall 759,448 imported cars. Affected vehicles may have faulty Takata airbags installed by car owners, which could cause safety hazards. BMW will replace the driver's front airbag free of charge for confirmed defective vehicles. This is part of a broader recall in the US, which affected 394,000 vehicles.

images.alt_text: BMW expects the economic situation in China to stabilise in the third quarter, it says.

site_title: Asia: Markets surge on strong US consumer data
summary: Asia's markets surged on Friday, August 16, following strong US consumer data, with the Nikkei 225 index rising nearly 3% and the Hang Seng index making a strong start. The US retail sales report reassured investors about the health of the US economy, causing the US dollar to rise against the yen. Asian markets, including those in Japan, Hong Kong, and Singapore, also posted gains, despite concerns about inflation and recession. The data suggests the Federal Reserve may achieve a "soft landing" and avoid a recession, boosting investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Positive growth figures from Japan meant the Nikkei 225 led the Asian surge, as the world’s fourth-largest economy reported a better-than-expected GDP rise of 0.8 per cent for the second quarter.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, August 16th, 2024 (Ep 124)
summary: Asian markets surged on positive US economic data. NY-listed PropertyGuru will be delisted in a US$1.1 billion acquisition by EQT Private Capital Asia. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) said its rate-cut path could change based on price and wage setting.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ this week began its easing cycle much earlier than previously signalled as the economy slumps and inflation slows.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of SoftBank Group Corp is seen at the company's headquarters in Tokyo, June 30, 2016.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo/File Photo
The transaction is expected to be completed in the last quarter of 2024 or first quarter of 2025.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise as market sentiment improves; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% on Friday, driven by regional market rallies and receding recession fears. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 37.16 points to 3,352.89. Asian markets also rallied, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi rising 3.6% and 2% respectively. Analysts attribute the market's improvement to reduced recession fears and expectations of a rate cut in September. Top gainers included Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust and CapitaLand Investment, while Singtel was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng index made a strong start while the Shanghai composite was marginally higher.
On a seasonally adjusted monthly basis, xxx
The comments come after Centurion announced a 209 per cent jump in earnings to S$118.2 million, from S$38.3 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Mpox vaccine maker Bavarian wants approval for adolescents
summary: Bavarian Nordic, the sole US and European-approved mpox vaccine maker, plans to submit clinical data to the European Medicines Agency to extend its approval to include adolescents aged 12-17 in Europe. The move comes as the World Health Organization declares the spread of mpox in Africa a global public health emergency. The vaccine's effectiveness and safety in children aged 2-12 years will be assessed through a clinical trial, with the possibility of approval for adolescents during the fourth quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: The WHO on Wednesday declared the outbreak in Africa a public health emergency of international concern after cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo spread to nearby countries.

site_title: SpaceX to launch a methane satellite to hold super polluters accountable
summary: SpaceX is set to launch the Tanager-1 satellite, a methane-detecting satellite developed by Planet Labs with NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory technology, on August 16. The satellite will help pinpoint methane and carbon dioxide emissions from individual facilities, with a focus on "super emitters" such as oil and gas wells and landfills. The satellite's data will be made available by the nonprofit Carbon Mapper, which aims to deploy a constellation of satellites to observe up to 90% of major sources of emissions globally. The launch is seen as a step towards increasing accountability for methane super emitters and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: Since launching its first two-person crew of astronauts to space in 2020, the Elon Musk-led company has conducted 13 human spaceflight missions.

site_title: Centurion upbeat on strong student dorm demand, bed shortage in key study destinations
summary: Centurion Corporation, a specialized accommodation operator, reported a 209% jump in earnings to S$118.2 million, driven by strong rental reversions and fair-value gains. The company expects demand for purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) to outstrip supply in several markets, including the US, UK, Australia, and Hong Kong. Centurion's UK portfolio is performing well, with an average financial occupancy of 99%. The company is focusing on expanding its PBSA pipeline in Australia and Hong Kong, and has plans to redevelop existing car parks and seek planning approvals. Analysts see this as a re-rating catalyst for the company's stock, with a target price raised to S$0.78.

images.alt_text: Centurion's revenue for H1 rose 27 per cent to S$124.4 million, from S$97.9 million a year earlier.
Generic photo of SGX signage

site_title: Serial champions Man City on quest to make it 5 EPL wins on the trot
summary: Manchester City, serial EPL champions, are favourites to win the title again, with barely three months since their fourth consecutive league title. The new season begins this weekend, with significant changes in the summer transfer window and some teams starting with a new manager. Arsenal is building momentum, potentially giving City a run for their money, following a memorable 2023-2024 season that saw Liverpool's Jurgen Klopp depart and Manchester United finish eighth, their worst-ever finish.

Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag has endured a difficult season but he will hope to keep the club's FA Cup hope alive against Coventry on Sunday.

site_title: Indonesia’s 2025 budget forecasts growth at 5.2%, modest deficit of 2.53% of GDP
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has proposed a 2025 budget of 3,613 trillion rupiah, a 5.2% growth forecast, and a modest deficit of 2.53% of GDP. The budget includes 400.3 trillion rupiah for infrastructure, including the new capital city Nusantara. Widodo has laid the groundwork for a seamless transition by supporting initiatives championed by his successor Prabowo Subianto, including a free school meal programme. The budget aims to stimulate consumption, control inflation, and create jobs, with a focus on infrastructure development and expanding value-added processing for agricultural products.

images.alt_text: Construction at Indonesia's new capital city, Nusantara, in Kalimantan is progressing.
Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, wearing the traditional Betawi attire, delivers his annual state of the nation address at the parliament building in Jakarta on Aug 16, 2024.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's proposed Postbank case settlement offer rejected by plaintiffs
summary: Deutsche Bank's proposed settlement offer to shareholders who sued the bank for underpaying them for the acquisition of Postbank has been rejected. The offer, which included paying 36.50 euros per Postbank share, was deemed "dead on arrival" by a lawyer for the plaintiffs. The rejection comes after years of litigation and has prompted Deutsche Bank to set aside 1.3 billion euros ahead of any possible payout. A court hearing in the case is scheduled for next Wednesday and has urged the parties to work on a settlement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Deutsche Bank is seen in Brussels, Belgium December 6, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Japanese flows and yen show markets recovering from BOJ scare
summary: Japanese investors poured the most money into long-term overseas bonds in 12 weeks, buying a large amount of short-term foreign debt, indicating a market recovery from recent BOJ scare. The yen's slide, which began after the Bank of Japan's hawkishness, has slowed, and investors are now betting on the BOJ slowing rate hikes and the yen staying cheap. This suggests a shift in market sentiment, with investors shifting away from riskier assets and towards more stable investments. The data follows a sharp rally in the yen earlier this month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration
FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: RBA’s Michele Bullock says it’s ‘premature’ to think about rate cuts
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock stated it's premature to think about rate cuts due to persistent inflation, which will only return to target range late next year. Despite a solid labor market and resilient business confidence, the RBA remains vigilant to upside risks to inflation. The central bank will not cut rates in the near term, as it seeks to balance slowing inflation with preventing unnecessary damage to the labor market. The RBA next meets on September 23 and is expected to maintain its hawkish stance.

images.alt_text: Bond investors are shrugging off a relatively hawkish stance from the RBA, at least compared to peers.

Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock, in a speech in her home town of Armidale, New South Wales, reiterated that the board was vigilant to the upside risk of inflation, days after the bank decided to hold rates steady.
Reflecting stronger consumer demand and public spending, Australia’s economic growth is expected to pick up to 1.7 per cent by the year end and to 2.6 per cent by June 2025.

site_title: NY-listed PropertyGuru to be delisted in US$1.1 billion acquisition by EQT Private Capital Asia
summary: New York-listed PropertyGuru Group will be acquired by EQT Private Capital Asia for $1.1 billion, marking the company's delisting from the New York Stock Exchange. The deal, expected to be completed in the last quarter of 2024 or first quarter of 2025, comes two years after PropertyGuru's initial public offering in 2022. Private equity groups KKR and TPG, holding a combined 56% of shares, have agreed to sell their stake in support of the merger. The acquisition price represents a 7% premium to PropertyGuru's last closing price.

images.alt_text: The Mall Intelligence Module will open up “an entire new customer segment” PropertyGuru never had access to, Krishnan said.

site_title: Thaksin’s daughter Paetongtarn Shinawatra becomes Thailand’s new prime minister
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister is Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 37, daughter of former leader Thaksin Shinawatra. She secured 319 lawmakers' support in the 500-member House of Representatives, making her the youngest PM in Thailand's history. This comes after a tumultuous period, including a court ousting her predecessor and dissolving the top opposition party. Paetongtarn's elevation maintains an alliance between the Shinawatra-controlled Pheu Thai Party and other royalist and military-backed parties. She has declined to answer questions about her government's policies until her appointment is endorsed by King Maha Vajiralongkorn.

images.alt_text: The economy likely grew 2.1 per cent in the second quarter from a year ago, according to a median estimate of economists ahead of the announcement on Monday.
Thaksin's daughter Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 37, received the backing of a majority of lawmakers in Thaksin’s Pheu Thai party at a meeting on Thursday.

site_title: To solve housing woes, Britain turns to  old idea – new towns
summary: The UK Labour Party has vowed to build 1.5 million homes over the next five years to address the country's housing crisis. The plan includes reviving the idea of new towns, which was first introduced after World War II. The government has set a target of 370,000 homes per year, with a focus on expanding small communities and establishing settlements. However, critics argue that the development process has been slow and that the planning system has led to delays and resistance from local residents. The goal is to create thriving towns like Northstowe, which aims to become a 25,000-resident community by 2040.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A row of residential houses is seen with the financial district in the distance in South London, Britain, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Jokowi touts Indonesia-centric growth, bigger global role
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, also known as Jokowi, delivered his final State of the Nation address, highlighting the country's steady economic growth, reduced poverty, and increased global standing. He touted his success in boosting onshore processing of critical minerals, creating over 200,000 jobs, and positioning Indonesia as a voice for the Global South. Despite criticisms of his tenure, Jokowi emphasized his efforts to expand downstreaming to agricultural products and urged his successor to focus on boosting growth in less developed provinces. He will step down in late October after serving two five-year terms.

images.alt_text: Jokowi has championed the Nusantara project and made it a goal for the new city to host Indonesia’s independence day celebrations before he leaves office in October.
BT

site_title: SoftBank is picking stock winners in India’s red-hot IPO market
summary: SoftBank's investments in Indian startups have yielded significant returns, with shares of Ola Electric Mobility, Unicommerce eSolutions, and Brainbees Solutions surging over 60%, 80%, and 40% respectively. The successful IPOs may provide funds for SoftBank's planned expansion into AI and semiconductors, bolstering its enormous cash pile and soaring asset value. SoftBank's CEO, Masayoshi Son, is optimistic about the future, stating that the company will continue to invest globally, including in fund transactions.

SoftBank has blamed Intel for the collapse of the talks, claiming Intel was incapable of meeting its demands for volume and speed, the report says.

site_title: New Thai leader to scrap US$14 billion cash handout
summary: Thailand's next prime minister, Paetongtan Shinawatra, is expected to scrap a US$14 billion cash handout to its citizens, a key campaign promise of her father, Thaksin Shinawatra. The plan, which aimed to boost economic growth to 5% annually, has been delayed due to disagreements over funding and inflation. The economy likely grew 2.1% in the second quarter, and the new administration may roll out more direct stimulus measures instead.

images.alt_text: Thaksin's daughter Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 37, received the backing of a majority of lawmakers in Thaksin’s Pheu Thai party at a meeting on Thursday.

Srettha’s removal after less than a year in power means parliament must convene to choose a new premier, with the prospect of more uncertainty in a country dogged for two decades by coups and court rulings.
Less than half of Thailand’s 3.2 million SMEs have access to loans from financial institutions, according to Thailand's central bank.

site_title: UK retail sales rise 0.5% in July
summary: UK retail sales rose 0.5% in July, beating forecasts, with volumes 1.4% higher than a year ago. The increase was partly due to easing inflation pressures, which returned to 2% in May and June. Consumer confidence also rose to its highest in nearly three years, with shoppers reporting improved finances and increased willingness to make big purchases. This comes after the Bank of England cut interest rates for the first time in 16 years.

images.alt_text: Market researcher Kantar said annual grocery price inflation was 1.8 per cent in the four weeks to Aug 4, versus 1.6 per cent in the previous four week period.
Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.

site_title: Srettha Thavisin’s dramatic fall; Nusantara’s challenging rise
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was dismissed for breaching ethical rules. In other news, Vietnam remains classified as a non-market economy by the US, while Indonesia scaled back Independence Day celebrations at its new capital. Malaysia launched the country's biggest IPO in seven years with 99 Speed Mart's IPO. The EMA granted a conditional license to RGE and TotalEnergies' Indonesian solar project to import electricity to Singapore.

images.alt_text: An upturn in the global electronics cycle is expected to buoy growth in Singapore, Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines.
The Philippines’ gambling sector is the third largest in Asia, next in size only to Macau and Singapore.
The abrupt departure of Bambang Susantono, the head of the Nusantara Capital City Authority, has stirred speculation among investors.

site_title: EV giant BYD plans to build Karachi plant as part of entry into Pakistan
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD plans to build a factory in Karachi, Pakistan, in partnership with Mega Conglomerate. The factory, expected to be completed by mid-2026, will produce battery-electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, including an SUV and sedan. BYD aims to enter Pakistan's growing EV market, which is still relatively small compared to total auto sales. The company will also set up showrooms in Karachi, Lahore, and Islamabad to start selling in the fourth quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: Separately on Wednesday, BYD announced a partnership with Uber Technologies to put 100,000 EVs onto the ride-hailing company’s platform.
Under the multiyear partnership, Uber and BYD will offer drivers lower vehicle pricing and financing.

site_title: Harris to propose US$25,000 assistance for first-time homeowners
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris plans to propose a US$25,000 down-payment support for first-time home buyers with a two-year history of on-time rent payments. This program, part of her economic policy rollout, aims to address rising housing costs. Harris also aims to build or preserve three million new housing units through construction tax incentives. The proposals come amid high inflation and shelter price increases, with many Americans struggling to afford homes.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in New York, US, on Friday, July 12, 2024. President Joe Biden is calling on Congress to pass a form of national rent control for some 20 million apartment units nationwide, a dramatic federal intervention in the housing market on behalf of current tenants. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The US housing market has been starting to benefit from an expectation that the Federal Reserve will cut its benchmark interest rate at its meeting in September.

site_title: Paetongtarn Shinawatra: The new Thai PM with an old name
summary: Thailand's new Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 37, is the country's youngest premier and third member of the Shinawatra dynasty to hold the role. A political newcomer, she was chosen by her party, Pheu Thai, to replace Srettha Thavisin, who was sacked by the Constitutional Court due to a cabinet minister's criminal conviction. Paetongtarn, who is pregnant, entered politics in 2022 and was a key figure in her party's campaign, despite being beaten in the national vote last year. She will hope to avoid the fate of her father and aunt, whose terms as PM ended with the army seizing power.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn, 37, secured the support of at least 251 lawmakers midway through the voting in the 500-member House of Representatives.
The economy likely grew 2.1 per cent in the second quarter from a year ago, according to a median estimate of economists ahead of the announcement on Monday.

site_title: NTUC, Institute of Banking and Finance partner financial associations to upskill workforce
summary: NTUC and the Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) have partnered with seven financial associations to upskill the workforce in sustainable finance and generative artificial intelligence skills. The collaboration aims to align upskilling efforts with future trends and sectoral needs, providing training programs, mentoring, and career-growth prospects. The partnership also enables institutions to stay competitive and supports employees with career advisory, training, and job-placement services, ensuring responsible management of job displacement.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024
MAS projects that the financial sector will grow by an average 4 per cent to 5 per cent per annum during 2021 to 2025.

site_title: Home prices in Seoul rise at fastest pace in more than 4 years
summary: Seoul's home prices surged 0.76% in July, the largest monthly increase in over 4 years, driven by growing demand for investment in areas undergoing or planned for reconstruction. This sharp rise comes amid concerns about financial stability risk from a bullish housing market. The Korea Real Estate Board reported a 0.15% monthly rise in the house transaction price index, the fastest since October 2023.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees room for one more rate cut this year
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), the Philippine central bank, sees room for one more interest rate cut this year, according to Governor Eli Remolona. The decision comes after a 25 basis point rate cut on Thursday, the first since November 2020, and follows data showing the economy grew 6.3% in the second quarter. The peso slipped to 57.15 against the US dollar after the rate cut, but BSP governor Remolona is not overly concerned about the depreciation.

site_title: Spanish fashion group adds Hong Kong shop with rent 60% off peak
summary: Spanish fashion group Mango has rented a 19,000-square-foot store in Hong Kong's Central district, with a monthly rent of about HK$1.2 million (S$203,285), 60% lower than peak rent in 2014. The new store, in a vacant location since 2020, is part of a trend of global brands returning to the city, lured by lower rents. This marks the latest sign that global brands' waning confidence in Hong Kong is coming to an end, as the city's relaxed visa rules and influx of middle-class residents from mainland China strengthen local spending.

images.alt_text: Mango is also offering clothes for men using “performance” fabrics that are more breathable and that better handle sweat on hot days.
The company has been carrying out an internal reorganisation, creating a new board of directors led by founder Isak Andic.

site_title: China central bank sees more growth steps but nothing ‘drastic’
summary: China's central bank chief, Pan Gongsheng, pledged further economic support without adopting drastic measures. The PBOC will strengthen monetary and financial policies, focusing on interest rates and price stability. Retail sales and investment growth remained subdued, while the housing market remains weak. Pan emphasized the importance of maintaining policy patience and stability, warning against drastic tightening or easing. The PBOC is expected to implement moderate interest rate cuts, with potential reductions of 10 basis points before year-end, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Traders in China rushed back into buying bonds after a report showed bank loans to the real economy contracted for the first time in 19 years.
The PBOC in recent weeks began an overhaul that could allow it to operate more such as global peers and influence market borrowing costs more effectively.
Growth in outstanding yuan loans slowed to 8.7 per cent compared with 8.8 per cent in June.
China’s sovereign debt has rallied this year as demand for haven assets has surged due to a sluggish economy and expectations of further rate cuts.

site_title: Singapore stocks open Friday higher on surprise exports surge; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, August 16, 2024, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1% to 3,347.45 points. Non-oil domestic exports surged 15.7% in July, exceeding economists' estimates, driven by growth in electronics and non-electronics exports. Gainers outnumbered losers 102 to 41 across the broader market, with banking stocks leading gains, including DBS and UOB. The strong performance followed a strong showing on Wall Street, where all three indices rallied on encouraging consumer data.

images.alt_text: Paragon Reit's special distribution is expected to be paid on Oct 7.

site_title: Gold eyes weekly gain on US rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices steadied on Friday, headed for a weekly gain, driven by optimism about a US interest rate cut. Spot gold eased 0.2% to $2,450.91 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.2% to $2,488.50. The anticipated rate cut is expected to boost non-yielding bullion's appeal in a low interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was nearly unchanged at US$2,448.49 per ounce.

site_title: Alibaba’s long-awaited China stock link may provide timely boost
summary: Alibaba Group Holding is set to gain a much-needed boost as Chinese investors can now buy its shares, potentially injecting up to $20 billion into the company by next year. The move, known as the "southbound link," could help stabilize Alibaba's stock, which has underperformed rivals like Tencent Holdings due to concerns over competition and sluggish China consumption. Analysts predict a positive impact on the stock, with potential inflows reaching 7% of Alibaba's total outstanding shares.

images.alt_text: Investors worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share back from PDD Holdings and JD.com in China will compress margins.
Tencent’s advertising, fintech and business services operations are sensitive to deteriorating economic growth.
Signage at the Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. offices in Beijing, China, on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023. Alibaba is scheduled to release earnings results on Aug. 10. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Donald Trump reveals US$513 million from golf clubs and resorts
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has revealed $513 million in income from his golf clubs and resorts, including $161 million from a Miami-based company, $57 million from Mar-a-Lago, and $37 million from Bedminster. Trump's net worth is $5.3 billion, with Trump Media & Technology Group accounting for more than half of it. He has disclosed over $50 million in liabilities, including debts related to a civil fraud case and a defamation suit, and has secured a $175.3 million bond to put a $454 million judgment on hold.

images.alt_text: Walz has emerged as a powerful advocate of Harris, describing himself as the head of “White Dudes for Harris”, and as a critic of the Republicans, saying “these guys are just weird” – a comment that has become a popular Democratic line of attack.

The interview on Musk’s social media platform could allow Trump to reach a different audience than the conservative faithful who attend his rallies and watch his interviews on Fox News.
Trump has celebrated the latest market developments on his social media accounts, blaming the Biden administration for the emerging  slowdown.

site_title: StarHub’s finance chief resigns; GoTo’s Jacky Lo to take over
summary: StarHub's finance chief, Dennis Chia, has resigned due to personal reasons, effective September 2. He will be succeeded by Jacky Lo, GoTo Group's current CFO, who will take over from September 2. Chia will remain as adviser to the group's CEO until December 31, 2024. Lo brings "wealth of experience" to the role, with expertise in financial planning and corporate governance. StarHub shares closed down 0.8% on the news.

images.alt_text: StarHub has declared an interim dividend of 3 cents per share for H1, compared to an interim dividend of 2.5 cents per share in the corresponding year-ago period.
Analysts believe that the local telecoms industry is due for consolidation, which should help improve margins.
The company attributed the rise in net profit to higher share of profits from joint ventures and associates, lower net finance costs, lower depreciation and amortisation and taxation charges.

site_title: Binance restarts India business after getting local registration
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has restarted its operations in India after registering with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU). The move comes after the exchange was banned in the country in 2023 due to non-registration. Binance's rival, WazirX, has suspended trading and deposits following a $235 million hack. Registered exchanges in India, such as KuCoin, are now collecting a transaction tax, which led to a decline in volumes and complaints from local exchanges. Binance claims its positions comply with applicable laws.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies are placed on a keyboard in this illustration taken, June 8, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan hit by another big quake, no immediate reports of damage
summary: A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck 34km off Taiwan's eastern city of Hualien, followed by a 5.7 magnitude quake, on August 16. No immediate damage reports were made. The quake had a depth of 9.7km and shook buildings in Taipei, with subway services operating at lower speeds. Authorities have warned of the risk of landslides in mountainous areas due to recent rain. This is the second strong tremor to hit Taiwan in less than a day, following a 5.7 magnitude quake on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The government issued an emergency warning of a strong tremor for the capital city and Kanagawa, Saitama, Yamanashi and Shizuoka prefecture, without a tsunami alert.
Police officers stand guard near a building damaged following an earthquake in Miyazaki, southwestern Japan.
There were no immediate reports from Philippine authorities of damage or casualties caused by the offshore quake.
Fallen rocks on the Suhua highway due to an earthquake in Hualien, Taiwan, April 22, 2024.

site_title: Singapore’s key exports surge by surprise 15.7% in July, reversing from June drop
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 15.7% in July, reversing the 8.8% drop in June, with both electronics and non-electronics exports experiencing double-digit growth. This is the largest increase since January, exceeding economists' expectations of a 1.2% rise. The turnaround is attributed to strong sequential expansion and favourable base effects, with NODX on a seasonally adjusted monthly basis jumping 12.2%.

images.alt_text: Singapore lowers full-year NODX forecast, expects growth of 4-5%

site_title: A speech to watch: How will Prime Minister Lawrence Wong approach his first National Day Rally?
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver his first National Day Rally (NDR) speech on Sunday, with heightened political significance as a pre-general election rally. Wong's speech will address key policy moves, domestic issues, and geopolitical tensions amid uncertainty. He faces challenges in establishing himself as a distinct leader, navigating crises, and reassuring the public on economic and social policies. Key topics expected to be covered include cost-of-living worries, gig worker support, family-friendly measures, and balancing the needs of the older and younger generations. Observers expect a safe and light-hearted tone, with potential for innovation in multimedia content, but warn against addressing sensitive topics like immigration.

images.alt_text: “We cannot control global prices, but we can and we have shielded Singaporeans from the worst effects of global inflation by keeping the Singapore dollar strong," said PM Wong.
Will there be more refinements to Singapore's world class public housing at this year's NDR?

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi gives evidence in civil hearing  over purported nickel Ponzi scheme
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, accused of perpetrating a S$1.5 billion nickel trading scam, testified in a civil hearing for the Envy companies, which he was a majority owner and director of. He expressed concern that his evidence might be used against him in his criminal proceedings, where he faces over 100 charges. Ng denied allegations that he covered up evidence and hired employees to help with the Ponzi scheme. The civil hearing aims to hold three defendants – Lee, Ju, and Cheong – jointly and severally liable for the outstanding sum of about S$854 million owed to investors.

images.alt_text: Investigations show that Envysion's former chief executive officer and directors did not put in place appropriate risk management framework for a fund related to a nickel trading fraud case, says MAS.

A MAN is facing a charge for obstructing the course of justice, by offering to help businessman Ng Yu Zhi leave Singapore unlawfully while the latter was under investigation for fraud.

site_title: Fed chair Powell to headline next week’s Jackson Hole meet
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will deliver remarks on the economic outlook at the Kansas City Fed's annual economic symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, next Friday. The gathering provides an opportunity for Powell to assess the US economic trajectory and potential monetary policy changes. Powell previously mentioned the possibility of an interest rate cut if inflation and labor market data continue to cool. The Fed has held its policy rate in the 5.25-5.5% range for over a year, aiming to slow economic growth and control inflation.

site_title: Malaysia’s Q2 GDP growth beats forecasts at 5.9%
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded by 5.9% in the second quarter, beating forecasts, driven by stronger domestic demand and exports. The services sector rose 5.9% year on year, while the manufacturing sector grew 4.7%. Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour attributed the growth to higher household spending and improved exports. The central bank expects full-year GDP growth to hit the upper end of its projection of 4-5%. The ringgit has strengthened, but remains undervalued, and inflation is expected to rise in the coming months due to the removal of the diesel subsidy.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s economy grew more than expected in the second quarter of 2024, exceeding the 5.8 per cent advance estimates made by the Department of Statistics Malaysia.
Key factors driving Malaysia's growth in 2024 include continued investment realisation, recovering external demand, and resilient domestic spending.
After a lacklustre performance in 2023, Bursa Malaysia’s initial public offering (IPO) market has gained momentum in 2024 and growing stronger.
Offshoring is always an option because of the high cost in Singapore, although UOB is also mindful of the quality of labour supply, said CFO Lee Wai Fai.

The new plant will focus on making power semiconductors that can help with decarbonisation in automotive, industrial and data centre fields.

site_title: Crypto Democrats rally behind Harris campaign in push for policy revamp
summary: A group called Crypto4Harris, comprised of cryptocurrency advocates, has rallied behind Kamala Harris' presidential campaign, urging her to reset the Democratic party's policy on digital assets. The group, which includes billionaire Mark Cuban and Wall Street financier Anthony Scaramucci, aims to push nonpartisanship and calls for an end to the Biden administration's crackdown on the cryptocurrency industry. They plan nationwide fundraisers and are discussing potential crypto-friendly picks for regulators, aiming to draw up a list to present to Harris if she wins.

images.alt_text: The action came after Musk and Trump held a two-hour conversation on social media platform X Monday night, during which the two discussed workers walking off the job to go on strike.
The interview on Musk’s social media platform could allow Trump to reach a different audience than the conservative faithful who attend his rallies and watch his interviews on Fox News.
Trump has celebrated the latest market developments on his social media accounts, blaming the Biden administration for the emerging  slowdown.

Microsoft's report follows recent statements by senior US Intelligence officials that they’d seen Iran ramp up use of clandestine social media accounts with the aim to use them to try to sow political discord in the United States.

Harris, the US vice-president, is expected to announce her selection by Tuesday, ahead of her first scheduled public appearance with her running mate in the evening at Temple University in Philadelphia.

site_title: China’s electric vehicles lose ground in EU after new tariffs take effect
summary: China's electric vehicle sales in the EU declined 45% in July, following the implementation of EU tariffs on Chinese-made EVs. The tariffs, which took effect on July 5, aimed to protect EU automakers from low-cost competition. BYD, China's top-selling car brand, is pressing on with its expansion in Europe despite the decline. The drop in EV sales may have been exaggerated by carmakers rushing to get EVs to dealers before the tariffs took effect. EU member countries have reported July figures, but the full impact of the tariffs is yet to be seen.

images.alt_text: A BYD Co. sponsorship stand at a Fan Zone in Berlin for the Euro 2024 football championship. Photographer: Liesa Johannssen/Bloomberg
In July, the EU slapped extra provisional duties of up to 38 per cent on Chinese EVs after its executive arm concluded in an investigation that they were unfairly undermining European rivals.
China is both the largest producer and the world’s biggest market for EVs, yet the manufacturers mostly rely on foreign companies for the multiple chips that modern high-end cars require.
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.
Chinese firms need a workaround for European tariffs to avoid sacrificing profit or exposing customers to the pain.

site_title: Applied Materials forecasts quarterly revenue above estimates on AI-driven demand
summary: Applied Materials forecasted fourth-quarter revenue slightly above Wall Street estimates, driven by surge in AI-fueled demand for chip-making equipment. The company's revenue is expected to benefit from the growing need for high-performance computing and data centers, which require sophisticated and expensive wafer fabrication equipment. This increase in demand is expected to boost the need for memory semiconductors, further benefiting suppliers of chip-making tools.

images.alt_text: The company has benefited from growing demand for wafer fabrication equipment.

site_title: JPMorgan says buying corporate debt on dips pays off 70% of time
summary: JPMorgan research notes that buying US high-grade corporate bonds on dips pays off 70% of the time within three months. The strategist's claim is based on historical data, suggesting that most dips in corporate bond spreads are short-term opportunities to buy. This contradicts the conventional wisdom that it's usually costly to buy bonds during market downturns.

images.alt_text: Banks have lately been selling more bonds that transfer credit risk to investors, allowing them to book a lighter capital charge on their assets.
JPMorgan Asset Management plans to maintain its exposure mainly in the 10-year notes unless it sees massive stimulus.
JPMorgan sysd it has been given options by the CFPB to either pursue a settlement or face an enforcement action.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks into the JP Morgan headquarters at Canary Wharf in London May 11, 2012.  REUTERS/Dylan Martinez//File Photo

site_title: Australia’s ASX profit slips as regulator scrutiny drives up costs
summary: Australia's ASX reported a 3.4% decline in annual underlying profit to A$474.2 million due to higher expenses from regulatory scrutiny, including a lawsuit from the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) over a troubled software upgrade. The company has been required to provide governance reports and has faced a lawsuit alleging misleading statements to the public. ASX shares fell 3.3% in early trading but recovered to be flat, with analysts citing the ongoing ASIC investigation as an overhang on the stock.

images.alt_text: A man stands in front of an electronic board displaying stock information inside the Australian Securities Exchange, operated by ASX Ltd., in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Sept. 9, 2013. The Australian dollar's strongest weekly advance since December 2011 is a reminder to Prime Minister-Elect Tony Abbott that his plans to revive a slowing economy will be hostage to currency markets. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: RBNZ says rate-cut path could change on price, wage setting
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) lowered its Official Cash Rate by a quarter point to 5.25% and projects it will fall below 4% by the end of 2025. Assistant Governor Karen Silk stated that the decision was driven by a decline in inflation expectations, price and wage setting, and a slowdown in the economy. The RBNZ will maintain a "measured approach" and will remain data-dependent, considering a potential 50 basis point cut but not assigning significant weight to it. The central bank now expects a 0.5% contraction in the second quarter and a 0.2% decline in the third quarter, marking the third technical recession in less than two years.

images.alt_text: The central bank reckons the economy is now in its third recession in less than two years while inflation will return to its 1 to 3 per cent target range in the current quarter.
The RBNZ’s pivot to easing is a rapid change of tune after it said in May it considered raising rates and wouldn’t cut them until the second half of 2025.
The economy is showing signs of entering its third recession in less than two years and inflation has slowed more than the RBNZ expected.

site_title: Australia’s NAB posts lower cash earnings, flags decline in asset quality
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) posted an 8% drop in third-quarter cash earnings, citing sustained high costs of living eroding households' disposable incomes and leading to rising arrears. The bank's asset quality is expected to decline further, with a non-performing exposures ratio of 1.31% at June-end, the highest since September 2021. Despite a stable net interest margin and a 12.6% common equity tier one ratio, NAB's unaudited cash earnings fell to A$1.75 billion, down from A$1.90 billion a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Under the buyback programme, ongoing since August last year, NAB will now purchase shares worth a total of A$1.7 billion, which will reduce its common equity tier 1 ratio by about 40 basis points.
Australia's second-biggest lender by market valuation posted cash earnings of A$1.80 billion (S$1.6 billion) for the quarter ended Dec 31.
Between January 2017 and July 2018, National Australia Bank continued to charge its customers periodic payment fees for transferring money despite knowing it had no contractual entitlement to do so.
The move marks the latest blow for Hong Kong’s ambitions to keep growing as a primary Asian financial hub alongside places such as Singapore and Tokyo.

site_title: Giant metal stockpile in Singapore sparks rare warehouse battle
summary: A surge in metal stockpiles in Singapore, fueled by a slowdown in global demand, has sparked a rare warehouse battle. Refined zinc and lead inventories have more than 10-fold since May 2023, reaching a record 430,000 tonnes. The buildup is partly driven by a lack of consumer spending in China, but also by a trading strategy that allows companies to benefit from higher storage costs in Singapore. Warehouse operators are sharing storage fees with traders through "rent-sharing" agreements, which come with a financial risk if traders shift inventories elsewhere.

images.alt_text: The LME’s nickel contract has picked up dramatically this year, with daily volumes finally resembling pre-crisis levels for the first time.
The exchange has already operates warehouses across Asia, including Singapore, South Korea, Malaysia, Japan and Taiwan.

site_title: China to limit antimony exports in latest critical mineral curbs
summary: China will impose export limits on antimony and related elements starting September 15, citing national security concerns. The move affects six types of antimony-related products, including antimony ore, metals, and oxide, and requires exporters to obtain licenses for dual-use items. China, which accounts for 48% of global mined antimony output, aims to safeguard national security and fulfill international obligations. The restrictions follow a series of curbs on critical minerals, including rare earths, graphite, gallium, and germanium, amid growing demand and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: During the first seven months of 2024, China’s rare earths exports climbed 7.5 per cent from the same period a year earlier to 34,032 tonnes.

site_title: WHO confirms first case of new mpox strain outside Africa as outbreak spreads
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the mpox outbreak in Africa a global public health emergency of international concern, marking the first case of the new strain outside the continent. A new strain of the virus, clade Ib, has spread to nearby countries, with cases reported in Sweden, and is linked to the recent outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The WHO has up to $500 million to spend on vaccine distribution, and global health officials warn of potential rapid international spread of the disease.

images.alt_text: A laboratory nurse takes a sample from a child suspected of having Mpox at a treatment centre in Munigi, Democratic Republic of Congo, July 19, 2024.

site_title: China to screen arrivals for mpox symptoms
summary: China will screen arrivals for mpox symptoms for six months, following the WHO's global health emergency declaration. Customs officials advise travelers from outbreak areas to declare symptoms upon entry. Vehicles and items from affected areas will also be sanitized. This move comes after the discovery of a more dangerous mpox variant in Sweden and amid a worsening outbreak in Africa. The WHO has sounded alarm over the spreading virus, which causes fever, muscular aches, and skin lesions, and can be transmitted through close contact.

images.alt_text: The WHO on Wednesday declared the outbreak in Africa a public health emergency of international concern after cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo spread to nearby countries.
A laboratory nurse takes a sample from a child suspected of having Mpox at a treatment centre in Munigi, Democratic Republic of Congo, July 19, 2024.

site_title: Preserving the dollar: Role of CBDCs in securing economic stability for future generations
summary: The US dollar's dominance as the global reserve currency is under threat due to rising national debt and budget deficits. To counteract this trend, developing a US central bank digital currency (CBDC) is crucial. A CBDC would enhance tax collection, reduce transaction costs, and boost fiscal transparency, fostering sustainable economic growth. It could also counter the threats posed by decentralised cryptocurrencies and maintain the dollar's status as a reserve currency. Balancing strategic fiscal discipline with digital currency advancements is key to sustaining US economic leadership and global financial stability.

images.alt_text: Francois Villeroy de Galhau, Governor of Banque de France, is seen after French Minister for Economy, Finance, Industry and Digital Security Bruno Le Maire delivered his New Year address to France's economic actors at the Bercy Finance Ministry in Paris, France, January 8, 2024. Most, if not all, central banks are conducting research into developing their own digital currencies.

The dollar is and will remain for the foreseeable future the main store of value for global investors. Geopolitical tensions favour the greenback as investors search for a haven and further escalations do not necessarily point to an imminent weakening of its dominant position.
The US dollar isn't going away.

site_title: Meta fends off AI-aided deception as US election nears
summary: Meta has released a security report stating that Russia-backed online deception campaigns using generative AI have been unsuccessful in attacking US political candidates who support Ukraine. Despite the efforts, Meta has been able to disrupt deceptive influence operations and has been working with other internet firms to thwart misinformation. The report also highlights concerns that social media platforms, including X (formerly Twitter), are being used to spread disinformation, with Elon Musk's personal account being flagged for its potential influence on the US election.

site_title: Millennium opens Singapore office as Asia credit trading soars
summary: Millennium Advisors, a US-based trading firm, has opened a new office in Singapore to capitalize on the region's growing demand for electronic trading and US dollar bonds. The office, which began operations on July 3, marks the firm's expansion into Asia. This move follows a significant increase in electronic trading in the region, with 56% of investors using electronic trading last year, up from 36% a decade ago. The firm aims to take advantage of these trends and evolving markets.

images.alt_text: South Korean retailers have been scooping up Nvidia, Tesla and Apple shares this year fuelled in part by the worldwide AI-frenzy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Paragon Reit, UOB Kay Hian, SingPost
summary:
Key developments in the markets include:

- CapitaLand Investment priced S$350 million in senior notes at 3.58% interest.
- Paragon Reit's unitholders will receive S$0.0185 per unit from a special distribution due on Oct 7.
- UOB Kay Hian reported a 64.3% increase in six-month net profit to S$113.9 million.
- Singapore Post's operating profit rose 105.2% year on year to S$24.4 million in the first quarter.
- RE&S agreed to a proposed acquisition by Relish Investments, taking the company private.
