site_title: Qualcomm extends sponsorship of Manchester United until 2029
summary: Qualcomm has extended its sponsorship deal with Manchester United Football Club until 2029, boosting its Snapdragon brand visibility. The partnership aims to promote Qualcomm's push into personal computers, as the company seeks to challenge Intel's dominance in the market. The deal, initially set for three years, now runs for six years, with Qualcomm reportedly paying £60 million annually. The partnership has already led to the Snapdragon logo being seen over two billion times, highlighting Qualcomm's efforts to expand its presence in the PC market.

site_title: Malaysia’s September target for Johor-Singapore SEZ deal pushed to year end
summary: Malaysia's plan to finalize the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JSSEZ) agreement by September has been pushed to the end of the year due to ongoing negotiations over several sticking points. Discussions will continue until the 11th Singapore-Malaysia Leaders' Retreat in December. The issues include contributions to a facilitation fund for companies expanding operations in Johor and skilled workforce provisions. The JSSEZ, covering 3,505 sq km across southern Johor, aims to ease the movement of people and goods across the border and generate employment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Teo Siong Seng, chairman of JS-SEZ Singapore Business Working Group, notes the SEZ to be a potential game-changer for both Singapore and Malaysia, leveraging the two sides' complementary strengths.
UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong (right) with Johor Chief Minister Onn Hafiz Ghazi during his visit to UOB's Singapore headquarters in UOB Plaza.
The 1-kilometre-long Causeway is one of the busiest border crossings in the world, with an average of 350,000 travellers daily.

The demand for properties in Johor Bahru is on the rise as investor confidence rebounds, thanks to the positive news of RTS Link construction progress and the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 2% on upbeat US economic data, geopolitical tension
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Thursday, driven by upbeat US economic data and geopolitical tensions. US crude oil stockpiles rose by 1.4 million barrels, alleviating recession fears. Brent crude futures gained $1.28, or 1.6%, to $81.04 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose $1.18, or 1.53%, to $78.16. Geopolitical concerns, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict and Iran's response to the Hamas leader's killing, also supported price gains.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures closed 93 cents lower, or 1.15 per cent, at US$79.76 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Bank of America partners Fifa as first-time sponsor for 2026 World Cup
summary: Bank of America has partnered with FIFA as its first-ever global sponsor in the banking category for the 2026 World Cup. The US lender will be featured in FIFA's global marketing campaigns, allowing it to reach a wider audience and boost brand recognition. The partnership will complement Bank of America's global market strategies and engage with a worldwide audience, according to CEO Brian Moynihan. The 2026 World Cup will feature 104 matches and 48 participating teams, co-hosted by the US, Canada, and Mexico.

images.alt_text: Spain's forward #19 Lamine Yamal controls the ball during the UEFA Euro 2024 semi-final football match between Spain and France at the Munich Football Arena in Munich on July 9, 2024. (Photo by JAVIER SORIANO / AFP)
Fifa said the current calendar was unanimously approved by the Fifa Council following a comprehensive consultation, which included Fifpro and league bodies.
Spain climb to third in Fifa rankings, Argentina stay top
Fifa's new Club World Cup tournament has also been criticised by the player unions who say that it will put the world’s elite footballers under too much physical strain.
Fifa's new Club World Cup tournament has also been criticised by the player unions who say that it will put the world’s elite footballers under too much physical strain.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US increase for first time since end of July
summary: US mortgage rates have increased for the first time in three weeks, rising to 6.49% for a 30-year, fixed loan, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the lowest rate in over a year. The expected Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September is expected to benefit the housing market, with prices and inventory starting to recover. Experts predict downward pressure on mortgage rates this fall and winter, setting the stage for a better season for homebuyers in 2025.

images.alt_text: us home united states rent housing Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) refinancing index jumped 34.5 per cent to a more than two-year high of 889.3.
The decline in mortgage rates increases prospective homebuyers’ purchasing power, say market watchers.
Some 980 homeowner mortgaged properties were taken into possession between March and June.

site_title: Europe: Shares led higher by tech, banks as US slowdown fears ease
summary: Europe's benchmark stock index, the Stoxx 600, closed at a two-week high, up 1.2% on Thursday, driven by strong US retail sales data that eased fears of a US slowdown. Technology and bank shares led the gains, with risk appetite boosted by the data. The pan-European index reversed losses from the first half of August, with major regional bourses also rising over 1%. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut expectations remain intact, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.5 per cent higher on Wednesday, with all the major regional bourses also ending in positive territory.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as recession fears recede
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 1.4% to 40,563.06, the S&P 500 adding 1.6% to 5,543.22, and the Nasdaq Composite Index surging 2.3% to 17,594.50. The gains followed strong US retail sales data, which exceeded expectations and eased recession fears. Initial jobless claims also fell, indicating a weakening but not rapid labor market. Retail giant Walmart's earnings were also a positive factor, with its shares rising 6.6%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 287.3 points, or 0.72 per cent, at the open to 40295.74.

site_title: At least one arrested over actor Matthew Perry's death: US media
summary: At least one person has been arrested in connection with the ketamine overdose death of actor Matthew Perry, who was 54 when he died in October last year. Perry, best known for playing Chandler Bing on the hit TV sitcom "Friends," was found unresponsive in his pool. An autopsy found ketamine as the cause of death, and investigators are probing how Perry obtained the drug. At least one doctor and multiple dealers have been implicated in the investigation.

images.alt_text: Matthew Perry (third from left), who played Chandler Bing on the hit TV sitcom Friends from 1994 to 2004, died at the age of 54, having been found unconscious in a swimming pool at his house in Los Angeles in October.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment unit prices S$350 million in senior notes at 3.58%
summary: CapitaLand Investment's wholly-owned unit CLI Treasury Limited priced S$350 million worth of senior notes at 3.58% due 2035. The notes will be issued under the S$6 billion euro medium-term note programme established in 2021. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings and fund investments and corporate purposes. The issue date is Aug 22, and UOB has been appointed as the sole lead manager and bookrunner. The maturity date is 10.5 years from the issue date, with CLI guaranteeing the payment obligations of the issuer.

images.alt_text: CLI posts higher portfolio gains in H1 of S$35 million, from S$7 million the year before.

site_title: Cordlife reverses into the red with S$12.4 million H1 loss, loses accreditation with blood banking body
summary: Cordlife Group, a Singapore-based cord-blood bank, reported a net loss of S$12.4 million for the first half of 2024, down 67.5% from a net profit of S$2.2 million in the previous year. The company's Singapore operations were suspended due to storage lapses in seven of its 22 tanks, leading to the loss of accreditation from the Association for the Advancement of Blood & Biotherapies (AABB). Cordlife is exploring new business opportunities in other markets and has engaged a subsidiary to assist with rectification efforts.

images.alt_text: The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Cordlife shares were up 2.8 per cent or S$0.004 to S$0.147 at Monday’s close.
Cordlife says it will disclose more details when it announces its unaudited first half results on or before Aug 14.

site_title: MAS review group or not, boards and directors need to be more dynamic
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange's latest earnings season ended with companies reporting slightly below-expectations earnings and revenue, with real estate investment trusts still struggling with elevated interest rates. The Straits Times Index has largely erased its gains from July and August, leaving investors slightly better off than at the start of the year. The MAS review group, tasked to strengthen the equities market, has been announced, but its timeline for a report is 12 months, with no concrete measures expected until then. Boards and directors are urged to be more dynamic and disclose specific details about their strategies and actions to address the challenging environment.

site_title: The role of artificial intelligence in cardiology
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is poised to revolutionize cardiology, reducing cardiovascular mortality. AI-powered devices can monitor heart health at home, detect abnormal heart rhythms, and assess heart damage with precision comparable to experienced cardiologists. AI can also automate echocardiogram images, predict heart attacks, and diagnose heart failure with high accuracy. By leveraging AI, cardiologists can gain a clearer understanding of coronary artery disease severity, detect high-risk patients, and implement timely preventive measures, ultimately reducing cardiac mortality.

images.alt_text: Recent advancements in integrating AI with MRI technology hold promise for medical professionals seeking improved outcomes for patients experiencing cognitive decline.
Artificial intelligence can potentially drive the next major revolution in reducing cardiovascular mortality.

site_title: US business inventories rise marginally in June
summary: US business inventories rose 0.3% in June, in line with economists' expectations. This increase was driven by a surge in retail inventories, which rose 0.9% after a 0.7% increase in May, offsetting mild gains at wholesalers. Inventories increased 2.1% year-on-year, contributing to the economy's 2.8% annualized growth pace in the second quarter. Business sales fell 0.1% in June, indicating that it would take 1.38 months to clear shelves at the current sales pace.

site_title: A new chapter in time
summary: Three luxury watch brands, Audemars Piguet, IWC, and Rado, have unveiled new novelties showcasing innovative designs and cutting-edge technology. Audemars Piguet's Royal Oak Offshore features a classy smoked bronze dial, while IWC introduces Ceralume, a proprietary luminous ceramic technology allowing for bright blueish glows. Rado's True Square Thinline watches boast high-tech ceramic cases and sleek square shapes, ideal for urban nightlife.

images.alt_text: Omega, the official timekeeper of the Olympics since 1932, marks this year's Games with a new Speedmaster Chronoscope collection.

site_title: Canada home sales slip as buyers seek more interest-rate relief
summary: Canada's home sales decreased 0.7% in July from the previous month, as buyers waited for further interest rate cuts from the central bank. The benchmark home price rose 0.2% to C$718,700. Economists expect the Bank of Canada to lower its interest rate to 4% by the end of the year, with some predicting a rate cut to 3.75%. Despite a rise in newly listed properties, the market is cautious, with sellers and buyers holding off until more rate relief arrives.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, August 15th, 2024 (Ep 123)
summary: Asian markets rallied following Wall Street gains, with Temasek spending billions on US tech stocks before a July sell-off. Convenience-store chain 99 Speed Mart launched Malaysia's largest listing in seven years. Meanwhile, Indonesia's new capital Nusantara faces delays ahead of Independence Day celebrations, marking its first major test.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Google launches Pixel 9 Phones, Pixel Watch 3 in renewed push to sell AI
summary: Google has launched the Pixel 9 phones, Pixel Watch 3, and Pixel Buds Pro 2, emphasizing its artificial intelligence capabilities. The new devices include upgraded smartphones, a foldable phone, and a smartwatch with improved displays and battery life. The Pixel 9 phones feature Google Assistant with Gemini generative AI, while the Pixel Watch 3 offers 24 hours of battery life and integration with Google TV. The launch comes ahead of Apple's new gadgets and marks a renewed push for Google to sell AI-powered devices.

images.alt_text: According to Google, aggregators and telcos will verify a company’s legal identity and sender ID against Singapore’s SMS Sender ID Registry to ensure that messages are only sent by legitimate brands.

site_title: SIA’s planned frequency and capacity boost unlikely to raise yields by much, analysts say
summary: Singapore Airlines' planned frequency and capacity boost for the 2025 travel season is unlikely to significantly impact yields and load factors, according to analysts. The airline's moves are strategic shifts to capture demand on popular routes with robust competition from Chinese airlines. Industry watcher Jason Sum noted that such actions are consistent with SIA's usual moves, and the impact on yields and load factors may be minimal. The airline's efforts aim to capitalize on travel demand in the mid-year summer season.

site_title: Thomson Medical, OUE Healthcare subsidiaries partner on surgery centre in Vietnam
summary: Thomson Medical, a subsidiary of OUE Healthcare, has partnered with O2 Healthcare to establish a surgical centre in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The centre, located at FV Hospital, aims to serve patients from Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar. Dr. Su Jang Wen, a cardiothoracic surgeon from O2 Healthcare, will lead the treatments. This partnership enables Singapore doctors to offer specialized treatments in an underserved region, while Thomson Medical's acquisition of FV Hospital's owner in 2023 further solidifies its presence in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The US$381.4 million consideration comprises an initial consideration of US$359.6 million in cash, together with an additional earn-out consideration of US$21.8 million.
Incoming chief executive officer of Thomson Medical Group Lee Suen Ming will take over from Nov 1.

site_title: Starbucks’ US$113 million deal puts Niccol among top-paid CEOs
summary: Starbucks has announced a US$113 million deal for new CEO Brian Niccol, with a pay package including US$75 million in stock grants and a US$10 million signing bonus. The move is expected to cost the company at least US$120 million, with shares soaring 25% and adding US$21.4 billion to market capitalization after the announcement. Niccol will not be required to relocate to Seattle, instead working from a remote office in California. Outgoing CEO Laxman Narasimhan will leave with a payout likely worth around US$10 million and millions of dollars in equity awards.

images.alt_text: Fresh leadership is now brewing at Starbucks.

(FILES) Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol walks across the 14th hole during the Pro Am event prior to the Memorial Tournament presented by Workday at Muirfield Village Golf Club on June 05, 2024 in Dublin, Ohio. Narasimhan steps down as chief executive and as a member of the Starbucks board "with immediate effect," said the company in a statement. (Photo by Dylan Buell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: How to turn your HDB flat into a dual-key unit
summary: A three-room HDB flat in Hougang features an oversized sliding partition door, allowing flexibility in usage as a single or dual key unit. The feasibility of converting flats into dual-key units depends on the floor plan, with a discussion between owners and designers crucial. Goodman Interior, which has converted several flats, advises closely examining the flat configuration and discussing space usage with owners. The company's business development director notes that there is no single HDB layout that works best for dual-key conversions.

site_title: Little-known fact: HDB flats can be turned into dual-key homes
summary: HDB flats can be converted into dual-key homes, allowing owners to rent out a smaller studio space while maintaining a private living area. This concept, popular in private condominiums, has gained interest in the HDB market, with a few analysts estimating fewer than 10 such flats have been converted in the past decade. Renovation costs can start at S$10,000, and the concept may lead to increased housing supply and lower rents for tenants. However, it may also encourage homeowners to own multiple properties, potentially spurring a rise in million-dollar flat transactions and creating challenges for flat owners when selling their homes.

images.alt_text: This 3-room HDB flat features an oversized, full-height sliding partition door to allow flexibility in usage as a single or dual key unit.

site_title: In providing re-employment support, will Singapore’s fourth-generation leadership remain wary of giving too much?
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is set to announce re-employment support details in his National Day Rally speech. The move comes amid scrutiny of healthcare insurance and doctors. For decades, Singapore's politicians have been cautious about providing unemployment benefits, citing concerns of abuse and eroding self-reliance. The exact eligibility criteria, length, and financial support are yet to be disclosed, but Wong's speech is expected to address these questions, potentially marking a shift in the government's stance on re-employment support.

images.alt_text: “We cannot control global prices, but we can and we have shielded Singaporeans from the worst effects of global inflation by keeping the Singapore dollar strong," said PM Wong.
Health Minister Ong Ye Kung noted that the government is “very worried” about escalating costs to the Republic’s healthcare system.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on retail sales boost
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by resilient retail sales data for July, which alleviated fears of an imminent recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 287.3 points, or 0.72%, to 40,295.74, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground, rising 45.9 and 201.9 points, respectively. The data suggests consumer spending remains strong, supporting the US economy despite ongoing trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Shareholders at RE&S scheme meeting approve privatisation offer from Southern Capital Group unit
summary: RE&S Holdings, a Singapore-based food services group, has approved a proposed privatisation offer from Relish Investments, a unit of Southern Capital Group. The offer, which is made by way of a scheme of arrangement, was accepted by 99.98% of shareholders, with payment expected on or around October 18. The deal represents a 56.5% premium to the last traded price and is expected to take the company private. RE&S will next submit its application to the court for the sanction of the scheme, with a hearing expected on or around August 29.

images.alt_text: Tai Er is a sauerkraut fish brand that owns six restaurants in Singapore, including one at 313@somerset.

site_title: Maersk agrees to study nuclear-powered container shipping
summary: Maersk, a Danish shipping group, has agreed to join a study with Lloyd's Register and Core Power to assess the feasibility of nuclear-powered container shipping in Europe. The study will investigate regulatory frameworks and safety rules for a fourth-generation nuclear reactor. This comes as the maritime industry explores cleaner fuel solutions to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, which account for nearly 3% of global emissions. The study's findings may pave the way for nuclear power as a decarbonization pathway for the logistics industry in 10-15 years, according to Maersk's head of fleet technology.

images.alt_text: Maersk, viewed as a barometer of world trade, said global container demand increased about 7 per cent year on year in the first half of the year, boosted by robust demand from Europe, emerging markets and strong Chinese exports.

site_title: US retail sales rise more than expected in July
summary: US retail sales rose 1.0% in July, exceeding expectations, as consumers maintained spending through bargain hunting and trading down to lower-priced substitutes. This data could alleviate financial market fears of a sharp economic slowdown, potentially leading to a quarter-point interest rate reduction. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and food services, rose 0.3% in July after a 0.9% increase in June. The solid data puts retail sales on a strong footing at the start of the third quarter, despite a marginal July gain.

images.alt_text: Job seekers register at a Disabled American Veterans (DAV) and RecruitMilitary LLC job fair in Detroit, Michigan, U.S, on Thursday, Oct. 31, 2019. The Department of Labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on November 7. Photographer: Anthony Lanzilote/Bloomberg via Getty Images
A Walmart store in Secaucus, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Walmart is revamping more than 800 store locations and adding high-end products. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 15)
summary: New-home sales in July plummeted nearly 60% year on year, with the suburban Outside Central Region leading condo and private apartment sales at 77.8% of total sales. This decline reflects a softer property market, with homebuyers remaining cautious and selective.

site_title: Hard-to-beat  under-S$100 sushi deals at Aoki
summary: Aoki, a renowned sushi restaurant, has reopened in its new premises at Millenia Walk with a streamlined menu offering top-quality seafood at affordable prices. The restaurant offers various set lunches and omakase options, with prices ranging from S$75 for a nine-piece sushi lunch to S$450 for a 17-piece sushi omakase. Chef-owner Kunio Aoki's commitment to using fresh, seasonal ingredients and flexible pricing makes Aoki a firm favourite in Singapore's dining scene, with a rating of 7.5. The restaurant's compact space features a 10-seater counter and two private rooms, with a focus on close interaction between chefs and customers.

site_title: US dollar rises after retail sales and jobs data
summary: The US dollar rose 0.36% against a basket of currencies, following lower-than-expected jobless claims and a rise in retail sales, which may signal upcoming rate cuts. The dollar index reached 102.96, while the euro held above $1.10, and the pound strengthened against both the dollar and euro. Other currencies, including the yen, Norwegian crown, and Australian dollar, also moved in response to economic data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee of a bank counts US dollar notes at a branch in Hanoi, Vietnam May 16, 2016. REUTERS/Kham

site_title: Positive economic figures from China, Japan lift regional markets; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,315.73, driven by strong retail sales and GDP data from China and Japan. Regional markets also saw gains, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index rising 0.8% and 0.9% respectively. The US August payroll figures are expected to be closely watched, with analysts speculating on possible interest rate cuts. Top gainers on the STI included ST Engineering, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, while City Developments Ltd fell 3.1%.

images.alt_text: AEM CEO Amy Leong says she will share her plans for the company in November this year.
The group's higher Q1 net profit comes amid a net exceptional gain of S$88 million.
Heavy rainfall could increase the chances of diseases for rubber trees and reduce the number of tapping days, the company says.

site_title: Samsonite board approves plan to pursue second listing in the US
summary: Samsonite International's board has approved a plan to pursue a second listing in the US, citing the country's "global footprint, growth drivers, and strategic priorities". This move aims to improve liquidity and make its shares more accessible to investors globally. The company, which owns American Tourister, Tumi, and High Sierra brands, has seen its Hong Kong shares fall 18% this year, leading to a market value of HK$30.9 billion. Samsonite's first-half net income rose 7.7% to US$164.3 million, while net sales were little changed at US$1.77 billion.

images.alt_text: The rapid ramp-up of international flights by Chinese airlines has reduced the SIA group’s market share on these routes.
Urban farm at Parkroyal Collection Marina Bay. Singapore hotels have been upping their game in going green.

site_title: Indonesia’s trade surplus plummets to US$470 million in July; lowest in 14 months
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus plummeted to US$470 million in July, the lowest in 14 months, due to a surge in import activity. This decline signals potential risks for the rupiah, which could face greater pressure ahead. Crude palm oil exports, one of Indonesia's biggest dollar earners, dropped 39.22% year on year to US$1.39 billion. The decline fell short of expectations, with forecasts predicting a surplus of US$2.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Construction at Indonesia's new capital city, Nusantara, in Kalimantan is progressing.

site_title: SoftBank scraps AI chips tie-up plan with Intel: FT
summary: SoftBank has scrapped plans to produce an artificial intelligence (AI) chip with Intel, citing Intel's inability to meet its demands for volume and speed. SoftBank blamed Intel for the collapse of talks, which were aimed at competing with Nvidia. The Japanese technology investor is now focusing on discussions with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker.

site_title: US industrial production declines by most since January
summary: US industrial production declined by 0.6% in July, the largest drop since January, due to a 0.3% decrease in manufacturing and a 3.7% drop in utilities output. The decline was attributed to a Hurricane Beryl-related decrease in Gulf Coast refinery activity and factory production, which was restrained by a drop in motor vehicle production. Excluding auto output, factory production increased 0.3% in July. This marks the third consecutive month of factory surveys showing a downbeat trend.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman looks at beauty products in a local store in New York City, U.S., December 10, 2023. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz/File Photo

Job seekers register at a Disabled American Veterans (DAV) and RecruitMilitary LLC job fair in Detroit, Michigan, U.S, on Thursday, Oct. 31, 2019. The Department of Labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on November 7. Photographer: Anthony Lanzilote/Bloomberg via Getty Images

site_title: Your favourite wine regions will feel the heat
summary: Europe's protected wine regions are at risk due to climate change, which may drive some to extinction. A recent study found that 1,085 wine geographic indications are vulnerable to warming temperatures, particularly in northern Italy, central Spain, and eastern Europe. To adapt, the EU's geographic indication system needs to be revised to allow for changes in viticultural practices. Some regions, like Champagne, may consider blending different grape varieties to preserve their unique characteristics. If winemakers don't adapt, they risk losing their unique wine styles and traditions.

images.alt_text: Erica Ritchie's family planted 23 rows of grapes at Haven Vineyard, on Long Island Sound on the North Fork, surrounded by commercial wineries.
Sweden's vineyards are aiming to make their mark in the wine world.
These easy-going wines are perfect for relaxing and just right for watching the Paris Olympics from afar.
Champagne shipments in the first half of 2024 reached 106.7 million bottles, down 15.2 per cent from a particularly high level recorded over the same period of 2023 and closer to the level in 2019.

site_title: Paragon Reit unitholders to get special S$0.0185 DPU from The Rail Mall divestment
summary: Paragon Reit's unitholders will receive a special distribution of S$0.0185 per unit following the completion of The Rail Mall divestment. This brings the year-to-date distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0417. The divestment, announced on June 20, was completed on August 15 for a cash consideration of S$78.5 million. The proceeds will be used to pay down debt obligations, with the remainder distributed to unitholders, expected to be paid on October 7.

images.alt_text: The Reit manager says the fall in DPU was a result of management fees being paid fully in cash to reduce dilution of unitholders' returns.
HPL opened its first Japan hotel, Four Seasons Osaka, on Aug 1
The Woodleigh Mall at Bidadari estate.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall
summary: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fell 7,000 to 227,000 for the week ended Aug 10, suggesting an orderly labour market slowdown remained in place. The jump in the unemployment rate to 4.3% in July sparked fears of a labour market deterioration, but layoffs remain low. Businesses have scaled back hiring due to the 525 basis points of rate hikes from the US central bank, and the number of people receiving benefits fell 7,000 to 1.864 million. The Fed maintains its benchmark interest rate in the 5.25-5.50% range.

site_title: Tapestry beats revenue, profit estimates on steady demand for Coach handbags
summary: Tapestry, the parent company of Coach, reported stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter results, driven by robust demand for its Tabby handbags. Sales rose 2% on a constant currency basis, beating analysts' estimates, and earnings per share exceeded expectations. The company attributed the success to its affordable luxury goods, particularly the Tabby bags, which have held up despite a global spending slowdown. Tapestry's shares rose 8% in premarket trading, and the company expects to close its Capri deal this year.

images.alt_text: This year’s Olympic medals, which contain an inset made of iron from the Eiffel Tower, were made by the LVMH-owned jeweler Chaumet.Credit...

site_title: US drug price negotiations cut costs by US$7.5 billion in first year
summary: The US government's landmark drug price negotiations, part of the Inflation Reduction Act, have saved Americans $7.5 billion in the first year, with $1.5 billion less spent by senior citizens and $6 billion less by the government. The policy uses Medicare's buying power to cut medication costs, potentially slashing the federal deficit by $237 billion over a decade. The new prices, set for 10 medications, are expected to be significantly cheaper than current net prices, with some analysts suggesting a 40% reduction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: DP World's H1 profit more than halves amid Middle East tensions
summary: DP World's first-half profit plummeted 59% to US$265 million due to shipping disruptions caused by the ongoing Red Sea crisis and tensions in the Middle East. The company's revenue rose 3.3% to US$9.34 billion, driven by its logistics and ports divisions. The Red Sea attacks forced vessels to reroute, impacting DP World's Middle East, Africa, and Europe operations. The company expects an improved performance for the second half of the year despite investments to expand its logistics platform.

images.alt_text: The port operator is expanding in Dar es Salaam in Tanzania and has recently assessed harbors in South Africa and Kenya for potential investment.

site_title: Sri Lanka's inflation to remain below target until March 2025, central bank says
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation is expected to remain below the central bank's target of 5% until March 2025, with projections showing a 2% point gap. The economy is experiencing a fragile recovery, aided by a US$2.9 billion IMF program. Inflation is anticipated to temporarily rise in the second half of 2025 but is expected to stabilize around the targeted level of 5% in the medium term. The central bank has cut interest rates by 75 basis points this year to ease inflation.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Colombo main port is seen beyond the main wholesale market, on the day President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is also the island nation's finance minister, presents the annual budget in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 12, 2023.Picture taken November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte
A general view of the main port in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo
Sri Lanka Photographer: Jonathan Wijayaratne/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese e-commerce group JD.com beats profit forecasts in Q2
summary: JD.com, a major Chinese e-commerce group, reported a 73.7% increase in second-quarter profit to 9.36 yuan per share, beating forecasts. The company attributed the growth to price cuts that attracted cost-sensitive consumers. JD.com's US-listed shares rose 3.5% in premarket trading. The company's focus on discounts and lower-priced goods is part of a price war among Chinese e-commerce players, with increased competition triggered by a stuttering post-Covid recovery in China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an Ant Group logo at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun
Investors worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share back from PDD Holdings and JD.com in China will compress margins.

site_title: Walmart lifts earnings outlook after revenues rise
summary: US retail giant Walmart reported a 4.8% rise in revenues to $169.3 billion in the second quarter, beating analyst estimates. Despite a 43% fall in profits, the company's operating income rose 8.5%. Walmart attributed the strong sales to consumers choosing the store over more expensive options due to post-pandemic cost increases. The company raised its year-end outlook and saw its global e-commerce sales grow 21% and advertising business rise 30%. Walmart's CEO Doug McMillon stated that customers from all income levels are looking for value, and the company has it.

images.alt_text: A Walmart store in Secaucus, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Walmart is revamping more than 800 store locations and adding high-end products. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: S$3b money laundering case: First Singaporean charged with disposing of Rolls-Royce, Ferrari cars
summary: A Singaporean, Liew Yik Kit, 41, has been charged with two counts of disposing of luxury cars belonging to Cambodian fugitive Su Binghai in a S$3b money laundering case. Liew, a former driver, allegedly lied to police about Su's assets and disposed of four luxury cars, including a Rolls-Royce and Ferrari, between Sep 11 and Oct 5, 2023. He was granted bail of S$15,000. Two Chinese nationals, Liu Kai and Wang Qiming, also face charges related to the case.

images.alt_text: The biggest money laundering probe in Singapore saw about $3 billion in cash and assets seized or issued with prohibition of disposal orders.
The Bill will introduce several proposals to improve the processes involved in dealing with seized properties including those linked to money laundering.
Singapore did not consult Cambodian authorities before deporting convicted money launderer
Su Binghai's home in Jalan Asuhan features a KTV lounge, arcade game machines, a dedicated massage room, and 10 large safes.
Wang Dehai was deported on July 6 after serving about 11 months of his 16-month jail term.

site_title: Stay sustainable: Hotels raise their green game
summary: Singapore hotels are stepping up their sustainability efforts, driven by technological advancements and regulations. Properties like Pan Pacific Orchard and Grand Hyatt Singapore have incorporated cutting-edge innovations, such as rainwater irrigation systems, trigeneration plants, and automated waste management. Food waste reduction is also a focus, with hotels like PARKROYAL COLLECTION Marina Bay and Fairmont Singapore using in-house farms to supply produce sustainably. The industry aims to achieve 60% internationally recognized sustainability certification by next year and reduce emissions by 2030, with the Singapore Hotel Association (SHA) tracking progress.

images.alt_text: The Kimen Group is developing a boutique residential project in London and doing it from scratch.

site_title: Grab’s Q2 loss narrows to US$53 million, but misses analyst estimates
summary: Grab, a NASDAQ-listed ride-hailing company, reported a Q2 loss of US$53 million, narrower than the US$135 million loss in the previous year. Revenue rose 17% to US$664 million, driven by growth across all segments, but missed analyst estimates. The company's adjusted Ebitda reversed into the black at US$64 million, while on-demand GMV grew 13% year on year to US$4.4 billion. Grab's digital banks, GXS Bank and GXBank, saw significant growth, and the company expects to achieve positive adjusted free cash flow for the full year of 2024.

images.alt_text: Forrest Li, chief executive of Sea.
In this prolonged dry spell, caution is the name of the game.

site_title: Modi wants to end India’s religion-based laws
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi called for a replacement of the country's religion-based laws with a uniform civil code, a move opposed by some minority groups. In his Independence Day speech, Modi stated that a secular civil code is the "need of the hour" and wants a comprehensive discussion on the subject. The current civil code governs marriage, divorce, adoption, and inheritance through multiple religious and customary laws, which critics argue promotes discrimination and inequality. The Bharatiya Janata Party, led by Modi, has campaigned for a uniform civil code in its election manifestos for decades.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) failed to secure a majority in the election last month, making it dependent on allies to form a government for the first time since he came to power more than a decade ago.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian H1 profit up 64.3% to S$113.9 million
summary: UOB Kay Hian reported a net profit of S$113.9 million for the six months ended Jun 30, up 64.3% from S$69.3 million in the previous period. Revenue increased 10.2% to S$317.1 million. Commission and trading income rose 18.8% to S$166 million. Earnings per share were 12.64 Singapore cents, up from 7.83 cents. The company's H1 profit and revenue beat expectations, driven by strong growth in commission and trading income.

images.alt_text: DBS believes the semiconductor and machine manufacturer is poised for recovery, supported by a sound balance sheet and its diversified portfolio.
Nanofilm posted a 29 per cent year-on-year decline in group revenue to S$128 million for the nine months ended September.
UOB Kay Hian reported a 32.7 per cent rise in earnings and a 22.4 per cent increase in revenue in H1 2023.

site_title: UBS puts 1.88 billion francs Credit Suisse real estate fund into liquidation
summary: UBS has initiated the liquidation of a real estate fund worth 1.88 billion Swiss francs (approximately $2.9 billion), formerly owned by Credit Suisse. The fund's value had fallen significantly in 2023, with 36% of its units redeemed by the end of 2023. UBS acquired Credit Suisse in 2023 following its collapse due to financial setbacks.

images.alt_text: A year after completing the takeover of Credit Suisse, UBS is on track for pre-merger levels of profitability, and plans to repurchase some US$2 billion in shares by 2026.

site_title: Fancy heading to space? Be prepared to pay US$600,000
summary: Virgin Galactic, a commercial spaceline, is offering sub-orbital flights to space for US$600,000, with at least two Singaporeans signing up for the experience. The company, which has taken 37 people to space over 12 flights, is working on its new Delta-class spaceships and expects to start commercial service in 2026. Customers will undergo training and preparation before the flight, which includes a two-seater aircraft experience and a journey to a top speed of Mach 3. With 700 seats reserved, Virgin Galactic aims to fly approximately 275 flights per year, with a projected 3,300 passengers annually.

images.alt_text: Patina Maldives sits on the largest of four man-made islands in the Malvdives’ North Male Atoll.
Capella Sydney is housed in the Australian city’s heritage-listed former Department of Education building.

site_title: Malaysia’s 99 Speed Mart unveils RM2.4 billion IPO, the country’s biggest in 7 years
summary: 99 Speed Mart, Malaysia's largest mini-market chain, has launched its RM2.4 billion initial public offering (IPO), the country's biggest in seven years. The IPO aims to raise funds for expansion, transparency, and efficiency. With 2,651 outlets across Malaysia, the company plans to increase its presence to 3,000 outlets by 2025. The IPO will also be used to set up six new distribution centers and upgrade delivery trucks. Trading is scheduled to start on September 9, with the company's shares priced at RM1.65.

images.alt_text: After a lacklustre performance in 2023, Bursa Malaysia’s initial public offering (IPO) market has gained momentum in 2024 and growing stronger.
The company said proceeds will be used for expansion of new outlets in Malaysia, establishment of new distribution centres and the purchase of delivery trucks, among other things.

site_title: Green power is losing the battle to clean up hydrogen
summary: Green hydrogen production is struggling to gain traction, with costs increasing and production levels lagging behind expectations. Despite initial optimism, the vast majority of hydrogen production remains "grey" and relies on fossil fuels, emitting significant amounts of carbon dioxide. In contrast, "blue hydrogen" - a method that captures and reuses carbon dioxide from fossil fuel production - is gaining popularity, with major oil companies investing heavily in this technology. This shift could undermine the potential of green hydrogen to decarbonize industries, which would require significant policy support and investment.

images.alt_text: Hydrogen could supply up to half of Singapore’s power needs by 2050
Employees of German technology company Bosch work on a hydrogen-powered fuel-cell module. There's a gold rush brewing in green hydrogen.
The EU alone hopes to be consuming 20 million tonnes a year of manufactured green hydrogen by 2030.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM falls as much as 19.2% after earnings miss
summary: AEM's shares fell 19.2% to S$1.18 after the company posted a 95.4% decline in net profit to S$895,000 for the first half of the fiscal year. Revenue declined 36.9% due to weaker demand from its key semiconductor customer. The decline was the largest since October 2019.

images.alt_text: AEM chief executive Amy Leong (left) and non-executive chairman Loke Wai San. Leong says she will share more details about her vision for the company in November.

site_title: Temasek spent billions on US tech stocks before July sell-off
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-owned investor, spent billions of US dollars on tech shares in the second quarter, including increases in Microsoft, Apple, Nvidia, Alphabet, Meta Platforms, and Amazon.com. The value of its holdings in these firms rose by US$3.3 billion, but many of these companies saw their stocks slide in July due to concerns about artificial intelligence gains and recession fears. By the end of July, Alphabet and Amazon's share prices had fallen by around 12%, while Microsoft's were down about 7%.

site_title: Thailand’s Pheu Thai party chooses Paetongtarn Shinawatra as PM candidate
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai party has chosen 37-year-old Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of billionaire ex-PM Thaksin Shinawatra, as its candidate for prime minister after a majority of lawmakers backed her at a meeting. This move signals continuity after Srettha Thavisin was removed as prime minister due to an ethics case. The appointment is likely to bring few changes to policies pursued by Srettha's administration, and Pheu Thai has secured the support of over 300 lawmakers in the lower house.

images.alt_text: Srettha’s removal after less than a year in power means parliament must convene to choose a new premier, with the prospect of more uncertainty in a country dogged for two decades by coups and court rulings.

site_title: ‘Factory’ is no longer a dirty word to cities
summary: The return of manufacturing to cities is gaining momentum, with innovative companies like Nanotronics setting up shop in Brooklyn's waterfront. This trend holds promise for urban vitality, diversity, and smarter business management, as it allows for closer proximity to consumers, high-quality universities, and skilled workers. The shift away from traditional factories to more efficient, AI-driven production methods also reduces ecological footprint and promotes innovation. While not all manufacturing should be re-urbanized, companies are rethinking their production strategies, and cities are adapting to welcome this change, potentially restoring the middle-class ideal and promoting more diverse and inclusive economies.

images.alt_text: Brooklyn project once pitched for Amazon lands first tenant
NYC manufacturing goes through high-tech revival

site_title: Australia July employment jumps past forecasts, unemployment at 2½ high
summary: Australia's employment numbers jumped past forecasts in July, with a 58,200 net increase, despite the jobless rate ticking up to 4.2%, the highest since early 2022. Full-time employment surged 60,500 for the third month, while the participation rate reached an all-time high of 67.1%. The Reserve Bank of Australia remains cautious, citing a tight labour market, and interest rate cut expectations have decreased to 35% for November, down from 55% previously.

images.alt_text: The index measuring whether it was a good time to buy major household items bounced 0.6 per cent, but remains historically low at 82.6.

Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

Even during a period of Covid-19 measures that closed many pubs, clubs and casinos in the 2020-2021 financial year, Australian state government statistics showed gambling losses exceeded A$24 billion.

site_title: Japan cancels flights and trains as another typhoon approaches
summary: Japan cancels hundreds of flights and trains as Typhoon Ampil approaches, threatening the Tokyo region and Pacific coast. The typhoon, forecast to bring gusts up to 180 km/h, has prompted evacuation advisories and warnings of violent gusts, flooding, and landslides. Major bullet train services, including those between Tokyo and Nagoya, are also cancelled. The typhoon follows Tropical Storm Maria, which dumped record rains, and is part of a trend of intensifying typhoons in the region due to climate change.

images.alt_text: A sign alerting passengers of possible delays in northern Japan - due to "Typhoon No. 5", now classified as Severe Tropical Storm Maria - at an entrance to Japan Rail (JR) at Tokyo Station in central Tokyo, Japan, Aug 12, 2024.

wscyber - Container terminal complex on the east side of Tobishima Pier at the Port of Nagoya, Japan's largest shipping port.




Credit: NAGOYA PORT AUTHORITY
News about Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's resignation flashed on public screens in Tokyo; August 14,  2024.
FILE PHOTO: Shigeru Ishiba, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Makiko Yamazaki/File Photo

site_title: Google launches RCS business messaging as a more secure alternative to SMS
summary: Google has launched Rich Communication Services (RCS) business messaging in Singapore, a more secure alternative to SMS, in partnership with Singtel. The service will enable Android users to receive verified business messages with a "verified" mark, enhancing cyber resilience and trust in the mobile ecosystem. However, not all telcos in Singapore have been approached, with M1, Simba, and StarHub expressing interest but not participating. The service aims to address security concerns, such as intercepted or tampered messages, and will be available to companies through aggregators and messaging partners.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A computer keyboard lit by a displayed cyber code is seen in this illustration picture taken on March 1,  2017. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/Illustration
The government will likely seek a ban on the type of exclusive contracts that were at the centre of its case against Google.
The earlier timing is Google’s latest bid to keep up with rivals in injecting AI features into its consumer-facing products and comes ahead of Apple’s planned launch of a new iPhone in September.

site_title: UK economy grows 0.6% in Q2
summary: The UK economy grew 0.6% in the second quarter of 2024, in line with economists' expectations. This marks a slow growth since the Covid-19 pandemic, with June seeing no change in gross domestic product compared to the same period last year. The Bank of England raised its annual growth forecast for 2024 to 1.25% due to a stronger-than-expected start to the year. This growth is a slight improvement from the previous quarter, which also saw a 0.7% increase.

images.alt_text: The BOE remains relatively focused on longer-term inflation pressures, including services prices and wages, as well as general labour market slack.

site_title: Sri Lanka presidential candidates submit election nominations
summary: Sri Lanka's presidential candidates have submitted their nominations for the September 21 election, with 39 candidates vying for the top spot. Incumbent President Ranil Wickremesinghe, opposition leader Sajith Premadasa, and Marxist-leaning parliamentarian Anura Kumara Dissanayake are seen as frontrunners. The election comes as Sri Lanka seeks to chart a path out of a financial crisis, with the winner expected to implement a four-year IMF programme and finalize a debt restructuring plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe speaks during an interview with Reuters at his office in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 28,2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

site_title: David Yong from Netflix’s ‘Super Rich in Korea’ handed fourth fraud charge, granted S$1 million bail
summary: David Yong, CEO of Evergreen Group Holdings, has been charged with fourth fraud related to falsifying financial statements, potentially inflating profit by nearly S$8 million. He was granted S$1 million bail with conditions, including electronic tagging. Yong faces up to 10 years' imprisonment and a fine. This brings the total number of charges against him to four, following previous allegations of abetting an employee to falsify papers. The investigation into Evergreen Group Holdings' business activities is ongoing, with authorities still checking on the surrender of Yong's Cambodian passport.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow Wall Street climb
summary: Asian markets followed the US stock surge, with the Nikkei 225 leading the way after Japan reported a 0.8% GDP rise in the second quarter, beating expectations. The positive growth figures were fueled by easing US consumer inflation, which set the stage for a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Traders are optimistic about a possible 25-50 basis point cut at the September meeting, boosting market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.6 per cent higher at 40,008.39, while the broad-based S&P 500 rose 0.4 per cent to 5,455.21 on Wednesday.
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.5 per cent higher on Wednesday, with all the major regional bourses also ending in positive territory.
On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumber losers 73 to 48.

site_title: Singtel Q1 net profit up 42.9% to S$690 million on exceptional gain
summary: Singtel's Q1 net profit rose 42.9% to S$690 million due to a net exceptional gain from dilution of its equity shareholding in associate Airtel. The underlying net profit increased 5.4% to S$603 million. Revenue fell 2.1% to S$3.4 billion, mainly due to the absence of contributions from sold cybersecurity arm Trustwave. Despite higher net finance expenses, Singtel remains optimistic about growth opportunities across its markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman using a mobile phone walks behind a Singtel signage at their head office in Singapore February 11, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
The new data centre campus can be scaled up to 200MW in response to market demand.
FILE PHOTO: A woman using a mobile phone walks behind a Singtel signage at their head office in Singapore February 11, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: DBS’ Piyush Gupta, Temasek’s Dilhan Pillay, DPMs part of 21-member Future Economy Advisory Panel
summary: DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta and Temasek's CEO Dilhan Pillay are among 21 members of Singapore's new Future Economy Advisory Panel (Feap), which aims to navigate rapid changes in technologies and markets amid a challenging geopolitical environment. The panel, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, will provide expert advice to support Singapore's economic growth and transformation. The Feap's formation follows the end of the Future Economy Council, which oversaw the creation and implementation of industry transformation maps across 23 industries.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offers 3.34% cut-off yield
summary: The latest Singapore 6-month Treasury bill auction saw a cut-off yield of 3.34%, down from 3.4% in the previous auction. The auction received S$16 billion in applications, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.32. Demand fell, and about 30% of competitive applications were allotted at the cut-off yield. Experts attribute the decline in yields to investors repositioning to expected easing of interest rates, with US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell signaling potential rate cuts in September.

images.alt_text: Singapore dollars notes. Tags: 钞票, 新币, 纸钞，新元，兑换率, Singapore’s strong exchange rate, currency

site_title: Global rush for Thai debt may cool on BOT policy, political risk
summary: Global investors may reduce their interest in Thailand's sovereign bonds due to rising political risk and a potential tightening of monetary policy, contrary to recent investments of $1.7 billion in Thai bonds this quarter. The Constitutional Court's dismissal of Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin from office has increased uncertainty, making Thai debt less attractive compared to peers in South Korea, India, the Philippines, and Indonesia. Forecasts of rate cuts in these countries this year may also shift investor sentiment away from Thai debt.

images.alt_text: Pichai Chunhavajira, Thailand’s finance minister, speaks at a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Thailand unveiled detailed plans for a long-delayed distribution of cash to most adult citizens, the centerpiece of government efforts to revive growth and the fortunes of the ruling coalition. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

site_title: US FTC finalises ban on fake online reviews
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has finalized a ban on companies buying or selling fake online reviews, which includes trafficking in fake reviews, buying and selling fabricated views or followers, and using intimidation tactics. The ban, which can impose fines of up to $51,744 per violation, aims to protect consumers from fake reviews that waste time and money. The rule does not require platforms to verify review accuracy, but instead aims to deter companies from engaging in the practice. The FTC Chair Lina Khan stated that fake reviews "pollute the marketplace" and divert business from honest competitors.

images.alt_text: A Meta spokesperson says the company removes false ads from its platforms when it learns about them and works with local authorities to battle scammers.

In what is widely billed as America’s first AI election in November, researchers warn that tech-enabled fakery could be used to steer voters toward or away from candidates - or even to avoid the polls altogether - stoking tensions in an already hyperpolarised environment.
The HDB Ethnic Integration Policy was introduced in 1989.
X owner Elon Musk’s repost appeared to violate X’s policies, which prohibit sharing “synthetic, manipulated or out-of-context media that may deceive or confuse people and lead to harm.”

site_title: Berkshire invests in Ulta Beauty, Heico as it retreats from Apple
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has invested in Ulta Beauty and aircraft parts maker Heico, marking a shift away from its large stake in Apple. Berkshire sold over $3.8 billion of Bank of America stock in the third quarter, nearly halving its stake in Apple. The investments in Ulta Beauty and Heico have led to a 14% and 3% surge in their shares, respectively. The moves reflect Berkshire's diversification strategy and its interest in the aerospace industry, according to Heico's co-president Eric Mendelson.

images.alt_text: In the wake of Berkshire’s sale, passive funds tracking these indexes may now have to buy as much as US$40 billion of Apple stock when they next rebalance.
Taipei-listed iPhone assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry and chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing slid about 10 per cent each.
Warren Buffett’s conglomerate still has an approximately 12.4 per cent stake in Bank of America, worth US$39.5 billion as of Monday’s close.
Berkshire lowered its stake in BYD’s issued H-shares to 4.94 per cent from 5.06 per cent on Jul 16.

site_title: Britain to trial use of drones in deliveries, emergency services
summary: Britain's Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has selected six projects, including Amazon's Prime Air, to test drone use in deliveries, inspection, and emergency services. The trials will allow drones to fly beyond the visual line of sight using advanced navigation and control technologies. The CAA aims to integrate drones safely into UK airspace, paving the way for "full integration" of drone flights with other airspace users. The trials are expected to help the regulator develop policy and regulations for drone operations beyond visual line of sight.

images.alt_text: China has already begun commercial deliveries by drone.

DJI Technology, a leading Chinese drone maker, told Reuters in a statement on Wednesday (Jul 31) it was pleased to see the export control adjustments, which it said would be favourable for the development of the drone industry.
Amazon is the latest company to gain approval from the FAA to fly drones more freely amid the proliferation of rapid delivery services.

site_title: Gold subdued as hopes for deeper Fed rate cut dim
summary: Gold prices were flat on Thursday, following a 1% drop in the previous session, as US data showed moderate inflation growth and a slowing annual inflation rate. The data lowered bets on a deeper rate cut from the Federal Reserve in September, with traders now seeing a 36% chance of a 50-basis-point rate cut. Spot gold remained nearly unchanged at $2,448.49 per ounce, while silver fell 0.4% to $27.49 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,465.27 per ounce.

site_title: China’s battle of the bonds has supply surge adding X factor
summary: China's bond market is seeing a surge in supply, driven by a report showing bank loans to the real economy contracted for the first time in 19 years, prompting traders to rush back into buying bonds. The government is expected to issue a doubling of bonds this month, with predictions ranging from 1.4 trillion to 1.8 trillion yuan. This comes as concerns over a slowing economy and record-low yields have driven yields to record lows, and policymakers' efforts to arrest the rally have had a fleeting effect.

images.alt_text: An electronic ticker displays stock figures in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024. The People's Bank of China is potentially getting the respite it’s been hoping for from global financial markets, bringing closer a dose of monetary stimulus long awaited by investors and traders. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Apple pushes ahead with tabletop home device in shift to robotics
summary: Apple is developing a pricey tabletop home device that combines an iPad-like display with a robotic limb, codenamed J595. The device, envisioned as a smart home command centre, videoconferencing machine, and remote-controlled home security tool, is part of a broader effort to boost sales and capitalize on Apple Intelligence, a suite of AI technology coming to the iPhone, iPad, and Mac this year. A team of several hundred people is working on the project, which was approved by Apple's executive team in 2022.

images.alt_text: Apple takes a cut of all payments made via the iPhone.
Tencent is exploring ways to offer in-app transactions via Apple’s iOS payment system.
Apple is weaving OpenAI’s ChatGPT capabilities into its software and expects to do the same with Google’s Gemini chatbot.

site_title: WHO declares mpox a global health emergency
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared the mpox surge in Africa a global public health emergency, the highest alarm level the organization can sound. The decision comes after the African Union's health watchdog also declared a public health emergency. The surge, which has already exceeded last year's total in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is primarily due to the clade 1b subclade, which causes more severe disease and a higher fatality rate. The WHO is coordinating a global response to prevent transmission, treat those infected, and save lives.

images.alt_text: A child being given the chickenpox vaccination. The vaccination protects against chickenpox for about 80 per cent of the time, and is very effective in protecting against severe chickenpox.
Observation of the virus has been spotty.

Ending the Ebola outbreak that emerged in December 2013 took more than two years and required a massive global humanitarian response, including the US military. By then, 28,652 cases and 11,325 deaths had been recorded.
WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus addresses during a press conference at the World Health Organization's headquarters in Geneva, on December 14, 2022. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
People pass by the Europa-Center shopping mall, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Berlin, Germany, December 14, 2020. REUTERS/Michele Tantussi/Files
New name suggestions for monkeypox range from terms that remove the monkey imagery to ones that are farcical, such as "Poxy McPoxface".

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening 8.67 points higher at 3,294.95. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 48, driven by positive US and European indices overnight. Key gainers included Genting Singapore, Seatrium, and Singtel, with Singtel posting a 42.9% increase in net profit to S$690 million. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also edged higher, while the Nasdaq increased marginally.

images.alt_text: Singtel's net profit increases following a net exceptional gain from the dilution of its effective equity shareholding in Airtel, among others.

site_title: Lenovo’s profit beats as AI demand drives a gradual PC recovery
summary: Lenovo reported a 38% increase in net income to $243 million in the June quarter, driven by growing demand for AI-powered servers. Revenue rose 20% to $15.4 billion, with the company shipping 14.7 million units. Lenovo's CEO, Yang Yuanqing, is betting on AI-powered devices to boost global business, but faces geopolitical risks, including possible new PC tariffs or chip-export restrictions. The company's stock has lagged behind rivals this year due to concerns about China's economy and exposure to tensions. Demand for AI-related PCs is expected to kick in from 2025.

images.alt_text: The company is the latest to join a rush in Asia to raise capital through convertible bonds.

site_title: Thailand’s Pheu Thai party to decide PM candidate as parliamentary vote looms
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai party is set to choose a new prime minister candidate ahead of a parliamentary vote on Friday, following the dismissal of former premier Srettha Thavisin. The party must choose between Chaikasem Nitisiri, a former attorney-general and justice minister, or Paetongtarn Shinawatra, the 37-year-old daughter of divisive politician Thaksin Shinawatra. The decision comes as the party seeks to shore up its alliance and deliver on its populist agenda amid an economic downturn.

images.alt_text: Srettha’s removal after less than a year in power means parliament must convene to choose a new premier, with the prospect of more uncertainty in a country dogged for two decades by coups and court rulings.

The influx of Chinese products has added to challenges facing Thailand’s stuttering economy with recorded growth of just 1.5 per cent in the first quarter and saw nearly 2,000 factory closures in the past year.

Pichai Chunhavajira, Thailand’s finance minister, speaks at a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Thailand unveiled detailed plans for a long-delayed distribution of cash to most adult citizens, the centerpiece of government efforts to revive growth and the fortunes of the ruling coalition. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

site_title: 💕 When love meets money
summary: A recent article in the THRIVE newsletter discusses the intersection of love and money, particularly for young adults. The article emphasizes the importance of financial literacy and provides advice on various financial topics, including investing in CPF, life insurance, and navigating the complexities of GenAI financial advisers. The article aims to empower Gen Z with the knowledge and skills needed to make informed financial decisions and achieve financial stability. By addressing common financial concerns, the article seeks to promote financial well-being among young adults.

images.alt_text: BT

site_title: New-home sales in July dive nearly 60% year on year in softer property market
summary: New-home sales in July plummeted 59.6% year-over-year to 571 units, the lowest recorded in the month since 2014. The suburban Outside Central Region led in condo and private apartment sales, accounting for 77.8% of sales. This marks a significant decline from the average of around 1,280 units sold in July over the past decade. The slowdown in the property market is attributed to homebuyers' selective and cautious behavior amid economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Condominiums along Alexandra Road at night on Feb 26, 2022.
Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Harris to focus on grocery costs, child tax credit in economic agenda, advisers say
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris's economic agenda will focus on lowering grocery, housing, and healthcare costs, bolstering the child tax credit, and contrasting with Republican Donald Trump on tariffs and taxes. Her platform closely mirrors that of President Joe Biden, but with a focus on middle-class issues. Harris will propose a federal law banning price gouging and increasing scrutiny on merger activity in the food and grocery industry. Her campaign aims to appeal to voters in battleground states, with less than 90 days until the presidential election.

images.alt_text: Walz has emerged as a powerful advocate of Harris, describing himself as the head of “White Dudes for Harris”, and as a critic of the Republicans, saying “these guys are just weird” – a comment that has become a popular Democratic line of attack.
