Kamala Harris has made big gains since replacing the president at the top of the ticket and naming running mate Tim Walz.
US Vice President Kamala Harris has clinched the Democratic presidential nomination and is enjoying a super-charged wave of popularity and donations.
The letter calls presidential candidate Kamala Harris an “archetypical innovator” and “champion of technology”.

site_title: China’s economy fails to pick up after worst stretch in five quarters
summary: China's economy failed to recover from its worst stretch in five quarters, with fixed-asset investment and consumption remaining weak. Industrial output rose 5.1% in July, but domestic demand remains insufficient, with the economy operating at a two-speeds model where manufacturing drives growth. Retail sales climbed 2.7% in July, but likely benefited from a favorable base and summer holiday season. The government's annual growth target of around 5% is at risk, and policymakers may need to consider additional policy stimulus to support the economy.

images.alt_text: China's new home prices fell 4.9 per cent from a year earlier, deeper than a 4.5 per cent slide in June, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data.
The PBOC in recent weeks began an overhaul that could allow it to operate more such as global peers and influence market borrowing costs more effectively.
The MOUs were signed at the 24th Singapore-Sichuan Trade and Investment Committee meeting on Aug 14.
CBDCs can cut transaction costs and time, bring financial services to the unbanked, and appeal to younger generations who prefer digital transactions.
Tencent is exploring ways to offer in-app transactions via Apple’s iOS payment system.

site_title: Australian bond yields hit 13-month low on bets RBA will break
summary: Australian bond yields fell to a 13-month low, dropping as much as five basis points to 3.88%, amid speculation the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is poised to cut interest rates. Despite the RBA's relatively hawkish stance, investors are betting on a rate cut due to slowing inflation and expectations of a US interest rate cut. The benchmark 10-year yield is now at its lowest level since July 2023, with investors watching the release of Australia's jobs report later Thursday for signs of a loosening labor market.

site_title: China’s home-price slump deepens in July to new 9-year low
summary: China's new home prices fell 4.9% from a year earlier in July, reaching a new 9-year low, according to National Bureau of Statistics data. This marks the 13th straight month of decline, with prices down 0.7% from June. Beijing's efforts to support the housing market, including reduced mortgage rates, have failed to stabilize the sector. The housing market downturn is seen as a hindrance to China's 5% GDP growth target for 2024, with analysts warning that the target may be too ambitious. Property sales by floor area also declined 18.6% from a year earlier.

site_title: PBOC delays one-year loan operation date amid policy overhaul
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has delayed the one-year loan operation date for its medium-term lending facility (MLF) funds to August 26 amid a policy overhaul. The delay comes as the bank aims to gradually de-link the MLF from benchmark lending rates. The PBOC provided 577.7 billion yuan in seven-day reverse repo to offset maturing MLF funds and other market liquidity factors. This move is part of a broader effort to improve the economy's faltering momentum and influence market borrowing costs more effectively.

images.alt_text: Growth in outstanding yuan loans slowed to 8.7 per cent compared with 8.8 per cent in June.
China’s sovereign debt has rallied this year as demand for haven assets has surged due to a sluggish economy and expectations of further rate cuts.
The People’s Bank of China governor Pan Gongsheng said a tighter band would signal a clearer policy target.
The securities watchdog has recently asked major mutual fund companies to cap the duration of their new bond funds to two years.

site_title: Indonesia’s new capital Nusantara set to face first major test
summary: Indonesia's new capital city, Nusantara, is set to face its first major test as construction delays and funding challenges force a scale-back of Independence Day celebrations. The city, located on the island of Borneo, is 95% complete, but infrastructure projects, including a VVIP airport, are still experiencing significant delays. The government has scaled back the guest list for Independence Day celebrations from 8,000 to 1,300, citing food and accommodation issues. President Joko Widodo has expressed confidence in completing the project by 2045, despite concerns about its sustainability.

images.alt_text: Indonesia president Joko Widodo begins to work in Nusantara capital on Monday (July 29).
Nusantara is not yet legally the nation’s capital until the president issues a decree transferring the status from Jakarta.
BT

site_title: Sri Trang Agro-Industry Q2 net profit rises 471.3% to 628.4 million baht
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry reported a 471.3% increase in Q2 net profit to 628.4 million baht, driven by a 77.1% rise in Ebitda to 2.2 billion baht. Revenue rose 21.6% to 25.8 billion baht, with the natural rubber segment accounting for 77.9% of total revenue. However, the company's net profit fell 24.9% to 298.7 million baht for the first half of the year due to higher finance costs. Heavy rainfall is expected to impact rubber tree health and potentially reduce natural rubber supply.

images.alt_text: The group's loss for the full financial year amounts to 434.4 million baht, which is a reversal from a net profit of 4.8 billion baht a year earlier.

site_title: Slowing global jet fuel consumption adds to oil demand concern
summary: Global jet fuel demand is expected to soften due to a slowdown in consumer spending, which could weigh on oil prices in the months ahead. Despite a nearly 500,000-barrel-per-day increase in jet fuel demand over the same period last year, Goldman Sachs estimates signal demand growth from August through October at only around 400,000 barrels per day. A cooling economy, reduced air travel, and improved fuel efficiency in newer aircraft are contributing to the decline in jet fuel demand.

images.alt_text: Benchmark Brent crude futures settled down US$1.61.

The IEA said the end of a post-Covid economic bounce in China was limiting global oil demand, but that advanced economies, notably the US, where one-third of global petrol is consumed, compensated for that loss.
Global benchmark Brent crude futures settled higher at US$82.30 a barrel on Monday, gaining US$2.64, or 3.3 per cent.
Opec in a monthly report said world oil demand will rise by 2.11 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2024, down from growth of 2.25 million bpd expected last month.

site_title: Singapore dollar rises to 18-month high amid tighter policy view
summary: The Singapore dollar rose 0.2% to 1.3154 per US dollar on August 14, its highest level since February 2023, due to forecasts of a tighter monetary policy from the Monetary Authority of Singapore compared to the Federal Reserve this year. The currency is expected to continue its upward trend as the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates as soon as September, reducing the appeal of the US dollar. The Singapore dollar is forecast to grow 2-3% this year, narrowing its earlier projection of 1-3%.

images.alt_text: The city-state’s stock market is also a big beneficiary of a strong local currency.
Moving into 2024, Asian currencies will likely be most affected by the US monetary policy and China’s growth.

site_title: Japan’s economy rebounds strongly in Q2 on consumption uptick
summary: Japan's economy expanded by 3.1% in the second quarter, exceeding expectations, driven by a solid increase in consumption. The growth reverses a 2.3% decline in the first quarter, with private consumption rising 1.0% and capital spending increasing 0.9%. The data supports the Bank of Japan's forecast of a sustainable inflation target of 2% and may lead to further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: News about Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's resignation flashed on public screens in Tokyo; August 14,  2024.
FILE PHOTO: Shigeru Ishiba, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Makiko Yamazaki/File Photo
Fumio Kishida’s decision to quit will trigger a contest to replace him as party boss, and by extension as the leader of the world’s fourth-biggest economy.

Currency markets have been rocked by a sharp rally in the yen since July that has prompted – and been driven by – an unwinding of a highly popular investment strategy called the carry trade and contributed to a slide in stocks.
Markets are waiting for data due this week on Japanese second-quarter economic growth and US inflation.
Inflation data will be scrutinised by the central bank, which raised interest rates on Jul 31 to levels unseen in 15 years and signalled its readiness to hike borrowing costs further.

site_title: Wally Amos, creator of Famous Amos cookies, dies at 88
summary: Wally Amos, creator of Famous Amos cookies, died at 88 due to complications of dementia. Amos, an entrepreneur, started the company with a $25,000 loan in 1975, using real ingredients and no preservatives. Famous Amos became a household name, with dozens of stores and packaged products, but Amos struggled to keep profits as the company expanded. He sold off equity stakes and eventually left the company, but continued to work as an author, speaker, and advocate for childhood literacy. Amos' legacy includes his emphasis on quality and his rags-to-riches story.

images.alt_text: Jollibee expects to add 750 to 820 stores this year given the consolidation of South Korea’s Compose Coffee which it acquired in July.

Sudeep Nair, group chief executive of Food Empire, said: “We are very excited about the performance of our South-east Asia and South Asia segments, which have maintained a strong growth trajectory due to the successful execution of our business strategies.”
Snack chain Old Chang Kee has outlets in Malaysia, Indonesia, Australia and Britain.
The company does not have a standing practice of declaring interim dividends, says Yeo Hiap Seng.

site_title: Apple to open payment chip to third parties and charge fees
summary: Apple is opening its payment chip to third-party developers, allowing banks and services to compete with Apple Pay. The move, announced on August 14, will enable developers to use the NFC chip for in-store payments and other transactions starting with iOS 18.1. Users can set a third-party payment app as their default, and Apple will charge associated fees to developers. The change, following EU pressure, aims to ensure only authorized developers meet security and regulatory requirements, while still threatening Apple's revenue from Apple Pay transactions.

images.alt_text: Tencent is exploring ways to offer in-app transactions via Apple’s iOS payment system.

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves Q2 profit surges more than 20 times to 378.4 million baht
summary: Sri Trang Gloves, a Thai glove manufacturer, reported a 20-fold increase in Q2 earnings to 378.4 million baht (S$14.2 million) due to rising revenue and demand for gloves. Revenue rose 13.9% to 5.7 billion baht, driven by sales of latex-powdered and nitrile gloves. Despite higher raw material costs, gross profit increased 48.3% to 773.6 million baht. The company aims to continue cost-saving initiatives and achieve economies of scale to improve efficiency and create higher profits.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Sri Trang Gloves ready for the next pandemic
Among glove makers, Riverstone has most attractive margins
Sri Trang Gloves sees tepid net profit growth amid increased supply

site_title: RBNZ aims to lower cash rate at measured pace, governor says
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) aims to lower interest rates at a measured pace to return to a neutral setting, with the goal of anchoring inflation expectations at 2% by mid-2027. The central bank cut the Official Cash Rate by a quarter-percentage point to 5.25% and forecasts it will decline to 3% by mid-2027, which is considered around the neutral rate. This move is seen as a response to the economy's current recession, with inflation expected to return to the 1-3% target range in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) building in Wellington, New Zealand, on Thursday, August 9, 2018. Photographer: Birgit Krippner/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil prices settle 1% lower after surprise rise in US crude stockpiles
summary: Oil prices settled 1% lower on Wednesday, closing at US$79.76 a barrel, after US crude inventories rose unexpectedly and as concerns about a wider Middle East conflict eased. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.8% to US$76.98 per barrel. The rise in US crude inventories, after six straight weeks of draws, weighed on prices. Geopolitical tensions and demand woes, including a slowdown in China's economy and jet fuel demand, also contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: CAO noted that its strong performance reflected the “continued robust recovery” in global air travel, citing a report that showed total air passenger traffic in 2024 had surpassed pre-pandemic levels.
Benchmark Brent crude futures settled down US$1.61.

site_title: Nasa still deciding if ISS astronauts can go home this year
summary: NASA officials are deciding whether two US astronauts, Barry "Butch" Wilmore and Sunita "Suni" Williams, can return home this year due to issues with Boeing's Starliner capsule. The agency expects to make a final decision by the end of next week or early the week of August 26. The astronauts have been living on the ISS since June 6, and NASA is working with SpaceX to plan an alternative return in February 2025 if the Starliner is not ready. The agency must make a decision by the end of August due to resource constraints and space station traffic.

images.alt_text: The crew of US astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, have lifted off on Jun 5 as a final demonstration to obtain routine flight certification from Nasa.
Williams and Wilmore, who are joining seven other people currently on board the space station, will stay for about a week.

site_title: Hong Kong's CK Infrastructure applies for UK listing
summary: CK Infrastructure Holdings, a part of the CK Hutchison conglomerate, has applied for a secondary listing on the London Stock Exchange (LSE). The company expects its admission to occur on August 19. This move aims to benefit its geographically diverse shareholder base and enhance the company's profile, as the UK is its largest market, accounting for 36% of its earnings in 2023.

site_title: Meta shuts down CrowdTangle, tool used for tracking online misinformation
summary: Meta has shut down CrowdTangle, a tool used to track online misinformation, amid relaxed content moderation policies and information integrity efforts. The shutdown comes months ahead of a major US presidential election, drawing concern from groups that relied on the tool to monitor trending posts and track the spread of false information. Meta cited the tool's maintenance challenges and lack of a representative platform picture as reasons for the shutdown, despite a bipartisan lawmaker letter requesting a six-month delay.

images.alt_text: A Meta spokesperson says the company removes false ads from its platforms when it learns about them and works with local authorities to battle scammers.
The renewed agreement also addresses the issue of compensation for artists and songwriters, Universal Music Group said.
Issuing bonds now gives firms like Meta increased financial flexibility even if they have large sums of cash on its balance sheet.

site_title: Singapore, Sichuan companies ink five MOUs as bilateral trade grows
summary: Singapore and Sichuan, China's western province, have signed five memorandums of understanding (MOUs) to boost bilateral trade. The agreements cover sectors such as utilities, healthcare, and commodities trading, and include initiatives like a smart medical consultation system and an integrated energy management project. Total trade between the two regions grew 15% year-on-year in the first half of 2024, while Singapore's investments in Sichuan increased 7.9%. The move aims to establish a strong foundation for green trade and leverage each other's strengths in research and development collaborations.

images.alt_text: Tai Er is a sauerkraut fish brand that owns six restaurants in Singapore, including one at 313@somerset.

site_title: JPMorgan is selling a new type of mortgage credit risk transfer
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to sell a $531 million portfolio of adjustable-rate mortgages through a new type of credit risk transfer, removing the assets from its balance sheet. The deal, called a "deconsolidated portfolio risk transfer," will issue bonds tied to the riskiest portions of the loans while keeping the remainder. Fitch and Morningstar DBRS assigned preliminary ratings ranging from AAA to B- to the bonds, and the bank has described the deal as "inaugural." This is part of the industry's efforts to de-risk balance sheets and comply with stricter capital rules.

site_title: Unloved Hong Kong luxury tower spawns wildly popular debt deal
summary: Hong Kong's luxury tower, The Corniche, was expected to generate HK$30 billion in sales but remained largely empty due to luxury prices and a property market meltdown. To avoid default, developers Logan Group and KWG Group Holdings secured a US$1.05 billion private loan with an 13% interest rate, nearly twice the original 7% rate. The loan was secured by the complex's cash waterfall and attracted investors due to its transparency and clear return calculations. The deal marked one of Hong Kong's largest-ever private credit deals, with major players including Davidson Kempner Capital Management and Pacific Investment Management.

images.alt_text: The refinancing plan will pave a path forward for Logan to restructure its US$8 billion of offshore debt.
China is seeing a fundamental shift in buyer preference, with existing home sales overtaking new homes by area for the first time ever last year.
Top-tier Chinese cities, namely Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen, have eased homebuying requirements for downpayments and mortgages this year to revive demand.

A new residential property development in Wuhan, China, on Wednesday, March 15, 2024. Chinese officials on Friday, May 17, 2024, took their boldest step yet, unveiling a nationwide plan to buy up some of the vast housing stock languishing on the market. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

site_title: Cisco gives upbeat sales forecast even as it cuts jobs
summary: Cisco Systems announced a bullish revenue forecast for the current period, with sales expected to be $13.7 billion to $13.9 billion in the fiscal first quarter, beating analyst estimates. Despite this, the company plans to cut approximately 6,300 jobs, or 7% of its workforce, as part of a strategy shift to focus on networking services and software. The job cuts will help the company save money and invest in growth opportunities, with pretax charges expected to reach up to $1 billion.

images.alt_text: The number of people affected could be similar to or slightly higher than the 4,000 employees Cisco laid off in February, and will likely be announced as early as Aug 14 with the company’s fourth-quarter results.
Foundation AI models are built using huge volumes of data and can be applied across a wide range of use cases.
Cisco’s revenue has fallen for two straight quarters now, as it deals with an inventory backlog.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Genting Singapore, ComfortDelGro, Haw Par, StarHub, Wing Tai
summary: Singapore stocks saw positive developments this week, with Singtel posting a 42.9% increase in net profit to S$690 million for the first quarter, driven by a net exceptional gain from the dilution of its effective equity shareholding in Airtel. Genting Singapore reported a 29% increase in profit for the first half of the year to S$356.9 million. Other companies, including ComfortDelGro, Haw Par, and StarHub, also reported positive earnings growth. However, Wing Tai Holdings warned of a potential loss for its Hong Kong associate, and China Aviation Oil's net profit for the first half ended June 30 surged 114.8% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Offshoring is always an option because of the high cost in Singapore, although UOB is also mindful of the quality of labour supply, said CFO Lee Wai Fai.

site_title: Blinken, Qatar PM warn all sides not to ‘undermine’ Gaza truce talks: US
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Qatar's Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al-Thani warned all parties not to undermine Gaza ceasefire talks, in a call that emphasized the importance of reaching a deal. The two leaders discussed efforts to calm tensions in the region and finalize a ceasefire in Gaza. The US State Department stated that "no party in the region should take actions that would undermine efforts to reach a deal."

images.alt_text: Doubts over the possibility of securing an Israel-Hamas ceasefire grow. There is also the looming possibility of a wider regional war.
Fitch maintained Israel’s outlook at “negative” and forecast the country’s debt to “remain on an upward trend beyond 2025” if higher military spending and economic uncertainties continue.

Abbas Araqchi, 61, who was Iran’s ambassador to several countries, including Japan, played a key role in negotiating Teheran’s 2015 nuclear agreement with six world powers, which then-US president Donald Trump exited in 2018 and re-imposed sanctions on Iran.
The US State Department intends to disburse US$3.5 billion in new military aid to Israel.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 climbs as upbeat earnings buoy travel and leisure, financial stocks
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by travel and leisure, and financial stocks, as investors drew comfort from moderating US inflation. US consumer prices rebounded in July, supporting an early rate-cut narrative, with the Federal Reserve expected to cut interest rates soon. The travel and leisure sub-index gained 3%, lifted by Flutter's surge, while Swiss bank UBS and German insurer Talanx also posted strong earnings.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, August 12, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Wing Tai warns half-year loss at associate could more than treble to HK$1.4 billion
summary: Wing Tai Holdings' associate Wing Tai Properties is expected to report a loss of HK$1.3 billion to HK$1.4 billion for the six months to Jun 30, 2024, due to fair value changes and impairments for overseas properties. This would widen the loss to HK$374.2 million reported in the year-ago period. Despite this, Wing Tai Properties' overall financial position remains healthy, with a low net gearing ratio of approximately 0.07.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s office vacancy rate hit a historic high of 16.9 per cent in the first half of the year, while rental prices are expected to fall as much as 10 per cent in 2024.
CMG20240610-HoPY01/何炳耀/Stock photo: Generic pic of Hong Kong. [Hong Kong] . Photos taken on 4/6/2024. Caption: 太平山頂,山頂, 旅客. The Peak, Victoria Peak

site_title: Goldman agrees to sell Ireland’s largest shopping mall to SVP
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to sell Ireland's largest shopping mall, the Blanchardstown Centre, to Strategic Value Partners (SVP) for a lower price than initially sought, reportedly around 650 million euros. The 180-store mall attracts 16 million visitors annually and has seen a decline in rents, making it more attractive to investors. The sale comes as the retail sector experiences a recovery, driven by rising consumer spending in Dublin and declining capital values for prime shopping centers in Europe. The deal marks a shift for Goldman Sachs, which acquired the mall in 2020.

images.alt_text: The Goldman Sachs & Co. logo is displayed at the company's booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 19, 2013. U.S. stocks fell after benchmark equities gauges rose to records yesterday, after disappointing earnings from Google Inc. and Microsoft Corp. overshadowed better-than-forecast results from General Electric Co. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

site_title: Gen Z voters oppose social media limits, new study finds
summary: A recent study by non-profit Helena found that 60% of Gen Z voters oppose requiring parental consent for social media use under 16, and 85% think there should be no time limits on social media notifications. Despite knowing the potential harms of social media, Gen Z voters are not in favor of government restrictions on social media use. The study, which polled 430 first-time voters, suggests that young people may be resistant to regulations due to concerns about influencing their own decisions and the potential for "weird precedent" to be set.

images.alt_text: The Anthem of the Seas ship arrives at the Barcelona Cruise Terminal of the Port of Barcelona in Barcelona, Spain, on Saturday, July 27, 2024. Barcelona plans to enact a citywide ban on all short-term rentals to address complaints that tourism is to blame for a local housing crisis and soaring rents. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
The move is an acknowledgement that the traditional media outlets, which are offering wall-to-wall coverage of the summit, may not be reaching Generation Z.
Younger Australians are often stuck in insecure work and face soaring costs of rental accommodation, leaving them in a precarious financial position

site_title: Nike rises after Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square discloses stake
summary: Nike shares rose 5.5% in late trading after Pershing Square Capital Management disclosed a new stake in the company, worth $229 million. The investment firm, led by Bill Ackman, has previously made a $100 million profit from a passive stake in Nike in 2018. Ackman has stated he will adopt a "quieter approach" with management, sparking questions about potential activist involvement. Nike's sales slump has raised concerns, and the company's board is controlled by Nike co-founder Phil Knight, who owns nearly all voting shares.

images.alt_text: NIke Photographer: Nicole Tung/Bloomberg

site_title: Yanlord Land Group sinks into the red with 486 million yuan H1 loss on write down
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a loss of 486 million yuan (S$89.3 million) for the first half of the year, despite a 34.8% increase in revenue to 20 billion yuan. The loss was attributed to a write-down of 729.6 million yuan for completed properties and an increase in net impairment losses. The group delivered several projects, including Poetic Villa in Shanghai, Star Century in Tianjin, and Yanlord on the Park in Shenyang, which accounted for 90.4% of revenue. The company's gross profit decreased by 37% to 2.6 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: Nanjing Yanlord Landmark 南京仁恒置地广场

site_title: US: Stocks close higher after more evidence of cooling inflation
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.6% to 40,008.39 and the S&P 500 gaining 0.4% to 5,455.21, following evidence of cooling consumer inflation. The consumer price index (CPI) eased to its lowest level since March 2021, bolstering the chances of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September. The news also sparked a 4.5% gain for Mars's share price and a 7.8% rise for Kellanova's, while Alphabet fell 2.4% and Tesla dropped 3.1%.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 06: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 06, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up slightly up in the three major indexes a day after the Dow Jones and the S & P 500 had their worst day of trading since 2022, amid a global market sell-off centered around fears of a U.S. recession.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Why presidents should keep their hands off the Fed
summary: US President Kamala Harris has stated her opposition to President Donald Trump's suggestion that the president should have a say in the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, citing the Fed's independence as crucial for avoiding hyperinflation and ensuring the stability of the economy. Historically, central banks have been treated like ordinary government agencies, but most wealthy nations have independent central banks to prevent politicians from abusing monetary policy. The Fed's independence allows it to make swift and simple policy decisions without needing to go through Congress, but this also means it can be subject to political pressure and manipulation.

images.alt_text: Vice-President Kamala Harris’s view contrasts sharply with that of Donald Trump, who has said that US presidents should have a say over the Fed’s decisions.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signalled last week that the first interest rate cut could come “as soon as” September but some analysts fear that may not be soon enough, as the markets have responded in dramatic fashion to last week’s below-target US jobs report, which raised fears that the US was entering a recession.

site_title: Affordability, financing now top concerns for homebuyers: ERA survey
summary: A survey by ERA found that affordability and financing concerns are top priorities for homebuyers in Singapore, with 61% of respondents agreeing that HDB Build-To-Order flats remain affordable. Concerns about home prices, loan security, and interest rates also prevail, leading to a softening in new home sales in the first six months of 2024. Expected rate cuts by the Federal Reserve may spur homebuying if financing terms ease, but current challenges and elevated interest rates are affecting buyers' aspirations, with 34% aiming to buy a BTO or resale flat.

images.alt_text: Will there be more refinements to Singapore's world class public housing at this year's NDR?

site_title: Frencken posts 50.3% rise in H1 profit to S$18.1 million
summary: Frencken, a semiconductor player, reported a 50.3% increase in H1 profit to S$18.1 million, driven by a 6.2% rise in revenue to S$372.7 million. The increase was mainly attributed to the mechatronics division, which saw a 7.9% rise in revenue. The IMS division saw a 4.3% decline in revenue due to a slowdown in orders from a key customer. Despite geopolitical tensions, Frencken guides for higher revenues in H2 2024 and continues to monitor the business environment.

images.alt_text: Based on current indicators and barring unforeseen circumstances, Frencken expects its revenue in H1 2024 to be comparable to H2 2023
Semiconductor companies in Singapore supply equipment makers instead of foundries, which could limit any impact from disruptions caused by the Taiwan earthquake.
Semiconductor producer Frencken Group's H2 2023 net profit shows a recovery from the first half, while challenges loom amid the global tech downturn.

site_title: Citigroup lifts pre-Brexit cap on top London bankers’ bonuses
summary: Citigroup is lifting its pre-Brexit cap on top London bankers' bonuses, allowing them to earn up to six times their base salary. The change, similar to rivals JPMorgan and Barclays, aims to make the bank more attractive to talent and encourage desired behaviors. The move follows the UK's removal of the cap in 2023 and is part of Citigroup's effort to offer competitive pay and remain a major player in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Bankers who help companies sell debt may see payouts swell as much as 35 per cent, as deals pick up and capital markets rebound from multiyear lows.
The change will allow Barclays’ so-called material risk takers to now earn a bonus that’s as much as 10 times their base salary.
The clawback amounts to less than 10 per cent of bonuses at China Everbright, the main Hong Kong-listed arm of Everbright Group.
Morgan Stanley said in a regulatory filing that it was replacing the current limit that restricts certain employees’ bonuses to two times their fixed pay with “an appropriate internal bonus cap.”
UBS has targeted growing private banking assets to more than US$5 trillion after buying Credit Suisse last year.

site_title: Tencent in talks with Apple about mini games mobile revenue
summary: Tencent is in talks with Apple to offer in-app transactions via the iOS payment system, potentially allowing Apple to take a cut of WeChat mini game revenue. The discussions aim to make in-game transactions available on iOS in a way that benefits developers, users, Apple, and Tencent. The move comes after Apple pressured Tencent and ByteDance to close loopholes in their in-app payment systems. If the talks are successful, Tencent's WeChat mini games could generate new revenue streams for the company, with gross receipts increasing over 30% in the second quarter.

site_title: Yoma says new directors have ‘sufficient time and bandwidth’ to fulfil responsibilities
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Singapore-listed conglomerate, has confirmed that its new directors, Alberto Macapinlac de Larrazabal and Cyrus Pun, have sufficient time and bandwidth to fulfill their responsibilities. Following Serge Pun's July departure as executive chairman, his son Melvyn Pun took over the role. The company's board changes were announced on August 9, and the new directors have made significant contributions at board meetings.

images.alt_text: Executive chairman Serge Pun's meetings with authorities has no impact on the group's financials, says Yoma.
Executive chairman Serge Pun has been meeting and cooperating with relevant authorities, says Yoma Strategic.
Yoma's trading volumes are higher than usual on Thursday.

site_title: Hotels going green
summary: Singapore hotels are stepping up their sustainability efforts, incorporating energy conservation, food waste reduction, and technology changes to cater to eco-conscious travelers. Hotels like Pan Pacific Orchard and Grand Hyatt have implemented sustainability into their DNA, improving operational efficiency. These hotels leverage design and infrastructural changes to reduce their environmental impact. This shift towards sustainability aims to appeal to a growing breed of environmentally aware travelers, while also improving operational efficiency.

site_title: Dollar pares losses after US inflation data
summary: The US dollar index recovered from losses, closing at 102.59, down 0.04% from the previous day, after inflation data showed a decline, reducing expectations of a large rate cut. The dollar had eased against major currencies ahead of the data release. The decision was largely attributed to the subsiding inflation rate, which did little to support rate cut expectations.

images.alt_text: Currency markets have been rocked by a sharp rally in the yen since July that has prompted – and been driven by – an unwinding of a highly popular investment strategy called the carry trade and contributed to a slide in stocks.

site_title: Taiwan’s artificial-intelligence fundraising survives market maelstrom
summary: Taiwanese companies have raised US$1.3 billion in convertible bonds so far in 2024, surpassing the annual total of the last two years. This surge in funding is attributed to the popularity of hybrid securities and demand for artificial intelligence investments. Quanta Computer, a major supplier to Apple, is set to raise up to US$1 billion through a convertible note offering, which will be used to buy raw materials. Despite recent market volatility, companies expect to access the markets to fund growth.

images.alt_text: Worries about the global economic outlook over the past week interrupted the AI rally that had seen key players such as TSMC gain billions in market value.
FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang
Taiwan’s export recovery was thanks to “strong business opportunities in new technology applications” such as AI and high performance computing.
Taiwan's GDP grew 6.51 per cent year on year to NT$5.46 trillion (S$22.82 billion) in the first quarter.
FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as CPI report cements rate-cut bets
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, August 14, 2024, as the CPI report showed inflation was moderating as expected, confirming bets for a Federal Reserve policy-easing cycle next month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 34.9 points, or 0.09%, to 39,800.59, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with gains of 7.9 and 40.0 points, respectively. The positive market trend was driven by the expectation of a rate cut, which has been a long-held bet among investors.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 06: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 06, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up slightly up in the three major indexes a day after the Dow Jones and the S & P 500 had their worst day of trading since 2022, amid a global market sell-off centered around fears of a U.S. recession.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Haw Par’s H1 2024 net profit rose 17.1 per cent to S$122 million
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 17.1% increase in H1 2024 net profit to S$122 million, driven by strong demand for healthcare products. Revenue rose 6.3% to S$118.1 million, despite higher costs of sales. The company forecasts costs pressures to weigh down operating margins in the next 12 months. A S$0.20 dividend per share was declared, and shares closed up 0.6% on the announcement.

images.alt_text: Although Haw Par Corp’s healthcare products make up its largest segment, it could also turn to its other businesses to rev up growth – a move similar to what its Hong Kong-listed peer has done.
Tiger Balm’s maker Haw Par Corporation reports a net profit of S$112.4 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, a 58.1 per cent increase from the corresponding year-ago period.

site_title: S$3b money laundering case: 2 ex-bank employees and former driver of fugitive to be charged in court
summary: Singapore's largest money laundering probe resulted in the seizure of approximately $3 billion in cash and assets, with prohibition of disposal orders issued. Two former bank employees and the former driver of fugitive businessman Su Binghai will be charged in court on August 15 over money laundering and forgery offences. Su Binghai, who fled amid the probe, is currently wanted for his involvement in alleged money laundering offences. The charges mark the culmination of a one-year investigation that involved 400 police officers raiding multiple luxury homes.

images.alt_text: The Bill will introduce several proposals to improve the processes involved in dealing with seized properties including those linked to money laundering.
Singapore did not consult Cambodian authorities before deporting convicted money launderer
MAS has been working to reduce the processing time for its tax incentive scheme in Singapore, with wait times expected to return to three months by the beginning of next year.
Su Binghai's home in Jalan Asuhan features a KTV lounge, arcade game machines, a dedicated massage room, and 10 large safes.
Industry watchers expect the move by MAS to standardise and fill up the gaps of compliance systems across different financial institutions.

site_title: Drugmaker AstraZeneca’s market value soars past £200 billion
summary: AstraZeneca's market value surpassed £200 billion for the first time, driven by a rally in shares following a big bet on cancer drugs. The UK's most valuable listed company has kept a lead over Shell since April and ranks seventh in Europe by market value in US dollar terms. Shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday, extending a 22% advance this year.

site_title: London house prices post first annual rise in more than a year
summary: London's house prices rose 0.6% in June, the fastest growth since May 2023, with average prices reaching £523,000 (S$883,656). The market is recovering after suffering declines following higher interest rates, with economists expecting further gains after the Bank of England cut interest rates. Prices in London are still 3.5% below their peak, but experts predict a 3% increase in 2024.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in view of the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district skyline in London, UK, on Monday, May 27, 2024. The UK's chronic housing shortage has become a key battleground between the ruling Conservative Party and the opposition Labour Party ahead of the general election. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: US mortgage refinancing surges by most since 2020 on lower rates
summary: US mortgage refinancing surged 34.5% last week, reaching a two-year high of 889.3, as borrowing costs continued to fall. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate eased to 6.54% and the 15-year fixed mortgage rate dropped to 5.96%, the lowest since May 2023. Mortgage applications to purchase a home climbed 2.8% in the week ended Aug 9, the largest advance since June. Despite rising housing prices, investors expect the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates at its September meeting.

images.alt_text: Prices for existing single-family houses in the San Jose-Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area rose 11.6 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier to US$2.08 million.
Housing has been one of the main contributors to post-pandemic inflation, and further improvement in rental supply should help bring headline rates lower.
The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped 27 basis points in the week ended Aug 2, to 6.55 per cent, the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) said.
The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was five basis points lower than a week earlier when it averaged 6.78 per cent, mortgage finance giant Freddie Mac said.
Entry level buyers depend on their personal savings and incomes, which haven’t kept up with inflation.
New home sales in June came in at an annual, seasonally-adjusted, revised rate of 617,000.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage slipped five basis points to 6.82 per cent in the week ended Jul 19.
The slowdown came as prices reached another record in June, with the median sales price up 4.1 per cent to US$426,900.
Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, fell 2.2 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 980,000 units last month, the lowest level since last October.

site_title: North Korea to open borders to tourism in first since pandemic
summary: North Korea plans to open its borders to general tourism for the first time in nearly five years, allowing foreign visitors from various countries to travel to the country. The initial tours will be in Samjiyon, near the border with China, starting in December 2024. The move is seen as a step towards easing pandemic border restrictions, which were put in place at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. North Korean authorities will closely monitor visitors, who will be restricted in their movements and stay at designated lodgings.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Foreign tourists take photos of the city skyline from the viewing deck at Juche Tower in Pyongyang, North Korea, September 11, 2018. Picture taken September 11, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 14)
summary: UOB plans to move some back and middle-office functions to Malaysia to maintain its cost-to-income ratio at 40% by 2026. The group aims to serve around 10 million retail customers in the region. Meanwhile, over 12,000 households have taken up the HDB's Lease Buyback Scheme, with nearly 90% receiving between S$100,000 and S$300,000. Several companies also reported positive earnings, including CDL, ST Engineering, and Wilmar, which contributed to Singapore stocks closing higher.

site_title: US consumer prices increase as expected in July
summary: US consumer prices increased 0.2% in July, following a 0.1% decline in June, as inflation moderates and borrowing costs cool demand. Annual consumer price growth has slowed to 2.9% from a peak of 9.1% in June 2022. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates next month, with economists predicting a 25-50 basis point reduction. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.2% and 3.2% year-over-year, the smallest increase since April 2021.

images.alt_text: General view of metal cutting machines inside Gent Machine Co.'s 55-employee factory in Cleveland, Ohio, U.S., May 26, 2021. REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel
Many manufacturers handle dangerous materials and operate heavy machinery that can cause accidents and fires, which has always meant paying hefty premiums.

site_title: Low-carbon hydrogen: Timely for Singapore to deepen research
summary: Singapore is deepening its research on low-carbon hydrogen as an energy source, with the Energy Market Authority calling for a study on developing laws and policies related to hydrogen fuel. The goal is to supply up to half of Singapore's power needs by 2050, reducing carbon emissions and diversifying the city-state's power sources. However, balancing costs with emissions remains a challenge, with grey hydrogen being more cost-competitive but releasing substantial carbon emissions, while green hydrogen is cleaner but more expensive. New breakthroughs in solar and wind power, as well as technological innovation, could improve the economics of hydrogen fuel, making it a viable option for Singapore's energy future.

images.alt_text: Employees of German technology company Bosch work on a hydrogen-powered fuel-cell module. There's a gold rush brewing in green hydrogen.
Vopak owns and operates Singapore’s only ammonia tank currently. The tank is situated at its Banyan terminal, the biggest of the three terminals it operates on Jurong Island.
In the longer term, renewable hydrogen from the project could be directly supplied to help lower industrial emissions in the region as customer demand evolves, Shell said.

site_title: Uruguay's Fede Alvarez returns Alien saga to roots with Romulus
summary: Uruguay's Fede Alvarez returns the Alien saga to its horror roots with Romulus, the latest installment in the franchise. The film, set in the 1970s, follows a group of space travelers as they discover the existence of deadly xenomorphs. Alvarez, who previously directed Evil Dead and Don't Breathe, aims to recreate the gore and horror of the original 1979 film, directed by Ridley Scott. With a focus on practical effects and a nostalgic visual style, Romulus promises to bring back the franchise's intense atmosphere and suspense.

images.alt_text: Disney is forging ahead with the ambitious plans despite a slowdown in its parks business tied to weaker consumer trends.

Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.

site_title: China should seriously consider a 2% inflation target
summary: China is being urged to consider adopting a 2% inflation target, a concept that has been used in other countries such as New Zealand, the UK, and Australia. This target aims to add predictability to policy and encourage households and businesses to adjust their behavior accordingly. However, China's current problem is not too much inflation, but rather broad deflationary forces that persist. The country's central bank, the PBOC, has been criticized for not acting sooner to address the issue. While the idea of a target may be seen as Western, it has merit and could help tackle the risk of deflation and stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders already signalled a more supportive stance towards growth at a recent Politburo meeting by vowing to shift their focus to consumption.
The People’s Bank of China governor Pan Gongsheng said a tighter band would signal a clearer policy target.

site_title: Some eurozone banks too optimistic in valuing commercial property, ECB finds
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has found that some eurozone banks may be overvaluing commercial property, potentially masking a deterioration in loans to the sector. Commercial property prices have plummeted nearly a tenth last year due to higher borrowing costs and weak demand. The ECB's inspection found that banks are using outdated valuations, basing them on transaction data from 2021 or earlier, and are not accurately reflecting the current market downturn. This may lead to borrowers facing debt servicing challenges.

images.alt_text: Commercial real estate valuations, in decline for two years, rose 0.4 per cent from the first three months of this year, suggesting that the market was “calming down”.
Despite the tough conditions, LaSalle is targeting growing its overall property acquisitions in Europe to US$2 billion in 2024, up from US$1.8 billion last year.

site_title: Bank of England scrutinising lenders’ prime brokerage risks
summary: The Bank of England is conducting a review of lenders' prime brokerage businesses, examining the disclosure of risks and information provided by hedge fund clients. Regulators are also reviewing rates and commodities businesses. The review, which began six weeks ago, follows earlier reviews after major market events, including the Archegos Capital Management collapse and the 2022 market turmoil. The central bank aims to assess the risks and vulnerabilities in the global financial system, particularly in relation to leverage given to non-bank clients.

images.alt_text: Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.

site_title: iPhone maker Hon Hai beats profit estimates thanks to AI boom
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the maker of iPhones, reported a profit of NT$35 billion (S$1.4 billion) in the second quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's revenue surged 19% to NT$1.55 trillion, driven by strong demand for AI servers powering applications. Hon Hai aims to secure 40% of the global AI server market, leveraging its partnerships with tech companies and manufacturing expertise. The company's shares have risen 80% this year, fueled by its AI pitch, and is expected to drive growth with AI servers.

site_title: US backs global target to reduce plastic production
summary: The US has shifted its stance on a global plastic treaty, supporting a reduction in new plastic production each year, in contrast to countries like Saudi Arabia and China. This move aligns the US with high-ambition countries like the EU, South Korea, Canada, and Peru, which aim to cap and phase down plastic production. The US now supports a global list of chemicals to phase out and criteria to identify "avoidable plastic products" to phase out, amid concerns that ongoing divisions over treaty scope may hinder negotiations.

site_title: US junk debt investors cautious of leveraged loans as economy slows
summary: US junk debt investors are cautious about leveraged loans as the economy slows, with only six deals worth $3.3 billion sold last week, short of the $10 billion weekly average this year. The disappointing jobs data and concerns about aggressive interest rate cuts have led to a decline in investor demand, resulting in $3.1 billion in outflows from leveraged loan funds last week. Experts predict a pickup in primary issuance in both markets, but further signs of an economic slowdown could be detrimental to certain leveraged borrowers' refinancing or new loan plans.

The National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) said on Tuesday (Aug 13) its Small Business Optimism Index rose 2.2 points to 93.7 last month, the highest reading since February 2022.
US consumers’ delinquency fears rise to highest level since 2020.

site_title: Far East Orchard H1 profit more than doubles to S$18.2 million on student housing segment growth
summary: Far East Orchard's first-half net profit more than doubled to S$18.2 million, driven by 22.8% growth in its purpose-built student housing accommodation (PBSA) segment. Revenue rose 7.1% to S$97.3 million, with the hospitality business segment contributing S$62.4 million. The group remains cautiously optimistic about the mid-term outlook of international travel demand, despite volatile macroeconomic climate and mounting geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Far East Orchard chief executive Alan Tang said the global economy presents challenges such as higher-for-longer interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia central bank imposes penalties on 4 banks over service disruptions
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has imposed penalties on four banks for prolonged disruptions to their banking services. CIMB Bank and CIMB Islamic Bank were fined RM760,000, while Malayan Banking and Maybank Islamic were fined RM4.3 million. The penalties were imposed under the Financial Services Act 2013 and Islamic Financial Services Act 2013, following disruptions to e-banking channels on July 29.

site_title: Tencent sales growth sped up after blockbuster game release
summary: Tencent Holdings reported an 8% revenue growth to 161.1 billion yuan (S$29.7 billion) for the April-to-June period, surpassing projections. The company's core gaming arm rebounded from two consecutive quarters of decline, while its fintech and cloud services division grew 4%. Net income surged 82% to 47.6 billion yuan. The strong earnings report lifted shares in Tencent and its major backer Naspers, amid a volatile Chinese economy. Executives will face questions about artificial intelligence investments and plans for shareholder returns.

images.alt_text: Large Chinese tech companies have conspicuously turned to buybacks this year to enhance shareholder return given their lacklustre sales growth.
Tencent Music said revenue fell 1.7 per cent to 7.16 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) in the three months ended Jun 30.
Tencent’s advertising, fintech and business services operations are sensitive to deteriorating economic growth.
The Information earlier reported that Moonshot was seeking investments at a pre-money valuation of US$3 billion and had held talks with Tencent.
GMM Music boosted its valuation to about US$700 million after selling a 10 per cent stake to China’s Tencent.

site_title: Singapore stocks close in the black; STI up 0.9%, led by Wilmar
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,286.28, led by Wilmar International's 2.7% gain after reporting a 5.2% year-on-year increase in first-half net profit to US$579.6 million. ST Engineering also rose 2.1% after posting a 19.9% year-on-year rise in H1 earnings to S$336.5 million. Local banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also ended in the black, with DBS rising 1.4%, UOB adding 0.9%, and OCBC gaining 0.9%.

site_title: ComfortDelGro’s H1 2024 earnings rise 21.4% to S$95.3 million
summary: ComfortDelGro's earnings for the first half of 2024 rose 21.4% to S$95.3 million, driven by a 13.7% increase in revenue to S$2.1 billion. The growth was mainly attributed to new acquisitions and increased contributions from existing businesses, particularly its taxi/private-hire vehicle segment. The company's newly acquired Australia-based taxi company contributed significantly to the revenue rise.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro, in a tie-up with Pony.ai, said that it expects autonomous vehicle technology to alleviate global driver shortage.
Jonathan Jong is ComfortDelGro’s Group Chief Sustainability and Risk Officer.
ComfortDelGro Engie is one of two electric vehicle (EV) charger operators to be awarded public EV charger deployment contracts by EV-Electric Charging.

site_title: New Starbucks CEO must strike while the coffee is hot
summary: Starbucks has appointed Brian Niccol, CEO of Chipotle Mexican Grill, as its new CEO and chairman, replacing Laxman Narasimhan. The move is seen as a rare opportunity to revitalize the coffee giant, with investors, Howard Schultz, and Elliott Management backing Niccol. Niccol has a track record of success at Chipotle, including improving efficiency and customer experience. He will need to balance the demands of activist investors and Schultz, who built Starbucks into an international brand, to push through much-needed changes and avoid the mistakes of Narasimhan.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol walks across the 14th hole during the Pro Am event prior to the Memorial Tournament presented by Workday at Muirfield Village Golf Club on June 05, 2024 in Dublin, Ohio. Starbucks said on August 13, 2024, that Niccol would be the coffee chain's new CEO, just over a year after current boss Laxman Narasimhan took over the role. Narasimhan steps down as chief executive and as a member of the Starbucks board "with immediate effect," said the company in a statement. (Photo by Dylan Buell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)
The size of the hedge fund’s stake in the company is not known.

site_title: Genting Singapore H1 profit up 29%; resort operator flags competitive headwinds
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 29% increase in profit for the first half of the year to S$356.9 million, driven by a 25% rise in revenue to S$1.36 billion. Gaming revenue rose 28% to S$957.6 million, while non-gaming revenue increased 19% to S$397.9 million. However, the company flags competitive headwinds due to regional travel recovery and rising geopolitical tensions, which may hinder a full recovery to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: US lenders push Indian ed-tech giant Byju’s towards insolvency
summary: The Indian Supreme Court has revived insolvency proceedings against Byju's, an education technology company, following a lawsuit by US lenders who claim they are owed $1 billion. The decision is a setback for founder Byju Raveendran, who had valued the company at $22 billion in 2022. The company was previously undergoing insolvency proceedings after a dispute with India's cricket board, but a tribunal had quashed the process. The US lenders, represented by Glas Trust, are now seeking to put the tribunal's decision on hold, which could complicate matters for the company.

images.alt_text: The missing money is at the heart of a dispute between lenders owed US$1.2 billion and the startup founded by entrepreneur Byju Raveendran.
Even after two unsuccessful attempts at filing two-step bankruptcies in its effort to cap product liabilities, Johnson & Johnson plans to file a third time.

site_title: AEM H1 net profit falls 95.4% as demand from key customer weakens
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 95.4% decline in net profit to S$895,000 for the half-year ended Jun 30, 2024, due to weaker demand from its key semiconductor customer. Revenue declined 36.9% to S$173.6 million, and earnings per share fell to S$0.0029. The company forecasts revenue to be in the range of S$160 million to S$180 million for the second half of the year, with quarter-on-quarter revenue growth anticipated in Q4 2024. AEM is rationalizing its cost structure and realigning talent to drive new business growth.

site_title: Global banks’ tech revival sparks hope for US$254 billion Indian IT sector
summary: Global banks are reviving technology projects, sparking hope for the US$254 billion Indian IT sector, which relies heavily on banking, financial services, and insurance (BFSI) clients. Quarterly reports from major IT firms show a nascent recovery in BFSI client demand after six quarters of depressed spending since the Silicon Valley Bank collapse. Big banks such as JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America are boosting their annual technology spending, with JPMorgan investing $1.5 billion and Bank of America earmarking $4 billion for new technology initiatives. Analysts expect a US interest rate cut, which could ease cost pressures and boost demand for IT projects.

TCS net income rose 9 per cent to 120.4 billion rupees (S$1.9 billion) in the first quarter through June.

site_title: India’s July merchandise trade deficit widens amid global headwinds
summary: India's merchandise trade deficit widened to $23.5 billion in July, surpassing economists' expectations, amid weak global demand and a fragile economy. Merchandise exports stood at $33.98 billion, while imports reached $57.48 billion. India is exploring new markets and diversifying its export goods basket to offset the weakness in western economies. Despite this, the country's services exports remained steady.

images.alt_text: Prices of food, which account for nearly half of the retail inflation, rose 5.42 per cent from last year in July, compared to a 9.36 per cent rise in June.
Top exporter India’s 5 per cent broken parboiled variety was quoted at US$539-to-US$545 per tonne, down from last week’s US$543-to-US$551.
India government wants to make sure there is enough sugar for the local market at reasonable prices, and on using more cane to produce ethanol.

site_title: 9 in 10 households that sold part of remaining lease back to HDB receive S$100,000 to S$300,000 each
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has facilitated over 12,656 households to sell part of their remaining lease back to the agency under the Lease Buyback Scheme since its launch in 2009. On average, about 1,680 households opt for the scheme annually, with 53% of households living in three-room flats or smaller. Eligible seniors receive between S$100,000 to S$300,000, which is used to top up their Central Provident Fund (CPF) Retirement Account and purchase a CPF Life plan, providing monthly payouts for life.

site_title: Eurozone employment growth weakens in sign of trouble ahead
summary: The eurozone employment grew 0.2% in Q2, a decline from the previous quarter's 0.3% growth, signaling economic weakness. Despite outsized wage increases, consumers are unwilling to spend, and private-sector activity has halted. The European Central Bank is expected to ease monetary policies with a 50% chance of two more interest-rate cuts this year, a significant shift from recent expectations. The euro economy's recent distress signals, including a slump in industrial production and declining confidence in Germany, have raised concerns about the region's economic health.

site_title: StarHub H1 earnings up 7.1% to S$82.1 million despite revenue staying largely flat
summary: StarHub announced a net profit of S$82.1 million for the half-year ended June, a 7.1% increase from the previous year. Despite revenue staying largely flat at S$1.1 billion, earnings per share rose 8.5% to S$0.046 due to higher contributions from its enterprise business. The company attributed the decline in mobile revenue to a shift from device plans to SIM-only plans, but saw an increase in postpaid subscribers. StarHub declared an interim dividend of S$0.03 per share and has previously guided for a full-year dividend of at least S$0.06.

site_title: China Aviation Oil H1 profit doubles to US$42.4 million on oil price, business volume increases
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a net profit of US$42.4 million for the first half of 2024, doubling from US$19.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 20.1% to US$7.5 billion, driven by a "continued robust recovery" in global air travel, with total air passenger traffic surpassing pre-pandemic levels in 2024. The company attributed the strong performance to higher gross profit and associate results, partially offset by higher expenses.

site_title: Aviva tops earning forecasts on home, motor insurance price rises
summary: Aviva, a British insurer, reported a 14% rise in operating profit to £875 million, exceeding analysts' forecasts. The company saw a 15% increase in general insurance premiums overall, with an 18% rise in Britain and Ireland. Despite criticism of rising premiums, Aviva remains confident of meeting its 2026 targets, including achieving £2 billion in annual operating profit. The insurer also plans to launch a long-term asset fund and pay an interim dividend of 11.9p per share.

images.alt_text: Life and general insurer Aviva is aiming for operating profit of £2 billion by 2026

site_title: China’s embrace of rail and EVs stalls holiday petrol demand
summary: China's holiday travel season has seen a decline in petrol sales, with domestic tourists opting for alternative modes of transport such as high-speed rail and electric vehicles. Petrol receipts at two major retailers have dropped over 5% since July, with rail network passenger numbers increasing 6.1% and electric car usage on the rise. This shift is attributed to China's growing adoption of clean energy and the country's efforts to reduce oil demand, which is expected to peak by 2025.

images.alt_text: The upcoming ban on new diesel cars and taxis comes before all new cars and taxis registered here are required to be cleaner-energy models from 2030.
Thailand and Malaysia have let diesel prices climb in the past weeks to ease the burden on public finances as global crude prices rise.

site_title: Global banks are nowhere near reaching their CO2 targets
summary: Global banks are failing to meet their climate change targets, with 25 of the world's largest lenders not on track to reduce their financing of activities that fuel climate change. A new study by the World Resources Institute found that banks' 2030 targets are less ambitious than they seem, and many have no or weak targets in key sectors. The study also found that banks are not investing enough in clean energy, with the finance industry requiring an additional $4 trillion annually by 2030 to meet the necessary reductions in emissions.

site_title: A 481-year age difference? For some readers, that’s hot
summary: A subgenre of romantasy novels, combining fantasy and romance, has gained popularity with its "shadow daddies" - male characters who are centuries old, possessing dark powers and a youthful appearance. Fans of this genre, such as Sarah J. Maas' books, find the enormous age gap between younger female protagonists and older male love interests appealing, with some citing it as a desire for maturity and experience in a partner. However, others argue that the power imbalance and lack of boundaries between the characters can be problematic, raising questions about the acceptability of such relationships.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s financial centre says company registrations up 31%
summary: Abu Dhabi's financial centre, ADGM, saw a 31% increase in company registrations to 1,271 new licenses in the first six months of the year, a 20.5% rise compared to 2023. Major financial services firms, including Morgan Stanley, have been moving to the emirate, drawn by its wealthy market and home to sovereign wealth funds like ADIA, Mubadala, and ADQ. This trend is attributed to the growing presence of banks, hedge funds, family offices, venture capital firms, and crypto traders in the UAE's capital.

site_title: Thai court removes PM Srettha Thavisin for gross ethics violation
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court removed Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin for "grossly" violating ethics by appointing a minister with a jail record, becoming the fourth Thai premier in 16 years to be removed by the same court. The ruling, 5-4 in favor of dismissal, means parliament must convene to choose a new premier, potentially leading to more uncertainty in a country plagued by coups and court rulings.

images.alt_text: The disbandment of the 2023 election winner is the latest setback for Thailand’s major political parties, which remain embroiled in a tumultuous two-decade battle for power with an influential nexus of conservatives, old money families and royalist generals.

After a one-day debate by lawmakers to scrutinise the much-criticised handout scheme, the budget passed with 297 votes in favour and 164 against as the Pheu Thai Party-led government commands a majority in the House of Representatives.

site_title: Mars to buy Pringles maker Kellanova for US$36 billion in 2024’s biggest deal
summary: Mars is acquiring Kellanova, the maker of Pringles and Pop-Tarts, in a $36 billion deal. Mars will pay $83.50 per share, a 33% premium to Kellanova's closing price. The acquisition aims to bolster Mars' snacking division, introduce more healthy options, and expand its presence in Africa and China. The deal is seen as a bet on consumers continuing to indulge in branded snacks, despite stalling growth in the packaged food sector due to inflation. The combined company expects to hold prices steady and not pass on costs to consumers.

images.alt_text: Kellanova makes its products in 21 countries and markets them in more than 180 countries.

site_title: Malaysia to acquire trains through US$2.4 billion leasing deal with China
summary: Malaysia plans to acquire 62 new passenger train sets from China through a US$2.4 billion leasing deal over a 30-year period. The first phase, from 2024 to 2027, will be financed with estimated payments in installments. The leasing costs will include maintenance, repair, and operations services. Almost 90% of Malaysia's passenger trains are currently manufactured by China, and this deal aims to upgrade the country's rail network.

site_title: Green data centres, energy transition among most promising growth areas in sustainable financing: UOB
summary: UOB's head of sector solutions group and global financial institution group Lim Lay Wah identified green data centres, energy transition, food security, and industrials as the most promising growth areas in sustainable financing. The bank has seen robust growth in its sustainable banking solutions, with cumulative total of sustainable loans issued reaching S$44 billion, a 46% compound annual growth rate. Generative AI is driving the growth of green data centres, while the electric vehicle boom is propelling the industrials sector. Lim emphasized the importance of supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the region's sustainability journey.

images.alt_text: Offshoring is always an option because of the high cost in Singapore, although UOB is also mindful of the quality of labour supply, said CFO Lee Wai Fai.

site_title: How to invest in chaotic markets
summary: Investors should not ignore market volatility, contrary to popular advice to wait for the storm to pass. Instead, they should rebalance their portfolios to maintain a balanced risk-reward ratio. This can be done by adjusting the proportion of stocks and bonds based on market conditions and risk appetite. A regular rebalancing schedule can help mitigate the risks of timing the market, and using advanced formulas like the Merton share can optimize portfolio allocation. However, investors should approach rebalancing with caution, avoiding impulsive decisions made during market chaos, and instead adopting a procedure devised during calmer times.

images.alt_text: Markets have been rocked by premature recession fears during the current bull market.
Getting an accurate read on a person's risk tolerance is harder than it sounds. Investors tend to perceive markets as less risky when they’re going up, and riskier when they’re going down.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, August 14th, 2024 (Ep 122)
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday, driven by Cathay Pacific's recovery from profit woes. The airline's stock became the world's most-shorted airline stock. Meanwhile, a new stock exchange and local investments by family offices are being considered to revive Singapore's bourse. Additionally, UOB plans to move some back-office functions to Malaysia, aiming to sustain its return on equity at 14% by 2026.

site_title: Kishida’s resignation opens the door to a chaotic era
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced his resignation, paving the way for a chaotic leadership vote within the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Kishida's decision not to seek re-election comes after years of struggling to reconnect with the public, and the party is now expected to elect a new leader in late August. Potential candidates, including former prime ministers and senior lawmakers, will vie for the position, with some analysts predicting a left-of-field candidate could emerge. Kishida's legacy is mixed, with accomplishments in defense and foreign policy, but also controversy surrounding the LDP's funding scandal and economic policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shigeru Ishiba, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Makiko Yamazaki/File Photo
Fumio Kishida’s decision to quit will trigger a contest to replace him as party boss, and by extension as the leader of the world’s fourth-biggest economy.

site_title: China’s latest blockbuster casts rare, harsh light on gig economy
summary: China's latest blockbuster, "Upstream," sheds light on the country's gig economy, tackling issues of uncertain job markets, downward mobility, and the lives of millions working in low-paid gig jobs. The movie follows a middle-aged programmer pushed into the food-delivery gig economy after being laid off, showcasing the struggles of scooter drivers and their low-paid work. With over 5 million viewers, the film highlights the harsh realities of the industry, including long hours and payment per delivery often less than $1. The movie's focus on economic issues contrasts with typical Chinese blockbusters and has sparked both praise and criticism for its portrayal of the industry.

site_title: Capturing the beauty of everyday things in the quest for a heartwarming ‘Singapore design’
summary: Singaporean design studio Onlewo, co-founded by Mike Tay, aims to capture the beauty of everyday life in Singapore through its designs. The company, which produces a range of products including wallpapers, upholstery, and table runners, focuses on personal memories and storytelling elements to create heartwarming designs. Tay's designs often pay tribute to his childhood memories and Singaporean heritage, such as the "My Home – Blk 1" cushion cover featuring his former childhood home. Onlewo has maintained a balance between business interests and heritage, with over half its products made in Singapore, and has attracted corporate clients including BlackRock and Spotify.

site_title: UBS profit beats estimates as client inflows hit US$27 billion
summary: UBS posted a higher-than-expected profit of $1.1 billion in the second quarter, driven by strong client inflows of $27 billion in its wealth management business. The bank plans to repurchase $2 billion in shares by 2026 and is on track to achieve pre-merger levels of profitability a year after completing the takeover of Credit Suisse. However, tougher Swiss regulation, including $25 billion in extra capital demands, may impact the bank's ability to maintain payouts. UBS expects positive investor sentiment and continued momentum in client transactions into the third quarter.
