UBS said that despite extended talks with Bank of America about indemnification, including for about US$53 million of legal costs, BofA “ultimately refused to comply with its indemnification obligations.”

site_title: Cathay Pacific world’s most-shorted airline stock on profit woes
summary: Cathay Pacific, the Hong Kong-based airline, has become the world's most-shorted major airline stock with over 25% of its shares being shorted, according to S&P Global data. This follows its first-half results, which showed a decline in net income due to lower passenger yields and higher costs. Analysts at Morgan Stanley have downgraded Cathay Pacific's shares, citing "negative earnings growth" and "macro headwinds" in the second half, with shares down 5% this year. The airline industry faces challenges including staff shortages and overly ambitious growth plans.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Adrian Cheng expects city to become No 1 hub for rich
summary: Hong Kong is aiming to become the world's top destination for family offices, with over 2,700 single family offices at the end of 2023. Tycoon Adrian Cheng expects the city to achieve this goal in the "medium term" due to its existing advantages, including a large number of wealth management practitioners serving wealthy families. The city has introduced tax and residency incentives to attract more family offices, with an estimated HK$2 trillion in assets under management at the end of 2023. However, Hong Kong faces challenges from geopolitical risks and Beijing's crackdown on billionaires, with rival Singapore also competing for the title.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s office vacancy rate hit a historic high of 16.9 per cent in the first half of the year, while rental prices are expected to fall as much as 10 per cent in 2024.
A slew of luxury residential units are hitting the market as rich local families have been caught up by a debt crunch.
FILE PHOTO: People cross a street in a shopping area of the Central business district in Hong Kong, China August 22, 2019. Picture taken August 22, 2019.  REUTERS/Thomas Peter
Tourism in the city cratered after the pandemic and remains down 40 per cent from 2019, according to Hong Kong Tourism Board data.

site_title: UK inflation picks up less than expected, boosting rate cut bets
summary: UK consumer price inflation rose to 2.2% in July, below expectations, boosting bets on a rate cut by the Bank of England. The annual rate was unchanged from June, but services price inflation fell to 5.2% from 5.7% in June, the lowest since June 2022. The BOE remains focused on longer-term inflation pressures, including wages and labour market slack. Sterling fell against the US dollar, with financial markets pricing in a 44% chance of a quarter-point rate cut in September, up from 36% before the data was released.

images.alt_text: Shoppers walk along Regent Street in London, Britain, July 9, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams
Regular pay has been growing at roughly double the pace the BOE thinks is compatible with keeping inflation at its 2 per cent target over the medium term.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains as US inflation data boost rate hopes
summary: Asia markets extended gains on Wednesday as US inflation data boosted hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut next month. The US wholesale prices rose less than forecast, fueling optimism for a "soft landing" for the economy. However, Tokyo retreated after Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced he would not seek re-election as party leader. Despite this, Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul, advanced, with oil prices edging up. Analysts expect the Fed to cut rates 25 basis points in September, with potential further cuts before December.

images.alt_text: Tokyo’s Nikkei returned from a long weekend to lead the rally and briefly top the levels touched at the start of the month before last Monday’s rout, helped by a weaker yen and a Bank of Japan pledge not to hike interest rates further.

site_title: Potential candidates to be next Japanese prime minister
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced his resignation, paving the way for a leadership election within the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Potential candidates include Shigeru Ishiba, a four-time party presidential candidate and former defense minister, who leads in public opinion polls. Other contenders include Toshimitsu Motegi, a seasoned diplomat and secretary-general of the LDP, and Shinjiro Koizumi, a former environment minister and son of a charismatic former prime minister. The field also includes Yoko Kamikawa, a relatively low-profile foreign minister, and Taro Kono, a digital minister who has pushed to modernize government technology.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shigeru Ishiba, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during an interview with Reuters in Tokyo, Japan, August 6, 2024. REUTERS/Makiko Yamazaki/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: LDP Secretary-General Toshimitsu Motegi delivers a speech during the Liberal Democratic Party convention on March 17, 2024, in Tokyo, Japan.    Rodrigo Reyes Marin/Pool via REUTERS//File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Japan's Environment Minister Shinjiro Koizumi speaks at a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, September 16, 2020. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Japan's Minister in Charge of Economic Security Sanae Takaichi arrives at Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's official residence in Tokyo, Japan August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Japan's Minister for Digital Transformation Taro Kono walks on the day of the cabinet reshuffle, at the Prime Minister's office in Tokyo, Japan September 13, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Japanese Foreign Minister Yoko Kamikawa speaks at a press conference during the QUAD ministerial meeting in Tokyo,  Japan July 29, 2024. Tomohiro Ohsumi/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Fumio Kishida’s decision to quit will trigger a contest to replace him as party boss, and by extension as the leader of the world’s fourth-biggest economy.

site_title: Asic sues ASX over ‘misleading’ blockchain upgrade statements
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has sued the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) over misleading statements about its blockchain upgrade project. The lawsuit claims ASX misled the public about the project's progress, risking damage to the integrity of the Australian financial markets and investor confidence. ASIC alleges the company broke the law by flagging the project as on track to switch to a new blockchain-based clearing and settlement platform in 2022, despite being told by its software developer that it was falling behind.

images.alt_text: The index measuring whether it was a good time to buy major household items bounced 0.6 per cent, but remains historically low at 82.6.

Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

Even during a period of Covid-19 measures that closed many pubs, clubs and casinos in the 2020-2021 financial year, Australian state government statistics showed gambling losses exceeded A$24 billion.
Reflecting stronger consumer demand and public spending, Australia’s economic growth is expected to pick up to 1.7 per cent by the year end and to 2.6 per cent by June 2025.

site_title: Gold prices steady as US inflation data takes centre stage
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$2,465.27 per ounce, as soft US producer prices reinforced hopes of an imminent interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The market expects a 54% chance of a 50-basis-point interest rate cut in September and another in December, driven by cooling inflation. US inflation data due later in the day is expected to show month-on-month inflation edged up to 0.2%, while retail sales data is scheduled for Thursday.

images.alt_text: Spot gold fell by 0.2 per cent to US$2,466.69 per ounce.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,280.15 points, driven by gains from local banks and the tech sector. US and European indices also rallied overnight, boosted by cooler-than-expected producer inflation data and hopes of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. Other heavily traded securities included Soilbuild Construction Group and Genting Singapore, with the three local banks trading higher.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: UOB plans to move some back, middle-office functions to Malaysia; aims to sustain ROE at 14% by 2026
summary: UOB plans to move some of its back and middle-office functions to Malaysia, mainly in Kuala Lumpur, to maintain its cost-to-income ratio at 40% by 2026. This move aims to sustain its return on equity (ROE) at around 14% and increase contributions from around Asean. The bank expects income from its businesses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam to reach 30% by 2026, with non-interest income contributing 37% of income. UOB also forecasts a high single-digit growth in its current and savings account (Casa) balance and plans to double its assets under management of private banking customers.

images.alt_text: Net interest income falls 1 per cent on year, to S$2.4 billion, due to a moderation in net interest margin.
UOB Q2 profit rises 1% to S$1.43b; to pay S$0.88 per share dividend for H1
“All of us have fought the battle, and we have to prepare for the new ground, to energise the organisation,” said Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman and chief executive of UOB.
Current UOB head of group retail Eddie Khoo (right) will retire from the role, with  head of group technology and operations Susan Hwee succeeding him.

site_title: Now a Singapore brand, bubble tea chain Playmade sets its sights on the US
summary: Singapore-based bubble tea chain Playmade, now a Singapore brand, aims to raise S$20 million to expand into the US, with plans to open 250 outlets by 2029. Co-owners Amanda Poo and Crystal Wee, who acquired the Playmade trademark in 2023, are capitalizing on a US bubble tea boom. The duo plans to open their first flagship outlet in the US by 2025 and has already opened outlets in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. Playmade's revenue grew 15-20% to S$15 million in 2023, with diversification efforts including lifestyle merchandising, cafe concepts, and brand collaborations.

images.alt_text: From left: Brian Ng, Bernard Ng and Samuel Pei, co-founders of KC Group. Facial brand Kskin is the biggest contributor to sales.
Evercomm co-founder and chief executive Ted Chen aims to grow revenue to S$10 million in the next two years.

site_title: China economy is plodding along in absence of consumption spark
summary: China's economy likely failed to recover from its worst stretch in five quarters, with sluggish retail sales and stagnant industrial production. Consumer spending remains weak, despite a slight improvement in July, while investment growth is expected to stagnate. The government is considering additional policy stimulus to boost consumption, which accounts for nearly half of gross domestic product, as the country chases its annual growth target of around 5%. The central bank may soon introduce more monetary stimulus, with economists predicting a rate cut as early as August.

images.alt_text: Growth in outstanding yuan loans slowed to 8.7 per cent compared with 8.8 per cent in June.
China has approved a total of US$167 billion QDII quotas as of end-July to 189 institutions with foreign firms each given US$300 million to US$4.7 billion.
The People’s Bank of China governor Pan Gongsheng said a tighter band would signal a clearer policy target.
The consumer price index climbed 0.5 per cent from a year earlier, data from the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) on Friday (Aug 9) show.

site_title: Indonesia cuts back independence day party at remote new capital
summary: Indonesia has scaled back its Independence Day celebrations in its new capital, Nusantara, due to logistical challenges. The event, originally planned for 8,000 guests, will now only invite 1,300 people, down from previous reductions. The president, Joko Widodo, has championed the Nusantara project, but construction has been slow. The project is expected to be "functionally running" in 4-5 years, according to President-Elect Prabowo Subianto. The scaled-back event will include cultural performances, flag-raising, and military drills, but will be split between Jakarta and Nusantara due to capacity limits.

images.alt_text: Nusantara is not yet legally the nation’s capital until the president issues a decree transferring the status from Jakarta.

epa11501608 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C), accompanied by some Indonesian influencers, rides a motorcycle during his working visit to Indonesia's new capital city Nusantara in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, 28 July 2024.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA
Jakarta is the largest metropolitan area in Southeast Asia, with a tremendous rate of population growth and wide range of urban problems.

site_title: Google Fitbit, Peloton announce fitness content partnership
summary: Google Fitbit has partnered with Peloton Interactive to provide its premium users with access to Peloton's fitness content starting in early September. The deal offers Fitbit premium members US categories of pilates, running, boxing, and cycling classes. In return, Peloton members will receive offers on Google Pixel watches and Fitbit Charge 6 devices. The partnership aims to boost Peloton's sales amid uncertain demand for its stationary bikes and treadmills.

site_title: US considers a rare antitrust move: breaking up Google
summary: The US Justice Department is considering a rare antitrust move to break up Google, citing a landmark court ruling that found the company monopolized the online search market. Options include breaking up the Android operating system and Google's web browser Chrome, as well as forcing Google to sell off its AdWords platform. The move would be the first to dismantle a company for illegal monopolization since AT&T in the 1980s, and would need to be accepted by Judge Amit Mehta. The government is also exploring ways to prevent Google from gaining an unfair advantage in AI products, including requiring the company to share data with rivals.

images.alt_text: The earlier timing is Google’s latest bid to keep up with rivals in injecting AI features into its consumer-facing products and comes ahead of Apple’s planned launch of a new iPhone in September.

US district judge Rita Lin in San Francisco on Aug 9 dismissed the consumers’ antitrust lawsuit against Google, finding they had not provided enough factual evidence showing any harm from the Alphabet unit’s market dominance.

Google illegally monopolised the search market through exclusive deals, a judge ruled on Aug 5,  handing the US government a win in its first major antitrust case against a tech giant in more than two decades.

site_title: Google unveils new phones and other gadgets powered by AI
summary: Google unveiled new Pixel smartphones with deeper AI integrations on August 13, 2024. The new phones feature a Pixel-only feature that lets users search for information stored in screenshots. This marks a departure from Google's traditional autumn launch schedule for the Pixel series. The move aims to keep up with rivals, including Apple, which is set to launch a new iPhone in September with AI-powered features. Google's AI integrations are part of its efforts to incorporate AI into its hardware, following recent announcements from other tech companies.

images.alt_text: US district judge Rita Lin in San Francisco on Aug 9 dismissed the consumers’ antitrust lawsuit against Google, finding they had not provided enough factual evidence showing any harm from the Alphabet unit’s market dominance.

Google illegally monopolised the search market through exclusive deals, a judge ruled on Aug 5,  handing the US government a win in its first major antitrust case against a tech giant in more than two decades.

US District Court Judge Amit Mehta found that Google had a monopoly for search and for text ads through exclusive distribution agreements that made it the “default” option that people were likely to use on devices.
The deal will see Character.AI co-founders Noam Shazeer and Daniel De Freitas rejoin Google, where they were formerly employees.

site_title: A haven for black film on Martha’s Vineyard keeps growing
summary: The 22nd annual Martha's Vineyard African American Film Festival, a 9-day celebration of Black filmmakers, has concluded with a successful event. The festival drew a crowd of about 800 to its premiere of "The Supremes at Earl's All-You-Can-Eat," with attendees including actress Jennifer Hudson, director Spike Lee, and former President Barack Obama. Founded in 2002 by husband-and-wife team Floyd and Stephanie Rance, the festival has grown to screen about 70 films, including shorts, features, and documentaries, and has received accreditation as a qualifying festival for the short film category at the Oscars.

images.alt_text: Attendees dance at an after-party during the 22nd annual MarthaÕs Vineyard African American Film Festival, a nine-day event devoted to celebrating Black filmmakers, at the Loft, a nightclub in Oak Bluffs, Mass., Aug. 10, 2024. (Gabriela Herman/The New York Times)
In an undated image provided by Julia Pickett/Michigan Governors Office, Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, rendered in Barbie form by her staff.

site_title: Brokers’ take: KGI initiates United Hampshire US Reit at ‘outperform’, US$0.60 target
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on United Hampshire US Reit with an "outperform" rating and a price target of US$0.60. The analyst expects a 25 basis point interest rate cut in September to benefit the Reit by lowering borrowing costs and enhancing financial flexibility. The target price includes a terminal growth rate of 2% and a 9.6% cost of equity.

images.alt_text: Walmart at United Hampshire Reit's Hudson Valley Plaza property in New York. The Reit's gross revenue for Q1 is up 2.3 per cent to US$18.5 million.
The Reit's NPI increases 1.7 per cent to US$24.8 million for the half year, from US$24.4 million.

site_title: Tencent’s buyback plan in focus as Chinese tech rivals catch up
summary: Chinese tech companies, including Tencent, are turning to buybacks to boost shareholder returns amid lackluster sales growth. Tencent has spent nearly $8 billion on share repurchases this year, exceeding other Hong Kong-listed companies. The firm is expected to continue its spending, as its total outlay for the year is only 60% of its projected $12.8 billion. This move comes as competitors catch up on spending levels, with investors scrutinizing Tencent's buyback plans during its quarterly results announcement.

images.alt_text: Tencent’s advertising, fintech and business services operations are sensitive to deteriorating economic growth.
The Information earlier reported that Moonshot was seeking investments at a pre-money valuation of US$3 billion and had held talks with Tencent.
Tencent is among the best performers in the global game sector this year, with its Hong Kong-listed shares outpacing gains in peers from NetEase to Nintendo.

site_title: Philippine business buoys Jollibee profit as China pain persists
summary: Jollibee Foods' Philippine businesses boosted the company's second-quarter profit by 31% to 3 billion pesos, driven by strong sales from its key restaurants, including Jollibee, Chowking, and Mang Inasal. However, sales in China fell 13.4% due to weak consumer spending, a decline steeper than the 3.7% drop in the first quarter. Despite this, the company expects to add 750 to 820 stores this year and has revised its full-year operating income growth forecast to 18-20%.

images.alt_text: Jollibee’s unit Jollibee Worldwide will acquire 70 per cent of Compose Coffee and its majority-owned Titan Fund will take 5 per cent, the fast-food firm said in a disclosure.
Jollibee has 567 stores in China across a handful of fast-food brands.

site_title: Vanke’s rating cut deeper into junk territory on weak sales
summary: China Vanke's debt rating was cut deeper into junk territory by Moody's due to weak sales and declining margin pressure. The developer faces a cash crunch and ongoing refinancing needs, with Moody's citing concerns about its financial health amidst China's property market slump. Vanke's contracted sales for July fell 13% from a year earlier, and its 3.15% US dollar bond due 2025 traded at around 86 US cents. Moody's cut Vanke's rating to B1, further underscoring mounting pressure on the state-backed developer.

images.alt_text: China Vanke said that it expects to post a first-half loss of seven billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) to nine billion yuan.
Shenzhen-based Penging, which is partially owned by Vanke, used revenue from real estate projects related to the developer as underlying assets for products it then sold to some Vanke staff.
Property developer China Vanke
The pickup in sales has not been strong enough to ease a cash crunch at Vanke, which has been raising funds to calm investors’ concerns over its liquidity strains.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher after favourable producer inflation data
summary: US stocks closed higher on August 13 after cooler-than-expected producer inflation data, bolstering expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The producer price index rose 0.1% in July, down from a month earlier, and is expected to influence the Fed's decision. The Nasdaq Composite index led the gains, rising 2.4%, while the Dow Jones and S&P 500 also finished higher. Analysts predict the Fed will likely cut interest rates in September, citing the trend in inflation.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 08: Traders work on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) floor on August 08, 2024 in New York City. The Dow rose over 600 points following a strong jobs report showing that the American economy is still growing despite high interest rates.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: The EU should help Ukrainian refugees return home
summary: The European Union should help Ukrainian refugees return home to strengthen Ukraine's economy and resist Russian aggression. Ukraine faces significant labor shortages and a declining population, with over 40 million pre-war residents projected to drop to 31 million in 2035. The EU can address concerns over security and housing by providing relocation aid and financing for on-the-job training, and linking it to employment opportunities. This would enable Ukrainian refugees to return, supporting the labor market in their home country and encouraging European investment in western Ukraine, essential for Ukraine's post-war recovery and integration into the EU.

images.alt_text: Construction workers rebuild a destroyed district in Mariupol, Ukraine, on April 17, 2024 amid the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
Buildings damaged by shelling in Orikhiv, Ukraine. The country has released a  recovery plan for not only rebuilding but also transforming itself.
Two years in, the war rages on. Park Hotel in central Kharkiv, Ukraine, destroyed during a Russian missile strike; January 11, 2024.
People fleeing from Ukraine at a border crossing in Hungary in February 2022. As at Nov 14, there are 6.3 million recorded Ukrainian refugees globally.

site_title: At 83, Kwek Leng Beng confident of seizing opportunities, as CDL posts 32% rise in H1 profit
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) posted a 32% year-on-year rise in first-half net profit to S$87.8 million, driven by divestment gains. The group's net gearing climbed to 69% as of June 30, 2024, but CEO Sherman Kwek aims to reduce it to the high-50s by end-2025. CDL made S$1.1 billion of acquisitions and investments in H1 2024, excluding the purchase of Delfi Orchard. The company declared a special interim ordinary dividend of S$0.02 per share, half the payout for H1 FY2023. Kwek is confident of seizing opportunities despite high interest rates and global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: 城市发展（CDL）执行主席郭令明（Kwek Leng Beng）。
Mr Sherman Kwek, CEO of City Developments Limited, speaking at a media briefing at M Hotel, on February 25, 2022.

site_title: Unpopular Japan PM Kishida to step down
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced he will step down next month, ending a three-year term marked by low popularity and a struggling economy. Kishida stated he will not seek re-election as party chief, paving the way for a leadership contest within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party. The party is expected to hold a contest next month, with the winner becoming the new prime minister, aiming to show the people that the party is changing and becoming a "new LDP".

images.alt_text: Inflation data will be scrutinised by the central bank, which raised interest rates on Jul 31 to levels unseen in 15 years and signalled its readiness to hike borrowing costs further.

At the July 30-31 meeting, the Bank of Japan raised its short-term policy target to 0.25 per cent from a range of 0 per cent to 0.1 per cent and released a detailed plan on how to taper its huge asset buying in another landmark shift away from a decade-long stimulus programme.
Volatility coursed through Japan's markets with the Nikkei 225 suffering its biggest rout since 1987 on Monday, only to come roaring back 10 per cent the next day.

site_title: New Zealand cuts rates as slumping economy slows inflation
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), cut interest rates by a quarter percentage point to 5.25% as the economy slows and inflation decreases. The decision marks a rapid shift in tone from May, when the RBNZ indicated it wouldn't cut rates until the second half of 2025. The move aims to anchor inflation expectations around the 2% target, and the RBNZ forecasts the average interest rate will fall to 4.36% by mid-2025. The local dollar plummeted to 60.34 US cents following the decision.

site_title: Oil tumbles on easing fears of wider Middle East war
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as traders reduced their concerns about a wider war in the Middle East. Benchmark Brent crude futures settled down $1.61, or 1.96%, to $80.69 a barrel. The International Energy Agency kept its 2024 global oil demand growth forecast unchanged, citing a lacklustre Chinese consumption impact on economic growth. Iran suggested renewed cease-fire talks with Hamas, reducing the risk of retaliation, and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries trimmed its 2024 demand estimate.

images.alt_text: Global benchmark Brent crude futures settled higher at US$82.30 a barrel on Monday, gaining US$2.64, or 3.3 per cent.

site_title: Intel, pinched by losses, sells stake in chip designer Arm
summary: Intel sold its 1.18 million shares in chip designer Arm Holdings during the second quarter, generating approximately $147 million. The sale comes as Intel struggles to regain its footing in the industry, having delivered a poor earnings report and cutting 15,000 jobs. The company reported a net loss of $120 million on its equity investments in the period. Intel's decision to sell its stake in Arm is part of its efforts to reduce expenses and turn around its business.

images.alt_text: Intel investors have been losing patience with a turnaround plan that involves investing heavily in new chip and production technology, which it is trying to do as revenue shrinks.

Intel was set to lose about US$35 billion in market value as its disappointing forecast and planned 15 per cent job cuts raised worries about its ability to catch up with Taiwan’s TSMC and other chipmakers.
Intel shares slumped 20 per cent in extended trade, setting it up to lose more than US$24 billion in market value after its announcement.
Intel has reduced its workforce by about 5 per cent in 2023 to 124,800 by year’s end after announcing job cuts beginning in October 2022.

site_title: Bumitama Agri H1 profit falls 27.9% to 856.8 billion rupiah
summary: Bumitama Agri reported a 27.9% drop in net profit to 856.8 billion rupiah for the first half of 2024, mainly attributed to foreign exchange losses and increased average purchase price of external fresh fruit bunch. Revenue rose 1.4% to 7.6 trillion rupiah, driven by increases in palm product prices. An interim dividend of S$0.012 per share was declared, down from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Palm oil stocks book strong performance but face volatility, demand destruction ahead
Malaysia plantations to profit as CPO prices widen from Indonesia: Maybank
Analysts bullish on Bumitama Agri, expect rally of CPO prices
Brokers' take: Analysts bullish on Bumitama Agri, expect continued rally of CPO prices

site_title: Greater flexibility of regulatory framework essential for Reit market development
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed changes to the leverage requirements for real estate investment trusts (Reits), aiming to simplify the regulatory framework. The proposed amendments would allow Reits to increase their aggregate leverage from 45% to 50% with a minimum interest coverage ratio (ICR) of 1.5 times. This move is seen as a positive step by Reit players, who have long been awaiting such changes. The changes would make it easier for Reits to borrow and invest, enhancing their competitiveness in a global economy.

images.alt_text: Consider riding rising interest in Singapore-listed Reits amid softening interest rates with the two largest Reits by market cap.
Well Chip’s successful Bursa Malaysia debut is particularly noteworthy because its parent company is Singapore-listed pawnshop operator ValueMax Group, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
MAS wants to subject all S-Reits to a minimum ICR of 1.5 times, and an aggregate leverage cap of 50 per cent.

site_title: Reliance, Disney offer concessions to win antitrust nod for India media merger: sources
summary: Reliance and Walt Disney have offered to sell some channels to win faster antitrust approval for their $8.5 billion India media assets merger. The companies are resisting changes to cricket broadcast rights, which will give them lucrative rights worth billions of US dollars. The merged company will have a combined 120 TV channels and two streaming services, raising concerns of market power and pricing power. The Competition Commission of India has asked Reliance and Disney around 100 questions related to the merger, and the companies are willing to sell fewer than 10 TV channels to assuage concerns.

images.alt_text: Paramount Nickelodeon and other networks, has been looking to reduce its debt by selling noncore assets such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm.
Reliance will inject US$1.4 billion in the merged entity, with the company and its affiliates holding a more than 63 per cent stake, with Disney owning the rest.

site_title: Keppel unit enters JV to manage cooling sector in Thailand
summary: Keppel's unit, Keppel EaaS in Thailand (KET), has entered into a joint venture (JV) with Combined Heat and Power Producing (CHPP) to manage the cooling sector in Thailand. The JV will design, install, operate, and maintain cooling systems. KET will pay 490,000 baht (S$18,451) for 49% interest, while CHPP will purchase the remaining 51% for 510,000 baht. The partnership aims to support Thailand's energy policy, aiming to reduce energy intensity by 30% by 2037.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has pledged to boost the proportion of renewables in its energy mix and foreign lenders have promised to provide funding.

site_title: China’s 48 million unbuilt homes threaten to prolong crisis
summary: China's 48 million unbuilt homes pose a threat to the country's property crisis, with pre-sales data showing over 48 million homes sold before construction completion. This figure is comparable to Germany's total housing stock in 2021. The property sector faces multiple headwinds, including liquidity shortages, aging demographics, and a decline in construction workers. The non-completion ratio has soared from 17% to 47% since 2015, and completed homes now account for 27% of new sales, a significant shift from previous years.

images.alt_text: Top-tier Chinese cities, namely Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen, have eased homebuying requirements for downpayments and mortgages this year to revive demand.

A residential building under construction at the China Vanke Co. Elegant Lifestyle project in Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. Vanke, the Chinese state-backed developer that's become the latest flashpoint in the nation's property crisis, is preparing an asset package totaling about 130 billion yuan ($18 billion) to use as collateral as it seeks new bank loans, people familiar with the matter said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Commercial and residential buildings stand in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 6, 2014. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Carlsberg sees higher profit as cost cuts offset weak demand
summary: Carlsberg has raised its profit growth outlook for the year, citing cost controls that offset weaker consumer demand. Organic operating profit is expected to rise between 4% and 6%, up from previous guidance. The brewer's CEO, Jacob Aarup-Andersen, plans to diversify the company's offerings to include non-alcoholic beverages, as customers increasingly opt for alternatives to beer. Despite a 1.4% decline in volumes in the first half of the year, Carlsberg aims to maintain prices and invest in marketing to attract consumers.

images.alt_text: Penalties under the new rules rely on consumer law, opening manufacturers and endorsers to fines of up to five million rupees.
Carlsberg will buy a 33.33 per cent stake in Carlsberg South Asia (CSAPL) from partner CSAPL (Singapore) Holdings as well as other stakes in underlying companies for a total of US$744 million.
FILE PHOTO: Taps for Carlsberg beer are seen in a bar in Copenhagen, Denmark, July 30, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: South Korea’s jobless rate unexpectedly dips to lowest since October
summary: South Korea's jobless rate unexpectedly fell to 2.5% in July, the lowest level since October, according to the statistics office. This decline is seen as a positive sign for the economy, potentially leading to upward pressure on prices. The labour force participation rate remains at 64.9%. Economists expect the Bank of Korea to maintain its policy settings steady, pushing back their timelines for a potential policy pivot to October.

site_title: Home prices in Silicon Valley area top US$2 million for first time
summary: Home prices in the San Jose-Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area in Silicon Valley surpassed US$2 million for the first time, with existing single-family houses rising 11.6% in the second quarter to US$2.08 million. This marks the first time a US metropolitan area has exceeded US$2 million. The median home price in San Francisco ranked second, with a 8.5% increase, while 89% of metropolitan areas saw home-price increases. The steep appreciation reflects the nation's persistent affordability challenge, with 48% of US markets requiring an income of at least US$100,000 to afford a mortgage.

images.alt_text: Housing has been one of the main contributors to post-pandemic inflation, and further improvement in rental supply should help bring headline rates lower.
The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped 27 basis points in the week ended Aug 2, to 6.55 per cent, the Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) said.
The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was five basis points lower than a week earlier when it averaged 6.78 per cent, mortgage finance giant Freddie Mac said.
Entry level buyers depend on their personal savings and incomes, which haven’t kept up with inflation.
New home sales in June came in at an annual, seasonally-adjusted, revised rate of 617,000.
The slowdown came as prices reached another record in June, with the median sales price up 4.1 per cent to US$426,900.
Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, fell 2.2 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 980,000 units last month, the lowest level since last October.

site_title: UAW files labour charges against Trump, Musk
summary: The United Auto Workers Union (UAW) has filed federal labour charges against Donald Trump and Elon Musk, alleging they threatened and intimidated workers by discussing the possibility of striking. The charges stem from a two-hour conversation between the two on social media platform X, where Trump praised Musk's ability to get workers to go on strike. Under federal law, workers cannot be fired for going on strike, and threatening to do so is illegal. The UAW has endorsed Kamala Harris in her presidential bid.

site_title: Olam H1 profit inches up 0.2% to S$48 million
summary: Olam Group reported a net profit of S$48.03 million for the first half-year, a 0.2% increase from the previous year. Earnings per share remained unchanged at S$0.0084. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.03 per share, payable on August 29.

images.alt_text: Namoi has 10 cotton processing plants, while Olam’s Queensland Cotton unit operates nine, including two joint ventures.
The revolving credit facility has a tenor of three years.

site_title: Digital wealth platform Syfe gets US$27 million to grow business in key markets
summary: Syfe, a digital wealth platform, has secured US$27 million in funding from UK family offices and existing investors, bringing its total funding to US$79 million. Founded in 2019 by Dhruv Arora, the company aims to make investing more accessible. This latest round comes amid a challenging funding environment in Asia, with venture funding falling to its lowest level since 2015. The investment is expected to help Syfe grow its business in key markets.

images.alt_text: In this prolonged dry spell, caution is the name of the game.
Among the 16 acquisitions made in H1 2024 is the Singlife purchase by Sumitomo Life Insurance Company for US$1.2 billion
Brokerages offering free shares and commission-free trades in tussle for younger investors
Robo adviser Syfe gets US$30m in Series B funding led by Peter Thiel's Valar Ventures

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit’s H1 DPU falls 24.2% to US$0.0201
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 24.2% decline in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0201, mainly due to accounting for a manager fee in cash instead of units and a US$1 million capital reserve. Revenue rose 2.4% to US$36.9 million, driven by new leases and rental escalations. The Reit's net property income (NPI) dipped 1.7% to US$25.4 million, while distributable income declined 24% to US$12.7 million. The Reit expects improved NPI contributions after completing store fit-outs for larger vacancies and divesting two properties to lower leverage.

images.alt_text:
Hudson Valley Plaza in Kingston, New York. It is one of the grocery & necessity properties in United Hampshire US Reit's (UHReit) portfolio.
美国汉普郡联合REIT的初始资产组合，包括18个杂货为主中心和四个自助仓储设施。图为杂货为主中心之一的Hudson Valley Plaza。（美国汉普郡联合REIT提供）
Walmart at United Hampshire Reit's Hudson Valley Plaza property in New York. The Reit's gross revenue for Q1 is up 2.3 per cent to US$18.5 million.
The Reit's NPI increases 1.7 per cent to US$24.8 million for the half year, from US$24.4 million.
Upland Square, acquired by the Reit in July 2022.

site_title: First Resources H1 profit rises 45.4% to US$103.9 million
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 45.4% increase in net profit to US$103.9 million for the first half of FY2024, driven by higher production volumes and improved processing margins. Revenue rose 1.9% to US$457.2 million. The company attributed the better performance to restrained palm oil prices due to expected seasonal production in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: First Resources expects production to pick up in the second half of the year.

site_title: Investing success comes down to one word: focus
summary: Legendary investor Warren Buffett and Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates agree that focus is key to success in investing. Buffett emphasizes the importance of a rigorous process of eliminating unprofitable ideas to hone in on a select few. He also highlights the need to focus on a company's management team, particularly their integrity, intelligence, and energy. Additionally, Buffett suggests that investors should say "yes" to cash and be proactive in searching for positive trends within a company, rather than just focusing on negative headlines. By combining these factors, investors can make informed decisions and achieve success in the market.

images.alt_text: There is no one-size-fits-all approach to investing. Many seek to emulate Warren Buffett, but other successful investors do not follow his approach.
History shows that the longer you hold a stock investment, the better your chances of reaping a positive return. From 1980 to 2023, the S&P 500 delivered positive returns in 33 out of 43 years.

site_title: Cancer test maker Grail cuts 350 jobs as part of restructuring programme
summary: Grail, a cancer test maker, has cut approximately 350 existing jobs as part of a restructuring program. The company expects these cost reductions to extend its cash runway from 2026 into 2028. Grail's flagship cancer-detection test, Galleri, is being commercialized through partnerships with health systems, employers, and life insurance companies, aiming to fuel near-term growth. The company reported second-quarter revenue of $32 million, up 43% from the year earlier, and sold over 215,000 Galleri tests during the period.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) headquarters in White Oak, Maryland, U.S., August 29, 2020. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Dr Fang says the Onco-PDO test can be used on all known types of solid tumours.
Mammograms, a special type of X-ray of the breasts, is used to detect tumours as part of cancer screening.

site_title: Global economy’s looming geopolitical risks
summary: Global economic instability is heightened by looming geopolitical risks, including a potential Israel-Hamas ceasefire collapse and a wider regional war in the Middle East. Iran's response to recent killings of Hamas and Hezbollah leaders may escalate into a full-scale conflict with Israel. The US and Western intelligence agencies warn of significant attacks, while US President Joe Biden and European leaders urge restraint. The region's instability is part of a broader "polycrisis" of interconnected challenges, including health risks, technological challenges, climate crises, and economic inequality.

images.alt_text: While there are more than plausible pathways to escalation in the Russia-Ukraine and Israel-Hamas conflicts, investors and many businesses presently show little to no reaction.
In an era of extreme uncertainty, planning for a single high-probability scenario is a mistake.

Demonstrators march during a "For our Children” protest against pollution in Belgrade, on Nov 13, 2022. Around the world, environmental issues affect billions of people, contributing to population displacement, social instability and conflict.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, ST Engineering, Wilmar, City Developments, Olam
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported their financial performance for the first half of the fiscal year. CapitaLand Investment's profit fell 6% to S$331 million, while ST Engineering's profit grew 19.9% to S$336.5 million. Wilmar's net profit increased 5.2% to US$579.6 million, and City Developments' profit grew 32% to S$87.8 million. Olam Group's H1 net profit inched up 0.2% to S$48.03 million. Shares of these companies fluctuated, with some closing higher and others lower, due to various factors including fee-income related business performance and real estate investment business.

Yangzijiang Shipbuilding leads gains on Tuesday; STI up 0.7%

site_title: CapitaLand Investment H1 profit falls 6% to S$331 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) posted a 6% decline in net profit to S$331 million for the first half of the year, despite a 1% increase in revenue to S$1.37 billion. The group attributed the drop to higher interest expenses and foreign exchange losses. However, CLI's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation rose 8% to S$819 million, driven by higher portfolio gains. The company prioritized capital recycling to build a more balanced and diversified portfolio, with plans to divest assets and invest in new markets.

images.alt_text: Rock Square, a shopping mall in Guangzhou owned by CapitaLand China Trust. CLCT's revenue fall was partially mitigated by higher revenue growth from the retail portfolio.
Galileo in Frankfurt's Central Business District has achieved 96.7 per cent in committed occupancy even as it undergoes asset enhancement, said CICT.

site_title: Nvidia rebound adds US$420 billion market value in four days
summary: Nvidia shares have surged 17% in the past four sessions, adding nearly $424 billion to the company's market value. The chipmaker's rebound has propelled the broader market higher, with Nvidia accounting for 22% of the S&P 500's gain. Despite a recent sell-off, investors remain bullish on Nvidia's long-term trajectory, particularly given the expected solid quarterly earnings report and continued investment in artificial intelligence by major clients. The company's valuation now trades at 36 times forward earnings, considered relatively attractive by some investors.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s approval of Samsung’s latest HBM chips comes amid soaring demand for sophisticated GPUs created by the generative AI boom that Nvidia and other makers of AI chipsets are struggling to meet.

Samsung and Nvidia have yet to sign a supply deal for the approved eight-layer HBM3E chips but will do so soon, the sources said, adding that they expect supplies would start by the fourth quarter of 2024.
Chief executive officer Jensen Huang is introducing new chip designs and technology more rapidly, aiming to maintain an edge in AI computing.
Jensen Huang has personally sold about US$1.4 billion in shares since the start of 2020, including this summer’s sales.

site_title: A new stock exchange, local investments by family offices among wish list to revive Singapore bourse
summary: Singapore's equity market faces challenges, including low liquidity, poor valuations, and declining investor interest. To revive the market, stakeholders propose "bold" measures, including forming a new stock exchange, encouraging family offices to invest locally, and creating an ombudsman to protect investors. A separate exchange could represent South-east Asian companies and improve listings. Institutional investors, particularly sovereign wealth funds, are also encouraged to invest in the Singapore Exchange. Rebuilding an investing culture and stronger investor protection are also key recommendations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore sets up a review group to strengthen the equity market.

images.alt_text: MAS said the Review Group will study ways to galvanise greater public sector participation in the effort to strengthen the local market, including from capital market intermediaries, investors, and listed companies
SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye says xx
The review group will come up with measures to support companies listed on the Singapore Exchange and encourage them to expand globally.

site_title: Shunning home markets, South Korean retailers pile up on US stocks
summary: South Korean retailers have been investing heavily in US stocks, particularly in tech giants like Nvidia, Tesla, and Apple, driven by the worldwide AI-frenzy. Despite government efforts to boost the domestic stock market, South Korean investors continue to favor the US market due to its higher dividend payouts and shareholder returns. The trend is attributed to the "Korea discount," where South Korean listed companies have lower dividend payments and depressed valuations compared to their global peers. Retail investors, known as "ants," have been pouring funds into US stocks, with a record $9 billion invested between January to July this year, further fueling the trend.

images.alt_text: Interest rate swaps are trades of a fixed interest rate for a floating rate or vice versa, widely used by investors and banks to hedge risks in financial markets.
Export growth slowed in July, suggesting a slight cooling in global demand.
South Korea's consumer price index in July rose 2.6 per cent from the same month a year earlier, after rising from an 11-month low of 2.4 per cent in June.

site_title: Shein hires ex-EU official to bolster lobbying as IPO nears
summary: Shein, the online fashion retailer, has hired former EU budget commissioner Gunther Oettinger as a consultant to bolster its lobbying efforts in Europe ahead of its planned London IPO, valued at approximately £50 billion. The move comes as the EU considers stricter regulations on ultra-fast-fashion and import duties on cheap parcels. Oettinger, a senior member of Germany's conservative CDU party, has faced criticism for past remarks about Chinese people, but has since apologized. Shein has pledged to improve its supply chain and engage on sustainability and ethical labor policies, amid growing competition from low-cost online retailers.

images.alt_text: Shein, which is planning to go public in Britain, taps a network of largely China-based suppliers which take small initial orders and scale up based on demand.
The campaign accuses Shein of exploiting workers, damaging the environment and avoiding tax.
The European Commission later this month will suggest scrapping a current 150 euros (S$218) threshold under which items can be bought duty free, the FT report said.
Shein has expanded rapidly into South-east Asia in 2022, not long after moving its parent firm to Singapore from China.

site_title: Conflicting viewpoints, interests will be MAS review group’s biggest challenges
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has formed a review group to improve the Singapore stock market, but it faces significant challenges due to conflicting viewpoints and interests. The group must balance the need for tougher regulation with the concerns of market participants, including companies and family offices. MAS will need to make unpopular decisions and stick with them, even if they don't yield immediate results, to address issues such as limited investor protection and the dominance of the US market. Success will require patience, constant improvements, and a willingness to face criticism.

images.alt_text: xxx

MAS said the Review Group will study ways to galvanise greater public sector participation in the effort to strengthen the local market, including from capital market intermediaries, investors, and listed companies
