A vibrant exchange is vital to Singapore's economy, and activism could help inject some life into Singapore's stocks.
A liquid market is an incredible economic lubricant.

site_title: ST Engineering’s H1 profit rises 19.9% to S$336.5 million
summary: ST Engineering's net profit for the first half of 2024 rose 19.9% to S$336.5 million, driven by a 13.5% surge in revenue to S$5.5 billion. The group's earnings before interest and tax (Ebit) increased 17.7% to S$522.9 million. Commercial aerospace segment revenue rose 20% and Ebit increased 7% to S$190 million, while the defence and public security segment saw a 12% revenue increase and an 8% Ebit increase. ST Engineering will pay out a second interim dividend of S$0.04 per share on September 5.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering says its offload support augments Safran Aircraft Engines’ MRO capacity, while optimising the turnaround time of engine shop visits for customers.
Artist impression of ST Engineering's latest data centre situated in Jurong.
ST Engineering showcased 155mm ammunition at Singapore Airshow in February.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits two-week closing high as Fed rate cut bets strengthen
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed at a two-week high on August 13, driven by growing expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September, with markets anticipating around 100 basis points of rate cuts by year's end. The index rose 0.5% despite weak earnings from Tecan and Fortnox. Moderating inflation data in the US and a decline in Spanish inflation also contributed to the gains. Meanwhile, shares in Pandora and HelloFresh rose after beating earnings expectations, while Bellway rose after dropping its bid for Crest Nicholson.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed on a flat note on Monday, after last week’s muted performance as the continent-wide index rebounded from last Monday’s sharp selloff in risk assets on US recession fears.

site_title: Workers strike at world's largest copper mine in blow to BHP
summary: Workers at the world's largest copper mine, Escondida in Chile, began a strike on August 13 after pay negotiations with BHP fell apart. The strike, involving about 2,400 workers, is set to last until a new agreement is reached. BHP has activated a contingency plan to handle the strike, which could impact production. The union is demanding 1% of shareholder dividends to be distributed equally among workers, citing favorable copper prices. The strike is the latest in a series of labor disputes at the mine, which has been the site of previous strikes in 2017.

images.alt_text: Iron ore prices have fallen by about a fifth this year.

site_title: US producer prices rise less than expected in July
summary: US producer prices rose 0.1% in July, less than expected, after a 0.2% increase in June. The 12-month increase was 2.2%, down from 2.7% in June. The moderation in inflation suggests the Federal Reserve may start easing monetary policy in September, with a potential 50-basis-point rate cut. The labor market remains a concern, with the unemployment rate surging to 4.3% in July.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial posts 34% fall in H1 earnings to S$107.4 million
summary: Yangzijiang Financial reported a 33.9% decline in net profit to S$107.4 million for the first half of 2024, due to a 30% drop in interest income. However, its maritime fund assets grew 62.2% to S$376.6 million, driven by a higher average proportion of maritime-related investments. The group aims to invest up to US$900 million in maritime-related assets and has already invested US$325 million in deals involving 50 vessels. CEO Ren Yuanlin stated that the group now has a "healthier position with lessened single-country risk."

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding leads gains on Tuesday; STI up 0.7%
Yangzijiang's focus on building eco-friendly ships enabled it to secure a record number of orders.

site_title: Paramount Global begins planned layoffs with 15% job cuts in US
summary: Paramount Global, the parent company of CBS, MTV, and Comedy Central, announced a 15% job cut in the US as part of its plan to reduce annual costs by $500 million. The layoffs, affecting approximately 2,000 people, will continue through the end of 2024, with 90% of the cuts expected to be completed by September. The restructuring aims to strengthen the business ahead of its merger with Skydance Media and navigate a challenging linear TV market.

site_title: ‘Basket case’ on its way to upper-middle income status despite turmoil
summary: Bangladesh, despite its turbulent past, is on track to reach upper-middle income status by 2031, according to the World Bank. The country has made significant poverty reduction and development strides since its independence in 1971, despite being vulnerable to floods and political unrest. A recent wave of violence over reinstated quotas for civil service jobs, which led to an estimated 150-450 deaths and thousands of injuries, has not deterred the country's economic and social development. Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus has been appointed as chief adviser to the interim government, and opposition leaders have been freed, paving the way for the country's continued growth.

images.alt_text: The new interim government led by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus appealed to the Bangladeshi citizens to restore order and eschew violence.
Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus led a solemn tribute to Bangladesh's fallen independence heroes on Aug 9 in the first act of his interim government.
People waves Bangladeshi flags on top of the Ganabhaban, the Prime Minister's residence, as they celebrate the resignation of PM Sheikh Hasina in Dhaka, Bangladesh, Aug 5, 2024.

site_title: Boeing delivers 43 jets in July, flat year-on-year
summary: Boeing delivered 43 commercial jets in July, matching the same period last year, despite regulatory issues. The company resumed deliveries to China after a delay and handed over 31 MAX jets to customers, including Chinese carriers. Boeing reported 72 gross orders in July, up from 52 last year, with 57 of those orders for 737 MAX planes. The company's net order total for the year so far is 98, and it delivered 218 airplanes, including 166 MAX jets, through July 31.

images.alt_text: The Boeing Co. logo on the company's stand during the opening day of the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, UK, on Monday, July 22, 2024. The aviation summit is typically a platform for planemakers to rack up multibillion-dollar deals. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Vietnam set for a wave of global hotel brands amid booming demand for travel
summary: Vietnam is poised to attract a wave of global hotel brands amid booming demand for travel, driven by foreign arrivals and a thriving domestic tourism industry. The country is expected to see 40% of its hotels affiliated with international brands within the next three years, up from 30% currently. Foreign tourist arrivals hit 8.8 million in the first six months of 2024, a 58.4% increase year-on-year, while domestic tourism remained robust with 66.5 million local arrivals. Experts attribute the growth to Vietnam's growing middle class and higher disposable incomes, as well as its central location in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Some 67,000 Blackpink fans filled Vietnam's second-largest stadium in Hanoi over two nights in July.
The three border-shared countries of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland have a long history of cultural exchange and cooperation.
Michelin gives one star to four restaurants in Vietnam and honors 99 other local eateries in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City

Vietnam Airlines Corp plans to lease 20 A321 neo aircraft to add domestic as well as regional flights after carrying a record number of passengers in one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets.

site_title: Is CP Group scion’s AI startup worth the US$60m it raised?
summary: CP Group scion Korawad Chearavanont's AI startup Amity Solutions has raised US$60 million, planning to list on the local stock exchange by 2025. Founded as an employee engagement platform, Amity Bots uses AI to understand user questions and provide tailored responses, reducing the need for traditional chatbot training data. Despite being 10 times cheaper than Amity Bots, the company believes its solution is more cost-effective for enterprise clients. With over 20 clients, mostly based in Thailand, Amity has reached net profitability and is set to expand globally, challenging traditional players like Sprinklr.

images.alt_text: Generative artificial intelligence could hurt or help businesses.

site_title: Harris-Walz on the offence; Trump campaign disoriented and deflated
summary: US Presidential Election: Former President Donald Trump's campaign appears disoriented and deflated after a series of setbacks, including Biden's withdrawal and the emergence of Kamala Harris as a strong rival. Harris has gained momentum, leading Trump by 4 percentage points in key battleground states and 47-45% in national polls. Despite her strong performance, Harris and the Democrats remain vulnerable on the economy, with Americans citing inflation as their main concern. Trump's failure to develop a strategy to tackle economic issues has left him struggling to regain the narrative, instead focusing on personal attacks against Harris.

site_title: Delfi profit dips 22.3% to US$19.6 million
summary: Delfi, a confectionery manufacturer, reported a 22.3% drop in net profit to US$19.6 million for the first half of the year due to lower sales and currency weakness. Revenue declined 7.8% to US$260.8 million, with purchases of raw materials affected by the rupiah weakening against the US dollar. The company attributed the decline to reduced spending on trade promotion and terminated one of its agency brands. Delfi plans to continue investing in brand building and strengthening its routes to market to support long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Top chocolate bar manufactured by Singapore-listed consumer company Delfi

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on PPI, Starbucks boost
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, August 13, 2024, after producer prices data showed abating inflation pressures, supporting a Federal Reserve rate cut in September. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 88.3 points, or 0.22%, to 39,445.27. Starbucks surged after appointing Chipotle's Brian Niccol as CEO. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the S&P 500 up 32.6 points, or 0.61%, and the Nasdaq up 164.1 points, or 0.98%.

site_title: Home Depot warns of sales, profit decline on weak consumer spending
summary: Home Depot warns of a decline in annual profit and comparable sales due to weak consumer spending, citing higher interest rates and macroeconomic uncertainty. Customers delayed big-scale projects, such as flooring and kitchen cabinets, to tackle inflation. The company expects annual comparable sales to drop between 3% and 4%, compared to a previous forecast of a 1% decline. Comparable sales in the second quarter fell 3.3% and customer transactions fell 1.8% for the 13th straight quarter.

images.alt_text: A Walmart store in Secaucus, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, March 5, 2024. Walmart is revamping more than 800 store locations and adding high-end products. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Nanofilm Technologies H1 loss narrows 51.1% to S$3.7 million
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 51.1% decrease in its H1 loss to S$3.7 million, from S$7.6 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 13% to S$82.6 million, driven by higher contributions from its advanced materials, nanofabrication, and Sydrogen business units. Loss per share narrowed 51.3% to S$0.0057. The company has declared an interim dividend of S$0.0033 per share and expects higher revenue contributions from its 3C business segment in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The group's shares near a seventh-month high.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s Hotel Properties trims H1 loss to S$4.9 million
summary: Hotel Properties (HPL), owned by Ong Beng Seng, reported a net loss of S$4.9 million for the half year ended Jun 30, narrowing from S$17.2 million in the previous year. Revenue increased 8.9% to S$347.3 million, driven by better performance from hotels and resorts, including the opening of its first Japan hotel, Four Seasons Osaka. The loss per share decreased to S$0.0162 from S$0.0397 year on year.

images.alt_text: The Four Seasons Hotel Osaka; HPL’s 15th Four Seasons property, is located inside the One Dojima building in Osaka’s popular Dojima neighbourhood, which is near the city’s business district.
The Woodleigh Mall at Bidadari estate.

site_title: Yen remains weak, dollar slips as markets await US CPI data
summary: The yen remains weak, with a 8% increase since mid-July, as investors unwind the carry trade strategy. The US dollar softened against other currencies, awaiting US CPI data that could indicate Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. The dollar index slipped to 102.92, while the euro rose 0.22% to US$1.0957. Markets expect the Fed to cut interest rates, with potential 25-50 basis point reductions in September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen are seen in this illustration picture taken September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: US small business sentiment near 2½-year high
summary: US small business sentiment has reached its highest level in nearly 2½ years, with the National Federation of Independent Business's Small Business Optimism Index rising 2.2 points to 93.7 in July. Despite inflation concerns, fewer businesses reported raising worker compensation and average selling prices, indicating an improving inflation outlook. The index also showed a rebound in planned inventory investment, which could boost the gross domestic product. Financial markets and economists expect the Federal Reserve to start cutting interest rates in September.

images.alt_text: US consumers’ delinquency fears rise to highest level since 2020.
Housing has been one of the main contributors to post-pandemic inflation, and further improvement in rental supply should help bring headline rates lower.
The recent easing of price pressures has bolstered Fed officials’ confidence that they can start to lower borrowing costs.
The emerging clusters of unsheltered migrants in New York may indicate that two of the city's most vexing challenges are becoming intertwined.
The Commerce Department’s Census Bureau said on Thursday (Aug 8) that wholesale inventories rose 0.2 per cent in June as previously estimated.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 233,000 for the week ended Aug 3, the Labor Department said.

site_title: Jewels stolen in Germany's Green Vault heist back on display
summary: Nearly five years after a museum heist in Eastern Germany, millions of euros' worth of jewelry has been recovered and is on display at the Historic Green Vault museum in Dresden. Thieves stole pieces containing over 4,300 diamonds valued at over $124 million in November 2019. Most stolen jewels have been recovered, but an epaulette featuring the Dresden White Diamond remains missing. The recovered pieces are now on display, offering visitors a glimpse into the museum's extensive art collection.

images.alt_text: The Bleu Royal, a pear-shaped diamond weighing 17.61 carats and set on a ring, has been in a private collection for decades.

site_title: Streaming cushions Tencent Music’s second quarter revenue fall
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group reported a 1.7% fall in quarterly revenue to 7.16 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) in the three months ended Jun 30, despite a 27.7% increase in online music business revenue. The number of paying users at the music streaming business rose 17.7% to 117 million. The social entertainment business, which includes live-streaming, dropped 42.8% due to regulatory pressures. Despite this, the company's core online music business is expected to continue growing, diminishing the impact on total revenue.

images.alt_text: Tencent’s advertising, fintech and business services operations are sensitive to deteriorating economic growth.
The Information earlier reported that Moonshot was seeking investments at a pre-money valuation of US$3 billion and had held talks with Tencent.
Tencent and its controlled entity Tencent Music will buy the stake through a combination of cash and a minority stake in music streaming app JOOX Thailand, valuing GMM Music at US$700 million.

site_title: Halcyon Agri’s H1 loss narrows to US$21.8 million
summary: Halcyon Agri, a rubber producer, reported a narrowed loss of US$21.8 million for the six months ended June 2024, compared to a loss of US$62.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 25.7% to US$1.5 billion due to expanded sales and higher market prices, with total sales volume rising 14.2% to 901,780 metric tonnes. The company expects rubber demand to be affected by interest rates, geopolitical tensions, and China's economic trends, but will capitalize on market opportunities for traceable natural rubber products.

images.alt_text: Halcyon Agri posted a 20.5 per cent increase in revenue to US$592.9 million in the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2024.

Sinochem International (Overseas) – which still holds a direct interest in around 29.2 per cent of Halcyon Agri’s shares following the closing of the November acqusition – has provided an irrevocable undertaking that it will reject the offer.
China Hainan Rubber launched the offer for Halcyon Agri at S$0.413 per share in February this year.
Halcyon rubber processing factory in Palembang, Indonesia. The group reported a widening net loss to US$24.9 million for H2 2023. PHOTO: HALCYON AGRI

site_title: Zeekr tackles EV range anxiety with 10-minute battery charge
summary: Zeekr, a Chinese automaker, has unveiled an upgraded lithium iron phosphate battery that can charge in 10½ minutes, aiming to tackle electric vehicle range anxiety. The battery will be available in the 2025 Zeekr 007 sedan, with deliveries starting next week. Even in cold conditions, the cells can charge to 80% in around 30 minutes. This technology is part of the company's efforts to address the main impediment to electric car adoption, which is range anxiety. The move is seen as a significant step forward in the industry's quest for faster and more powerful charging cells.

site_title: UOL to launch freehold Meyer Blue condo in September as H1 net profit falls 3% to S$130.4 million
summary: UOL Group reported a 3% drop in H1 net profit to S$130.4 million, with revenue falling 7% to S$1.27 billion. Despite lower property development contributions, the group is bullish on its hospitality portfolio, which saw higher revenue in H1. UOL is launching its freehold Meyer Blue condominium in September and has a strong pipeline of launches, targeting sites with strong locational attributes. The group's net gearing ratio rose to 0.27, and shares closed flat at S$5.31.

images.alt_text: In H2, revenue from property development was up 11 per cent to S$977.4 million due primarily to higher progressive recognition of revenue from Clavon, The Watergardens at Canberra and AMO Residence (pictured).

site_title: Hong Leong Asia H1 profit from continuing operations up 60% to S$49.4 million
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a 60.1% increase in net profit from continuing operations to S$49.4 million for the first half of the year, up from S$30.9 million in the same period last year. The building materials unit's revenue rose 5% to S$321.4 million. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.01 per share, payable on September 10. This represents a 56.3% increase in earnings per share from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: The recovery in construction activity comes on the back of the lifting of a Heightened Safety Period (HSP) put in place by the Ministry of Manpower from Sep 1, 2022 to May 31, 2023, after a spate of workplace fatalities in the sector.
Hong Leong Asia chief executive Stephen Ho said that the economic slowdown in China has contributed to a slowdown in demand for trucks.

site_title: China’s outbound investing quota crunch spurs foreign asset managers to get creative
summary: China's Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (QDII) program has sparked a quota crunch, forcing foreign asset managers to get creative to meet the demand for offshore investments. Despite a recent sell-off in US and Japanese markets, Chinese investors continue to seek higher returns, leading to a surge in QDII product demand. To cope with the quota limits, firms are introducing measures such as subscription caps, swap structures, and rationing quotas among branches. The quota squeeze underscores the challenges foreign financial firms face in leveraging their global network and product suites in competition with Chinese peers.

images.alt_text: The government’s attempts to intervene in shares and currency trading in recent years have deterred international money managers.
China’s sovereign debt has rallied this year as demand for haven assets has surged due to a sluggish economy and expectations of further rate cuts.
The fall comes despite Beijing’s growing efforts to attract and retain foreign investment, following the smallest increase on record last year.

site_title: UK homebuilder Bellway abandons takeover bid for Crest Nicholson
summary: UK homebuilder Bellway has abandoned its £720 million takeover bid for Crest Nicholson, citing no reason for the decision. Bellway's shares rose 4% while Crest's declined 9%. Crest remains confident in its standalone prospects, with the company previously stating it may recommend a sweetened proposal if a firm offer is made.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources Q2 profit falls 27.8% to US$65 million
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 27.8% decrease in Q2 net profit to US$65 million, down from US$90 million in the previous period. Revenue improved 10.4% to US$2.6 billion. The company attributed the decline to higher financial expenses and unrealised foreign-exchange losses. Despite this, the downstream segment's sales volume rose 11% to US$5.1 billion, driven by a "robust" margin of 5.5%.

images.alt_text: GAR says merchandising volume of the downstream business contributes to the sales expansion.
Bursa Malaysia-listed crude palm oil futures are up about 20.8 per cent this year as at Mar 4 at RM4,345 per tonne. This is the highest price CPO futures have reached in a one-year period.
SGX-listed palm oil companies have booked positive total returns this year, despite weaker crude palm oil prices and lower average selling prices on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 13)
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 0.4% in Q2 on a seasonally adjusted basis, narrowly narrowing its 2024 growth forecast to 2-3%. External demand is expected to remain resilient, but downside risks remain. Meanwhile, prime office spaces in Singapore have a 21% price premium over the broader Grade A market, and DBS launched a blockchain-powered treasury tokens pilot for 24/7 treasury and liquidity management.

images.alt_text: ST20240228_202478689815 pixgeneric Azmi Athni// Generic of Singapore's city skyline during sunset on Feb 28 Can be used for: Business; CBD; population; work; tourism; employment; traffic; GST; Singapore ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI

site_title: Prime US Reit H1 DPU dives 92% to US$0.0018 as manager retains funds to meet capex needs
summary: US real estate investment trust Prime US Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) plummeted 92% to US$0.0018 for the first half of 2024, down from US$0.0224 in the same period last year. The move was made to preserve capital expenditure funds and meet business objectives. Despite a 7.5% decline in revenue, Prime US Reit's leasing volume more than doubled to 268,600 square feet, and leased occupancy reached 83.9%. The company also secured a new credit facility agreement worth up to US$550 million to fund capital expenditures.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit gained as much as 7.1 per cent in early morning trade on Tuesday.

site_title: German investor confidence plunges to lowest since January
summary: German investor confidence has plummeted to its lowest level since January, falling to 19.2 in August from 41.8 in July, according to the ZEW institute. This decline is attributed to disappointing data, global stock market turmoil, and high uncertainty. The economic outlook for Germany is seen as deteriorating, with a Bloomberg survey predicting little to no economic expansion this year. Output unexpectedly shrank by 0.1% in the second quarter, and persistent weakness in exports and rising bankruptcies underscore the country's manufacturing woes.

site_title: Starbucks names Brian Niccol as CEO, replacing Narasimhan
summary: Starbucks names Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol as its new CEO and chairman, replacing Laxman Narasimhan after just over a year in the role. The move comes after activist investors Elliott Investment Management and Starboard Value reportedly amassed stakes in the company, following two straight quarters of comparable sales declines. Niccol starts his new role on September 9, with the current CFO leading the company until then. Board chair Mellody Hobson downplayed Elliott's influence, stating the board took full responsibility for the weakness at Starbucks and wanted to move fast to fix the business.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Chipotle CEO Brian Niccol walks across the 14th hole during the Pro Am event prior to the Memorial Tournament presented by Workday at Muirfield Village Golf Club on June 05, 2024 in Dublin, Ohio. Starbucks said on August 13, 2024, that Niccol would be the coffee chain's new CEO, just over a year after current boss Laxman Narasimhan took over the role. Narasimhan steps down as chief executive and as a member of the Starbucks board "with immediate effect," said the company in a statement. (Photo by Dylan Buell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, August 13th, 2024 (Ep 121)
summary: Japan's Nikkei index surged 3.5% on Tuesday, driven by a weak yen. Meanwhile, Hong Kong's property market slump threatens the city's funding model. DBS launched a blockchain-powered treasury tokens pilot for 24/7 treasury and liquidity management, aiming to improve treasury and liquidity management.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian rupiah has strengthened on the back of favourable domestic conditions and global sentiment. Economists expect further relief for Asean currencies after the US Federal Reserve cuts rates in September.
Hong Kong’s office vacancy rate hit a historic high of 16.9 per cent in the first half of the year, while rental prices are expected to fall as much as 10 per cent in 2024.
Since 2016, DBS has piloted transactions involving atomic settlement use cases with tokenised bank deposits securities.

site_title: IEA trims 2025 oil demand outlook as China offsets global gains
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) trimmed its 2025 global oil demand forecast to 2.11 million barrels per day, citing China's weakened economy as a limiting factor. Despite this, the agency expects strong demand in Western economies, particularly the US, where one-third of global petrol is consumed, with the US summer driving season expected to be the strongest since the pandemic.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A coal-burning power plant can be seen behind a factory in the city of Baotou, in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, October 31, 2010.  REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo
Heatwaves will continue to push electricity demand, with May 2024 the Earth’s 12th consecutive month of record-breaking temperatures.
Global benchmark Brent crude futures settled higher at US$82.30 a barrel on Monday, gaining US$2.64, or 3.3 per cent.
Opec in a monthly report said world oil demand will rise by 2.11 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2024, down from growth of 2.25 million bpd expected last month.

site_title: DBS launches blockchain-powered treasury tokens pilot for 24/7 treasury and liquidity management
summary: DBS has launched a blockchain-powered treasury tokens pilot, enabling 24/7 treasury and liquidity management. The pilot, in collaboration with Ant International, utilizes DBS' permissioned blockchain and smart contracts to improve banking efficiencies. This move comes as businesses' treasury needs evolve to meet the rise of e-commerce and on-demand services. The pilot aims to enhance banking efficiencies and provide a more efficient treasury management system.

images.alt_text: DBS boosts digital asset push with first stablecoin tie-up

site_title: US manufacturers hit by soaring property insurance costs
summary: US manufacturers, particularly those handling hazardous materials and operating heavy machinery, are facing significant increases in property and casualty insurance costs. The cost of insuring everything from homes to cars has surged in recent years, driven by rising costs of repairs and more storm damage amid climate change. Many manufacturers, including smaller ones, are being forced to piece together coverage from multiple, higher-cost providers, leading to increased costs. The industry is concerned about the impact on operations and customer prices, with some companies considering reducing coverage or passing on the increases to customers.

images.alt_text: PE firms want to take advantage of deep American discounts after office values fell by almost a quarter last year, more than in Europe, following the pandemic work from home shift.
Goldman Sachs Asset Management (GSAM) had begun to deploy more cash in real estate in Europe and Japan over the past three months, without quantifying its investment.

The office sector, battered by remote work and declining tenant demand for space, “continued to be the driving force behind growing distress, providing 93 per cent of the additional balance for the quarter”, according to MCSI Real Assets.

site_title: China says Foreign Minister Wang to visit Myanmar, Thailand this week
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi will visit Myanmar and Thailand from August 14 to 17, co-chairing the ninth Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Foreign Ministers’ Meeting. During the trip, Wang will also attend an informal discussion with counterparts from Laos, Myanmar, and Thailand. The visit aims to deepen bilateral cooperation and provide constructive help for Myanmar to address differences through political consultation. Wang's visit comes amid ongoing conflict in Myanmar's Shan state and a recent meeting between China's special envoy and the junta chief.

images.alt_text: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi speaks at a ceremony marking the 70th anniversary of the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence, at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing on June 28, 2024. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP)

site_title: India's SBI aims to sell its Yes Bank stake worth US$2.2 billion by end-March
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) aims to sell its 24% stake in Yes Bank worth $2.2 billion by end-March. Japanese lender Sumitomo Mitsui Banking and Dubai-based Emirates NBD are in advanced talks to acquire a majority stake in Yes Bank. The Reserve Bank of India has verbally approved the proposal, and due diligence is underway. SBI is seeking relaxation on regulatory requirements and expects to make a profit of around $1.57 billion. Talks may be delayed due to market volatility and a parallel government stake sale process in IDBI Bank.

site_title: Wilmar H1 profit rises 5.2% to US$579.6 million on better feed, industrial and food products performance
summary: Wilmar International reported a net profit of US$579.6 million for the first half of 2024, a 5.2% increase from the same period last year, driven by better performance from its feed, industrial, and food products segments. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.06 per share, maintained from last year. Revenue declined 4.9% to US$30.9 billion due to decreasing commodity prices, but was cushioned by higher sales volume.

images.alt_text: Bottles of Wilmar International Ltd. Arawana brand cooking oil sit on a shelf at a supermarket in Shanghai, China, on Friday, Aug. 14, 2009. Wilmar International Ltd., the world's biggest palm oil trader, said second-quarter profit climbed 23 percent as production and processing margins of the food ingredient increased. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: China new loans hit 15-year low in July, more policy steps expected
summary: China's bank lending slowed to a 15-year low in July, with new yuan loans extending 260 billion yuan, down 88% from the previous month. Growth in outstanding yuan loans slowed to 8.7% compared to 8.8% in June. Analysts expect the People's Bank of China to take further easing steps, but may need to tread cautiously to avoid fuelling capital flight and hurting the yuan currency. The central bank's recent rate cuts have not driven significant recovery in credit demand.

site_title: Honing in is what matters amid market volatility
summary: US investors should focus on longer-term outcomes amid market volatility, rather than reacting to short-term dislocations. Softer-than-expected July jobs and ISM data have sparked fears of a US recession, but the Federal Reserve is unlikely to react until its September meeting. The US presidential election, with a potential second Trump presidency, could drive inflation and support long-dated US Treasuries. Investors should diversify portfolios across asset classes, regions, and industries, and maintain a "Neutral" stance on duration in fixed income, with a focus on shorter-term yields.

images.alt_text: Physical gold demand in India increased slightly last week due to a price correction.

Japan had become one of the favourite markets of global traders this year amid expectations that inflation will return after more than two decades of price stagnation and hopes that Japanese companies will return more cash to shareholders at the urging of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
While earnings have been a bright spot, revenue misses have been more frequent this time around, grabbing the attention of market watchers.

site_title: More Indian hospitals hit by doctors' protest against alleged rape and murder
summary: Doctors in India protested against the alleged rape and murder of a 31-year-old doctor in Kolkata, disrupting health services nationwide. Thousands of doctors marched, calling for justice and better security measures. Protests spread to cities such as Lucknow, Maharashtra, and Goa, leaving thousands of patients stranded. The Indian Medical Association stated that pedestrian working conditions, inhuman workloads, and violence in the workplace are the reality. Authorities have registered a case against the suspect and are assessing the impact on health services.

site_title: To stand out, financial advisers may evolve into advisers on clients’ well-being
summary: Financial advisers are evolving to focus on clients' overall well-being, rather than just providing generic financial services. A new book by Meir Statman explores how financial well-being is linked to life well-being, and how advisers can integrate financial planning into lifestyle choices. Statman argues that having more money is correlated with higher life well-being, but social status, education, health, and work also play important roles. To compete, financial advisers can shift from just providing financial advice to becoming well-being advisers, offering holistic support and building relationships with clients.

images.alt_text: Four pillars of investing, as espoused by the book by William Bernstein, are like the legs of a chair and serve as guiding principles for making good investment decisions.
Author Paul Sheard writes that every generation leaves to the next generation a capital stock that is always bigger and better than what it received from the prior generation

site_title: Traders hope Alphabet’s Pixel event can stem US$360 billion rout
summary: Google's Pixel event is set to unveil one of its biggest redesigns, with new AI features expected to boost its stock performance, which has fallen 15% from a high in mid-July. Investors hope the event will demonstrate Google's leadership in generative AI technologies, which has been critical to its stock performance over the past year. The event is expected to showcase native integration of its Gemini large language model for text, image, and voice-level features, potentially turning around the current sell-off and stopping a US$360 billion rout in the market.

images.alt_text: US district judge Rita Lin in San Francisco on Aug 9 dismissed the consumers’ antitrust lawsuit against Google, finding they had not provided enough factual evidence showing any harm from the Alphabet unit’s market dominance.

site_title: Ride the S-Reits revival via market leaders CICT and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit
summary: Reit investors may benefit from rising interest rates as they look for alternative yield instruments. Market leaders CICT and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit (Clar) are recommended for their decent yields, size, and strength of sponsor. The two Reits have substantial Singapore exposure, diverse property asset types, robust balance sheets, and competitive borrowing costs. Their size also allows for economies of scale, and their strong sponsor, CapitaLand Investment, is expected to support their performance. With long track records, CICT and Clar are well-positioned to navigate disruptions and challenges, making them a winning formula for investors.

images.alt_text: The latest consultation is an effort by MAS to simplify leverage requirements for Reits. It is not the first time the authority has made such a move.
The recent set-up of a committee to look at measures to revitalise the local stock market is a positive move in the right direction to re-energise the local exchange for the longer term
The average rental reversion for leases signed in H1 was positive at 13.4 per cent

site_title: India orders unusual recall of reports on Apple antitrust probe
summary: India's antitrust body, the CCI, has ordered the recall of reports on an investigation into Apple's alleged abuse of its dominant position in the apps market, following a complaint from the company that its commercial secrets were disclosed. The reports, which found Apple breached competition laws, will be revised to remove confidential information, causing a delay in the procedure. This move follows a global trend of Apple facing antitrust investigations, including a probe by the European Union.

images.alt_text: Apple's iOS powered about 3.5 per cent of 690 million smartphones in India as at mid-2024, with the rest using Android, according to Counterpoint Research.

site_title: UK grocery inflation edges higher after 17 months of decline
summary: UK grocery inflation edged higher, reaching 1.8% in the four weeks to Aug 4, marking the first increase in 17 months. This uptick follows a low rate in July, which was the lowest in almost three years. Despite this, prices are still at average levels seen before the cost of living crisis, with growth fastest in vitamin and mineral supplements and slowest in toilet tissues and dog food. Take-home grocery sales rose 3.8% year on year, with online supermarket Ocado leading the growth.

images.alt_text: Shoppers walk along Regent Street in London, Britain, July 9, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams
Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.
The S&P Global UK Services Purchasing Managers Index rose in July to 52.5 from 52.1 in June and revised up slightly from a preliminary estimate of 52.4.

site_title: Mercedes, BMW reveal EV battery makers amid fire fears in South Korea
summary: Mercedes-Benz Korea and BMW have revealed the names of their electric-vehicle battery suppliers amid growing concerns over EV safety in South Korea. The move follows a nationwide safety investigation after an unplugged electric Mercedes-Benz sedan caught fire, leading to the evacuation of 200 families. The German carmakers have offered free inspections for their EV models, and the government plans to hold a joint meeting with automakers to discuss short-term measures to prevent further EV fires. Hyundai Motor and Kia had previously shared the names of their battery makers.

images.alt_text: The logo of Mercedes-Benz is seen outside a Mercedes-Benz car dealer in Brussels, Belgium June 1, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman

FILE PHOTO: A BMW Vision Neue Klasse is displayed next to the company's logo during an event a day ahead of the official opening of the 2023 Munich Auto Show IAA Mobility, in Munich, Germany, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Angelika Warmuth/File Photo
The approval will let Mercedes start trials of its Level 4 self-driving capabilities on Beijing’s highways and urban roads.
Police move a burnt electric car from the underground parking lot of an apartment building after completing their probe in Incheon an Aug 5.
A charging plug on an electric vehicle in Guangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The supplier to automakers including Tesla and General Motors has been struggling with slowing sales of EVs and a drop in lithium prices tied to its selling prices.

site_title: Thailand to expand state equity fund by up to US$4.3 billion to invest in local stocks
summary: Thailand plans to expand a state mutual fund by $2.8-$4.3 billion to invest in local stocks, aiming to restore confidence in the capital market. The Vayupak Mutual Fund will offer new units to the public by September, focusing on companies with good returns, long-term stability, and good corporate governance. The fund's asset value is currently around $12.1 billion, with top holdings including PTT, SCBX, and Krung Thai Bank. The move comes as Thailand's main stock index has fallen 8.4% this year, amid a sluggish economy, weak currency, and political uncertainty.

site_title: Sea posts US$79.9 million Q2 profit, beating estimates
summary: Sea Ltd., a gaming and e-commerce player, reported a net profit of US$79.9 million for the second quarter, beating estimates of US$60 million. The figure represents a bounce-back from a net loss of US$23 million in the first quarter. Revenue rose 23% to US$3.8 billion, surpassing estimates of US$3.7 billion. Adjusted Ebitda was US$448.5 million, down 12.1% from the same period last year. Sea's e-commerce segment saw revenue growth, with Shopee's gross merchandise value reaching US$23.3 billion, up 29.1% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Megan Cheah
In this prolonged dry spell, caution is the name of the game.

site_title: Thai business group calls for help for firms facing ‘tsunami’ of Chinese imports
summary: Thailand's top business group, the Federation of Thai Industries, is urging the government to significantly increase subsidies for local firms participating in the country's procurement system to combat the impact of cheap Chinese imports. The group's chairman, Kriengkrai Thiennukul, recommends lifting the current 5% subsidy to 20% for two to three years to boost the economy. The move comes as Thailand's stuttering economy faces challenges, including recorded growth of 1.5% in the first quarter and nearly 2,000 factory closures in the past year, mainly from small- and medium-sized enterprises.

images.alt_text: Pichai Chunhavajira, Thailand’s finance minister, speaks at a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Thailand unveiled detailed plans for a long-delayed distribution of cash to most adult citizens, the centerpiece of government efforts to revive growth and the fortunes of the ruling coalition. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg
Less than half of Thailand’s 3.2 million SMEs have access to loans from financial institutions, according to Thailand's central bank.
“SMEs are the heart and important force of the country,” Bank of Thailand governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput said.
The government’s 500 billion baht handout scheme is not expected to lift product prices, Poonpong says.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding leads gains on Tuesday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares rallied with regional peers, led by Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which rose 14.7% after posting a 77% rise in H1 profit. The Straits Times Index gained 0.7% as gainers beat losers 347 to 179. Analysts, including Julius Baer's Mathieu Racheter, say equities have become more attractive, and now is the time to build an "equity shopping list".

images.alt_text: Tokyo’s Nikkei returned from a long weekend to lead the rally and briefly top the levels touched at the start of the month before last Monday’s rout, helped by a weaker yen and a Bank of Japan pledge not to hike interest rates further.
Yangzijiang's focus on building eco-friendly ships enabled it to secure a record number of orders.

site_title: Philippines central bank sees room to keep rates unchanged, governor says
summary: The Philippines' central bank governor, Eli Remolona, stated that there is room to maintain tight monetary policy settings, making a rate cut this month "a little bit less likely". Inflation accelerated to 4.4% in July, exceeding the central bank's target of 2.0-4.0%. Despite this, Remolona expects the central bank to eventually ease monetary policy when inflation is tamed, with a potential 25-50 basis point rate cut in the next two quarters or by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: The port of Manila on July 2, 2024. The Philippine economy grew 6.3 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: China goes to new extreme in crackdown on bond-market frenzy
summary: China's government has taken extreme measures to tighten its grip on the world's third-largest government bond market, renegeing on rural banks' purchases of government bonds in Jiangxi province. The interventions appear to be cooling a market rally that sent yields to record lows, but risk detaching the market from economic fundamentals and undermining investor confidence. The move follows recent attempts to intervene in shares and currency trading, which have deterred international money managers, and comes as foreigners pulled a record amount of money from China in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: China’s sovereign debt has rallied this year as demand for haven assets has surged due to a sluggish economy and expectations of further rate cuts.
Investors are pouring into the China bond market as banks have kept cutting deposit rates and stocks remain volatile.
The securities watchdog has recently asked major mutual fund companies to cap the duration of their new bond funds to two years.

site_title: China Everbright Water posts 8% lower H1 profit of HK$581.1 million
summary: China Everbright Water reported an 8% lower net profit of HK$581.1 million for the first half of 2024, despite a 9% higher revenue of HK$3.4 billion. The company's earnings per share fell to HK$0.2031, below the prior year's EPS of HK$0.221. A lower gross profit margin and higher direct costs contributed to the decline. The board recommended an interim dividend of HK$0.0609 per share, down from the prior year's per-share interim dividend of HK$0.0663.

images.alt_text: The clawback amounts to less than 10 per cent of bonuses at China Everbright, the main Hong Kong-listed arm of Everbright Group.
Former China Everbright Group Chairman Tang Shuangning had been under investigation by China’s anti-graft department.

China Everbright Water also said in a separate statement that chief financial officer (CFO) and executive director Luo Junling will resign as a result of “changes in work arrangements” without specifying the changes.
China Everbright Water's board proposes a final dividend of HK$0.0581 per share.

site_title: Japan parliament asks central bank governor Ueda to discuss rate hike
summary: Japan's parliament will request Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda to discuss the July 31 interest rate hike, a 15-year high, in separate sessions on Aug 23. The decision was made in response to the market's reaction, which saw the Nikkei benchmark's biggest selloff since the 1987 Black Monday crash. The central bank's readiness to hike borrowing costs further, coupled with US recession fears, prompted the call for Ueda's explanation. The move aims to provide clarity on the central bank's decision and its implications for the economy.

site_title: UK regular pay rises by annual 5.4% in three months to June
summary: The UK's average weekly earnings, excluding bonuses, rose 5.4% in the three months to June, exceeding the Bank of England's (BOE) inflation target. This growth rate is double the BOE's expected pace for medium-term inflation control. The BOE will continue to monitor wage growth, which may impact inflation, and cut interest rates after a 16-year high. Employers expect lower inflation to reduce wage pressure, with a 3% pay rise forecast, the lowest in two years.

images.alt_text: Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.
Bellway said buyer confidence was improving after a drop in mortgage rates.
Some 980 homeowner mortgaged properties were taken into possession between March and June.

site_title: Robots and AI are aiming to make IVF cheaper
summary: A US startup, Conceivable Life Sciences, is developing robots and AI to automate the IVF process, aiming to improve success rates and lower costs. The technology has shown promising results, with 19 pregnancies achieved in small studies. However, experts remain skeptical, citing the need for human input and the potential for errors. The startup has raised $20 million in seed funding and plans to expand its technology, which could revolutionize the $40 billion fertility industry and make IVF treatments more accessible.

images.alt_text: A medical technician selects eggs for an IVF procedure. At stake is a US$40 billion US industry that is expected to triple in size over the next decade as more people delay having babies until later in life – and more women freeze eggs in anticipation.

A medical technician selects eggs for an in-vitro fertilization (IVF) procedure (top). The gay couple said they were forced to put off having a family for years because the city’s employee health insurance plan denied them coverage for IVF procedures.

site_title: CGS International Clinches Over 50 Awards in 1H2024, Highlights Excellence as Asia’s Leading Investment Bank
summary: CGS International Securities has achieved 53 awards in the first half of 2024, including 16 number one rankings at the Institutional Investor Awards 2024. The firm received top recognitions in financial services, workplace, and corporate social responsibility, solidifying its market-leading position as Asia's leading investment bank. CGS International's commitment to creating a positive impact in the communities it serves was also highlighted, with awards for sustainability and CSR initiatives.

site_title: UK unemployment dips unexpectedly, but growth in wages slows
summary: UK unemployment fell 0.2 percentage points to 4.2% in the three months to June, a surprise drop. However, wage growth cooled to 5.4%, the weakest year-on-year pay increase since 2022. The Bank of England is watching the labour market closely for signs of inflation, with officials concerned about a shortage of workers driving up wages and inflation. The pound rose after the data, with investors betting on the next interest rate cut in November.

images.alt_text: Officials expect inflation to continue to edge higher over the rest of the year before cooling again, though hot services prices risks causing price pressures to linger.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation quickens to fastest in nearly a year
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation accelerated to its fastest pace in 11 months in July, rising 3% year-over-year, matching market forecasts. The corporate goods price index hit a record high for the eighth straight month. A weak yen drove up commodity import bills, contributing to the increase. The Bank of Japan's interest rate hike in July and potential further hikes will scrutinize the inflation data. The yen-based import price index climbed 10.8% year-over-year, reflecting the yen's weakness and rising raw materials prices.

site_title: Blackstone sells 3,000 homes to UK pension fund for £405 million
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative-asset manager, has sold 3,000 homes in the UK to the Universities Superannuation Scheme for £405 million (S$686 million). This deal is the second-largest residential sale in the UK this year, following a £580 million deal in May. The sale is part of Blackstone's strategy to invest in residential property with shorter leases to capture rising rents. This move comes as the firm anticipates a supply shortage in the market.

site_title: Singapore 7th most expensive market for prime offices: Savills
summary: Singapore ranks 7th globally in terms of the cost of prime office spaces, with a net effective cost of US$146.07 per square foot. This represents a 21% price premium over the broader Grade A market. The study found that prime offices globally experienced a 3% year-on-year increase in gross rents, while net costs rose 3.8%. Experts predict continued demand for prime spaces despite slow market movement, with rent increases ranging from -1 to 1% for top-grade offices.

images.alt_text: Tourism in the city cratered after the pandemic and remains down 40 per cent from 2019, according to Hong Kong Tourism Board data.
Construction delays have pushed back the building’s completion to spring 2025, from an initial target of late 2022.
Singapore skyline at sunset, 14 May 2024. Marina Bay Sands, MBS, Singapore Flyer, Benjamin Sheares Bridge, Gardens by the Bay, GBTB, Sunset, Central Business District, CBD

site_title: People leave New Zealand in record numbers as economy bites
summary: New Zealand has seen a record number of people leave the country, with 131,200 departing in the year ended June 2024, primarily due to economic factors such as high unemployment, interest rates, and low economic growth. Around a third of those leaving are headed to Australia, where job opportunities and relocation packages are more available. This trend is expected to continue as foreign nationals also seek better economic prospects elsewhere.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand aircraft sit on the tarmac at the International Terminal of Auckland Airport in Auckland, New Zealand. Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg

site_title: Economists keep 2024 GDP forecasts after expected narrowing of official forecast to 2-3%
summary: Singapore's Q2 GDP growth remained steady at 2.9% on year and 0.4% sequentially, as economists maintained their 2024 full-year growth forecast of 2-3% despite the Ministry of Trade and Industry's narrowed forecast. The manufacturing sector contracted, while services sector growth improved due to better-than-expected performance. Private-sector economists, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, kept their forecasts at the upper end of the official forecast range. The government expects growth to stay at 2-3% over the medium term, barring downside risks in the global economy.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Generic photo of the economy landscape of Singapore. Stories regarding navigating the economic landscape of Singapore. On Singapore innovation, enhancing ESG capabilities, and encouraging collaboration stories.
Singapore lowers full-year NODX forecast, expects growth of 4-5%
On a seasonally adjusted, quarterly basis, Singapore's economy contracted/expanded x per cent in Q2.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit prices S$100 million perpetual capital securities at 6%
summary: ESR-Logos Reit priced S$100 million perpetual capital securities at 6% as part of its S$750 million multicurrency debt issuance programme. The funds will be used to finance the acquisition of two facilities in Japan and Singapore, with the trust's FY2023 pro-forma distribution per unit expected to rise 3% to S$0.02641. The issuance size was reduced from S$194 million due to the preferential offering size.

site_title: Martian subsurface harbours oceans of life-giving liquid water
summary: A study using NASA's Mars InSight lander data has found evidence of liquid water beneath the Martian surface, advancing the search for life on the planet. The lander measured seismic data over four years, revealing liquid water was likely present deep beneath the surface. This finding confirms geological studies that show Mars' surface had lakes, rivers, and oceans more than three billion years ago, making water essential for life. The discovery provides new insights into Mars' ancient oceans and the possibility of life existing beneath the surface.

images.alt_text: epa09043579 A handout photo made available by NASA shows an image of rocks and soil around NASA's Perseverance Mars rover acquired by using its onboard Left Navigation Camera (Navcam), on Sol 9, the ninth Martian day of the mission 28 February 2021. The camera is located high on the rover's mast and aids in driving. Perseverance's main mission on Mars is astrobiology and the search for signs of ancient microbial life, according to NASA. site_title: Runway at Japan’s Narita airport closed due to emergency landing of cargo plane: NHK
summary: One runway at Japan's Narita airport near Tokyo has been closed due to the emergency landing of a cargo plane, which suffered a punctured tire. No crew members were injured in the incident. The repair of the plane is expected to be completed by around 8 am local time.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei surges 3.5% after boost from weak yen
summary: Japan's Nikkei index surged 3.5% on Tuesday, its session peak at 36,232.51, driven by a weaker yen and tech shares. The broader Topix rose 2.8%. Key gainers included Tokyo Electron (6.2%), Advantest (7.7%), Sony Group (5%), and Toyota Motor (3.3%). A weaker yen inflates the value of overseas sales when repatriated, boosting Japanese exports. The Japanese currency declined 0.3% to 147.64 per dollar, extending a 0.4% slide from overnight.

images.alt_text: Markets are waiting for data due this week on Japanese second-quarter economic growth and US inflation.

site_title: South Korea to set guidelines to speed up switch to new interest rate swaps benchmark: sources
summary: South Korea plans to announce guidelines to encourage the use of the Korea Overnight Financing Repo rate (KOFR) in its US$4.3 trillion interest rate swap market, aiming to replace Certificate of Deposit (CD) rates. The Bank of Korea and Financial Services Commission are working on transaction guidelines to introduce the KOFR-linked Overnight Index Swap market. This move aims to address fluctuations in CD rates and replace CD rates with the KOFR, a locally developed alternative reference rate. The transition is expected to speed up the switch to the new benchmark.

images.alt_text: Police move a burnt electric car from the underground parking lot of an apartment building after completing their probe in Incheon an Aug 5.
Kim Beom Su, founder of South Korean internet company Kakao, arrives at a court in Seoul, South Korea, July 22, 2024.
Export growth slowed in July, suggesting a slight cooling in global demand.

site_title: Gold hovers near one-week peak as investors gear up for US inflation data
summary: Gold prices hovered near a one-week high, easing 0.2% to $2,466.69 per ounce, ahead of US inflation data that may influence the Federal Reserve's next policy decision. Traders expect a 50% chance of a 50 basis point interest rate cut in September, which could boost gold prices. The US producer price index and consumer price index will be released later this week, with traders expecting a 0.2% month-on-month rise in headline and core prices.

images.alt_text: Physical gold demand in India increased slightly last week due to a price correction.

site_title: CICT posts 2.5% rise in H1 DPU to S$0.0543 despite higher finance costs
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 2.5% rise in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0543, despite higher finance costs. Net property income increased 5.4% to S$582.4 million, driven by lower utility expenses and property management savings. Gallileo, a Grade A commercial building in Frankfurt, achieved 96.7% committed occupancy despite undergoing an asset enhancement initiative. CICT's office and retail segments experienced healthy occupancy rates, with the overall portfolio occupancy at 96.8%.

images.alt_text: CICT has commenced asset enhance initiatives for IMM Building (pictured) in Singapore and Gallileo in Frankfurt.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding up 15% on robust H1 earnings
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 77.2% increase in first-half net profit to 3.1 billion yuan, driven by a 15.3% rise in revenue to 13 billion yuan, mainly due to strong shipbuilding business. The company secured a record number of orders for eco-friendly ships, with a record-high order book of US$20.2 billion. Its shares gained 14.3% to S$2.72, following a 15.1% surge on Tuesday morning.

site_title: US, Japan keen on US$15 billion Philippine projects as ties grow
summary: The US and Japan are interested in funding at least $15 billion worth of projects on the Philippines' main island, Luzon, as part of the country's Luzon Economic Corridor plan. This move is seen as a result of strengthened security ties between the Philippines and its allies, including the US. The projects, which include a cargo rail and renewable energy, are expected to be prioritized and may be Marcos' flagship investment program. The Philippines is seeking to leverage its ties with the US and its allies to unlock economic benefits and catch up with neighboring countries in terms of investments.

images.alt_text: The port of Manila on July 2, 2024. The Philippine economy grew 6.3 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier.

Philippine consumer prices rose 4.4 per cent on-year last month, exceeding the 4.1 per cent median forecast of economists in a Bloomberg News survey and surpassing the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas’ target for the first time this year.

site_title: Overseas investors turn bearish on Japanese equities after brutal sell-off
summary: Global investors are turning bearish on Japanese equities following a brutal sell-off, driven by concerns over the yen's surge, Bank of Japan rate hikes, and doubts on Japan's economic prospects. The Nikkei index has seen its worst one-day sell-off since 1987, with some analysts warning that the sell-off may continue due to expectations of yen appreciation. Investors are reassessing their exposure to Japanese stocks, with some hedge funds dumping equities at the fastest pace in over five years, and long-term investors cutting their exposure.

images.alt_text: Japan had become one of the favourite markets of global traders this year amid expectations that inflation will return after more than two decades of price stagnation and hopes that Japanese companies will return more cash to shareholders at the urging of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

site_title: Polish billionaire plans to sue Meta over fake advertisements
summary: Polish billionaire Rafal Brzoska and his wife plan to sue Meta over fake advertisements featuring their faces and false information on Facebook and Instagram. Despite reporting the issue in July, Meta failed to resolve the problem. Brzoska is considering filing a private lawsuit in the US or Europe, demanding Meta stop promoting violating content and seeking compensation. A recent court order in Poland also forced Meta to stop displaying the ads for three months.

images.alt_text: The renewed agreement also addresses the issue of compensation for artists and songwriters, Universal Music Group said.
Issuing bonds now gives firms like Meta increased financial flexibility even if they have large sums of cash on its balance sheet.
Malaysian government officials met with Meta representatives on Monday and later issued a missive calling the removal “discriminatory, unjust and a blatant suppression of free expression.”
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim accused Meta of “cowardice” last week for removing his posts.

site_title: Singapore lowers full-year NODX forecast, expects growth of 4-5%
summary: Singapore lowered its full-year exports forecast to 4-5% growth, down from 4-6% previously, citing a weaker-than-expected recovery in the second half of 2024. Non-electronics exports declined year on year for the second straight quarter, while electronics Non-Overall Merchandise Trade (NODX) grew for the first time in eight quarters. The decline in non-electronic NODX was driven by a fall in pharmaceuticals exports. Key downside risks remain, including a weaker-than-expected recovery in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Singapore NODX could come at ‘lower range of 4-6% forecast’: EnterpriseSG

site_title: Sun Life beats profit estimates on strong growth in Canada, Asia
summary: Sun Life Financial, Canada's second-largest life insurer, beat analysts' estimates for quarterly profit with strong sales in Canada and Asia, surpassing average estimates of C$1.58 per share with C$1.72 per share. Underlying net income rose 8.7% to C$1 billion, driven by 19% growth in Asia and 8% growth in Canada. The company has also inked several deals in Asia, including a bancassurance deal with Dah Sing Bank, to expand its presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Manulife's Asia business, which includes operations in 12 markets and over a hundred bank partnerships, is among the biggest income generators for the insurer.
Sun Life’s US business has been under pressure owing to a change in Medicaid dental policies.

site_title: Thailand to form credit guarantee agency to boost small business loans
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a plan to establish a national credit guarantee agency to improve loan access for small businesses, particularly those with limited access to financial institutions. The agency will provide financial risk guarantees for smaller firms seeking loans from banks, aiming to address the issue of less than half of Thailand's 3.2 million SMEs having access to loans. The agency is expected to take six months to be drafted, with initial credit guarantees worth 50 billion baht (S$1.88 billion) already approved. This move aims to boost the economy by supporting key SMEs.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% at 3,368.54. The STI gained initially but fell as the broader market saw losers outnumbering gainers 72 to 60. Top gainers included Sats and Seatrium, while Genting Singapore's shares fell 0.6%. The decline follows overnight gains in global markets and comes ahead of a US Federal Reserve speech later this week.

images.alt_text: Sats returned to black with a net profit of S$65 million for the first quarter of its new fiscal year, from a loss of S$29.9 million over the same period a year earlier.

site_title: Carlyle delays Asia buyout fund close as Japan pool saps demand
summary: Carlyle Group has delayed closing its pan-Asian buyout fund due to decreased demand, particularly from investors interested in a Japan-focused vehicle. The fund, which aims to raise $8.5 billion, has received only $3 billion in commitments so far, significantly lower than its target. The delay is attributed to increased scrutiny among global investors about overpaying for assets and exit opportunities, leading to more rigorous due diligence.

images.alt_text: Private equity firms are flourishing in Japan after struggling for years to shake off a perception that they are vultures.
FILE PHOTO: McDonald's Golden Arches are seen next to a Starbucks at the Union Square location in New York January 29, 2015. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Carlyle’s downsizing comes as private equity firms struggle to cash out on their assets amid volatility caused by conflicts in the Middle East and Europe, rising inflation and higher interest rates.

site_title: J&J gets plaintiff backing for US$6.5 billion baby powder accord
summary: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) has secured backing from over 75% of plaintiffs for its $6.5 billion settlement plan to resolve thousands of lawsuits claiming its baby powder caused ovarian and other gynaecological cancers. The settlement includes claims of talc-based powder causing ovarian and other gynaecological cancers. The company, which has already resolved 95% of claims its baby powder was tainted with asbestos, may seek to fast-track a "pre-packaged" bankruptcy filing in Texas if the plan is certified.

images.alt_text: In its settlement with 42 states and the District of Columbia, Johnson & Johnson did not admit wrongdoing, even though it withdrew its talcum-based powder from the North American market in 2020.
The deal has potential for an additional milestone payment, J&J said.

site_title: Sale of Suntec City strata office units expected to fetch S$57.1 million
summary: A portfolio of strata office units in Suntec City, comprising the entire floor on level 38 and two units on level 16, has been put up for sale via an expression of interest with a total guide price of S$57.1 million. The units offer "exceptional panoramic views" of the Central Business District and surrounding cityscape, and are currently owner-occupied. The sale is expected to fetch S$57.1 million, with individual unit guide prices ranging from S$3,150 to S$3,350 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Strata retail sales down 32.1% in H1 to S$215.5 million; strata office deals take a dip
Office space prices are up 3.1 per cent in Q2, compared with a 1.2 per cent decrease in the first quarter.
The office floor has a 99-year leasehold tenure starting from 1989.

site_title: Australia consumers brighten up as rate fears ease, tax cuts kick in
summary: Australian consumer sentiment improved in August, rising 2.8% from July, as rate fears subsided and tax cuts took effect. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment reached 85, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. The index, which measures whether it's a good time to buy major household items, rose 0.6% to 82.6, its lowest level since 2018. The improvement is attributed to the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to leave interest rates unchanged and the impact of government tax cuts and cost-of-living measures.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank has held its policy steady since November, judging the current cash rate of 4.35 per cent - up from the 0.1 per cent during the pandemic - is restrictive enough to bring inflation to target while preserving employment gains.

Even during a period of Covid-19 measures that closed many pubs, clubs and casinos in the 2020-2021 financial year, Australian state government statistics showed gambling losses exceeded A$24 billion.
Issuance of catastrophe bonds hit a record high in June, as the market braced for a rough hurricane season with the potential to do substantial damage.

Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock, in a speech in her home town of Armidale, New South Wales, reiterated that the board was vigilant to the upside risk of inflation, days after the bank decided to hold rates steady.

site_title: Recession may be the only thing that can save Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is trailing Democratic challenger Kamala Harris in the polls, with a recession potentially being the only factor that can save him. Despite celebrating recent market developments on social media, blaming the Biden administration, Trump's chances are dwindling. Harris has gained momentum, with recent polls showing her edging ahead of Trump by up to three percentage points. Her selection of Tim Walz as vice-presidential running mate could extend her lead, particularly among rural voters. A recession could shift momentum back in Trump's favor, but for now, Harris appears to be gaining ground.

images.alt_text: Whether market conviction around the recession narrative gains momentum depends entirely on the reaction function of the US Federal Reserve.
US Vice President Kamala Harris has clinched the Democratic presidential nomination and is enjoying a super-charged wave of popularity and donations.
The recent set-up of a committee to look at measures to revitalise the local stock market is a positive move in the right direction to re-energise the local exchange for the longer term

site_title: It can cost more to power a house than rent it in Pakistan
summary: Pakistan's electricity bills have surpassed home rental rates for some people due to a 155% surge in tariff increases since 2021. The country's chronic economic crisis has led to widespread protests, with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif announcing a 50 billion rupees subsidy to cushion the poorest users. As part of an IMF bailout program, Pakistan aims to restore energy sector viability through cost cuts and privatization of state-owned power distribution companies, addressing losses of 16% of generated electricity due to theft and inefficiencies.

site_title: Asia: Stocks build on gains ahead of US inflation data
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei leading the rally, as investors became more optimistic ahead of US inflation data and a Bank of Japan pledge not to hike interest rates further. The Nikkei briefly topped levels touched at the start of the month before last week's rout, driven by a weaker yen. Oil prices remained up about 8% for the week due to concerns about a possible conflict in the Middle East. However, investors remain cautious due to worries about a US recession and geopolitical concerns.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 80 to 35.
The Stoxx 600 index closed on a flat note on Monday, after last week’s muted performance as the continent-wide index rebounded from last Monday’s sharp selloff in risk assets on US recession fears.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4 per cent to 39,357.01, while the broad-based S&P 500 was flat at 5,344.39 on Monday.

site_title: SpaceX plans crewed mission to observe Earth’s polar areas
summary: SpaceX plans to launch its sixth commercial crewed mission, Fram2, in late 2024, sending a four-person team to fly over the polar regions of Earth. The mission, commanded by Chun Wang, will observe Earth's poles and conduct research experiments. This will be the first human spaceflight mission to fly over Earth's poles. The crew will spend three to five days aboard SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft, marking the company's 14th human spaceflight mission.

site_title: The age-old leasehold question
summary: Singapore's housing market remains a hot-button issue, with the government considering changes to curb prices. The resale market for public housing, including HDB flats, may come under scrutiny, and lease decay in old public housing flats is a growing concern. Meanwhile, a bumper crop of retail and hospitality assets are up for sale, with several high-profile developments on the market, including Tekka Place and Golden Mile Tower. Experts warn that ageing 99-year-leasehold properties may not depreciate as expected, and rental income can still make up for declining values.

images.alt_text: In a nation where much of household wealth is tied to one’s residential property, the housing market remains a hot-button issue for Singaporeans and the government, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Hong Kong’s collapsing land sales threaten city’s funding model
summary: Hong Kong's government revenue from land sales, a key source of income, is collapsing due to the city's real estate slump. The office vacancy rate hit a historic high of 16.9% in the first half of 2024, while rental prices are expected to fall 10% in 2024. This has led to a significant shortfall in land-related revenue, with the government's fiscal year 2023-2024 revenue from land dropping to HK$19.6 billion, 77% below the official budget estimate. The city is now expected to issue close to HK$95.8 billion in debt this year, with a focus on cutting spending and developing new industries to mitigate the structural deficit.

images.alt_text: A slew of luxury residential units are hitting the market as rich local families have been caught up by a debt crunch.
FILE PHOTO: People cross a street in a shopping area of the Central business district in Hong Kong, China August 22, 2019. Picture taken August 22, 2019.  REUTERS/Thomas Peter
Tourism in the city cratered after the pandemic and remains down 40 per cent from 2019, according to Hong Kong Tourism Board data.
Centaline has branches across mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau.

site_title: US consumers’ delinquency fears rise to highest level since 2020
summary: US consumers' delinquency fears have risen to the highest level since 2020, with a 13.3% likelihood of missing a minimum debt payment in the next three months, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey. This increase in stress disproportionately affects low-income earners and those with limited education. The findings align with weakening labor market data and rising unemployment, prompting the Federal Reserve to focus on employment as inflation cools. Policymakers are expected to cut borrowing costs as early as September.

images.alt_text: Housing has been one of the main contributors to post-pandemic inflation, and further improvement in rental supply should help bring headline rates lower.

The emerging clusters of unsheltered migrants in New York may indicate that two of the city's most vexing challenges are becoming intertwined.
The Commerce Department’s Census Bureau said on Thursday (Aug 8) that wholesale inventories rose 0.2 per cent in June as previously estimated.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 233,000 for the week ended Aug 3, the Labor Department said.
The latest US jobs report, which showed a material slowdown in hiring and an unexpected pickup in joblessness, heightened these concerns.

site_title: Musk pitches White House cost-cutting role in glitchy Trump conversation
summary: Elon Musk participated in a rambling conversation with former US President Donald Trump on the X social media network, where Trump discussed various conspiracy theories and made dismissive comments about climate change and President Joe Biden. Trump also expressed interest in developing a new missile defense system and dismissed the idea of a "zombie apocalypse" of immigration. The conversation was initially derailed by a technical glitch, and Musk attempted to address the issue, but the exchange was largely one-sided and focused on Trump's views.
