Vice-President Kamala Harris’s view contrasts sharply with that of Donald Trump, who has said that US presidents should have a say over the Fed’s decisions.
The interview on Musk’s social media platform could allow Trump to reach a different audience than the conservative faithful who attend his rallies and watch his interviews on Fox News.

X had recently started “irreversibly feeding” the personal data of more than 60 million European users into its Grok AI technology, “without ever informing them or asking for their consent”, according to the European Centre for Digital Rights, also known as Noyb.
Tesla Cybertruck has an unconventional trapezoidal exterior design inspired by the “Blade Runner” movie and a stainless steel body.
The lawsuit is the latest in a series of legal actions taken against Elon Musk.
The letter calls presidential candidate Kamala Harris an “archetypical innovator” and “champion of technology”.
Tesla's experience centre in Kuala Lumpur. The US-based EV maker had previously in July 2023 committed to set up a country head office and service centres in Selangor.

site_title: GM cuts China jobs as it resets in world’s biggest car market
summary: General Motors (GM) is cutting staff in China, with a focus on research and development, as part of a strategic overhaul of its operations in the country. The move is a recognition that GM's sales in China are unlikely to return to 2017 peak levels, due to intense competition from local brands. Despite this, GM will continue to produce less expensive vehicles and electric vehicles locally in partnership with Saic Motor and Wuling Motors, with some for export to other markets. The company aims to redirect its American nameplates sold in China.

images.alt_text: Cruise has been working to rebuild the business by overhauling top management with a new chief executive officer and by mending relationships with regulators

GM said it would produce EVs in Lansing at a future date and declined to discuss details of the planned models.
GM expects to exhaust the remaining US$1.1 billion of the prior plan by the end of this quarter.
General Motors did not increase chief executive officer Mary Barra’s target compensation for 2024.

site_title: Paris Olympics average 30.6 million viewers, 82% bump from Tokyo
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympics averaged 30.6 million US viewers per day, an 82% increase from the Tokyo Olympics. The NBC broadcast network, cable channels, and Peacock streaming service were among the platforms that drew viewers. Sunday's closing ceremony attracted a US audience of 20.8 million, more than double Tokyo's. Warner Bros Discovery and the BBC also reported significant viewership, with 215 million and 218 million streams, respectively, more than doubling Tokyo's numbers.

site_title: When Olympic sponsors go rogue
summary: The French luxury goods conglomerate LVMH, owned by Bernard Arnault, agreed to pay $175 million to underwrite the Paris Olympics' organizing committee. As a result, LVMH-owned companies such as Chaumet, Berluti, and Louis Vuitton provided exclusive Olympic sponsorship, including medal designs, parade uniforms, and event trays. However, the extent of the company's involvement was not publicly disclosed until a private gathering, where Antoine Arnault revealed the secret partnerships. This move has raised questions about the level of corporate influence and sponsorship in Olympic events.

site_title: Singapore narrows 2024 growth forecast to higher end, at 2-3%; no revision to Q2 GDP
summary: Singapore has narrowed its full-year growth forecast for 2024 to 2-3%, from 1-3% previously, as gross domestic product growth for the second quarter came in at 2.9%. The economy is expected to remain resilient, with external demand outlook remaining strong, but downside risks from global economic uncertainties persist. The manufacturing sector is anticipated to recover gradually in the second half, with electronics and precision engineering sectors expected to benefit from robust demand.

site_title: Leveraging digitalisation for business growth
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must continue to digitally transform to remain competitive in today's dynamic landscape. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the move to the cloud, with industries such as retail and healthcare seeing significant changes. Digital solutions have helped SMEs streamline operations, enhance customer relationships, and innovate, enabling them to maintain a competitive edge. Key benefits include increased operational efficiency, improved customer experiences, and enhanced productivity. SMEs can take the first step by implementing foundational tools such as cloud accounting or customer relationship management, and working with experts to evaluate workflows and identify pain points.

images.alt_text: By embracing training initiatives proactively, small businesses can thrive in today’s dynamic business landscape.

site_title: Fitch cuts Israel’s credit rating to ‘A’ as Middle East tensions rise
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Israel's credit rating to 'A' from 'A+' due to worsening geopolitical risks amid the ongoing war in Gaza. The agency maintains a "negative" outlook, forecasting Israel's debt to rise beyond 2025 if military spending and economic uncertainties persist. The downgrade comes as the conflict in Gaza has cost thousands of lives and unfolded into a humanitarian crisis, with Fitch predicting the conflict could last well into 2025 and potentially broaden to other fronts.

site_title: OUE sinks into the red with S$96.1 million H1 loss
summary: OUE Limited reported a net loss of S$96.1 million for its first half, down from a net profit of S$40.2 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 3.3% to S$314.5 million, driven by growth in its real estate and "others" segments. Higher finance expenses, tax expenses, and lower net change in fair value of investments contributed to the loss. The company's loss per share was 11.42 Singapore cents, down from 4.75 cents the previous year. An interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share was declared.

site_title: China’s Human Horizons seeks up to 300 million yuan in debt financing to revive EV production
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Human Horizons is seeking up to 300 million yuan in debt financing to revive EV production. The company, which suspended production in February, will use the funds for guaranteeing after-sales services and restarting work, production, and sales. This follows bankruptcy proceedings by other Chinese EV makers, including units of China Evergrande and WM Motor. Human Horizons' parent firm, Hiphi, has filed for a pre-bankruptcy process, highlighting the challenges facing the Chinese EV industry.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher in lead up to data deluge
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, August 12, as they attempt to recover from a decline early last week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.02%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.24%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.45% ahead of data releases, including US consumer prices.

summary: Straits Trading Company reported a 64.9% drop in net profit to S$5.2 million for the six months ended June 30, due to increased costs in tin mining. Revenue rose 7.1% to S$252.5 million, primarily from fair-value gains in its logistics properties. The company's balance sheet remains robust, with S$476.3 million in cash and bank balances. site_title: Oil prices jump on prospect of widening Middle East war shrinking supply
summary: Oil prices surged by 3.3% on Monday, reaching US$82.30 a barrel, amid expectations of a widening Middle Eastern conflict that could tighten global crude oil supplies. The US Defence Department announced plans to send a guided missile submarine to the region, while Iran and Hezbollah vowed to retaliate for the assassinations of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah military commander Fuad Shukr. The conflict could lead to embargos on Iranian crude exports, affecting 1.5 million barrels per day of supply, and boost prices.

site_title: Earth registers hottest July on record: US agency
summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) reported that July 2024 was the hottest July on record, with a global temperature 1.21 degrees Celsius above the 20th-century average. This marks the 14th straight record-breaking month, with 2024 now having a 77% chance of being the warmest year on record. The trend of record-breaking heat continues, with Africa, Europe, and Asia recording their hottest July on record, and North America the second hottest. Ocean temperatures were their second warmest ever in July.

images.alt_text: Floodwater from the rivers Avon and Severn surrounds Tewkesbury Abbey in the aftermath of Storm Henk in Tewkesbury, Britain, Jan 8, 2024. site_title: US SEC sues over alleged US$650 million global crypto fraud
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sued NovaTech and its co-founders, Cynthia and Eddy Petion, alleging they raised over $650 million from 200,000 investors worldwide through a global crypto fraud. The SEC claims the Petions used new money to repay earlier investors and pay commissions, while syphoning millions for themselves. The scheme lasted four years until NovaTech's May 2023 collapse. The SEC also charged six NovaTech promoters with fraud, seeking restitution for victims and civil fines.

images.alt_text: Three Arrows, once one of crypto’s most famous hedge funds, collapsed soon after Luna and TerraUSD crashed along with a handful of other large crypto businesses.

site_title: Google wins dismissal of US consumer lawsuit over mobile search
summary: A US district judge, Rita Lin, has dismissed a consumer lawsuit against Google, finding that the plaintiffs did not provide enough factual evidence to show harm from the Alphabet unit's market dominance. However, she allowed the consumers to file an amended lawsuit citing a separate ruling that found Google's exclusive contracts with Apple and other companies created an illegal monopoly. The ruling gives consumers some hope, but Google has denied the allegations and plans to appeal.

images.alt_text: Google illegally monopolised the search market through exclusive deals, a judge ruled on Aug 5,  handing the US government a win in its first major antitrust case against a tech giant in more than two decades.

US District Court Judge Amit Mehta found that Google had a monopoly for search and for text ads through exclusive distribution agreements that made it the “default” option that people were likely to use on devices.

site_title: Man City hearing over Premier League charges may be brought forward: report
summary: Manchester City's hearing over alleged Premier League charges may be brought forward to September, according to a report. The 10-week hearing, initially scheduled for November, could begin in mid-to-late September, potentially leading to points deductions or even relegation if found guilty. The outcome of a separate legal case is also due soon, which may allow the hearing to proceed. Manchester City deny all 115 charges, which cover alleged breaches of regulations and financial rules between 2009 and 2023.

site_title: Heat killed nearly 50,000 in Europe in 2023: study
summary: A new study published in Nature Medicine found that heat-related deaths in Europe reached nearly 50,000 in 2023, with 47,690 deaths attributed to heat, making it the world's warmest year and Europe's second-warmest year on record. The study, which analyzed temperature and mortality records from 35 countries, highlighted that older people were most at risk, with countries in southern Europe worst affected by the heat. The authors called for more effective strategies to reduce mortality burdens from forthcoming hotter summers due to climate change.

site_title: Elon Musk to interview Trump on X social media network
summary: Elon Musk is set to interview Donald Trump on his X social media platform, allowing Trump to reach a different audience than his conservative supporters. The interview, scheduled for Tuesday, aims to inject surprise into the US presidential election. Trump's campaign has been seen as sagging, with Democratic candidate Kamala Harris gaining momentum. Musk, who has backed Trump's campaign, faces criticism for his handling of hate speech and controversy surrounding his endorsement of Trump.

images.alt_text: X had recently started “irreversibly feeding” the personal data of more than 60 million European users into its Grok AI technology, “without ever informing them or asking for their consent”, according to the European Centre for Digital Rights, also known as Noyb.

Elon Musk emerges as a central character in the US presidential race.

site_title: New Zealand to loosen gene editing regulation, make commercialisation easier
summary: New Zealand is set to introduce new legislation to make commercializing gene editing technologies easier, with the goal of having the law passed and a regulator in operation by the end of 2025. The current regulations, which consider gene editing the same as genetic modification, are seen as a barrier to research. Under the new law, low-risk gene editing techniques will be exempted from regulation, and local authorities will no longer be able to prevent the use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The changes aim to bring New Zealand's laws up to global best practice and capitalize on the benefits of gene technologies.

images.alt_text: The economy is showing signs of entering its third recession in less than two years and inflation has slowed more than the RBNZ expected.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast a 4.7 per cent unemployment rate and a 0.2 per cent contraction in employment.

New Zealand’s economy has stalled after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) rapidly raised interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: US: Stocks in wait-and-see mode ahead of inflation data
summary: US stocks were mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% and the S&P 500 flat, ahead of the release of US inflation data this week. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.2%. Investors are watching for a report on the consumer price index, which could influence the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates in September. The market is monitoring inflation trends, hoping for a "soft landing" where price increases ease without a downturn.

images.alt_text: Stocks are trying to recover from a hammering early last week, with investors gearing up for a deluge of data including US consumer prices.

site_title: PropNex H1 profit falls 13.8% to S$19 million
summary: PropNex, a real estate agency, reported a 13.8% decline in net profit to S$19 million for the first half of 2024, compared to S$22.1 million in the same period last year. The company's earnings per share also fell by the same percentage. The board proposed an interim dividend of S$0.0225 per share, lower than the previous year's S$0.025 per-share dividend. Despite this, the executive chairman and CEO, Ismail Gafoor, expressed cautious optimism about the private residential property outlook for 2024.

images.alt_text: Ismail Gafoor, CEO of PropNex, says the company's FY2023 performance was resilient.

site_title: Europe: Shares muted as investors brace for data-packed week
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Monday, erasing early gains, amid investors' anticipation of key US inflation data and European data releases. The index rebounded from last week's sharp selloff due to US recession fears. Energy and basic resources led sectoral gains, while real estate declined 0.9%. Investors are focused on the US Fed's potential rate cut, with a 46% chance of a 50-basis-point cut priced in. Trading volumes in August are expected to be lower due to summer holidays.

images.alt_text: Bankers were already bracing for a slower second-half after more than US$14 billion was raised on European stock exchanges in the first six months for this year, marking the best first-half for the region since the global IPO boom of 2021.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4 per cent to 39,357.01, while the broad-based S&P 500 was flat at 5,344.39 on Monday.

site_title: Three Arrows liquidators seek US$1.3 billion over 2022 Luna crash
summary: Liquidators for failed hedge fund Three Arrows Capital are seeking at least US$1.3 billion from TerraForm Labs, the bankrupt digital assets business co-founded by Do Kwon, for losses suffered after the 2022 crash of his related TerraUSD and Luna tokens. The liquidators claim TerraForm manipulated the market to artificially inflate the price of these tokens before they crashed, causing substantial losses for Three Arrows. This claim comes after a jury found TerraForm and Kwon liable for fraud in a US government lawsuit over Luna's collapse.

site_title: US$2.4 billion wiped off Adani shares after Hindenburg allegations against regulator
summary: A Hindenburg Research report has accused Madhabi Puri Buch, chair of India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi), of having links to offshore funds used by the Adani Group, sparking a US$2.43 billion share sell-off. The allegations, made against Buch and the regulator, have been denied by the Adani Group and Sebi. Despite earlier losses of over US$13 billion, shares in Adani companies recovered some ground, with the group's flagship firm closing 1.1% lower. Adani Group is set to launch a US$1 billion share sale by mid-September.

site_title: Asean currencies turn the tide against the greenback after a rocky start to the year
summary: Southeast Asian currencies, particularly the Malaysian ringgit, have regained strength against the US dollar following a rocky start to the year. The ringgit has gained over 3% against the dollar, while the Thai baht and Indonesian rupiah are also expected to follow suit. Economists attribute this to favorable domestic conditions, global sentiment, and the US Federal Reserve's rate cuts in September. Further relief is expected in the fourth quarter, with central banks in the region expected to follow the Fed's lead.

site_title: ‘Jokowi Effect’: Reflecting on Indonesia’s era of progress
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's decade in power has seen significant economic growth, with infrastructure development, increased industrial production, and improved welfare for citizens. The country has navigated global economic uncertainty, with the "Jokowi Effect" attributed to his bold vision. Despite governance hurdles, Indonesia has become the largest economy in Southeast Asia. However, challenges persist, including a US$2.2 billion sell-off of GoTo shares and ongoing issues with Malaysia's economy. Overall, Widodo's presidency has been marked by progress, but also underscores the need for continued improvement.

site_title: HRnetGroup H1 profit falls 22.8% to S$21.7 million in tough market conditions
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 22.8% drop in H1 net profit to S$21.7 million due to a tough market, with revenue falling 2.1% to S$285.9 million. The company attributes the decline to declines in seven geographies, with only Taiwan's overall gross profit remaining stable. Market conditions are expected to worsen in Q3 and Q4 due to geopolitical tensions and trade war deterioration.

site_title: Food Empire H1 profit falls 11.3% to US$23.6 million on Russia market weakness
summary: Food Empire reported a 11.3% drop in net profit to US$23.6 million for its first half of 2024, mainly due to lower profit contributions from its Russia market. Revenue rose 13.6% to US$225.2 million, driven by strong growth in its South-east Asia and South Asia segments. The company attributed the decline in profit to short-term price disruptions in Russia and higher ingredient prices. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about its business strategies and plans to allocate more resources to its growing South-east Asia and South Asia segments.

site_title: Yen dips, markets stabilise ahead of US inflation data
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen, trading at 147.55 yen, up 0.7%, ahead of US inflation data. Markets have stabilized after a volatile week, with investors weighing the odds of a deep Federal Reserve rate cut next month. Despite this, investors still expect 100 basis points of Fed cuts by year-end, and US economic data on Tuesday and Wednesday may shift market perceptions.

site_title: Europe’s autumn IPO plans on track to defy volatility spike
summary: Europe's planned IPOs for September are moving forward despite a recent spike in volatility, with several issuers considering listings in the second half of the year. Private equity firms, such as Partners Group Holding, are also eyeing listings. Bankers expect the market to calm down, and top-end pricing may be achievable in the September window, with the US election and post-election listing window limiting the time available for deals. The European IPO market raised over $14 billion in the first half of the year, marking the best first-half since 2021.

site_title: Tekka Place on the market, with S$450 million asking price
summary: A joint venture between Lum Chang Holdings and LaSalle Investment Management is selling Tekka Place in Singapore for S$450 million. The mixed-use development includes retail space and serviced residences with a hotel license. Other assets being sold include lyf Farrer Park, Rivervale Mall, and i12 Katong, amid lower interest rates and a more favorable market. Sellers are optimistic about finding buyers, with some expecting borrowing costs to be around 4% or less. Retail and hospitality assets with value-add potential are more sought after, and potential buyers are looking to resize rooms, convert properties, or change operators.

site_title: A funny thing happened on the way to the polls
summary: Voters may struggle to recall details of the conservative "Project 2025" but will likely recall JD Vance's association with a couch, following baseless online claims that he assaulted a couch. The Trump campaign has refused to discuss the matter. According to activist Samuel Alinsky, ridicule can be a powerful tool in politics, infuriating opponents and reacting to their advantage.

site_title: India’s retail inflation eases to 3.54% in July
summary: India's retail inflation eased to 3.54% in July, the lowest since August 2019, due to a base effect. Food prices, which account for nearly half of retail inflation, rose 5.42% year-on-year, down from 9.36% in June. Economists attribute the moderation to a high base effect, suggesting the slower pace of price rises was temporary. The Reserve Bank of India's target of 4% inflation was largely met, but policymakers remain concerned about uneven monsoon rainfall and its impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: It is important for monetary policy to stay the course in bringing inflation down towards its 4 per cent medium term target, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das said.

site_title: US renters get perks as building boom eases supply, Zillow says
summary: US renters are receiving concessions such as free rent and parking privileges as the building boom eases supply, according to a Zillow blog post. In June, 60,000 multifamily units were completed nationwide, the most in 50 years, leading to a 33% increase in concessions on Zillow listings. This trend is expected to bring headline rents lower and bolster the Federal Reserve's case for lower interest rates, easing post-pandemic inflation. A slowing job market and lower mortgage rates may also contribute to falling rents.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding H1 profit rises 77% to 3.1 billion yuan on robust sales, production revenue
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 77.2% increase in net profit to 3.1 billion yuan (S$553.7 million) for the six months ended Jun 30, driven by a 15.3% rise in revenue to 13 billion yuan. The company's shipbuilding business contributed 95% of the total revenue, with revenue from this segment growing 16% to 12.4 billion yuan. The company added 79 new orders worth US$8.5 billion, bringing its order book to a record-high US$20.2 billion for 224 vessels.

site_title: Iswaran’s graft trial set to begin on Sep 10
summary: Former Singapore transport minister S Iswaran's graft trial will begin on September 10 and last for four days until September 13. The trial was originally set for August 13 but was vacated at the request of Iswaran's defense team, who plan to apply to the Court of Appeal for permission to refer the prosecution to provide witness statements before the trial starts. Iswaran faces 35 charges, including two counts of corruption, related to his dealings with billionaire Ong Beng Seng and David Lum.

images.alt_text: Former transport minister S. Iswaran arrived with his team of lawyers at the Supreme Court building on May 8, 2024

site_title: The risks of radical accounting changes
summary: Conventional accounting can send misleading signals for policy, particularly in the context of central bank finances and pension funds. Central banks incur losses on assets purchased through quantitative easing, but their balance sheets exclude seigniorage, a valuable asset. This has led to a perception of insolvency, despite being technically insolvent. In the pension sector, the recording of surpluses and deficits on company balance sheets has damaged the industry, influencing investment decisions and leading to a systemic risk. Additionally, conventional accounting fails to reflect externalities such as environmental pollution, highlighting the need for policymakers, regulators, and investors to be aware of the lacunae between accountancy and economic reality.

images.alt_text: The International Accounting Standards Board launched a consultation on Wednesday on proposed guidance for companies to apply the board’s existing rules for reporting climate change impacts or other uncertainties in their financial statements.

site_title: New signature scheme for second von der Leyen European Commission
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is introducing a new European Clean Industrial Deal to succeed her signature Green Deal initiative, aiming for sustainable industrial growth by 2029. Von der Leyen seeks to maintain her office's environmental legacy despite a different economic competitiveness context following the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The new deal focuses on European cleantech industry growth, with ambitions to make the future of the industry "made in Europe."

images.alt_text: The 720-member European parliament approved Ursula von der Leyen  with 401 votes in favour, 284 against and 15 abstentions. She needed 361 votes to pass.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen was approved for her first term in 2019 by only nine votes, and Thursday’s ballot could be tight, too. This is despite her generally strong record over the last five years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 12)
summary: Ho Bee Land sold a 49% stake in its biomedical life-science project Elementum to a sovereign wealth fund for S$134 million. Meanwhile, a Singapore Airlines plane experienced a technical issue with its brakes upon landing in Tokyo, but all passengers and crew were safe. Cordlife Group warned of a net loss for the first fiscal half of the year due to MOH investigations. Singapore-based medtech startup Aevice Health secured US$7 million to expand its operations globally, and Q&M Dental's net profit surged 84% to S$9.8 million for the first half of 2024.

site_title: Japan’s SMBC has raised stake in Jefferies Financial to nearly 11%
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp (SMBC) has increased its stake in US investment bank Jefferies Financial Group to nearly 11%, surpassing its previous target of 10%. The partnership, established in 2021, allows Jefferies to lead M&A and ECM deals while SMBC focuses on corporate lending and debt issuance. The alliance has led to a significant number of completed deals and a robust pipeline of future transactions, according to Jefferies president Brian Friedman. SMBC plans to further increase its ownership to 15% in the future.

images.alt_text: Lobby of Sumitomo Mitsui Bank, with rumours that a retrenchment would be executed on 26th July 2001.
Toyota is also unwinding cross-shareholdings within its network of manufacturing partners.
Japan’s second-biggest bank plans to start its Gujarat International Finance Tec­City branch likely in July with around 10 people, says Rajeev Kannan.

site_title: Universal Music, Meta expand music licensing agreement
summary: Universal Music Group (UMG) and Meta Platforms have expanded their music licensing agreement, creating new opportunities for artists and songwriters across Meta's social platforms, including Facebook, Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp. The renewed agreement addresses compensation for artists and songwriters. UMG, home to artists like Taylor Swift and billie Eilish, had previously ended a partnership with Meta for streaming premium music videos, citing lower popularity. The deal follows UMG's recent agreement with TikTok and comes as the music label faces declining streaming revenue.

site_title: Opec cuts oil demand growth forecast, highlighting dilemma over Oct hike
summary: OPEC has cut its forecast for global oil demand growth in 2024 to 2.11 million barrels per day, citing softer expectations for China. This is the first cut in OPEC's 2024 forecast since July 2023 and highlights the dilemma faced by the OPEC+ group in raising production from October. The revised forecast is lower than the International Energy Agency's estimate of 970,000 bpd. Despite this, OPEC still expects summer travel demand to remain robust and plans to start unwinding output cuts in October, with the possibility of pausing or reversing them if needed.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 7 cents, or 0.09 per cent, to US$79.59 a barrel by 0021 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 2 cents, or 0.03 per cent, to US$76.86 on Monday.
Brent crude futures settled US$1.85, or 2.42 per cent, higher at US$78.33 a barrel on Wednesday.
Brent crude futures rose by 18 cents, or 0.2 per cent to settle at US$76.48 a barrel on Tuesday.
Brent crude futures settled 51 cents, or 0.66 per cent, lower at US$76.30 a barrel on Monday, with prices earlier trading around their lowest levels since January.

site_title: Severe tropical storm makes landfall in Japan
summary: Severe Tropical Storm Maria made landfall in northern Japan on Monday, dumping over two months' worth of rain in 24 hours. The storm brought gusts of up to 126 km/h and forced the cancellation of dozens of flights, with 315,000 residents issued evacuation advisories. There were no reports of injuries, but residents were advised to be vigilant about landslides and flooding. The storm is expected to cross Japan and head out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening.

images.alt_text: Issuance of catastrophe bonds hit a record high in June, as the market braced for a rough hurricane season with the potential to do substantial damage.
The government issued an emergency warning of a strong tremor for the capital city and Kanagawa, Saitama, Yamanashi and Shizuoka prefecture, without a tsunami alert.
A majority of China's economic losses in July are caused by heavy rains, floods or their effects.

site_title: Sea raises seller fees to above TikTok, Temu to lift margins
summary: Shopee, a leading e-commerce platform in South-east Asia, has raised its commission fees for merchants by about a third since the start of the year, exceeding its rivals TikTok and Lazada. The fee hikes, which include a 13% commission in Thailand, reflect the company's confidence in retaining merchants despite competition. Shopee's decision is seen as a strategic move to boost its bottom line, but also carries a risk as competitors like Temu and TikTok have quickly gained users.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker wipes the door of a car with the sign of Shopee, an Indonesian e-commerce platform, in Jakarta, Indonesia, February 5, 2021. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Structuring for complex family needs: Act globally, think locally
summary: Ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs) are seeking wealth managers that can meet their increasingly complex and cross-border needs. With growing mobility and shifts in time horizons, UHNWIs are looking for medium-term solutions and planning for retirement, while also transferring wealth to the next generation. A global wealth manager with local knowledge is essential, as UHNWIs face various economic and regulatory challenges, such as tax changes and market instability. Smaller firms with bespoke, localised solutions are preferred, as UHNWIs value a holistic approach and trust in advisers.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s tax exemptions and other incentives have attracted hundreds of family offices in recent years along with wealthy Asians, Europeans and Americans.
Wealth in many Asian families has historically been closely managed within the family unit, often passing from generation to generation with minimal formal structures.

site_title: HSBC’s wealth push is a good story only half told
summary: HSBC's new CEO, Georges Elhedery, faces challenges in boosting non-interest income, particularly wealth management, as interest rates decline in the UK and US. Despite a 12% growth in wealth fees in the first half of 2024, the absolute numbers are small, and volatility in quarterly revenue remains. Elhedery must prove that wealth management can replace income from units squeezed by interest rate declines, which could cost the bank up to $7 billion in net interest income. His first year in charge will be crucial in demonstrating the bank's investments in wealth management can pay off.

images.alt_text: Noel Quinn will hand over the reins to the current chief financial officer Georges Elhedery on Sep 2.
Georges Elhedery (above) will take over on Sept 2 from current CEO Noel Quinn.
HSBC is expected to pick its new chief executive from a crop of internal candidates, with an announcement possible as soon as this month, two sources with knowledge of the matter said.
HSBC to target wealth management in latest strategic shift

site_title: Director of vehicle parallel importer SGCARS4U.COM charged with forgery, obstruction of justice
summary: Director of vehicle parallel importer SGCARS4U.COM, Jaye Tham, 49, was charged with 6 counts of forgery and obstruction of justice. He allegedly submitted forged documents to register two imported vehicles, a Honda Fit and a Mercedes-Benz 280S, and deleted WhatsApp messages to hinder the police investigation. Tham is out on bail of S$15,000 and will next appear in court on Sep 9. The charges carry punishments of up to 17 years in prison or a fine.

images.alt_text: The Bill will introduce several proposals to improve the processes involved in dealing with seized properties including those linked to money laundering.
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.
De-registrations, which feed the Certificate of Entitlement quota, are expected to rise significantly from 2026 onwards.
The Zeekr X sport utility vehicle at the luxury Chinese electric vehicle maker's launch in Singapore at the ArtScience Museum on Thursday (Aug 1).

site_title: UMS Q2 profit falls 20% to S$9.3 million on softer sales
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 20% drop in net profit to S$9.3 million for its second quarter, primarily due to slower sales and a 25% decline in revenue to S$56 million. The semiconductor segment saw a 29% decline in sales, while the aerospace segment improved 5%. Despite the challenges, the company expects to benefit from a rebound in the global chip sector and the post-Covid aviation boom, with a projected profitable 2024 financial year.

images.alt_text: The massive subsidies and incentives offered by China and the US to their chipmaking industry will be difficult for Singapore to outdo.

site_title: What exactly were we cheering for at the Olympics?
summary: At the Paris 2024 Olympics, athletes from various countries and backgrounds competed, with Botswana winning its first Olympic gold in the men's 200-metre sprint. The author, a messy Olympics fan, cheered for multiple national delegations, including the US, China, and the Philippines, while also celebrating the achievements of countries like India, Nigeria, and Pakistan. However, the author cautions against insinuating that victory is evidence of broader superiority, emphasizing that Olympic medals are awarded to individual humans, not anonymous parcels of the population.

What the Olympic medal table really tells us

site_title: Bonds bounce back as a hedge after failing investors for years
summary: Fixed income assets are experiencing a resurgence as a hedge against market volatility, particularly in the wake of a 6% decline in the S&P 500 Index. Investors are seeking the safety of bonds as fears of a US recession grow, driving 10-year Treasury yields to their lowest levels since mid-2023. This shift reverses the traditional relationship between equities and bonds, with fixed-income assets offsetting losses when stocks slump. While some investors remain cautious, many are taking advantage of the rally, with yields on two-year notes briefly trading below those on 10-year bonds, indicating a market bracing for recession and rapid rate reductions.

images.alt_text: US Vice President Kamala Harris has clinched the Democratic presidential nomination and is enjoying a super-charged wave of popularity and donations.
The incentive for speculators to borrow in Japan increased once other central banks started racing to contain the steep spike in inflation after the world reopened from the pandemic.

site_title: China’s top utility completes world’s biggest pumped hydro plant
summary: China's State Grid has completed the world's largest pumped hydro plant, the Fengning plant in Hebei Province, with a capacity of 3.6 gigawatts. The $3.5 billion project, designed to supply power to the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, surpasses the US's Bath County project. China aims to expand its pumped hydro capacity to 120 gigawatts by 2030, with energy storage playing a key role in its green transition. The Fengning plant features variable-speed technology, allowing for faster adjustments to power grid loads.

site_title: Ho Bee Land back in the black with H1 S$8.8 million profit
summary: Ho Bee Land, a real estate development and investment company, reported a net profit of S$8.8 million for the six months ended Jun 30, 2024, reversing a net loss of S$155.7 million in the same period a year ago. Revenue increased by 48% to S$230 million, driven by higher sales in Australia and Sentosa Cove in Singapore. The company also sold a 49% stake in its biomedical life-science development, Elementum, for S$134 million.

images.alt_text: Ho Bee Land agrees to sell a 49 per cent stake in its wholly owned subsidiary which owns the group’s landmark biomedical development, Elementum.
Biomedical development Elementum is expected to be completed in the last quarter of this year and contribute to the group's revenue in FY24.
The emerging clusters of unsheltered migrants in New York may indicate that two of the city's most vexing challenges are becoming intertwined.
Elementum, Ho Bee Land’s landmark biomedical life-science development. The group is selling a 49 per cent stake in this project to a sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Van Gogh’s Starry Night recreated as park in Bosnian hills
summary: A 10-hectare park in Visoko, Bosnia, has been recreated as a replica of Vincent Van Gogh's famous painting "The Starry Night." Local businessman Halim Zukic, who bought the land 20 years ago, transformed the area into a nature park featuring fields of lavender, shrubs, lakes, and paths inspired by the painting's swirling motifs. The park, which took six years to complete, includes 13 lakes, 130,000 bushes of lavender, and medicinal herbs. It will focus on art programs and promoting central Bosnia's cultural heritage.

images.alt_text: Personnel members hang for display a rare Vincent van Gogh painting, "Tete de paysanne a la coiffe blanche" (Head of an old farmer's wife with a white hat), painted circa 1884, that will be auctionned at the TEFAF Maastricht art fair, in Maastricht, on March 6, 2024. site_title: Elon Musk’s X faces privacy complaints in Europe over data use
summary: Elon Musk's X, a social media platform, faces privacy complaints in eight European countries over "unlawfully" feeding the personal data of over 60 million users into its AI technology without consent. The European Centre for Digital Rights (Noyb) filed complaints, calling for a full investigation and urging X to comply with the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which requires user consent for data use. The complaints come after Ireland's Data Protection Commission took action against X over its data collection practices, and Noyb warns that the fate of already ingested EU data remains unclear.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit is the latest in a series of legal actions taken against Elon Musk.
Elon Musk has been vocal about his disdain for San Francisco and previously blamed the city’s left-leaning culture for making Twitter too liberal.
The filing of the complaint by Elon Musk comes nearly two months after he abruptly withdrew a similar suit against OpenAI, Altman and Brockman.
Social media platforms, including X, have been under scrutiny for years over the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories, including false information about elections and vaccines.

In what is widely billed as America’s first AI election in November, researchers warn that tech-enabled fakery could be used to steer voters toward or away from candidates - or even to avoid the polls altogether - stoking tensions in an already hyperpolarised environment.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline amid shift in interest rate expectations; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.8% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 26.45 points to 3,235.38, as investors reacted to a shift in interest rate expectations. Asian markets, however, rose, with South Korea's Kospi up 1.2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index increasing 0.1%. Analysts believe markets are betting on 100 basis points of US interest rate cuts this year, which has put the US dollar on notice.

site_title: Sinarmas Land H1 profit falls 18.7% to S$89 million on fair value, impairment losses
summary: Sinarmas Land reported an 18.7% drop in H1 net profit to S$89 million, primarily due to fair value losses and impairment losses from subsidiaries. Revenue rose 28.1% to S$766.1 million. Earnings per share fell to 2.09 cents, down from 2.57 cents last year. The company will monitor property markets and adjust strategies in anticipation of potential rate cuts by central banks.

images.alt_text: Sinarmas Land anticipates a slowdown in its operational area in 2024, with property supply surpassing demand and customers adopting a cautious stance.
The development is the first in BSD City by Sinar Mitbana Mas, and will be constructed in phases starting from 2023.
Sinarmas Land and K2 Data Centres' first development, K2 Data Centre Jakarta 1 Campus will see the first phase come online in early 2024.

site_title: Shell, PetroChina to expand Surat coal seam gas project in Australia
summary: Shell and PetroChina are expanding the Surat coal seam gas project in Australia, with the second phase expected to produce over 130 terajoules of gas per day. The project, which began in 2020, will contribute around 22,400 barrels of oil equivalent per day at peak production. Shell did not provide a cost estimate for the second phase, but said first gas is expected in 2026. The expansion aims to boost local energy supply amid calls for increased investment to address a supply crunch in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren//File Photo

site_title: Sembcorp suspends operations in Myanmar power plant on escalating civil unrest
summary: Sembcorp Industries has temporarily suspended operations at its Sembcorp Myingyan Independent Power Plant in Myanmar due to escalating civil unrest. The company prioritizes employee safety and has implemented security measures to safeguard the plant. The shutdown has been approved by the Electric Power Generation Enterprise, and Sembcorp will look to resume operations as soon as conditions are safe. The company's insurance coverage is in force, and relevant stakeholders have been notified.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp announced a 2 per cent rise in net profit to S$540 million for the first half of the year.
Sembcorp has approved an interim cash dividend of S40.06 per share for the first half ended June.
Semcorp proposed ventures in Batam come as the city's economic growth of 7% outpaced the national average in 2023.

site_title: Paris, uncharacteristically giddy, bids au revoir to the Olympics
summary: The Paris Olympics, which concluded on August 11, 2024, ended with a raucous spectacle and a sense of euphoria among residents, who are reluctant to let go of the event's magic. The Games' legacy is expected to live on, with lasting improvements to the lives of citizens, particularly in the poor suburbs of Seine-Saint-Denis. The event's environmental impact was significant, with a reduction in carbon emissions and plastic use, and the creation of 160 km of bike lanes and 10,000 bike parking spaces. The athletes' village will become a community center, providing social housing for 6,000 people.

images.alt_text: US actor Tom Cruise waves the Olympic flag during the closing ceremony of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Stade de France, in Saint-Denis, France, Aug 11, 2024.

site_title: China regulators tell some rural banks to renege on bond trades
summary: China's regulators have instructed some rural banks in Jiangxi province to reneg on bond trades, a measure aimed at cooling a bond-market bubble that has raised concerns in Beijing. The move, announced in a quarterly monetary policy report, comes as regulators seek to prevent excessive risk-taking in the bond market. Several banks failed to settle transactions on Monday after receiving guidance to halt purchases, a practice that could undermine market integrity if it leads to more failed transactions.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Monday, June 26, 2023. China's consumer-driven recovery is showing more signs of losing momentum as spending slows on everything from holiday travel to cars and homes, adding to expectations for more stimulus to support the economy. site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, August 12th, 2024 (Ep 120)
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday, with foreign investors pulling a record amount of money out of China. The yen carry-trade blowup continues to haunt markets, which were rattled by recent sell-offs. Ho Bee Land sold 49% of its stake in Elementum for S$134 million to a sovereign wealth fund. Despite the mixed market movements, no major conclusions were reached in the article.

site_title: Strata retail sales down 32.1% in H1 to S$215.5 million; strata office deals take a dip
summary: Singapore's strata retail sales plummeted 32.1% to S$215.5 million in the first half of 2024, with 131 transactions, mostly smaller units under S$4 million. Only three units sold for above S$10 million. The average price for freehold strata retail units fell to S$3,266 psf, while leasehold units dropped 21.1% to S$2,411 psf. In contrast, strata office sales fell 15.5% to S$437.3 million, with 154 transactions. Knight Frank expects S$400-500 million in total strata retail sales for 2024 and S$1 billion in strata office sales.

images.alt_text: Despite the uncertain global economy, investors' interest in shophouses remain strong, says Knight Frank.

site_title: Straco H1 profit up 64.5% to S$10.5 million on tourism recovery
summary: Straco, a tourist attraction developer and operator, reported a 64.5% increase in net profit to S$10.5 million for the first half of 2024, driven by a revival in the tourism industry. The company saw 13% more visitors than the previous year and all of its attractions were profitable. Earnings per share rose to 1.23 Singapore cents from 0.75 cent.

images.alt_text: Economists said the results are consistent with the improved business sentiments among Singapore’s manufacturing and services companies in recent business expectations surveys by the Economic Development Board and the Singapore Department of Statistics.
The improved performance was partly due to the full resumption of the Singapore Flyer's operations in the first quarter.

The company, which operates the Singapore Flyer, attributed the income surge to the 2022 financial half’s low base. That was when Chinese municipal authorities were still imposing strict Covid-19 measures, it noted.
