Much of the slowdown was due to a sharp drop in energy prices, and food prices to a lesser extent. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)
The Singapore Flyer in the Marina Bay area.

site_title: DatVietVAC, DatVietOOH and NTT DOCOMO, Inc. cooperated to establish Vie Board Joint Venture
summary: DatVietVAC, DatVietOOH, and NTT DOCOMO, Inc. have established a joint venture called Vie Board to operate the first and only Digital OOH digital measurement and advertising distribution platform in Vietnam. The partnership aims to develop a differentiated competitive advantage in the market, providing outstanding digital OOH advertising resources, accurate analysis tools, and effective ad optimization for businesses and brands. The joint venture is expected to contribute positively to the sustainable development of the advertising and communication industry in Vietnam, aligning with the city's 2030 vision for a smart city.

site_title: Will America’s economy swing the election?
summary: The US economy is slowing down, with a rise in unemployment to 4.3% in July, its highest since 2021. This could harm Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris, who may not be given credit for the economic boom under the Biden administration. While an outright recession would be detrimental to Harris, a gradual slowdown could still hurt her and help Donald Trump. Despite the economy's growth in the second quarter, consumer confidence is low, and the slowdown may impact the election outcome. Harris's chances of winning are narrow, but not impossible, with enthusiasm for her on other issues such as abortion and healthcare.

images.alt_text: The US hiring rate is now back down to its 2014 levels, when the unemployment rate was 6 per cent.
The US unemployment rate has been gradually trending up over the past few months.

US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference after a Federal Open Market Committee meeting at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on July 31, 2024. The US Federal Reserve left its key lending rate unchanged again on July 31 and said it had made "some further progress" in its inflation fight. Policymakers voted unanimously to maintain the US central bank's benchmark interest rate between 5.25 percent and 5.50 percent, the Fed announced in a statement, adding it was "attentive to the risks to both sides of its dual mandate." (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

site_title: PAP appoints two new faces in WP-controlled Aljunied GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has appointed two new branch chairs in the Worker's Party-controlled Aljunied GRC, Jagathishwaran Rajo and Kenny Sim, replacing Chua Eng Leong and Alex Yeo. Rajo, a trade unionist, and Sim, a chief executive of an IT reseller, are expected to be part of the PAP's slate in the upcoming general election, which must be held by 2025. The appointments aim to refresh the PAP's slate in the constituency, which has been held by the WP since 2011.

images.alt_text: The EBRC must make public the reasons that boundaries of certain constituencies are changed while others are untouched, said PSP MP Hazel Poa.
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong has warned his social media followers about deepfake videos using his image.
Sengkang GRC MP Jamus Lim (left) is youth wing president while his GRC mate Louis Chua is now head of the media team.

site_title: China test-flies biggest cargo drone as low-altitude economy takes off
summary: China has successfully test-flown its largest-ever cargo drone, designed for civilian use, with a payload capacity of two tonnes. The twin-engine aircraft, built by Sichuan Tengden Sci-tech Innovation, completed a 20-minute flight in southwestern Sichuan province. China aims to build a low-altitude economy, with the aviation regulator predicting a two trillion yuan industry by 2030, driven by autonomous aerial vehicles (UAVs) that can ferry goods and people. The country has already begun commercial deliveries by drone and plans to test larger payloads in the future.

images.alt_text: A worker transfers packages for delivery ahead of the Singles’ Day shopping festival at a logistics center in Nanjing, in China's eastern Jiangsu province on November 10, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Olympics equipment heads for ‘second life’ post-Games
summary: The 2024 Paris Olympics are coming to an end, and organizers have plans for the equipment left behind. Unlike previous Games, Paris has prioritized sustainability, with temporary venues and suppliers thinking about the "second life" of their products. This includes repurposing the extra-fine sand from the beach volleyball court in front of the Eiffel Tower, which has been promised to a club in the Paris region. The move aims to reduce waste and promote a more circular economy, setting a precedent for future Olympic Games.

images.alt_text: Paris 2024 is designed for sustainability from the start. Apart from the purpose-built Athletes’ Village and Aquatic Centre, 95 per cent of the infrastructure is either existing or temporary.

site_title: Indonesia eases local content requirement for solar power plants to 20%, official says
summary: Indonesia has eased its local content requirement for solar power plants to 20% from around 40%, aiming to boost investment and lower emissions. The new rule allows imported panels until June 2025, provided the project operator meets certain conditions. The move is part of Indonesia's plan to increase renewable energy in its energy mix, which currently stands at 13.1% of total energy needs. Foreign lenders have promised funding, but investment has been limited due to previous local content rules.

site_title: Gold prices steady with spotlight on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices held steady at $2,425.94 per ounce, awaiting US inflation data for a potential interest rate cut. Investors anticipate a 54% chance of a 50 basis point cut in September. Physical gold demand in India increased due to a price correction, while premiums in China rose due to safe-haven buying. The US producer price index is due on Tuesday, followed by the consumer price index on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: In the medium term, the outlook for gold remains positive, says Zain Vawda, market analyst at MarketPulse by Oanda.

site_title: Bank of America CEO says US consumers could become discouraged unless rates drop soon
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan warned that US consumers may become dispirited if interest rates don't decrease soon. The Federal Reserve has kept rates between 5.25-5.50% for over a year, but signaled a possible rate cut in September if inflation cools. Moynihan stated that if rates don't decrease, consumers may lose confidence, despite the Fed's assurance that rates won't go up.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust posts 6.1% lower H1 DPU of S$0.0245
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust reported a 6.1% year-on-year decline in first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0245, and a 8.2% decrease in net property income to S$21.2 million. Revenue fell 10.7% to S$27.6 million. The trust maintained a portfolio occupancy rate of 96.6% and an aggregate leverage of 36.8%.

images.alt_text: As at end of March, its portfolio occupancy rate stays at 100 per cent.

site_title: Australia’s central bank underlines uncertainty about economy, policy forecasting
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has expressed uncertainty about the country's economy and policy forecasting, citing a sticky inflation rate and less spare capacity in the economy than previously thought. Despite holding interest rates steady since November, the RBA expects core inflation to ease back to target by the end of 2025, with a risk of unemployment rising faster than expected. The central bank's Deputy Governor Andrew Hauser noted the huge uncertainty in forecasts, cautioning against overconfidence and advocating for a cautious approach to policy decisions.

images.alt_text: The recent easing of price pressures has bolstered Fed officials’ confidence that they can start to lower borrowing costs.

Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock, in a speech in her home town of Armidale, New South Wales, reiterated that the board was vigilant to the upside risk of inflation, days after the bank decided to hold rates steady.
Reflecting stronger consumer demand and public spending, Australia’s economic growth is expected to pick up to 1.7 per cent by the year end and to 2.6 per cent by June 2025.
Michele Bullock is unlikely to draw from that playbook, however, with economists expecting the RBA will again debate hiking rates, before agreeing to stand pat.

site_title: StanChart cutting about 20 jobs in revamp of lender’s M&A team
summary: Standard Chartered is cutting about 20 jobs in its mergers and acquisitions team as part of a restructuring effort. The London-headquartered bank is redeploying industry expertise into financing teams to provide more M&A capability and reduce overlaps. The move aims to deliver more to clients and maximize returns for shareholders. The restructuring, announced in an August 8 memo, will result in around 100 staffers in the M&A division, down from an earlier target of 150. The bank is responding to increased demand for advisory work and cross-border risk management services.

site_title: SIA flight to Tokyo had technical issue with brakes; all on board are safe
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight to Tokyo experienced a technical issue with its brakes upon landing, but all 276 passengers and crew members were safely unhurt. The issue was resolved by replacing one of the tyres on the Boeing 787-10 aircraft. The incident caused a delay of over two hours, but aviation experts say it is unlikely to dent passengers' confidence in the airline.

images.alt_text: It is the second time this year Qantas has been forced to redirect flights due to unrest in the Middle East.
Scoot will fly to Kertajati twice a week from Sept 28, and to Melaka five times each week from Oct 23.
The group's net profit fell 38.5 per cent to S$451.7 million in the first fiscal quarter of 2024.
The global airline industry continues to face challenges from increased competition, supply chain constraints, inflationary pressures on operating costs, SIA said.

site_title: Guangzhou R&F considers ‘holistic’ solution after bond payment miss
summary: Guangzhou R&F Properties' subsidiary Easy Tactic has missed US$147 million of coupon payments on US dollar notes due 2025, 2027, and 2028. The non-payment may lead to accelerated repayment demands from bondholders. The company is in discussions with creditors to find an "amicable solution" and is considering a "holistic liability management solution." Guangzhou R&F has engaged financial advisers and lawyers to address liquidity pressures, which are part of a broader Chinese property sector crisis. The non-payment highlights the deepening liquidity crisis in China's property sector.

site_title: UK to see first inflation rise this year, bolstering Bank of England caution
summary: The UK is expected to see its first inflation rise this year, with forecasters predicting a 2.3% inflation rate in July, up from 2% in May and June. This data is likely to keep the Bank of England cautious about further interest rate reductions, with markets expecting a delay before the next rate cut. The BOE is also expected to show that unemployment is rising, posing fresh risks to the economy's recovery from last year's recession.

images.alt_text: Skyscrapers beyond The Royal Exchange, center, and the Bank of England (BOE), left, in the City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. A selloff in the riskier corners of the global market deepened, with stocks plunging and traders rushing to the safety of bonds as concerns about a slowdown in the world’s largest economy intensified. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

site_title: Will the HDB resale market, land tenure and senior living feature at the National Day Rally?
summary: Singapore's National Day Rally may feature changes to the HDB resale market, land tenure, and senior living. The government aims to build more public housing developments integrating elderly housing with supporting amenities, catering to the growing desire to age within the community. However, concerns about waiting times, prices, and exclusions from buying new or resale flats remain. The rally is also expected to address issues related to private housing, such as low mortgage rates and the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: More than half of the resale flats transactions were from non-mature estates.
The rise is a notch higher than the earlier estimated 2.1 per cent released on Jul 1.

site_title: China rapidly expands battery fleet but needs to start using it
summary: China rapidly expands its battery fleet, with new-energy storage capacity reaching 44 gigawatts at the end of June, a 40% increase from the start of the year. However, the capacity is largely unused, with the average system in use for just 390 hours and idle 91% of the time. Incentives, mainly from provincial requirements, are the main issue, and further power market reforms are needed to encourage usage. China needs to utilize its battery fleet to cope with increasing intermittent power generation from wind and solar farms.

images.alt_text: China is by far the world’s largest emitter of the greenhouse gases that scientists say drive climate change and make extreme weather more frequent and intense.
China is facing rising trade barriers in developed economies such as the United States and European Union.

site_title: Saudi crude oil exports to China set to slip in September: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia's crude oil exports to China are expected to decline in September to approximately 43 million barrels, down from a revised August estimate of 46 million barrels. This decrease is attributed to slowing oil demand growth in China, the world's top oil importer. The move comes after Saudi Aramco raised official selling prices for light crude grades sold to Asia, but maintained prices for medium and heavy grades. This reduction in exports is expected to have a minor impact on global oil prices, which have been influenced by factors such as market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Prabowo commits to continue building Indonesia’s new capital
summary: Indonesia's President-Elect Prabowo Subianto has committed to continuing the construction of the country's new capital, Nusantara, despite speculation about abandoning the multibillion-dollar project. Prabowo estimated the new capital will be "functionally running" in 4-5 years. This comes as some observers questioned whether he would prioritize funding for his welfare policies over the project. Prabowo's commitment to Nusantara has alleviated concerns about his policy agenda.

images.alt_text: epa11501608 Indonesian President Joko Widodo (C), accompanied by some Indonesian influencers, rides a motorcycle during his working visit to Indonesia's new capital city Nusantara in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, 28 July 2024.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA
Jakarta is the largest metropolitan area in Southeast Asia, with a tremendous rate of population growth and wide range of urban problems.
The planned city of Nusantara is set to begin operating on Aug 17, replacing traffic-clogged and sinking Jakarta as Indonesia’s new capital.
Unresolved issues, including the availability of unencumbered land and a severe lack of water, are stalling progress at Nusantara.

site_title: Ho Bee Land sells 49% stake in Elementum for S$134 million to sovereign wealth fund
summary: Ho Bee Land sells 49% stake in its biomedical life-science development Elementum to a Singapore-incorporated company, Fermium 257, representing a sovereign wealth fund, for S$134 million. The deal is expected to pave the way for broader collaboration and strategic growth. Completion is slated for Aug 21. The sale consideration was based on an agreed property value of S$555 million for Elementum, which has a gross floor area of 445,300 square feet.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of Ho Bee's Elementum project in one-north. The group will issue its green notes due 2029 in July.
Ho Bee Land recommends a first and final dividend of 3 cents per ordinary share for the financial year 2023, which is to be paid out on May 24.

site_title: India set to close in on China as emerging-market stock anchor
summary: India is poised to narrow the gap with China in MSCI's Emerging Markets Index, with analysts expecting India's weight to rise by at least one percentage point following the index provider's review. This would bring India's weight to 20.33%, almost on par with China's 22.33%. India's NSE Nifty 50 Index has risen 12% this year, driven by robust economic growth, a growing middle class, and a burgeoning manufacturing sector. The shift could make India the new anchor for emerging market equities, attracting increased global investment.

images.alt_text: The company has been incurring losses and negative cash flows from operations since inception, according to its listing document.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as focus turns to US inflation data
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as investors awaited key inflation and retail data, following last week's US recession worries. Despite a report showing fewer people claimed unemployment benefits, traders remain cautious and await the release of the consumer price index and retail sales reports. Expectations suggest the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates 25 basis points next month, but officials differ on the outlook for rates. The yen weakened after last week's gyrations, while Tokyo was closed for a holiday.

images.alt_text: CMG20240716-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Singapore medtech startup raises US$7 million to expand accessible respiratory care globally
summary: Singapore-based medtech startup Aevice Health has secured US$7 million in funding to expand its operations globally, focusing on accessible respiratory care. The company's remote patient monitors track respiratory conditions and features a world's smallest smart wearable stethoscope. The funding will be used to enhance product development, aiming to make its solutions ubiquitous for managing chronic respiratory disease. Aevice Health has obtained approvals in the US and Singapore and partnered with Japanese medical equipment manufacturer A&D.

images.alt_text: Medtech startup Aevice Health raises S$2.8m, secures commercialisation partnership

site_title: German commercial property prices drop but show some stabilisation
summary: German commercial property prices dropped 7.4% in the second quarter compared to the same period last year, but showed signs of stabilisation with a 0.4% increase in valuations from the first quarter. The market has been in decline for two years, with a weak economy and low transaction volume contributing to the crisis. Despite this, the situation remains tense, and further setbacks are possible, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz set to launch a new bid to tackle the crisis later this year.

images.alt_text: Prices for apartments and single-family houses in the period ended Jun 30 gained 2.4 per cent and 2 per cent respectively compared with the previous three months, according to the German Real Estate Index.

People walk past apartment buildings on the banks of the river Spree in the Heidestrasse quarter in Berlin‘s Mitte (Centre) district in the German capital, on August 14, 2023. Since 2018, the Heidestrasse area of some 85.000 square meters has been constructed with new buildings for housing, working, shopping. (Photo by Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP)

Prices in Germany have corrected much more strongly than in other European countries because the majority of people rent their homes, meaning consumers have the option to remain tenants rather than take out pricey mortgages.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.3% lower at 3,252.05 on Monday, August 12, despite Wall Street's gains. The broader market saw 86 gainers and 46 losers, with 46.2 million securities worth S$89.9 million changing hands. Banking stocks traded mixed, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average also gaining.

images.alt_text: Ho Bee Land agrees to sell a 49 per cent stake in its wholly owned subsidiary which owns the group’s landmark biomedical development, Elementum.

site_title: Ola Electric jumps by 20% after biggest India IPO in two years
summary: Ola Electric Mobility, India's largest e-scooter maker, made its debut with a successful initial public offering (IPO), raising about $733 million. The company's shares jumped 20% on their first day, valuing it at $4 billion, despite concerns over its financials. The IPO attracted anchor investors and received 4.3 times the demand, indicating strong sentiment for Indian IPOs. Ola is expected to become the lowest-cost maker of electric two-wheelers in India and break even in the next couple of years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ola Electric's S1 Air e-scooters are pictured inside its manufacturing facility in Pochampalli in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, India, August 15, 2023. REUTERS/VarunVyas Hebbalalu/File Photo

site_title: Oil holds on to last week’s gains buoyed by Mideast tensions, economic data
summary: Oil prices remained steady, holding on to last week's 3% gains, driven by Middle East tensions and improved economic data. Brent crude futures fell 7 cents to $79.59 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 2 cents to $76.86. Analysts attributed the stability to traders' focus on simmering tensions in the Middle East, despite some market concerns.

images.alt_text: A weaker greenback helps demand as oil becomes cheaper for foreign buyers.

site_title: Hindenburg accusation of Adani conflict denied by Sebi chief
summary: India's market regulator, Sebi, has denied allegations of conflicts of interest against its chair, Madhabi Puri Buch, amid a report by short seller Hindenburg Research accusing her of having ties to the Adani Group. The report claimed Buch and her husband had invested in offshore entities linked to the group, but Buch and Sebi have denied the allegations, stating they have already disclosed required information. Sebi has launched investigations into the Adani Group and is looking into Hindenburg's report for potential securities law violations.

images.alt_text: The offering of existing shares will mark Adani Enterprises’ return to equity markets after the flagship company scrapped a US$2.5 billion share sale in February last year.
Electric power transmission pylon miniatures and Adani Green Energy logo are seen in this illustration taken, December 9, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
Adani is planning to strengthen cooperation with Vietnamese partners in the fields of aviation and logistics, via the construction of Long Thanh airport and Chu Lai airport.

A statement from Adani Energy, which is led by billionaire Gautam Adani, said the floor price for the issue has been set at 1,027.11 Indian rupees, at a discount to Tuesday’s (Jul 30) close of 1,124.9 rupees.

site_title: Hong Kong court gives developer Kaisa more time to restructure debt
summary: A Hong Kong court has granted Chinese developer Kaisa four more weeks to restructure its debt, deferring a winding-up petition until September 9. Kaisa reported 226 billion yuan (S$42.4 billion) in total liabilities as of last year. The company, which first defaulted on its debt in 2021, has been working with bondholders to come up with a viable restructuring plan. The adjournment was agreed upon by both the company and the petitioners, with the expectation that a deal will be signed this time.

images.alt_text: Kaisa, with about US$13 billion of offshore borrowings subject to restructuring, carries one of the largest debt loads in the industry.
Kaisa, with about US$13 billion of offshore borrowings subject to restructuring, carries one of the largest debt loads in the industry.
The Center skyscraper in Hong Kong. On a visit by Bloomberg News reporters in April, ceiling panels were missing in places, with long electric wires hanging from the gaps on some floors.
The turn in the trajectory of new-home sales may offer some relief for China’s economy, which is on track to undershoot the government's official 5 per cent growth target for this year.
A growing list of Chinese property developers are facing liquidation lawsuits filed by creditors, including Country Garden.
Beijing is lowering the minimum down-payment ratio for buying a home to 20 per cent from 30 per cent, and for some second home buyers to 35 per cent from 40 per cent
Kaisa has been working to restructure its offshore debt since defaulting on US$12 billion in offshore debt payments in late 2021.

Investors sit in front of a board showing stock information at a brokerage house on the first day of trade in China since the Lunar New Year, in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, China February 3, 2020. China Daily via REUTERS/Files
Many Chinese property developers have defaulted since the sector slipped into a debt crisis in mid-2021.

site_title: Deadpool & Wolverine tops North American theatres, passes US$1 billion globally
summary: Deadpool & Wolverine, a Disney/Marvel superhero comedy, topped North American theatres and globally passed the US$1 billion mark, with US$494.3 million in North America and US$535 million internationally. The film, led by Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds, enjoyed an exceptional third weekend with US$54.2 million in North American ticket sales. In contrast, Sony's It Ends With Us, starring Blake Lively, had a near-historic opening weekend with US$50 million. The film is expected to rank among the top all-time romance openings.

images.alt_text: Disney’s plans could build on the recent success of films like 'Inside Out 2' and the company’s television business.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on May 04, 2022 US actor Tom Cruise arrives in a helicopter to the world premiere of "Top Gun: Maverick!" aboard the USS Midway in San Diego, California. - Boycotted by A-listers and studios last year, the Golden Globes will attempt to rebuild their reputation as one of Hollywood's top award shows with organizers unveiling this year's nominees on December 12, 2022. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which organizes the film and television awards, has scrambled to reform itself since long-harbored criticisms of the group's practices went public in early 2021. Tinseltown completely distanced itself from the Globes last January over voters' lack of diversity, alleged corruption and lack of professionalism, and the show took place behind closed doors. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)

(FILES) Chinese-American actress Joan Chen poses during a photocall for Chinese director Jia Zhang Ke's film '24 City' at the 61st Cannes International Film Festival on May 17, 2008 in Cannes, southern France. Chen, 63, has had a long career: before seducing the West in "The Last Emperor" and "Twin Peaks," the actress was a child star in China, chosen by the wife of former Communist leader Mao Zedong. Her career, from Red Army propaganda films to Hollywood glamour, may soon be crowned by an Oscar nomination thanks to "Didi," a critically acclaimed teen story in which she plays a single immigrant mother. The role "sprang from me, because it's the life I've lived," Chen tells AFP. (Photo by Anne-Christine POUJOULAT / AFP)

site_title: Carry-trade blowup haunts markets rattled by rapid-fire unwind
summary: The yen carry trade, a strategy that involves borrowing in Japan and investing in emerging markets, experienced a rapid unwind after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised interest rates, sparking a global market meltdown. The strategy, which produced returns of 40% last year, saw investors bail out of the trade, fueling a rebound in the yen and a swift exodus from equities and other currencies. The BOJ's benchmark rate increase to 0.25% has raised concerns about the leverage built up around Japan, with some estimating that $1.1 trillion is tied up in carry trades.

images.alt_text: The yen has been strengthening sharply in recent weeks, up 10 per cent against the dollar since it touched a 38-year low in early July.
In the BOJ’s summary of opinions, some called for a cautious approach to rate policy at a time when the economy remains fragile.

At the July 30-31 meeting, the Bank of Japan raised its short-term policy target to 0.25 per cent from a range of 0 per cent to 0.1 per cent and released a detailed plan on how to taper its huge asset buying in another landmark shift away from a decade-long stimulus programme.

site_title: China developers Logan and KWG secure refinancing for US$1 billion debt facility
summary: Chinese developers Logan Group and KWG Group Holdings secured a private loan to refinance a US$1 billion debt facility, backed by luxury real estate in Hong Kong. The refinancing, arranged by JPMorgan Chase, will pave a path for Logan to restructure its US$8 billion offshore debt. Private equity firms Davidson Kempner Capital Management and Dignari Capital Partners HK provided US$250 million each, while other firms lent US$200 million each. The loan has a 13% annualized yield and a 30-month tenor with two six-month extension options.

site_title: UK insurers pay out record claims as weather-related claims surge: industry body
summary: UK insurers paid out a record £1.4 billion in claims during the second quarter, primarily due to weather-related catastrophes such as fires and flooding. This marks the fifth consecutive quarter weather-related claims exceeded £100 million. Insurers are reevaluating coverage, particularly for commercial properties and residential landlords, due to increased flooding from overflowing rivers and blocked drains. Industry representatives stress the need for urgent government action to tackle surface water flooding and maintain flood investments to mitigate the impact of climate change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Floodwater from the rivers Avon and Severn surrounds Tewkesbury Abbey as floodwaters continue to fall in the aftermath of Storm Henk in Tewkesbury, Britain, January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: RBNZ faces crunch rates call amid uncertainty over pivot timing
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is set to make a crucial policy decision on Wednesday, with economists and investors divided on whether to cut interest rates. Despite signs of a potential recession and slowing inflation, some economists believe the RBNZ should cut rates now, while others argue it's too early to make a significant change. Traders expect a 25 basis-point cut, with the RBNZ aiming to keep inflation around 2% and maintain its hawkish stance. The decision will be made in conjunction with the quarterly Monetary Policy Statement (MPS) and will have significant implications for the New Zealand economy.

images.alt_text: Economists polled by Reuters had forecast a 4.7 per cent unemployment rate and a 0.2 per cent contraction in employment.
The RBNZ has softened its stance in its July rate review, acknowledging signs of declining activity and opening the door for policy to ease sooner than previously signalled.
New Zealand’s economy has stalled after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) rapidly raised interest rates to combat inflation.
Prime Minister Christopher Luxon has announced it will reverse a ban on oil and gas exploration, push the pricing of agricultural emissions back five year and encourage more mining.

site_title: Q&M Dental’s H1 net profit surges 84% to S$9.8 million
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 84% year-on-year surge in its first-half net profit to S$9.8 million, driven by higher revenue and net other gains. Earnings per share (EPS) rose to S$0.0104, up from S$0.0056 in the same period last year. The company proposed a S$0.004 per share interim dividend, a 150% increase over the prior year. Revenue grew 2% to S$88.8 million, with contributions from Singapore dental clinics. The company's gearing ratio decreased to 0.71 times, strengthening its financial position.

images.alt_text: Under the arbitration filed, QDGM had sought – amongst others – a declaration that it had validly exercised its rights under the shareholders agreement requiring Tye, Chong and Chan to buy back QDGM’s 70 per cent stake in AR Dental.
Dr Ng Chin Siau, Group CEO (left), and Dr Raymond Ang, Executive Director and COO of Q&M Dental Group.

site_title: Cordlife warns of H1 net loss amid MOH investigations
summary: Cordlife Group has issued a profit warning, expecting a net loss for the first half of the year due to the impact of refunds and fee waivers related to high-risk tanks. The company will disclose more details when it announces its unaudited first half results on or before Aug 14. Investigations by the Ministry of Health (MOH) are ongoing, with no certainty on the outcome. Cordlife's draft unaudited results show a significant decline from the prior year.

images.alt_text:
CMG20240507-SarahLee01/李姿仪/王阳发/访问Ivan Yiu, CEO of Cordlife [1 Kim Seng Promenade, #15-01, Great World City East, Singapore 237994]

Cordlife generics.
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.

site_title: World youth unemployment rate lowest for 15 years: UN
summary: The UN's International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that global youth unemployment rates have reached a 15-year low of 13% in 2023, with 64.9 million young people (15-24 years old) not in employment, education, or training. However, the recovery has not been universal, with higher youth unemployment rates in the Arab States, East Asia, and South-East Asia. The ILO warned of the growing casualization of work and the widening gap between young graduates and job opportunities, with 20.4% of young people globally classified as NEETs, mostly women.

images.alt_text: July was the second consecutive month of job losses and add to signs of easing in Canada’s labour market, which would support the case for the central bank to lower interest rates again at its next announcement in September.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 233,000 for the week ended Aug 3, the Labor Department said.
Young hopefuls visit a job fair in in Shanghai, China, May 31, 2024.

Actress Guo Ting gets ready for an audition in Hengdian, Zhejiang, China, June 18, 2024. Guo is part of a trend of young Chinese giving up the traditional aspiration of a stable, mainstream job in exchange for alternative careers and a chance at self-fulfillment.
China’s tech advances and resulting export boom have helped to keep economic growth within reach of its targeted pace of around 5 per cent.

site_title: Britain’s CEOs get record pay in 2023, research shows
summary: Britain's CEOs enjoyed record pay in 2023, with the median FTSE-100 CEO pay rising 2.2% to £4.19 million, according to the High Pay Centre. This represents 120 times the median full-time British worker's earnings. Nine firms offered CEOs over £10 million, and the highest-paid CEO was Pascal Soriot of AstraZeneca, earning £16.85 million. The pay growth is seen as a reflection of a business culture prioritizing investors' interests over workers.

images.alt_text: People hold placards calling for better pay for junior doctors, as they stand on a picket line outside St Thomas' Hospital in central London on January 3, 2024, on the first day of six days of strike action. Hospital doctors in England on Wednesday began their longest consecutive strike in the seven-decade history of Britain's National Health Service (NHS). Junior doctors -- those below consultant level -- started a six-day walkout, in a major escalation of their long-running pay dispute with the UK government. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)
Unlike previous cycles of monetary easing, the UK economy is expected to pick up momentum this year and next, leaving the risk of inflationary pressures.

With Manchester not far away, Burnley has attracted commuters seeking cheaper properties, typically at the higher end of the market, where most of the town’s new homes tend to fall. At the cheaper end, there has been a post-pandemic feeding frenzy as landlords snapped up terraces for the rental market.
Rent especially in the capital has become a major concern, with high prices and a lack of places to live becoming a prime constraint for those seeking to work in London.
UK prime minister Rishi Sunak greets supporters after delivering a general election campaign speech in London, Britain, June 24, 2024.

In a message to workers, Ortberg expressed how “proud and excited I am to be a member of the Boeing team.”
Tan Su Shan will be DBS’ first female CEO, and the first home-grown staff member hired internally to take the top role at the bank.

site_title: Australian pensions boost investment in insurance for disasters
summary: Australia's largest pension funds are boosting investments in insurance for disasters, seeking to capitalize on record-high catastrophe bond issuance and growing natural disaster risks. Colonial First State and Insignia Financial, among others, are exploring investments in catastrophe bonds and quota shares to provide capital for insurers and reinsurers. The move aims to generate outsized returns and diversify portfolios, as the industry faces increasing competition and scrutiny.

images.alt_text:

Mark Delaney – like other large investors – has benefited from exposure to the “Magnificent Seven” mega caps.
Australia's central bank predicts that inflation will fall back within its 2 to 3 per cent target in late 2025.

site_title: Disney plots villains-themed land, new ships in big resorts push
summary: Disney unveiled ambitious plans for its resorts business, including a villains-themed land at Walt Disney World's Magic Kingdom, a Cars-themed area in Frontierland, and new attractions at Disney's California Adventure and Animal Kingdom. The company also plans to double its investment in its parks and resorts unit to $60 billion over 10 years. Four new cruise ships are also on the horizon, with construction set to begin over the next five years. Despite a slowdown in its parks business due to weaker consumer trends, Disney remains confident in its growth ambitions and is investing in new experiences to reinvigorate demand.

images.alt_text: Disney’s plans could build on the recent success of films like 'Inside Out 2' and the company’s television business.
FILE PHOTO: The entrance to Walt Disney studios is seen in Burbank, California, U.S. August 6, 2018. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson/File Photo
Disney is transitioning to streaming from broadcast and cable TV, where audiences are shrinking and ad sales are declining.
Walt Disney is eliminating about 140 jobs, or about 2 per cent of staff at Disney Entertainment Television.

site_title: Australian government urged to ban gambling ads
summary: A group of over 60 prominent Australians has urged the government to ban all gambling ads in the country, citing estimated annual losses of A$25 billion and harm caused by gambling. The call comes after a 2023 report recommended a total ban on advertising. The Alliance for Gambling Reform says a ban is essential to protect children and prevent mounting financial ruin, mental health problems, and family violence. The government has not confirmed whether a ban is planned, but is expected to announce proposed legislation within weeks.

images.alt_text: Singapore citizens and permanent residents previously needed to pay a daily entry levy of S$100 or an annual entry levy of S$2,000.
The Philippines’ gambling sector is the third largest in Asia, next in size only to Macau and Singapore.
Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr orders the gaming regulator to wind down and cease such offshore gaming operations by the end of the year.
Su Binghai's home in Jalan Asuhan features a KTV lounge, arcade game machines, a dedicated massage room, and 10 large safes.
South-east Asia bets big on casinos, but who will take Singapore’s crown?

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ho Bee Land, Q&M Dental, Daiwa House Logistics Trust, PSC, Tat Seng, Cordlife
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading of their securities. Ho Bee Land sold a 49% stake in its biomedical development, Elementum, for S$134 million. Q&M Dental Group reported a 84% increase in net profit to S$9.8 million, proposing a S$0.004 per share interim dividend. Daiwa House Logistics Trust posted a 6.1% year-on-year fall in distribution per unit, while PSC Corp reported a 14% increase in net profit to S$11.2 million. Tat Seng Packaging saw a 20.3% increase in net profit, while Cordlife Group issued a profit warning due to refunds and fee waivers.

The move comes amid heightened regional tensions, following the recent killings of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr, which drew threats of retaliation against Israel. Pezeshkian aims to improve ties with the world and promote a pragmatic foreign policy.

site_title: China's central bank to extend low-carbon lending tool to end of 2027
summary: China's central bank will extend its low-carbon lending tool to the end of 2027 to support carbon-reduction projects by companies. The People's Bank of China launched the program in 2021, providing financial institutions with low-cost loans for up to 60% of the principal at a 1.75% one-year lending rate. The goal is for China's economy to be "fully on the green and low-carbon track" by 2035, with declining carbon emissions by that time, and increasing non-fossil energy consumption to 25% by 2030.

site_title: Kaisa, Times China face Hong Kong court to avoid liquidation

The court has warned Kaisa that Monday's hearing may be its last chance to avoid liquidation, while Times China has an in-principle agreement with creditors and hopes to buy more time to finalize its restructuring plan. site_title: Singapore equities market has pockets of outperformers; investors need to be shrewd, realistic
summary: Singapore's local equities market has underperformed the global benchmark, with younger investors often missing out on opportunities. However, smaller to mid-cap companies in various industries, such as oil and gas, construction, and manufacturing, have shown strong gains this year. Investors can find these outperformers by adopting a "top-down" approach, focusing on sectors like semiconductors, and analyzing companies with good corporate governance, consistent track records, and regular dividend payouts. Analysts recommend doing homework and forming own opinions rather than relying on broker research reports.

site_title: The Belarusian wheelchair barista 'making the world better'
summary: Belarusian exile Sasha Avdevich, a wheelchair user, has opened the first "Inclusive Barista" coffee shop in Warsaw, Poland, after fleeing his home country due to persecution. Avdevich, who lost the use of his legs in a 2011 motorbike accident, founded the coffee shop to promote disability inclusion and hire people with various disabilities. The cafe also aims to be an international and inclusive space, hosting events like rap battles and speed dating, and launching a DJing school. Avdevich's mission is to make the world better, one cup of coffee at a time.

Ukraine's official claims the operation is part of a larger effort to relieve pressure on its troops in other parts of the front line, while Russia vows a "tough" response.

site_title: Can you be emotionally reliant on an AI voice? OpenAI says yes
summary: OpenAI has released a report on its human-like voice feature in its ChatGPT app, citing concerns about users forming emotional reliance on the AI model. The report notes that users have engaged in language indicating a connection with the model, such as "This is our last day together." OpenAI acknowledges the potential risks, including anthropomorphization and reduced human interaction, which could negatively affect healthy relationships. The company plans to conduct further research to better understand these risks and define potential consequences.

The ceremony, which included performances by Red Hot Chili Peppers and Billie Eilish, featured a memorable abseiling stunt by Tom Cruise, waving the Olympic flag. The games saw the US take the top spot in the overall medal table, with 126 medals, while China finished second with 91. site_title: Singapore banks keep guard against rate cuts, market volatility in Q2, but expect to remain strong
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, reported strong second-quarter net profits, with DBS and OCBC guiding for continued strength in 2024. Despite rising macroeconomic uncertainty and impending interest rate cuts, the banks have taken measures to reduce their interest rate sensitivity and ensure sufficient capital. They expect fee income to remain a bright spot, driven by lower interest rates and increased wealth management activity. The banks' asset quality remains strong, and they have a solid capital base, supporting "strong dividend visibility" despite the uncertain economic environment.

While some experts argue that the market correction is healthy, others worry about the impact of Japan's central bank on the country's stock market. Meanwhile, Dyna-Mac Holdings, a Singaporean offshore services provider, reported a 283.9% increase in earnings, making it a potential stock to watch. summary: Nomura is leveraging growing interest in Japan's equity markets to drive growth in its Asia-Pacific business. The bank's strong Japanese branding and expertise have attracted global investors, particularly from Asean, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and South Korea. Nomura's pre-tax income from its Asia ex-Japan business reached $215 million, representing about 9% of the bank's overall business. The bank is expanding its international wealth management segment and exploring opportunities in the private markets space, with a focus on tailor-made solutions.

summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a review group to strengthen the local equities market, amid heightened global market volatility. The group, chaired by Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat, aims to galvanize greater public sector participation and realign interests among stakeholders, including capital market intermediaries, investors, and listed companies. The review process will study ways to spur demand and improve the market's attractiveness, including exploring investment opportunities for global investors seeking diversification. The MAS hopes the group's recommendations will help revitalize the local market and make Singapore a more attractive hub for business and finance.

site_title: Bangladesh puts its eggs in one economic basket. Now, a reckoning
summary: Bangladesh's interim government, led by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus, faces a daunting task to restore order and stabilize the economy after Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's ouster. The country's singular focus on textiles and apparel has led to steep inflation, joblessness, and widespread corruption, exposing the limitations of its economic strategy. The interim government must address these challenges, including institutional reforms, while navigating the transition to free and fair elections. With a high growth rate but uneven income distribution and high corruption, Bangladesh's future remains uncertain, and the interim government's success will be crucial in determining the country's path forward.

site_title: Singapore could improve on its social inclusivity measures: report
summary: Singapore's social inclusivity measures can be improved, according to a report by Cushman & Wakefield. 64% of people with disabilities aged 15-64 were outside the labor force in 2022-2023, with 3.6% actively seeking employment. Creating inclusive workspaces and integrating people with disabilities into the workforce can bring unique perspectives and skills. Employers, such as Pan Pacific Hotels, are already adapting, with tailored job carving and flexible work arrangements. However, challenges persist, including stigma and low productivity concerns, and more needs to be done to promote disability-inclusive hiring practices and workplace adaptations.

site_title: Retirement as we know it is ending – it’s time to rethink the idea of working age
summary: The traditional concept of retirement based on chronological age is being reevaluated as people live longer and contribute to the economy in various ways. The current system, which sets a fixed age limit for working, can lead to generational tensions and exacerbate ageist attitudes. Alternative approaches, such as a functional age or cognitive age, are being explored, but these metrics have limitations. The author argues that phasing out structures based on chronological age and adopting a more dynamic, age-fluid approach is necessary to recognize the value of non-economic contributions and needs.

site_title: Yen could strengthen further if BOJ signals further tightening
summary: The USD/JPY currency pair has recently broken its trendline after rising since January 2024, driven by US economic data and a dovish BOJ stance. However, a recent BOJ interest rate hike, rising Japanese wage growth, and potential government intervention may signal further yen strengthening if the BOJ tightens monetary policy. US economic indicators and the Fed's policy decisions will also influence the pair's future trajectory, with investors remaining vigilant for geopolitical developments and global economic conditions.

site_title: New construction blocking the view? ‘If you can’t beat them, join them.’

After consulting with the architects, the Benrubis decided to "join them" by hiring the same architects to renovate and expand their own home, creating a 2,200-square-foot house with a 1,600-square-foot deck and more spacious interior. The project was completed at a cost of about $700 per square foot, and both families are now thrilled with the results, enjoying amicable neighborly relations.

The country aims to achieve 70% renewable energy capacity by 2050, with solar power expected to be the dominant source. Integrating solar and battery energy storage systems is recommended to enhance affordability and energy security. Despite progress, the country still relies heavily on gas, and energy interconnections across Asean are needed to optimize resource allocation and reduce costs.

summary: A recent podcast episode, "BT Money Hacks: Ways to get out of debt" (Ep 179), discusses the topic of debt and available help. Tan Huey Min of Credit Counselling Singapore and Seth Wee of Providend share tips on the cheapest ways to get out of debt, and emphasize that seeking help is not as difficult as it may seem. site_title: Indonesia’s quick commerce startups lose speed amid tight competition and funding crunch
summary: Indonesia's quick commerce industry is experiencing a decline due to tight competition and a funding crunch. Several home-grown startups, including Tokopedia Now, have exited the market or pivoted to new ventures. The industry is grappling with profitability challenges, with elevated inflation and rising interest rates dampening spending growth. Key players with substantial funding, such as Grab and AC Ventures-backed Astro, continue to thrive, while smaller players struggle to maintain operations. Analysts predict that the industry will be led by players with extensive networks of "dark stores" in densely populated residential areas to facilitate rapid delivery.

site_title: What works in Taiwan doesn’t always work in Arizona, a chipmaking giant learns
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has faced significant challenges in establishing a chip-making facility in Arizona, despite initial expectations. The company, which has committed $65 billion to the project, has pushed back its start date and now expects to begin production in the first half of 2025. Cultural differences and clashes between Taiwanese managers and American workers have been a major issue, with some employees quitting due to disagreements over expectations. TSMC is working to address these issues through communication training and recruiting local talent, but the project faces competition from other companies and the need to build a skilled workforce from scratch.

site_title: Malaysian economy to thrive in H2 on rising external demand, robust domestic spending: analysts

Strong exports, manufacturing, tourism, and a stable job market are key factors fueling growth. Analysts attribute the boost to resilient growth prospects in major economies, higher commodity prices, and a reacceleration in the global technology cycle. However, wild cards include the US election outcome and prolonged high US interest rates, which may impact the country's growth trajectory.

site_title: PSA International unit to buy majority stake in Polish intermodal operator
summary: PSA International, a Singapore-based port operator, signed an agreement to acquire an 85% majority stake in Polish intermodal operator Loconi International from publicly traded Polish freight forwarder ATC Cargo. The acquisition will enhance existing hinterland connections from PSA's container terminal in Poland and extend its reach into new markets in Central and Eastern Europe. The deal, subject to approval from relevant authorities, will allow Loconi to handle more than 250,000 20-foot equivalent units per year, and PSA aims to develop port-adjacent services and grow its role as a port ecosystem player.

site_title: Saudis reform investment law in bid to attract foreigners
summary: Saudi Arabia has introduced new business regulations to boost transparency and ease investment processes, aiming to attract more foreign capital and support economic diversification. The updated investment law guarantees the rule of law, fair treatment, and freedom to transfer funds without delay. Foreign investor licenses will be scrapped and replaced with a simplified registration process, with dedicated service centers to expedite the process. The reforms are set to take effect in early 2025.

site_title: How economic grievances were exploited in Britain’s violent unrest
summary: In Britain, far-right rioters in economically challenged areas exploited economic grievances, specifically immigration, as a misguided target for violence. Research shows that immigration benefits the economy, with migrants contributing to public finances and staffing critical positions. However, economic problems, such as stagnant wages and declining public services, have fueled anti-immigrant attitudes. Politicians like Nigel Farage have exploited these frustrations to gain power, spreading false claims about immigrants draining public budgets. The riots, characterized by violence for its own sake, do not align with specific economic grievances, but rather with a broader expression of rage towards migration and migrants.

site_title: US says it won’t halt aid to Israeli military unit accused of abuses

The aid is expected to be disbursed in 15 days.

Despite the sell-off, analysts see the market as overvalued and ripe for a rebound, citing attractive valuations and bullish sentiment. The benchmark Topix is down 12% since June, with semiconductor-related stocks falling 25% and banks down 16%. The seven biggest tech companies, known as the "Magnificent Seven," are set to see a 35% profit growth, while the rest of the S&P 500 Index is on pace for a 7.4% growth. However, revenue misses have been more frequent, with 21% of companies reporting below-estimate revenue. Huang, a former Google engineer, co-founded Pinduoduo, an e-commerce platform known for cheap products with massive promotions. His company's expansion outside China under the Temu brand helped counteract China's weak domestic economy, leading to his remarkable ascent. Despite protests from suppliers and concerns over working conditions, Huang's steady growth has drawn praise from analysts, who see Temu as a value retailer in a time of economic uncertainty.

Harris's campaign is gaining momentum, with an opponent 20 years her junior. The presidential election is just three months away, with Harris and Trump's schedules set to intensify.

site_title: UK homebuilders boosted by rate cut and promise of planning reforms
summary: The UK homebuilding sector has seen a boost following the Bank of England's rate cut and the new Labour government's promise of planning reforms. Bellway, Persimmon, and Taylor Wimpey have forecast annual housebuilding numbers towards the upper end of their guidance range, with buyer confidence improving after a drop in mortgage rates. However, challenges remain, including affordability issues for younger buyers and the time-consuming process of implementing planning reforms. The sector's outlook has improved, with some builders reporting increased enquiries and approvals for new plots.

images.alt_text: Some 980 homeowner mortgaged properties were taken into possession between March and June.
On a monthly basis, house prices jumped by 0.8 per cent in July from June, Halifax said.
The S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers’ Index leapt to 55.3 – the highest since May 2022 – from 52.2 in June.
Taylor Wimpey said it now expects to build close to the upper end of its target range of 9,500 to 10,000 homes in 2024 in the United Kingdom.
House sales remain on track for 1.1 million in 2024, Zoopla says, but that’s still 10 per cent lower than the 20-year average.

Mortgage rates have been starting to come down as investors increasingly expect the BOE to cut its interest rate from a 16-year high, possibly as soon as Thursday, but this has not yet spurred an increase in purchases.

site_title: Ma Long makes Chinese history with sixth Olympic gold
summary: Chinese table tennis player Ma Long made Olympic history with his sixth gold medal on August 9, 2024, in the men's team event in Paris. The 35-year-old surpassed divers Wu Minxia and Chen Ruolin, and gymnast Zou Kai, to become the athlete with the most gold medals in Chinese Olympic history. Ma, who was overlooked for the singles event, partnered with Wang Chuqin to secure China's clean sweep in the team event, with a 3-0 victory over Sweden.

site_title: Japanese urged to avoid panic buying as megaquake fears spread
summary: Japanese authorities have urged people to avoid panic buying amid fears of a possible megaquake, triggered by a magnitude 7.1 earthquake in the south on Thursday. A huge earthquake is more likely in the aftermath, with the government estimating a 70% probability over the next 30 years. Despite low risk, demand for disaster kits and daily necessities has skyrocketed, with retailers reporting shortages of bottled water, portable toilets, and preserved food. Experts emphasize the risk is still low, and the agriculture and fisheries ministry has urged people to refrain from excessively hoarding goods.

images.alt_text: The government issued an emergency warning of a strong tremor for the capital city and Kanagawa, Saitama, Yamanashi and Shizuoka prefecture, without a tsunami alert.
Police officers stand guard near a building damaged following an earthquake in Miyazaki, southwestern Japan.

site_title: Gaza civil defence says 90 killed in Israeli strike on school
summary: At least 90 people, including children and women, were killed in an Israeli strike on a school in Gaza City, according to the Gaza civil defense agency. The strike occurred two days after Israeli strikes on two other schools in Gaza City, killing over 18 people. Israel's military claims the strike targeted Hamas terrorists, but critics say it's a "horrific massacre." The incident comes amid ongoing tensions and fears of a regional war, with Iran and Hamas vowing retaliation for previous strikes. International mediators are pushing for a ceasefire and resumption of talks between Israel and Hamas.

images.alt_text: The US State Department intends to disburse US$3.5 billion in new military aid to Israel.

site_title: Appeals court orders license restored to Philippine news site Rappler
summary: A Philippine appeals court has ordered the restoration of Rappler's business license, reversing a ruling that revoked the company's operating license in 2018. The decision, made public on Friday, found that Rappler is "wholly owned and managed by Filipinos," contrary to the Securities and Exchange Commission's claim that it was owned by a foreign entity. Nobel laureate Maria Ressa, Rappler's co-founder, welcomed the decision, saying it's a rare victory for free press in South-east Asia.

site_title: Cohen & Steers ups Digital Core Reit interest; Beng Kuang Marine CEO also adds to interest
summary: Institutions sold S$586 million worth of Singapore stocks from Aug 2 to 7, contributing to the Straits Times Index's 5% decline over the period. Meanwhile, 12 primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$20.4 million. Digital Core Reit's deemed interest increased to 8.14% after Cohen & Steers Capital Management purchased 3,640,500 units at US$0.58 per unit. Beng Kuang Marine CEO Yong Jiunn Run acquired 200,000 shares, taking his direct interest to 5.10%. Raffles Medical Group's executive chairman Loo Choon Yong increased his total interest to 55.14% after acquiring 3.6 million shares.

site_title: ‘Unknown Boy’ may be the youngest ever Olympic champion
summary: The 1900 Paris Olympics may have produced the youngest-ever champion, a child coxswain who steered two Dutch rowers to victory, but his identity remains unknown. The "Unknown French Boy" is the only name recorded in the Olympic archives, and despite numerous theories, no conclusive proof has been found. Historians believe he was either 8 or 12 years old, making him the youngest champion of all time. Researchers, including Olympic historian Hilary Evans, continue to search for clues, hoping that someone will uncover the mystery behind this enduring Olympic enigma.

images.alt_text: (From left) US' Simone Biles; Brazil's Rebeca Andrade; and US' Jordan Chiles pose during the podium ceremony for the artistic gymnastics women's floor exercise event of the Paris 2024 Olympic.

site_title: Hedge funds most bearish on commodities since at least 2011
summary: Hedge funds have reached the most bearish position on commodities since 2011, with a combined net-short position of almost 153,000 futures and options across 20 raw-material markets. This is the largest on record, driven by fears of a deeper economic slowdown and declining demand for commodities such as crude oil and metals. The Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index has fallen almost 11% since its high in May, with rising supplies, a stronger dollar, and declining China demand cited as "solid price headwinds" by analysts.

site_title: Bets against Yen crater as volatility scares crowded carry trade
summary: The Japanese yen has strengthened sharply, up 10% against the dollar since its 38-year low in early July, prompting hedge funds to pull back on bets for further weakness. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission data shows a 49,336 contract reduction in wagers against the yen, the fifth-largest boost to trader sentiment since 2006. The pullback is attributed to the Bank of Japan's rate hikes, which have led to the unwinding of carry trades worldwide, with estimates suggesting 60% of yen-funding carry trades have been unwound.

images.alt_text: A Japanese 10,000 yen banknote and US 100 dollar banknotes arranged for a photograph in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, July 12, 2024. Japan’s top currency official continued his attempts to keep speculators on edge amid potential signs of an evolution in Tokyo’s yen strategy as he played down a report that government officials had confirmed intervention. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg

site_title: Brazilian plane spins before crashing, killing all 61 on board
summary: A regional turboprop plane, operated by Brazilian carrier Voepass, crashed into a residential neighborhood near Sao Paulo, killing all 61 people on board. The ATR-72 aircraft took off from Cascavel and crashed at around 1:30 pm local time, with video footage showing the plane spinning out of control before hitting the ground. Aviation experts have expressed curiosity over the unusual final circling motion, with some speculating that ice could have played a role in the loss of control. An investigation is underway, with French and Canadian investigators participating, and officials have confirmed that there were no survivors.

images.alt_text: Crashes such as that of Japan Airlines at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda in Tokyo on Jan 3, 2024, with a smaller coast guard plane on the ground, were the top cause of claims.

site_title: A growing number of homeless migrants are sleeping on New York streets
summary: A growing number of homeless migrants are sleeping on New York streets, with clusters emerging in areas near migrant shelters. The city is housing nearly 65,000 asylum seekers, straining the shelter system and leading to a rise in unsheltered migrants. Some migrants have been evicted due to stricter time limits on stays, while others have chosen to sleep outside voluntarily. The situation has raised concerns about public safety and the city's ability to balance its humanitarian response with the need to address street homelessness. The number of asylum seekers in shelters has declined, but the unsheltered migrant population continues to grow.

site_title: Ex-Twitter chairman sues Elon Musk’s X for US$20 million in shares
summary: Former Twitter Chairman Omid Kordestani sued Elon Musk's X for $20 million in shares, claiming Musk is refusing to cash out his $20 million in owed shares. Kordestani served as Twitter's executive chairman from 2015 to 2020 and received most of his compensation in stock. Musk's company is seeking to "reap the benefits" of Kordestani's seven years of service without paying him. This is the latest in a series of legal actions taken against Musk by former Twitter leaders, following a March lawsuit for allegedly withholding $128 million in severance payments.

site_title: Taylor Swift cancellations deal blow to insurers: sources
summary: Taylor Swift's concert cancellations in Austria due to a foiled attack have resulted in millions of US dollars in insurance claims. Insurers, including those from Lloyd's of London, will share the losses, as Swift rarely cancels concerts. The cancellations of three concerts in Vienna, with 195,000 attendees, are expected to cost insurers in the tens of millions of US dollars. While the event's rescheduling may limit losses, insurers may consider restricting coverage due to terrorism concerns.

site_title: Activist Starboard Value takes stake in Starbucks, WSJ reports
summary: Activist hedge fund Starboard Value has taken a stake in Starbucks, according to a Wall Street Journal report. The size of the stake is unknown, but the fund is reportedly pushing the coffee giant to improve its stock price. Following the news, Starbucks shares rose 3.2% in extended trading. This move comes after the company reported a drop in quarterly global sales, and it is the latest development in a growing activist investor landscape, with another activist, Elliott Investment Management, already engaging in discussions with Starbucks.

images.alt_text: Starbucks’ business has taken a hit as consumers pressured by inflation and dwindling savings tighten their spending.

site_title: S-Reits score lower in transparency overall but five see marked improvement
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) and business trusts saw their overall scores decline to 86.6 points in the 2024 Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI), down from 89.3 last year. Nearly two-thirds of the 38 S-Reits decreased in overall scores, with a mean penalty of 1.8 points for poor disclosure practices. However, five S-Reits showed significant improvement in transparency, including Clas, which retained its top position with 104 points for the fourth consecutive year.

site_title: BlackRock’s Wei Li sees risk of Donald Trump challenging Fed’s independence
summary: BlackRock's global chief investment strategist Wei Li warns that a potential Donald Trump presidency poses a risk to the US Federal Reserve's independence, breaking a long-standing norm. Li advises investors to consider this scenario when evaluating Treasury yields, as Trump's influence on monetary policy could impact government bond portfolios. Fiscal concerns will also influence appetite for longer-term Treasuries, while expectations of interest rate cuts could counterbalance these effects.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump, weather turbulence to eke out weekly gain
summary: Europe's main index rose 0.6% on Friday, logging a fourth consecutive session of gains and a slight weekly advance despite a turbulent week sparked by US recession fears. The Stoxx 600 index briefly reclaimed the 500-point mark, with healthcare stocks leading the gain. The US jobs report calmed investor nerves about labour market weakness, helping to lift European stocks. Despite this, some companies, such as Indivior and Generali, fell due to concerns over their sectors.

site_title: How not to elevate a colleague to a leadership role
summary: Leaders should identify and support potential leaders within their group early on, rather than pressuring or forcing them into leadership roles. This approach can damage morale, lead to resentment, and hinder performance. Leaders should instead have open and supportive conversations, recognizing and celebrating colleagues' strengths and potential, and providing training and resources to help them succeed. By avoiding common pitfalls such as ignoring workload, neglecting career goals, and failing to provide support, leaders can create a positive and motivating environment that encourages growth and fosters a self-policing culture.

images.alt_text: Applying pressure can be damaging and counterproductive to what you are trying to build. Pressure can lead to resentment and stress, especially if you are asking someone to go beyond his comfort zone.

site_title: Oil posts 3% weekly gains on positive economic data, rate cut hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 3.5% in the week, driven by positive economic data and signals of potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. A weaker US dollar made oil cheaper for foreign buyers, while geopolitical tensions in the Middle East continued to raise supply risks. Brent crude futures rose $0.50 to $79.66 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose $0.65 to $76.84 a barrel. Despite fears of a widening conflict, oil prices have been boosted by rising inflation in China and a gradual softening in the labor market.

Brent crude futures inched down 4 cents, or 0.1 per cent, to US$76.77 a barrel by 0035 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$73.39 a barrel, down 13 cents, or 0.2 per cent on Monday morning.

site_title: Tesla stops taking orders for cheapest Cybertruck, offers US$100,000 version now
summary: Tesla has stopped taking orders for its least expensive Cybertruck version priced at $61,000, while making the $100,000 version available for immediate order. The company had previously estimated 200,000 Cybertrucks per year, but demand appears lower, with only 4,800 units sold in July, its best month yet. This shift suggests that customers are waiting for less expensive versions, which will be a challenge for sustained high volume sales. Deliveries of the Cybertruck began in November 2023, and the company now offers higher-priced variants.

images.alt_text: Tesla's experience centre in Kuala Lumpur. The US-based EV maker had previously in July 2023 committed to set up a country head office and service centres in Selangor.

site_title: China’s Harvest Fund chairman under investigation steps down
summary: China's Harvest Fund chairman Zhao Xuejun has resigned and is cooperating with authorities in an investigation into "personal problems," which has nothing to do with the company's fund business. Zhao, the longest serving fund management executive in China, steps down amid Beijing's crackdown on the financial sector. Co-chairman An Guoyong will serve as acting chairman, and the company stated it is operating normally.

site_title: Kirin-backed Indian brewer seeks more clout with new factory
summary: Indian craft brewer Bira 91, backed by Japan's Kirin Holdings, plans to build a US$70 million beer factory in Uttar Pradesh, India's largest beer factory, to expand production and raise fresh funds ahead of a public listing in 2026. The company aims to increase its market share and become profitable, with CEO Ankur Jain targeting a double-digit Ebitda margin and 8-10% market share. Bira 91 has already raised US$290 million in equity and debt and is appointing investment bank Morgan Stanley to lead another round of fundraising.

site_title: Threat to Keir Starmer persists as riots expose UK social divisions
summary: The UK riots, which led to hundreds of arrests over two weeks, appear to have subsided, but the threat of fresh violence remains for Prime Minister Keir Starmer's government. The recent unrest exposed deep-seated social divisions and challenges that the new government must address. Starmer's team recognizes the need to resolve these issues to prevent further unrest, with officials warning of potential fresh violence over the weekend.

site_title: Chinese robotaxi firm WeRide eyes up to US$5 billion valuation in US IPO
summary: Chinese autonomous driving startup WeRide is seeking a valuation of up to $5 billion in its US IPO, aiming to raise $119.4 million. The company, known for its robotaxis, vans, buses, and street sweepers, is testing and conducting commercial pilots in 30 cities across seven countries. WeRide reported a net loss of $163 million for the six months ended June 30. The IPO comes amid concerns about Chinese software in autonomous vehicles in the US, which is expected to be proposed by the Biden administration in the coming weeks.

site_title: Gold holds ground on US Fed rate-cut hopes, lower yields
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Friday, holding above Thursday's 1.9% gain, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cut in September. US Treasury yields dipped, boosting gold prices, with spot gold at $2,427.73 per ounce and US gold futures at $2,473.40. Despite a 0.6% weekly decline, analysts see a positive outlook for gold in the medium term.

site_title: Growing acceptance of private assets shows up among insurers’ products
summary: Insurance companies are increasingly incorporating private assets into their portfolios, with 53% of insurers ranking private credit as one of the top five asset classes with the highest expected returns over the next 12 months, according to a Goldman Sachs Insurance Asset Management survey. This shift is driven by insurers' growing comfort with private credit, which has shown steady performance, and their desire to diversify their investment portfolios. Insurers are partnering with private capital firms to offer products to high-net-worth clients, such as FWD's partnership with Apollo Global Management, and are exploring opportunities to introduce additional private market products.

Revenue from China operations rose 1.9% despite weaker yuan, while Singapore operations declined 4.2%. Gross profit increased 12.8% and an interim dividend of S$0.03 per share was declared. The company expects reduced demand and potential raw material price increases to impact profitability.

site_title: Malaysia opens anti-dumping duty probe on plastic imports from China, Indonesia
summary: Malaysia has launched an anti-dumping duty investigation on imports of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) from China and Indonesia, following a petition from a domestic producer. The investigation was initiated after the petitioner alleged that PET imports from these countries were sold at a significantly lower price than their domestic selling price. This probe aims to protect the domestic PET industry from unfair trade practices.

site_title: US dollar dips as yen heads for first weekly drop in six
summary: The US dollar fell 0.56% against the Japanese yen, marking its first weekly rise in six weeks, amid a chaotic week of market fluctuations. The yen and Swiss franc, considered safe-haven currencies, rose to one-week lows as stocks rose and Treasury yields dipped. A drop in US jobless claims and a decrease in bets for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts fueled the dollar's decline. The dollar index fell 0.203% to 103.07, while the euro was slightly higher against the dollar.

site_title: A master plan for seniors to age well and more entertainment sites: Liu Thai Ker’s wishes for the country
summary: Singapore needs a city-wide master plan to meet the needs of its aging population, according to architect Liu Thai Ker, who oversaw the development of 20 new towns and over half a million housing units during his time in the public service. The plan should consider physical, mental, and economic needs, with facilities such as healthcare centers, training centers, and entertainment sites. Liu also emphasized the importance of affordable public housing, repurposing disused schools, and designing cities with a humanist approach, prioritizing the well-being of residents and functionality of the land.

site_title: 27,000 brave the rain, humidity to commemorate Singapore’s 59th birthday
summary: About 27,000 spectators attended the National Day Parade in Singapore to celebrate its 59th birthday, despite early evening showers and high humidity. The event marked the first National Day Parade attended by President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in their new roles. The parade featured various performances, a 360-degree fireworks experience, and a tribute to former Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The event concluded with a recitation of the pledge and singing of the National Anthem, as Singaporean Max Maeder won the bronze medal in kitefoiling at the Paris Olympics.

site_title: King Charles III ends silence on UK far-right riots
summary: King Charles III has made his first public comments on the UK's far-right riots, praising police and emergency services for restoring peace in affected areas. The monarch expressed hope that shared values of mutual respect and understanding will unite the nation, following near-daily unrest in cities across England and Northern Ireland. Hundreds have been arrested, with officials blaming far-right agitators. The king's comments come after a noticeable silence, with critics questioning why he did not speak out sooner.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends up, little changed for week after Monday's steep selloff
summary: The S&P 500 ended up on Friday and was little changed for the week after recovering from a steep decline on Monday due to recession fears and unwinding of a global yen-funded carry trade. The technology sector boosted the index, while the Cboe Volatility Index fell. Investors await the next Fed meeting and await July's consumer prices and retail sales data for fresh evidence on the US economy's chances of a soft landing.
