Renald Yeo

site_title: German property prices record first quarterly rise in two years
summary: German residential property prices rose 2.4% and 2% for apartments and single-family houses, respectively, in the second quarter, according to the German Real Estate Index. This marks the first quarterly increase in two years, driven by lower borrowing costs and a lack of new housing. Prices are still down 4.5% from the same period last year, but the drop has narrowed for the third consecutive quarter. The European Central Bank's interest rate cuts are expected to stabilize the market, with a further loosening of monetary policy anticipated in September.

images.alt_text: People walk past apartment buildings on the banks of the river Spree in the Heidestrasse quarter in Berlin‘s Mitte (Centre) district in the German capital, on August 14, 2023. Since 2018, the Heidestrasse area of some 85.000 square meters has been constructed with new buildings for housing, working, shopping. (Photo by Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP)

Prices in Germany have corrected much more strongly than in other European countries because the majority of people rent their homes, meaning consumers have the option to remain tenants rather than take out pricey mortgages.
High financing and construction costs continue to weigh on   Germany, triggering the most severe property crisis in the country in decades.
Some 17,600 permits were issued, which is 17 per cent fewer than a year earlier, the data showed, making for a nearly 44 per cent drop over the past two years.

site_title: Even as a developed economy, Singapore must still pursue growth and upgrading: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for economic growth and upgrading, despite the country being a developed economy. He stated that the government will invest in research and development, new technologies, and infrastructure projects to sharpen the country's competitive edge. Wong also highlighted the confidence of multinational firms in Singapore as a stable and trusted base for business, with several major brands opening new facilities in the country. However, he acknowledged the pressing concern of rising inflation and the need to cushion its impact on lower and middle-income groups through support measures.

images.alt_text: NTUC plans to have at least 2,500 company-training committees by 2025.
High-priced transactions continue to make up a small minority of total HDB resale transactions.
Most regional economies reported improvement in operating conditions, with some notable exceptions such as China and Malaysia.

site_title: Foreigners added US$36.5 billion to EM portfolios in July, IIF says
summary: Foreigners added US$36.5 billion to emerging market (EM) portfolios in July, the largest inflow since January, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). This is primarily due to debt issuance, totaling US$29.4 billion, with stocks receiving US$7.1 billion. A contraction in carry trade operations and a rally in the Japanese yen may have weighed on local currency debt. However, the prospect of lower US interest rates is expected to boost EM assets, with the US Federal Reserve predicted to cut interest rates by 50 basis points at its September meeting.

images.alt_text: Should Donald Trump win a second term aas US president, investors should expect a strong attempt to renew his flagship 2017 tax cuts and further reduction in corporate taxes.
he sell-off abated throughout the session as Latin American stocks moved well off their lows.
If recent trends hold, Taiwan or India may catch up with China’s standing in MSCI EM this year.
US consumer prices slid 0.1 per cent in June, while the core measure that excludes food and energy rose at its lowest monthly pace since August 2021.

site_title: Layoffs are a last resort looming for more US companies
summary: The US jobs market is showing signs of slowing, with a material slowdown in hiring and an unexpected pickup in joblessness, according to the latest jobs report. The unemployment rate climbed to a three-year high of 4.3% and the number of Americans working part-time for economic reasons jumped to a three-year high. Despite this, many companies have avoided layoffs and instead reduced hours, leading to concerns that employers may soon be forced to cut jobs to avoid a downturn. Federal Reserve officials are warning of the risk of a surge in unemployment, with some predicting a jumbo half-point reduction in borrowing costs at their next gathering in September.

site_title: Xiaomi-backed AI chipmaker Black Sesame falls in Hong Kong debut as AI frenzy wanes
summary: Black Sesame International, an AI chipmaker backed by Xiaomi, fell 35% on its Hong Kong debut, with shares reaching a low of HK$18.28. The company's initial public offering (IPO) raised about HK$1 billion, but received weak demand from institutional investors. The listing is a setback for Hong Kong's efforts to revive its equity market, which has seen declining IPOs and liquidity concerns.

images.alt_text: Black Sesame’s potential listing comes as China is pausing its massive investments aimed at building a chip industry to rival the US.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 8)
summary: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye announced that the exchange will represent broader views in a review group aimed at improving Singapore's stock market. Meanwhile, Tesla's EV ambitions in South-east Asia were cast in doubt after Malaysia's Ministry of Investment dismissed a report on the company's plans to build manufacturing plants in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The Singapore Exchange reported a 10.5% increase in H2 profit to S$316.3 million, while derivatives volume rose 15% to 23.5 million contracts in July.

site_title: UK mortgage possessions jump as higher rates squeeze homeowners
summary: UK mortgage possessions increased by 8% in the second quarter of 2024, with 980 homeowner mortgaged properties taken into possession between March and June. This is 30% higher than the previous year, largely due to courts processing historic arrears cases. The number of buy-to-let mortgages taken into possession also rose sharply, climbing 13% in the same period. This is attributed to landlords being more exposed to regulation and the shift of rentals into corporate structures to cut costs.

site_title: China chipmaker SMIC beats Q2 estimates despite steep profit fall
summary: China's largest chip foundry, SMIC, reported a 59.1% fall in second-quarter net profit to $164.6 million, beating analyst expectations. However, revenue rose 21.8% to $1.9 billion, also exceeding forecasts. The results reflect a global semiconductor industry recovery after a prolonged slump. Despite this, advanced chip production remains limited, constraining SMIC's growth. Industry leader TSMC reported a 40% increase in second-quarter revenue, driven by strong demand for AI and high-performance computing chips.

images.alt_text: The details shed new light on measures the Biden administration is taking to thwart Huawei, as the company has started to rebound despite Washington’s efforts to cripple it on national security grounds.
TSMC uses extreme ultraviolet lithography equipment to produce more advanced 3nm chips, but such tools cannot be sold in China due to export controls.
The latest investment vehicle, known as Big Fund III, showcases the renewed push from Beijing to build its own semiconductor supply chain.

site_title: Geo Energy H1 profit drops 2% to US$26.7 million
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a 2% decline in net profit to US$26.7 million for its first half year, down from US$27.1 million last year, due to lower Indonesian Coal Index prices. Revenue declined 29% to US$169.4 million. Despite this, cash profit per tonne remained healthy at US$11.94 per tonne. The company has recalibrated its mining plan to open more pits and ramp up production in the second half of the year, aiming to improve cost efficiencies and expand its value proposition.

images.alt_text: The shift comes as Germany has said it wants to shrink its exposure to China, citing political differences and accusing Beijing of “unfair practices”, though it has been vague on policy steps.

site_title: Vietnam backs Cambodia’s Mekong canal, urges cooperation on impacts
summary: Vietnam backs Cambodia's plan to build a $1.7-billion Funan Techo Canal, a project aimed at diverting shipping away from Vietnam. The project, which broke ground on August 5, has raised environmental concerns, with conservationists and Vietnamese authorities warning it could damage the fragile Mekong Delta. Vietnam's foreign ministry has expressed a willingness to collaborate with Cambodia on finding solutions to mitigate the canal's negative effects, with the goal of reducing its impact on the region.

site_title: British Airways suspends Beijing flights on airspace challenges
summary: British Airways is suspending flights from London to Beijing starting October 26, 2024, until November 2025 due to airspace challenges and weaker demand. The airline will continue to operate daily flights to Shanghai and Hong Kong. This decision comes as several carriers, including Virgin Atlantic and Qantas, have also reduced or curtailed services to China amid slower demand and longer flight times. The move is attributed to the ongoing Russian airspace closure.

site_title: India to keep sugar export curbs in blow to local producers
summary: India will retain sugar export curbs to ensure domestic supplies and boost ethanol production, according to government officials. The curbs, introduced in 2023, limit exports to 6 million tonnes, affecting local sugar mills. The restrictions are aimed at supporting global prices, which have fallen by 12% this year, and meeting Prime Minister Narendra Modi's target of increasing ethanol in petrol blends to 20% by 2026. India's sugar inventories are expected to be around 8.5 million tonnes by the end of the season, sufficient for domestic consumption and ethanol blending.

images.alt_text: India was a leading source of sugar, rice, and onions for Malaysia, which itself is the second-largest exporter of palm oil to India, after Indonesia.
Global sugar production in 2023/24 was seen at 179.270 million tonnes, down from a previous forecast of 179.749 million.
The US Department of Agriculture’s Foreign Agricultural Service predicts India wheat imports at 2 million tonnes in the season that began on Apr 1 on steady local demand.
StoneX has projected that global sugar production exceed total demand by 3.9 million tonnes, up from 3.4 million tonnes seen in February.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance H1 net profit up 12.9% to S$52.6 million on higher net interest income
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 12.9% increase in H1 net profit to S$52.6 million, driven by higher net interest income and improved asset yields. The company also proposed an interim dividend of 3.75 Singapore cents per share. Net interest income rose 11.1% to S$112.7 million, while fee and commission income fell 9.2%. Total operating expenses rose 5.6% to S$55.7 million, mainly due to staff cost increases and enhanced regulatory compliance.

images.alt_text: While Hong Leong Finance reported a 40.7 per cent year-on-year increase in interest income and hiring charges during the second half of the year, net interest income and hiring charges was 30.9 lower, amid higher interest expenses.

site_title: SGX will represent broader views in MAS review group: CEO
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will represent broader views in the MAS review group, which aims to improve Singapore's stock market. The group includes SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye, Temasek's Dilhan Pillay, and Ministry of Finance's Lai Chung Han, but will also engage with industry players and stakeholders outside the group to gather diverse views. The 10-member group will recommend measures to aid in the equities market's development and submit a report within 12 months, focusing on improving liquidity and demand for stocks.

images.alt_text: GIC set up its first global office in New York 40 years ago. It is now in nine other cities including Tokyo, London, Mumbai and Sao Paulo.
XX
The emergence of new groups and initiatives come as the Singapore Exchange struggles to attract new listings and improve its liquidity.
Some market watchers say that allocating a small portion of GIC's funds to the local bourse will help to jumpstart the market.
The review group will come up with measures to support companies listed on the Singapore Exchange and encourage them to expand globally.

site_title: South Korea to hold emergency meeting after EV fires raise safety concerns
summary: South Korea's environment ministry plans an emergency meeting next week to discuss fires involving electric vehicles (EVs), including a recent blaze that damaged 140 cars and hospitalized 23 people. The meeting will also focus on measures to prevent such incidents and alleviate public concerns about EV safety. The government may require EV makers to disclose battery brands, a move that comes amid a slowdown in EV sales and growing consumer distrust.

images.alt_text: A charging plug on an electric vehicle in Guangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Siemens profit beats market view on software but outlook remains guarded
summary: Siemens reported an 11% increase in adjusted operating profit to €3 billion (S$4.3 billion) for its April-to-June quarter, beating market expectations. The company attributed the growth to demand for electricity infrastructure and production software, but warned that customers remain hesitant to invest amid uncertainty over borrowing costs. Siemens maintained its full-year revenue growth guidance at the lower end of a 4-8% range and kept its outlook guarded, citing a one-off boost from new customers for its software for microchip production and product design.

images.alt_text: Siemens Energy's third-quarter sales rose 18.5 per cent to 8.8 billion euros, beating the analyst consensus of 8.6 billion euros
Siemens Energy’s wind unit has been in turmoil due to supply-chain bottlenecks, soaring costs and quality problems.
The job cuts plan comes shortly after Siemens Energy fleshed out major restructuring moves at Siemens Gamesa.

Siemens operates several units bundled together as ‘Portfolio Companies’ since 2019 which employ around 13,585 people and generate approximately 3.2 billion euros (S$4.7 billion) in revenue according to its own 2022 data.

site_title: World’s largest 3D-printed neighbourhood nears completion in Texas
summary: Icon's robotic 3D printer is nearing completion of the world's largest 3D-printed neighbourhood in Wolf Ranch, Texas, with 100 single-storey homes. The printing process takes about three weeks, and the homes are designed to be resistant to water, mould, and extreme weather. The community's homes range in price from $450,000 to $600,000, with over a quarter sold. Icon's technology aims to reduce construction time, cost, and material waste, and the company plans to expand its use to the Moon as part of NASA's Artemis programme.

images.alt_text: Nikon has also signed an agreement to jointly develop a handheld camera for Nasa for use on the moon’s south pole.

site_title: Allianz Q2 net profit up better-than-expected 7.5%; affirms targets
summary: Allianz, a German insurer, reported a 7.5% increase in second-quarter net profit to 2.513 billion euros, exceeding a consensus forecast. The company attributed the growth to strength in its property and casualty business, offsetting claims from natural catastrophes. Allianz reaffirmed its full-year operating profit target of 13.8-15.8 billion euros and expanded its share buyback program to 1.5 billion euros.

site_title: China auto market hits milestone as EVs, hybrids make up half of July sales
summary: China's auto market achieved a milestone in July, with new energy vehicles (NEVs) making up 50.7% of car sales, a record high. NEV sales jumped 37% from the same period last year, driven by China's investments in EV supply chains. The growth has propelled the domestic EV industry, leaving established foreign brands behind, and marks a significant leap ahead of Western countries in EV adoption.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Electric vehicle (EV) models are displayed at the booths of Denza, a joint venture between Mercedes-Benz Group AG and BYD Auto, and Chinese EV maker Voyah, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The Rome government could join Dongfeng with a minority stake in the investment which aims to set up a hub for the whole of Europe.
Pre-sales of the Land Aircraft Carrier are due to start in the final quarter of 2024 in China, the company says.
Separately on Wednesday, BYD announced a partnership with Uber Technologies to put 100,000 EVs onto the ride-hailing company’s platform.
More than 500 electric robotaxis built by Baidu currently ply the city’s streets, with plans for an additional 1,000 to be deployed by year-end.
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.

site_title: Bangladesh Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus takes charge of caretaker government
summary: Bangladesh Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus took charge of a caretaker government on August 8, three days after Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina was forced to quit and flee the country following violent protests. Yunus, 84, will oversee fresh elections for a new leader, tasked with restoring stability in the country of 170 million people. He vowed to work with student leaders and government officials to move forward together, following the student-led movement that ousted Hasina. The move comes after weeks of violence that killed about 300 people and injured thousands, and has sparked jubilation and anger among some Bangladeshis.

images.alt_text: Bangladeshi Nobel peace laureate Muhammad Yunus, who is currently in Europe and is due to return to Dhaka on Thursday afternoon, told AFP he was willing to lead the interim government.

site_title: KKR launches 558.4 billion yen tender offer for Japan’s Fuji Soft
summary: US private equity firm KKR launches a 558.4 billion yen (S$5.1 billion) tender offer to take Japanese software developer Fuji Soft private. KKR will offer 8,800 yen for shares, and if successful, Fuji Soft will be delisted. The deal comes as Fuji Soft's management has been at odds with major shareholders, including Singapore-based fund 3D Investment Partners. The offer price is slightly above Fuji Soft's closing price of 8,890 yen on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Indonesia’s fintech microfinance marketplace Amartha aims to bridge funding gap for MSMEs
summary: Indonesia's fintech microfinance marketplace Amartha aims to bridge the funding gap for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) by working directly with rural banks and financial institutions. Founded in 2010, Amartha now serves over 2 million borrowers, mostly women who run small shops and need working capital. The company uses technology to manage banks' portfolios, reducing non-performing loans and risks. Amartha has been profitable since 2016 and has enabled 67,000 MSMEs to advance to small enterprises, creating over 200,000 jobs. The company is seeking to raise additional funds and partner with international organizations to expand its services.

site_title: ‘Don’t lose sight of the Singaporean way, stay open-minded’, say SMEs that have ventured abroad
summary: Three Singaporean companies, Lucence, Kimen Group, and The Editor's Market, have successfully expanded their businesses abroad. Lucence, a biotech startup, became the first Asian-headquartered company to have its cancer test approved by US Medicare, while Kimen Group developed a luxury residential project in London, incorporating Singapore's unique approach to urban development. The Editor's Market, a women's apparel brand, expanded to 14 stores overseas, applying a "less-is-more" strategy to its product lines and store designs. These companies emphasize the importance of adapting Singapore's efficiency and meticulousness to diverse regulatory systems and staying open-minded when working with foreign markets.

site_title: India’s central bank holds rates again despite global market volatility
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept its key interest rate unchanged at 6.5% for the ninth consecutive meeting, maintaining its focus on bringing inflation down to its 4% medium-term target. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das emphasized the need to prioritize price stability for sustainable growth, despite global market volatility. The decision was in line with market expectations, with all 59 economists polled predicting no rate change.

images.alt_text: An electronic ticker board indicates stock figures at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, Fab. 1, 2018. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government ended a tax break on equity investments as it taps the stock market boom to boost its coffers. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
The RBI currently has a mandate to keep headline inflation at the midpoint of a 2 to 6 per cent range and adjusts monetary policy settings to achieve that end.

SAN ANSELMO, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 07: In this photo illustration, Visa credit cards are displayed on February 07, 2024 in San Anselmo, California. According to a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, credit card debt in the United States has reached $1.13 trillion. (Photo Illustration by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images) (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Asia: Stocks turn lower again as nervous traders navigate volatility
summary: Asian stocks declined sharply on Thursday, following a sell-off on Wall Street, amid concerns over the global economy. Fewer US jobs than expected in July fueled fears of a recession, while weak earnings from major companies added to the sense of unease. Investors are now eyeing larger interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve, but a risk-off mood has been exacerbated by profit-taking in the tech sector. Tokyo managed a gain, but the rest of Asia followed suit with losses, with analysts warning that the market volatility may not yet be over.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, May 27, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.6 per cent lower at 38,763.45 on Wednesday.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 76 to 50.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Etihad Airways reports surge in first-half profit
summary: Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways reported a 48% increase in first-half profit to 851 million AED dirhams, driven by a 21% rise in revenue to 11.7 billion dirhams and a 38% increase in passenger numbers to 8.7 million. The airline's cargo revenue also rose 10%. The profit boost comes ahead of a possible stock market listing, with credit rating agency Fitch upgrading Etihad's rating to A+ in July 2024. CEO Antonoaldo Neves stated that the airline is improving transparency and governance to prepare for a public flotation.

site_title: You like wine? Try planting a vineyard at home
summary: Homeowners are turning their backyards into vineyards to grow grapes for wine production. Novice vintners are planting grapevines, researching suitable varieties for their climate, and outsourcing the hard work of winemaking to companies like Long Island Vine Care. These backyard winemakers, like Erica Ritchie and Craig Lemoine, are not seeking commercial success but rather enjoying the process and sharing their wine with friends and family. The process can range from $1,500 to $3,500 per month, depending on the services required.

images.alt_text: Sweden's vineyards are aiming to make their mark in the wine world.
These easy-going wines are perfect for relaxing and just right for watching the Paris Olympics from afar.
Champagne shipments in the first half of 2024 reached 106.7 million bottles, down 15.2 per cent from a particularly high level recorded over the same period of 2023 and closer to the level in 2019.

Sales are down and health concerns are up, but wineÕs history of providing beauty, joy and affirmation should not be forgotten. (Craig Frazier/The New York Times) Ñ FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY POUR WINE JOY BY ERIC ASIMOV FOR JUNE 25, 2024. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. Ñ

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, August 8th, 2024 (Ep 119)
summary: Asian stocks declined for the second consecutive day as traders navigated volatility, with JPMorgan reporting that three-quarters of global carry trades have been unwound. DBS appointed Tan Su Shan as deputy CEO, set to succeed CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 10.5% increase in H2 profit to S$316.3 million, and proposed a Q4 dividend of S$0.09 per share.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas withdraws from South Sudan amid investment shift
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas is withdrawing from South Sudan due to its long-term investment strategy amid a changing industry environment and accelerated energy transition. Petronas Carigali Nile will work with stakeholders to ensure a smooth transition. Following Petronas' announcement, Britain's Savannah Energy has also pulled out of a $1.25 billion purchase of Petronas' oil and gas business in South Sudan, citing inability to complete the transaction on envisioned terms.

site_title: BOJ didn’t see July hike as policy tightening, summary shows
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) conducted a small interest rate hike to 0.25% in July, but its policy remains accommodative, according to a summary of opinions from the board meeting. The BOJ aims to adjust monetary accommodation in line with underlying inflation, which will not have tightening effects. Despite a hawkish tone from Governor Kazuo Ueda, real interest rates are expected to remain below the neutral rate, indicating policy continuity. The BOJ will continue to monitor market volatility and adjust its policy as needed.

images.alt_text: At the July 30-31 meeting, the Bank of Japan raised its short-term policy target to 0.25 per cent from a range of 0 per cent to 0.1 per cent and released a detailed plan on how to taper its huge asset buying in another landmark shift away from a decade-long stimulus programme.
Separate data from the finance ministry showed that Japan’s foreign reserves fell to US$1.22 trillion at the end of July, down US$12.4 billion from a month earlier.
Shinichi Uchida's, which contrasted with Governor Kazuo Ueda’s hawkish comments made last week when the BOJ raised interest rates, boosted Japan’s Nikkei average and sent the yen sharply lower.
Governor Kazuo Ueda last week repeatedly stressed the BOJ decided to increase rates based on economic and inflation data showing that developments were in line with previous expectations.

site_title: US tops China as Germany’s biggest trading partner
summary: Germany's largest trading partner shifted from China to the US in the first half of 2024, according to German statistics office data. The US overtook China with total imports and exports of around 127 billion euros, while China had 122 billion euros. This shift comes as Germany aims to reduce its dependency on China due to political differences and accusing Beijing of "unfair practices."

images.alt_text: Eurozone gross domestic product rose 0.3 per cent in the three months through June, sustaining the same pace as it did at the start of the year.

site_title: My recession rule was meant to be broken
summary: The US economy is not in a recession despite the Sahm rule, which indicates a downturn, triggering concerns about a potential recession. The rule, created by economist Claudia Sahm, suggests a recession when the three-month average unemployment rate is 0.5 percentage point or more above the prior 12 months. However, recent data shows a rise in unemployment, but it's largely due to an increase in the labour force, particularly immigration, rather than weakening demand. The hiring rate has fallen to 2014 levels, and the Federal Reserve may need to cut interest rates to mitigate the risk of a recession.

images.alt_text: Traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Aug 6, 2024, a day after the Dow Jones and the S&P 500 had their worst day of trading since 2022, amid a global market sell-off centred around fears of a US recession.

site_title: BT Podcasts: Xero invests in your growth
summary: Xero, a leading accounting software provider, has invested in BT Podcasts to support the growth of its content offerings. This investment is aimed at expanding the reach and quality of BT Podcasts' content, which covers various financial topics such as market analysis, wealth management, and money hacks. The partnership is expected to enhance the overall user experience and provide more valuable information to listeners. No specific details on the investment amount or terms have been disclosed.

site_title: Deliveroo orders grow as demand picks up across markets
summary: Deliveroo reported a 6% increase in gross transaction value in the first half, reaching £3.69 billion. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation to be in the upper half of its previous forecast of £110 million to £130 million. Demand for the UK food delivery platform rose, contributing to the growth.

images.alt_text: Singapore aims to plug the gaps that food delivery and ride-hailing workers face in financial security

While orders were up 4 per cent in the international division, Deliveroo reported flat order growth in the UK and Ireland due to a “more stable but still uncertain consumer environment” in the region.

site_title: Tokyo Electron ups forecast after AI demand helps sales beat
summary: Tokyo Electron raised its full-year operating profit forecast to 627 billion yen (S$5.7 billion), up 8% from previous guidance, after beating analyst expectations with a 8% surge in sales. The company cited strong growth trends from the previous fiscal year, primarily due to investments in mature generation of semiconductors in China. Revenue for the quarter to June was 555 billion yen, above expectations, and operating profit for the quarter was 165.7 billion yen. The company sees no sign of stricter US curbs on chip tools incoming, and continues to monitor the situation closely.

images.alt_text: Exempting companies such as ASML and Tokyo Electron from such a move would mean Chinese manufacturers would be able to manoeuvre around stricter restrictions.

site_title: Gold drifts higher on Middle East tensions, US rate outlook
summary: Spot gold rose 0.3% to US$2,389.42 per ounce, driven by Middle East tensions and optimism over US rate cuts. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield slipped, making non-yielding bullion more attractive. Market analysts forecast a 50 basis-point interest rate cut by the Fed in September. Silver, platinum, and palladium also saw gains, while Impala Platinum reported a US$1 billion impairment due to lower metal prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 0.2 per cent at US$2,385.23 per ounce.

site_title: Malaysia boasts of chip clout as Infineon opens 7 billion euro site
summary: Infineon Technologies has opened a major semiconductor manufacturing complex in Malaysia's Kulim district, valued at $10.1 billion, as the country aims to boost its chip industry. The new plant, expected to create 4,000 jobs, will focus on power semiconductors for automotive, industrial, and data centre fields, helping with decarbonisation efforts. This move highlights Malaysia's potential to attract tech investments amid geopolitical uncertainties, following a series of efforts by the government to upgrade its chip industry.

images.alt_text: Themed “Stronger Together”, the event will provide an overview of the latest industrial developments, trends and innovations, as well as critical areas including efficiency, artificial intelligence, chip technology and workforce development.
“The interest in data centres will continuously drive the demand for semiconductors,” Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said.

site_title: Singaporean David Yong from Netflix’s Super Rich In Korea faces more fraud charges, denied bail
summary: Singaporean businessman David Yong, CEO of Evergreen Group Holdings, has been handed two new charges over falsifying accounts, bringing the total to five charges. Yong allegedly falsified tax invoices to defraud his employee, Jolene Low Mong Han, and could face up to 10 years in jail or a fine. He was denied bail on August 8 after the prosecution argued that he is a flight risk due to his possession of a Cambodian identity card. Yong's case will be heard again on August 15.

images.alt_text: David Yong was arrested on Aug 1 and charged on Aug 3.

site_title: SGX derivatives volume rises 15% in July
summary: SGX derivatives volume surged 15% year-over-year to 23.5 million contracts in July, driven by global investors seeking to manage risk amid increased volatility. This increase was particularly evident in the Tokyo Overnight Average Futures, which topped 532 lots, and record forex futures volume, up 44% year-on-year. The bourse attributed the growth to bolstered portfolio hedging, fueled by anticipated rate decisions and uncertainties over the US presidential elections.

images.alt_text: The proposed final quarterly dividend will be payable on Oct 25, upon approval by shareholders at SGX’s upcoming annual general meeting on Oct 10.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday as DBS weakens; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's stock market declined on Thursday, with the STI down 0.2% due to DBS' share price dropping 0.8% after announcing CEO Piyush Gupta's retirement in 2025. The broader market saw 76 losers compared to 50 gainers. Analysts expect a modestly negative reaction to Gupta's departure, but anticipate an internal candidate to ease concerns about strategy continuity.

site_title: Philippines Q2 GDP rises 6.3% y/y, just above forecasts
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.3% in Q2, surpassing forecasts, driven by government spending and investment. This brings first-half GDP growth to 6.0%, on track to meet the 6.0-7.0% full-year target. Inflation is expected to revert to its longer-term downtrend, according to Economic Planning Secretary Arsenio Balisacan. The growth beats the 6.2% forecast in a Reuters poll, and the 0.5% quarter-on-quarter growth is below expectations.

site_title: Qantas scraps non-stop UK flight due to Middle East unrest
summary: Qantas scrapped its non-stop Perth to London flight due to tensions in the Middle East, redirecting the flight to refuel in Singapore. This is the second time this year the airline has been forced to redirect flights due to unrest in the region. The decision comes as Iran and Hamas threaten reprisals for the killing of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh. The return service will continue to fly non-stop on a readjusted path.

Falling fares reflect the growing number of international flights on offer, particularly in Asia and Europe, and a travelling public that is increasingly cost conscious.

site_title: Australia’s central bank won’t hesitate to raise rates if needed, governor says
summary: Australia's central bank Governor Michele Bullock has reaffirmed her commitment to raising interest rates if needed to control inflation, despite holding rates steady in recent months. Bullock cited the risk of persistently high inflation as a concern, stating it would "hurt everyone." The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has set its inflation target at 2-3% and has maintained a cash rate of 4.35%, which is above the pre-pandemic level of 0.1%. The central bank will not lower rates quickly unless the economy slows down significantly.

images.alt_text: Reflecting stronger consumer demand and public spending, Australia’s economic growth is expected to pick up to 1.7 per cent by the year end and to 2.6 per cent by June 2025.

site_title: SGX H2 profit up 10.5% to S$316.3 million; proposes Q4 dividend of S$0.09 per share
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 10.5% increase in H2 profit to S$316.3 million, driven by a 17.6% surge in operating revenue from fixed income, currencies, and commodities. The proposed final quarterly dividend of S$0.09 per share, a 5.9% increase, is in line with the company's target of mid-single digit percentage compound annual growth rate. SGX aims to increase group revenue, excluding Treasury income, to a 6-8% CAGR over the medium term.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange CEO Loh Boon Chye said “not at the moment”, when asked whether SGX would be open to crypto listings.
The board has declared an interim quarterly dividend of S$0.085 per share, payable on Feb 20. This brings total dividends in H1 FY2024 to S$0.17 per share.
SGX's full year net profit for FY2023 rises to S$503.2 million from S$456.4 million.

site_title: Old Chang Kee among 7 Singapore firms named in Forbes Asia Best Under A Billion list
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Singaporean fast-food chain, has been named one of seven local firms in Forbes Asia's Best Under A Billion list for 2024. The list recognizes top-performing public companies in the Asia-Pacific with annual sales above $10 million but below $1 billion. Old Chang Kee posted a 50% rise in net profit to $5.3 million in the six months to March 31, 2024, and has outlets in Malaysia, Indonesia, Australia, and Britain. The company's inclusion is attributed to strong domestic demand and global trade driving the region's overall growth in 2023.

images.alt_text: Old Chang Kee noted that inflationary pressures have remained persistent, particularly for raw material and labour costs.
Bak chor mee at Singapulah is made with mee pok from Hiap Giap, sauces from Kwang Cheong Thye and fishballs from DoDo.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated further rate hikes in July, one saw neutral rate at 1%: summary
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) debated further interest rate hikes in July, with some members suggesting rates should reach 1% to counter inflation. The BOJ raised its short-term policy target to 0.25% and released a plan to taper asset buying, shifting away from a decade-long stimulus program. Some board members believe inflation-adjusted interest rates will remain low, supporting the economy with loose monetary policy. The neutral interest rate, considered the level that neither cools nor overheats the economy, is estimated to be around 1% by analysts.

site_title: Thai central bank chief says wants to boost credit access for SMEs
summary: Thailand's central bank is exploring ways to reduce credit risks for small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs), aiming to improve their access to loans. Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stated that SMEs are crucial to the country's economy and wants to promote a more accessible loan ecosystem with reasonable interest rates. The Bank of Thailand is also considering a flexible loan guarantee mechanism. This move comes as the country's economy continues to recover from the pandemic, with a forecasted growth rate of 2.6% this year and 3% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Despite government calls for policy easing, the Bank of Thailand held its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2.50 per cent for a fourth straight meeting last month. The next rate review is on Aug 21.

Thailand’s central bank governor warned that any move to raise the monetary authority’s inflation target may unanchor expectations and result in quickening price gains, which carries risks for economic growth. site_title: South Korea prosecutors indict Kakao group founder on stock manipulation charges
summary: South Korean prosecutors have indicted Kakao group founder Kim Beom Su, also known as Brian Kim, on charges of stock market manipulation. Kim, billionaire founder of tech giant Kakao Corp, was arrested last month and has been detained since. Prosecutors claim he manipulated the stock price of SM Entertainment in February last year to hinder a competitor, Hybe, from acquiring it. Kim has denied the accusations, stating he never ordered or tolerated any illegal activity.

images.alt_text: Brian Kim, founder of Kakao Corp, arrives at the Seoul Southern District Court in Seoul, South Korea, July 22, 2024.
Kakao won a controlling stake in SM after an intense bidding battle with Hybe, the label behind boyband sensation BTS.

Kakao fought an intense battle for SM with Hybe, the label behind boyband sensation BTS, electrifying South Korea as two of the best-known K-pop labels slugged it out over for control of their destinies.

site_title: Doubts cast over Tesla’s EV ambitions in South-east Asia
summary: Tesla has reportedly dropped plans to set up manufacturing plants in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia, according to a Thai news portal. The move comes as the US electric vehicle maker faces stiff competition from Chinese and South Korean contenders in the region. Malaysia's Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry has dismissed the report, stating that it is not an official statement from Tesla and that the company will focus on developing charging facilities instead. This decision marks a broader withdrawal from investments in Asia and beyond, with Tesla's focus shifting to China, the US, and Germany.

site_title: 2024 ‘increasingly likely’ to be warmest on record: EU monitor
summary: The EU's climate monitor, Copernicus Climate Change Service, has stated that 2024 is "increasingly likely" to be the hottest year on record, despite July ending a 13-month streak of record-breaking temperatures. The month of July 2024 was 1.48°C warmer than the estimated average temperatures for the month from 1850-1900. Global temperatures have been above the 1991-2020 average by 0.70°C from January to July, making it increasingly likely that 2024 will surpass 2023 as the warmest year on record.

site_title: Infinity Financial Advisory bolsters advisory team with the appointment of Lee Song Yong as Financial Services Director
summary: Infinity Financial Advisory has appointed Lee Song Yong as its new Financial Services Director. With a 20-year career in serving high-net-worth individuals, doctors, lawyers, and senior executives, Song Yong brings expertise in financial planning and a client-centric approach. His appointment aims to enhance the company's service offerings and align with its mission to provide comprehensive financial solutions. Song Yong joins a company that has grown in strength and is considered the FA of choice for top financial adviser representatives and team leads.

site_title: Strong fees, more resiliency will boost earnings in 2024 despite rising uncertainty: DBS CEO
summary: DBS Bank reported a strong Q2 with net profit rising 6% to S$2.79 billion, beating consensus forecasts. CEO Piyush Gupta attributed the growth to a strong fees business, lower interest rate sensitivity, and stable loan growth. The bank also reduced specific provisions guidance to 10-15 bps of loans. Gupta raised 2024 forecasts for total income and net profit growth, expecting a "pretty solid year" despite rising uncertainty. DBS' total income growth is expected to be a high single digit, with group net interest income growth likely in the mid-single digit range.

images.alt_text: Tan will be the first female CEO at DBS.
Tan Su Shan, DBS’ group head of institutional banking and newly appointed deputy CEO, will take over the helm from CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025.
DBS Group Holdings saw fees from wealth management jump 37 per cent to S$518 million, faster than the growth from lending income.
The lender declares a dividend of 54 Singapore cents per share for the period, up from 44 cents in the year-ago period.
Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

site_title: Amazon deforestation rises for the first time in 15 months
summary: Amazon deforestation rose 33% in July, the first increase in 15 months, with 666 sq km destroyed. This is a 33% increase from the 500 sq km lost in July 2023. Deforestation had decreased by 45.7% over the last 12 months. The increase is attributed to a strike by public employees in the environmental agency IBAMA and a high decrease in deforestation in the previous year. Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has pledged to stop illegal deforestation by 2030.

site_title: Oil settles 2% higher on falling US crude stockpiles, rebounds from multi-month lows
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, rebounding from multi-month lows, after US crude stockpiles fell by 3.7 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. Brent crude futures settled at $78.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 2.77% to $75.23. The tighter supply and stronger demand than expected are supporting oil prices, with lower production at Libya's Sharara oilfield also adding to concerns.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose by 18 cents, or 0.2 per cent to settle at US$76.48 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Sasseur Reit H1 DPU falls 5.1% to S$0.03153
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a 5.1% decline in DPU to S$0.03153 for the first half of 2024, driven by changes in upfront borrowing costs and manager's base fee. Distributable income fell 2.9% to S$42.7 million. Despite a 0.9% increase in rental income in yuan terms, the Reit's EMA rental income fell 0.4% in SGD terms. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate remained stable at 97.8% and gearing stood at 25.3%. Despite the decline, the Reit's management remains positive on China's economic outlook for the rest of the year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, SGX, Frasers Property, Sasseur Reit
summary: DBS announced Tan Su Shan as its new deputy CEO, set to succeed Piyush Gupta as CEO in March 2025, marking the bank's first female CEO. The Singapore Exchange reported a 10.5% increase in net profit for the second half of 2024, and proposed a final quarterly dividend. Frasers Property noted a challenging operating environment in Thailand, while Sasseur Reit reported a 5.1% decline in distribution per unit for the first half of 2024.

site_title: China’s drivers fret as robotaxis pick up pace – and passengers
summary: China's ride-hailing drivers face job loss as thousands of robotaxis hit the streets, threatening a nationwide glut of unsold apartments. By year-end, Baidu's robotaxi service plans to deploy 1,000 vehicles in Wuhan, with ambitions to operate in 100 cities by 2030. Economists warn that automation could benefit China in the long run, but in the short term, a balance must be struck between job creation and destruction. Industry leaders, including Apollo Go and Pony.ai, are pushing for swift permits and approvals, with some cities approving tests without human-driver monitors, sparking concerns over safety.

summary: Qantas has decided to cut former CEO Alan Joyce's 2023 pay by A$9.26 million (S$8 million) due to the airline's attempts to restore trust among investors and fix its reputation. Joyce, who retired in September 2023, initially took home A$21.4 million (S$18.5 million) in the 2023 financial year. The decision comes after a governance review found that the board made "mistakes" that resulted in significant reputational and customer service issues, leading to growing calls for management reorganisations.

site_title: Manulife’s second-quarter profit rises on strong Asia growth
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial reported a 40% rise in Asia earnings, driven by a 93% increase in Japan sales and a 61% jump in Canada business. The company's Asia business, which includes 12 markets and 100+ bank partnerships, is a key income generator. Manulife's core earnings rose to $1.74 billion, exceeding analyst expectations, and the company expects higher returns on equity and cash generation of over $22 billion by 2027. The insurer's shares have jumped 13.4% this year, outperforming smaller peer Sun Life.

site_title: UK jobs market stays in slow gear, recruiters say
summary: The UK jobs market remains sluggish, with permanent hiring extending a nearly two-year downturn, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation. Pay increases were weaker than in June, with temporary staff seeing the weakest pace of pay increases in nearly three and a half years. The survey suggests businesses may be cautious about investment until the Autumn Budget. The Bank of England is watching pay growth as part of its assessment of inflation pressures.

site_title: US: Stocks finish lower as rally loses steam
summary: US stocks finished lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% at 38,763.45, following a weak start. The S&P 500 dropped 0.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 1.1%. Analysts attribute the decline to lingering unease after recent market weakness, including a poorly received US Treasury bond auction and concerns over a potential US recession. Individual companies like Disney, Airbnb, and TripAdvisor also fell sharply due to disappointing earnings reports.

site_title: Small businesses flying the Singapore flag
summary: Local companies, including small and medium-sized enterprises, are establishing a presence overseas, showcasing Singapore brands abroad. The Kimen Group, a local developer, has ventured into London with Cedaroe Mansion, and the article highlights these lesser-known companies making inroads abroad. These businesses bring unique perspectives and experiences, contributing to Singapore's global presence.

site_title: Over 90% of US population growth since 2020 came from Hispanics
summary: The US population grew by 3.4 million from April 2020 to July 2023, with 91% of this growth attributed to the Hispanic population, which increased by 3.2 million. This "diversity explosion" is driven by a combination of immigration, shifts in births and deaths, and a decline in the White population. The trend is seen as a significant aspect of the nation's future, highlighting the need for American policies and politics to recognize and adapt to this demographic shift.

site_title: Climate change is fuelling rise in hot nights: analysis
summary: Human-induced climate change is significantly increasing the number of hot nights globally, affecting nearly one-third of the world's population. According to a global analysis, around 2.4 billion people experienced additional weeks of hot nights over the past decade, with extreme temperatures gripping vast areas of the world. The World Health Organization recommends keeping nighttime temperatures below 24°C, as high temperatures can harm sleep and physical recovery, leading to cascading impacts on health outcomes. Climate change is fuelling a rise in nights above 25°C, particularly in vulnerable populations.

site_title: Biden ‘not confident’ of peaceful transfer if Trump loses
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed concerns over a peaceful transfer of power to Vice-President Kamala Harris if Donald Trump loses the November election. In a CBS interview, Biden stated he is "not confident at all" of a calm handover, citing Trump's past comments about not accepting a defeat. Trump has maintained false claims of election rigging and hinted at a "bloodbath" if he loses. Biden framed Trump as a threat to US democracy, warning that Trump's allies could try to manipulate election counts.

site_title: Robinhood results beat estimates on meme-stock, crypto-trading boom
summary: Robinhood's second-quarter earnings exceeded expectations, driven by a surge in meme-stock and crypto-trading activity. The company's transaction-based revenue rose 69% to $327 million, and its quarterly net interest revenue jumped 22% to $285 million. The stock rose 2.6% in extended trading after the company teased the launch of a desktop version of its mobile trading application. Despite regulatory challenges, Robinhood's CEO expressed optimism about the company's growth prospects, citing its market share gains from rivals and the potential for new products to drive revenue.
