site_title: Shipper Maersk sees growth slowing after Red Sea crisis boost
summary: Maersk, a barometer of world trade, reported a 7% year-on-year increase in global container demand in the first half of 2024, driven by robust demand from Europe, emerging markets, and strong Chinese exports. However, the company expects growth to slow in the second half of the year due to customers stockpiling goods to prevent disruptions caused by the Red Sea crisis. CEO Vincent Clerc stated that the strong start to the year was largely due to customers' efforts to mitigate risks, and growth is now expected to be less strong.

images.alt_text: Containers are seen on the Maersk's Triple-E giant container ship Majestic Maersk, one of the world's largest container ships, next to cranes at the APM Terminals in the port of Algeciras, Spain January 20, 2023. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File photo

site_title: ‘Star Wars’ star Daisy Ridley diagnosed with Graves’ disease
summary: British actress Daisy Ridley, 32, has been diagnosed with Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder affecting the thyroid, she revealed in a recent interview. The Star Wars star, who previously discussed struggles with endometriosis and polycystic ovaries, experienced fatigue and irritability after filming the thriller Magpie in 2023. Ridley shared her diagnosis in an article with Women's Health, marking the first time she has publicly spoken about her Graves' disease diagnosis.

images.alt_text: (From left) Ryan Reynolds, Blake Lively, Gigi Hadid and Hugh Jackman attend the premiere of 'Deadpool and Wolverine' in New York City, New York, July 22, 2024.
Meta is racing to close deals so it has time to develop a suite of AI tools for unveiling at its Connect 2024 event in September.
The restaurant is staying, at least for now.

Victoria Beckham in New York on April 30, 2024. At 50, and after some promising years for her business, the designer and former Spice Girl has softened up (a little). (Luisa Opalesky/The New York Times)

site_title: GoTo investors may need a more exciting growth story
summary: GoTo Group, Indonesia's ride-hailing and food delivery player, reported a 39% increase in Q2 revenue to 4.3 trillion rupiah, driven by its on-demand segment, which includes Gojek. Despite narrower losses, the company's share price has fallen 85% since its IPO in 2022, with investors seeking more exciting earnings drivers. The company aims to increase revenue further and hit adjusted Ebitda breakeven for the full year. GoTo's fintech arm is seen as a potential growth story, but a merger with Grab is also being considered to unlock cost savings.

images.alt_text: Citi Research maintained its "buy" call on GoTo.
GoTo's second-quarter net revenue, which strips out incentives to driver and merchant partners and promotions to users, rose 115 per cent on a pro-forma basis to 3.5 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Five things to know about DBS’ CEO-designate Tan Su Shan
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, has announced the appointment of Tan Su Shan as its deputy chief executive officer. She will become the bank's first female CEO, succeeding Piyush Gupta, who will retire on March 28, 2025. Tan currently serves as head of institutional banking and is poised to become the second woman to lead a Singapore bank, following Helen Wong's appointment at OCBC in 2021.

images.alt_text: Female empowerment in the workplace has been high on Ms Tan's agenda for much of her career.
Tan Su Shan, DBS’ group head of institutional banking and newly appointed deputy CEO, will take over the helm from CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025.
The lender declares a dividend of 54 Singapore cents per share for the period, up from 44 cents in the year-ago period.
Piyush Gupta, Chief Executive Officer and Director of DBS Group, at Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 3 on Oct 26, 2022.
Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

ST20230811_202347069730/Azmi Athni//

Profile of Mr Piyush Gupta, Group CEO of DBS on August 11, 2023.

Mr Gupta speaking to the media at the DBS Headquarters about DBS’ 10-year commitment to uplift vulnerable and low-income communities in Singapore and the bank’s five other key markets.

(ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI)

site_title: Meta begins blue-chip bond sale as market volatility eases
summary: Meta Platforms is selling investment-grade bonds, offering notes in five parts for general corporate purposes, with the longest portion yielding 1.55 percentage points above Treasuries. The sale is expected to boost Meta's cash pile as the company spends heavily on artificial intelligence. Analysts say the move gives Meta increased financial flexibility, allowing it to keep investing in AI and the metaverse despite having an ample amount of cash on its balance sheet. The sale comes as market volatility eases, with Meta's shares jumping after the release of second-quarter results that topped expectations.

images.alt_text: Malaysian government officials met with Meta representatives on Monday and later issued a missive calling the removal “discriminatory, unjust and a blatant suppression of free expression.”
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim accused Meta of “cowardice” last week for removing his posts.
Meta is racing to close deals so it has time to develop a suite of AI tools for unveiling at its Connect 2024 event in September.
Meta is investing in large language models, the technology that underpins AI chatbots.

site_title: Italy doubles ‘flat tax’ for the rich who move fiscal residence to country
summary: Italy's government approved a decree doubling the flat tax for wealthy individuals who move their tax residence to the country, from 100,000 euros to 200,000 euros. The change, aimed at boosting the economy, will only apply to those signing up in the future, while existing residents will continue to pay the lower rate. The move is seen as a bid to bolster Rome's public finances, but has been criticized by the EU as unjust and detrimental to state accounts.

images.alt_text: Trevi Fountain in Federico, Rome, Italy.
The Rome government could join Dongfeng with a minority stake in the investment which aims to set up a hub for the whole of Europe.
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing. Meloni is seeking to reset bilateral relations after Italy pulled out of the Belt and Road agreement.

site_title: Thailand’s food delivery sector edges towards consolidation
summary: Thailand's food delivery sector is expected to consolidate, with industry players anticipating restructuring and mergers as companies vie for dominance. Only Grab (Thailand) is currently profitable, with the others facing significant losses. Line Man Wongnai CEO Yod Chinsupakul predicts the market will consolidate, leading to profitable major players, citing the strong network effect and lower logistics costs. The sector's boom began in 2019, with companies like Robinhood and GET Food entering the market, but fierce competition has led to significant losses for many players.

images.alt_text: Line Man Wongnai sees a listing in Bangkok as its base case, but would also consider a dual listing if there is sufficient investor interest, says chief financial officer In Young Chung.
Grab's buzzy, neon-lit sign announcing “GrabFood Dine Out Deals in bars 24/7” at Clarke Quay MRT station.
Delivery Hero had attempted to sell off parts of the Foodpanda business to pull back from Asia this year with mixed success.

site_title: Frasers Property sees challenging operating environment for its business in Thailand
summary: Frasers Property has reported a challenging operating environment for its residential business in Thailand, with strong interest rates, minimum wage increases, and rising construction costs affecting the market. Despite this, the company has managed to drive sales through strategic diversification across housing segments and achieved a 10% reduction in average material costs. Its industrial and logistics portfolio in Thailand continues to perform well, with a 87% average occupancy rate and net leasing growth of 48,222 square meters.

images.alt_text: The loan facility has a tenure of five years.
Frasers Property’s capital recycling transactions total S$1.1 billion in H1 2024

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps 1% on banks-led recovery; Novo Nordisk slumps
summary: Europe's main stock index, the Stoxx 600, rose 1.5% on Wednesday, its largest one-day gain since November, driven by a strong comeback by banks. The banking index jumped 2.7% and ABN Amro raised its full-year net interest income forecast. Meanwhile, Novo Nordisk slumped 6.7% after trimming its full-year profit outlook. European Central Bank policymaker Olli Rehn said rate cuts can continue if confidence in slowing inflation strengthens.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, May 27, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: China Evergrande unit faces liquidation petition over unpaid sum
summary: A liquidation petition has been filed against Guangzhou Kailong Real Estate, a unit of China Evergrande Group, over an unpaid investment of 200 million yuan. Guangdong Vanward New Electric claims the unit owes the investment sum, 10% annual interest, and an arbitration fee of over 1.4 million yuan. The petition comes after liquidators sought to recover US$6 billion from seven defendants, including Evergrande's founder Hui Ka Yan. Kailong holds a 60% stake in Hengda Real Estate, Evergrande's main property unit.

site_title: Thousands of riot police on standby as UK fears more riots
summary: The UK remains on high alert for violent far-right protests, with thousands of riot police on standby. Nightly riots, targeting mosques and migrant communities, have erupted in English towns since three children were murdered in a knife attack on July 29. Over 430 people have been arrested and at least 120 charged, with the government vowing to take a tough line on the unrest. Prime Minister Keir Starmer has warned of "substantive sentencing" for those involved, and the UK has seen its worst unrest in 13 years, prompting warnings from countries about traveling in the UK.

images.alt_text: The government says the police have “all the resources they need” to deal with the disorder as officers warned of more demonstrations on Sunday, leading to fears the unrest could spread further again.

site_title: Another digital trade deal, what’s the big deal?
summary: The European Union and Singapore have concluded negotiations on a Digital Trade Agreement (EUSDTA), the EU's first bilateral digital economy agreement. The agreement sets rules for cross-border data flows and consumer protection, aiming to enhance market access and digital trade. The EU's preference for open and secure data flows is reflected in the agreement's provisions, including prohibitions on data localisation requirements. The deal is seen as a step forward in digital trade governance, but its effectiveness depends on implementation and enforcement, as well as the development of regulatory frameworks and technologies.

images.alt_text: European Commission’s Executive Vice-President for an Economy that Works for People and Commissioner for Trade Valdis Dombrovskis and Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations Grace Fu jointly made the announcement on Thursday (Jul 25).

site_title: Bangladesh Nobel winner Yunus to lead interim govt
summary: Bangladesh Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus has been appointed to lead an interim government after mass protests forced Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to flee. Yunus, 84, was chosen in a meeting with President Mohammed Shahabuddin, military leaders, and student leaders. He will serve as chief advisor and has called for a free and fair election within a few months. The move comes after hundreds of thousands of people protested against Hasina's rule, resulting in the deaths of at least 455 people since early July.

images.alt_text: The release of Zia (above) comes after her bitter enemy Sheikh Hasina was ousted as premier.
People waves Bangladeshi flags on top of the Ganabhaban, the Prime Minister's residence, as they celebrate the resignation of PM Sheikh Hasina in Dhaka, Bangladesh, Aug 5, 2024.
Anti-government protesters clash with police and pro-government supporters,  Dhaka, Bangladesh, Aug 4, 2024.
Yunus, known as the “banker to the poorest of the poor”, was awarded the Peace Prize in 2006 for his work loaning small cash sums to rural women.

site_title: Shopify soars as AI focus powers quarterly beat, bullish forecast
summary: Shopify reported a 21% jump in second-quarter revenue to US$2.05 billion, beating analysts' average estimate of US$2.01 billion. The company's AI-enabled tools attracted more merchants to its e-commerce services, sending its shares up over 20%. Shopify forecast upbeat sales growth in the third quarter, with revenue expected to grow at a low-to-mid-twenties percentage rate year-over-year. The company's gross merchandise volume rose 22% to US$67.2 billion, and over 10,000 merchants posted their best GMV week ever on the company's Shop App.

images.alt_text: Shopify has launched new tools and offerings along with artificial intelligence products to stay ahead in a competitive e-commerce space.
Shopify provides software and services to online sellers.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, August 7, 2024 (Ep 118)
summary: Asian stocks rallied on Wednesday, driven by the Bank of Japan's reassurance to investors, while the yen fell. DBS Group reported a 6% increase in Q2 profit to S$2.79 billion and declared a S$0.54 per share dividend. Sembcorp rose as much as 7% after its H1 profit increased. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 1%, following the market's open.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Wednesday.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as tech stocks surge
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 rising 53.1 points, or 1.01%, to 5,293.13, and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 255.5 points, or 1.56%, to 16,622.31. The gains came after Japan's top policymaker calmed investor concerns over interest rates, partly alleviating volatility in global markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 232.4 points, or 0.60%, to 39,230.09.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - AUGUST 06: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on August 06, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up slightly up in the three major indexes a day after the Dow Jones and the S & P 500 had their worst day of trading since 2022, amid a global market sell-off centered around fears of a U.S. recession.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Boeing’s instructions to workers criticised as complicated, confusing
summary: Boeing's quality management system has come under scrutiny after a worker representative criticized its complexity and ambiguity, citing frequent changes to procedures and instructions that can lead to misinterpretation. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers representative, Lloyd Catlin, stated that Boeing's system is "very complicated" and "open to misinterpretation." The criticism follows a scathing FAA report earlier this year that faulted Boeing for unclear processes. Boeing is trying to simplify instructions and get more feedback from shop floor workers, but the company's factory processes remain under investigation by regulators and safety inspectors.

images.alt_text: Boeing’s senior vice-president for quality Elizabeth Lund said the planemaker is working on design changes that it hopes to implement within the year and then to retrofit across the fleet.
National Transportation Safety Board chair Jennifer Homendy attends a NTSB hearing on the Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 MAX door accident at NTSB headquarters in Washington.

site_title: Health experts urge Olympics to cut ties with Coca-Cola
summary: Health experts Trish Cotter and Sandra Mullin have urged the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to cut ties with Coca-Cola due to the company's sponsorship of the Olympics promoting unhealthy sugary drinks and contributing to global plastic pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, and water waste. The experts argue that Coca-Cola's "sportswash" strategy allows the company to profit from unhealthy products while claiming to support athletes and the environment. The IOC has defended its partnership with Coca-Cola, citing the company's efforts to offer sugar-free options and reduce plastic use.

images.alt_text: FILE — Weight lifter Jeon Sang-guen performs during the Summer Olympics in London, 2012. After his Russian rival, Ruslan Albegov, secured third place, Jeon returned home and started a new life. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

World silver medallist Erriyon Knighton tested for the banned substance trenbolone this year but was not suspended for the Paris Games after an arbitrator found the result was likely caused by contaminated meat.
Nelly Korda of the United States has had a sensational start this year, with six tour titles including the first major of the year, the Chevron Championship.

Carolina Marin, a badminton player for Spain, wears her trading pins at the Olympic Village. Pin mania has come roaring back, elevated by celebrity star power and athletes chronicling their most prized conquests on social media.

US' Noah Lyles celebrates after winning the men's 100m final of the athletics event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at Stade de France in Saint-Denis, north of Paris, on August 4, 2024. (Photo by Loic VENANCE / AFP)

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate drops on weak jobs data, Fed rate-cut signals
summary: The US 30-year fixed mortgage rate dropped 27 basis points to 6.55% in the week ended Aug 2, its lowest level in 15 months. The Federal Reserve signaled a potential policy rate cut in September, which bolstered financial market bets on reduced borrowing costs. This decrease gives potential homebuyers relief in an increasingly unaffordable housing market, with home prices and borrowing costs rising in recent years. Refinancing applications rose sharply, and purchase activity edged up less than 1%.

images.alt_text: The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was five basis points lower than a week earlier when it averaged 6.78 per cent, mortgage finance giant Freddie Mac said.
Entry level buyers depend on their personal savings and incomes, which haven’t kept up with inflation.
New home sales in June came in at an annual, seasonally-adjusted, revised rate of 617,000.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage slipped five basis points to 6.82 per cent in the week ended Jul 19.
The slowdown came as prices reached another record in June, with the median sales price up 4.1 per cent to US$426,900.
Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, fell 2.2 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 980,000 units last month, the lowest level since last October.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage dropped 13 basis points to 6.87 per cent in the week ended Jul 12.
An index of housing market conditions from the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) and Wells Fargo slipped one point to 42, the lowest level this year.

site_title: Walt Disney earnings beat market estimates; profit slips at parks
summary: Walt Disney reported quarterly earnings that exceeded market estimates, driven by the success of animated film Inside Out 2 and its streaming services. Adjusted earnings-per-share reached $1.39, topping analyst estimates of $1.19. Revenue rose 4% to $23.2 billion, beating forecasts. However, the Experiences segment, which includes parks and consumer products, recorded a 3% decline in operating income due to "moderation" of demand at US parks. Disney's entertainment division reported a significant increase in operating income, with its combined streaming businesses turning a profit.

images.alt_text: Disney is transitioning to streaming from broadcast and cable TV, where audiences are shrinking and ad sales are declining.
Walt Disney is eliminating about 140 jobs, or about 2 per cent of staff at Disney Entertainment Television.

site_title: Hilton lifts profit view as international travel offsets weak US demand
summary: Hilton Worldwide raised its 2024 profit forecast to $6.93-$7.03 per share, beating estimates, driven by strong international travel demand. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) grew 3.5% internationally, with 10.7% growth in the Middle East and Africa, but 2.9% in the US, where domestic travel has been weak. The company lowered its RevPAR growth forecast to 2-3% from 2-4%.

images.alt_text: The freehold property boasts four food and beverage outlets, two leased retail units, a fitness centre, and eight conference and meeting rooms.
Hilton forecast 2024 adjusted profit of between US$6.89 and US$7.03 per share

site_title: China’s July rare earths exports up as regulatory uncertainty spurs demand
summary: China's rare earths exports rose 7.5% in the first seven months of 2024, reaching 34,032 tonnes, driven by uncertainty over new regulations aimed at protecting rare earth supplies. In July, exports increased 2.24% from June, with 4,937 tonnes shipped. This surge is attributed to fears of potential export restrictions. Meanwhile, imports slid 44.3% in July from the prior year to 8,264 tonnes, largely due to reduced buying from Myanmar. The new regulations are set to take effect on October 1.

images.alt_text: The new regulation could reduce China’s supply of rare earths oxides by about 20 per cent, and that should provide support to domestic prices.
Rare earths are a group of 17 elements used in products as varied as lasers, military equipment, magnets for electric vehicles, wind turbines and consumer electronics.

site_title: Intel has lost Wall Street’s patience as headwinds keep mounting
summary: Intel's stock has lost nearly a third of its value since its grim earnings report, with the company facing headwinds including shrinking revenue, high production costs, and intense competition in the AI era. The company has cut 15,000 jobs and suspended its dividend, with analysts downgrading the stock and slashing estimates. Intel's valuation is now near 26 times estimated earnings, making it the least-liked semiconductor company among analysts. The company's turnaround plan is seen as expensive and slow, with investors losing patience as the stock continues to decline.

images.alt_text: Intel was set to lose about US$35 billion in market value as its disappointing forecast and planned 15 per cent job cuts raised worries about its ability to catch up with Taiwan’s TSMC and other chipmakers.
Intel shares slumped 20 per cent in extended trade, setting it up to lose more than US$24 billion in market value after its announcement.
Intel has reduced its workforce by about 5 per cent in 2023 to 124,800 by year’s end after announcing job cuts beginning in October 2022.
The semiconductor giant has been present in Israel for fifty years, with the opening of a research centre in Haifa.
Intel has invested US$18.4 billion in the facility to date.

site_title: Timeline: DBS’ key milestones under CEO Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta will retire at the bank's next annual general meeting on March 28, 2025. Gupta, who has been with the bank since 2009, will be succeeded by Tan Su Shan, who was appointed deputy CEO and group head of institutional banking. Under Gupta's leadership, DBS has undergone significant transformations, including simplifying its management structure, expanding into regional lenders and digitalizing its services. However, the bank has also faced challenges, including online banking disruptions. DBS has reported a record net profit of S$8.2 billion in FY2022 and has seen its market capitalization cross the S$100 billion mark, the first time for a Singapore-listed company.

images.alt_text: Tan will be the first female CEO at DBS.
The lender declares a dividend of 54 Singapore cents per share for the period, up from 44 cents in the year-ago period.
Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

ST20230811_202347069730/Azmi Athni//

Profile of Mr Piyush Gupta, Group CEO of DBS on August 11, 2023.

Mr Gupta speaking to the media at the DBS Headquarters about DBS’ 10-year commitment to uplift vulnerable and low-income communities in Singapore and the bank’s five other key markets.

(ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI)
For the second quarter ended Jun 30, 2024, OCBC’s net profit rose 14 per cent to S$1.94 billion, underpinned by income growth and a decline in allowances.

site_title: Singapore banks see wealth fees surge as rich step up trading
summary: Singapore's major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have seen a surge in wealth fees as the rich step up trading and asset shifts in the Asian wealth hub. DBS reported a 37% increase in wealth management fees to S$518 million, while OCBC and UOB also saw significant growth. The banks' earnings are driven by higher fund inflows, active trading, and expanding wealth franchises. Despite interest rate uncertainty, DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expects continued profit growth, with net income projected to expand in a mid- to high-single digit percentage in 2024.

images.alt_text: “All of us have fought the battle, and we have to prepare for the new ground, to energise the organisation,” said Wee Ee Cheong, deputy chairman and chief executive of UOB.
Net interest income falls 1 per cent on year, to S$2.4 billion, due to a moderation in net interest margin.
UOB Q2 profit rises 1% to S$1.43b; to pay S$0.88 per share dividend for H1
For the second quarter ended Jun 30, 2024, OCBC’s net profit rose 14 per cent to S$1.94 billion, underpinned by income growth and a decline in allowances.
Singapore banking counters have enjoyed strong share performances on expectations that the US Federal Reserve will hold rate cuts to later in the year, say analysts.
The lender declares a dividend of 54 Singapore cents per share for the period, up from 44 cents in the year-ago period.
Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

site_title: New York Times beats estimates, adds 300,000 digital subscribers
summary: The New York Times reported second-quarter earnings that beat analysts' expectations, with earnings per share of 45 cents and revenue of $625.1 million. The company added 300,000 digital subscribers, reaching a total of 10.84 million subscribers. Despite forecasted revenue of $624.6 million, ad revenue was lower due to weakening advertising spends. The company forecasts a 7-9% increase in subscription revenues for the third quarter.

site_title: Government rejects opposition’s suggestions to involve political parties, set hard criteria in electoral boundary changes
summary: The Singapore government has rejected opposition suggestions to involve political parties in the electoral boundary review process, citing concerns that it would politicize the process. The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has not yet been convened, and the government has also dismissed proposals to introduce major and minor boundaries, and to codify the committee's composition in law. The opposition, led by Progress Singapore Party (PSP) MPs, had called for greater transparency and fairness in the process, including publishing reasons for boundary changes and using algorithms to suggest changes.

images.alt_text: The upcoming general election must be held by November 2025.
The committee is typically made up of civil servants from the Singapore Land Authority, Housing Board, Department of Statistics and ELD.
There has been speculation that the upcoming general election, due by November 2025, may be called this year.

site_title: ‘Board decision was unanimous’: DBS appoints Tan Su Shan as deputy CEO, to succeed CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025
summary: DBS appoints Tan Su Shan as its new deputy CEO, succeeding CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025. Tan, who is DBS' group head of institutional banking, is the bank's first female CEO and the first home-grown staff member to hold the position. Her appointment was made by the unanimous board decision, marking a significant milestone for the bank.

images.alt_text: Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

ST20230811_202347069730/Azmi Athni//

Profile of Mr Piyush Gupta, Group CEO of DBS on August 11, 2023.

Mr Gupta speaking to the media at the DBS Headquarters about DBS’ 10-year commitment to uplift vulnerable and low-income communities in Singapore and the bank’s five other key markets.

(ST PHOTO: AZMI ATHNI)

site_title: Yen dives as BOJ plays down chance of hikes, soothing markets
summary: The yen fell 2.5% to a session low of 147.94 per US dollar after BOJ Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida played down the chance of a near-term rate hike, soothing investors' concerns about the currency's volatility. Uchida's comments contrasted with Governor Kazuo Ueda's hawkish comments last week, which led to a 12% crash in Japanese equities. The BOJ's rate hike and Tokyo's intervention in early July have contributed to a carry trade unwind, with the dollar index rising 0.18% to 103.16.

images.alt_text: The dollar was last at 144.75 yen, up 0.6 per cent on the day, the first day it has traded higher against the Japanese currency this month.
Shinichi Uchida's, which contrasted with Governor Kazuo Ueda’s hawkish comments made last week when the BOJ raised interest rates, boosted Japan’s Nikkei average and sent the yen sharply lower.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 7)
summary: DBS appoints Tan Su Shan as deputy CEO, succeeding CEO Piyush Gupta in March 2025. The bank's Q2 profit rose 6% to S$2.79 billion, and a dividend of S$0.54 per share was declared. Singapore sets up a task force to investigate the CrowdStrike IT outage's impact on digital resiliency. Additionally, Singapore banks see a surge in wealth fees due to the rich's increased trading activity, while the Straits Times Index rose 1.6% on Wednesday.

site_title: EU looks to ink major economic deal with Latin America this year
summary: The European Union is set to negotiate a major economic deal with Latin America this year, with the Mercosur trade agreement potentially key to Europe's economic diversification agenda away from China and Russia. The EU has around 300 billion euros of investments in Mercosur countries and is seeking a breakthrough deal with Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay. The agreement could be sealed at the G20 summit in Brazil in November, and EU officials believe there is a window of opportunity to ink an agreement this year.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on April 23, 2024, shows the European flag flying in front of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg eastern France. (Photo by FREDERICK FLORIN / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 5, 2020.  REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Industry event Semicon Southeast Asia, held in Malaysia since 2015, returns to Singapore next year
summary: Semicon Southeast Asia, a global supply chain and electronics manufacturing event, will return to Singapore in 2025 for its 30th anniversary. The event, themed "Stronger Together," will take place from May 20 to 22 at the Sands Expo and Convention Centre, with over 18,000 delegates expected to attend. The event highlights Singapore's key role in the global semiconductor ecosystem, emphasizing its dynamic business environment, strategic location, and robust infrastructure. The event aims to provide an overview of the latest industrial developments, trends, and innovations in the field.

images.alt_text: Most regional economies reported improvement in operating conditions, with some notable exceptions such as China and Malaysia.

site_title: Sony raises outlook after music, software help earnings beat
summary: Sony raised its forecast for revenue and profit in the fiscal year to March after beating earnings expectations with its music and gaming software divisions. The company reported a 279.1 billion yen operating profit, exceeding the consensus estimate and year-earlier profit of 253 billion yen. Sales are now expected to reach 12.6 trillion yen, with 1.3 trillion yen in operating profit. The music segment contributed the largest share of profit, driven by its catalogue of artists and growing overseas popularity of anime.

images.alt_text: The tale of a boy fighting human-eating demons which murdered his family, "Demon Slayer" is poised to become Japan's top-grossing film ever, thanks to a boost in fan numbers due to the coronavirus pandemic and its message of resilience.
Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of Queen at Wembley Stadium in 1986 wearing a crown and cloak during a performance.

Sony sent letters to more than 700 companies in an effort to protect its intellectual property, which includes album cover art, metadata, musical compositions and lyrics, from being used for training AI models.

This general view shows the Sony Group Corporation company name outside the company's headquarters in Tokyo on May 2, 2024. The Japanese entertainment and electronics conglomerate will release full year earnings on May 14. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Museum where blind get to feel the world’s wonders
summary: The Madrid Typhlological Museum, founded in 1992 by Spain's national organization for the blind, ONCE, features 37 reproductions of world heritage sites that allow blind visitors to explore through touch. The museum, accessible to all visitors, provides a hands-on sensory experience of architecture, including models made of wood, stone, metal, or resin. Visitors can explore iconic landmarks like the Taj Mahal, Sagrada Familia, and the Colosseum through tactile models, offering a unique and immersive experience.

images.alt_text: Artefacts dating back to the Chalcolithic and Bronze Age period are seen at the Cyprus Museum in Nicosia, Cyprus.
#SGJewelleryNow is staged as an intervention in the jewellery gallery of the Asian Civilisations Museum.

FILE — Visitors make their way through the Tower of Faces at the United States Holocaust Memorial in Washington, D.C., April 22, 2013. Students who visit Holocaust museums are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza? (Drew Angerer/The New York Times)

site_title: Thai court orders dissolution of anti-establishment Move Forward party
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court ordered the dissolution of anti-establishment opposition party Move Forward, ruling its campaign to amend a law protecting the monarchy from criticism risked undermining the democratic system. The decision comes after a court-ordered drop of Move Forward's plan to reform the law on royal insults. The ruling's impact may be minimal, with only 11 party executives receiving 10-year political bans. Move Forward's leaders announced plans to form a new party, despite the ruling, and vowed to continue their progressive agenda.

images.alt_text: Former prime ministerial hopeful Pita Limjaroenrat says his party will “fight tooth and nail” for its future amid efforts to bring down the party.

site_title: Vicom posts 1.3% higher H1 net profit of S$14.1 million
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, reported a 1.3% increase in its half-year net profit to S$14.1 million, driven by a 0.8% year-on-year revenue growth to S$56.3 million. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.028 per share, representing a payout ratio of 70%. Vicom expects strong demand for vehicle testing and related work, with plans to install On-board Units in Singapore-registered vehicles for electronic road pricing. However, profit margins are expected to remain under pressure due to strong competition.

images.alt_text: 为进一步提升本地空气质量，国家环境局将通过颁发现金奖励，鼓励拥有2003年7月1日前注册、排放污染较高的电单车车主在接下来五年内报销电单车。车辆检验中心维康（Vicom）的工作人员通过仪器检查电单车的操作性能和尾气排放。

Vicom expects demand for vehicle testing and related work to be “strong” as the company has been appointed by the Land Transport Authority as an authorised partner for the On-Board Unit installations, part of the Electronic Road Pricing 2.0 exercise.

site_title: Chinese regulators limit bond risks with duration cap on new funds: sources
summary: China's securities watchdog has asked major mutual fund companies to cap the duration of new bond funds to two years, aiming to curb investment in long-dated treasuries amid a sizzling bond rally. The move, targeting new bond funds managed by top mutual fund companies, aims to rein in funds that invest in medium- and long-dated bonds. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has also asked financial institutions to report daily changes in their long-term treasury bond positions, signaling tighter scrutiny of the bond market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A China yuan note is seen in this illustration photo May 31, 2017.     REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration

As part of the efforts to head off misbehaviour, the CSRC said it has been working to revise laws towards harsher punishment.

site_title: UK house prices rise by most since January, Halifax data shows
summary: UK house prices rose by 0.8% in July from June, the largest monthly increase since January, according to Halifax data. Annual house prices increased by 2.3%, the biggest yearly rise since January 2023. Economists had expected a 0.3% monthly increase. The Bank of England's recent interest rate cut to 5% is expected to continue a modest upward trend in house prices this year, despite affordability constraints and a lack of available properties.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers’ Index leapt to 55.3 – the highest since May 2022 – from 52.2 in June.
Taylor Wimpey said it now expects to build close to the upper end of its target range of 9,500 to 10,000 homes in 2024 in the United Kingdom.
House sales remain on track for 1.1 million in 2024, Zoopla says, but that’s still 10 per cent lower than the 20-year average.

Mortgage rates have been starting to come down as investors increasingly expect the BOE to cut its interest rate from a 16-year high, possibly as soon as Thursday, but this has not yet spurred an increase in purchases.
The average price of renting a private home in the UK capital rose 9.7 per cent in the 12 months to June.
Buyers are hoping the central bank could start cutting interest rates from a 16-year high when policymakers meet in August as inflation returned to the 2 per cent target.
FILE PHOTO: A company logo is seen on a banner outside a Bellway housing development in Liverpool, Britain, August 23, 2023. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
Activity in commercial construction and civil engineering rose, but the survey showed a renewed fall in residential building work.

site_title: S$25.7 million of S$60 million Agri-food Cluster Transformation Fund used as at April
summary: The Singapore Food Agency has awarded S$25.7 million of the S$60 million Agri-food Cluster Transformation (ACT) Fund to 42 companies across 68 projects as of April. The fund supports the transformation of the agri-food sector into a productive, climate-resilient, and resource-efficient one. Senior Minister Koh Poh Koon stated that the fund aims to promote long-term sustainability and durability, rather than directly offsetting operating expenses, which could be inefficient. The ACT Fund now includes energy-efficiency programs for energy audits and adopting renewable energy sources.

images.alt_text: Local vegetable and seafood production as a proportion of consumption has been slipping over the past three years, though hen shell production has grown.
A spread of Insect-based food items at the House of Seafood.
House of Seafood is one restaurant offering insect-incorporated dishes.

site_title: Google’s antitrust loss is a hollow victory for regulators
summary: US Judge Amit Mehta ruled that Google is a monopoly and its payment of billions of dollars to become the default search engine is illegal. The ruling is a significant victory for antitrust regulators, but it comes too late to curb Google's dominance in search. The court's decision will lead to a series of hearings to determine what should be done about it, with options including forcing Google to cancel its revenue-sharing agreements or requiring device makers to offer a "choice menu" to consumers. However, the process is expected to be arduous and the outcome uncertain, with Google likely to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: US District Court Judge Amit Mehta found that Google had a monopoly for search and for text ads through exclusive distribution agreements that made it the “default” option that people were likely to use on devices.

site_title: Flexxon inks MOU with CyberSecurity Malaysia, AI MSP to offer AI cybersecurity solutions
summary: Flexxon, an AI-powered hardware security solutions provider, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with CyberSecurity Malaysia and AI MSP to develop AI-driven cybersecurity solutions in Malaysia. The partnership aims to enhance Malaysia's cybersecurity framework and foster a safer digital environment for its citizens. Flexxon will provide cutting-edge hardware-based security solutions, while CyberSecurity Malaysia and AI MSP will promote capacity building in information technology and information security. The collaboration will enable the rapid adoption of Flexxon's cybersecurity technologies within the Malaysian government and establish best practices in cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: While AI can be a transformational tool in fields like cancer research, it also lowers the costs and barriers to entry for misfits and terrorists who might wish to cause harm.
No room for cyber threats with world's first AI-embedded SSD
Singapore cybersecurity firm launches world's first AI-embedded solid-state drive

site_title: The tiny Chinese restaurant that unwittingly became an Olympic hot spot
summary: A small Chinese restaurant in Paris, Yang Xiao Chu, has become an unofficial Olympic hot spot for table tennis athletes, team officials, and fans. The restaurant, run by Tang Zhongqiu, has been flooded with luminaries from China, such as Olympic gold medalists Ding Ning and Zhang Yining, who have sought comfort in Tang's authentic Sichuan dishes. The restaurant has become a makeshift clubhouse, with fans and celebrities gathering to watch games and share meals. Tang, who has lived in France for 20 years, has been overwhelmed by the unexpected demand, but has enjoyed the experience, saying it's "very happy" to see his dishes appreciated by the athletes.

images.alt_text: FILE — Weight lifter Jeon Sang-guen performs during the Summer Olympics in London, 2012. After his Russian rival, Ruslan Albegov, secured third place, Jeon returned home and started a new life. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

site_title: Singapore stocks end four days of losses; STI closes 1.6% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.6% on Wednesday, ending a four-day losing streak, after global equity markets recovered overnight. DBS shares rose 2.7% after posting a 6% improvement in second-quarter net profit. Other companies, such as Sembcorp Industries, also saw gains. The market saw a trading turnover of 1.2 billion securities valued at S$1.8 billion, with gainers beating decliners 379 to 207.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp announced a 2 per cent rise in net profit to S$540 million for the first half of the year.
Volatility coursed through Japan's markets with the Nikkei 225 suffering its biggest rout since 1987 on Monday, only to come roaring back 10 per cent the next day.
Technology solutions provider Venture Corporation is proposing an interim dividend of S$0.25 per share for H1.

site_title: Siemens Energy raises cash flow outlook as turnaround gains momentum
summary: Siemens Energy raised its free cash flow outlook for 2024, citing stronger demand for its power grid equipment and gas turbines. The company's third-quarter sales rose 18.5% to 8.8 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. Siemens Energy's shares have more than doubled since the beginning of the year, driven by the growth of the electricity market. The company now expects free cash flow of 1 billion-1.5 billion euros in 2024, up from an initial estimate of up to 1 billion euros.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A trader walks next to Siemens Energy AG logos during Siemens Energy's initial public offering (IPO) at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, September 28, 2020.     REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo
Siemens Energy’s wind unit has been in turmoil due to supply-chain bottlenecks, soaring costs and quality problems.
The job cuts plan comes shortly after Siemens Energy fleshed out major restructuring moves at Siemens Gamesa.

site_title: ABN Amro lifts full-year interest income outlook on higher rates
summary: ABN Amro raised its full-year interest income outlook to 6.4 billion euros, beating estimates and sending its shares 3% higher. The bank's net profit was above estimates at 642 million euros, down 26% compared to last year. ABN Amro attributes the boost to a "higher-for-longer" interest rate environment and a rebounding housing market. The bank also announced a 500 million euro buyback and a 60 cent euro per share interim dividend.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of ABN Amro Group NV stand in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Friday. Feb. 21, 2014. ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch bank preparing to sell shares to the public, said fourth-quarter losses widened 24 percent as economic woes in the Netherlands forced it to set aside more bad-loan provisions. Photographer: Jasper Juinen/Bloomberg

BNP Paribas Cardif intends to acquire all shares in Neuflize Vie for an undisclosed amount, creating a leader in high-end life insurance in France with assets under management of over 25 billion euros.
Banks have been among the main beneficiaries of rising interest rates over the last three years.

FILE PHOTO: ABN AMRO logo is seen at the headquarters in Amsterdam, Netherlands May 14, 2019. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw

site_title: Japan's April yen-buying intervention sets new daily record
summary: Japan conducted a record single-day yen-buying intervention in April, selling 5.92 trillion yen (S$53.5 billion) to combat a falling yen. The intervention, combined with another in May, helped push up the yen by 5% from a 34-year low but failed to reverse its longer-term weakness. Japan's foreign reserves fell to $1.22 trillion at the end of July, down $12.4 billion from a month earlier, largely due to a drop in foreign securities holdings.

images.alt_text: SoftBank posted a narrower quarterly net loss of 174.3 billion yen compared with a loss of 477.6 billion in the same period a year earlier.

site_title: Rents for Apac logistics spaces continue rising in H1, but slowly: Knight Frank
summary: Rents for logistics spaces in the Asia-Pacific region rose 2.4% in the first half of 2024, a slowdown from the 6.2% increase in 2023. This growth was driven by Singapore's strong manufacturing sector, with logistics rents in the Republic increasing 6.7% in the half-year period. However, other cities such as Beijing and Shanghai saw a 13.5% decline in rentals due to slowing business activities. Vacancies rose to over 20% in these markets, leading landlords to cut rents and shorten leases. More warehouses are being built in Chinese mainland markets, exacerbating the situation.

images.alt_text: Cars for export wait to be loaded on a ship at a port in Lianyungang, in eastern China's Jiangsu province, July 29, 2024.
More owners have turned to the auction market to sell their properties, say market watchers.

site_title: Hyundai to invest one billion baht in Thailand for EV assembly, batteries
summary: Hyundai Motor Company plans to invest one billion baht (S$37 million) in Thailand to assemble electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries. The facility, set to start production in 2026, will source at least a third of its raw materials and parts from within Thailand, supporting the local industry. This move comes as EV sales surge across South-east Asia, with Thailand accounting for 55% of the region's EV sales in the first quarter. The investment is expected to boost Thailand's booming EV sector, currently dominated by Chinese carmakers.

site_title: All COE premiums rise; large car category leads with 6.1% jump to S$106,101
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rose in August, with Category B (larger cars) increasing 6.1% to S$106,101. The rise is attributed to new Chinese EV brands Xpeng and Zeekr spurring purchases. Category E (open category) also rose 4.9%. The longer bidding interval between July and August contributed to increased demand, with a 29.1% increase in bids for Category B. Dealers attribute the rise to new brands and increased showroom footfall.

images.alt_text: EV cars
Production of the Hyundai Ioniq 6, now on sale, began in Singapore in late June 2024.
The quota for the commercial vehicle category increased the most, by 5.4 per cent.
The Zeekr X sport utility vehicle at the luxury Chinese electric vehicle maker's launch in Singapore at the ArtScience Museum on Thursday (Aug 1).

site_title: Honda Q1 profit jumps 23%, helped by hybrid vehicle sales
summary: Honda Motor reported a 23% increase in first-quarter profit to 484.7 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) due to a weaker yen, higher pricing, and growing hybrid vehicle sales in the US and Japan. The company maintained its full-year operating profit forecast of 1.42 trillion yen, despite slashing its sales outlook for China by 21% to 840,000 vehicles. Honda's global vehicle sales grew 2% to 1.9 million, with a 9% rise in US sales, while China sales slumped 23% to 416,000 vehicles due to intense competition.

images.alt_text: Nissan and Honda aim to conduct the basic research into technologies for the next-generation software platform in about a year.
Honda began manufacturing cars in China in 1999 and a move to reduce production would be the biggest by any Japanese automaker in the past few years.
Honda has seen the combined production at the plants fall from 228,000 vehicles in 2019 to under 150,000 a year for each of the four years to 2023.

AUSTIN, TEXAS - MARCH 18: The Honda logo is displayed at the Howdy Honda dealership on March 18, 2024 in Austin, Texas. Honda Motor and Nissan Motor shares rose significantly after the companies announced a collaboration on electric vehicles. Nissan shares rose 5.6%, with Honda shares rising 2.7%. The collaboration is an effort to compete with other automakers both in the U.S. and China.   Brandon Bell/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Brandon Bell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: German industrial output rises more than anticipated on cars
summary: German industrial production rose 1.4% in June, surpassing the one% median estimate, driven by cars and electrical equipment. This follows a bigger-than-expected gain in factory orders. However, exports declined 3.4% in June, contradicting predictions. The Bundesbank warns that industrial activity will improve only slowly, but predicts slightly firmer economic activity in the third quarter. A boost from industry could lead to a more balanced recovery for Germany, which has been struggling with stubborn inflation and fading wage increases.

site_title: South Korea logs biggest current account since 2017 on AI demand
summary: South Korea logged its largest current account surplus in over six years, driven by strong demand for AI and technology exports. The nation's exports grew, with semiconductors and communications devices leading the way, while imports of raw materials and capital goods fell. The surplus reached $12.3 billion in June, the most since September 2017. Export growth slowed in July, but policymakers believe it was a minor blip, with a global chips upturn driven by AI demand expected to continue. This data supports the central bank's decision to keep interest rates at a restrictive level.

site_title: How will the market respond to a US rate cut when it finally comes?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is under pressure to loosen monetary policy, possibly aggressively, despite the inflation situation. Despite initial projections of at least three rate cuts in 2024, none have occurred so far. Markets are expecting a rate cut in September, with a 100% chance of a reduction, but the chance of a 50-point cut has increased to 72%. A Fed rate cut may lead to a "relief rally" initially, but the market may then experience selling, as seen in the past year's gains.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq stock exchange in New York on Aug 5. There was a massive global stock-market sell-off in reaction to the US unemployment report.
The US unemployment rate has been gradually trending up over the past few months.

site_title: DBS Q2 profit rises 6% to S$2.79 billion; declares S$0.54 per share dividend
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 6% increase in net profit to S$2.79 billion for its second quarter, beating the consensus forecast. The bank declared a S$0.54 per share dividend and saw loans grow 3% and deposits rise 6% in constant-currency terms. Commercial book net interest income rose 5% and wealth management fees grew 37% amid a shift from deposits into investments. The bank's non-performing loans ratio remained unchanged at 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.

Singapore banking counters have enjoyed strong share performances on expectations that the US Federal Reserve will hold rate cuts to later in the year, say analysts.

site_title: China cities rush to lure homebuyers with sweeteners, price cuts
summary: China's top cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen, have eased homebuying requirements to revive demand, offering price cuts and downpayment incentives. Guangzhou, the country's first Tier-1 city to use the "Hukou" permit, will provide public education access to buyers of private properties. Other cities, including Suzhou and Zhengzhou, have also implemented similar measures. Local governments aim to stem the decline in housing demand, which deepened in July.

images.alt_text: China high-yield real estate bonds, once the largest segment of the Asia high-yield market with a 35 per cent weight, is now less than 10 per cent and is expected to shrink further.

A new residential property development in Wuhan, China, on Wednesday, March 15, 2024. Chinese officials on Friday, May 17, 2024, took their boldest step yet, unveiling a nationwide plan to buy up some of the vast housing stock languishing on the market. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

A residential building under construction at the China Vanke Co. Elegant Lifestyle project in Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. Vanke, the Chinese state-backed developer that's become the latest flashpoint in the nation's property crisis, is preparing an asset package totaling about 130 billion yuan ($18 billion) to use as collateral as it seeks new bank loans, people familiar with the matter said. The Zhengzhou's move could lead to further falls in house prices, putting pressure on homeowners and China’s weak property sector.

site_title: Cathay Pacific says profit drops 15%, declares interim dividend
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a 15% drop in first-half profit, citing strong demand for travel and a solid cargo business. Despite the decline, the airline paid its first dividend since 2019 and reported its first annual profit in four years in March. Load factor fell to 82.4% and passenger yield decreased by 11% to HK68.9 cents, but the company attributed its strong performance to robust travel demand.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembcorp rises as much as 7% after H1 profit increase
summary: Sembcorp's shares rose 7% after announcing a 2% increase in net profit to S$540 million for the first half of the fiscal year, driven by the absence of a S$78 million loss from a discontinued operation.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp has approved an interim cash dividend of S40.06 per share for the first half ended June.

site_title: Majority of HDB resale flats remain affordable to first-timers: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that the majority of Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale flats remain affordable to first-timers. Approximately eight in 10 first-timer families can service their monthly loan instalments with their Central Provident Fund, with minimal or no cash outlay. High-priced transactions continue to make up a small minority of total HDB resale transactions, alleviating concerns about the affordability of public housing.

images.alt_text: Will there be more refinements to Singapore's world class public housing at this year's NDR?
More than half of the resale flats transactions were from non-mature estates.

The rise is a notch higher than the earlier estimated 2.1 per cent released on Jul 1.

site_title: Samsung’s 8-layer HBM3E chips clear Nvidia’s tests for use, sources say
summary: Samsung's 8-layer HBM3E chips have passed Nvidia's tests for use in artificial intelligence (AI) processors, clearing a major hurdle for the company. The qualification comes amid soaring demand for sophisticated GPUs created by the generative AI boom, which Nvidia and other makers of AI chipsets are struggling to meet. Supplies are expected to start by the fourth quarter of 2024, with Samsung's 12-layer version of HBM3E chips still awaiting approval. This approval is seen as a significant step forward for Samsung, which is racing to catch up with rival SK Hynix in the market for advanced memory chips.

images.alt_text: Samsung and Nvidia have yet to sign a supply deal for the approved eight-layer HBM3E chips but will do so soon, the sources said, adding that they expect supplies would start by the fourth quarter of 2024.
Samsung, the world’s biggest maker of memory chips, smartphones and TVs said operating profit rose to 10.4 trillion won (S$10 billion) in April-June, up from 670 billion won a year earlier.
HBM is made up of a collection of Dram chips stacked on top of each other, eight high in the most recent generation.
The new foldables come as part of a wave of new devices introduced by Samsung in Paris.

site_title: Dubai airport traffic sets new half-year record
summary: Dubai International Airport set a new half-year record for passenger traffic with 44.9 million passengers, an 8% increase from 2023, and is on track to break annual records with 91.8 million forecasted for 2024. The airport's expansion plans, including a new $35 billion terminal, aim to increase capacity to 260 million passengers annually. Despite regional turmoil, strong demand from key markets such as India and China has contributed to the airport's success.

images.alt_text: From L-R: Ryan Gwee, founder and chairman, Aleta Planet; Al Ketbi, founder and chairman, National Pulse

site_title: Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat ‘highly confident’ ahead of possible ban
summary: Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat, former leader of the Move Forward Party, expressed confidence that a Constitutional Court ruling on whether to dissolve his party will favor him. The court is expected to decide on a ban due to the party's pledge to reform the royal insult laws. Limjaroenrat believes his party presented strong facts and argued the illegality of the process conducted by the Election Commission, which initially asked the court to dissolve the party. The ruling is expected on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Consumers were worried about future political instability and about the economy.
Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said he would talk with the central bank and National Credit Bureau about shortening the time that bad debtors remain on the bureau’s blacklist.

In Asia’s south, Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines remained above the 50 level that separates expansion from contraction, while Indonesia entered contraction territory.

site_title: The stock market rout may not be over
summary: The stock market rout may not be over, with concerns of a full-blown crisis still looming. Despite a brief recovery on August 6, the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices are down by 3% and 1% respectively. The VIX index, a measure of market volatility, spiked on August 5, indicating a high level of investor anxiety. Investors are selling assets indiscriminately, with popular trades such as Japanese stocks and AI-related bets being unwound. The risk of a margin call or a catastrophic collapse of a large investment vehicle remains, with potential contagion risks to the market.

images.alt_text: Volatility coursed through Japan's markets with the Nikkei 225 suffering its biggest rout since 1987 on Monday, only to come roaring back 10 per cent the next day.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signalled last week that the first interest rate cut could come “as soon as” September but some analysts fear that may not be soon enough, as the markets have responded in dramatic fashion to last week’s below-target US jobs report, which raised fears that the US was entering a recession.

The Bank of Japan’s decision on Wednesday (Jul 31) to raise rates to 0.25 per cent sent a wave of volatility through the market, with the Topix jumping 1.5 per cent on the day, only to plunge on both Thursday and Friday
Getting an accurate read on a person's risk tolerance is harder than it sounds. Investors tend to perceive markets as less risky when they’re going up, and riskier when they’re going down.

site_title: BlackRock, Nasdaq seek rule change to list options on spot Ethereum ETFs
summary: BlackRock and Nasdaq have proposed a rule change to list and trade options for the company's spot Ethereum exchange-traded fund (ETF). The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved similar ETFs from other firms in July. Options allow investors to buy or sell an asset at a predetermined price by a set date. The proposed rule change aims to provide investors with a lower-cost investing tool to gain exposure to spot ether. Comments on the proposal are due in 21 days.

site_title: SoftBank unveils US$3.4 billion buyback amid pressure from investors
summary: SoftBank Group, a Japanese technology investor, has announced a US$3.4 billion share buyback plan to boost its stock price amid investor pressure. The company, led by Masayoshi Son, posted a narrower quarterly net loss of 174.3 billion yen, down from 477.6 billion yen in the same period last year. SoftBank's market capitalization is significantly lower than its portfolio assets, leading to calls for a larger buyback program. The new plan, which represents 6.8% of shares, falls short of Elliott Management's US$15 billion request.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of SoftBank Group Corp is seen at the company's headquarters in Tokyo, June 30, 2016.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo
SoftBank’s stock fell 19 per cent, extending its decline for the September quarter so far to 38 per cent, in line to be the biggest such drop since 2001.

FILE PHOTO: Ola Electric's S1 Air e-scooters are pictured inside its manufacturing facility in Pochampalli in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, India, August 15, 2023. REUTERS/VarunVyas Hebbalalu/File Photo

PayPay Securities needs to increase its users and the amount of assets they invest in to meet its goal of becoming profitable in the next few years.

site_title: Has the AI bubble finally popped?
summary: The AI bubble has deflated, with the Nasdaq Composite closing 10% below its July peak and Japan's Nikkei entering bear-market territory. US tech stocks, including the Magnificent Seven mega-cap stocks, have been hit hard as investors grew tired of AI hype and demanded financial impact. The Nasdaq's decline has marked the end of the short-lived AI bull market, with the bigger question now being whether the bubble has popped irrevocably.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of New York's survey of household debt and credit conditions, showed that overall debt levels rose by US$109 billion, or 0.6 per cent, in the second quarter to US$17.80 trillion.

site_title: South Korea EV explosion prompts charging rethink, sparks safety fears
summary: A fire in an unplugged electric Mercedes-Benz sedan in South Korea's Incheon city has led to over 200 family evacuations, 140 damaged cars, and 23 hospitalizations. The incident has sparked concerns about EV safety and prompted office buildings and apartment complexes to reconsider EV charging. The country's National Fire Agency reported an increase in car fires, including EVs, since 2017, and lawmakers are proposing revisions to the Parking Lot Act to address safety concerns. The incident coinces with slowing global EV sales growth, adding to the challenges facing the industry.

summary: Singapore has set up a task force to assess the impact of the CrowdStrike software update incident, which caused a global tech outage and disrupted businesses with Microsoft Windows-based computers. The task force will engage with relevant partners to identify measures to improve the country's digital resilience. Minister for Digital Development and Information Josephine Teo stated that while the government has robust business continuity and disaster recovery plans in place, not all disruptions can be prevented. The task force's findings will inform further measures to enhance Singapore's digital resilience.

site_title: Thai headline inflation picks up in July, still below central bank target
summary: Thailand's annual headline inflation rate rose 0.83% in July, exceeding forecasts, but remained below the central bank's target range of 1-3%. The Commerce Ministry retains its forecast for the full year at 0-1%. The government's 500 billion baht handout scheme is expected to have little impact on product prices, and inflation is expected to remain steady in August. The Bank of Thailand keeps its benchmark interest rate steady at 2.50% despite calls to cut rates to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Can you heal Olympic heartbreak with belated medals?
summary: Weightlifter Jeon Sang-guen's Olympic heartbreak from a 2012 bronze medal finish in London was finally alleviated when the International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced his medal would be reinstated due to a doping violation by the Russian athlete who had finished ahead of him. Nearly 12 years after his initial disappointment, Jeon will receive his bronze medal, allowing him to pass on his Olympic legacy to his daughter, who is now a weightlifter herself, and fulfilling his wish to have her surpass him.

images.alt_text: Carolina Marin, a badminton player for Spain, wears her trading pins at the Olympic Village. Pin mania has come roaring back, elevated by celebrity star power and athletes chronicling their most prized conquests on social media.

site_title: PBOC eases support for yuan as short covering fuels rebound
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) reduced its daily support for the yuan to 7.1386, the lowest since November, amid a weakening US dollar and an unwind of leveraged short positions. This move suggests an opportunity for further monetary stimulus to boost China's sluggish economy. The yuan has pared losses against the US dollar in recent days. The PBOC's decision to close the spot-fix gap could lead to further easing, with some analysts predicting a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs.

site_title: EV fund outflows hit US$1.6 billion as Trump fears add to slowdown
summary: US electric vehicle (EV) funds have seen combined net outflows of $1.6 billion through July, with investors rushing out of the sector amid cooling growth forecasts and potential challenges under a potential Donald Trump reelection. Trump has vowed to ditch existing EV policies and extend tariffs on Chinese EV imports, threatening to exacerbate concerns over a slowdown in EV sales growth. The moves could also impact companies such as Tesla and BYD, with some analysts warning of devastating losses and a need for companies to reassess their outlook on the technology.

The company's shares gained 11.5% to S$0.58, with revenue growing 42.5% to S$259.7 million. Looking forward, Dyna-Mac is positive on future growth opportunities for its floating production storage and offloading vessels operations, supported by its current order book of S$681.3 million.

site_title: China’s exports growth slows to 3-month low in July, but imports up solidly
summary: China's exports grew 7.0% in July, the slowest pace in 3 months, but imports rose 7.2%, beating forecasts. The trade surplus narrowed to $84.65 billion, down from $99 billion forecast. The economy's growth rate in the second quarter was 4.7%, below expectations, and policymakers may need to roll out more support to hit the 5% growth target. Chinese leaders have pledged stimulus measures targeting consumers and will make "countercyclical adjustments" in the rest of 2024.

site_title: Elon Musk’s X sues advertisers over boycott
summary: Elon Musk's social media platform X has filed a federal antitrust lawsuit against the World Federation of Advertisers and several large corporations, alleging a "systematic illegal boycott" that has cost the platform billions of dollars in advertising revenue. X, formerly Twitter, accuses the group of conspiring to withhold ad revenue in response to concerns about content moderation and Musk's comments on the site. X is seeking a jury trial and unspecified damages, citing revenue losses of $114 million in the US in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: BOJ deputy governor plays down chance of near-term rate hike, yen slumps
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida played down the chance of a near-term interest rate hike, citing intense market volatility that could change the central bank's rate hike path. His comments, which contrasted with Governor Kazuo Ueda's hawkish remarks last week, led to a boost in Japan's Nikkei share average and a sharp decline in the yen. Uchida stated that the central bank will maintain current levels of monetary easing for the time being, citing factors that require caution about raising interest rates.

site_title: Indonesia launches China-built anode plant for EV batteries
summary: Indonesia has inaugurated a plant built by China's BTR New Material Group and Singapore's Stellar Investment to produce anode materials for electric vehicle (EV) batteries. The $778 million plant, which will produce 80,000 tonnes of materials per year, is part of Indonesia's efforts to develop a domestic EV industry. President Joko Widodo said the move is a key step in materializing his country's EV ecosystem, with plans to double production to 160,000 tonnes annually in the second phase.

images.alt_text: The plant is a joint venture between South Korean manufacturers Hyundai Motor Group and LG Energy Solution (LGES) and can produce up to 10 Gigawatt hours (GWh) of battery cells every year.

site_title: Airbnb plunges on soft outlook, signalling slowing US demand
summary: Airbnb's shares plummeted over 14% after the company delivered a disappointing third-quarter outlook, citing slowing demand from US travelers. The company expects "sequential moderation" of growth in nights and experiences booked, falling short of investors' estimates. Despite strong international travel demand, particularly in Latin America and Asia-Pacific, Airbnb's revenue growth is expected to slow, with the company blaming foreign exchange headwinds and investments in new markets. The decline sets up the slowest pace of growth since 2020.

site_title: Gold prices inch lower as US dollar, yields rebound
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,385.23 per ounce due to a stronger US dollar and rising Treasury yields. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates by 50 basis points in September, supporting gold prices. Despite this, spot silver and other precious metals declined, while platinum rose 0.31% and palladium gained 0.13%. The US and Iran/Islam have warned against escalating conflict in the Middle East.

site_title: Japan morphs into the centre of worry for global investors
summary: Japan's markets experienced significant volatility, with the Nikkei 225 suffering its biggest rout since 1987, only to rebound 10% the next day, after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) hiked rates and governor Kazuo Ueda indicated a shift towards higher interest rates. The move triggered a sharp rise in the yen, causing widespread market turmoil and uncertainty, affecting consumer confidence and Japan's climb out of deflation. Analysts warn of potential global ramifications if the yen's rebound continues, while politicians and business leaders seek to soothe concerns, highlighting the need for a new approach to fundamental analysis in the market.

site_title: Evergrande liquidators start legal action against PwC
summary: Evergrande Group's liquidators have launched court proceedings against PwC, the global auditor's mainland China arm, in a bid to recover at least a fraction of creditors' investments. The lawsuit alleges negligence and misrepresentation in auditing work, specifically for Evergrande's financial statements in 2017 and 2018. This move follows a 4.2 billion yuan fine imposed by Chinese authorities on Evergrande's main unit, Hengda, for overstating revenue by 564 billion yuan between 2020. The liquidators are also pursuing claims against CBRE Group and Avista Valuation Advisory over valuation reports for Evergrande and its subsidiaries.

site_title: Hamas names Sinwar new chief as region braces for Iran retaliation against Israel
summary: Hamas has named Yahya Sinwar as its new political leader following the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran. The move has heightened tensions in the region as Iran vows to retaliate against Israel, while Hezbollah has pledged to retaliate for Haniyeh's killing and the death of its military commander Fuad Shukr. Sinwar, who has been Hamas's leader in Gaza since 2017, has been more reluctant than Haniyeh to agree to a ceasefire deal. The United States is working around the clock to avert an all-out war, with extra warships and fighter jets deployed to the region in support of Israel.

summary: Japan's two key stock gauges rose on Wednesday after the yen fell by over 2% against the dollar, following a statement from the Bank of Japan's deputy governor that it won't raise interest rates if markets are unstable. site_title: Telling the Singapore story through treats, tours and textiles
summary: Singaporean SMEs are reinterpreting the country's heritage through modern forms, such as treats, tours, and textiles. Haig Road Putu Piring, a century-old family business, has expanded from a humble food stall to seven outlets across Singapore, with plans to open an outlet in the west. The company is focusing on catering and increasing revenue from live putu piring stations at events. Meanwhile, Everyday Tour Company has pivoted to virtual tours after the pandemic, which now accounts for 70% of sales. YeoMama Batik is creating modern batik prints that tell the Singapore story, including designs inspired by tropical fruits and Peranakan tiles, and hopes to expand to Kuala Lumpur next.

The National Transportation Safety Board has criticized Boeing's safety culture, citing a lack of improvements and inadequate oversight. The company has placed two employees on paid administrative leave and is working on retrofitting the design change across its fleet. Changes include adding a bright blue and yellow sign to the door plug and ensuring it is firmly secured.

site_title: Chevron dumps California for Texas after 145 years
summary: Chevron, a California-based oil company, is relocating its headquarters to Texas after 145 years, citing strict environmental policies and costly regulations. The move comes as Chevron has slashed new investments in California refining and posted disappointing second-quarter results. CEO Mike Wirth stated that the relocation is not driven by politics, but rather about being closer to the industry's epicenter and taking advantage of Texas's business-friendly environment. Chevron joins a list of California emigres, including tech giants Oracle and Tesla.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to buy 30 Airbus A330-900 aircraft
summary: Cathay Pacific has agreed to buy 30 Airbus A330-900 wide-body aircraft, with options to purchase another 30. The planes are expected to be delivered by the end of 2031 and will primarily fly regionally within Asia, with potential use on longer-haul routes in the future. The purchase price was not disclosed, but Cathay received significant concessions, with the basic price of 30 A330s estimated at US$11 billion. The Airbus A330-900 jets offer a capacity of up to 460 people and reduced fuel consumption and carbon emissions by 25% compared to previous models.

site_title: ARA H-Trust H1 DPS falls 50.2% to US$0.00747

The decline was attributed to higher financing costs due to maturing interest rates and rising borrowing costs. Revenue fell 2.4% to US$83.9 million, and gross operating profit decreased 3.3% to US$29.6 million. The trust's manager expects average leverage to fall to 42.9% after repaying debt and improving gearing ratio, despite a challenging hospitality market due to rising interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Microsoft hits back at Delta in clash over system breakdown
summary: Microsoft has responded to Delta Air Lines' claims of a catastrophic system outage, saying the airline turned down repeated offers for assistance and never responded to CEO Satya Nadella's personal email. Delta had invested billions in IT since 2016 but allegedly hasn't modernized its infrastructure. The US Department of Transportation is investigating Delta's handling of the outage, which is expected to cost $500 million this quarter. Microsoft claims Delta's internal system, used to process flight changes, was affected by an errant software update from CrowdStrike, leading to a cascading effect.

site_title: New Zealand’s jobless rate rises to 4.6% in second quarter
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate rose to 4.6% in the second quarter, exceeding economists' forecast of 4.7%. Employment increased 0.4% compared to the prior quarter, easing labor market pressure. Quarterly wage inflation accelerated slightly, with the private sector labor cost index rising 0.9% on the quarter. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand may consider a rate cut due to the easing of labor market conditions, which could help slow inflation.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has softened its stance in its July rate review, acknowledging signs of declining activity and opening the door for policy to ease sooner than previously signalled.
