site_title: Waymo to expand autonomous ride-hailing service areas in Los Angeles, San Francisco
summary: Waymo, a subsidiary of Alphabet, is expanding its autonomous ride-hailing service areas in San Francisco and Los Angeles. The service will now be available in San Francisco's Peninsula, including Daly City, Broadmoor, and Colma, and in Los Angeles, including Marina del Rey, Mar Vista, Playa Vista, Hollywood, Chinatown, and Westwood. This expansion comes as Waymo aims to boost its self-driving unit's growth plans, with a planned $5 billion investment over several years. The move follows the recent opening of its Waymo One service to everyone in San Francisco, ending waiting lists.

images.alt_text: A Waymo autonomous vehicle on Toland Street in San Francisco, Nov 17, 2023.

site_title: Reddit forecasts quarterly revenue above estimates on strong ad spend
summary: Reddit forecasts third-quarter revenue between $290 million and $310 million, surpassing analysts' average estimate of $278.7 million. The company's daily active unique visitors increased 51% to 91.2 million in the second quarter, while its global average revenue per user (ARPU) rose about 2% to $3.08. Despite a conservative quarterly forecast, the results fueled optimism that content licensing deals with Google and OpenAI are paying off, and the company plans to test AI-powered search results later this year.

images.alt_text: GameStop shares were down 11.6 per cent at US$25.38 on Monday afternoon after the annual general shareholder meeting, which lasted about 20 minutes.

GameStop, widely regarded as the first meme stock, is a video game retailer struggling to adapt in an era dominate by online commerce and digital downloads. Its sales are expected to drop by dougle digits.
FILE PHOTO: GameStop logo is seen in front of displayed Reddit logo in this illustration taken February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
People on Reddit can currently make money from subscriptions, digital gifts and collectibles such as avatars.

site_title: Super Micro’s weak profit fuels AI server margin anxieties
summary: Super Micro Computer reported a quarterly profit of $6.25 per share, missing analyst estimates, and sales of $5.31 billion, below projections. Despite a surge in demand for AI servers, investors are concerned about the company's long-term profitability due to its reliance on a growing market. CEO Charles Liang stated that Super Micro is well-positioned to become the largest IT infrastructure company, forecasting $26-30 billion in revenue for 2025. The stock initially jumped 18% before reversing and declining 8% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Dell is assembling half of the racks for xAI’s supercomputer.

site_title: Kamala Harris taps a progressive as a running mate
summary: Vice-President Kamala Harris has chosen Governor Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, a progressive Midwestern politician, in a move to highlight the ideological differences between Democrats and Republicans. Harris initially considered centrist Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, but faced opposition from Muslim voters and progressive Democrats. Walz's left-leaning policies and strong personal chemistry with Harris led to his selection, which could appeal to swing voters in battleground states like Pennsylvania and the Midwest.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Kamala Harris and Democratic vice-presidential candidate Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz during a campaign event at Girard College in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Aug 6, 2024.
This combination of pictures shows US Vice-President Kamala Harris and Governor of Minnesota Tim Walz in Washington, DC.

(COMBO) This combination of pictures created on August 2, 2024, shows US Vice President Kamala Harris in Washington, DC on July 22, 2024, and Governor of Minnesota Tim Walz in Washington, DC, July 3, 2024. Harris named Walz as her running mate on August 6, 2024, US media reported, as the vice president prepares to take on Republican Donald Trump in November's US election. (Photo by Jim WATSON and Chris Kleponis / AFP)

site_title: Disney raises streaming prices up to 25%, adds new channels
summary: Disney is raising prices for its streaming services, with Disney+ with ads increasing by 25% to $9.99/month, and Disney+ without ads rising 14% to $15.99/month. The company is also adding new channels, including ABC News Live and preschool programming, starting September 4. The price hikes follow similar increases by rival streaming services, as Disney transitions to streaming from broadcast and cable TV due to declining audiences and ad sales. The company aims to make its streaming business profitable by its fourth fiscal quarter.

images.alt_text: Walt Disney is eliminating about 140 jobs, or about 2 per cent of staff at Disney Entertainment Television.
The NBA adds to Prime Video’s growing roster of live sports offerings, which include NFL and Nascar in 2025.

Disney’s experiences business, which includes its domestic and international parks and cruise line, accounted for more than one-third of the company’s revenue in the March quarter, and nearly 60 per cent of its operating income.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 edges up in global recovery, earnings relief
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 rose 0.3% on Tuesday, marking its steepest three-day decline since June 2022, as global markets recovered from the previous day's slump. Energy and technology stocks led the way, driven by upbeat corporate earnings. The Euro Stoxx volatility index cooled down, reflecting improved investor sentiment, while the US market also climbed in volatile trading. Despite a stronger-than-expected rise in German industrial orders, traders refrained from making big bets, awaiting fresh catalysts.

images.alt_text: he Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  0.8 per cent higher at 38,997.66 on Tuesday.

site_title: Elite UK Reit posts 19.5% lower H1 DPU of £0.014
summary: Elite UK Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported a 19.5% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to £0.014 for the first half of the year, down from £0.0174 in the same period last year. The trust's distributable income fell 1.7% to £9.2 million, while portfolio occupancy remained stable at 92.3%. Revenue declined 0.6% to £18.6 million. The decline was attributed to a lower asset base compared to the previous year.

images.alt_text: Newport Road, Cardiff, Wales. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead, and a building in Newport Road (pictured).

site_title: South Korea’s Coupang posts first loss since 2022 as Farfetch deal saps profit
summary: Coupang, South Korea's largest online retailer, posted its first loss in two years due to a net loss of $77 million in the June quarter. The company's acquisition of unprofitable Farfetch Holdings and a government regulatory fine offset strong growth in its core e-commerce business, which saw a 25% increase in net revenue to $7.3 billion. Despite this, shares fell over 5% in late US trading, overshadowing the company's resilient top-line growth.

site_title: Banks poised to seize more buildings in Hong Kong, PwC says
summary: Banks in Hong Kong are expected to take more enforcement actions on distressed buildings as the city's property market downturn worsens. A portfolio of real estate under receivership valued at over HK$10 billion is being managed by PwC, with assets including the Cheung Kei Center. Luxury residential units are hitting the market as local families struggle with debt, while high interest rates and low rental yields deter investors. The city's office vacancy rate has reached a historic high of 16.9%, and rental prices are expected to fall 10% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians along the promenade in the Tsim Sha Tsui district of Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Once known for their luxury tenants and world-topping rents, neighborhoods like Canton Road and Russell Street are plagued by empty shop fronts. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: People cross a street in a shopping area of the Central business district in Hong Kong, China August 22, 2019. Picture taken August 22, 2019.  REUTERS/Thomas Peter
Hong Kong’s monetary policy typically moves in lock-step with the United States, with the city’s currency pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75 to 7.85 per US dollar.
Tourism in the city cratered after the pandemic and remains down 40 per cent from 2019, according to Hong Kong Tourism Board data.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies claw back losses as Ether ETF investors buy dip
summary: Bitcoin and Ether regained ground on Tuesday, August 6, after a sharp decline on Monday, with Bitcoin rising to around $56,000 and Ether increasing by 4.9% to over $2,500. The moves were partly attributed to investors buying into the dip, with Ether ETF investors posting a $49 million net inflow. However, the gains may be short-lived without a broader improvement in the macro-economic environment and easing of tensions in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: ETFs that invest directly in Bitcoin have had four straight days of outflows, totalling roughly US$423 million.

site_title: Nobel winner Yunus says ready to head Bangladesh 'interim government'
summary: Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus has announced his readiness to lead an interim government in Bangladesh, following mass demonstrations that forced long-time ruler Sheikh Hasina to flee the country. Yunus, known as the "banker to the poorest of the poor," expressed his willingness to take action if necessary to restore democracy and call for free elections. His statement comes as the country faces a power vacuum and uncertainty following Hasina's departure.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People gesture near smoke as protesters clash with Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) and the police outside the state-owned Bangladesh Television as violence erupts across the country after anti-quota protests by students, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, July 19, 2024. REUTERS/Mohammad Ponir Hossain/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices settle higher; signs of tighter supply end 3-day swoon
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, settling higher after a three-day decline, due to concerns about supply tightness and protests in Libya. Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $76.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures gained 0.4% to $73.20 a barrel. The Middle East tensions, including Iran's vow of retaliation against Israel and the US, and Libya's declining production, are contributing to the price increase. Oil fundamentals suggest an undersupplied market, with inventories falling, and economists expect higher prices in coming months.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 51 cents, or 0.66 per cent, lower at US$76.30 a barrel on Monday, with prices earlier trading around their lowest levels since January.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after global sell-off
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, August 6, 2024, after a global sell-off, driven by dovish rate commentary from Federal Reserve officials. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.16 points, the S&P 500 opened 17.73 points higher, and the Nasdaq Composite was up 63.7 points. This uptick comes after a global stocks rout in the previous session.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign for Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Instacart posts sales beat, issues strong earnings outlook
summary: Instacart reported a sales beat in the second quarter, with revenue reaching US$823 million and order value totaling US$8.2 billion. The company's strong earnings outlook, including expected adjusted earnings of US$205-215 million, exceeded analyst estimates. This comes after recent earnings beats by other delivery companies, affirming resilient US consumer spending and emerging as a bright spot in the tech sector. Instacart's shares gained 6% in after-market trading.

images.alt_text: In addition to the cuts, three company executives are leaving the company, each for personal reasons, the spokesperson says.
The grocery delivery firm, whose stock has lost more than a third of its value since its debut, also announced a US$500 million share repurchase programme.
At least half of Instacart’s 20 IPO underwriters have initiated coverage with their top ratings after the quiet period ended.

site_title: Sats is prudent to hold off food hub construction
summary: SATS has decided not to proceed with the development of a food hub in Jurong Innovation District, citing disruptions in the global supply chain and escalating inflationary pressures that have driven up construction and labour costs. The five-storey building, originally slated for completion in 2024, will instead remain as existing institutional catering businesses at several JTC-leased premises in Pandan Loop. The decision comes two years after a high-profile ground-breaking ceremony in April 2022.

images.alt_text: SATS Food Solutions India, a wholly owned subsidiary of Singaporean company SATS Ltd. , has opened its largest international food solutions facility outside Singapore in Bengaluru, India. Photo courtesy: SATS
DBS' higher target price on Sats is the result of the research house rolling forward its valuation peg to FY2025.

Sats' partnership with Mitsui will help to grow its food solutions business. Left to right: Kerry Mok, Sats president and chief executive; and Naoharu Asaumi, Mitsui & Co. chief operating officer of retail business

site_title: The creator economy’s bright future in Asia
summary: The creator economy in Asia is poised for significant growth, driven by the increasing consumption of digital content and the expansion of monetisation opportunities. Asia, led by countries such as China, India, Indonesia, and South Korea, is home to millions of active creators producing content for a diverse and highly engaged audience. The region's vast digital content consumption, technology advancements, and affordable internet access have lowered barriers to entry for content creation. The creator economy is valued at $250 billion and projected to reach $480 billion by 2027.

images.alt_text: Affiliates can post videos promoting products sold in TikTok Shop and collect commissions on the sales they generate.

Left: Ng Jing Shen, chief technology officer of 17Live. The live-streaming platform listed on the Singapore Exchange after completing a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Company.

site_title: Chinese-born academic convicted in US of acting as covert Chinese agent
summary: A Chinese-born academic, Wang Shujun, was convicted in Brooklyn federal court of acting as a covert Chinese agent. He was found guilty of four counts of acting and conspiring to act as an agent of a foreign government. Wang, 75, co-founded a pro-democracy group while secretly collecting and reporting sensitive information to China's intelligence service since 2006. He faces up to 25 years in prison and will be sentenced in January.

images.alt_text: The aircraft with the exchanged prisoners arrives at the military section of Cologne Bonn Airport in Cologne, Germany, Aug 1, 2024.

A Chinese official (right) tries to block cameras from filming Chinese-born Australian journalist Cheng Lei (seated in second row), who is attending a signing ceremony by Premier Li Qiang and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the Australian Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, June 17, 2024.

site_title: Hope, optimism abound as energised Harris crowd relishes VP pick Walz
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris has chosen moderate Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as her running mate, boosting her presidential bid with renewed energy and optimism among supporters. The pick is seen as a unifying force, particularly among moderate Democrats, with Walz's word "weird" resonating with voters. Harris's campaign has raised $310 million in July, topping Donald Trump, and her supporters believe the choice of Walz will help her defeat Trump in the upcoming election. The pick has brought a sense of hope and optimism to the campaign, with supporters describing it as a "dream" and a "nightmare" for Trump.

images.alt_text: Should Donald Trump win a second term aas US president, investors should expect a strong attempt to renew his flagship 2017 tax cuts and further reduction in corporate taxes.

Harris, the US vice-president, is expected to announce her selection by Tuesday, ahead of her first scheduled public appearance with her running mate in the evening at Temple University in Philadelphia.

site_title: US fears of recession are exaggerated
summary: US economists and markets are overreacting to the July unemployment report, with some predicting a recession. The unemployment rate rose to 4.3% from 4.1% in June, but key indicators, such as services and labor market conditions, remain strong. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates in September, and markets are already discounting future rate cuts. While some recession concerns are valid, the soft landing story remains the base case, and the Fed's decision should not be overanalyzed.

images.alt_text: The US unemployment rate has been gradually trending up over the past few months.

site_title: Citigroup’s trading division hit with fresh toxic-culture claim
summary: Citigroup's trading division has faced another toxic-culture claim, with a former broker alleging years of unwanted sexual attention and threats from a trader. Christine O'Reilly, a 31-year-old broker, sued Citigroup and ICAP, alleging she was subjected to a pattern of harassment by trader Benjamin Waters, who had the power to direct big transactions to her team. The lawsuit claims O'Reilly was pressured to tolerate the behavior and even apologized to Waters to keep business flowing, despite reporting it to a supervisor.

images.alt_text: An Ola electric scooter being charged at an electric vehicle charging station in New Delhi, India, Feb 12, 2022. India has made significant investments in clean energy, adding more than 100 gigawatts of capacity in the last 10 years.

site_title: Fox reports rise in quarterly revenue, beats profit estimates
summary: Fox Corp reported a 2% rise in revenue to $1.44 billion in the fourth quarter, beating profit estimates. The company's cable-network programming business saw a 2% increase, while its Tubi streaming service gained momentum in viewership. Advertising revenue remained flat year over year at $1.01 billion. On an adjusted basis, the company earned 90 cents per share, surpassing estimates of 81 cents.

images.alt_text: Venu Sports will be available directly through a new app and subscribers can opt to bundle the service with Disney+, Hulu or Max.

As part of its efforts to grow business, Fox agreed to form a sports-streaming joint venture with Walt Disney and Warner Bros Discovery and the venture is expected to have 5 million subscribers in the first five years, says Fox Corp CEO Lachlan Murdoch (top).

site_title: US: Stocks rebound after three days of losses
summary: US stocks rebounded 0.8% on Tuesday, ending a three-day losing streak, driven by bargain hunting and a bounce in US bond markets. Caterpillar and Uber reported solid earnings, lifting shares of both companies. Analysts see potential stability, but caution about "downside risks to the market." Despite the rebound, the Dow Jones Industrial Average remains below record levels, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also nearing fresh highs.

images.alt_text: A sign for Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan in New York City.

site_title: China’s Dongfeng in pole position to build an auto plant in Italy: sources
summary: Italy is in advanced talks with China's Dongfeng Motor Group to build an auto plant, with the potential for the Italian government to join with a minority stake in the investment. The plant aims to create a hub for Europe and could involve other key investors. Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government seeks to increase domestic auto production to 1.3 million vehicles annually. This comes after discussions with Stellantis, Italy's sole major automaker, to boost production to 1 million units by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: A hostess poses next to Dongfeng Motor Corp A9 sedan at the Auto China 2016 auto show in Beijing, China, April 26, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/Files

In the first nine months, China shipped 2.26 million vehicles, up 51.6 per cent from a year earlier and surpassing the 2021 total, according to the General Admission of Customs.
Stellantis rejigs China financing ops in latest reboot plans

site_title: Scoot to launch flights to Kertajati in Indonesia and Melaka in Malaysia on new Embraer jets
summary: Budget airline Scoot will launch flights to Kertajati in Indonesia and Melaka in Malaysia on new Embraer regional jets starting September 28 and October 23, respectively. Scoot will operate the Embraer E190-E2 planes twice a week to Kertajati and five times a week to Melaka. The new services will be available for booking from August 6 and will increase frequencies on existing routes, with plans to expand to 72 destinations worldwide by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The global airline industry continues to face challenges from increased competition, supply chain constraints, inflationary pressures on operating costs, SIA said.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1% at the opening of trading on Wednesday, mirroring global market gains. The Straits Times Index (STI) opened 31.29 points higher at 3,229.73. Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 30. The actively traded counter, Genting Singapore, lost 0.6% after 5.5 million shares changed hands.

site_title: US household debt levels edge up in Q2, NY Fed survey shows
summary: US household debt levels rose by 0.6% in Q2, increasing by $109 billion to $17.80 trillion, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's survey. This represents a stable overall delinquency rate, indicating that borrowers remain in decent financial shape to support the economy. The slight increase in debt levels suggests that households are continuing to manage their debt responsibly, despite ongoing economic uncertainty.

The labour market is slowing as the Federal Reserve’s hefty interest rate hikes in 2022 and 2023 curb demand.

site_title: F&N net profit up 37.3% to S$123 million for first nine months of FY2024
summary: F&N, a beverage maker, reported a 37.3% increase in net profit to S$123 million for the first nine months of FY2024, driven by effective marketing campaigns and increased revenue growth in its F&B segment. Revenue rose 2.1% to S$1.61 billion, with core soft drinks brands like F&N and 100Plus seeing higher volumes. The company's profit before interest and taxes jumped 35.4% to S$238.7 million.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows to US$73.1 billion as exports pick up
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $73.1 billion in June, a 2.5% decrease from the prior month, as exports of goods and services increased by 1.5% and imports rose 0.6%. This marks the first time the deficit has narrowed in three months. On an inflation-adjusted basis, the merchandise trade deficit narrowed to $91.4 billion, the smallest in three months. The increase in merchandise exports was broad, with gains in commercial aircraft, natural gas, and motor vehicles.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq stock exchange in New York on Aug 5. There was a massive global stock-market sell-off in reaction to the US unemployment report.

site_title: Riverstone H1 net profit up 54.6% as demand for gloves recovers
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, reported a 54.6% increase in net profit to RM144.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2024, driven by a recovery in demand for healthcare and cleanroom gloves. The company attributed the growth to the global semiconductor manufacturing sector's recovery. New production lines are expected to be commissioned by the end of this year, and the company is continuing research and development to optimize product specifications. Riverstone declared an interim dividend of RM0.04 per share.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian glovemaker posts a net profit of RM50.7 million (S$14.5 million) for the three months ended May 31, versus a loss of RM130.6 million in the previous corresponding period.

An employee handles latex gloves at an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020. The world’s biggest glovemaker got a vote of confidence from investors in the credit market, as the coronavirus fuels demand for the Malaysian company’s rubber products. The World Health Organization is taking an unprecedented step of negotiating directly with suppliers to improve access to gloves, face masks and other forms of protective equipment. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
The glove maker’s dipping lines were designed to cater to more flexible manufacturing, allowing it to manufacture customised gloves.

Riverstone chief executive and executive chairman Wong Teek Son expects the consumer electronics sector to recover in the first half of next year.

site_title: Population growth isn’t a progressive issue; it should be
summary: Population growth isn't a progressive issue, and conservatives are right to sound the alarm. As populations decline, there won't be enough young people to care for seniors and economically support them. Progressives should develop their own version of pronatalism, focusing on government benefits like paid parental leave and subsidized child care, while defending abortion rights and rejecting regressive ideas. Immigration is a temporary solution, and eventually, newcomers assimilate and have fewer children. To address declining fertility rates, governments should provide financial relief for families, like restoring and expanding the child tax credit.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Newborn babies inside a ward at the Tambak Maternity Hospital in Jakarta, on September 19, 2022. Babies born by cesarean section don't acquire the same healthy bacteria as those delivered vaginally, a setback to the development of their immune system thought to increase their risk of certain diseases later in life. But a new study, published on June 15, 2023, in the journal Cell Host & Microbe, finds that applying the mother's vaginal fluids on C-section babies after birth successfully restores this microbial balance, and has neurodevelopment benefits, too. (Photo by Adek BERRY / AFP)
Despite the decline in births, Australia’s population growth has actually surged in recent years, underpinned by immigration.
With more couples choosing to delay or opt entirely out of parenthood, many countries around the world, including Singapore, are facing a population crisis.

site_title: Boeing details production issues at 737 MAX 9 mid-air emergency hearing
summary: The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is questioning key witnesses from Boeing, Spirit AeroSystems, and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) about a mid-air cabin panel blowout of an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 door plug in January. The incident damaged Boeing's reputation and led to production issues, a criminal investigation, and the departure of executives. Boeing's senior vice-president for quality, Elizabeth Lund, and vice-president of supplier quality, Doug Ackerman, testified, stating that Boeing is still building fewer MAXs than allowed and is working to improve quality. The hearing is reviewing issues including 737 manufacturing, safety management, and quality management systems.

images.alt_text: Members of the news media view the Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 door plug at the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) materials lab in Washington, US, July 30, 2024.
Kelly Ortberg is returning from retirement to head the 108-year-old US planemaker, which is bleeding cash and beset by companywide problems expected to take years to fix.
The resumption is a boost to Boeing, which had flagged Chinese delivery delays to investors, and which is engulfed in a separate safety and quality crisis.

The Federal Aviation Administration in January took the unprecedented step of barring Boeing from increasing production beyond 38 MAX planes per month until it is satisfied with the planemaker’s quality and manufacturing improvements.
Boeing projects the global aircraft fleet to almost double over the next 20 years.

Delays are the norm in aerospace as planemakers and engine manufacturers grapple with disrupted shipments of parts and raw materials, worker turnover and other market turmoil still lingering from the Covid pandemic.
FILE PHOTO: A Boeing logo is seen on a 777-9 aircraft on display during the 54th International Paris Airshow at Le Bourget Airport near Paris, France, June 18, 2023. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

The DOJ says Boeing breached a previous agreement and failed to “design, implement, and enforce a compliance and ethics program to prevent and detect violations of the US fraud laws throughout its operations”.
An Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX was forced to make an emergency landing after a panel blew out midair in January. Alaska Airlines said on Friday it has returned the plane to Boeing.
The claims are the latest in a series of allegations flagging concerns about the manufacturing practices of Boeing or its suppliers.

site_title: Bangladesh ex-PM and opposition leader Zia freed: party
summary: Bangladesh ex-Prime Minister Khaleda Zia has been released from house arrest after her bitter enemy Sheikh Hasina was ousted as premier. The release comes after the military took control, with orders given to free Zia a day earlier. The Bangladesh National Party spokesman confirmed Zia's release, stating she is now "freed."

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, August 6, 2024 (Ep 117)
summary: Asian stocks rebounded on Tuesday, but the Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) was dragged down by local banks. US office S-Reits rose on expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut and a proposal to relax leverage limits by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered decliners 94 to 56 at the opening bell.
Tokyo’s Nikkei, which tanked more than 12 per cent on Monday and suffered a record points loss, jumped 10.2 per cent.
Manulife US Reit gained as much as 7.1 per cent in early morning trade on Tuesday.

site_title: China to beef up regulations on fentanyl chemicals, White House says
summary: China plans to add controls and regulations to the production of three fentanyl chemicals, a move seen as a step forward by the US. The decision follows bilateral counter-narcotics cooperation resumed in November 2023 and comes after a US congressional committee found China was subsidizing fentanyl production and fueling the US opioid crisis. The move is part of an effort to address the growing issue of fentanyl-related overdoses in the US, which have become the leading cause of death for Americans aged 18-45.

site_title: Toronto home prices climb for second month even as sales slow
summary: Toronto home prices rose 0.1% in July to C$1.09 million, marking the second consecutive month of growth despite a 1.7% decline in sales. New listings also dropped 0.8%, as buyers pulled back amid concerns over borrowing costs. The Toronto Regional Real Estate Board attributes annual sales growth to improved supply, with transactions up 3.3% and new listings surging 18.5%. TRREB chief market analyst Jason Mercer expects buyers to benefit from increased inventory as mortgage payments become more affordable.

site_title: CSE Global H1 earnings up 36.4%, boosted by growth of electrification business
summary: CSE Global reported a 36.4% increase in first-half earnings to S$15 million, driven by a 22.8% rise in revenue to S$428.9 million, led by growth in its electrification business segment, which rose 32.4% to S$216.7 million. The company's order book increased by 32.7% to S$692.3 million, positioning it for a healthy financial performance in 2024. CEO Lim Boon Kheng plans to expand the company's engineering capabilities and technology solutions, focusing on electrification and communications.

site_title: US dollar rebounds broadly, yen weakens for first day this month
summary: The US dollar rebounded broadly, with a 0.6% gain against the Japanese yen, marking the first day of trading higher this month. The yen, which had gained 9 yen in the past week, steadied after recent volatility caused investors to unwind carry trades. The dollar also strengthened against the euro and pound, while the Swiss franc weakened. The move was attributed to a reassessment of market sentiment, with analysts suggesting that markets had gotten ahead of themselves and that the dollar's gains were a correction.

site_title: Kamala Harris picks Minnesota governor Tim Walz as running mate
summary: US Vice Presidential candidate Kamala Harris has picked Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as her running mate, aiming to balance her ticket with a white man from a battleground state. Walz, 60, has a folksy manner and championed popular Democratic policies, appealing to progressives. The duo will launch a five-day swing through battleground states, starting in Pennsylvania, after Harris secured the Democratic nomination. Harris' pick was seen as a strategic move to broaden her appeal and counter Republican attacks, and her team has been branding Trump and his vice-presidential pick J.D. Vance as "weird".

images.alt_text: US Vice-President Kamala Harris has been closing the gap with Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump in the national polls as well as the races in battleground states.
Should Donald Trump win a second term aas US president, investors should expect a strong attempt to renew his flagship 2017 tax cuts and further reduction in corporate taxes.

site_title: Hot ringgit trade gets another boost from foreign bond flows
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has received a boost from foreign bond flows, with RM5.5 billion (S$1.6 billion) poured into local bonds in July, the largest monthly inflow in a year. This surge has pushed total returns on ringgit notes to 5.9% this year, among the highest in emerging markets. Analysts attribute the increase to expectations of ringgit strength, creating a positive feedback loop and supporting the country's improving economic outlook.

After three years of losses, the ringgit is outperforming its Asian peers in 2024 as the government drove policies to boost foreign investments and began rolling back subsidies to narrow the budget deficit.

site_title: Olympics: China’s anti-doping agency accuses US  counterpart of double standards
summary: China's anti-doping agency (CHINADA) accused the US Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) of double standards, citing the case of 23 Chinese swimmers who tested positive before the 2021 Tokyo Olympics but were allowed to compete. In contrast, US sprinter Erriyon Knighton was not suspended despite testing positive for the banned substance trenbolone due to an arbitrator's ruling that the result was likely caused by contaminated meat. CHINADA's head, Cui Yanyan, made the accusation on Tuesday, August 6, in response to USADA head Travis Tygart's comments on the matter.

site_title: Venture Corp H1 profit down 11.7% to S$123.7 million on lower revenue, demand
summary: Venture Corporation reported a net profit of S$123.7 million for the first half of 2024, down 11.7% from S$140 million in the same period last year, due to softer demand and lower revenue of 12.5% to S$1.4 billion. The company proposed an interim dividend of S$0.25 per share, unchanged from last year. Despite lower expenses and foreign currency exchange gains, Venture remains proactive in pursuing initiatives to improve performance in the second half of 2024.

site_title: US to give SK hynix US$450 million for chip packaging hub
summary: The US Commerce Department has agreed to provide up to $450 million in direct funding and $500 million in loans to South Korean semiconductor firm SK hynix to build a chip packaging plant in Indiana. The plant, which will manufacture next-generation high-bandwidth memory chips, aims to fill a critical gap in the US supply chain. The facility is expected to create around 1,000 jobs and support the development of artificial intelligence, with SK hynix CEO Kwak Noh-Jung calling it a "new hub for AI technology" and a key supplier for Nvidia, which controls 80% of the global AI chip market.

site_title: Dyna-Mac H1 profit surges 283.9% to S$38.8 million on higher productivity, revenue and projects completion
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings' net profit more than doubled to S$38.8 million in the first half of 2024, driven by the completion of major projects, improved productivity, and increased project volume. Revenue grew 42.5% to S$259.7 million, attributed to the completion of major projects. The company is optimistic about future growth opportunities in its floating production storage and offloading vessels operations.

site_title: Uber’s second-quarter revenue beats on ride-sharing demand
summary: Uber reported a 16% increase in revenue to $10.70 billion in the second quarter, beating estimates, driven by steady demand for ride-sharing and food-delivery services. The company's core earnings of $1.60 billion also beat estimates. Ride-sharing revenue rose 25% to $6.13 billion, while delivery revenue grew 1% to $3.29 billion. Uber forecasts third-quarter gross bookings between $40.25 billion and $41.75 billion, below analyst estimates.

site_title: ByteDance joins OpenAI’s Sora rivals with AI video app launch
summary: ByteDance, the owner of Faceu Technology, has launched Jimeng AI, a software that generates videos based on text prompts, on the Apple App Store for Chinese users. This move expands the company's offerings in the emerging market, where Chinese tech firms are developing similar tools, including OpenAI's Sora, a text-to-video model not yet open to the public. Jimeng AI follows its release on Android on July 31, as Chinese companies rapidly develop similar technologies.

site_title: Bayer sales surprise on demand for new cancer, kidney drugs
summary: Bayer's second-quarter revenue exceeded analysts' estimates at 11.1 billion euros, driven by strong demand for new cancer and kidney medicines, including Nubeqa and Kerendia. The company's pharma division saw a significant improvement, with revenue expected to stay flat or grow slightly in 2024, a revision from previous guidance. This positive performance was partly offset by weaker sales in its crop science business and consumer health unit. Despite challenges ahead, including litigation related to the Roundup herbicide, Bayer's shares remained unchanged.

site_title: Harris has the momentum; Trump’s rattled
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris is closing the gap with Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump in national polls and battleground states, gaining momentum ahead of the Democratic National Convention. Trump's decision to choose JD Vance as his running mate, despite Vance's lack of experience, has damaged his campaign. Harris, an African-American/South-Asian candidate, is exceling among traditionally Democratic voters, including African-Americans, Hispanics, and young people. Her immigration background and multicultural appeal are key factors in her rising popularity.

site_title: What a Trump win means for economies and emerging markets debt
summary: A potential second term for US President Donald Trump is expected to lead to renewed tax cuts, deregulation, and incentives for domestic oil exploration, which could negatively impact emerging markets (EM) debt. Investors should anticipate higher tariffs on imports, potentially leading to temporary inflation and dampened economic growth. However, lower taxes could boost economic activity. EM countries may be less directly affected due to increased intra-EM trade, but could still face fiscal and monetary policy reactions to US-imposed tariffs. The author expects marginally weaker global growth and higher inflation, with an acceleration of global monetary policy normalization and lower global interest rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 6)
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that it will prioritize policyholders' interests when assessing Allianz's proposed acquisition of a majority stake in Income Insurance. The deal has faced public scrutiny, raising concerns about its impact on Income's social mission. Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat made this statement in Parliament on August 6, addressing worries about the deal's potential erosion of Income's social mission.

site_title: Pockets of opportunity in private-market assets
summary: Private-market assets, such as private equity, credit, and real estate, are gaining traction as investors seek diversification and higher returns. The healthcare sector and technology are emerging as key areas of opportunity, driven by demographic shifts and digitalization. Private credit is expected to remain attractive, with yields in the high single to low double-digit range. Infrastructure investments with "inflation hedging" characteristics are also gaining attention. Experts recommend endowment-style portfolios with a higher allocation to alternatives, combining active strategies and different types of private markets to achieve the highest risk-adjusted return and diversification.

images.alt_text: Access to private markets via exchange-traded funds has the potential to open the closed-off world to investors of all stripes. It could also channel fresh cash into an asset class struggling to keep the boom alive after years of breakneck expansion.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng posts lower net profit of S$3.2 million for H1
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a food and beverage group, reported a lower net profit of S$3.2 million for the half year ended June 30, 2024, down 3.8% from S$3.3 million in the previous year. Revenue decreased 8.7% to S$165.3 million, mainly due to foreign exchange rate movements and lower sales volume. The company attributed the decline to cautious consumer sentiments in its key markets due to economic uncertainties, but noted that its core F&B business remained relatively unchanged.

However, same-store sales for the US KFC division fell 5%, following a 7% decline in the prior quarter, due to sticky inflation and lower-income Americans opting for home-cooked meals. Despite efforts to invest in loyalty programs and menu refreshes, stiff competition for value meals and promotions continues to impact KFC's US business.

summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.4% or 45.23 points to close at 3,198.44 points on August 6, 2024, amid calls for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to support the US economy. The decline was partly due to the STI's heavy weighting in banking counters, which were squeezed by rate cuts. Despite this, the equity market is expected to benefit from policy rate cuts.

summary: IReit Global's first-half DPU rose 3.2% to 0.96 euro cent, driven by a 28.8% year-over-year increase in revenue to 36.6 million euros. The group attributed the growth to the completion of its French retail property acquisition and improved revenue from its Germany portfolio. As of June 30, IReit Global's aggregate leverage stood at 37.2%, while its interest coverage ratio was about 7.4 times for the trailing 12 months period. site_title: Thai consumer confidence falls to 11-month low in July
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence fell to an 11-month low in July, dropping to 57.7 due to concerns over economic recovery, rising cost of living, and political uncertainty. The drop marks a fifth consecutive month of decline. A Constitutional Court verdict on Wednesday could further destabilize the government, potentially leading to a change in leadership and policies. If the government accelerates budget disbursement and stimulates the economy, consumer confidence may improve by the end of the year.

site_title: Evergrande aims to recover US$6 billion from founder Hui Ka Yan, former top execs
summary: Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, has initiated legal proceedings to recover approximately US$6 billion from seven defendants, including founder Hui Ka Yan and former executives. The liquidators have obtained injunctions against three defendants, restraining them from dealing with their worldwide assets. The company's shares remain suspended until further notice. The recoveries aim to cover dividends and remuneration paid to the defendants based on allegedly misstated financial statements from 2017 to 2020. The liquidation process began after Evergrande failed to offer a concrete restructuring plan for its US$23 billion offshore debt.

site_title: Pricking the equities bubble
summary: The US market bubble is nearing a potential pop, with stocks falling globally due to anxiety over the US economy. Warren Buffett has halved his stake in Apple, and investors are concerned about a wider war in the Middle East, civil unrest in the UK, and a potential US recession. However, a rational analysis of charts suggests that the market may be due for a rebound, with the S&P 500 potentially falling to around 5,060 before rising again. Chart analysis is seen as a reliable probability framework for making informed investment decisions, rather than a method for predicting the future with certainty.

site_title: China launches first satellites of constellation to rival Starlink, state media says
summary: China successfully launched its first satellites of the "Thousand Sails Constellation" plan, a state-backed project to rival SpaceX's Starlink network, on Tuesday. The 18 satellites were placed into low Earth orbit (LEO) using a Long March six rocket at Taiyuan Satellite Launch Centre in northern Shanxi province. This marks one of China's answers to Starlink, which has about 5,500 LEO satellites in space to provide global internet access. The launch is seen as a strategic move to counter US influence in space and secure China's interests.

site_title: Luxury condo sales pick up in Q2 as ultra-rich buyers help reverse 3 quarters of decline
summary: Luxury condo sales in Singapore increased in Q2 2024, with 57 non-landed private homes worth S$482.5 million changing hands. This marks a 7.5% rise from the previous quarter and a 9.5% increase from Q2 2023. The ultra-rich buyers, including foreign buyers, contributed to the sales. However, analysts warn that the recent recovery may not last due to the current soft property market and increased checks on the source of wealth of ultra-high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: UK construction sector kicks up a gear after election, PMI shows
summary: The UK construction sector experienced a significant surge in growth, with the S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 55.3 in July, its highest level since May 2022. This marked a reversal of the slowdown seen in June, following the Labour Party's election win. Activity in the sector grew at the fastest pace in over two years, driven by new orders and increased building work in civil engineering, residential, and commercial sectors. The improvement is seen as a positive sign for the UK economy, with the Bank of England cutting interest rates recently.

Buyers are hoping the central bank could start cutting interest rates from a 16-year high when policymakers meet in August as inflation returned to the 2 per cent target.

site_title: Australia central bank sees more gradual decline in core inflation, less spare capacity
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has revised its forecast for Australia's economy, predicting a 1.7% growth rate by the end of the year and 2.6% by June 2025. Core inflation is expected to slow more gradually than initially thought, falling to 2.6% by the end of 2026. The RBA also notes there is less spare capacity in the economy than previously assumed, implying it may take longer for inflation to return to target.

site_title: How the rise of Big Tech is shaping the future of US equity markets
summary: The US equity market has seen significant growth since the 21st century, driven by megatrends towards digitalisation and innovation. Eight of the top 10 largest publicly listed companies in the world are from the US, with six being Big Tech firms. The tech sector now accounts for 32% of the S&P 500 index, up from less than 10% prior to the dotcom bubble. The US' robust ecosystem for innovation, entrepreneurship, and strong intellectual property protection contribute to its dominance in the tech sector. As the world becomes increasingly digitalised, tech stocks are expected to continue driving market performance and shaping the future of global equity markets.

site_title: German factory orders rise first time this year on cars, metals
summary: Germany's factory orders rose 3.9% in June, the first increase this year, driven by the automotive industry and fabricated metal products. Domestic orders were particularly strong, surpassing economists' expectations of a 0.5% gain. The rise may offer some comfort to Germany's manufacturing sector, which has been struggling, but the economy still faces challenges, including a shrinking first quarter and sticky inflation.

site_title: Chill-seeking: Japan’s haunted house summer tradition
summary: Japan's haunted house summer tradition, "chill-seeking," is a long-established custom where people visit spooky attractions to experience a refreshing fright amidst the country's sweltering heat. The tradition dates back to the Japanese summer solstice, when ancestral souls return to their household altars during the mid-August "obon" holiday. Modern haunted houses use air-conditioning and special effects to create a chilling experience, with many establishments playing up the refreshing aspect of the activity. This year, Japan has experienced its hottest July on record, with temperatures 2.16 degrees Celsius higher than average, leading to a record number of heatstroke-related deaths.

images.alt_text: US' Noah Lyles celebrates after winning the men's 100m final of the athletics event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at Stade de France in Saint-Denis, north of Paris, on August 4, 2024. (Photo by Loic VENANCE / AFP)

site_title: Goodbye grocery greedflation and shrinkflation; hello deals
summary: Consumers in the US and Europe are voting with their wallets, trading down to cheaper off-brand and private labels, as food prices show signs of easing. Supermarkets, manufacturers, and fast-food chains are stepping up promotions to entice customers to buy more, but profit margins are at risk. "Value-seeking" shoppers are driving demand for cheaper products, and companies are responding with deals and advertising. However, some items remain stubbornly expensive, and wages and freight rates pose challenges, potentially squeezing profits unless shoppers buy more.

images.alt_text: Grocery giants Walmart, Kroger and Albertsons are booking 20-plus per cent gross profit margins, roughly in line with where they were before the Covid-19 pandemic spiked inflation.

Less product, same price: companies use 'shrinkflation' to hide price increases

site_title: World’s biggest car shipper warns charter rates will come down
summary: Höegh Autoliners, the world's largest car shipper, warns that global charter shipping rates for transporting cars will decline amid geopolitical moves to limit Chinese automakers' exports. The company's CEO, Andreas Enger, notes that the current high rates, near $115,000 a day, may not be sustainable due to tariffs imposed on Chinese EVs and a shortage of capacity. Enger estimates that rates may drop to half the current level, and the company has an order backlog of 50 vessels from China, which could impact the global car shipping market.

images.alt_text: New car sales this year are expected to be at 1.97 million units, down from an earlier forecast of 1.98 million units, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said.

A Volkswagen ID.4 electric vehicle (EV) at a Rivian charging station in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024. Volkswagen AG is taking another swing in its long struggle to catch up with Tesla Inc., plowing $5 billion into a tie-up with the US company's closest would-be rival, Rivian Automotive Inc. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Saic Motor is offering generous leasing deals, including a two-for-one MG4 promotion in Germany, where EV sales have sputtered.

site_title: Spike in million-dollar deals, strong volumes nudge HDB resale prices up further in July
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.6% month-over-month in July, driven by strong market volumes and a surge in million-dollar deals. A record 120 HDB flats sold for over S$1 million, with 47 new projects contributing to the increase. Resale volumes surged 39.6% to 3,049 flats, with four-room flats accounting for 46% of total volumes. Analysts attribute the surge to increased household income, new BTO classification system, and buyers being priced out of the market, driving demand for resale flats.

images.alt_text: An EC site in Pasir Ris fetched a record-high land price for ECs or S$557 million or S$729 psf ppr.
There is a need for diverse housing options for seniors, says Bernie Poh, chief executive officer of Allium Healthcare.

It may be better for landlords to remain flexible in lease negotiations during tenancy renewals, says Savills.

site_title: Kirin raises Fancl tender offer price seeking to secure deal
summary: Kirin Holdings has raised its tender offer price for Fancl by 4.1% to 2,800 yen per share, seeking to secure the deal amid market expectations of a higher bid. The revised offer is aimed at increasing certainty of consummation and comes after Fancl shares traded above Kirin's prior offer of 2,690 yen per share. The deadline for the bid has been extended to August 28.

images.alt_text: Japanese skincare brand Fancl counter in Isetan Scotts.

site_title: Meta apologises for removing Malaysian PM’s social media posts
summary: Meta apologized for removing Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's social media posts paying tribute to Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh, who was killed last month. The posts were restored with a newsworthy label. A live stream was briefly halted due to an intellectual-property complaint. Malaysian officials met with Meta representatives and issued a statement calling the removal "discriminatory, unjust and a blatant suppression of free expression." Meta said it was an operational error and not intended to suppress free speech. The incident has sparked tensions between Malaysia and Meta.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim accused Meta of “cowardice” last week for removing his posts.

site_title: Emergency power rationing among measures for Singapore’s energy security under new Bill
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) has proposed measures to strengthen the country's energy security, including emergency power rationing, centralized gas procurement, and cost recovery. The Energy Transition Measures and Other Amendments Bill, introduced in Parliament, aims to regulate the power sector, introduce new guardrails, and establish a fund to support Singapore's energy transition. The EMA will implement power rationing as a "last resort" and lift measures expeditiously, with the goal of ensuring energy security and reliability.

images.alt_text: One proposal is the establishment of a regulatory regime for centralised gas procurement, which is seen to allow Singapore to benefit from demand aggregation, diversify its energy sources and ensure there is sufficient gas to meet its power needs.
The new approach is needed “given the global gas market conditions and Singapore’s relatively small demand”, says EMA.

site_title: MAS prioritises policyholders, competitive market in assessing Allianz-Income deal: Chee Hong Tat
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will prioritize policyholders' interests when assessing Allianz's proposed acquisition of a majority stake in Income Insurance. MAS will ensure existing policies are not changed and will hold Income and Allianz accountable for their commitments. Chee Hong Tat, Second Minister for Finance, stated that a competitive insurance industry is the most effective way to meet Singaporeans' needs, and MAS will focus on protecting policyholders' interests. The deal has faced public scrutiny due to concerns over Income's social mission, but MAS expects Income to fulfill its obligations under existing contracts.

site_title: Star power elevates pin-trading, the unofficial sport of the Olympics
summary: The unofficial sport of the Olympics, pin-trading, has made a comeback at the Paris 2024 Games, with athletes trading pins as a symbol of friendship and goodwill. The activity has been elevated by celebrity star power, with athletes such as Serena Williams, Stephen Curry, and Snoop Dogg participating. The pins, originally used to identify athletes, judges, and officials, have become a coveted currency among athletes, with rare pins like those from North Korea and Haiti highly sought after. Social media has amplified the activity, with pins going viral and becoming the hottest thing in the Olympic Village.

images.alt_text: Singapore's badminton star Loh Kean Yew celebrates after the win over China's Li Shifeng on Thursday that saw him book a place in the quarter-finals at the Paris Olympics.

US' Noah Lyles celebrates after winning the men's 100m final of the athletics event at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at Stade de France in Saint-Denis, north of Paris, on August 4, 2024. (Photo by Loic VENANCE / AFP)

site_title: Korda defends title as women’s golf stars relish Paris crowds
summary: Nelly Korda, the US women's golf world No 1, will defend her Olympic title in Paris, seeking to complete a second consecutive US gold medal sweep. Korda, who has six tour titles this year, including the first major, Chevron Championship, faces a competitive field, including South Korea's Amy Yang and Japan's Yuka Saso. The women's Olympic competition starts on Wednesday, following the same format as the men's, with a 72-hole stroke-play contest over four days.

images.alt_text: Britain's Andy Murray waves goodbye after playing with Britain's Daniel Evans  against US' Taylor Fritz and US' Tommy Paul in their men's doubles quarter-final tennis match on Court Suzanne-Lenglen at the Roland-Garros Stadium during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, in Paris on August 1, 2024. (Photo by CARL DE SOUZA / AFP)
Singapore's badminton star Loh Kean Yew celebrates after the win over China's Li Shifeng on Thursday that saw him book a place in the quarter-finals at the Paris Olympics.
Paris gold medal-winning fencer Vivian Kong gets lifetime travel tickets for Hong Kong’s MTR subway system from the Hong Kong government.

site_title: Anti-money laundering regime to be kept robust without impeding legitimate businesses: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's anti-money laundering (AML) regime will remain robust while minimizing disruptions to legitimate businesses and investors, according to Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo. The government has introduced measures to improve the handling of seized properties, enhance compliance capabilities, and strike a balance between prevention and hindering financial activities. The Bill, passed on Tuesday, strengthens law enforcement agencies' abilities to prevent, detect, and take action against money laundering, while maintaining Singapore's attractiveness to investors and promoting a stable financial environment.

images.alt_text: The amendments will allow law enforcement agencies to reduce the cost of property maintenance and preserve the value of seized or restrained properties, enhancing asset recovery and restitution to victims.

site_title: Mercedes gets nod to test high-level self-driving in Beijing
summary: Mercedes-Benz has received approval to test its Level 4 self-driving capabilities on highways and urban roads in Beijing, marking the first time an international auto brand is permitted to do so. The trials will focus on advanced autonomous driving tasks such as parking, reversing, and turning in busy traffic, with human override still an option. This move follows similar approvals for Tesla and General Motors in Shanghai, and comes as Chinese manufacturers and technology companies such as Alphabet's Waymo and Baidu's Apollo Go develop robotaxis for the country's auto market.

site_title: Casinos collected S$4.4 million more in entry levies from April to May due to lapse in law: MHA
summary: Singapore's two casinos collected S$4.4 million more in entry levies from April to May due to a lapse in law. The levies, previously set at S$100 daily and S$2,000 annually, were increased to S$150 and S$3,000 respectively in 2019. The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) overlooked the expiry date, causing the higher levies to be collected for one month. The MHA has since introduced a new order to restore the levies to the original rates, and there are no plans to increase the entry levy.

images.alt_text: The Gate building, centre left, in the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Monday, July 5, 2021. Credit Suisse AG Chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio has vowed to undertake a global corporate strategy review after taking over in the wake of a pair of disasters. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
The Philippine gambling sector, next only in size to Macau and Singapore in Asia, attracts high rollers from countries like China, Japan and South Korea.
Mayor Alice Guo's case sheds light on criminal activity in the mostly Chinese-backed online casino industry in the Philippines.
South-east Asia bets big on casinos, but who will take Singapore’s crown?

site_title: The unexpected winners and losers as markets went into meltdown
summary: Markets worldwide experienced a significant downturn on Monday, with equities, bonds, and currencies taking a hit. However, some investors shifted their focus to emerging markets and alternative assets, resulting in unexpected winners and losers. Malaysia's ringgit saw its best single-day rally since 2015, outperforming emerging-market peers, while the yuan bond market in China gained traction. The Mongolian stock market was the only Asian benchmark to rise, driven by gains in coal and consumer staples companies. Meanwhile, gold prices dropped 3.2% and the US dollar strengthened against several currencies.

images.alt_text: CMG20231027-HengYY03 / 王彦燕 / 拍马币、令吉 [SPH]  Ringgit Malaysia
All three major US indices spent the entire day in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 2.6 per cent, or more than 1,000 points, to finish at 38,703.27 on Monday.
Lenders typically feel the squeeze as recessions heighten concerns over credit losses due to higher unemployment, while loan demand – a key factor in profitability – also takes a beating.
Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.

With the widely expected September rate cuts looming, recent movements in the US market are likely due to a myriad of factors, such as profit-taking from mega-cap technology counters, recession fears as well as a rotation into cyclical sectors.

After the biggest two-day selloff since March 2023, the anxiety has ratcheted up significantly, as the Fed faces criticism that it waited too long to cut and weak earnings batter the technology companies that were driving the rally.

site_title: The economy is looking pre-recessionary
summary: The US economy is showing pre-recessionary signs, with the unemployment rate trending up and private surveys indicating a softening labor market. The Federal Reserve, which made a mistake by not cutting rates last week, needs to act quickly to prevent serious economic deterioration. The Fed should cut interest rates by half a percentage point at its next meeting in September to address the rising risk of a near-future recession. Policymakers must move before perfect certainty is achieved, as waiting too late will guarantee that they'll miss the opportunity to prevent economic pain.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signalled last week that the first interest rate cut could come “as soon as” September but some analysts fear that may not be soon enough, as the markets have responded in dramatic fashion to last week’s below-target US jobs report, which raised fears that the US was entering a recession.

site_title: Saudi Aramco’s second-quarter profit slips 3% on lower crude output
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 3.4% decline in second-quarter profit to 109.01 billion riyals (S$38.6 billion), primarily due to lower crude output and softer refining margins. The company declared dividends of US$31.1 billion, including US$10.8 billion in performance-linked payouts. Despite this, Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund PIF holds nearly 81.5% of Aramco and benefits from its dividends. The kingdom's oil finances are under pressure due to lower output and prices, with a reported second-quarter deficit of over US$4 billion.

images.alt_text: Baosteel will also reduce the financing collateral principal for the joint venture to nearly US$1.1 billion from US$1.3 billion.
The US$925 billion Saudi wealth fund has listed several of its portfolio companies in recent years and is becoming an active debt issuer.

The plan to issue debt comes weeks after the Saudi government offloaded an US$11.2 billion stake in Aramco.

site_title: Singapore did not consult Cambodian authorities before deporting convicted money launderer
summary: Singapore deported convicted money launderer Zhang Ruijin to Cambodia in June without consulting Cambodian authorities, Minister for Home Affairs K Shanmugam said in Parliament. Shanmugam stated that whether a deportation destination is more or less favourable to an offender is 'legally irrelevant' and that the government does not disclose discussions with foreign governments on deportations due to operational security and intelligence concerns. Zhang was later expelled from Cambodia in July after being deported.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Home Affairs Sun Xueling said foreigners convicted in Singapore will be deported to “any country to which their passport or travel document allows them to go”.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust bags S$165 million OCBC sustainability-linked loan
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust secured a S$165 million sustainability-linked multi-currency revolving credit facility from OCBC, dubbed the OCBC 1.5°C Loan. The loan is linked to greenhouse gas emission targets validated by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi). As of May 2024, the stapled group has "greened" 51% of its global portfolio by gross floor area, exceeding its 2025 target. This brings the stapled group's sustainable financing to over S$700 million, with OCBC's sustainable financing loans growing 33% from the prior year.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.
OCBC’s SME sustainable financing loan book doubled to over S$7 billion in 2023
Visitors and tenants at CapitaSpring can immerse themselves in the Green Oasis which is spread over four levels from the 17th floor.

site_title: Telkom Indonesia taps Goldman, Mandiri to seek strategic investor for data centre business
summary: Telkom Indonesia has appointed Goldman Sachs and Mandiri Sekuritas to find a strategic investor for its data centre business, NeutraDC. The move comes as investors and technology companies prepare for billions of dollars in deals linked to data centers in Asia. NeutraDC, a subsidiary of Telkom, operates 29 data centers across Indonesia and globally, with one hyperscale center in Jakarta and plans to build more. A potential sale of a minority stake could value NeutraDC at over $1 billion.

images.alt_text: Singtel said Telkomsel’s decline in net profit was driven mainly by fair value revaluation.

site_title: OpenAI co-founder John Schulman leaves ChatGPT maker for rival Anthropic
summary: John Schulman, co-founder of ChatGPT maker OpenAI, has left the company for rival Anthropic, citing a desire to focus on AI alignment and hands-on technical work. This move follows recent departures of other key OpenAI executives, including Greg Brockman and Peter Deng. Schulman's departure comes as OpenAI faces significant personnel changes and amid Elon Musk's ongoing lawsuit against the company. Schulman's departure marks the latest in a series of high-profile exits from OpenAI, which has been undergoing significant restructuring.

images.alt_text: Apple is weaving OpenAI’s ChatGPT capabilities into its software and expects to do the same with Google’s Gemini chatbot.
The filing of the complaint by Elon Musk comes nearly two months after he abruptly withdrew a similar suit against OpenAI, Altman and Brockman.

The new timing means the AI capabilities will not be widely launched until a subsequent update to the new operating system.
Despite a frenzy of investment, most AI firms are still working out business models while spending heavily on technology.
Large language models have a tendency to hallucinate, or deliver incorrect information in convincing fashion.
OpenAI has been striking licensing deals with publishers to train its AI models and to integrate more authoritative, up-to-date information within its products.

site_title: India’s biggest lender deploys 2,000 bankers to woo the wealthy
summary: State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest lender, is deploying 2,000 bankers to expand its wealth management business. The bank aims to change its approach to managing wealth, focusing on smaller companies and ties with existing clients. SBI joins global and domestic players in grabbing a share of India's growing wealth, which generated $590 billion in new financial wealth in 2023. The bank faces competition from HSBC, Barclays, and local players, and its chairman, Dinesh Khara, declined to comment on assets under management.

site_title: United Food special audit uncovers ‘unusual’ cash transactions, potential listing rule breaches
summary: A special audit by KPMG has uncovered "unusual" cash transactions and potential breaches of SGX listing rules at United Food Holdings, a mainboard-listed company. The audit found $32.2 million in cash transactions between two entities and third parties, as well as potential contraventions of listing rules related to the company's proposed acquisition of two Chinese companies in 2017. The audit also raised concerns about United Food's internal controls and corporate governance, recommending that the company seek legal counsel to assess potential breaches of fiduciary duties and listing rules.

images.alt_text: United Food Holdings posts Q2 loss of 1.9 million yuan
United Food, CDW issue profit warnings
United Food Holdings' independent auditor issues qualified opinion on FY2019 financial statements
United Food Holdings posts 3 straight years of pre-tax losses

site_title: Former manufacturing giant SunPower files for bankruptcy
summary: US solar energy firm SunPower has filed for bankruptcy in Delaware, planning to wind down operations. The company listed assets and liabilities of $1 billion to $10 billion in its Chapter 11 petition. It agreed to sell assets to Complete Solaria for $45 million. High interest rates and subsidy changes in California have been a drag for the industry. SunPower, founded in 1985, has faced corporate struggles, defaulting on a credit agreement in 2023 and restating earnings. The company will focus on supporting employees and customers under new ownership.

images.alt_text: China’s world-leading solar industry is grappling with a wave of company failures and consolidation as excessive capacity pushes prices below production costs.
The projects in Saudi Arabia mark a major step forward for China’s clean energy industry.

site_title: Citi hires DBS’ Yeo Wenxian as head of wealth for Asia South
summary: Citi appoints Yeo Wenxian as head of wealth for Asia South, effective Nov 1. She will also become Citibank Singapore's CEO, following regulatory approval. Yeo, a Singaporean executive, will oversee Citigroup's retail onshore and offshore wealth management businesses in Asia South and the UAE, with minimum assets under management of S$250,000 and S$1.5 million, respectively. The appointment marks a key move as Citi builds its Asia South business, which is considered one of the fastest-growing wealth clusters globally. Yeo previously spent 13 years at DBS, most recently as head of DBS Treasures Singapore.

images.alt_text: Angel Ng will join Prudential's group executive committee starting from Oct 1.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Paragon Reit, Lendlease Global Reit, CSE Global, Cordlife
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported an 11% fall in half-year net profit to S$540 million, down from S$608 million in the previous period. The energy company approved an interim cash dividend of S$0.06 per share for H1. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Ascott Trust secured a S$165 million sustainability-linked credit facility from OCBC, while Sembcorp's shares closed 2.4% lower at S$4.51 on Monday.

images.alt_text: The banking trio, making up nearly 45 per cent of the 30-stock blue-chip barometer, also contributed to the STI’s steep decline.

site_title: Apple’s shift to AI is poised to soften blow from Google ruling
summary: Apple is shifting towards AI technology to mitigate the impact of a US government ruling that found Google's payments to device makers for preferential search engine placement were illegal. Apple has been integrating OpenAI's ChatGPT capabilities into its software and expects to do the same with Google's Gemini chatbot. This move could allow Apple to reach new agreements with AI providers and steer consumers towards AI-powered tools, potentially reducing its dependence on traditional Internet searches.

images.alt_text: Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.
Taipei-listed iPhone assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry and chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing slid about 10 per cent each.

The commercial sparked concerns among lawmakers in the tourism committee of the House of Representatives, which had planned to invite representatives from Apple and state agencies for a discussion on the matter.

Apple's sales totaled US$85.78 billion in the three months ended June 29, beating the average analyst estimate of US$84.53 billion, according to LSEG data. Its revenue had declined in the first three months of the year.

site_title: Bank of Japan under fire for rate-hike timing after market meltdown
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has faced criticism for raising interest rates too early, contributing to a historic stock market plunge and global market turmoil. The BOJ's decision, made on July 31, was based on economic and inflation data that was seen as in line with previous expectations. However, the yen's rapid surge has now hurt exporters' earnings and led to a rebound in the currency, which has weighed on Japanese consumers' purchasing power. Analysts now expect the BOJ to wait and see how the US economy will unfold before making its next move.

images.alt_text: Houses and buildings in Hadano, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. The Bank of Japan’s second interest-rate hike in nearly two decades is set to impact millions of personal mortgages, raising borrowing costs for homebuyers for the first time in a generation.
The discussions underscore how the yen’s declines were among key factors that were discussed at the BOJ’s June meeting, and led to its decision in July to raise interest rates.

The Bank of Japan’s decision on Wednesday (Jul 31) to raise rates to 0.25 per cent sent a wave of volatility through the market, with the Topix jumping 1.5 per cent on the day, only to plunge on both Thursday and Friday
