site_title: Chip Wars: South-east Asia’s semiconductor surge amid US-China rift
summary: Southeast Asia's semiconductor industry is experiencing a surge amid the US-China rift, with countries like Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand advancing their chip capabilities. Indonesia's industry is lagging behind regional champions, while Malaysia's sector is booming due to the tech clash. Singapore is also experiencing growth, but faces challenges in nurturing its local semiconductor industry. Vietnam, which has been gaining momentum, is now seeking lower US tariffs after a surprise announcement from Trump. The industry is expected to continue growing, with foreign investors returning to the region.

site_title: Four killed after Storm Debby hits Florida coast
summary: Tropical Storm Debby made landfall on Florida's Gulf Coast as a Category One hurricane, killing at least four people, including a 13-year-old boy and a truck driver. The storm is expected to bring heavy rainfall and catastrophic flooding to south-eastern US states, with the National Hurricane Center warning of a "prolonged extreme rainfall event" and potential for catastrophic flooding. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has activated the state's National Guard and declared a state of emergency, while President Joe Biden has approved an emergency declaration for the state.

images.alt_text: The Shore Acres neighborhood begins to flood from high tide in the Tampa Bay while Tropical Storm Debby approaches the gulf coast, in St. Petersburg, Florida, August 4, 2024.

site_title: AI chip startup Groq gets US$2.8 billion valuation in new funding round
summary: Groq, an AI chip startup, raised US$640 million in a new funding round, valuing the company at US$2.8 billion. The funding, led by BlackRock and backed by Cisco Systems and Samsung Electronics, will be used to build 108,000 language processing units, hire significantly, and explore acquisitions. The deal almost triples Groq's valuation from US$1 billion in 2021, competing with major players like Intel and Nvidia. CEO Jonathan Ross plans to utilize the funding to drive growth and innovation in AI computing power.

images.alt_text: Aidan Gomez, CEO of Cohere, which is profiting from highly specialised data, says: “Enterprises are sceptical of technology, and they’re risk-averse, and so we need to win their trust and to prove to them that there’s a way to adopt this technology that’s reliable, trustworthy and secure.”

site_title: Fujitsu struggles to find workers to expand in IT consultancy
summary: Fujitsu is struggling to find workers to expand its IT consultancy arm, despite targeting a five-fold growth to 10,000 workers by March 2026. The Tokyo-based company is facing stiff competition from larger system integrators like Accenture. To address the issue, Fujitsu is exploring acquisitions of companies both domestically and internationally to bolster its workforce. Corporate executive officer Yoshinami Takahashi stated that the company has a "lot in our pipeline" to support its expansion plans.

site_title: Philippine inflation rises as central bank prepares to cut rates
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate rose 4.4% in July, surpassing the central bank's target for the first time this year. Consumer prices increased due to higher utility costs, exceeding economists' median forecast of 4.1%. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas is preparing to cut interest rates as early as next week, despite the inflation breach. The rate cut is expected to support the economy amid global growth concerns and lower borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s inflation rate of 2.13 per cent is among the lowest in the Asean region.
The handout is also crucial to the fortunes of the ruling coalition as it aims to please voters battling high cost of living and the highest household debt in South-east Asia.
The central bank sees inflation possibly breaching its 2 to 4 per cent goal this month due to higher power rates as well as food and fuel prices.
Factory output for the January to June period fell 2.01 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Xpeng Aeroht raises US$150 million for production of flying cars
summary: Xpeng Aeroht, a unit of Chinese electric carmaker Xpeng, raised $150 million to fund the development and production of its proposed flying car, the Land Aircraft Carrier. The vehicle consists of a ground vehicle with a rechargeable, two-seat airborne module. Pre-sales are set to start in the final quarter of 2024 in China, with the company planning to build manufacturing facilities in Guangzhou. Xpeng Aeroht aims to carry four or five passengers and is owned by Xpeng and its chairman, He Xiaopeng.

site_title: Hot stocks: US office S-Reits up on Fed rate-cut expectations, MAS proposal to relax leverage limit
summary: US office Reits Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit, and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit gained in early morning trade on Tuesday, with Manulife US Reit rising as much as 7.1%. The gains followed expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut and the Monetary Authority of Singapore's proposal to simplify Reit requirements.

images.alt_text: xx
The proposals will simplify leverage requirements for all Reits, says MAS.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound but Singapore’s dips 0.7%
summary: Asia markets rebounded on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index inching up 0.04% after a record 12.4% plunge on Monday. However, Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.7%, weighed down by its banking trio. Other regional markets rebounded, with Nikkei 225 surging 9.7%, Kospi Index rising 4.2%, and the S&P/ASX 200 climbing 0.4%. Analysts attribute the rebound to a brief respite from market turmoil, with the US Federal Reserve's soothing words calming investor nerves, but caution remains, with Tokyo's markets still reeling from a 12.4% drop.

images.alt_text: epa11053156 People cross the street beneath a large screen showing the latest stock exchange and economy data in Shanghai, China, 02 January 2024. On Tuesday 02 January 2024, most Asian markets were down following the release of data that indicated further weakness in Chinese property and manufacturing sectors.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

site_title: Lifting the hood on S$100m new GCBs
summary: Housing developers in Singapore remain cautious despite softening interest rates, with subdued bidding at recent land tenders. The US Federal Reserve's anticipated rate cut may not boost developers' risk appetite, as equities markets have taken a beating due to recession concerns. However, Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) may attract buyers due to their scarcity and perceived value. The landed housing market saw a 58.1% increase in transactions in Q2, while HDB resale prices rose 0.6% month-on-month. Overseas, China's residential market slumped, and the US office property market continues to struggle.

images.alt_text: While the market continues to see a steady flow of headline deals, more signs of distress are also surfacing, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Developers are pricing more risk into their land bids or are staying away completely, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Letting overseas visitors stay in residential properties for such durations increases accommodation choices for visitors, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Injections of fresh flat supply and new resale curbs were meant to tame secondary market prices – yet, momentum is building up, writes deputy news editor Michelle Low.
It’s also possible that some demand is decanting into the public housing market, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: UK weather rains on consumer spending in July
summary: UK consumer spending declined in July due to rainy weather, with a 0.3% drop in annual terms according to Barclays. The British Retail Consortium reported a 0.5% rise in sales values, below the 1.4% average over the past 12 months. Non-essential spending fell, contrasting with a 2% inflation rate. Despite this, Barclays' chief economist expects a recovery in spending power and consumer confidence, driven by a growing economy and reduced interest rates, potentially leading to stronger spending growth in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: New car sales this year are expected to be at 1.97 million units, down from an earlier forecast of 1.98 million units, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said.
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer is aiming to raise overall economic growth to around 2.5 per cent a year, similar to Britain’s pre-financial crisis average.

The government says the police have “all the resources they need” to deal with the disorder as officers warned of more demonstrations on Sunday, leading to fears the unrest could spread further again.
Taylor Wimpey said it now expects to build close to the upper end of its target range of 9,500 to 10,000 homes in 2024 in the United Kingdom.
Lloyds Bank’s headline gauge of business confidence in Britain rose to 50 per cent in July from 41 per cent in June, matching May’s eight-year high.

Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Britain’s top antitrust enforcer has opened an investigation into eight housebuilders to probe potential information sharing, sharpening scrutiny of a sector that’s failing to deliver enough affordable housing to meet demand. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Singapore's marine and offshore players can adapt to take part in constructing critical components in the wind energy value chain, such as offshore substations, support vessels, and mooring products.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer (right) and Leader of the Opposition Rishi Sunak at the opening of Parliament in July.

site_title: Emperador H1 net profit falls 19.6% to 3.8 billion pesos
summary: Emperador, a global spirits conglomerate, reported a 19.6% fall in first-half net profit to 3.8 billion pesos, citing a challenging Philippine market. However, second-quarter net profit rose 19% quarter-on-quarter to 2.1 billion pesos, driven by better global consumer confidence. Revenue fell 7.9% to 28.6 billion pesos, with brandy revenue down 10.3% and whisky revenue decreasing 4.4%. The company plans to expand its distilleries and warehouses to accommodate more products, and expects its long-term strategy to offer premium products to drive future growth.

images.alt_text: (From left) George Schulze, Dalmore whisky expert for Asia at Emperador; Bryan Donaghey, chief executive of Whyte & Mackay and head of whisky business at Emperador; Loh Boon Chye, SGX chief executive; Dr Andrew Tan, chairman of Emperador; Gerard Ho, Singapore’s Ambassador to the Philippines and Kevin Andrew Tan, director of Emperador at the listing of Emperador at the Singapore Exchange on 14 July 2022.

site_title: Country Garden sales drop 72% as China’s housing woes persist
summary: Country Garden Holdings' contracted sales for July dropped 72% from a year ago to 3.4 billion yuan, following a 73% slide in June. The Chinese developer is trying to avoid liquidation after a failed rescue package. Buyer concerns over Country Garden's liquidity have led to a decline in home sales, with a recent rescue package failing to revive China's housing market. The company is counting on a turnaround in sales to increase its survival chances, with a Hong Kong court adjourning a wind-up petition until January.

images.alt_text: Chinese developer Country Garden defaulted on its US$11 billion worth of offshore bonds last year.
Country Garden has become one of the biggest casualties of China’s real estate crisis, with 1.4 trillion yuan of total liabilities, according to its unaudited 2023 interim results.
Contracted sales dropped 73 per cent to 4.3 billion yuan (S$804 million) in June from a year earlier, following a 76 per cent slide in May, a filing by Country Garden showed.
Hong Kong  stock exchange has asked the cash-strapped Country Garden to publish all its outstanding financial results along with any audit modifications.

site_title: Gold prices drift higher on US rate-cut optimism
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,411.97 per ounce on Tuesday, rebounding from multi-week lows, amid US interest rate cut optimism. US central bank policymakers signaled a potential September rate cut, which put pressure on the dollar and bond yields, increasing gold's appeal. Traders now price in a 50-basis-point cut at the Fed's September meeting and anticipate an additional cut in December.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Emerging-market equities get crushed in worst day since 2022
summary: Emerging-market equities experienced their worst day since February 2022, plummeting 4.2% on Monday as concerns over a US economic slowdown fueled volatility. Asian technology shares led declines, with traders weighing the odds of a potential emergency interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve amid recession fears. Despite a brief recovery, overall losses remained, with emerging markets trading at 11.6 times their blended-forward 12-month earnings, slightly below their 10-year historical average. Experts predict a cautious and volatile market for the next few weeks.

site_title: Nvidia’s next-generation AI chip rollout slowed by engineering snags
summary: Nvidia's rollout of its next-generation AI chip, the Blackwell lineup, has been slowed by engineering snags, including issues with data center infrastructure and supporting technology. The delays affected the company's highly anticipated products, although production is expected to ramp up in the second half. Despite the setbacks, Nvidia remains confident in its ability to maintain its lead in AI computing, with demand for its Hopper generation remaining strong. The company's stock price declined 6.4% on Monday, but analysts expect the delays to have a minimal impact on Nvidia's revenue and long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang has personally sold about US$1.4 billion in shares since the start of 2020, including this summer’s sales.
Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.
The chips may be delayed by three months or more.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed NVIDIA logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Wall Street strives to rebound, Tokyo soars after rout
summary: Global markets rebounded on Tuesday, with Tokyo's Nikkei surging 10.2% to close at 34,675.46 points, following a record 12% drop on Monday. US stocks also rebounded, with the Nasdaq Composite rising 0.5% after a 3% loss on Monday. European equities failed to hold onto early gains, with analysts warning of potential further volatility. The rebound is attributed to a calming of the yen carry trade and reassurances from US data, including a narrowing US trade deficit. However, analysts caution that the market may still be leery of a recession, with some predicting further sell-offs.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered decliners 94 to 56 at the opening bell.
Markets have been rocked by premature recession fears during the current bull market.
Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumped 7.39 per cent, or 2,324.26 points, to 33,782.68, while the Topix jumped 7.28 per cent, or 162.07 points, to 2,389.22 on Tuesday morning.

site_title: Hearing to probe Alaska Airlines emergency on Boeing jet
summary: The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) holds a two-day hearing in Washington to investigate a January incident on an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 MAX, which required an emergency landing after a panel blew out, exposing passengers to open air at 16,000 feet. Preliminary findings revealed four missing bolts securing the panel, and Boeing employees had removed them during an inspection last October. The NTSB will hear from 15 witnesses, including Boeing officials, regulators, and the machinists union, and will determine the probable cause of the accident and make recommendations to improve transportation safety.

images.alt_text: Boeing projects the global aircraft fleet to almost double over the next 20 years.
The guilty plea marks a low point in Boeing's century-long history after years of turmoil sparked by two crashes of its 737 Max aircraft in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.
Details of the deal, which requires Boeing to pay a fine and submit to an outside supervisor, were given to the families in a two-hour presentation by the Department of Justice on Sunday.
For months, Boeing has been dealing with production problems in three commercial jets - the 737 MAX, the 787 Dreamliner and the 777.
An Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX was forced to make an emergency landing after a panel blew out midair in January. Alaska Airlines said on Friday it has returned the plane to Boeing.
Kelly Ortberg is returning from retirement to head the 108-year-old US planemaker, which is bleeding cash and beset by companywide problems expected to take years to fix.

This undated image released by Boeing on July 31, 2024, shows the aerospace company's new CEO Robert "Kelly" Ortberg. Boeing named the former Rockwell Collins chief its next CEO on July 31, 2024, as the aviation giant reported a hefty loss on continued operational problems. Ortberg, 64, helped lead Rockwell Collins and integrate it into United Technology prior to his retirement from RTX in 2021. (Photo by Handout / BOEING / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / Boeing" - NO MARKETING NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS
Crashes such as that of Japan Airlines at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda in Tokyo on Jan 3, 2024, with a smaller coast guard plane on the ground, were the top cause of claims.
The resumption is a boost to Boeing, which had flagged Chinese delivery delays to investors, and which is engulfed in a separate safety and quality crisis.
Airbus secured orders from Japan Airlines and Virgin Atlantic – although much of the business had already been flagged.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.8% to 3,268.46 on Tuesday, following a global market rout. Gainers outnumbered decliners 94 to 56, with banking stocks such as DBS and UOB trading higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.6% on Monday, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. The main European stocks index hit its lowest in over six months due to concerns over a slowdown in the world's largest economy.

images.alt_text: The banking trio, making up nearly 45 per cent of the 30-stock blue-chip barometer, also contributed to the STI’s steep decline.

site_title: Elon Musk’s X to close San Francisco office, relocate workers
summary: Elon Musk's social media platform X will close its San Francisco office, ending the company's 18-year presence in the city. Employees will be relocated to offices in San Jose and Palo Alto. The move follows Musk's criticism of San Francisco's left-leaning culture and comes after he announced plans to relocate X's headquarters to Texas. The closure marks the end of X's long history in San Francisco, where the company had its Market Street office since 2012.

images.alt_text: The filing of the complaint by Elon Musk comes nearly two months after he abruptly withdrew a similar suit against OpenAI, Altman and Brockman.
Social media platforms, including X, have been under scrutiny for years over the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories, including false information about elections and vaccines.
Neuralink is in the process of testing its device, which is intended to help people with spinal cord injuries.
Elon Musk was so upset by the judge’s decision to block the pay packages that he moved Tesla’s state of incorporation out of Delaware to Texas.

site_title: Nvidia’s Jensen Huang sold US$323 million of stock in July before decline
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang sold a record $322.7 million worth of shares in July, ahead of a tech stock sell-off. This sale, combined with his June sales, totals $500 million since 2020. Huang's net worth fell $5.9 billion, dropping him to 16th on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, as Nvidia shares tumbled 14% over the last three trading days. The sell-off erased $184.9 billion from the world's 500 richest people's fortunes, including tech tycoons.

images.alt_text: Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.
The chips may be delayed by three months or more.
Jensen Huang, 61, is the world’s 14th-richest person, just behind Michael Dell.

site_title: Dow plunges over 1,000 points: Is the ‘great unwind’ only just starting?
summary: The global stock market experienced a sudden and drastic downturn, with the Dow plunging over 1,000 points. The US$6.4 trillion in global stock value was wiped out, with Asian markets, including Tokyo's Nikkei and Seoul's Kospi, falling 12% and 9% respectively. The sell-off was triggered by premature recession fears, fueled by weak July jobs report, disappointing Big Tech earnings, and the Bank of Japan's interest rate hike. The market panic has raised concerns about the financial system's stability, with economists predicting potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.
Investors are selling AI giants to snap up smaller stocks and defensives that had lagged behind.
The Nasdaq indexes tumbled more than 3 per cent for the worst day since October 2022.

site_title: Small nuclear reactors: Big potential for Singapore, but with caveats
summary: Singapore has signed a 30-year deal with the US to study small modular reactors (SMRs) and other advanced nuclear-power technologies, marking a cautious approach to harnessing the potential of SMRs for clean energy. Despite challenges such as fuel supply, costs, and geopolitics, policymakers will need to navigate these issues to determine the financial sustainability of SMR projects. The deal provides access to technical information under US export control, and Singapore's neighbours, including Indonesia and Vietnam, are already studying nuclear energy. The outcome of the deal will depend on the future direction of US climate policy and the development of fuel supply, with the US aiming to increase domestic high assay low enriched uranium (Haleu) production.

images.alt_text: The agreement is expected to come into force by the end of this year after a review by the US Congress
Nuclear power requires the least land to produce electricity among sources of low-carbon electricity.
The region has a complicated history with nuclear power, and there are reasons for both optimism and caution.
Tokamak Energy's CEO Warrick Matthews (left) and Dr Victor Nian of the Centre for Strategic Energy and Resources see room for Singapore to play an active role in nuclear fusion research.

US scientists achieved net energy gain in a fusion reaction for the second time in July 2023, producing a higher yield than its initial fusion ignition breakthrough seven months prior at the National Ignition Facility in California.

site_title: Oil falls as global equities selloff offsets rising Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices fell 0.66% on Monday, settling at $76.30 a barrel, amid a global equities selloff. The decline was limited by concerns over Iran's retaliation for the assassination of a Hamas leader, potentially leading to a wider Middle East war. Investors fled riskier assets, expecting rapid interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve to drive US economic growth. Oil prices are hovering at 8-month lows due to US recession fears and slumping diesel consumption in China.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 2.2 per cent lower on Monday.
All three major US indices spent the entire day in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 2.6 per cent, or more than 1,000 points, to finish at 38,703.27 on Monday.

Brent crude futures inched down 4 cents, or 0.1 per cent, to US$76.77 a barrel by 0035 GMT, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$73.39 a barrel, down 13 cents, or 0.2 per cent on Monday morning.

site_title: Investors bet on RBNZ rate cut next week amid global repricing
summary: Investors are betting on the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) to cut interest rates next week, with expectations of a 25 basis point reduction to 5.25% followed by two further reductions to 4.75% by the end of the year. The RBNZ's July rate review softened its stance, acknowledging signs of declining activity and opening the door for policy easing sooner than previously signalled. Economists expect the OCR to fall from 5.5 to 4.5% by November, with some predicting a more rapid easing cycle.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s economy has stalled after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) rapidly raised interest rates to combat inflation.
Prime Minister Christopher Luxon has announced it will reverse a ban on oil and gas exploration, push the pricing of agricultural emissions back five year and encourage more mining.
Values remain about 16 per cent below the boom-time peak of NZ$982,918 in January 2022.

The survey’s headline measure showed a net 27.1 per cent of New Zealand respondents expected the economy to improve over the year ahead, versus an 6.1 per cent optimism level in the previous poll in June.

site_title: SVB bankruptcy plan approved, but US$2 billion FDIC fight lingers
summary: A US federal judge approved Silicon Valley Bank's (SVB) restructuring deal, allowing it to distribute assets to creditors and preferred equity holders. However, the FDIC's fight to recover approximately $2 billion in deposits held by the former SVB subsidiary remains unresolved. The judge rejected SVB's argument that its Chapter 11 bankruptcy plan should extinguish the FDIC's right to set off amounts owed to the bank. The FDIC's set-off rights allow it to reduce liabilities owed to SVB, and the dispute will be analyzed by district courts.

images.alt_text: The battle over the seized funds will play out in a California federal court.
HSBC countered that it “lawfully extended job offers” to former SVB workers whose employment status was up in the air after the First Citizens acquisition.
The FDIC’s annual report last month reported that it sold US$10.5 billion of the securities in January to trusts tied to the Federal Financing Bank, an arm of the US Treasury.

site_title: Japan’s real wages rise first time in 27 months in June
summary: Japan's real wages rose 1.1% in June, the first positive increase in 27 months, according to the labour ministry. This marks a turning point for the country's economy, which is seen as a key factor in the Bank of Japan's efforts to achieve a virtuous cycle of demand-led price gains. Nominal wages grew 4.5% and full-time workers' wages increased by 2.7%, the most in nearly 30 years. The positive wage growth is a welcome sign for the BOJ, which raised interest rates last week, as it suggests a potential recovery in consumption.

site_title: Frankfurt airport suffers partial power outage, flights not affected
summary: Frankfurt airport experienced a partial power outage in Terminal One due to a technical defect at an external substation. The outage occurred around 2100 GMT, but flights were not affected as planned take-offs and landings took place before the airport's ban on night flights began. The airport's backup power supply was activated, ensuring no disruption to flights. The incident is being addressed by technicians, but no further details are available at this time.

site_title: Lucid gets US$1.5 billion lifeline before electric SUV rollout
summary: Lucid Group, a US electric vehicle maker, has secured a US$1.5 billion funding from Ayar Third Investment Company, its largest investor. The investment includes a US$750 million loan and US$750 million in convertible preferred stock, supporting the company's production of the upcoming SUV, Lucid Gravity. The funding comes as Lucid works to overcome production hurdles and cope with slowing EV demand. The company reported second-quarter revenue of US$200.6 million, beating estimates, and plans to use the new funding to support operations until the fourth quarter of next year.

images.alt_text: Lucid expects to incur a total of around US$21 million to US$25 million in charges related to the workforce reduction plan and expects to complete the process by the end of the third quarter of 2024.

site_title: Dell cuts workers in sales team reorganisation with new AI-focused unit
summary: Dell Technologies is reorganizing its sales teams, including a new AI-focused unit, amid a struggling personal computer market. The company will cut jobs and streamline management as part of its efforts to adapt to the post-pandemic market decline. Dell has seen increased interest in its high-powered servers for AI workloads, but concerns remain about the payoff from AI investments. The reorganization aims to prioritize investments and focus on emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Dell is assembling half of the racks for xAI’s supercomputer.
Fuelled by optimism about demand for its AI-optimised servers, Dell’s stock has more than doubled this year and hit a record high earlier this week.
Dell AI-capable PCs will come with the Qualcomm Snapdragon X series chips that feature neural processing units dedicated to processing complex AI tasks.
The layoffs come after sluggish demand for its PCs for nearly two years partly contributed to a 11 per cent drop in revenue in fourth-quarter earnings posted last month.

site_title: US banks tumble as weak economic data sparks recession fears
summary: US bank stocks plummeted on Monday as recession fears intensified, with Citigroup leading the decline at nearly 5% and other major banks falling 2-4%. The slump is attributed to concerns over credit losses due to higher unemployment and declining loan demand. The US unemployment rate jumped to a near three-year high in July, fueling fears of a potential recession. Analysts say the economic weakness may impact the sector's outlook, but some believe it may be a temporary blip.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has been buffeted by a range of factors since hitting a record of US$73,798 in March.

epa11520221 A person walks past American flags hanging on the front of the New York Stock Exchange in New York, New York, USA, 02 August 2024. The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics released an 'Employment Situation Summary' reports on 02 August that the unemployment rate in the United States rose to 4.3 percent in July 2024. Investors reacted negatively to the economic news, leading the Dow Jones industrial average to lose over 800 points during the day.  EPA-EFE/OLGA FEDOROVA
Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.
Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.
SoftBank’s stock fell 19 per cent, extending its decline for the September quarter so far to 38 per cent, in line to be the biggest such drop since 2001.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks surge 7% after record fall
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 7% on Tuesday morning, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 7.39% to 33,782.68 and the Topix index rising 7.28% to 2,389.22. The historic selloff on Monday, which saw the Nikkei close down 12.40%, was reversed as investors reacted to worries over the US economy and a stronger yen. The rebound is seen as a sign of market resilience, but concerns over global economic uncertainty remain.

site_title: Hatten Land files application for judicial management; trading in shares suspended
summary: Hatten Land, a Singapore-based real estate developer, has filed an application to be placed under judicial management, effective immediately. Trading in its shares has been suspended since Aug 2. The company aims to wind up its inactive Malaysian subsidiary, Prolific Properties, with zero equity value. Deloitte & Touche has been proposed as the joint judicial managers of Hatten Land. The judicial management application is a proactive measure to facilitate the company's restructuring efforts and prevent any precipitous action by creditors.

images.alt_text: A MAN is facing a charge for obstructing the course of justice, by offering to help businessman Ng Yu Zhi leave Singapore unlawfully while the latter was under investigation for fraud.

site_title: Crypto ETF complex hit by selling spree in first big stress test
summary: Global investors have pulled nearly $423 million from cryptocurrency-linked funds in four straight days, marking the first major sell-off for the speculative asset class since its mainstream launch via exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in January. The outflows contributed to the worst weekly exodus since early May, as Bitcoin plummeted 16% and wiped out over $150 billion in market value. Other digital assets, such as Ether, have also seen significant declines, with total net outflows for spot Ether ETFs exceeding $500 million since their debut in July.

images.alt_text: New York state maintains some of the strictest crypto regulations in the US.
This will be at least the second recent meeting between the crypto industry and officials in the White House.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits six-month low in global rout on US recession fears
summary: The Stoxx 600, Europe's main stocks index, hit its lowest in over six months, closing 2.2% lower on Monday, amid fears of a US recession and global economic uncertainty. The decline was driven by a broad-based market slide, with energy and utility stocks leading the way. The Euro Stoxx volatility index reached its highest level since March 2022, reflecting investor anxiety. Some relief was offered by news of a US services sector rebound, but concerns about global demand growth and economic uncertainty continued to weigh on markets.

images.alt_text: Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.
All three major US indices spent the entire day in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 2.6 per cent, or more than 1,000 points, to finish at 38,703.27 on Monday.
Lenders typically feel the squeeze as recessions heighten concerns over credit losses due to higher unemployment, while loan demand – a key factor in profitability – also takes a beating.

site_title: US Federal Reserve under pressure to cut rates as market turmoil continues
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled a potential interest rate cut "as soon as" September, but some analysts fear it may not be soon enough amid market turmoil following a below-target US jobs report. The futures market now sees a half-point cut as more likely, with some economists calling for an emergency rate cut before the September meeting. The US economy is still growing, but inflation is falling, and the labor market has weakened, leading to calls for swift action to prevent a recession.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell speaks during a press conference following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy in Washington, U.S., July 31, 2024. REUTERS/Kevin Mohatt/File Photo
Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.
The Stoxx 600 closed 2.2 per cent lower on Monday.
All three major US indices spent the entire day in the red, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 2.6 per cent, or more than 1,000 points, to finish at 38,703.27 on Monday.

site_title: Bangladesh PM Hasina flees country, military takes over
summary: Bangladesh Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled the country after a month of deadly protests, which resulted in nearly 100 deaths. The military took over, forming an interim government, following her resignation. Protests began over civil service job quotas and escalated into wider calls for her to stand down. At least 366 people have been killed since protests started, with many more injured. The military vowed to address injustices and lift a curfew, while opposition leaders were released from prison. A major vacuum has been created, with the international community urging a peaceful and democratic transition.

images.alt_text: Anti-government protesters clash with police and pro-government supporters,  Dhaka, Bangladesh, Aug 4, 2024.

FILE PHOTO: People gesture near smoke as protesters clash with Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) and the police outside the state-owned Bangladesh Television as violence erupts across the country after anti-quota protests by students, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, July 19, 2024. REUTERS/Mohammad Ponir Hossain/File Photo

site_title: US: Dow falls more than 1,000 points as stocks extend slump
summary: US stocks fell sharply on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 2.6% and more than 1,000 points, as investors extended a pullback amid economic unease and overseas market volatility. The losses follow recent poor US employment data and a negative survey from manufacturers sparking recession fears. Despite stronger-than-expected growth in services companies, market watchers are calling for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates, citing the ripple effects of Japan's interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Asia’s rout arrived hot on the heels of the meltdown on Wall Street last Friday.

epa11520221 A person walks past American flags hanging on the front of the New York Stock Exchange in New York, New York, USA, 02 August 2024. The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics released an 'Employment Situation Summary' reports on 02 August that the unemployment rate in the United States rose to 4.3 percent in July 2024. Investors reacted negatively to the economic news, leading the Dow Jones industrial average to lose over 800 points during the day.  EPA-EFE/OLGA FEDOROVA
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the entrance of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain. Aug 23, 2018. REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo
Lenders typically feel the squeeze as recessions heighten concerns over credit losses due to higher unemployment, while loan demand – a key factor in profitability – also takes a beating.

site_title: Indonesia’s chip ambitions: A slow burn as it lags regional champs
summary: Indonesia is struggling to compete in the booming chip sector due to regulatory hurdles and a less favorable business environment. Despite possessing abundant semiconductor resources, the country lags behind regional powerhouses Malaysia and Singapore. Key reasons for Indonesia's lag include a lack of a comprehensive strategy, limited investor-friendly laws, a shortage of skilled workers, and insufficient infrastructure. The country's automotive value chain success has not translated to the semiconductor sector, where Malaysia and Singapore have established themselves as major players.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: TikTok, bowing to EU, withdraws rewards programme
summary: TikTok has permanently withdrawn its rewards program, "TikTok Lite Rewards," from the European Union, following pressure from European regulators. The program, which rewarded users for watching and liking videos, was removed from France and Spain, the only EU countries where it was available. The move is seen as a victory for the EU's landmark Digital Services Act, which requires digital firms to police online content and protect users from harm. TikTok has made binding commitments to remove the program and not launch similar initiatives.

images.alt_text: TikTok and parent company ByteDance and a group of TikTok creators have filed suits to block the law that could ban the app used by 170 million Americans.
The US alleges that for years millions of American children under 13 have been using TikTok and the site “has been collecting and retaining children’s personal information”.
The US Department of Justice's filing details wide-ranging national security concerns about ByteDance’s ownership of TikTok.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. flag is placed on a TikTok logo in this illustration taken March 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: London’s FTSE falls after US recession fears spark global rout
summary: London's FTSE 100 index fell 2% to its lowest since April 22, marking its worst day in over a year, amid fears of a US recession sparked by weak economic data. The US job growth slowdown raised concerns of a potential recession, prompting bets for a half-point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. All sub-sectoral indexes in London ended in the red, with water utilities and energy shares declining 4% and 3.2%, respectively.

images.alt_text: SoftBank’s stock fell 19 per cent, extending its decline for the September quarter so far to 38 per cent, in line to be the biggest such drop since 2001.
Lenders typically feel the squeeze as recessions heighten concerns over credit losses due to higher unemployment, while loan demand – a key factor in profitability – also takes a beating.
Bitcoin has been buffeted by a range of factors since hitting a record of US$73,798 in March.

site_title: Rising new executive condominium prices a concern for buyers: PropNex survey
summary: A recent PropNex survey found that 55% of HDB flat owners believe new executive condominium prices are unaffordable or extremely unaffordable. The median transacted unit price of new ECs rose to S$1,417 psf in 2023, exceeding S$1,500 psf in the first half of 2024. To improve affordability, suggestions include raising the monthly household income ceiling, adjusting mortgage servicing ratios, and increasing EC land supply under the GLS Confirmed List.

Together, the two residential sites could potentially yield 730 residential units.

site_title: US judge rules Google is monopoly in key anti-trust case
summary: US District Court Judge Amit Mehta ruled that Google has a monopoly in search and text ads due to exclusive distribution agreements that made it the default option on devices. The ruling, in a landmark anti-trust case, concludes that Google's dominance is largely unseen and significant, particularly on mobile devices. Google plans to appeal the verdict, which may impact its search business and revenue. The decision could lead to remedies or damages, potentially including forced divestiture of the search business or default deals for rival search engines like Bing.

images.alt_text: Nvidia shares took a hit from a report that the launch of its upcoming AI chips could be delayed by three months due to design flaws.
The chips may be delayed by three months or more.
CrowdStrike was sued by shareholders on Wednesday over misleading and false assurances about its software which caused the global outage.
The deal will see Character.AI co-founders Noam Shazeer and Daniel De Freitas rejoin Google, where they were formerly employees.
Tech evangelists have touted the promised benefits of AI, but teachers, musicians, artists and others have accused its creators of training advanced computers to replace them.
Microsoft reported a net income of US$88.1 billion for its fiscal year on revenue of US$245.1 billion, up 22 per cent and 16 per cent respectively.

site_title: Harris set to name vice-president pick ahead of swing state tour
summary: US Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris is set to announce her vice-presidential pick within 24 hours, kicking off a five-day tour of battleground states including Pennsylvania, Arizona, and Georgia. Harris, who secured the Democratic nomination, has dominated fundraising records and social media, and is expected to introduce herself to the public before the national convention in Chicago. Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro is among the frontrunners for the vice-presidential spot, which is seen as crucial for Harris's showdown with Republican Donald Trump on November 5.

images.alt_text: Supporters of Republican presidential nominee and former President Donald Trump pose with his masks as they wait in line to attend a campaign rally during a hot and humid day in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania., July 31, 2024.

Harris, the US vice-president, is expected to announce her selection by Tuesday, ahead of her first scheduled public appearance with her running mate in the evening at Temple University in Philadelphia.
Social media platforms, including X, have been under scrutiny for years over the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories, including false information about elections and vaccines.

In what is widely billed as America’s first AI election in November, researchers warn that tech-enabled fakery could be used to steer voters toward or away from candidates - or even to avoid the polls altogether - stoking tensions in an already hyperpolarised environment.

Harris on Monday compared her election rival Donald Trump to "predators" and "cheaters," as she attacked the first former US leader to be convicted of a crime. (Photo by Erin SCHAFF / POOL / AFP)
US Vice President Kamala Harris started August with US$377 million cash on hand, the largest war chest at this point in an election cycle.

(Right) Donald Trump’s worst impulses resurfaced on Wednesday with his outlandish claim that Kamala Harris (left) - the first female and non-white vice-president - recently “became a Black person” for political convenience.

site_title: Ringgit rallies, erasing year’s losses against SGD
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has rallied nearly 4% this year, erasing its year's losses against the Singapore dollar. The currency has become the region's star performer, trading at 3.35 against the Singapore dollar, its highest level since May 2023. External factors, including a dovish Federal Reserve pivot and rosier domestic conditions, are driving the rally. Domestic factors, such as a global semiconductor upcycle and positive Q2 GDP figures, are also contributing to the ringgit's strength. However, economists note that the currency's appreciation may be short-lived due to potential downside risks, including weakening external demand.

images.alt_text: The local currency fell 0.2% to 4.7965 against the dollar, its weakest level since an all-time low of 4.8850 in 1998 following the fallout from the regional financial crisis.
Intel Malaysia's ATP facilities in Penang. With MNCs implementing US+1 and China+1 strategies, Malaysia stands to benefit from this trend.

site_title: Europe at sharp end of potential second Trump presidency
summary: Europe is preparing for a potential second Trump presidency, with key teams scenario-planning for the implications. Despite a low confidence rating in Trump, Europe is investing in security and self-sufficiency, with Poland and the UK leading the way. The EU is considering early trade deals with Trump to reduce a 150 billion euro trade deficit, and preparing for countermeasures if he imposes sanctions. Europe's dependence on US security guarantees is a concern, and the region must invest in its own security to maintain transatlantic ties.

images.alt_text: If Donald Trump defeats his Democratic opponent, likely to be Vice-President Kamala Harris, in November, he looks set to start a second term right where the last one left off — railing against an overvalued currency, which he blames for blowing out America’s trade deficit and hollowing out its industry.
Under President Joe Biden, US GDP in absolute terms is at the highest level ever.

site_title: UK beekeepers and scientists tackle sticky problem of honey fraud
summary: UK beekeepers and scientists are using advanced technology, including lasers, to detect honey fraud. Adulterated honey, often made with syrups, has become a significant problem, with 46% of honey tested in the EU being flagged as potentially fraudulent between 2021 and 2022. The European Union has updated its honey regulations to improve labelling, but the UK's lack of stringent labelling has led to widespread availability of adulterated honey in supermarkets. Researchers at Aston University are developing a technique called Fluorescence Excitation-Emission Spectroscopy (FLE) to detect the unique molecular fingerprint of genuine honey, aiming to create a unified standard and protect the industry and consumers.

images.alt_text: The Anthem of the Seas ship arrives at the Barcelona Cruise Terminal of the Port of Barcelona in Barcelona, Spain, on Saturday, July 27, 2024. Barcelona plans to enact a citywide ban on all short-term rentals to address complaints that tourism is to blame for a local housing crisis and soaring rents. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Elon Musk of Tesla has warned about the dangers of AI, saying it could  pose an existential threat to humanity.

site_title: New York City’s outdoor dining sheds will start disappearing
summary: New York City's outdoor dining sheds, which have been a staple of the city's pandemic-era dining scene, will start disappearing due to a deadline for permits. Only about 2,600 of the 6,000 to 8,000 restaurants currently using outdoor dining permits sought extensions, meaning the structures will have to be dismantled. Critics have called the sheds "eyesores" that attract rats and take up parking spaces, while proponents argue they boost small businesses and inject life into the urban landscape. The decision marks the end of a heated debate over the future of outdoor dining.

images.alt_text: DFI Retail Group’s pivot to ready-to-eat comes as cigarette sales in the stores have fallen.
Asahi, since early 2023, has been intending to exit its restaurant operations as part of its shift to its core alcohol and beverage segment.
The restaurant is staying, at least for now.
House of Seafood is one restaurant offering insect-incorporated dishes.
Last month, celebrity chef Kylie Kwong announced she will shut her beloved eatery Lucky Kwong and retire.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges, Ether has worst drop since 2021 as crypto sinks
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 16% to $54,653, its worst drop since March, as the crypto market was hit by risk aversion in global markets. Ether, the second-largest cryptocurrency, fell 21% to $2,440, its worst decline since 2021. The decline is attributed to factors such as the global stock sell-off, geopolitical tensions, and the unwinding of the yen carry trade. Despite the downturn, some analysts see it as a buying opportunity, citing oversold technical indicators and a potential rebound in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin’s year-to-date advance has moderated to approximately 34 per cent.
Morgan Stanley’s decision may pave the way for other banks that have been reticent to offer digital assets to consider tapping into the sector.
Bitcoin has climbed more than 45 per cent this year, aided by inflows into US exchange-traded funds for the token.

site_title: New Zealand faces triple-dip recession, Westpac predicts
summary: New Zealand's economy is facing a triple-dip recession, according to Westpac Banking's forecast. The economy is expected to shrink 0.6% in the second quarter and 0.2% in the third, driven by high interest rates curb spending and investment. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand raised interest rates to combat inflation, but the pace of price increases is slowing. Westpac predicts a 25 basis-point rate cut at the next monetary policy statement and three more by the end of the year, leading to a 5% Official Cash Rate by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Cordlife shareholder linked to Nanjing Xinjiekou owner dumps entire 10% stake
summary: Global Cord Blood Corporation's joint liquidators have disposed of over 25.5 million shares, representing around 10% of Cordlife Group's shares, after being placed in provisional liquidation in 2022. The shares were held indirectly through China Stem Cells (East) Company, which is ultimately owned by Sanpower Group Corporation. Sanpower Group also holds a stake in Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store. The move comes amid ongoing investigations and potential breaches of disclosure obligations involving Cordlife directors.

images.alt_text: Cordlife says it will work to expedite potency testing, in addition to other rectification efforts.
Cordlife Group reports a net loss of S$11.6 million for the three months ended Mar 31, reversing a net profit of S$1.2 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.
Cordlife has been in the spotlight after it was revealed last November that seven of Cordlife’s 22 storage tanks were exposed to temperatures above acceptable limits.
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.

site_title: Capitol Singapore’s hotel, theatre and retail arcade put on market for S$650 million
summary: Singapore's Capitol Singapore development, including the 157-room Kempinski Hotel, Capitol Theatre, and retail arcade, is on the market for S$650 million. Perennial Holdings has appointed CBRE and Savills to identify a buyer for the 244,500 sq ft property, which has 85.5 years of lease remaining. Across the road, Singapore Land Group is seeking S$150 million for Stamford Court, a 78,190 sq ft building with a 99-year leasehold tenure. The sale of these properties could potentially add value by repurposing the upper levels for hospitality use, such as hotels or serviced apartments.

site_title: Creating more good jobs
summary: The 2022 US Chips and Science Act aims to create geographically dispersed innovation hubs, promoting breakthroughs in various sectors and addressing regional disparities in innovation and job creation. The Act authorized federal support for research and science, spreading it across the country to create next-generation tech hubs. With a 64-33 vote, it overcame the Senate's filibuster rule, providing a boost to federal support for research and science. The US Economic Development Administration has designated 31 tech hubs in 32 states and Puerto Rico, with $504 million in funding for 12 regional technology and innovation hubs. The Act is seen as a crucial step towards making the US more competitive and creating more good jobs.

President Joe Biden signing into law the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022, in a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, August 2022.

site_title: How to maximise your CPF for greater retirement income
summary: Singaporeans' Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings are insufficient for a comfortable retirement, with the average 60-65 year-old having a balance of S$194,296, falling short of the estimated S$450,000 needed. Many must supplement their incomes through part-time work, external savings, or family support. To maximize CPF returns, investors can consider a globally diversified equity portfolio, which has delivered an annualized return of 11% since its launch in 2019. A balanced portfolio of equities and fixed income can meet long-term needs, but requires balancing risk and returns.

images.alt_text: The Singapore stock market has suffered a hollowing out of capital over the past years, resulting in a vicious cycle in disincentivising listings and investments.
In addition to leveraging government schemes to grow one's nest egg, reaching out to professional wealth planning managers can help close gaps and boost financial resilience.
Investing our CPF savings is an increasingly important way to build a bigger nest egg.

site_title: Next DBS CEO should have the skills to run the ‘Digital Bank of Singapore’
summary: DBS, South-east Asia's largest lender, is set to face a new challenge as CEO Piyush Gupta steps down, with the bank needing a visionary leader who can maintain its digital lead and cope with AI risks. The ideal candidate should have a "unique blend" of traditional banking acumen and forward-thinking leadership, prioritizing strengthening digital infrastructure resilience while pushing forward with digital innovation. With ample capital and operations in 19 markets, DBS is poised for growth and expansion, including potential mergers-and-acquisitions, but faces uncertainty and volatility in the global operating environment.

DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta's lower salary for FY2023 comes after the bank announced it was cutting his variable pay by 30 per cent.
Piyush Gupta, the chief executive officer at DBS Group Holdings, has acknowledged the role of small things in making a bank good, average or bad in the digital age.
Piyush Gupta is in many ways the Jamie Dimon of Singapore, the highest-profile banker leading the country’s largest lender and surrounded by succession speculation.

site_title: Five US states push Musk to fix AI chatbot over election misinformation
summary: US Secretaries of State from Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Washington, Michigan, and New Mexico have urged Elon Musk to fix X's AI chatbot, Grok, which spread misinformation related to the Nov 5 election. The chatbot falsely told users that Vice-President Kamala Harris had missed the ballot deadline in nine states. The officials called on Musk to implement changes to ensure voters have accurate information in the critical election year. Musk has faced criticism for spreading misinformation, including false claims about Democrats allowing migrants to vote in federal elections.

site_title: Failing at succession? Try secession
summary: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch, 93, is trying to amend his family trust to give his son Lachlan control of his business after his death, but three of Lachlan's siblings are contesting this effort in court. This move is part of a larger power struggle within the Murdoch family, echoing the TV show Succession. Experts suggest that family-run businesses often struggle with succession issues, citing the odds of a child being up to the job and the potential for acrimony. The article posits that holding onto power and control can lead to unhappiness and that letting go may be a necessary step for personal growth and success.

images.alt_text: HBO's Succession series, starring Brian Cox and Matthew Macfadyen, illustrates how wealthy families can lose it all - by doing what Cox' character Logan Roy has done.

site_title: Schwab, Fidelity, other online brokerages face disruption on frenetic trading day
summary: Online brokerages Charles Schwab and Fidelity Investments experienced IT outages on a frenetic trading day, with over 3,400 and 3,500 users affected, respectively. The outages occurred amid market volatility triggered by weak economic data and geopolitical tensions, raising concerns about the capacity of brokerages to handle high volumes. The issues were resolved by Fidelity, while Schwab's outage persisted for several hours. Other brokerages, such as Robinhood Markets, experienced disruptions, but were able to resume trading. The outages added to investor frustration on a day when many were seeking to sell risky assets.

images.alt_text: “We are investigating reports of issues connecting to Microsoft services globally,” the company wrote in an update on a site to monitor accessibility of its Azure cloud services on Tuesday (Jul 30).

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit posts 21.2% lower DPU for H2 of S$0.0177
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit reported a 21.2% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0177 for the second half of 2024, due to higher borrowing costs, refinanced hedges, and an enlarged unit base. Distributable income decreased 19.4% to S$42.1 million, while gross revenue declined 2.1% to S$101 million. The Reit's net property income dropped 7.2% to S$71.9 million, primarily attributed to increased property operating expenses.

site_title: Magnificent Seven set to shed US$900 billion in value, led by Apple, Nvidia
summary: US technology stocks, including Apple and Nvidia, plummeted by as much as 6.5% on Monday, wiping out nearly $900 billion from their combined market value. The losses were triggered by a delayed launch of Nvidia's AI chips, a weak US payrolls report, and a cut in Berkshire Hathaway's stake in Apple. The sell-off also affected chip stocks, with Advanced Micro Devices and Intel falling as much as 7.8%. Analysts say the downturn may provide an opportunity to buy shares of the big technology firms at better valuations.

images.alt_text: With the widely expected September rate cuts looming, recent movements in the US market are likely due to a myriad of factors, such as profit-taking from mega-cap technology counters, recession fears as well as a rotation into cyclical sectors.

site_title: Japanese yen surges to 7-month high as US economy worries mount
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a 7-month high against the US dollar, reaching 141.675 per US dollar, amid growing concerns over the US economy and a potential rate cut from the Federal Reserve. Weaker-than-expected US jobs data, disappointing earnings reports, and heightened concerns over the Chinese economy led to a global sell-off in stocks, oil, and high-yielding currencies, with the US dollar losing ground to the yen and other safe-haven currencies like the Swiss franc.

images.alt_text: By the close on Monday, the Nikkei index had wiped out 113 trillion yen (S$1 trillion) of that peak market value.
The euro gained 1.12 per cent to US$1.0912 and reached US$1.0927, the highest since Jul 18.

site_title: Paragon Reit posts a 4.1% decline in DPU to S$0.0232 for H1
summary: Paragon Reit posted a 4.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0232 for the first half of 2024, down from S$0.0242 in the same period last year. The Reit's manager cited a shift in management fees being paid in cash to reduce dilution of unitholders' returns. Despite this, the Reit's gross revenue and net property income increased by 3% and 4.5% respectively. Occupancy rates remained high, with 98% occupancy across the portfolio, and the manager expects a moderation in retail sales growth due to easing labour market conditions and waning post-pandemic spending tailwinds.

site_title: BioNTech counts on shift to cancer drugs after second quarter losses quadruple
summary: BioNTech reported a 4x increase in 2Q losses to 807.8 million euros, citing a drop in Covid-19 vaccine sales. The company now focuses on new cancer treatments, with 90% of its R&D spending allocated to oncology. BioNTech predicts revenue growth in 2025 and plans to spend an additional 1 billion euros on research this year, with its first oncology launch expected in 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows GlaxoSmithKline headquarters in London, Britain, January 17, 2022.REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
BioNTech says it maps out plans to launch its first oncology drugs from 2026 onwards.
BioNTech said it expects to authorise new share buybacks worth up to US$500 million this year, having already spent US$1.3 billion on own shares through Mar 17.

site_title: Changes at MTI following perm sec Gabriel Lim’s retirement
summary: Permanent Secretary Gabriel Lim Meng Liang, 48, is retiring from the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Sep 1 after 24 years in the public service. Lim will be replaced by Beh Swan Gin, 56, who will take on the role of MTI Permanent Secretary, and Jeffrey Siow Chen Siang, 46, who will be designated as second permanent secretary. Lim's tenure saw efforts to grow the Singapore economy, create jobs, and strengthen trade relations, and he will be appointed joint head of corporate strategy at Temasek from Oct 1.

images.alt_text: Gabriel Lim (left) will join Temasek as its joint head for corporate strategy, while Eng Aik Meng (centre) and Dinesh Khanna (right) will join as joint heads of Temasek's portfolio development group.

site_title: Malaysia summons Meta over removed PM posts about Hamas leader
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim accused Meta of "cowardice" after the social media platform removed his posts about Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh's death. The posts were deemed "dangerous" due to association with the Palestinian armed group, which is considered a terrorist organization by Israel, the US, and the European Union. Anwar's office views Meta's actions as discriminatory and a suppression of free expression, demanding a public apology and explanation.

images.alt_text: The government reported more than 50,000 such cases to various social media platforms, including Meta’s Facebook and TikTok, in the first three months of this year alone.
Since the violence erupted, both social media firms have taken steps to improve moderation and remove or label graphic visuals.

site_title: US 2-year yield below 10-year for first time since July 2022
summary: US Treasury yields have reached a 2-year low below the 10-year yield for the first time since July 2022, sparking concerns of an economic downturn. This inversion of the yield curve has led investors to bet on a sharp monetary policy easing by the Federal Reserve, with some predicting a recession. The move follows weak economic data, including a disappointing job creation report and an unexpected rise in the unemployment rate. Experts warn that the inversion of the yield curve is a key indicator of an impending recession.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Asset Management plans to maintain its exposure mainly in the 10-year notes unless it sees massive stimulus.
China high-yield real estate bonds, once the largest segment of the Asia high-yield market with a 35 per cent weight, is now less than 10 per cent and is expected to shrink further.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles on growing recession worries
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday, August 5, as the unemployment rate rose to 4.3% in July, sparking recession fears. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 681.07 points, or 1.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped significantly. The negative reaction to the economic news led to a decline in global markets, with investors worried about the impact of weak economic data on the US economy.

site_title: US service sector rebounds in July; employment also recovers
summary: The US services sector rebounded in July with a 3.6-point increase in the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) non-manufacturing purchasing managers (PMI) index to 51.4, the highest level since May 2020. This growth suggests the labour market is slowing as the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes curb demand. The recovery in the services sector could help alleviate recession fears sparked by a surge in the unemployment rate last month. Economists had forecast a rise to 51, and the reading above 50 indicates growth in the services sector, which accounts for more than two-thirds of the US economy.

images.alt_text: Job seekers speak with prospective employers during a City of Los Angeles career fair offering to fill vacancies in more than 30 classifications of jobs on November 2, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. The US Bureau of Labour Statistics will release on November 3 the October jobs report amid expectations employment remains quite healthy. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Elon Musk suing OpenAI, Altman again
summary: Elon Musk is suing OpenAI, accusing co-founders Sam Altman and Greg Brockman of betraying the AI company's founding mission. The complaint, filed in a California federal court, alleges "altruism versus greed" and "Shakespearean proportions" of deceit. Musk's lawsuit comes nearly two months after he withdrew a similar suit against OpenAI, Altman, and Brockman. The case centers on OpenAI's development of ChatGPT, which Musk claims was not aligned with the company's original mission.

images.alt_text: A filing by an attorney representing Elon Musk (pictured) asked the court to dismiss the entire case, without offering a reason.
Elon Musk co-founded OpenAI but had a falling out with the San Francisco-based startup.
