Musk sues OpenAI and its chief executive Sam Altman (above) for allegedly breaking their founding agreement

site_title: Thai finance minister says to expand government equity fund by Oct to support bourse
summary: Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira announced plans to expand the government equity fund by October to support the stock market, which has declined 3% due to global market fears of a US recession. The fund, which will be increased from 100 billion baht to 150 billion baht, aims to mitigate the impact of external factors on the market. Chunhavajira also plans to discuss shortening the time bad debtors remain on the National Credit Bureau's blacklist.

site_title: CSE Global bags new Q2 orders worth S$204.4 million
summary: CSE Global secured S$204.4 million in new orders for Q2, a 11.7% decrease from the previous year due to one-off contracts. Excluding these, orders grew 2.5% year-over-year. The company's first-half order intake reached S$390.6 million, a 0.1% decrease from the same period last year. This brings its order book to S$692.3 million, a 32.7% increase year-over-year. The growth in data centre projects led to increased technical resources and production capacity.

images.alt_text: CSE’s chief executive Lim Boon Kheng expects order intake momentum to remain robust in 2024.

site_title: SoftBank Group shares plunge most since going public in 1998
summary: SoftBank Group shares plummeted 19% on Monday, extending a 38% decline for the September quarter, the largest single-day drop since 2001. The stock wipeout erased US$15 billion of value, with Masayoshi Son's personal wealth dropping by US$2.9 billion. Analysts attribute the decline to fading AI hype and rising geopolitical risks, with some predicting a smoother recovery with execution risk. SoftBank's quarterly results are set for Wednesday, where a slim profit is expected.

images.alt_text: Valued at US$2.77 billion at the end of 2020, a filing published last year revealed Graphcore needed more cash to break even.
PayPay Securities needs to increase its users and the amount of assets they invest in to meet its goal of becoming profitable in the next few years.
SoftBank’s close ties with Nvidia and OpenAI have strengthened the company’s position amid a global race to build AI-related infrastructure.

site_title: UK car industry body cuts 2024 sales forecast on weak EV demand
summary: The UK's Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) cut its 2024 new car sales forecast to 1.97 million units, down from 1.98 million units, citing weak private retail demand for electric vehicles as a major concern. This follows a 2.5% year-on-year increase in new car sales in July, which is its 24th consecutive month of growth. The SMMT also reduced its forecast for the battery electric vehicle (BEV) market share to 18.5% from 19.8%.

images.alt_text: China’s EV makers are grappling with domestic overcapacity for both battery cell and auto production, and Europe is a lucrative export outlet for its manufacturers
BYD, China’s biggest carmaker, displayed nine models, drawing the biggest crowd compared with its domestic rivals.

site_title: Can Samsung get its mojo back?
summary: Samsung Electronics, South Korea's most valuable company, is struggling to compete in the cutting-edge semiconductor industry, particularly in logic chips and memory chips. Despite a 16-fold increase in operating profit in the most recent quarter, the company has lost ground to rival chipmakers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and SK Hynix. Samsung's share of the global chip-foundry business has fallen from 19% to 11%, and its position as the global leader in memory chips is under threat. The company is investing heavily to catch up with rivals, but its vertical integration model and legacy of complacency may hinder its ability to adapt to changing technology.

images.alt_text: Samsung, the world’s biggest maker of memory chips, smartphones and TVs said operating profit rose to 10.4 trillion won (S$10 billion) in April-June, up from 670 billion won a year earlier.
HBM is made up of a collection of Dram chips stacked on top of each other, eight high in the most recent generation.

site_title: Asia markets in sell-off mode, triggered by US recession fears
summary: Asian markets experienced a significant sell-off on Monday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 plummeting 12.4% - its worst single-day decline since the 1987 Black Monday. The sell-off was triggered by US recession fears, following a report showing US hiring slowed and the unemployment rate rose to 4.3%, the highest in nearly three years. Other Asian markets, including China, Taiwan, and Singapore, also fell, with declines ranging from 1.5% to 8.4%. The sell-off was exacerbated by a spike in the VIX, a measure of market volatility, and declining US Treasury yields.

site_title: Singapore shares join global rout; STI dives 4.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 4.1% to 3,243.67, following a global stock rout due to recession fears from US employment data. The banking trio, making up nearly 45% of the STI, contributed to the decline, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 5.8%, 5.5%, and 5.3% respectively. MM2 Asia bucked the trend, rising 13.3% after announcing a proposed share placement.

images.alt_text: Asian markets were in a rout in Monday morning trading, triggered by the meltdown on the Wall Street last Friday.
Singapore shares fall at Monday’s open; STI down 2.5%
The fibre-optic owner posted a decline in its profit after tax by 9.1 per cent to S$25.7 million for the first quarter ended Jun 30.

site_title: Tencent joins US$300 million financing for China’s AI unicorn
summary: Tencent Holdings has contributed to a $300 million funding round for Chinese generative AI startup Moonshot, valuing the company at $3.3 billion. This deal, along with Alibaba's $1 billion investment in February, makes Moonshot one of the top contenders in China's AI sector, alongside other firms backed by Alibaba and Tencent. The funding round comes amid a heated battle for dominance in the market, with Western companies facing restrictions on providing ChatGPT-like services in China.

images.alt_text: GMM Music boosted its valuation to about US$700 million after selling a 10 per cent stake to China’s Tencent.
Tencent in June became one of China’s best-performing stocks.
Tencent is among the best performers in the global game sector this year, with its Hong Kong-listed shares outpacing gains in peers from NetEase to Nintendo.
DnF Mobile’s early success comes amid ongoing tensions between Tencent and smartphone vendors over gaming revenue sharing.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, August 5th, 2024 (Ep 116)
summary: The Nasdaq, a tech-heavy index, is in correction as an equity sell-off deepens, while Japan's Nikkei plummeted 13% in its biggest rout since 1987's Black Monday. Taiwan stocks fell by a record 8.4% due to tech sector fears. In contrast, the Ringgit rose by its most since 2015 amid government reforms.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.

site_title: China’s sweltering heat pushes Shanghai power demand to record
summary: China's extreme heat has pushed power demand to a record in Shanghai, with temperatures reaching 40.4°C (40.9°C previously recorded). The grid is holding up due to ample coal stockpiles and increased contributions from solar and hydroelectric power. Officials have warned farmers to protect crops from the heat, while nearby provinces monitor power supplies closely. The heat is part of the growing trend of extreme weather events caused by climate change, which is making such events more frequent and intense.

images.alt_text: China grew much more slowly than expected in the second quarter and faces deflationary pressures and a protracted property slump, with retail sales growth in June grinding to its weakest pace since early 2023.
The country’s economic growth unexpectedly slowed to the worst pace in five quarters in data released in July.
The Chinese government’s stimulus measures have so far failed to boost consumption, and the overleveraged property market has made consumers less likely to spend.
The expansion in China's manufacturing output was the slowest in nine months and was attributed to the first fall in new orders in a year.

site_title: Growth picks up among UK services firms after election result, PMI shows
summary: UK services firms reported a surge in new orders and employment in July, with the S&P Global UK Services Purchasing Managers Index rising to 52.5 from 52.1 in June. This optimism is linked to Prime Minister Keir Starmer's election victory, which has boosted business sentiment. The index also reached a five-month high, driven by expectations for lower interest rates. The Bank of England cut interest rates last week, and economists expect a reasonable GDP growth print in Q3, despite price pressures remaining historically high.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 52.1 from 50.9, its highest reading since July 2022 and up from a preliminary flash reading of 51.8.
Lloyds Bank’s headline gauge of business confidence in Britain rose to 50 per cent in July from 41 per cent in June, matching May’s eight-year high.

Shoppers cross a road near a Marks & Spencer Group Plc store on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Retail sales are set to be a drag on gross domestic product for the whole of the third quarter, following a steep decline in July and only a slight rise in August. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

The quarterly Deloitte survey of chief financial officers showed 23 per cent of large British companies reported high or very high uncertainty, down from 36 per cent in the previous survey and the lowest reading since late 2015.
Inflation is finally back at the BOE’s 2 per cent target, having hit double digits in 2022 in the wake of the pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: JPMorgan asset cools on China bond frenzy as curve flattens
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management plans to maintain its exposure to Chinese government debt, mainly in 10-year notes, unless it sees significant stimulus. The firm is cautious due to the narrowing yield gap between short and long-term bonds, which could lead to intervention by the People's Bank of China. The gap between two and 10-year bonds has narrowed to around 60 basis points, prompting concerns of a bubble threatening financial stability. JPMorgan will maintain its current positioning unless massive stimulus is implemented, which is considered unlikely.

images.alt_text: Last week ended with US jobs data showing that hiring had slowed markedly in July and unemployment had risen to the highest in almost three years.
Fears of a slowing economy and Fed delays have contributed to a sharp sell-off in US stocks last week.

site_title: Asia high-yield bonds still attractively valued
summary: Asia high-yield bonds delivered a strong performance in the first half of 2024, outperforming other major credit markets with a total return of 10.5%. The market's elevated starting yield and stable credit fundamentals outside China's property sector contributed to the rally. Default rates are expected to moderate to 4.5% this year, and the market is becoming more diversified, with China's weight decreasing and high-quality bonds performing well. The region's robust macro environment and access to cheap funding create opportunities for investors, with select sectors such as industrial companies in China and the gaming sector in Macau showing promise.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in Wuhan, China, on Monday, July 22, 2024. China increased support for the economy with surprise interest-rate cuts, seeking to prop up growth after a lack of short-term stimulus from a major Communist Party meeting disappointed investors. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Eurozone business growth at a standstill, July PMI shows
summary: Eurozone business growth stalled in July, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 50.2 from 50.9 in June, indicating a slowing expansion. The services sector, which accounts for the majority of the bloc's economy, showed a stuttering growth, while the manufacturing sector remained in contraction. Demand across the region fell for a second month, and firms raised prices at a slower pace. This suggests the European Central Bank may ease policy further, with a potential rate cut as early as September.

images.alt_text: Price growth in the 20 countries that share the euro accelerated to 2.6 per cent in July from 2.5 per cent in June according to Eurostat’s flash estimate.
Eurozone gross domestic product rose 0.3 per cent in the three months through June, sustaining the same pace as it did at the start of the year.
HCOB’s preliminary composite Purchasing Managers’ Index, compiled by S&P Global, dropped to 50.1 this month from June’s 50.9, barely above the 50 mark that separates growth from contraction.

Inflation this year could average 2.4 per cent, in line with the survey’s prediction three months ago and could then slow to 2 per cent next year, as predicted earlier, both below the ECB’s own in-house projections.

site_title: SocGen sells private banking units in push to slim down bank
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) agreed to sell its UK and Swiss private banking units to Union Bancaire Privee for approximately 900 million euros (S$1.3 billion). The units manage about 25 billion euros in assets under management. The sale is part of CEO Slawomir Krupa's plan to slim down the bank, following the sale of equipment finance and Moroccan operations. The transactions are expected to add 10 basis points to SocGen's CET1 ratio, with completion anticipated for the first quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: French banks including SocGen have not benefited as much from the rise in rates because of the high cost of deposits in the country.

A visitor arrives at the Societe Generale SA bank headquarters in the La Defense business district of Paris, France, on Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2023. SocGen reports earnings on August 3. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg
President Vladimir Putin approved an order on Sunday to allow Rosbank to buy the Russian stakes from the French bank.

site_title: Cheaper AI isn’t the panacea
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) technology has been criticized for being too costly, despite promising to help businesses cut costs. The high cost of deploying AI directly into a company's systems can range from $5 million to $20 million, with 30% of generative AI projects expected to be abandoned by the end of 2025 due to expense. However, AI costs appear to be coming down, with prices dropping by 99% for OpenAI's models since 2022. Despite this, the main issue remains the utility of AI for businesses, with many questioning its ability to provide a significant productivity edge.

images.alt_text: Amazon is developing its own processors to limit its reliance on costly Nvidia chips that power some of the artificial intelligence cloud business at its Amazon Web Services, the main growth driver.

site_title: Japan’s Nikkei sees biggest rout since 1987 Black Monday
summary: Japan's Nikkei index plummeted 12.4% on Monday, its largest single-day rout since the 1987 Black Monday sell-offs, amid economic concerns and a rising yen. The Nikkei has wiped out 113 trillion yen ($1 trillion) of its peak market value, pushing it into bear market territory. Banking stocks led the decline, with Tokyo Electron falling 18.48% and SoftBank Group sinking 18.66%. The yen's 2.5% surge against the US dollar and interest rate hike by the Bank of Japan are seen as contributing factors.

images.alt_text: Markets were already rattled by downbeat earnings updates from Amazon and Intel and Thursday’s softer-than-expected US factory activity survey and the monthly US non-farm payrolls report.
People take pictures of a monitor displaying Topix share average and Nikkei share average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan, July 4, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

A man looks at an electronic board?displaying stock prices of Nikkei 225 listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange along a street in Tokyo on April 24, 2024. Tokyo stocks ended sharply higher on April 24 after Wall Street rose for a second straight session on good corporate earnings. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Is Japan ready for a ‘world with interest’?
summary: Japan is set to experience a shift in its economic landscape as the Bank of Japan's second interest-rate hike in nearly two decades takes effect. The move will raise borrowing costs for homebuyers for the first time in a generation, affecting millions of personal mortgages. This change marks a significant departure from the country's past, where bank deposits yielded near zero and mortgage rates decreased over time. The new interest rate of 0.1% will require Japan to adapt to a "world with interest," where easy money is no longer the norm.

images.alt_text: The discussions underscore how the yen’s declines were among key factors that were discussed at the BOJ’s June meeting, and led to its decision in July to raise interest rates.
Higher mortgage rates may pressure the housing market.

The Bank of Japan’s decision on Wednesday (Jul 31) to raise rates to 0.25 per cent sent a wave of volatility through the market, with the Topix jumping 1.5 per cent on the day, only to plunge on both Thursday and Friday

site_title: Japan hails 100m champ Lyles as ‘world’s fastest anime fan’
summary: US Olympic 100m gold medallist Noah Lyles was hailed as the "world's fastest anime fan" by Japanese media after celebrating his win by miming the "kamehaha" attack from the anime franchise Dragon Ball. Lyles, 27, has openly expressed his love for Japanese pop culture, including comics and cartoons. His gesture paid tribute to Dragon Ball creator Akira Toriyama, who passed away earlier this year. The nickname "mankind's fastest otaku" was used by Japanese sports newspaper Daily Sports to describe Lyles, a term for hardcore anime superfans.

images.alt_text: Tech evangelists have touted the promised benefits of AI, but teachers, musicians, artists and others have accused its creators of training advanced computers to replace them.
Warner Bros said that by day five of the Games, the viewing audience had crossed 100 million across Europe, 32 per cent higher than for the same period at Tokyo.
Good vibes (and tax receipts) can also help the economy: Bloomberg Economics reckons French economic growth will pick up in the third quarter.

site_title: Temasek appoints 3 external hires to senior management, including MTI perm sec Gabriel Lim
summary: Temasek appoints three external hires to senior management roles, including Gabriel Lim, permanent secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry, as joint head for corporate strategy, and Eng Aik Meng and Dinesh Khanna as joint heads of portfolio development group. The appointments aim to strengthen Temasek's leadership and implement the Temasek 2030 strategy, which focuses on building a resilient and forward-looking portfolio. The new hires will work with portfolio companies to increase shareholder value and pursue initiatives that uplift their value, supporting Temasek's efforts to adapt to an era of unprecedented global challenges.

images.alt_text: Temasek has grown its US assets fivefold in the past decade.
GIC set up its first global office in New York 40 years ago. It is now in nine other cities including Tokyo, London, Mumbai and Sao Paulo.

site_title: China asks large state financial institutions to drop auditor PwC: sources
summary: Chinese regulators have asked several large state-owned financial institutions to drop PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) as auditor due to pressure over its work for troubled property developer China Evergrande Group. More than 30 listed Chinese companies have already axed PwC as auditor this year, including Bank of China, China Life Insurance, and China Taiping Insurance. The move puts further pressure on PwC, which has cut staff numbers and halved senior partner pay amid client exodus.

images.alt_text: PwC China’s layoffs started last week, and the overall target is expected to be met over a period of time.
A PWC corporate logo hangs on the side of a building housing the company's Shanghai office in Shanghai, China, on Saturday, Jan. 28, 2022. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
PwC came under the Chinese regulatory spotlight earlier this year for its role as the auditor of troubled property company China Evergrande Group.

site_title: Income Insurance needs adequate capital in order to stay financially sustainable: NTUC
summary: NTUC Enterprise Co-operative (NE) and Income Insurance will continue to offer two low-cost schemes to union members after Allianz's proposed 51% stake sale. The low-cost schemes, NTUC Gift and Income Insurance Luv, will remain affordable for policyholders, particularly those in lower-income segments. NTUC president K Thanaletchimi and secretary-general Ng Chee Meng emphasized the need for adequate capital to ensure financial sustainability, citing the insurer's repeated capital buffer issues since the Asian Financial Crisis in 1997. The NTUC will continue to support Income, but the insurer must access additional resources to meet its long-term commitments.

images.alt_text: NTUC Income announced a plan to corporatise its legal form, which would help pave the way for fresh injection of capital from institutions.

site_title: L’Oreal to acquire 10% stake in Swiss skin care company Galderma
summary: L'Oréal is set to acquire a 10% stake in Swiss skin care company Galderma from a consortium led by EQT, ADIA, and Auba Investment for an undisclosed premium. The deal is part of L'Oréal's strategy to tap into the booming injectable cosmetics market. Galderma, originally a joint venture between Nestle and L'Oréal, listed its stock in March. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Last month, L’Oreal had warned that the beauty market overall would grow less than it had expected earlier this year.

site_title: UOB prices A$1 billion worth of conventional single-tranche senior bonds
summary: UOB priced A$1 billion in four-year senior unsecured notes at the three-month Bank Bill Swap Rate plus 0.74%, marking the largest conventional Australian dollar single-tranche senior bond from a Singaporean issuer. This is the bank's second tap into the Australian dollar market this year, following an April dual-tranche three-year unsecured note issuance. The notes are expected to be issued on Aug 8, with UOB citing the Australian dollar market as integral to its funding strategy.

images.alt_text: The United Overseas Bank Ltd. (UOB) headquarters in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 19, 2024. Singapore expects its budget to swing back to a surplus in the fiscal year beginning April, as recent tax increases shore up revenue and help pay for social assistance seen as priority for the city-state's new generation of leaders. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
UOB Q2 profit rises 1% to S$1.43b; to pay S$0.88 per share dividend for H1

site_title: Apple supplier stocks slump after Berkshire nearly halves stake
summary: Berkshire Hathaway nearly halves its stake in Apple, selling $75.5 billion worth of shares, amid a broad market selloff. This led to a decline of 10% in Taiwanese suppliers Hon Hai Precision Industry and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, as well as 15% in Murata Manufacturing, 13% in LG Innotek, and 7.7% in Luxshare Precision Industry. The move is seen as a market negative, with some analysts noting that Berkshire's cash pile now stands at a record $276.9 billion.

images.alt_text: The commercial sparked concerns among lawmakers in the tourism committee of the House of Representatives, which had planned to invite representatives from Apple and state agencies for a discussion on the matter.
FILE PHOTO: Berkshire Hathaway Chairman Warren Buffett attends the Berkshire Hathaway Inc annual shareholders' meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, U.S., May 3, 2024. REUTERS/Scott Morgan/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan stocks fall by record 8.4% on tech sector fears
summary: Taiwan's main stock index plummeted 8.4% on Monday, the largest one-day decline in percentage terms, as investors sold off tech stocks amid concerns over a potential US recession. TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, dropped 9.75% to its lowest level since April. Other major tech stocks, including Mediatek, Quanta, and Foxconn, also fell heavily. Analysts predict the decline will continue, with technical support levels expected to be reached in the next two days.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang
The chips may be delayed by three months or more.

site_title: German carmaker mood darkens on slowing EV shift, China slump
summary: Germany's carmakers are experiencing a downturn in demand for electric vehicles, contrary to their significant investments in EV technology. The industry's business expectations have worsened to -18.3 points, down from -9.5 points, following disappointing earnings and a weakening Chinese market due to a housing crisis. Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz have reported poor financial results, with Mercedes trimming its annual margin forecast and Volkswagen pledging deeper cost cuts. The industry is under pressure to adapt to changing market conditions and maintain profitability.

site_title: Prudential taps former Citi executive to be new Greater China CEO
summary: Prudential appoints Angel Ng, a former Citi executive, as the new CEO for its Greater China, customer and wealth businesses. Ng, with 25 years of experience in financial services, will report to CEO Anil Wadhwani and be based in Hong Kong. She replaces Lilian Ng, who will retire at the end of the year and become an adviser to the CEO until June 2025. Ng's extensive experience and entrepreneurial mindset make her the ideal candidate for the role, according to Wadhwani.

images.alt_text: Pankaj Banerjee will assume the role on Sep 30, says Prudential.

Circumstances and priorities may change, and you want to ensure that your legacy plans are still on track and reflect your current wishes, says Goh Theng Kiat, chief customer officer at Prudential Singapore.

Chan San San (right) will take over the role of Prudential Singapore CEO from Dennis Tan (left). Tan remains as managing director of Prudential’s Strategic Business Group with oversight for Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

site_title: China’s Honor gets strong state backing as it readies IPO
summary: China's smartphone manufacturer Honor is receiving strong state backing as it prepares for an initial public offering (IPO). The company is receiving research-and-development funding, tax breaks, and support to expand overseas, with the goal of shipping 100 million handsets annually by 2026 and becoming a top-three global vendor by 2028. Shenzhen's government has pledged special policy support, including retroactive funding, certification support, and tax breaks, worth around 600 million yuan, to help Honor expand globally and improve its investor appeal.

images.alt_text: Apple’s market share in China dropped to 14 per cent in the second quarter of 2024, a decrease from 16 per cent in the same quarter of 2023.

site_title: Unearthed Productions and PLB Media partner to boost event ambitions of PropertyLimBrothers
summary: Unearthed Productions and PropertyLimBrothers Media have partnered to create more experience-led events in Singapore, reshaping the way homes are marketed. The partnership, following the success of the New Launch Convention 2024, aims to enhance event production value and deliver more value to property enthusiasts. Over the next two years, they will co-organize events centered on new residential developments, offering high-tech AV solutions and immersive experiences.

images.alt_text: Melvin Lim, CEO of PropertyLimBrothers, and Adam Piperdy, CEO of Unearthed Productions, at the Memorandum of Understanding signing ceremony.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee to propose ‘preferred candidates’ for internal manager personnel
summary: The trustee of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has identified and executed letters of intent with "preferred candidates" to propose as directors and senior management of the Reit's new internal manager. The trustee also reported a distribution per unit of S$0.0134 for the first half of its fiscal year ended Jun 30, down 16.8% from the previous year. HSBC Institutional Trust Services is in the midst of applying for a capital markets services licence for the new internal manager and has created a draft of the new manager's budget and operating plan.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit says that its portfolio valuation has improved 3.3 per cent year on year to S$914.5 million.
New Tech Park is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's internalisation process has dragged on for almost a year now.

site_title: India’s services growth slows a touch but still solid: PMI
summary: India's services sector growth slowed slightly in July to 60.3, but remained above the 50-mark for the 36th consecutive month, indicating expansion. Strong domestic demand and favourable conditions drove growth, with new business increasing and hiring rising despite elevated cost pressures. Selling-price inflation rose to a seven-year high, but service firms remained optimistic about the outlook for the year ahead.

images.alt_text: Penalties under the new rules rely on consumer law, opening manufacturers and endorsers to fines of up to five million rupees.
Anti-government protesters clash with police and pro-government supporters,  Dhaka, Bangladesh, Aug 4, 2024.

site_title: Takeaways from a S$93.9 million Tanglin Hill GCB deal
summary: A Singaporean developer, Meir Homes, sold a 2-storey Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Tanglin Hill for S$93.9 million, a record-breaking sale with a land price per square foot (psf) of S$6,200. The buyer's Stamp Duty totals S$5.6 million. The sale showcases that developers should be ambitious and build large, high-specification homes to attract buyers willing to pay premium prices. The sale also highlights the economic logic of building mega-sized houses, despite elevated construction costs.

site_title: Indonesia economy grows 5.05% in Q2, in line with expectations
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.05% in the second quarter, slightly below last year's 5.17% growth, but meeting market expectations. Strong consumption and domestic activities, driven by increased household spending during religious holidays and higher farmers' incomes, contributed to the growth. Government spending slowed down, while investment and export activity rose, with a trade surplus of $2.39 billion recorded in June. Despite a slight decline in growth, economists expect Indonesia's steady growth to persist, with forecasts of 5.2% growth in 2024 and 5.3% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said household consumption, investment and improving exports had likely driven growth in the April-June quarter.

Indonesia’s inflation rate of 2.13 per cent is among the lowest in the Asean region.

site_title: Cambodia PM launches project linking Mekong river to sea via canal
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet has launched a US$1.7 billion canal project linking the Mekong River to the sea, a 180-km waterway aimed at providing a new maritime route. The project, considered "historic" by Manet, has sparked controversy and is expected to be completed at all costs.

site_title: Philippine central bank says rates can stay steady, open for cut when price pressures ease
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Eli Remolona, stated that the bank can keep policy settings unchanged but may consider a rate cut if price pressures continue to ease. Remolona cited a shift in the balance of inflation risks to the downside and anchored inflation expectations. The central bank is set to announce key economic data, including July inflation and second-quarter GDP, on August 15, which will influence its monetary policy decision. Average inflation is projected to fall within the central bank's 2-4% target in 2024 and 2025.

images.alt_text: The central bank sees inflation possibly breaching its 2 to 4 per cent goal this month due to higher power rates as well as food and fuel prices.
The timing of the BSP’s easing in relation to the Fed is being closely watched as the peso continued to trade near a record low of 59 against the US dollar

site_title: US expected to propose barring Chinese software in autonomous vehicles
summary: The Biden administration plans to propose a rule barring Chinese software in US vehicles with Level 3 automation and above, effectively banning testing on US roads of autonomous vehicles produced by Chinese companies. The proposed rule would also prohibit vehicles with Chinese-developed advanced wireless communications abilities modules from US roads. The move is aimed at addressing concerns over cybersecurity and intellectual property risks associated with Chinese technology in the automotive sector.

site_title: Australia raises terror threat level as radicalisation spreads
summary: Australia has raised its terrorism threat level for the first time since 2014 due to growing concerns over online radicalization and community unrest over the Israel-Hamas war. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese stated that the likelihood of an attack on Australian soil is now "probable" instead of "possible." This change in threat level is attributed to a rise in extreme ideologies among Australians, emphasizing the need for vigilance.

Figures from property consultant CoreLogic showed prices across the nation climbed 0.5 per cent in July, an increase on unchanged from June.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year government yield tumbles as global bonds rally
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield dropped 17 basis points to 0.785% on Monday, its lowest since April, amid a global bond rally fueled by poor US economic data and traders' expectations of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy easing. The move follows a decline in yields on Friday and a circuit breaker for Japanese government bonds. The Bank of Japan's additional rate hike and upcoming 10-year JGB auction are expected to influence the market's trajectory.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 0.6% in June, miss forecasts
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 0.6% year-over-year in June, missing forecasts of 3.8% growth. The total retail sales stood at S$3.8 billion. Excluding motor vehicles, sales fell 3.1% year-over-year, with most categories recording declines. Online sales accounted for 12.1% of total sales. Economists attributed the decline to increased outbound travel during school holidays and rising price levels compared to regional economies, but remain optimistic that sales could improve in the second half of the year.

The technology firm hopes Delta will "agree to work cooperatively to find a resolution" and is seeking compensation for the disruption. site_title: Where rich Brits, French might go to escape higher taxes
summary: Wealthy individuals from the UK and France are considering moving abroad due to higher taxes, with destinations such as Italy, Switzerland, and Belgium offering more favorable tax environments. Italy's 15-year tax exemption for foreign income and gifts, as well as Switzerland's banking privacy and stable politics, are attractive options. France's left-wing government may also raise taxes on billionaires, prompting some to explore alternative countries. The US and Singapore are also popular destinations, with the UAE and other Middle Eastern countries offering tax-free environments and favorable business conditions.

site_title: Australia looks to overhaul slot rules at Sydney Airport to boost competition
summary: Australia is introducing new rules to free up more takeoff and landing slots at Sydney Airport, aiming to boost competition at the country's busiest airport. The move comes after the recent collapse of airline Bonza and the voluntary administration of Regional Express Holdings, which has led to job cuts. The new rules will require the Sydney Airport Slot Manager to demonstrate transparency and mitigate conflicts of interest, and are expected to be finalized in legislation soon. The goal is to reduce the dominance of Qantas and Virgin, which control about 90% of the airline market.

The move aims to curb alcohol consumption, with India's consumption expected to rise to nearly seven liters per person by 2030.

site_title: Neuralink implanted second trial patient with brain chip, Elon Musk says
summary: Neuralink, a startup led by Elon Musk, has successfully implanted its brain chip device in a second patient, allowing them to control digital devices with their thoughts. The device, which uses 1,024 electrodes, has enabled the patient to play video games, browse the internet, and move a cursor on their laptop. The second patient, who has a spinal cord injury similar to the first, has 400 of the implant's electrodes working. Musk expects to provide the implants to eight more patients this year as part of its clinical trials, with the goal of giving paralyzed individuals independence.

site_title: Communication Services, a formerly stodgy sector, is now rivalling Tech

This sector, created by merging Tech-like giants with defensive telecoms in 2018, has seen significant growth driven by Interactive Media & Services, Entertainment, and Wireless Telecom firms, which exhibit Tech-like tendencies such as low dividends and high gross operating profit margins. site_title: Bangladesh protesters demand PM resign as death toll mounts
summary: Thousands of protesters in Bangladesh demand Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's resignation, clashing with police and pro-government supporters in the deadliest day since demonstrations began. At least 283 people have been killed since protests started in July, with Sunday's violence resulting in 77 deaths, including 14 police officers. The protests, which began over civil service job quotas, have escalated into a wider anti-government movement. The United Nations rights chief has called for an end to the violence, while a former army chief has demanded the government withdraw troops and allow protests.

Policymakers agreed to closely monitor inflation data and consider raising interest rates to prevent future inflation overshoots, citing the growing willingness of companies to pass on rising costs to consumers.

site_title: Goldman economists lift ‘limited’ US recession risk to 25%
summary: Goldman Sachs economists have increased the US recession risk to 25% from 15%, but remain skeptical about a rapid deterioration in the labor market. They attribute this to solid job openings and no obvious shock to the economy. Despite a rise in unemployment to nearly three-year highs, the economists believe the economy looks "fine overall" and the Federal Reserve has room to cut interest rates quickly if needed. They forecast the Fed will reduce interest rates by 25 basis points in September, November, and December.

site_title: Britain to hold international investment summit on Oct 14
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer plans to hold an international investment summit on October 14 to catalyze investment in the UK, aiming to raise economic growth to 2.5% per year. Up to 300 industry leaders will attend the event, with Business Minister Jonathan Reynolds set to argue that the UK is a mature trading partner for sustained investment and growth. The summit aims to boost the UK's economy, which has shrunk for the second month, and bring investment to the country, similar to its pre-financial crisis average.

site_title: Thailand moves closer to legalising casinos to prop up tourism
summary: Thailand is moving forward with plans to legalize casinos, aiming to boost tourism and attract foreign investment. Draft rules allow for 30-year licenses, with options for renewal, and will be housed in large entertainment complexes with hotels and other amenities. The move is part of Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's efforts to attract foreign investment and collect taxes. Thailand joins the UAE and Japan in the global casino industry, which generated $263 billion in revenue last year, and is seen as a potential hedge against uncertain prospects in Macau.

summary: NTUC Enterprise and Income Insurance have defended their proposed sale of Income Insurance to Allianz, citing the prioritization of minority shareholders' rights. The joint statement claims that cooperative shares are purchased and redeemed at par value, and that minority shareholders will reap annualized returns of 10-39% over their holding period. The entities also argue that the sale will not erode the social mission of NTUC Income, as Allianz will provide more than just capital, but also a strategic growth partner, and that the insurer can continue its social mission with strengthened financial sustainability.

site_title: China rolls out action plan on boosting domestic consumption
summary: China's government has unveiled an action plan to boost domestic consumption, citing weak demand as a major factor in its economic growth slowdown. The 20-step plan includes expanding basic consumption in areas such as catering and elder care, fostering new types of spending, and supporting electronic sports and live streaming e-commerce. Authorities also aim to cultivate unmanned retail stores and self-pickup lockers. The move aims to address the country's economic challenges and stimulate growth.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government’s stimulus measures have so far failed to boost consumption, and the overleveraged property market has made consumers less likely to spend.
The expansion in China's manufacturing output was the slowest in nine months and was attributed to the first fall in new orders in a year.
At the end of 2023, China's state figures showed that 66.16 per cent of the resident population lived in urban areas.

site_title: Crypto is booming again in New York as sentiment turns positive
summary: Cryptocurrency companies are flocking to New York, with over 130 firms now having offices in the city, as sentiment towards the sector turns positive. This resurgence is partly due to the US Securities and Exchange Commission's setbacks and the approval of Bitcoin exchange-traded funds. The upcoming presidential election is also seen as a potential boost to the industry, with some crypto leaders donating to Donald Trump. New York state's strict regulations, such as the BitLicense program, are also being seen as a draw for companies looking to establish a presence in the city.

images.alt_text: This will be at least the second recent meeting between the crypto industry and officials in the White House.
Morgan Stanley’s decision may pave the way for other banks that have been reticent to offer digital assets to consider tapping into the sector.
Bitcoin has climbed more than 45 per cent this year, aided by inflows into US exchange-traded funds for the token.
At a crypto event on Saturday (Jul 27), Republican presidential nominee Trump vowed to fire top securities regulator Gary Gensler in favour of a more pro-crypto watchdog.

site_title: Snickers maker Mars explores acquisition of Kellanova: sources
summary: Mars, the manufacturer of Snickers and M&M's, is exploring a potential acquisition of Kellanova, maker of Cheez-It and Pringles, according to sources. A deal would be one of the largest in the packaged food sector, valued at around $27 billion, and could test regulatory approval due to market concentration. Kellanova's separation from WK Kellogg last year has led to a 20% increase in its shares, making it a potential target for acquisition. The deal's certainty is uncertain, with other suitors potentially approaching Kellanova.

images.alt_text: Legacy food companies have been trying to lure shoppers with different meal occasions, along with more snacks.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raises oil prices to Asia in sign of faith in demand
summary: Saudi Arabia raised the price of its flagship crude to Asia for the first time in three months, increasing the September official selling price of Arab Light crude by 20 US cents to $2 a barrel above the regional Oman-Dubai benchmark. The move comes as oil demand appears healthy in Asia, with refineries returning from maintenance and China's consumption peaking in September and October. However, concerns remain over a possible supply surplus if Opec+ countries proceed with their plan to begin unwinding voluntary cuts, which could put pressure on benchmark oil prices.

images.alt_text: Logo of of the Saudi BinLaden Group on their headquarters in Jeddah 20 September 2001.      AFP PHOTO/Mahmoud MAHMOUD (Photo by MAHMOUD MAHMOUD / AFP)
Saudi’s economic output shrank 0.4 per cent on an annual basis during the April-to-June period.

site_title: China’s weakening vitals
summary: China's slowing economy is affecting Singapore-listed stocks, with property developers and insurers reporting lower profits. The country's GDP growth is expected to fall to 4.2% in the second half, amid multiple headwinds in the property sector. However, Asean economies, particularly those in the region, are benefiting from China's restructuring, with Vietnam, Malaysia, and Indonesia seeing increased foreign direct investment. The FTSE Asean 40 Index is up 2.4% this year, while investment strategists advise investors to focus on low-cost consumer staples and gaming companies in China.

images.alt_text: Once upon a time, slower growth in China would have worried economists, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Well Chip’s successful Bursa Malaysia debut is particularly noteworthy because its parent company is Singapore-listed pawnshop operator ValueMax Group, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Whether Donald Trump or Joe Biden becomes the next president of the United States, the semiconductor sector is going to be under increased scrutiny, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
The Astrea series of bonds pay attractive coupons, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
GIC is not a pension fund, but the ultimate source of some of the money it manages is the pool of savings in the Central Provident Fund, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
More than 80 per cent of the world’s goods travel by sea, according to an article by the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Director of the Commerce Bureau at China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park under fraud probe
summary: Zhu Huan, 44, director of the Commerce Bureau at the China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park, has been suspended amid an investigation into alleged procurement fraud. Whistleblower Ma Xiangyu accused Zhu of manipulating government procurement rules to benefit certain bidders, with the investigation confirming collusion in five projects worth 8.47 million yuan (S$1.56 million). The investigation is ongoing, with authorities promising to hold those responsible accountable. Zhu has denied any wrongdoing, but the case has raised concerns about corruption in China's industrial development zones.

images.alt_text: The Four Seasons Hotel Osaka; HPL’s 15th Four Seasons property, is located inside the One Dojima building in Osaka’s popular Dojima neighbourhood, which is near the city’s business district.

site_title: RBA set for hawkish hold, trailing global peers in easing cycle
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to maintain its cash rate at 4.35% for a sixth consecutive meeting, defying global peers who have begun easing monetary policies. Despite core inflation cooling, it remains elevated, and economists predict the RBA will continue to hike rates before agreeing to stand pat. Governor Michele Bullock is unlikely to follow the Federal Reserve's lead in easing, instead maintaining a hawkish stance to ensure inflation returns to the 2-3% target.

images.alt_text: The price report comes on the heels of higher-than-forecast jobs growth and strong retail sales, while measures of business surveys remain resilient.
Retail sales can be an important consideration in policy decisions given consumption accounts for more than half of gross domestic product.

Homes stand in Subiaco, a suburb of Perth, Australia, on Monday, Jan. 31, 2011. Property prices in Perth posted the biggest declines in Australia as an oversupply of homes and a "two-speed economy" take their toll on the capital of the nation's biggest mining state. Photographer: Ron D'Raine/Bloomberg

site_title: Portability for Integrated Shield plans likely to raise premiums
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield (IP) plans face challenges with portability, with insurers under pressure to maintain a wide risk pool. A government-backed "risk equalization" mechanism may be needed to encourage insurers to take on those with claims history and chronic conditions. The Singapore Actuarial Society suggests three possible scenarios for IP portability: a "communal" approach, a "grandfathering" approach, and portability for IP base plans only. Each scenario has its pros and cons, with potential implications for premium rises and insurer profitability.

images.alt_text: The average cost of medical care in Singapore is expected to rise by close to 10.7 per cent in 2024, up from 10.3 per cent in 2023, data from advisory and solutions company WTW showed.
An Integrated Shield Plan is optional health coverage provided by private insurance companies, typically to cover stays in A or B1-type wards in public hospitals or private hospitals.

site_title: China’s weakening vitals
summary: China's weakening economy is affecting Singapore-listed stocks, particularly those with exposure to the Chinese market. The slumping property market and weak stock market are hitting household wealth, with 70% of assets tied up in property. China's GDP growth is forecast to fall to 4.2% in the second half, from 5% in the first half. In contrast, Asean economies, such as Malaysia, Vietnam, and Indonesia, are expected to outpace China's growth. The FTSE Asean 40 Index is up 2.4% this year, while the FTSE China A50 is still behind the MSCI World. Insurer Great Eastern (GE) reported a 45% increase in profit and declared an interim dividend of S$0.45 per share.

images.alt_text: Once upon a time, slower growth in China would have worried economists, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Well Chip’s successful Bursa Malaysia debut is particularly noteworthy because its parent company is Singapore-listed pawnshop operator ValueMax Group, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Whether Donald Trump or Joe Biden becomes the next president of the United States, the semiconductor sector is going to be under increased scrutiny, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for August 2, 2024, reveals a mixed week for the tanker and dry bulk market. The VLCC market fell away, losing recent gains, while the Capesize market struggled to gain momentum despite decent volumes. The Panamax market saw a compelling week, with North trans-Atlantic runs providing numerous points of discussion. Ultramax/Supramax vessels experienced uneventful weeks, with the Suezmax market also weakening. In the LNG market, the Pacific market pulled away from the Atlantic, while the LPG market saw a slow week with downward trends.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Jul 26, 2024)

site_title: Hyundai launches giving back programme in Singapore
summary: Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Center Singapore (HMGICS) has launched its corporate social responsibility (CSR) programme, "Uplifting Youth and Communities", aiming to give back to local youth and communities in a sustainable manner. Two memorandums of understanding were signed with President's Challenge and Food Bank Singapore. The CSR initiative includes a Smart Farm where robots are used to produce 30kg of vegetables daily, and educational learning journeys for schools and students with intellectual disabilities. The programme supports Singapore's aim of sustainably producing 30% of the country's nutritional needs by 2030.

images.alt_text: At the launch of Ressec at SIM on Tuesday were Jonathan Eu (second from left), Euleen Goh (second from right), SIM chairman Richard Eu (far left) and SIM chief executive Seah Chin Siong (far right).

site_title: In Aspen, a new art fair follows the money
summary: Aspen, Colorado, hosts a new art fair, despite a global slump in the art market. The fair, which took place at the Hotel Jerome, attracted visitors and exhibitors, with many galleries reporting multiple sales. The event's success can be attributed to Aspen's unique market, where wealthy individuals and collectors are willing to spend on art, even during economic downturns. The fair's director, Rebecca Hoffman, has built her business model on creating a fair with wide, lasting appeal, and exhibitors paid high booth rentals to participate. The event's focus on unique, immersive experiences and the hotel's luxurious setting also contributed to its success.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley’s decision may pave the way for other banks that have been reticent to offer digital assets to consider tapping into the sector.

site_title: Tropical storm Debby expected to become hurricane as it heads to Florida’s Gulf Coast
summary: Tropical Storm Debby is expected to strengthen into a hurricane as it heads to Florida's Gulf Coast, with life-threatening ocean surges and potentially historic rainfall forecast. The US National Hurricane Center warned of catastrophic flooding in Georgia and South Carolina, with 25-50 cm of rainfall and storm surges up to 3 meters. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has ordered 3,000 National Guard troops and mandatory evacuations, while the governors of Georgia and South Carolina have declared states of emergency. The storm is expected to bring heavy rain and damage as it moves slowly across northern Florida and southern Georgia.

images.alt_text: The Shore Acres neighborhood begins to flood from high tide in the Tampa Bay while Tropical Storm Debby approaches the gulf coast, in St. Petersburg, Florida, U.S., August 4, 2024. REUTERS/Octavio Jones
Short term costs may go up, but in the long run this is the more resilient strategy, said SM Teo.

A man sits at a convenience store where the windows are all taped as Typhoon Gaemi approaches, Yilan, Taiwan, July 24, 2024. Taiwan closed schools, suspended the stock market and declared a typhoon holiday on July 24 as Gaemi barrelled towards the island, bringing torrential rains and whipping winds to its north-east.
People walk along a flooded street in Manila amid heavy rains brought by Typhoon Gaemi, July 24, 2024.

site_title: Travellers rush to leave Lebanon amid spiking tensions, cancelled flights
summary: Travellers in Lebanon are rushing to leave amid spiking tensions and cancelled flights due to the escalating conflict between Israel and Hezbollah. Several airlines, including Lufthansa and Air France, have delayed or suspended flights to Lebanon, and countries have issued urgent calls for foreign nationals to leave. The tensions have sparked fears of an all-out war, with Hezbollah vowing to seek revenge for the killing of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hezbollah's military chief Fuad Shukr. Embassies have repeatedly urged their citizens to leave, while many Lebanese who work or study abroad are struggling to find flights to leave the country.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$2.71, or 3.41 per cent, to US$76.81 a barrel.

EPA-EFE/ALI ALI

Hamas political chief Ismail Haniyeh (pictured) and one of his bodyguards were killed in Tehran, Iran while in the country to attend the inauguration of Iran's newly elected president Masoud Pezeshkian, said the Islamic Republic News Agency.
Several airlines, including Lufthansa and Turkish Airlines, have cancelled flights to Beirut. Beirut-Rafic Hariri International Airport is Lebanon’s only airport.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust chairman increases interest at S$1.31 per unit
summary: Singapore stocks saw a net institutional outflow of S$115 million over the five trading sessions to Aug 1, with 11 companies conducting buybacks totaling S$6.4 million. Singapore Airlines led the buyback with 500,000 shares. Meanwhile, net institutional inflow was led by Singtel, UOB, OCBC, and ST Engineering. Director interests and substantial shareholdings were filed for 40 primary-listed stocks, with Mapletree Logistics Trust chairman Lee Chong Kwee acquiring 134,000 units at S$1.31 per unit.

site_title: Nvidia’s new AI chip delayed due to design flaws: report
summary: Nvidia's new AI chips are expected to be delayed by three months or more due to design flaws, according to reports. The delay affects the Blackwell series and may impact customers such as Meta Platforms, Google, and Microsoft. Shipments are not expected until the first quarter of 2025, according to The Information. Nvidia has confirmed a delay but declined to comment on the extent of the delay. The company stated that production is on track to ramp later this year.

site_title: South-east Asia’s ESG bond proceeds rise for third straight quarter
summary: South-east Asia's ESG bond proceeds rose for the third consecutive quarter, increasing 52.8% to US$5.6 billion in Q2 2024, outperforming the global market which declined 17.3% to US$184.9 billion. ESG loans in the region rose marginally, increasing 3.9% to US$5.9 billion.

images.alt_text: The Senoko Waste-to- Energy Plant is one of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Singapore-located assets.
Singapore property developers are building up fund platforms adjacent to their primary development business - though not in the traditional way that private equity firms do.
CapitaLand Investment had raised more than S$16.1 billion in sustainable finance since 2018 as at end-2023.
The loan facility has a tenure of five years.

The steel industry in China accounts for 5% of GDP and 15% of emissions. Transition bonds could be a way for the country to raise funds to decarbonise the industry.

Asia is warming faster than the global average and is most vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. It is in Asia's long-term interest to invest in a transition that contributes to sustainable growth.

site_title: Bromat’s controlling shareholder faces winding-up proceeding by creditor
summary: Bromat Holdings' controlling shareholder, Gazelle Ventures, is facing a winding-up proceeding by a creditor amid a legal dispute. The creditor initiated the proceeding on August 2, but Bromat's board claims it will not have a material impact on its business. Gazelle Ventures issued S$4.5 million worth of convertible redeemable preference shares to Bromat in March, convertible into 145 million shares, with no provisions for early repayment or termination.

site_title: UK grapples with worst riots in 13 years
summary: The UK is experiencing its worst rioting in 13 years, with disturbances linked to child murders and far-right agitators spreading across multiple towns and cities. The unrest, which began after misinformation about a mass stabbing, has posed a major test for Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who was elected just a month ago. The government has assured the police have "all the resources they need" to deal with the disorder, but fears of further demonstrations on Sunday have raised concerns that the unrest could spread further.

images.alt_text: HSBC, based in London, has clamped down on everything from business travel to new hiring, with even senior bankers being challenged over relatively small expenses.

site_title: Should ThaiBev’s minority shareholders support the proposed FPL-F&N share swap?
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) has proposed a share swap involving its minority interest in Frasers Property (FPL) and its stake in Fraser and Neave (F&N). The deal will see ThaiBev increasing its F&N stake to 69.61% and reducing its FPL stake to zero. Minority shareholders of ThaiBev may question the significant premium paid for F&N shares, which is 232% above its last closing price, while FPL shares are undervalued at 136% above its last closing price. The deal is expected to be immediately accretive to ThaiBev's earnings and will result in ThaiBev becoming a more focused beverage and food group.

images.alt_text: Range of F & N drinks, in Singapore, on Wednesday, August 28, 2013. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg
The narrow free floats of FPL and F&N mean dissident minority investors with relatively small stakes could prevent them from delisting
The share swap will be executed at an estimated ratio of 1.88 Frasers Property shares for each F&N share.
As at 1.34 pm, F&N was trading up 21.5 per cent or S$0.23 to S$1.30, with 1.7 million shares worth S$2.2 million changing hands.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s Hotel Properties opens its first Four Seasons hotel in Japan
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) has officially opened its first Four Seasons hotel in Japan, located inside the One Dojima building in Osaka's Dojima neighbourhood. This marks HPL's 15th Four Seasons property and its largest ownership in the world. The hotel features 175 guest rooms, a spa, indoor pool, and 24-hour fitness centre, and is part of the One Dojima project, a 49-storey ultra-high-rise mixed-use building. This is HPL's second hotel property to open in 2024, following the launch of The Boathouse Pulau Tioman in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s tourist arrivals have been falling since peaking in March this year, when Taylor Swift staged six concerts at the National Stadium.

site_title: MM2 Asia proposes to raise as much as S$40m via share placement; Ron Sim’s V3 Group potentially becomes top owner
summary: MM2 Asia proposes a S$40 million share placement, with an option to raise up to S$30 million. V3 Group, led by Ron Sim, plans to subscribe to at least S$15 million, potentially becoming the largest shareholder with an 18% stake. The placement shares will have the same rights as existing shares, and the company plans to use the funds to strengthen its financial position and support working capital. The corporate action is subject to shareholder approval and expected to be completed by October 31.

images.alt_text: Founded by Ron Sim (above), the group opened its first store in Singapore in 1983 and later in Hong Kong in 1986. It also expanded to Taiwan and Malaysia before officially launching the OSIM brand name in 1993 and expanding to China.

site_title: Greenback hits four-month low as weak US jobs data boosts rate cut bets
summary: The US dollar hit a four-month low on August 2 after a weaker-than-expected July jobs report, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.3% and employers adding 114,000 jobs below expectations. The Federal Reserve is now expected to cut interest rates by 50 basis points in September, with a 71% probability, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool. This move is seen as a response to the economy's slowdown, with traders pricing in a 71% chance of a rate cut in September, and 116 basis points of easing expected by year's end.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this photo illustration taken February 12, 2018. REUTERS/Jose Luis Gonzalez/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: ‘I’m still here’: Joan Chen plays thwarted immigrant mom in ‘Didi’
summary: Joan Chen, 63, stars in the coming-of-age film "Didi" as Chungsing, a Taiwanese single mom and frustrated artist in California, who struggles to connect with her 13-year-old son amidst cultural differences. Chen, who was hand-picked for her debut role by Mao Zedong's wife at 14, reflects on her own life as an immigrant and the "uncertainty of the ground you're standing on." With "Didi" earning Oscars buzz, Chen sees a late-career comeback and hopes to create more roles for Asian women in Hollywood.

images.alt_text: AMC will transfer ownership of 175 theatres, including leases, property, and associated assets and rights, to a newly established subsidiary named Muvico.

FILE PHOTO: Director Kevin Costner leaves following the screening of the film "Horizon: An American Saga - Chapter 1" Out of competition at the 77th Cannes Film Festival in Cannes, France, May 19, 2024. REUTERS/Yara Nardi/File Photo

site_title: Crypto executives to meet with White House advisers next week
summary: Crypto executives are set to meet with White House advisers next week to discuss concerns around digital assets and propose policy changes. This is the second recent meeting between the crypto industry and officials in the White House, following a roundtable in July. The meeting comes after the Republican nominee, Donald Trump, vowed to reverse the Biden administration's crackdown on the crypto industry. Executives are hopeful that a potential Harris-led White House will take a more favorable stance on crypto, but are seeking a true commitment towards engaging with the industry for a thoughtful regulatory environment.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has climbed more than 45 per cent this year, aided by inflows into US exchange-traded funds for the token.
At a crypto event on Saturday (Jul 27), Republican presidential nominee Trump vowed to fire top securities regulator Gary Gensler in favour of a more pro-crypto watchdog.
The price of Ether has dropped 4.6 per cent to around US$3,331 since the ETFs began trading on Jul 23.

site_title: Private credit sells funds for small investors as big ones balk
summary: Private credit firms are targeting individual investors with interval funds, which offer direct lending investments in amounts as low as $1,000. Interval funds are being launched by firms like KKR, Capital Group, and T Rowe Price Group, allowing registered investment advisers to easily sell and buy the funds without paperwork. This shift represents a growing trend in the $178 trillion personal wealth market, as large investors become less willing to invest due to high interest rates. Interval funds carry higher risks, but offer more investment flexibility and a broader distribution channel.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs’ data from a survey of more than 300 investors like family offices, sovereign wealth funds and pension schemes showed that just 15 per cent were still willing to pay for so-called pass-through fees, where the hedge fund passes on its costs.

site_title: Dasin EGM requisitionists will hold meeting themselves after trustee-manager allegedly breaches timelines
summary: A group of Dasin Retail Trust requisitionists are holding their own meeting to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) within the 21-day timeframe, as the trustee-manager allegedly breached the Business Trusts Act by not convening the meeting on time. The cost of the EGM will be claimed from the trustee-manager Dasin Retail Trust Management. The requisitionists aim to pass two resolutions, including amendments to the trust deed to prohibit the trustee-manager from appointing or removing directors without prior approval and to allow unitholders to remove the trustee-manager.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. The trustee-manager said it has received a letter of demand from GSUM-Titanland Capital for an alleged outstanding sum of S$214,000.
Zhang also demands the trio's resignation as members of the board.
Ocean Metro Mall was one of the properties financed by the credit facilities that has repossessed Dasin Retail Trust's director's properties.

site_title: Vietnam’s Communist Party names To Lam as top leader
summary: Vietnam's Communist Party named President To Lam as the country's top leader after the death of General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong two weeks ago. To Lam, a former public security minister, was elected General Secretary, succeeding Trong, who held the most powerful position in decades. The party stated that To Lam's promotion resulted from an "urgent need to ensure the leadership of the party." It remains unclear if To Lam will continue to serve as president simultaneously or relinquish that role.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees work at a shoe factory for export in Hanoi, Vietnam December 29, 2020. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Vietnamese exporters have increased their market share significantly in the US in sectors like footwear, textiles and leather over the past decade.
Robust exports drove Vietnam’s growth in the first half of 2024, with the gross domestic product advancing 6.42 per cent from a year ago.
The delegation of the Central Executive Committee of the Communist Party of Vietnam paying tribute to late Vietnamese General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong at the National Funeral Home in Hanoi.

site_title: Berkshire halves Apple stake, boosts cash to US$277 billion as it gets ‘defensive’
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has sold nearly half of its Apple stake, worth about $84.2 billion, as part of a defensive strategy amid concerns over the US economy and stock market valuations. The conglomerate's cash reserves have surged to $277 billion, with Buffett reportedly wary of attractive investment opportunities. Berkshire's second-quarter operating profit rose 15% to a record $11.6 billion, but revenue increased only 1%. Buffett has long urged shareholders to ignore quarterly gains and losses, but the company's cautious approach suggests growing unease about market conditions.

images.alt_text: This will be at least the second recent meeting between the crypto industry and officials in the White House.

site_title: Five things elite athletes can teach us about staying motivated and managing stress at work
summary: Elite athletes can teach non-athletes valuable lessons about staying motivated and managing stress at work. Key takeaways include the importance of routine and habits, goal-setting, finding motivation through caring about one's work, stress management through a growth mindset, autonomy, and resilience. Elite athletes' ability to maintain motivation and discipline through repetition and visualization can be applied to daily work lives. By adopting similar strategies, such as setting clear goals, finding autonomy, and managing stress, individuals can improve their performance and overall well-being.

images.alt_text: More companies are recognising that catering to all employees’ needs is, in fact, good for everyone.

site_title: Nasdaq expected to see turbulent times
summary: The US market experienced stellar growth in the first half of 2024, with the Nasdaq Composite rising 18.1%, but saw significant swings in July. Expected September rate cuts are likely driving recent market movements, including profit-taking from tech counters and a rotation into cyclical sectors. Recession fears, individual company earnings reports, and potential trade tensions with US trading partners due to tariffs also contribute to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq is still up 11.8 per cent year-to-date.

site_title: Market plunge has investors bracing for turbulent end to 2024
summary: US stocks are experiencing a significant plunge, with the Nasdaq 100 entering correction territory, amid growing concerns over the overall health of the US economy. The Fed faces criticism for waiting too long to cut interest rates, while weak earnings batter technology companies that drove the rally. Geopolitical tension and a chaotic US election, potentially between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, add to investor anxiety. Experts predict a mixed market, with small caps potentially benefiting from a Republican victory and bond yields rising under a Republican administration, but a Democratic victory could lead to lower yields and a more positive reaction for equities.

images.alt_text: Access to private markets via exchange-traded funds has the potential to open the closed-off world to investors of all stripes. It could also channel fresh cash into an asset class struggling to keep the boom alive after years of breakneck expansion.

site_title: Bill Ackman’s Pershing lost 4.7% in July, erasing most of 2024 gains
summary: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Holdings lost 4.7% in July, erasing most of its 2024 gains, as shares of Universal Music Group, a significant stakeholder, tumbled 24% after disappointing earnings. This decline follows Ackman's road show to promote his US-traded closed-end fund, which was initially estimated to raise $25 billion but was reduced to $2 billion due to lackluster demand. The fund now has a year-to-date gain of 0.7%.

site_title: South-east Asia’s private equity landscape demands more of managers
summary: South-east Asia's private equity landscape faces challenges due to the region's high-growth economies and limited PE investment. The region's PE and venture capital investment value is only 0.2% of GDP, compared to 1% in Japan and South Korea, and 0.7% in North America. Specialist managers with the ability to close deals and build market leaders are needed to capitalize on the region's growth. Local managers have an advantage due to their knowledge of the market, language, and culture, and are better equipped to navigate the region's complex business landscape.

images.alt_text: Within South-east Asia, the largest deal was the sale of an 86 per cent stake in health and wellness brand Eu Yan Sang for S$687 million.
MMA Offshore, a vessel operator that was listed on ASX, will now be part of Cyan Renewables, a company founded and majority-owned by Seraya.
Singapore-headquartered private equity firm Seraya Partners is focused on the hotspots of data centres and renewable energy but has set its sights on markets where it believes it will have an edge.
Arete Industrial Park at Milovice, Czech Republic. Arete differentiates itself with its specialised knowledge of Europe's real estate market.
Any fund that hopes to succeed in South-east Asia will require a focused approach to sourcing for deals.

site_title: Silicon Valley Bank’s former owner gains approval to end bankruptcy
summary: Silicon Valley Bank's former owner, SVB Financial Group, received approval to end its bankruptcy and turn over assets to creditors. The company will create a trust to pursue litigation against the FDIC over $1.9 billion seized funds. The outcome of the litigation will determine how much of the $3.3 billion owed to senior bondholders will be paid, with potential payouts ranging from 41% to 96%. The battle over seized funds will play out in a California federal court.

images.alt_text: Silicon Valley Bank’s inability to access the Federal Reserve's discount window in March of last year in the face of massive and rapid withdrawals by its uninsured depositors contributed to the bank’s sudden collapse.
The FDIC’s annual report last month reported that it sold US$10.5 billion of the securities in January to trusts tied to the Federal Financing Bank, an arm of the US Treasury.
The bank’s collapse almost a year ago represented the biggest US bank failure in more than a decade and marked the start of a crisis in the sector.

site_title: Diamonds, meatballs and motors: How Olympians can win more than medals
summary: Olympic nations and territories offer various incentives to their athletes for winning gold, silver, or bronze medals, ranging from financial rewards to unique gifts. Some countries provide exemptions from military service, cars, and luxury items, while others offer housing, food, and travel perks. Notable examples include South Korea's exemption from military service, Poland's cash prize and apartment, and Hong Kong's lifetime travel tickets to the MTR subway system. These incentives aim to motivate athletes to compete and showcase their talents on the global stage.

images.alt_text:

Gold medalist Man Wai Vivian Kong of Hong Kong celebrates with her medal in the Women's Epee Fencing. REUTERS/Maye-E Wong

site_title: Investors take long-term view as rate hike whipsaws Japan
summary: The Bank of Japan raised interest rates to 0.25% last week, causing market volatility and a 1.5% jump in the Topix index, only to plunge on Thursday and Friday. Despite this, investors remain optimistic about Japan's long-term outlook, citing strong corporate pricing power and higher pay for workers, which will spur economic growth. Financial stocks suffered the biggest whiplash, with some declining by 11-19%. However, analysts believe the long-term fundamentals remain fair, and investors should prioritize the immediate risk, with some considering a buying opportunity for companies with strong earning potential.

images.alt_text: A weak yen has become a source of concern for Japanese policymakers as it has dampened consumption by inflating the cost of importing fuel, food and raw material.

site_title: Four ways employers let down their employees
summary: Employers can inadvertently lead to employee disengagement through various management practices. Four common issues include overloading high-performing employees with excessive overtime, adopting an accusatory mindset when errors occur, unfair compensation, and flawed key performance indicator (KPI) reward systems. By addressing these concerns, leaders can foster a more motivated and committed workforce, recognizing the value of employees and providing adequate support, resources, and rewards to maintain motivation and prevent burnout.

images.alt_text: More companies are recognising that catering to all employees’ needs is, in fact, good for everyone.
Over 20 per cent of the workforce consists of millennials who are parents to young children. Accommodations for parental leave give these employees more time to care for children.
Panellists at the annual SkillsFuture Forum discussed how employers can help workers with their career development.

site_title: BlackRock leads big firms racing to put private assets into ETFs
summary: Major money managers, including BlackRock and Invesco, are racing to develop exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that offer access to private markets, a move that could channel fresh cash into the struggling asset class. Despite technical and regulatory hurdles, firms like Apollo Global Management and Goldman Sachs Asset Management are exploring private-asset ETFs, which could help investors tap into the $13 trillion private markets. The challenge lies in addressing liquidity mismatches between private investments and ETFs, with solutions including synthetic exposure and liquid alternative ETFs. The move aims to open up private markets to investors of all stripes, potentially alleviating pressure on buyout firms and keeping the boom alive.

site_title: Byju’s lenders seek to block payment to India cricket board
summary: US lenders of Byju's, owed $1.2 billion, are seeking to block the payment of $19 million to India's cricket board, citing the funds should be used to pay US courts. The payment is made by suspended director Riju Ravindran, brother of Byju's founder. Lawyers for the lenders claim Ravindran has improperly avoided accountability from US courts by using his residence abroad. The move comes as Byju's faces an insolvency case in India.
