site_title: Freeport LNG nears end of expansion that will increase output
summary: Freeport LNG, the US's second-largest liquefied natural gas processing plant, is nearing completion of an expansion project that will increase its output beyond 15.3 million metric tonnes per annum. The company's debottlenecking project, which began after a hurricane damaged the plant, is expected to boost capacity to 16.5 million metric tonnes per annum. Feedgas flows have reached a record 2.3 billion cubic feet per day, and the plant has restarted all three LNG liquefaction trains. The expansion is set to further solidify Freeport's position as a major US LNG exporter.

images.alt_text: The restart has been closely watched as demand for the fuel is expected to ramp up in Europe and Asia, and the Texas facility is a significant draw on domestic gas supplies.
This year, two new LNG projects in the US are due to start production, a joint venture between ExxonMobil and QatarEnergy.

site_title: Alphabet’s fund CapitalG cut stake in CrowdStrike before July global outage
summary: Alphabet's fund CapitalG cut its stake in cybersecurity company CrowdStrike to 427,895 shares before a July global outage caused by a software update. The outage affected sectors globally and resulted in a 35% loss in CrowdStrike shares. The company was sued by shareholders over misleading assurances about its software, which caused the outage. CrowdStrike blames a defect in a content update for the incident, while investors and regulators question the company's safety and security strategy.

images.alt_text: Delta has cancelled more than 6,000 flights so far, leaving hundreds of thousands of travellers stranded.

site_title: More than 50 US lawmakers, 21 states back DOJ in TikTok lawsuit
summary: The US Justice Department has gained support from 21 states and over 50 lawmakers in its lawsuit against TikTok, with the goal of requiring China-based ByteDance to sell TikTok's US assets by January 19 or face a ban. The lawmakers claim TikTok poses a national security threat to US consumers, while TikTok argues the ban would violate the First Amendment rights of its 170 million US users. The US Court of Appeals will hear oral arguments on September 16, potentially impacting the app's fate in the final weeks of the 2024 presidential election.

images.alt_text: The US alleges that for years millions of American children under 13 have been using TikTok and the site “has been collecting and retaining children’s personal information”.

site_title: Singaporean David Yong, from Netflix’s Super Rich in Korea, charged with falsification of accounts
summary: Singaporean businessman David Yong, 37, has been charged with falsification of accounts in relation to a promissory note arrangement involving Evergreen Group Holdings. Yong was arrested on Aug 1 and charged on Aug 3. He is accused of abetting Jolene Low Mong Han in falsifying papers belonging to Evergreen GH. The charges stem from a promissory note arrangement involving Evergreen Group Holdings.

site_title: JPMorgan, Citi see Fed dealing two supersized cuts this year
summary: US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts are expected to accelerate, with Wall Street banks calling for two supersized cuts this year. Economists at JPMorgan and Citigroup predict a half-point rate cut in September, followed by quarter-point reductions at every subsequent meeting until mid-2025. The jobs report showing a rise in the unemployment rate to 4.3% has led to a further rally in the Treasury market, with traders seeing a more-than-70% chance of a half-point move in September.

site_title: Covid surge limits CVS’s at-home test supply in some cities
summary: CVS Health pharmacies in cities such as Houston, Austin, and Reno, Nevada, are selling out of at-home Covid tests due to a summer surge in infections, with 91% of its stores still having at least one brand of test in stock. Covid viral activity has surpassed last summer's peak in the US South, West, and Midwest, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Demand for at-home Covid tests has increased sharply in recent months, with Walgreens and independent pharmacies in New York City reporting high sales.

site_title: Influencers’ go-to digital retailer finds actual stores are key
summary: Revolve Group, a popular fashion retailer, is shifting its focus from online sales to brick-and-mortar stores amid changing consumer trends. The company, which has seen its shares tumble due to declining sales, is launching its first permanent physical location in Aspen, Colorado, after a successful limited-time pop-up store. Revolve aims to expand to luxury destinations and flagship locations in wealthy urban areas, but its strategy differs from Aritzia, which has seen success with both online and offline sales. Analysts expect Revolve's stock to recover due to its solid cash position and growth potential, with some predicting it will become a major brick-and-mortar retailer in the next 10-20 years.

site_title: JPMorgan considers suing consumer watchdog over Zelle
summary: JPMorgan Chase is considering a lawsuit against the US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) over the agency's inquiries into the Zelle payment app. The bank was given options by the CFPB to pursue a settlement or face an enforcement action. The proliferation of fraud and scams on Zelle has drawn attention from lawmakers and regulators concerned about consumer protection. JPMorgan, along with other major banks, owns the Zelle network, which has grown since its launch in 2017.

site_title: Will AI upend white-collar work? Consider the Hollywood editor
summary: Hollywood picture editors face a growing challenge as artificial intelligence (AI) increasingly automates their work. Thomas R. Moore, a veteran editor, fears that AI will "hollow out" the job, which typically pays $125,000 to $200,000 a year. With the advent of AI, editors can work on multiple shows in a year, but AI may reduce the need for human editors, threatening their livelihoods. Despite actors and writers securing strict limits on AI in last year's contract negotiations, other workers, including picture editors, face a similar challenge.

site_title: SIM launches social-entrepreneur programme
summary: The Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) has launched the Ressec, a social-entrepreneurship centre, to equip students with practical skills to set up and run social enterprises. The Dr Richard K M Eu-SIM Social Entrepreneurship Centre will offer postgraduate and professional development courses, including a six-month Specialist Diploma in Social Entrepreneurship programme. This programme aims to equip students with the skills needed to create positive social impact through innovative and sustainable social enterprises.

site_title: Elon Musk makes final pitch to judge who blocked record pay deal
summary: Elon Musk made his final pitch to Delaware Chancery Court judge Kathaleen St J McCormick to overturn her ruling blocking the record $56 billion Tesla pay package. Musk's lawyers argued the June proxy vote by Tesla investors addressed concerns raised by the judge, while Tesla's board lawyer said the vote was irrelevant and protected shareholders' interests. The judge, however, expressed skepticism about the vote's legitimacy, and her decision is expected to be made in a timely fashion, potentially allowing Musk to appeal the decision to the Delaware Supreme Court.

site_title: Data provider Dun & Bradstreet explores sale: sources
summary: Dun & Bradstreet, a US data and analytics provider since 1841, is exploring a potential sale, according to sources. The company, valued at over $9 billion including debt, is working with Bank of America to evaluate takeover interest from private equity firms. Cannae Holdings, its largest shareholder with 15.6% stake, could roll its stake as part of any sale, potentially lowering the purchase price. A deal could be facilitated by this, but no further details have been confirmed.

site_title: Google pulls AI ad that irked some Olympics viewers
summary: Google has pulled an ad for its Gemini AI tool after it sparked backlash from Olympics viewers, who criticized the ad for promoting reliance on AI over human creativity. The ad featured a parent coaxing their child to write a fan letter to an athlete using Gemini AI. The ad was deemed insensitive and dystopian, with some questioning whether AI is replacing human expression. Google has decided to phase out the ad from its Olympics rotation following the negative feedback.

site_title: China plans to adopt volume-based emissions reduction targets
summary: China plans to adopt a volume-based emissions reduction target, shifting from relative to economic growth, to meet its climate goals. As the world's largest emitter, China aims to peak carbon emissions by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The new approach will help align domestic action with international commitments, and experts expect China to submit an absolute emission reduction target by 2035. This move comes as China expands its renewable energy capacity, potentially leading to emissions peaking in 2023.

images.alt_text: Carbon budgets will be created by China’s provinces and municipalities, and the budgeting system will be tested before the end of 2025.

site_title: ‘Blue Zones’ may hold the key to future travel, lifestyle and longevity
summary: The concept of "Blue Zones" has gained attention for its potential to promote stress-free harmony and longevity. Identified areas with high numbers of centenarians, these regions share nine lifestyle practices, including defined purpose, regular physical activity, and social connections. By embracing these habits, travelers can experience true luxury and wellness. As destinations become increasingly crowded, some are adopting measures to preserve heritage and limit tourism, highlighting the need for sustainable and responsible travel. Experts recommend exploring Blue Zones and adopting slow travel practices to promote a healthier and more mindful approach to travel.

images.alt_text: The town of Ave Maria, Fla., was “certified” last year as a blue zone, a designation for a community that meets healthy lifestyle criteria.
More than longevity and health, the focus needs also to shift to one of living and ageing well. The emphasis should not just be on living a long life, but a full one.

site_title: Google hires top talent from startup Character.AI, signs licensing deal
summary: Google has signed a licensing deal with startup Character.AI, granting the search engine giant non-exclusive access to the chatbot maker's large language model technology. Character.AI co-founders Noam Shazeer and Daniel De Freitas, who left Google in 2022, will rejoin the company as part of the deal. The startup will receive additional funding and Dominic Perella will become interim CEO. This deal follows similar agreements between Microsoft, Amazon, and Google, raising concerns about the concentration of AI talent and technology among tech giants.

site_title: Fed officials likely to push back against half-point rate cut
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to make a large interest rate cut in September, despite a weak July jobs report that showed a slowdown in hiring and a rise in the unemployment rate. Wall Street banks and futures investors had predicted a half-point move, but many economists, including Chicago Fed president Austan Goolsbee and Richmond Fed president Thomas Barkin, pushed back against the idea of a 50-basis-point cut, citing the Fed's hawkish bias and the need to avoid signaling alarm. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has signaled that the committee is focused on employment and preventing harm to the labor market, making a significant rate cut less likely.

images.alt_text: The Fed maintained key interest rate at 5.25 per cent to 5.5 per cent, as “further progress” has been made towards its 2 per cent inflation goal.

US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference after a Federal Open Market Committee meeting at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, on July 31, 2024. The US Federal Reserve left its key lending rate unchanged again on July 31 and said it had made "some further progress" in its inflation fight. Policymakers voted unanimously to maintain the US central bank's benchmark interest rate between 5.25 percent and 5.50 percent, the Fed announced in a statement, adding it was "attentive to the risks to both sides of its dual mandate." US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference after a Federal Open Market Committee meeting at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, July 31, 2024. site_title: PBOC to step up support for economy, shifts focus to consumption
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) plans to shift its focus to boosting consumption and supporting people's livelihoods, aiming to reignite the country's flagging economy. The central bank will use multiple policy tools to maintain liquidity and balance social financing and money supply targets with economic growth and inflation expectations. It also vows to implement a prudent monetary policy, prevent and resolve financial risks in key areas like the real estate sector, and support "high-quality firms" in issuing panda bonds. The PBOC aims to keep the yuan stable and maintain a reasonable equilibrium level.

site_title: US: Dow ends 2.1% lower for the week after poor jobs data
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 2.1% lower for the week after a disappointing US jobs report, with the US economy adding 114,000 jobs last month and the jobless rate rising to 4.3%. Recession worries and interest rate cut concerns boosted the market. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the Dow finishing at 39,737.26 and the S&P 500 at 5,346.56.

site_title: Batam emerges as data centre hub, rivals Johor for investments
summary: Batam, Indonesia, is emerging as a major hub for data centre investments, rivaling Malaysia's Johor for spillover investments from Singapore. The island aims to capitalize on Singapore's five-year moratorium on data centres, with major international players from China, the US, and Japan leading the charge. Batam now hosts 10 data centres, with plans to add four more hyperscale data centres in Nongsa Digital Park, a dedicated special economic zone. The island's proximity to Singapore, low electricity prices, and tax incentives make it an attractive destination for data centre investments.

images.alt_text: Johor, Malaysia’s southern state, has become South-east Asia’s fastest-growing data centre market, boasting over 1.6 gigawatts of total supply.

site_title: US cash, China’s patents, EU’s brakes: The race for controlling AI’s future is heading to a cliff
summary: The US, China, and EU are racing for AI dominance, with differing approaches. The US invests heavily, with $67 billion in AI investments last year, while China secures AI patents at a high rate. The EU aims to regulate AI to maintain control and steer it towards ethical boundaries. However, its approach is criticized for stifling innovation and startups. The future of AI is uncertain, and a unified vision among the three powers is necessary to prevent a "perilous" outcome. The world's AI car hurtles towards an uncertain destination, with risks of a "spectacular crash" or "surveillance" glitches.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to allow advisers to offer Bitcoin ETFs to wealthy clients
summary: Morgan Stanley has given its 15,000 financial advisers permission to solicit eligible clients to purchase Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs), starting next week. Only clients with a net worth of at least $1.5 million, high-risk tolerance, and intention to invest in speculative assets can be solicited. This decision may pave the way for other banks to consider offering digital assets. Since the SEC's approval of spot Bitcoin ETFs in January, the sector has seen record-breaking inflows, with BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust and Fidelity's Fidelity Wise Origin Bitcoin Fund attracting nearly $22 billion and $11 billion in assets, respectively.

site_title: Paramount gains edge in fight over Skydance buyout files
summary: Paramount Global has won a preliminary ruling in its fight against a pension fund's demand to turn over internal files related to its $2.4 billion acquisition by Skydance Media. The Delaware Chancery Court Magistrate ruled that the pension fund has not shown a legitimate purpose for inspecting the files, citing outdated information and anonymous sources cited by the fund. The ruling is subject to review by another judge, but Paramount argues that the terms of the Skydance deal have evolved, making the fund's demand outdated.

David Zaslav, CEO of Warner Bros, expects consolidation within his industry to ramp up in the next few years, as companies look to joint ventures as their next steps.

site_title: Pentagon chief revokes plea deals with three Sep 11 suspects
summary: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin revoked plea deals with three 9/11 suspects, including Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, held at Guantanamo Bay. The deals, which likely involved guilty pleas for reduced sentences, were entered into earlier this week but were withdrawn effective immediately. The decision was met with criticism from Republican lawmakers. Mohammed is accused of masterminding the 9/11 attacks that killed nearly 3,000 people. Austin took on the responsibility of overseeing pre-trial agreements in the case, relieving the Guantanamo war court's chief of her authority.

images.alt_text: The New York Times reported that 9/11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, (pictured) and his accomplices Walid bin Attash and Mustafa al-Hawsawi had agreed to plead guilty in exchange for a life sentence instead of the death penalty.

site_title: Top UBS executive Iqbal Khan to make Hong Kong his home base
summary: UBS is relocating top executive Iqbal Khan to Hong Kong as he assumes a dual role as leader of the bank's Asia operations and co-head of wealth management globally. Khan will split his time between Hong Kong and Singapore, reflecting the cities' status as key wealth management hubs. The move highlights the significance of Asia to UBS as it seeks to focus on fast-growing markets to achieve its goal of $5 trillion in wealth assets under management. Khan's relocation comes amid a global economic slowdown and uncertainty over government policies in Greater China.

images.alt_text: Iqbal Khan and Rob Karofsky are both seen as candidates to succeed UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti when he steps down.

site_title: Oil settles at eight-month low after disappointing US job numbers
summary: Oil prices fell to an eight-month low on Friday, August 2, after disappointing US job numbers and weak Chinese economic data. Brent crude futures settled at $76.81 a barrel, down 3.41% from the previous day, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 3.66% to $73.52 a barrel. The decline in oil prices is attributed to concerns about the global economic outlook and potential supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Global benchmark Brent crude futures closed US$1.32, or 1.6 per cent, lower at US$79.52 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell US$1.60, or 2.1 per cent, to US$76.31 on Thursday.

site_title: US to continue to classify Vietnam as non-market economy country
summary: The US Commerce Department has decided to continue classifying Vietnam as a non-market economy country, a decision that will disappoint Hanoi. Vietnam has sought an upgrade from its listing, citing recent economic reforms and the country's increasingly close ties with the US as a counterbalance to China. The decision has been opposed by some US business groups, including steelmakers and shrimpers, but backed by retailers and others. The move is expected to have significant economic implications for Vietnam, including potential tariffs and trade restrictions.

images.alt_text: Robust exports drove Vietnam’s growth in the first half of 2024, with the gross domestic product advancing 6.42 per cent from a year ago.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble as global equity rout amplifies
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index plummeted 2.7% to 497.85 points, hitting a three-month low, amid a global equity rout fueled by a US jobs report showing a near-three-year high unemployment rate and a slowdown in hiring. The financial and tech sectors suffered the most, with the technology sector declining 6.1% its largest one-day drop since October 2020. Defensive stocks such as Unilever, Nestle, and AstraZeneca rose, while Switzerland's annual inflation rate held steady at 1.3%.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index finished 1.2 per cent lower on Thursday after touching a two-week high in the previous session.

site_title: The case for investing in healthcare startups
summary: Healthcare startups face significant challenges in securing funding, navigating regulatory frameworks, and conducting clinical trials, despite their potential to transform the industry. In 2024, Singapore's healthtech startups raised $409 million, with deal volume doubling from the previous year. Startups are using AI, remote monitoring, and personalized care platforms to improve patient outcomes, access, and quality of care. Investors must recognize the unique chance to transform patient outcomes while weighing traditional financial metrics, and venture capitalists play a vital role in fostering the growth of healthcare startups by providing financial support, strategic guidance, and industry connections.

site_title: US sues TikTok over ‘massive-scale’ privacy violations of kids under 13
summary: The US Justice Department filed a lawsuit against TikTok and parent company ByteDance for allegedly collecting and retaining personal information of millions of American children under 13 without parental consent. The lawsuit claims TikTok violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, which requires services aimed at children to obtain parental consent to collect personal information. The move comes as the Biden administration cracks down on the social media site, which boasts around 170 million US users.

site_title: Drama and passion: The Paris Olympics have delivered these in spades
summary: The Paris Olympics have delivered drama and passion, with elite athletes from over 200 countries competing in various sports. The football competition has seen upsets, such as Morocco's 2-1 win over Argentina, while the Australian women's team made a miraculous comeback to defeat Zambia. Team Singapore has also performed well, with badminton star Loh Kean Yew reaching the quarter-finals and swimmer Gan Ching Hwee setting a new national record in two events. The Olympics have also seen notable moments, including Canada's women's team overcoming a coaching scandal to reach the quarter-finals.

site_title: US factory orders fall more than expected in June
summary: US factory orders fell 3.3% in June, more than expected, after dropping 0.5% in May. However, business spending on equipment remained solid, as initially estimated. Non-defence capital goods orders increased 0.9% in June, while plunging 22.5% in the same period last year. The decline in factory orders was attributed to a 22.5% drop in non-defence capital goods orders, which are seen as a measure of business spending plans.

site_title: Net-zero hour for ESG investing
summary: CFA Institute emphasizes the need for climate-related disclosures to be relevant, reliable, comparable, timely, and decision-useful to investors. To achieve this, standardization of corporate disclosure requirements is crucial, with independent standard setters developing climate reporting standards that include investor representation and technical expertise. CFA Institute supports investors' freedom to make portfolio decisions according to their objectives and values, while promoting sustainability and mitigating climate change through proactive use of capital.

site_title: Meta is offering Hollywood stars millions for AI voice projects
summary: Meta is offering Hollywood stars millions of dollars for their voices to be used in artificial intelligence projects. The company is in talks with Judi Dench, Awkwafina, and Keegan-Michael Key, with the goal of developing a suite of AI tools for its Connect 2024 event. The voices will likely be used in a chatbot, potentially serving as digital assistants or friends, with users interacting with a chatbot featuring the voice of a celebrity. Meta is racing to close deals before the event in September.

site_title: Hedge fund investor appetite hit by high fees and private credit, says Goldman Sachs
summary: Global hedge fund investor appetite has declined due to high fees, with only 15% of investors willing to pay pass-through fees. Despite this, more investors plan to add hedge funds to their portfolios, with 85% saying their performance exceeded or met expectations this year. Multistrategy hedge funds have returned over 6% through June, but there's a growing dispersion between top performers and struggling funds. Net outflows from hedge funds totaled 1.1% of assets managed in the first half of the year, with systematic investing strategies seeing net inflows.

images.alt_text: Chief investment officer Liu Xuan’s fundraising success comes even as global investors gravitate towards pod shops that employ teams of traders using different hedge fund strategies, instead of cherry-picking managers themselves.

Nearly 300 hedge funds out of the more than 8,000 in China have already terminated business so far this year, data from industry body Asset Management Association of China showed,

site_title: Layoffs pile up in US, Canada as companies uncertain of economy
summary: US and Canadian companies are continuing to cut jobs in 2024 amid uncertain economic conditions and recession fears. Major tech firms such as Intel, Amazon, Alphabet, and Microsoft are laying off thousands of employees, with some companies like Unity Software and eBay cutting up to 25% and 9% of their workforces, respectively. Other industries, including retail, finance, and healthcare, are also experiencing job losses, with companies like Walmart, Nike, and Novavax cutting hundreds or thousands of positions. The job cuts are attributed to the ongoing interest rate uncertainty and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Intel Corporation logo is seen at a temporary office during the World Economic Forum 2022 (WEF) in the Alpine resort of Davos, Switzerland May 25, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: China plans new carbon emission controls as it aims for 2030 peak
summary: China plans to accelerate its carbon emissions control system to reach a peak in emissions by 2030. The country's Cabinet has announced a "dual-control" system, where energy intensity will remain the main measure, but total emissions controls will supplement it. Carbon budgets will be created by provinces and municipalities, with a testing period by the end of 2025. The system aims to decouple climate targets from economic growth, with Greenpeace welcoming the move as a step towards emission reductions after 2030.

images.alt_text: Greening the steel industry, China’s second-largest source of carbon emissions at 15 per cent, is a vital part of the country’s plan to become carbon neutral by 2060.
China has vowed to peak carbon before 2030, a key milestone on its road to zeroing out emissions by 2060.

People swim and paddle in the Liangma River in Beijing, China, June 9, 2024. Authorities in Beijing issued an orange alert for extreme heat on Tuesday, warning that the mercury could climb as high as 37 deg C in some parts of the capital.
The plan said China would “strictly” control coal consumption, “reasonably” control petroleum consumption and promote use of biofuel and sustainable aviation fuel.

site_title: AMC Entertainment swings to loss in the second-quarter hurt by weak movie lineup
summary: AMC Entertainment reported a loss in the second quarter due to a weak movie lineup, largely affected by the lingering impact of last year's dual Hollywood strikes. The company will transfer ownership of 175 theatres to a new subsidiary, Muvico, as it diversifies and relies on alternative content. This move aims to address the disruption caused by the strikes, which delayed major releases and forced movie theatre owners to rely on sports and concerts. The loss is attributed to the limited number of major theatrical releases in the quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by an AMC theatre in Burbank, California, U.S., October 12, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni//File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens sharply lower after weak jobs data
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on Friday, August 2, 2024, after weak employment numbers raised concerns about a slowdown in the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 272.6 points, or 0.68%, to 40,075.33. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the Nasdaq on track to confirm a correction. Amazon and Intel's shares dropped due to downbeat forecasts, exacerbating market worries.

site_title: Fears for US economy send investors to safe havens, fuel stock slump
summary: US economic data showed weaker-than-expected job growth, fueling fears of a recession and prompting investors to seek safe havens. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.41% and the S&P 500 lost 2.19% as investors turned to government debt and gold. Richly valued technology firms took a hit, with Intel's shares plummeting to an 11-year low. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged has raised expectations of rate cuts, with some analysts predicting a 50 basis point cut in September.

Intel said it would cut more than 15 per cent of its workforce, some 17,500 people, as the chipmaker pursues a turnaround focused on its money-losing manufacturing business.

site_title: Maersk sees global trade disruptions lasting throughout 2024
summary: Maersk, a major shipping company, has raised its full-year profit forecast to $9 billion to $11 billion due to ongoing global trade disruptions caused by the conflict in the Red Sea. The company expects these disruptions to continue until the end of 2024, affecting the world's supply lines and leading to increased freight rates. Maersk also revised its forecast for 2024 global container trade, expecting 4-6% growth, and increased its free cash flow to at least $2 billion.

site_title: Warner Bros says subscriber gains from Paris already top Tokyo
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery reported a surge in subscriber gains from the Paris Olympics, with viewership exceeding 100 million across Europe by day five, 32% higher than Tokyo. The company saw a significant increase in streaming customers on the first Saturday of the Games, with about 2.2 billion minutes streamed, six times more than Tokyo. This surpasses the entire Tokyo Games' streaming viewership. Warner Bros. paid 1.3 billion euros for Europe-wide TV rights over the four-year Olympic cycle.

site_title: Intel shares set for record 28% slump as turnaround struggle deepens
summary: Intel shares plummeted nearly 28% on Friday, marking their worst day ever, as the company suspended dividend payments and slashed 15% of its workforce to fund a costly turnaround for its chip-making business. The move is expected to result in a $35 billion loss in market value. Analysts warn that Intel's ability to catch up with rival chipmakers, particularly Taiwan's TSMC, is uncertain, with some predicting the company may not regain its manufacturing edge for years.

images.alt_text: Intel shares slumped 20 per cent in extended trade, setting it up to lose more than US$24 billion in market value after its announcement.
Intel has reduced its workforce by about 5 per cent in 2023 to 124,800 by year’s end after announcing job cuts beginning in October 2022.
The semiconductor giant has been present in Israel for fifty years, with the opening of a research centre in Haifa.
Intel has invested US$18.4 billion in the facility to date.

site_title: How teaming supercharges collaboration
summary: NASA and other organizations have successfully implemented "teaming," a collaborative approach to problem-solving that fosters effective collaboration among individuals, groups, and organizations. Teaming, unlike the agile approach, is not limited to a specific project management methodology and can be applied in traditional and non-traditional workplaces. Research shows that teaming allows people and organizations to collaborate to learn, transform the way they operate, and solve complex problems. Key factors behind the teaming effect include a unique task, aware and proactive participants, and platforms that enable collaboration. Implementing teaming requires initiation, integration, and institutionalization stages, with senior leaders articulating their belief in teaming and adjusting organizational structures to reflect the teaming philosophy.

images.alt_text: If you are not assessing and planning where to focus your efforts on building something fresh, you will not be affecting any substantive change
The productivity-enhancing effect of dance is stronger in activities involving high levels of teamwork.
More tech types are sporting Whoop wristbands, Oura rings and On running shoes as they try to embody the old Victorian adage of mens sana in corpore sano (a fit mind in a fit body).

site_title: The great Singapore wealth transfer
summary: Singapore is poised for a significant wealth transfer, with Millennials expected to become the wealthiest generation ever, surpassing Baby Boomers. A 2022 report by HSBC forecasts 700,000 millionaires in Singapore by 2030, with the actual number already estimated to be around 333,204. The transfer of wealth is expected to be substantial, with a minimum of US$118.9 billion, and will likely impact the country's workforce competitiveness, social responsibility, and financial inclusiveness. The collective wealth of the new generation will shape Singapore's socio-economic landscape, with the government facing challenges in managing the resulting wealth divide.

images.alt_text: Singapore is widely regarded as the most business-friendly city on earth, says Henley & Partners.

site_title: Tech-heavy Nasdaq in correction as equity sell-off deepens
summary: The Nasdaq Composite index fell 2.4% on Friday, extending its decline to 10% below its record high, confirming it's in correction territory. The tech-heavy index is still up 11.8% year-to-date. Concerns over tech earnings and a slowing US economy, fueled by a softer-than-expected jobs report and disappointing earnings from Amazon and Intel, drove the decline. The Nasdaq has dropped 10% from its record close of 18,647.45 points on July 10, prompting worries over the Federal Reserve's next interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq indexes tumbled more than 3 per cent for the worst day since October 2022.

site_title: Singapore’s PMI rises in July, mirroring growth in region-wide factory activity
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment improved in July, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 50.7, a 0.3-point gain from June. This marks the 11th consecutive month of expansion, indicating growth from the previous month. The electronics sector, a key sector, declined 0.2 points to 51, while most regional economies reported improvement in operating conditions, except for China and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Electronics PMI continued its upward climb in June, edging up 0.1 point to 51.2 and remaining in expansion for eight consecutive months.

site_title: Trump pushes back on debate with Harris, saying he’s up in polls
summary: Donald Trump has pushed back on a debate with Kamala Harris, saying he is leading in the polls and voters already know where he and his Democratic rival stand on issues. Harris had been pushing Trump to follow through with a debate scheduled against President Joe Biden for September 10. Trump stated, "I'm leading in the polls, and everybody knows her, everybody knows me," dismissing pressure to debate.

images.alt_text: US Vice President Kamala Harris started August with US$377 million cash on hand, the largest war chest at this point in an election cycle.

(Right) Donald Trump’s worst impulses resurfaced on Wednesday with his outlandish claim that Kamala Harris (left) - the first female and non-white vice-president - recently “became a Black person” for political convenience.

Supporters of Republican presidential nominee and former President Donald Trump pose with his masks as they wait in line to attend a campaign rally during a hot and humid day in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania., July 31, 2024.
Trump now finds himself up against Kamala Harris who is almost two decades his junior, a trailblazer who became the country’s first Black, woman and South Asian-origin vice president.

site_title: US job growth misses expectations in July; jobless rate hits 4.3%
summary: US job growth slowed in July, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 114,000 jobs, missing expectations of 175,000. The unemployment rate rose to 4.3% from 4.1% in June, heightening concerns about a labor market slowdown. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes in 2022 and 2023 are likely to blame for the slowing growth, rather than layoffs. Average hourly earnings rose 0.2% last month, with wages increasing 3.6% in the past 12 months, the smallest gain since May 2021. This data supports a September rate cut from the US central bank.

images.alt_text: Job seekers speak with prospective employers during a City of Los Angeles career fair offering to fill vacancies in more than 30 classifications of jobs on November 2, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. The US Bureau of Labour Statistics will release on November 3 the October jobs report amid expectations employment remains quite healthy. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits increased 14,000 to a seasonally adjusted 249,000 for the week ended Jul 27, the highest level since August last year.

site_title: Apple pulls commercial after Thai backlash, calls for boycott
summary: Apple has pulled a commercial from Thailand after backlash from lawmakers, influencers, and citizens over its portrayal of the country. The 10-minute film, "The Underdogs: OOO (Out Of Office)," was set in Bangkok and Rayong and depicted the country as underdeveloped and outdated. Apple apologized for the film's portrayal, stating it was meant to celebrate Thailand's optimism and culture. The move comes as Thailand seeks to boost tourism and economic growth, with the tourism industry being a key driver of the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Apple's sales totaled US$85.78 billion in the three months ended June 29, beating the average analyst estimate of US$84.53 billion, according to LSEG data. Its revenue had declined in the first three months of the year.
Apple is rolling out portions of Apple Intelligence to its beta users this week.
The new timing means the AI capabilities will not be widely launched until a subsequent update to the new operating system.
Apple’s market share in China dropped to 14 per cent in the second quarter of 2024, a decrease from 16 per cent in the same quarter of 2023.

site_title: Ringgit on best run in 14 years as Malaysia’s outlook brightens
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is experiencing its best run in 14 years, with a 1.6% gain against the US dollar on August 2, marking its 10th consecutive day of gains. The currency's outperformance is attributed to the government's policies to boost foreign investments and narrow the budget deficit, as well as the country's economic recovery, with second-quarter GDP beating estimates. Analysts predict the economy can achieve 4-5% growth in 2024, with the ringgit expected to strengthen further.

images.alt_text: The ringgit has raced ahead of its emerging Asia peers as exports returned to positive territory in the three months ended June.

Malaysian ringgit banknotes of various denominations are arranged for a photograph in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, Sept. 2, 2013. Malaysias ringgit dropped the most in Asia on speculation that outflows will accelerate on prospects of a reduction in U.S. monetary stimulus this month. Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg

site_title: US 30-year mortgage slides to lowest since February: Freddie Mac
summary: The US 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has fallen to its lowest level since February, averaging 6.73% this week, according to Freddie Mac. This represents a 5 basis point decrease from the previous week's average of 6.78%. The decline is attributed to signs of cooling inflation, with chief economist Sam Khater stating that consumer confidence may prevent an immediate uptick in mortgage rates due to ongoing affordability challenges.

images.alt_text: Entry level buyers depend on their personal savings and incomes, which haven’t kept up with inflation.
New home sales in June came in at an annual, seasonally-adjusted, revised rate of 617,000.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage slipped five basis points to 6.82 per cent in the week ended Jul 19.
The slowdown came as prices reached another record in June, with the median sales price up 4.1 per cent to US$426,900.
Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, fell 2.2 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 980,000 units last month, the lowest level since last October.

site_title: Hong Kong’s New World sells first debt in two years with US$400 million in new bonds
summary: Hong Kong property developer New World Development has sold US$400 million in US dollar bonds, its first debt sale in two years. The sale, which priced at an 8.625% coupon, will mainly be used to fund tender offers for existing notes. The improved pricing helped lower New World's new issue funding costs compared to the start of the year, addressing investor concerns over weakening liquidity due to a struggling property market. The sale marks a positive step for the company, which has been selling China property assets amid the ongoing market downturn.

site_title: Isetan Singapore narrows H1 loss to S$126,000 but faces lower sales
summary: Isetan Singapore reported a narrower net loss of S$126,000 for the six months ended June, compared to a loss of S$681,000 in the same period last year. Revenue fell 8.9% to S$37.4 million due to lower sales, but was partially offset by higher rental income. The retailer cited "sustained high operating costs" as a challenge in its outlook, with employee compensation and inventory costs down 4.8% and 14% respectively.

images.alt_text: In April, Isetan Mitsukoshi, a major shareholder owning 52.73% of Isetan Singapore’s shares, proposed to take the retailer private at S$7.20 per share – a 37.4% premium over the counter’s highest closing market price in the past five years.
Isetan supermarket in Westgate mall at Jurong East.
Isetan Mitsukoshi’s privatisation offer for Isetan Singapore surpasses major benchmark values considered in an exit offer, such as the department store's net asset value.

site_title: Issue 111: Singapore dips toe in nuclear pond; Thailand sweetens ESG fund incentives
summary: Singapore has signed a 123 Agreement with the US to access controlled nuclear expertise and technical information for 30 years, aiming to assess nuclear power as a low-carbon option. The country's net-zero-by-2050 goal is ambitious, and nuclear power has potential benefits, including a small physical footprint and high energy density. However, concerns over safety and waste risks remain. Meanwhile, Thailand has approved and sweetened tax incentives for investments in qualifying environmental, social and governance (ESG) funds, which may have an indirect impact on sustainable investing in the region.

The Australian Accounting Standards Board is set to finalise new standards next month, with the rules being implemented in phases across three groups to 2027.

site_title: Carlsberg to take control of India and Nepal business, eyes expansion
summary: Carlsberg to acquire 100% control of its Indian and Nepalese business for $744 million. The Danish brewer will buy a 33.33% stake in Carlsberg South Asia and other underlying companies. The deal is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter, following a successful arbitration case against its Nepal-based partner Khetan Group in 2022. CEO Jacob Aarup-Andersen plans to accelerate investments in the Indian beer market, citing long-term growth opportunities.

site_title: World food prices ease slightly in July, UN says
summary: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world food price index eased slightly in July, averaging 120.8 points, down from 121 in June. The decline in the FAO Cereals Price Index, 3.8% lower, was largely offset by increases in meat, vegetable oils, and sugar. Wheat prices fell due to seasonal availability of winter wheat harvests in the northern hemisphere and favorable conditions for spring wheat crops in Canada and the US.

site_title: Chevron reports Q2 earnings miss on weak refining margins
summary: Chevron reported Q2 earnings of $4.4 billion, missing Wall Street estimates due to weak refining margins and lower natural gas prices. The company's shares fell 1.5% in premarket trading. Chevron warned of lower oil output and refining turnarounds, and reported a 9.4% decline in upstream earnings. Despite the disappointing results, CEO Mike Wirth said the company remains poised for long-term earnings and cash flow growth. Chevron also announced plans to relocate its headquarters from California to Houston over the next five years.

site_title: Dollar drops as jobs growth disappoints, unemployment rises
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.85% to 103.47, its lowest since March 21, following a weaker-than-expected employment report for July, which showed 114,000 jobs added and a 4.3% unemployment rate, above expectations. This raised concerns about an economic downturn, prompting predictions of a 50 basis point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September to mitigate the slowdown. Market analysts see this as a "growth scare" and a sign that the economy is indeed slowing.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which tracks the currency against six others, was up 0.35 per cent at 104.40.

site_title: Great Eastern gets extension to restore free float by Oct 23
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) has been granted nearly three months to restore its public float, which dropped below 10% in June. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has set Oct 23 as the deadline for GEH to explore options. OCBC, which holds over 90% of GEH's shares, has a final shareholding level still being determined. Existing shareholders have a three-month period to exercise their right to encash their shares. The extension allows time for OCBC to finalize its shareholding level and for GEH to restore its public float.

images.alt_text: OCBC plans to delist Great Eastern Holdings. However, the lender's plans rests on whether it will own and control a certain percentage of shares before Jul 12.

David Gerald, chief executive of Sias, says that minority shareholders of Great Eastern Holdings feel they have to choose between accepting an offer deemed "unfair" or potentially having their money locked up in an unlisted company for a long time.
OCBC only needs to acquire slightly more than 4.7 million Great Eastern shares to push its stake in the insurer past the 90 per cent threshold.
In May, OCBC made a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$1.4 billion for the remaining 11.56 per cent stake in GEH that it does not own, with the aim to delist the insurer.
OCBC needs to acquire only 7.4 million more Great Eastern shares to breach the 90 per cent threshold.

site_title: Gary Neville buys out Singapore businessman Lim's shares in Salford
summary: Former Manchester United defender Gary Neville has bought out Singaporean businessman Peter Lim's 10-year stake in English lower league team Salford City. The deal ends Lim's involvement with the club, which plays in League Two, and marks a new chapter for the team. Salford, known for its "Class of 92" members, aims to build on its legacy and continue growing in the best interests of supporters, stakeholders, and the local community. The club's future growth will be guided by its new ownership.

site_title: Exxon delivers US$9.2 billion second-quarter profit, raises output target
summary: ExxonMobil reported a second-quarter profit of $9.24 billion, exceeding analyst estimates, driven by rising oil prices and volume gains from its purchase of Pioneer Natural Resources. The company raised its 2024 output target by 13% to 4.3 million barrels of oil equivalent per day. Exxon also increased its annual capital expenditure guidance to $28 billion and plans to buy back $19 billion in shares this year. The company's refining business was weaker, but gains from asset sales and higher oil production offset the losses.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil plans to become one of the biggest suppliers of lithium.
A majority of the traders — 25 out of 36 — declined to relocate, according to Fransy Van de Gucht of the ACLVB union.

site_title: Seatrium dives after Friday results release, pulling STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore equities fell 1.1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,381.4. The benchmark index slid 38.39 points, driven by earnings reports on the local bourse. Over 1.3 billion shares worth S$1.7 billion changed hands, with decliners beating advancers 422 to 199.

images.alt_text: DFI Retail Group’s pivot to ready-to-eat comes as cigarette sales in the stores have fallen.
The company’s food division saw its revenue fall marginally to US$1.6 billion
Seatrium's Ebitda for the half-year was S$390 million, from S$36 million the year before.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei sinks nearly 6% on US slowdown fears
summary: Japan's Nikkei index plummeted 5.81% to 35,909.7, its lowest close since January 26, and largest one-day percentage drop since March 2020, due to fears of a US slowdown and uncertainty over the Bank of Japan's interest rate tightening path. The broader Topix fell 6.14% to 2,537.6, as concerns about recession and higher interest rates weighed on Japanese equities.

images.alt_text: A person walks in front of an electronic screen displaying Japan's Nikkei share average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan August 2, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: US launches antitrust probe into Nvidia over sales practices
summary: The US Department of Justice has launched an antitrust investigation into Nvidia, examining whether the company pressured cloud providers to buy multiple products and charges more for networking gear if customers want to buy AI chips from rivals. Nvidia commands 80% of the AI chip market and has faced criticism over its bundling of software and hardware. The investigation is also looking into Nvidia's potential anti-competitive practices, with shares falling 3.6% in premarket trading on the news. Nvidia has declined to comment, stating it will provide any required information.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, 61, is the world’s 14th-richest person, just behind Michael Dell.
Nvidia’s chips have become central to the surge in building new systems being deployed to support AI computing.

site_title: Singtel’s Philippine JV valuation doubles to US$5 billion on Ayala and MUFG investments
summary: Singtel's Philippine joint venture Mynt has doubled its valuation to US$5 billion after receiving investments from Ayala and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG). Ayala will acquire an 8% stake, while MUFG will acquire 8% for US$393 million. Mynt's stake in GCash will increase to 13%, with Singtel retaining a 22.3% stake in Globe Telecom. The investments are expected to expand GCash's social impact, particularly for the underserved population.

images.alt_text: GCash forms part of Globe’s drive to become a tech-centric enterprise, diversifying from its maturing core telco business.

site_title: OCBC looks to balance net interest income growth with NIM impact ahead of interest rate cuts
summary: OCBC's net profit rose 14% to S$1.94 billion in Q2, driven by income growth and a decline in allowances. The bank aims to balance net interest income growth with the impact of lower net interest margins ahead of expected interest rate cuts. OCBC expects two cuts this year, which will hit its asset yields and funding costs. The bank has deployed liquidity into lower-yielding assets and is managing its funding costs to prepare for the expected rate cuts.

images.alt_text: XXXXXX

Singapore banking counters have enjoyed strong share performances on expectations that the US Federal Reserve will hold rate cuts to later in the year, say analysts.
The earnings resilience coupled with the high interest rate environment compel investors to pile into Singapore banks.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate at one-year low in June; tourist arrivals continue falling
summary: Singapore's average room rate at hotels fell to its lowest level in a year in June, marking a sequential decline. International visitor arrivals have been falling for three consecutive months. Other hotel indicators, including overall room revenue, revenue per available room, and average occupancy rate, also registered decreases. The decline in tourist arrivals and hotel revenue is attributed to a drop in international visitor numbers, following a peak in March when Taylor Swift staged six concerts. This marks a concerning trend for Singapore's tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu delivering the keynote address at this year's Tourism Industry Conference.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 2)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a review group to recommend measures to support companies listed on the Singapore Exchange and encourage them to expand globally. OCBC aims to balance net interest income growth with the impact of lower net interest margins ahead of potential interest rate cuts. Employment claims by Singapore workers rose in 2023, driven by foreign construction workers. Singapore hotels' average room rate fell to a one-year low in June, with tourist arrivals continuing to decline. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) fell 1.1% following earnings reports.

site_title: Real estate player CBRE acquires sustainability advisory Paia
summary: CBRE acquires Singapore-based sustainability advisory Paia Consulting, expanding its environmental, social and governance (ESG) consulting and sustainability services. Paia, founded in 2002, has worked with over 100 Singapore-listed companies, providing sustainability strategy, implementation, and reporting services. The acquisition will integrate Paia with CBRE's existing ESG consulting team, enhancing its capabilities in the Asia-Pacific region. Carrie Johnson will lead the Paia team, while Corrado Forcellati will oversee client sustainability strategy. The move aims to help clients navigate ESG complexities and reporting requirements.

site_title: Coming back from the dead: Do People’s Park Complex, Far East Shopping Centre and other strata-titled malls have a chance?
summary: Singapore's strata malls, iconic in the 1970s and 80s, are facing challenges in rejuvenating their offerings as their upkeep becomes increasingly difficult. The fragmented type of ownership, with multiple landlords leasing out space, hinders effective tenant-mix strategies and rent optimization. Many strata malls have deteriorated, with shuttered stores and poorly maintained facilities. Some owners are choosing to exit with a profit by pursuing collective sales, while others are being considered for conservation. The government is taking a "delicate balance" approach, conserving buildings with architectural and cultural significance while meeting the physical needs of the nation. Adaptive reuse of strata malls poses challenges, including unknowns about existing structures and potential latent defects.

images.alt_text: City Developments Limited acquired freehold Delfi Orchard via public tender for S$439 million on Tuesday (May 28).
Owners of Far East Shopping Centre rejected an offer of about S$880 million.
Far East, Perennial offer to buy Golden Mile Complex for lower price of S$700m

site_title: Hong Kong hits AIA with record fine for anti-laundering lapses
summary: Hong Kong's Insurance Authority fined AIA Group a record HK$23 million (S$3.92 million) for anti-money laundering lapses, citing "technical issues" with the insurer's system and algorithm. The lapses led to delays in identifying source of funds for "politically exposed persons" and resulted in some customers failing to be screened. The fine was related to business between March 2016 and October 2022, with no policies sold to ineligible clients. AIA's shares fell 2.5% on the news.

images.alt_text: Located at Six Battery Road, the AIA Wealth Centre is a one-stop hub offering wealth management services beyond traditional wealth preservation and accumulation consultation.

AIA’s VONB, which gauges expected profits from new premiums and is a key barometer for future growth, came in at US$1.33 billion in the three months ending March 31 compared with US$1.05 billion a year ago.

site_title: PBOC adviser gives rare critique of China economic policies
summary: A member of the People's Bank of China's monetary policy committee, Huang Yiping, has urged the government to shift its strategy from focusing on investment to boosting consumer spending. He recommends setting a target for inflation and implementing measures such as cash handouts to households and better access to urban public services. Huang also warned that the economy is vulnerable to falling into a "low inflation trap," which could lead to serious consequences. The comments come as China's economy faces challenges, including a slowdown and a prolonged property market crisis.

images.alt_text: Banks have had little appetite for the MLF funds in recent months, as a decline in market rates meant it became cheaper for them to borrow from each other than from the PBOC.
Mired in a property slump and beset by deflation, China’s economy needs a low interest-rate environment to stimulate growth.

site_title: Sri Lanka needs to raise fiscal revenue to maintain stability, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Sri Lanka needs to raise fiscal revenue to maintain economic stability and restore debt sustainability. The IMF will review Sri Lanka's progress in meeting key commitments as part of a $2.9 billion bailout after the presidential election in September. The country has made progress in stabilizing its economy, with inflation slowing to 2.4% in July and the rupee rising 7% in recent months. The IMF will continue to support Sri Lanka's debt restructuring efforts and encourage a swift resolution to achieve debt sustainability.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka Photographer: Jonathan Wijayaratne/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe speaks during an interview with Reuters at his office in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 28,2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

site_title: UK banks cut business-class flights and taxis in cost-saving drive
summary: UK's largest lenders, including HSBC, are cutting business-class flights and taxis as part of a cost-saving drive following the Bank of England's interest rate cuts. The move aims to protect profits in coming quarters as high interest rates fuelled revenue growth in recent years. HSBC has clamped down on business travel and new hiring, even challenging senior bankers over small expenses. The bank's actions are in response to the expected shift in borrowing costs and economic data.

images.alt_text: Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), during the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, Feb. 1, 2024. The Bank of England opened the door to interest-rate reductions, slashing its outlook for inflation this year and dropping its guidance that borrowing costs may have to rise again. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Harris raises US$310 million in July, topping Trump in money race
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris raised a record $310 million in July, surpassing Republican Donald Trump's $138.7 million. Harris now has $377 million in cash on hand, the largest war chest in the election cycle. The haul highlights her strong grassroots fundraising and momentum among Democratic voters and donors. Harris' campaign has seen significant support from prominent donors and has spent heavily on media and resources to get out the vote. This development is a concern for Trump's campaign, which had previously had a fundraising advantage.

images.alt_text: (Right) Donald Trump’s worst impulses resurfaced on Wednesday with his outlandish claim that Kamala Harris (left) - the first female and non-white vice-president - recently “became a Black person” for political convenience.

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust records 9.1% lower profit after tax in Q1 at S$25.7 million
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 9.1% decline in profit after tax to S$25.7 million in Q1, driven by lower earnings before taxes and higher depreciation from a higher asset base. Revenue fell 2.9% to S$100.9 million, mainly due to lower non-regulated asset base revenue from ancillary projects. The decline is attributed to a higher asset base and lower earnings.

images.alt_text: The fall in H2 earnings contributed to a 5.5 per cent fall in NetLink's full-year earnings to S$103.2 million.
NetLink Trust's company vehicle. NetLink Trust has become the fibre network operator of the Next Gen NBN, in place of OpenNet Pte Ltd, since 1 October 2014.

site_title: From US$332 million to US$8.5 million: Office block’s price plunge captures Manhattan’s shocking office collapse
summary: A Manhattan office building, once the headquarters of Sports Illustrated, sold for $8.5 million after being listed for $7.5 million in an online auction. The 23-storey glass behemoth, built in 1963, was previously sold for $332 million in 2006, reflecting the significant decline in office building values due to the pandemic. Experts say this sale price is a sign of the new reality for Manhattan's office sector, with companies embracing hybrid and remote work, making offices less desirable.

images.alt_text: The bank has agreed to buy the office tower at 250 Park Avenue, in partnership with Hines, from seller AEW.
The listing has languished on the Chicago market, where the top end of the luxury market sits considerably lower than in cities such as New York and Miami.

site_title: Nintendo Switch sales halve and profit tumbles as successor device awaited
summary: Nintendo reported a 71% decline in operating profit to 54.5 billion yen (S$492 million) in the April-to-June quarter, falling short of estimates. The company sold 2.1 million Switch units, nearly halving from the previous quarter, but maintained a full-year sales forecast of 13.5 million units. Nintendo plans to announce a successor device in the current financial year, amid rising industry costs and weak pricing power.

images.alt_text: Each new chapter of Zelda is eagerly awaited by fans – the franchise has racked up well over 140 million sales since it began in 1986.
The move signals greater interest from Nintendo to bring in content to bolster the offerings from its in-house creative studios.
Nintendo expects to sell 13.5 million Switch units in the current financial year as the company squeezes out sales of the aging device.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, August 2, 2024 (Ep 115)
summary: Asia markets plummeted on Friday, August 2, 2024, following Wall Street's decline due to recession fears. Japan's Nikkei sank nearly 6% due to US slowdown concerns. In Singapore, OCBC Q2 profit rose 14% to S$1.94 billion, with a S$0.44 per share interim dividend declared. Seatrium marked a turnaround with H1 net profit of S$36 million.

site_title: Saudis may raise stake in top builder to support economic rejig
summary: Saudi Arabia's government may increase its stake in struggling construction conglomerate Saudi Binladin Group to support the country's trillion-dollar economic transformation plans. The move aims to stabilize the firm's financial structure, which has been weighed down by billions of dollars in debt. The kingdom hopes to turn Binladin into a national champion, capable of building key projects such as the Two Holy Mosques. The government's support is part of its broader efforts to secure financing for infrastructure projects, including the 2030 World Expo exhibition and the 2034 FIFA World Cup.

images.alt_text: Saudi's biggest construction firm hires new CEO as it plans US$15b debt revamp

site_title: The Olympic doom everyone predicted never came to Paris
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympics have defied expectations of chaos and overcrowding, with the city appearing less hellish than predicted. Despite concerns over overtourism and price-gouging, visitor numbers have been lower than anticipated, with vehicle traffic falling 22% and average speeds on major roads increasing. The event has also generated positive economic growth, with Bloomberg Economics predicting a boost in French economic growth in the third quarter. The city's landmarks and events have been well-received, with many locals and visitors alike enjoying the experience.

site_title: SP Group raises S$1 million through Community Chest for vulnerable seniors
summary: SP Group raised S$1 million through the annual SP Charity Golf event for the SP Heartware Fund, the highest amount raised at the event. The funds will support vulnerable seniors through Community Chest, reaching approximately 25,000 seniors, and will be used for programmes such as befriending, counselling, caregiver support, and community care. This brings the total amount raised by the SP Heartware Fund to over S$22 million since its inception in 2005.

images.alt_text: Minister for National Development of Singapore Desmond Lee (2nd row, centre) with beneficiaries and volunteers of Glyph.

site_title: What Toyota got for the US$835 million it spent on the Olympics
summary: Toyota spent a record US$835 million to join the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) TOP programme, becoming the largest-ever Olympic sponsor. The company contributed nearly 2,700 electric, hybrid, or hydrogen fuel cell vehicles to the Paris 2024 Olympic Games and created 250 Accessible People Movers. Toyota's support helped Paralympic snowboarder Amy Purdy win three medals. The company's sponsorship has boosted its brand value, with some experts citing Samsung as a successful example of Olympic sponsorship's impact. Toyota's involvement may be ending after the Paris Games, but it has already had a lasting impact on the lives of hundreds of athletes.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen’s ID Buzz offers a great view from the driver’s seat, the steering is light and the ergonomics make sense.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui profit beats expectations on lending income
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui's net income rose 50% to 371.4 billion yen (S$3.32 billion) in the first quarter, beating estimates. The Japanese bank's profit increase is attributed to higher lending income following interest rate rises. This marks the last of Japan's biggest banks to announce results, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group also reporting profits that beat estimates. Despite a broader selloff in Japan's equity market, analysts remain optimistic about the potential for record annual earnings due to tighter monetary policy boosting lending profitability.

images.alt_text: Toyota is also unwinding cross-shareholdings within its network of manufacturing partners.
Japan’s second-biggest bank plans to start its Gujarat International Finance Tec­City branch likely in July with around 10 people, says Rajeev Kannan.

site_title: German chancellor lines up fresh crisis talks with property titans
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is set to hold crisis talks with property titans on December 6 to address the country's severe housing shortage, exacerbated by failed developers and a slump in investment and financing. The crisis has contributed to a fifth of Germany's output, and the government has proposed measures such as cutting property sales tax and relaxing building regulations. However, industry leaders have expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of these measures, citing the need for concrete steps and real action. The talks come amid a recession and state elections that could bolster the far-right Alternative for Germany party.

images.alt_text: People walk past apartment buildings on the banks of the river Spree in the Heidestrasse quarter in Berlin‘s Mitte (Centre) district in the German capital, on August 14, 2023. Since 2018, the Heidestrasse area of some 85.000 square meters has been constructed with new buildings for housing, working, shopping. (Photo by Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP)

Prices in Germany have corrected much more strongly than in other European countries because the majority of people rent their homes, meaning consumers have the option to remain tenants rather than take out pricey mortgages.

site_title: Deutsche Bank unloading US$1 billion in US real estate loans
summary: Deutsche Bank is selling up to $1 billion in US commercial property loans, seeking capital relief amid declining profits in its real estate portfolio. The bank had $16 billion in US loan exposure at the end of Q2, with $7 billion linked to offices. Rising interest rates have dented the commercial real estate market, with office vacancies increasing. The sale is part of Deutsche Bank's book management strategy, with the bank having completed similar transactions in the past.

site_title: 7-Eleven operator DFI Retail wants a big bite of ready-to-eat food
summary: DFI Retail Group, the operator of 7-Eleven in Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau, and Southern China, is shifting focus to ready-to-eat food to compensate for declining cigarette sales. The company aims to transform its convenience stores into "quick-service restaurants" by driving traffic to its stores for cooked food. According to CEO Scott Price, this pivot could help the company become a player in the quick-service restaurants market, despite a robust first-half underlying profit driven by its food and convenience segments.

images.alt_text: The company’s food division saw its revenue fall marginally to US$1.6 billion
Despite its size and distance from China’s most important cities, Pangdonglai’s influence has percolated through the industry, with smaller chains adopting its model.

site_title: Future offer for Great Eastern, if any, will be made in interest of OCBC: CEO Helen Wong
summary: OCBC's group CEO Helen Wong stated that if the lender makes any future offers for Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) shares, it will be in the interest of OCBC and its shareholders, not GEH's minority shareholders. The offer price of S$25.60 is considered "meaningful" as it represents a premium to most listed life insurance peers. Over 130 shareholders have accepted the offer, and trading in GEH's shares remains suspended until the final shareholding of OCBC is known.

images.alt_text: Great

site_title: Gold prices set for weekly gain with US payrolls data on tap
summary: Gold prices are set to gain for the week, driven by safe-haven demand and speculation of a September Federal Reserve rate cut. Spot gold rose 0.4% to US$2,455.36 per ounce, just US$28 shy of the record peak of US$2,483.60 in July. US gold futures also climbed 0.8% to US$2,499.50, with market participants awaiting US payrolls data.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was steady at US$2,448.38 per ounce.

site_title: BNP in talks to buy Axa Investment Managers in 5.1 billion euro deal
summary: BNP Paribas is in talks to buy Axa Investment Managers for 5.1 billion euros, creating a top player in Europe with 1.5 trillion euros in assets under management. The deal, expected to be signed by the end of 2024, would allow BNP Paribas to expand its asset management capabilities, particularly in alternative assets. Axa will exit the asset management business and retain a 15-year strategic partnership with BNP Paribas, while also conducting a 3.8 billion euro share buyback. The deal aims to address consolidation in the asset management sector, where scale is crucial for competition.

site_title: Glencore’s billionaire ex-oil head charged with corruption
summary: Alex Beard, a former billionaire head of oil at Glencore, has been charged with corruption by the UK's Serious Fraud Office. Beard, 56, is one of five former Glencore employees accused of conspiring to make corrupt payments to government officials in West Africa between 2007 and 2014. The charges follow Glencore's 2022 guilty plea to corruption and market manipulation cases in the US and UK. Beard and four others are set to appear in court on September 10.

site_title: Intel to cut 15% jobs, suspend dividend in turnaround push; shares plummet
summary: Intel announced plans to cut 15% of its workforce and suspend its dividend, starting in the fourth quarter, as part of a turnaround push focusing on its loss-making manufacturing business. The company forecast third-quarter revenue below estimates, citing a decline in traditional data center semiconductors and a focus on AI chips. Intel's shares plummeted 20% in extended trade, setting the company up to lose over $24 billion in market value.

images.alt_text: Amazon's sales of US$148 billion fell just shy of lofty market expectations. Its shares slid more than four per cent to US$176.50 in after-market trades.

site_title: China’s stuttering recovery darkens global corporate growth outlook
summary: China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, with the government's stimulus measures failing to boost consumption and the overleveraged property market discouraging spending. The country's US$18.6 trillion economy grew slower than expected in the second quarter, and retail sales growth sank to an 18-month low in June. Global companies, including Starbucks, General Motors, and technology firms, are feeling the pinch, with some warning of a prolonged period of near-stagnation and persistent deflation threats. Analysts say Beijing's stimulus efforts are unlikely to ease soon, and the slowdown's effects can be felt across borders.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Jardine Matheson, Jardine C&C, Hongkong Land, Seatrium
summary: OCBC's net profit for the second quarter rose 14% to S$1.94 billion, beating a consensus forecast of S$1.8 billion. Jardine Matheson posted a 33% decline in underlying net profit to US$550 million, while Jardine C&C's underlying profit fell 14% to US$500 million. Hongkong Land reported an underlying loss of US$7 million, but Seatrium marked a turnaround with a net profit of S$36 million, reversing a net loss of S$264.4 million in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: It may be better for landlords to remain flexible in lease negotiations during tenancy renewals, says Savills.

site_title: Booking’s soft forecast overshadows second-quarter earnings beat
summary: Booking, the parent company of travel brands Kayak and Priceline, posted solid second-quarter results but delivered a disappointing forecast for the third quarter, citing "mild moderation" in the European travel market. The company expects 3-5% growth in room nights sold and 2-4% rise in gross travel bookings, falling short of analyst expectations. This forecast reignites concerns over a broader slowdown in consumer spending on travel, causing shares to fall 7% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Vietnam Airlines Corp plans to lease 20 A321 neo aircraft to add domestic as well as regional flights after carrying a record number of passengers in one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets.

The victory marks a historic milestone for Singapore in the Olympics, with Loh becoming the country's first man to reach the quarter-finals since 2004.

site_title: Asia: Tokyo tanks as markets track Wall Street down on recession fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 plummeted over 5% on Friday due to a stronger yen, which negatively impacted Japan's key export sector. The decline was fueled by US recession fears and disappointing economic data, including a weaker-than-expected jobs report and a sharp decline in Intel's workforce. Global markets also fell, with the Nasdaq tumbling over 2% and other Asian markets, such as Hong Kong and Sydney, shedding over 2%. The yen's appreciation to nearly 148 per dollar, its best level since March, also contributed to the market downturn.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down 5% after US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 5% on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 5.02% to 36,213.17, amid concerns over the US economy. The yen's appreciation against the dollar and US Federal Reserve comments hinting at a potential rate cut also weighed on the market. The declines followed a sharp drop in US shares, with the benchmark index edging down from records amid tariff threats. The Japanese market was expected to continue with sharp falls following the US stock market's decline.

site_title: MAS sets up review group to improve Singapore stock market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has established a review group to enhance the local equities market. The panel, chaired by Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat, aims to support companies listed on the Singapore Exchange and encourage them to expand globally. The group will build on existing initiatives, including funds for initial public offerings and measures to improve research coverage.

Trump's comments, which he claims were meant to highlight Harris's mixed race identity, have been widely criticized as racist. The incident has reignited attention on Trump's extensive record of racial transgressions, including his history of discrimination and pandering to white supremacist groups. Analysts say the controversy may not be effective in swaying Black voters, but rather highlights Trump's lack of self-control and narcissism.

site_title: How scoring for the Singapore governance index is done
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) evaluates listed companies on their corporate governance practices and financial transparency. The index assesses companies in two categories: General Category and Reit and Business Trust Category. The General Category score consists of five sections (BREAD) and is adjusted by bonuses and penalties, while the Reit and Business Trust Category score includes unique items covering their operations. SGTI 2024 covers 477 companies and 43 Reits and business trusts, using sources such as annual reports and SGXNet announcements.

site_title: Japan warns of weak yen impact on households in government white paper
summary: Japan's government has expressed concern over the weak yen's impact on households, citing its effect on fuel, food, and raw material costs, which has dampened consumption. The yen's decline has eroded purchasing power, particularly for smaller firms, and has raised inflation expectations. The government warned that a weak yen risks eroding consumers' purchasing power, outweighing wage growth. This comes as the Bank of Japan raises interest rates to combat inflation, which may also influence the US Federal Reserve's monetary easing cycle.
