site_title: French inflation retreats to its lowest level in three years
summary: French inflation eased to its lowest level since July 2021, with consumer prices rising 2.2% from a year ago in August, down from 2.7% in July. This slowdown in prices could give President Emmanuel Macron some breathing space, particularly ahead of snap elections and a meeting of the European Central Bank to decide on interest rate cuts. Economists predict the ECB may lower its deposit rate to 3.5% from 3.75% due to softer inflation and sluggish economic growth.

images.alt_text: A person walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building on September 14, 2023 ahead of the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: NTUC to form new platform work associations, if Bill implementing protections is passed
summary: NTUC plans to form new platform work associations to provide "union-like" representation for platform workers, if the Bill implementing protections is passed. Currently, workers are represented by three industry bodies without legal powers. Once the Bill is passed, NTUC will register the associations under the Ministry of Manpower, granting them "union-like" powers. The goal is to achieve a membership rate of 60-70% to indicate "good traction" for growth, with existing members to be transferred to the new organizations. Labour protections for platform workers will kick in on Jan 1, 2025.

images.alt_text: The SkillsFuture Jobseeker Support scheme marks a "paradigm shift" for the government, Manpower Minister Tan See Leng said during a visit to the Employment and Employability Institute on Aug 27.

site_title: Nike push in China to include tour with NBA stars Doncic, Tatum
summary: Nike's Jordan brand is taking a tour of China featuring NBA stars Luka Doncic, Zion Williamson, Jayson Tatum, and Paolo Banchero. The tour, set for this fall, aims to promote product lines in the crucial growth market. The event series will take place in Beijing and Shanghai, with tour details yet to be released. This move follows Nike's history of bringing top endorsers to China to connect with consumers and capitalize on the country's growing market.

images.alt_text: Pershing Square has been involved with Nike before, making a US$100 million profit in just a few months when it cashed out of a passive stake in 2018.
Nike has cut back on oversupplied brands including Air Force 1 to curb a worsening sales decline as part of a US$2 billion cost-cutting plan launched late last year.

site_title: Can the US fix the mess in the Middle East?
summary: US diplomacy in the Middle East is struggling to bring an end to the Israel-Hamas conflict, with President Joe Biden and Secretary of State Anthony Blinken having made numerous attempts to broker a ceasefire. Despite the Biden administration's efforts, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has resisted pressure to accept a ceasefire proposal, and Hamas' leader Yahya Sinwar has rejected the plan unless Washington guarantees a full ceasefire and withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The conflict's instability has strengthened Iran's position, with the country's proxy, Hizbollah, continuing to attack targets in northern Israel.

images.alt_text: Site of an Israeli airstrike on southern Lebanon; any major escalation in the fighting, which began in parallel with the war in Gaza, risks morphing into a regional conflagration drawing in Hizbollah’s backer Iran and Israel’s main ally the United States.
Hamas announced that senior Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar is the group's new political leader following the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran, July 31, 2024.

site_title: Michelin-starred Sushi Kimura to close over rent and manpower issues
summary: Michelin-starred sushi restaurant Sushi Kimura will close its doors in November due to rising rent and manpower costs. Chef-owner Tomoo Kimura attributes the closure to the saturated fine-dining industry, exacerbated by the weakened economy and increased competition. High salaries for Japanese staff, including chefs, also pose a challenge, with the cost of hiring a chef from Japan being over S$10,000 a month. Kimura plans to continue collaborating and consultancy work while searching for a new space for his next concept.

images.alt_text: One-Michelin-starred restaurant Sommer will close on Oct 26.

site_title: Macron, Starmer pledge deeper ties between France and Britain
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron agreed to deepen ties between the UK and France in areas of defense, security, migration, and energy. They also pledged to dismantle migrant smuggling routes and increase intelligence-sharing. The leaders discussed the Middle East, reiterating a call for an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. Additionally, they reaffirmed their support for Ukraine against Russia's invasion to ensure European continent security. A bilateral treaty is being considered to improve British-EU ties.

images.alt_text: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, left, and Olaf Scholz, Germany's chancellor, shake hands following a news conference at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024. The UK and Germany are edging toward a major new treaty as part of Keir Starmer's efforts to improve ties with European allies. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, August 23, 2024 (Ep 129)
summary: Asian stocks declined ahead of US Fed Chair Powell's speech, with China bond trading collapsing amid a PBOC crackdown on record rally. Indonesia and Malaysia stocks rose as foreign investors sold Asian stocks. China's real estate woes weighed down S-Reits, but the retail sector may be a bright spot.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 51 to 47.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei and Seoul stocks slipped while Wellington and Jakarta edged up on Friday.
Measures such as selling from state banks to drive up yields and repeated regulatory checks on some investors have kept traders on edge and dampened trading activities.
CapitaLand China Trust's distributable income has risen slightly in its latest financial results.

site_title: ECB says consumer inflation expectations edged higher in July
summary: The European Central Bank reported that consumer inflation expectations in the euro area edged higher in July, rising to 2.4% for three years ahead. This increase, however, is unlikely to deter officials from pursuing interest-rate cuts. Consumer expectations about prices over the next 12 months remained at 2.8%, with a slight decrease in forecasts for nominal incomes and spending growth. The ECB still aims to meet its 2% inflation target by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Aside from a slowdown in wage gains, the ECB’s inflation outlook needs corporate profit margins to absorb some of the rise in labour costs and productivity to improve.

site_title: HMD launches Barbie phone in partnership with Mattel
summary: HMD Global has launched the HMD Barbie Phone, a feature flip phone in partnership with Mattel, coinciding with Barbie's 65th birthday. The £99 (S$171) phone allows users to make calls and send texts, but lacks access to social media apps. The device features a retro design with a pink keypad and hidden designs that light up in the dark. Research firm CCS Insight estimates HMD could sell over 400,000 Barbie phones in the UK, with the phone available through Vodafone and Argos starting on August 28.

images.alt_text: Tennis icon Venus Williams hopes to motivate young girls into sports with the doll.
Sales grew 9.3 per cent to US$1.92 billion, exceeding projections of US$1.84 billion as shoppers snapped up Barbie dolls and other mainstays such as Hot Wheels cars.
Barbie has become a cultural phenomenon with many fans dressing in pink to see the live-action take on Mattel’s famous fashion doll.

site_title: Ikea pilots platform for secondhand furniture in Oslo, Madrid
summary: IKEA is trialing an online marketplace called Ikea Preowned, where customers can buy and sell pre-owned items made by the Swedish furniture manufacturer. The platform, centered on Oslo, Norway, and Madrid, Spain, will run until December. The venture aims to reduce waste and support the circular economy, as IKEA seeks to become climate-positive by the end of the decade. Initially, the platform will be free, but a symbolic fee may be charged in the future.

site_title: Indonesia approves development plan for Eni’s Geng North gas project
summary: Indonesia has approved the development plan for the Geng North and Gehem gas fields, operated by Eni, to create a new production hub called the Northern Hub. The project, valued at $17.49 billion, will develop 5 trillion cubic feet of gas and 400 million barrels of condensates. The development is expected to strengthen Indonesia's oil and gas supplies and is seen as a key step in the country's efforts to accelerate gas projects before the energy transition.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Model of natural gas pipeline and rising stock graph, July 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets boosted by Fed chief’s rate cut talk
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, boosted by US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's comments that interest rates may start cutting as soon as next month. The comments, made in a speech at Jackson Hole, Wyoming, helped lift the yen and pushed major indexes in Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, and Taiwan higher. However, Tokyo and Shanghai shares suffered losses due to a strengthening yen. Analysts warned that the market's optimism may be short-lived, with upcoming economic data releases and potential escalation in the Middle East weighing on investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: epa11556317 A passerby walks past a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 20 August 2024. The Nikkei Stock Average gained 674.30 points, or 1.80 percent, to close at 38,062.92.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%

site_title: Zoom projects better-than-expected sales growth on new products
summary: Zoom Video Communications reported better-than-expected sales growth, with revenue projected to be $1.16 billion to $1.17 billion for the current quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company raised its fiscal year sales and profit forecasts. Zoom also announced a new single-use webinar offering and expanded its suite of products, including phone systems and contact centers. The company's enterprise revenue increased 3.5% to $682.8 million, and shares rose about 3% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Zoom has turned its focus to business customers.
Zoom has projected revenue of about US$4.6 billion in the fiscal year ending in January 2025.
The team has now been dismantled, though the exact number of DEI-focused employees affected by the cuts could not be established. A
After vaulting into public consciousness during the pandemic, Zoom has struggled to maintain high revenue growth.

site_title: Food Empire to receive US$40 million from Ikhlas Capital under strategic partnership
summary: Food Empire Holdings will receive a US$40 million capital injection from Ikhlas Capital through a special-purpose vehicle in exchange for five-year redeemable exchangeable notes at 5.5% annual interest. The funds will accelerate plans in South-east Asia and South Asia, driving capital expenditure and mergers and acquisitions. This strategic partnership aims to support Food Empire's focus on the regions, with revenue growth from these segments reaching 34.8% and 36% in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Sudeep Nair, group chief executive of Food Empire, said: “We are very excited about the performance of our South-east Asia and South Asia segments, which have maintained a strong growth trajectory due to the successful execution of our business strategies.”
Food Empire intends to expand the group’s business in South-east Asia and South Asia through its partnership with Ikhlas Capital.
Sudeep Nair, chief executive officer of Food Empire.

site_title: Volkswagen’s China partner sees revenue shortfall as price war continues
summary: Chinese electric car maker Xpeng forecasts a revenue shortfall in the third quarter due to a continued price war in its home market. The company expects to deliver 41,000-45,000 vehicles and post a maximum revenue of 9.8 billion yuan, below analysts' estimates. Xpeng's net loss narrowed to 1.3 billion yuan in the second quarter, aided by revenue from its collaboration with Volkswagen. The company plans to launch new models and facelift versions in the next three years to boost sales and improve its economy of scale.

images.alt_text: Pre-sales of the Land Aircraft Carrier are due to start in the final quarter of 2024 in China, the company says.
Xiaomi’s SU7 debuts at an industry event in Shanghai on May 10.
The tariffs will kick in from Friday, with definitive duties to take effect in November for a period of five years, pending a vote by the EU’s 27 member states.
Xpeng said it expects to hand over between 29,000 and 32,000 vehicles, an increase of about 25 to 37.9 per cent from the previous year.

site_title: Europe: Energy shares lead Stoxx 600 to snap 5-day gains
summary: Europe's main stock index, the Stoxx 600, closed 0.5% lower on Tuesday, snapping a five-day winning streak, as heavyweight energy stocks fell 2% due to early drop in oil prices. Despite a near three-week high, investors await domestic economic data and central bankers' meeting in Jackson Hole, which may influence interest rate cuts and risk-on sentiment. The Stoxx 600 is up over 7% so far this year, with luxury and automobile stocks among the few bright spots, while healthcare and mining sectors were boosted.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.2 per cent to 40,834.97, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index retreated by the same amount to 5,597.12 on Tuesday.

site_title: BYD to self-import luxury brand Denza in Singapore; appoints Sime Darby unit and Harmony Auto as dealers
summary: China's BYD is launching luxury brand Denza in Singapore, adopting a self-distribution model similar to German luxury brands Audi and BMW. BYD has appointed Sime Darby unit Vantage Automotive and Harmony Auto as dealers, with the first Denza model being the D9 large multi-purpose vehicle. This move aims to improve margins and reduce operating costs, as BYD delegates stock management to multiple dealers. Denza's sales structure in Singapore will be similar to that of luxury brands, marking a departure from traditional mainstream car sales models.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Electric vehicle (EV) models are displayed at the booths of Denza, a joint venture between Mercedes-Benz Group AG and BYD Auto, and Chinese EV maker Voyah, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Singtel partners Bridge Alliance to offer GPU-as-a-Service in South-east Asia
summary: Singtel partners Bridge Alliance to offer GPU-as-a-Service in South-east Asia, allowing 35 member operators to access the cloud-based solution. Early adopters include AIS in Thailand, Maxis in Malaysia, and Telkomsel in Indonesia. The GPUaaS offering will provide access to high-performance computing and data processing capabilities, enabling businesses to scale resources on-demand for complex workloads like AI and machine learning. The service is set to launch in Singapore and South-east Asia in the third quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in Qingdao, China. Two-third of the global digital economy – will be powered by the US and China.

site_title: Taiwan defence spend to outpace GDP growth as China threat rises
summary: Taiwan's defence spending is set to rise 7.7% in 2025 to NT$647 billion, accounting for 2.45% of GDP, exceeding the government's expectation for economic growth. The increase includes a special budget for new fighter jets and missile production, as the island strengthens deterrence against China's rising threat. Taiwan's defence spending aims to reach 3% of GDP, with future spending dependent on acquiring key equipment, and is seen as a response to China's military modernization efforts, including new aircraft carriers and stealth fighter jets.

images.alt_text: A standard missile fires off a Patriot PAC-2 surface-to-air missile system during a military drill in Pingtung, Taiwan August 20, 2024. Reuters TV via REUTERS

site_title: Thai economy is nearly in crisis: caretaker finance minister
summary: Thailand's economy is at risk of a crisis due to declining exports and uncompetitive manufacturing, according to caretaker finance minister Pichai Chunhavajira. The country's economy grew 2.3% in the April-June quarter, accelerating from 1.6% in the prior quarter, but quarter-on-quarter growth slowed to 0.8%. Exports account for 70% of the economy, but the manufacturing sector cannot meet market demand. The finance ministry predicts 2.7% economic growth for 2024, lagging regional peers. The central bank is expected to leave interest rates unchanged at 2.50% for a fifth straight meeting.

images.alt_text: Workers assemble an EV car inside BYD's first electric vehicle (EV) factory in Southeast Asia, a fast-growing regional EV market where it has become the dominant player, in Rayong, Thailand, July 4, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Video gamers set for world’s biggest trade show
summary: The world's largest video game trade show, Gamescom, is set to open in Germany, attracting over 300,000 attendees and featuring upcoming big releases like "Indiana Jones and the Great Circle" and "Call of Duty: Black Ops 6". The video game industry is expected to generate over US$180 billion in revenue this year and attract more than 3.4 billion players, according to analyst firm Newzoo. The event comes at a sensitive time for the industry, which has been impacted by layoffs and studio closures.

site_title: Climate change a mixed blessing for sun-starved Irish vintners
summary: Ireland's climate is warming, with warmer and drier summers, potentially benefiting its small number of winemakers. Despite challenges like limited machinery, technology, and expertise, some Irish vintners, like Esperanza Hernandez, are seeing opportunities for high-quality wine production. Climate change brings unpredictability, including frosts and dry spells, but favorable conditions, such as fertile soil and long summer daylight, are already present in Ireland. Experts like Aileen Rolfe see potential for Irish wine to flourish, particularly in new markets like England and New Zealand.

images.alt_text: Winemaker Esperanza Hernandez poses with a glass of wine in her Old Roots Vineyard in Wellingtonbridge, near Wexford, southern Ireland on July 13, 2024. A tiny outpost in the wine world, Ireland's handful of wine-makers are cautiously eyeing long-term growth potential as climate change warms up its cool climate. And at Ireland's largest vineyard, owner Esperanza Hernandez says "better weather makes it more possible than before to make high-quality wine" even on the sun-starved island. Hernandez's 10-acre (4-hectare) vineyard lies near the village of Wellingtonbridge in the south-eastern coastal county of Wexford, statistically Ireland's sunniest corner. (Photo by Paul Faith / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY BY Peter MURPHY

site_title: Australian insurer Suncorp forecasts slower total premium growth in fiscal 2025
summary: Australian insurer Suncorp forecasts slower total premium growth in fiscal 2025, with mid to high single-digit growth expected. The company posted a 17% rise in fiscal 2024 cash earnings and a 14% rise in general insurance gross written premiums. Price increases offset natural hazard and higher reinsurance costs, contributing to the growth. Suncorp's cash earnings reached A$1.37 billion for the full year ended June 30.

site_title: Hot stock: Yoma falls 17% after denying criminal proceeds from online scam centres used to fund real estate project
summary: Yoma Strategic's shares plummeted 16.8% after the company denied allegations by news agency The Irrawaddy that its former executive chairman, Serge Pun, misused public funds and used criminal proceeds from online scams to fund a real estate project. The company stated that Star City has not required or received external funding in recent years and is currently a vibrant community with over 6,000 residents. Serge Pun faces additional charges of misusing public funds and using criminal proceeds, in addition to money laundering and other illegal transactions.

images.alt_text: Executive chairman Serge Pun has been meeting and cooperating with relevant authorities, says Yoma Strategic.

site_title: Traders need Fed go sign in Jackson Hole to keep stocks rallying
summary: US stocks are awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision at its Jackson Hole meeting in September, with traders expecting a rate reduction but uncertain about its size. Markets are hopeful that the Fed has achieved a "soft landing" by taming inflation without triggering economic pain. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole could provide clarity on the Fed's rate path, but traders are bracing for a potentially hawkish tone that could negatively impact stocks. The S&P 500 is expected to swing by over 1% on Friday, with some analysts warning that Powell's cautious approach could threaten the market's recent gains.

images.alt_text: In remarks earlier this month, San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President Mary Daly said it is too soon to know if the US July jobs report signals a slowdown or real weakness, but cautioned it is “extremely important” to prevent the labour market tipping into a downturn
Money market fund investors need to consider two powerful factors — inflation and short-term interest rates. The trend for both is clearly downward.
The Fed has held its policy rate in the 5.25 per cent to 5.5 per cent range for more than a year now to slow economic growth and keep downward pressure on inflation.

site_title: Fed confronts up to a million US jobs vanishing in revision
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to confront a downward revision of up to 1 million jobs in the year through March, the largest in 15 years, suggesting the labor market has been cooling for longer. This revision risks fuelling concerns that the Fed is falling behind the curve to lower interest rates. Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo economists expect the revision to show payrolls growth was at least 600,000 weaker than initially estimated, with monthly job gains averaging around 158,000. The revision will likely influence Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech and shape the tone for future interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JULY 05: People walk by the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on July 05, 2024 in New York City. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday that U.S. employers added 206,000 jobs in June, more than expected and slightly below the revised 218,000 added in May.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open with Fed in focus
summary: US stocks opened lower on August 20, with the Dow Jones falling 22 points (0.05%) to 40,874.52. The S&P 500 dropped 5.4 points (0.10%) to 5,602.88, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 27.7 points (0.15%) to 17,849.087. The declines come ahead of the Federal Reserve's minutes release and Chair Jerome Powell's speech at Jackson Hole. Investors are cautious, weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

images.alt_text: Traders work the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on August 16, 2024. US stocks edged lower in early trading Friday, as traders looked to lock in gains at the end of a positive week for major Wall Street indices. Around 10 minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1 percent at 40,518.87, and the S&P was 0.1 percent lower at 5,536.08. The Nasdaq slipped 0.2 percent to 17,566.08. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Global digital economy will hit US$16.5 trillion by 2028: report
summary: The global digital economy is projected to reach $16.5 trillion by 2028, accounting for 17% of global GDP, according to a Forrester report. The US and China will power two-thirds of the digital economy, with online retail and travel sectors driving growth at 9% and 7% CAGR, respectively. Countries must focus on digital businesses, public services, and tech investments to nurture growth, with the US and China dominating technology spending and e-commerce.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians along a promenade in Qingdao, Shandong Province, China, on Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024. China has announced a 20-step action plan to get people to spend more, but offered little in the way of financial incentives to rev up domestic demand. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Kaisa forecasts bigger H1 net loss on slower property deliveries
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group expects a net loss of 8.8 billion yuan to 9.8 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion to S$1.8 billion) for the half year ended June 30, citing slower property deliveries and higher impairment provisions. The slowdown in the property market, exacerbated by a regulatory crackdown, has led to decreased revenues and unsold inventory. This is the second consecutive year Kaisa has reported a net loss, with a 6.6 billion yuan loss in the previous year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of Kaisa is seen in front a Chinese flag at a construction site that is being developed by Kaisa Group Holdings, in Shanghai, China, December 7, 2021. Picture taken December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Chaos and consequence
summary: Market volatility is expected to continue, with a strategic, market-weight allocation offering the best balance of portfolio risk and reward. The US Federal Reserve's reaction to recession fears and monetary policy will significantly impact market conviction. The Fed is likely to ease policy, potentially with a 50 bp cut in September, to keep recession risks at bay. A diversified portfolio weathers volatility better than alternatives, and investors should consider unwinding overweight or underweight positions in favor of a market-weight position. The outcome of the US election and geopolitical tensions also pose significant risks to markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve Building stands in Washington April 3, 2012. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba’s revenue misses estimates in a blow to revival effort
summary: Alibaba's revenue missed estimates in the June quarter, rising 4% to 243.2 billion yuan, despite aggressive promotions and new shopping features. The company's net income fell 27% to 24.3 billion yuan, driven by heavy costs to attract shoppers. The disappointing results will likely unnerve investors, who worry that Alibaba's drive to win market share in China will compress margins. The company's efforts to enhance its commerce and cloud businesses, and invest in AI technology, may be hindered by the uncertain Chinese economy and intense competition from rivals PDD Holdings and JD.com.

images.alt_text: Tencent's revenue jumped 8 per cent to 161.1 billion yuan (S$29.7 billion) for the April-to-June period, versus the projected estimate of 161.4 billion yuan.

Upstream tells the story of a middle-aged programmer who is laid off, shut out of white-collar jobs because of his age and pushed into the perilous food-delivery gig economy to try to keep his family afloat.
Large Chinese tech companies have conspicuously turned to buybacks this year to enhance shareholder return given their lacklustre sales growth.

site_title: Standing out with bold sustainable strategies, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 applications are now open, with a deadline of June 30. The awards recognize and celebrate innovative and forward-thinking businesses, particularly those in the early stages of development. The awards aim to promote entrepreneurship, growth, and job creation. Eligible businesses can submit their applications online, and a panel of judges will select the winners based on their impact, innovation, and potential for growth. Winners will be announced in August, and the awards ceremony will take place in September. The awards are open to businesses of all industries and sizes.

site_title: Filipino food goes upscale at Hayop
summary: Hayop, a new Filipino restaurant in Singapore, serves traditional dishes in upscale surroundings. The eatery is a direct import from the Philippines, adhering to authentic recipes. Dishes include lumpia (S$14), crispy sisig (S$22), cured hamachi kinilaw (S$28), and wagyu and watermelon sinigang (S$56). Flavors can be intense, with vinegar and salty flavors prevalent. Friendly servers, led by Karen, cater to new diners, but some dishes may be too extreme for palates. Overall, Hayop offers a unique experience, with a rating of 7.

site_title: StarHub broadband service restored after DNS server outage on Tuesday
summary: StarHub's broadband service was restored after a DNS server outage affected customers in Pasir Ris and Jurong on Tuesday evening. The outage began around 8 pm and was resolved by 9:15 pm. Customers were advised to reboot their routers or restart their TV/set-top boxes to resolve connection issues. The problem was attributed to an issue with StarHub's domain name service (DNS) server, which has since been resolved.

images.alt_text: PHOTO OF STARHUB

site_title: US: Stocks lose ground ahead of Fed address
summary: US stocks lost ground on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.2% to 40,834.97 and the S&P 500 Index retreating by the same amount to 5,597.12, ahead of a Federal Reserve speech later this week. The Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 0.3% to 17,816.94. The losses come after a rally supported by strong retail sales figures and a cooler inflation report. The Fed's speech is expected to influence market sentiment and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, June 28, 2024. Wall Street traders sent stocks toward fresh all-time highs as signs of inflation cooling reinforced bets the Federal Reserve will be able to start cutting interest rates this year. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: TSMC breaks ground on 10 billion euros German plant in chip war salvo
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, broke ground on its first European plant in Dresden, Germany, valued at 10 billion euros. The 10 billion euro project aims to produce chips for the automotive and industrial sectors, with 70% stake held by TSMC. The move is part of Europe's efforts to reduce its reliance on Asia for semiconductor imports, amid growing US-China tensions and the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on global chip supplies. Production is slated to begin by the end of 2027.

site_title: Singapore beefs up operational technology masterplan to enhance cyber resilience
summary: Singapore has updated its Operational Technology Cybersecurity Masterplan to enhance the country's cyber resilience. The plan, launched by Minister for Digital Development and Information Josephine Teo, includes operational technology cybersecurity in computer science and engineering degree courses. This move aims to boost the cybersecurity of Singapore's OT sector, following high-profile attacks on critical infrastructure, such as Ukraine's heating systems. The refreshed masterplan will also professionalize the local cybersecurity workforce.

images.alt_text: Minister for Digital Development and Information and Minister-in-charge-of Cybersecurity Josephine Teo at OTCEP on Aug 20.

site_title:
Bespoke solutions, global vision beyond
traditional private banking are key to
manage ultra wealth across borders
summary: HSBC's Global Private Banking emphasizes tailored wealth management solutions for ultra-high-net-worth (UHNW) individuals, who often require holistic approaches to manage complex wealth across multiple jurisdictions. Despite 73% of UHNW individuals living in more than one market, only 20% have comprehensive wealth plans. HSBC's global network and local expertise enable it to provide bespoke solutions, including succession planning, family governance, and flexible investment strategies. The bank's presence in Singapore, a key financial hub, allows it to tap into the city-state's robust infrastructure while providing global diversification to its clients.

images.alt_text: From left (back row): Rowan Tan, head of global solutions group of South-east Asia; Wong Hsien Sheng, head of ultra-high-net-worth market solutions of South Asia; Pritash Mathur, head of family office coverage of global India/ global South Asia. From left (front row): Kerri Lim, head of ultra-high-net-worth segment of Asia; Tommy Leung, head of global private banking of South Asia.

site_title: US financial officials head to China after leaders’ policy meet
summary: US and Chinese economic officials will meet in Shanghai on August 15-16 for the Financial Working Group (FWG) talks, focusing on macroeconomic stability, governance of the International Monetary Fund, and capital markets issues. The US delegation, led by Treasury officials, aims to maintain communication channels with China on shared challenges while pursuing policies to protect national security. This meeting comes amid heightened trade tensions, with Washington raising concerns over China's export-oriented industrial policy. The talks are part of the Biden administration's efforts to engage with China on economic issues.

images.alt_text: A view of the Yangshan Deepwater Port from a nearby fishing pier in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, 06 DECEMBER 2023.   Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Small US inflation pickup won’t derail a Fed rate cut in September
summary: US inflation is expected to rise 0.2% in July, but not enough to derail a Federal Reserve interest-rate cut in September. Recent easing of price pressures has bolstered Fed officials' confidence in lowering borrowing costs. The jobs report showed a slowdown in hiring and a rise in the unemployment rate, contributing to a global stock market sell-off. A slight pickup in inflation is seen due to core services excluding housing, but the long-awaited slowdown in shelter costs should continue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A jogger runs past the Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, U.S., August 22, 2018. REUTERS/Chris Wattie/File Photo

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant sees profit slide 10% after shakeup
summary: Ant Group, backed by billionaire Jack Ma, reported a 10% profit drop in the March quarter due to a structural shakeup and efforts to grow overseas. The company contributed 3.9 billion yuan (S$717.7 million) to Alibaba Group Holding, with an estimated 11.7 billion yuan in profit. Ant has been expanding its international operations, including cross-border payments, and is awaiting a financial holding company licence to revive its IPO plans. The company made significant overhauls in March, including setting up independent boards for its international, database, and digital technologies units.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an Ant Group logo at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun

site_title: What the history-making elections of 2024 could mean for energy
summary: The 2024 elections in the US, UK, France, South Africa, and Mexico could impact the global energy landscape. A Trump victory in the US could limit tax incentives for electric vehicles and renewable energy, while a Labour government in the UK aims to achieve a carbon-free power grid by 2030. France's gridlock could delay energy investments, and South Africa's new government could facilitate private developers in clean energy projects. Mexico's president-elect has proposed a green transition, and a Democratic victory in the US would likely benefit renewables.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose by 18 cents, or 0.2 per cent to settle at US$76.48 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia expects to benefit from ramp-up in HDB building activity in H2
summary: Hong Leong Asia expects to benefit from a ramp-up in HDB building activity in the second half of the year, which is expected to boost its building materials segment. Despite a 4.4% year-on-year decline in revenue from the segment in the first half, CEO Stephen Ho is confident the company can meet prefabrication orders and increase production. The company's powertrain solutions segment saw a 16.3% growth in engine unit sales and a 28.8% increase in profit after tax. Hong Leong Asia's H1 net profit rose 60.1% to S$49.4 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of S$0.01 per share.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The VLCC market appears to have almost bottomed out, with rates easing slightly. The capesize market showed a steady positive trend, peaking at $20,509 on Wednesday. The Atlantic market maintained a positive tone, with the C3 index rising to $24.695. The Panamax market had a negative return, with rates receding throughout the week. The ultramax and supermax markets also saw weakening activity, with the South Atlantic remaining finely balanced. In contrast, the LNG market saw a significant increase, with the BLNG1-174 index rising by $11,000 to $87,800.

images.alt_text: Very Large Crude Carriers (VLCCs) line up at the Port of Corpus Christi, where they are being loaded with crude oil for shipping worldwide, in this handout picture taken July 2022. Port of Corpus Christi/Handout via REUTERS/File Photo
总吨位超过15万吨的双燃料动力油轮“Eagle Veracruz”，2024年1月23日正式注册为新加坡商船，这令在我国登记注册的船舶总吨位，突破1亿吨的重要里程碑。Eagle Veracruz是AET油轮控股公司旗下的天然气双燃料超大型油轮，主打节能环保。

site_title: Biden calls Harris' pick of Walz for VP 'great decision'
summary: US President Joe Biden praised the selection of Minnesota Governor Tim Walz as Kamala Harris' running mate, calling it a "great decision" that will make a "powerful voice for working people and America's great middle class". Biden expressed support for Harris' choice, highlighting the significance of the first major decision made by a party nominee.

images.alt_text: (COMBO) This combination of pictures created on August 2, 2024, shows US Vice President Kamala Harris in Washington, DC on July 22, 2024, and Governor of Minnesota Tim Walz in Washington, DC, July 3, 2024. Harris named Walz as her running mate on August 6, 2024, US media reported, as the vice president prepares to take on Republican Donald Trump in November's US election. (Photo by Jim WATSON and Chris Kleponis / AFP)

site_title: Philippine central bank cuts policy rate by 25 bps
summary: The Philippine central bank cut its key policy rate by 25 basis points to 5.50% to help the economy cope with global challenges, including US trade policy fallout. The move aims to support growth amid a "more challenging external environment" and manageable inflation. The rate cut follows data showing inflation eased to a near five-year low of 1.8% in March. The bank will continue to take a measured approach to monetary easing, with growth targets set at 6.0-8.0% this year.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, Chairman of the Monetary Board and Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (central bank of the Philippines), speaks during a press conference with Queen Maxima of the Netherlands (not pictured), who is the UN Secretary General's Special Advocate for Inclusive Finance for Development (UNSGSA), in Manila on May 23, 2024. (Photo by JAM STA ROSA / AFP)

site_title: Milos wins with simple formula of Greek fish and tomatoes
summary: estiatorio Milos, a high-end Greek eatery at Marina Bay Sands, offers an upscale dining experience with a focus on fresh seafood and Mediterranean flavors. The restaurant's spacious interior features marble accents and a range of Greek specialties, including the famous Milos tomato salad and crispy fried zucchini and eggplant. The chef's selection of fish, including lavraki and Mediterranean sea bass, is flown in daily and expertly prepared. Prices are premium, but the quality and presentation justify the cost. Overall, estiatorio Milos is a top-notch destination for seafood lovers, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

images.alt_text: Onmi's minimalist interiors.

site_title: EC World Reit H1 DPU down 18.6% to S$0.01671 on lower revenue, higher operating expenses
summary: EC World Reit reported a 18.6% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01671 for the first half of 2024 due to lower revenue and higher operating expenses. The Reit's gross revenue dropped 8% to S$51.2 million, while net property income decreased 8.9% to S$47.2 million. The manager attributed the decline to the discontinuation of China Tobacco leases and higher operating expenses. As a result, the Reit manager announced that there will be no distribution for the period due to insufficient funds.

images.alt_text: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of the seven properties in EC World Reit's portfolio. EC World Reit's NPI fell 10.6 per cent to S$23.3 million in the first quarter, from S$26.1 million.

site_title: ‘Without a healthy planet, no people or business will thrive’: CDL’s chief sustainability officer
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL), a Singapore-based property giant, has been a pioneer in sustainability efforts for over two decades. The company, led by Chief Sustainability Officer Esther An, has set a strategy to minimize its impact on nature and mitigate nature-related risks. CDL has achieved various milestones, including being the first organization in Singapore to publish sustainability reports and issue a green bond. The company has also launched initiatives such as energy-efficient retrofitting and a "1 degree Celsius Up" campaign to encourage tenants to reduce energy consumption. CDL's commitment to sustainability is driven by its recognition of the importance of a healthy planet for business and human well-being.

images.alt_text: Esther An, Chief Sustainability Officer, City Developments Limited (CDL)
Esther An, Chief Sustainability Officer, City Developments Limited (CDL)

site_title: Foreign investors are pulling record amount of money from China
summary: Foreign investors pulled a record $15 billion from China in the April to June quarter, marking the second-largest decline on record, amid deep pessimism about the country's economy. This could be the first annual net outflow since 1990, driven by the slowdown in China's economy and rising geopolitical tensions. Foreign investment into China has slumped after reaching a record $344 billion in 2021, with some companies reducing their exposure due to the rapid shift to electric vehicles and rising interest rates in advanced economies.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024. The People's Bank of China is potentially getting the respite it’s been hoping for from global financial markets, bringing closer a dose of monetary stimulus long awaited by investors and traders. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore firms’ optimism about business prospects reach two-year high in Q2: BT-SUSS poll
summary: Singapore companies' optimism about business prospects reached a two-year high in Q2, with the net balance for business prospects rising to 8%, a 5-point gain over the previous quarter. This improvement is consistent with recent government surveys, and economists attribute it to a strengthening overseas market, particularly in electronics and AI-related demand. The transport and communications sector emerged as the star performer, with the highest net balances for sales, orders, and new business. However, small firms performed worse than a quarter ago, and the construction sector remains optimistic about business prospects.

images.alt_text: CMG20240622-YeapCT01/ 叶振忠/ Aerial Archival Shots Tags: Singapore Skyline, CBD, Economy, MBS

site_title: SingPost records 105.2% higher Q1 operating profit of S$24.4 million
summary: SingPost reported a 105.2% increase in Q1 operating profit to S$24.4 million, driven by higher revenue from Australia and Singapore businesses. Revenue rose 22.4% to S$494.8 million, despite a 20.1% increase in operating expenses. The company attributed the growth to e-commerce volumes and postage rates, but noted a decline in letter mail and printed-paper volumes. SingPost is in talks with the government on a future operating model to lower costs and improve customer experience.

images.alt_text: ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.

site_title: South Korean AI chip makers Rebellions and Sapeon agree to merge
summary: South Korean AI chip makers Rebellions and Sapeon Korea have signed a definitive merger agreement, aiming to challenge global AI chip leaders like Nvidia. Sapeon's shareholders include SK Telecom and SK Hynix, marking a significant attempt by South Korean companies to disrupt the global market. The deal follows previous attempts by companies to compete with Nvidia, highlighting the growing importance of AI chips in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: AI (Artificial Intelligence) letters are placed on computer motherboard in this illustration taken, June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Wall Street wants more signs US consumers are still spending
summary: US stocks are awaiting signs of continued consumer spending, as retail earnings reports from Target, Macy's, and TJX Cos. are expected to ease concerns about the health of the American consumer. Despite strong headline figures, analysts are looking for more evidence that consumers are not slowing down, citing Walmart's focus on discounts and taking market share from rivals. Consumer spending drives 2/3 of US economic growth, making retail earnings crucial.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Aug. 15, 2024. US retail sales accelerated in July by the most since early 2023 in a broad advance that points to a resilient consumer, even in the face of high prices and borrowing costs. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Employment claims in Singapore higher in 2023 on back of salary claims by foreign construction workers
summary: Singapore saw a rise in employment claims in 2023, driven by salary claims from foreign construction workers. The total number of claims increased to 9,397, with 54% lodged by foreign employees, who accounted for a third of the workforce. Salary claims made up 86.5% of these, with 2.19 claims per 1,000 employees, up from 1.68 in 2022. The majority of claims were resolved through the Tripartite Alliance for Dispute Management (TADM) or the Employment Claims Tribunals (ECT) within two months, with 94% of employees recovering their salaries in full.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Non-resident employment growth was driven mainly by work permit holders working in non-professional, managerial, executive, and technical roles in construction and manufacturing.
Jobs pertaining to technology, finance and the media were also well represented among the top 20 roles ranked by median gross wage.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Aug 5)
summary: Asian markets plummeted Monday, following a global sell-off triggered by US recession worries. The Straits Times Index fell 4.8% or 150 points, with Tokyo to Taiwan experiencing similar declines. Indonesia's economy grew 5.05% in Q2, in line with expectations. Singapore retail sales fell 0.6% in June, missing forecasts. Global markets also saw a steep sell-off in Singapore, with the STI diving 4.1%.

site_title: World’s richest lose US$134 billion in stock slump, led by Jeff Bezos
summary: Jeff Bezos' net worth dropped by $15.2 billion, erasing $134 billion from the fortunes of the world's 500 richest people, amid a global stock slump. Amazon's 8.8% drop in shares led to Bezos' net worth of $191.5 billion, his third-worst loss. The decline is attributed to uncertainty over Federal Reserve rate cuts and concerns about the tech-heavy market's concentration. Other tech billionaires, including Elon Musk and Larry Ellison, also lost billions.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, 61, is the world’s 14th-richest person, just behind Michael Dell.
Now the nation’s richest clans are a step closer to a controversial reprieve on the levies, which are among the highest in the world.
Bernard Arnault has tumbled to No 3 from being the world’s richest individual as recently as last month.
HSBC’s 2022 report on the rise of Asian wealth forecast the number of millionaires in Singapore rising to 700,000 by 2030.
Zhong Shanshan, chairman of Hangzhou-based Nongfu Spring, has lost US$13 billion so far in 2024, according to the Bloomberg billionaires Index, with a fortune of US$54.8 billion.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise to 11-month high
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose to an 11-month high of 249,000 for the week ended July 27, surpassing economists' forecasts of 236,000. The increase was driven by a surge in claims in Michigan and Missouri, which have motor vehicle assembly plants. The data suggests a softening in the labor market, which could support a September interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Despite this, layoffs remain low, with a separate report showing planned job cuts decreased 47% in July.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JULY 05: People walk by the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on July 05, 2024 in New York City. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday that U.S. employers added 206,000 jobs in June, more than expected and slightly below the revised 218,000 added in May.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Unemployment rolls swelled to the highest level in more than 2½ years in the first week of July, in line with a recent increase in the jobless rate.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell 17,000 to a seasonally adjusted 222,000 for the week ended Jul 6, the lowest level since late May.
Employers have little need for extra help because they see business demand softening, says the author.
New inflation data will be released on Jul 11, and if price pressures continue easing it may prompt Fed officials to at least open the door to interest rate cuts as soon as September .

site_title: Infineon adjusts revenue outlook after missing quarterly forecast
summary: Infineon reported 3.7 billion euros in revenue for the April-to-June period, missing the forecast of 3.8 billion euros and down 9% from the year prior. The company cut 1,400 jobs and relocated 1,400 positions as part of its "Step Up" cost savings program. Infineon narrowed its annual revenue guidance to around 15 billion euros, its third downgrade in a few months. CEO Jochen Hanebeck attributed the weak economic momentum and prolonged inventory levels to the company's slow recovery in target markets.

images.alt_text: Unlike Malaysia and Singapore, Indonesia’s chipmaking facilities is still in its nascent stage and has not yet made a substantial contribution to the country’s gross domestic products.
Intel Malaysia's ATP facilities in Penang. With MNCs implementing US+1 and China+1 strategies, Malaysia stands to benefit from this trend.

site_title: China central bank asks some institutions to report daily long-term bond holdings: sources
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has asked some financial institutions to report daily changes in their long-term treasury bond positions and balances. This move comes amid a surge in demand for China's sovereign bonds, with yields hitting record lows. The PBOC has also warned of the risk of a bond market bubble and has announced plans to sell treasury bonds to cool the rally. Yields on China's 30-year treasuries dropped to a record low of 2.2925% on Monday, amidst concerns over financial instability.

images.alt_text: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee
The PBOC also plans to continue to prevent and resolve financial risks in key areas such as the real estate sector.

The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Monday, June 26, 2023. China's consumer-driven recovery is showing more signs of losing momentum as spending slows on everything from holiday travel to cars and homes, adding to expectations for more stimulus to support the economy. Source: Bloomberg
Banks have had little appetite for the MLF funds in recent months, as a decline in market rates meant it became cheaper for them to borrow from each other than from the PBOC.
Mired in a property slump and beset by deflation, China’s economy needs a low interest-rate environment to stimulate growth.

site_title: Kamala Harris vice-president choice narrows to Walz, Shapiro: sources
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to announce her vice-presidential running mate by Tuesday, ahead of her public appearance at Temple University in Philadelphia. The finalists are Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro and Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, with Harris having interviewed the three top candidates, including Senator Mark Kelly, over the weekend. The decision is crucial as Harris prepares to challenge Republican nominee Donald Trump in the November election.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris waves as she departs to return to Washington, at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston, Texas, U.S., August 1, 2024. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo
Social media platforms, including X, have been under scrutiny for years over the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories, including false information about elections and vaccines.
US Vice President Kamala Harris started August with US$377 million cash on hand, the largest war chest at this point in an election cycle.

Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) kicks off her 2020 Democratic presidential campaign at an outdoor rally in downtown Oakland, Calif., Jan. 27, 2019. Harris often embraced liberal ideas during the Democratic primary race, but her candidacy failed to catch fire and she dropped out in December. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)
Customers at a supermarket in California. The inflation that has plagued the US has come substantially from supply-side factors or shocks hampering the economy’s ability to churn out goods.
Overall, 7 per cent of US adults held or used crypto in 2023, down three percentage points from 2022 and down five percentage points from 2021.
While Harris has yet to map out her proposals, economists expect her to broadly adhere to the Biden administration’s current policy mix for now.

site_title: Tinned fish is swimming against the tide
summary: Tinned fish, once a staple during World War II, has made a comeback on social media, restaurant menus, and in Gen Z's cupboards. The product's reputation as "akin to cat food or bunker food" has changed, with artisanal tinned food companies like Fishwife and online-delivery businesses like Tinned Fish Market capitalizing on the trend. Influencers like Mei Liao are showcasing tinned fish as a convenient and flavorful option, with sales of premium tinned fish growing at triple the rate of the broader market.

images.alt_text: The entrance to 2-star Ynyshir. You don't get more rural than this.
From Spam to corned beef, sales of canned meat are booming

site_title: Bursa Malaysia sees IPO boom as investor demand soars and share prices surge
summary: Bursa Malaysia's initial public offering (IPO) market has gained momentum in 2024, with 28 new listings in the first seven months of the year, surpassing the highest number in South-east Asia. Strong investor demand, sectoral momentum, and a streamlined approval process are driving the surge, with share prices of nine newly listed companies jumping by more than double. The market is expected to reach its target of 42 IPOs this year, adding RM7.31 billion to Bursa's market capitalization.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's stock market is leading peers in South-east Asia with a 12 per cent advance this year, while the number of initial public offerings have surged. More gains await if Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim is able cut more subsidies and reduce the fiscal deficit, investors said.
Johor Plantations Group plans to use the IPO proceeds to build a renewable-powered palm oil complex, tree replanting, and debt repayment.
Well Chip Group is the third pawnbroking company listed on the Bursa Malaysia, after Evergreen Max Cash Capital and Pappajack.
Intel Malaysia's ATP facilities in Penang. With MNCs implementing US+1 and China+1 strategies, Malaysia stands to benefit from this trend.

site_title: Singapore luxury furniture market battles new challenges
summary: Singapore luxury furniture market faces new challenges, with local retailers adapting to changing consumer behavior and increased competition from international online stores. Grafunkt, a local furniture retailer, is moving to a new location in Joo Chiat, aiming to build a community of like-minded partners and create a design destination. Xtra, another local design-focused furniture store, has seen an increase in younger customers and is focusing on providing good pricing, in-store service, and excellent after-sales service. The demand for luxury furniture in Singapore is on par with overseas markets, but the market has declined by 20-30% due to economic uncertainty and increased interest rates. Despite this, retailers remain optimistic, with some segments, such as kitchen and wardrobe, performing well.

site_title: When will DBS get a new CEO?
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta is nearing his 15th year at the helm of the bank and has not ruled out stepping down, despite saying he has a "robust succession planning process" in place. Gupta, 64, is among the oldest CEOs of Singapore companies in Temasek's portfolio. The bank has historically chosen external successors, but internal candidates, such as Han Kwee Juan and Tan Su Shan, are also being groomed for the role. The timing of the change is uncertain, with factors including the bank's annual general meeting and board chairmanship renewal potentially influencing the decision.

images.alt_text: Under CEO Piyush Gupta’s leadership, DBS – South-east Asia’s largest lender – has continued to break its profit records, and provide strong returns to investors.
Singapore banking counters have enjoyed strong share performances on expectations that the US Federal Reserve will hold rate cuts to later in the year, say analysts.
Gabriel Lim (left) will join Temasek as its joint head for corporate strategy, while Eng Aik Meng (centre) and Dinesh Khanna (right) will join as joint heads of Temasek's portfolio development group.

site_title: North Korea Olympians not given Samsung phones: IOC
summary: North Korean Olympians were not given Samsung smartphones, contrary to initial reports suggesting the phones could violate UN sanctions against the country. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) stated that no Samsung phones were provided to North Korean athletes, amid concerns raised by South Korea's government that the phones could be a breach of UN resolutions. The move comes as tensions between the two Koreas remain high, with North Korea recently deploying 250 ballistic missile launchers to its southern border.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Bronze medalists South Korea's Lim Jonghoon (L) takes a selfie picture with his mobile as he celebrates on the podium with : gold medalists China's Wang Chuqin (rear R) and China's Sun Yingsha (front L), silver medalists North Korea's Ri Jong Sik (2nd L), and North Korea's Kim Kum Yong (C) and bronze medallist and teammate South Korea's Shin Yubin (rear R) at the end of their mixed table tennis doubles competition at the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the South Paris Arena in Paris on July 30, 2024. (Photo by JUNG Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: China rejects US$1 trillion housing rescue package proposed by IMF
summary: China has rejected a proposed $1 trillion housing rescue package by the International Monetary Fund, citing concerns over moral hazards and market-based solutions. The IMF proposed using central government funds to complete unfinished housing or compensate homebuyers. China's executive director for the IMF, Zhang Zhengxin, stated that direct government support would lead to expectations of future bailouts and undermine market principles. The rejection suggests China's reluctance to unleash a large fiscal stimulus to address the prolonged housing downturn.

images.alt_text: A new residential property development in Wuhan, China, on Wednesday, March 15, 2024. Chinese officials on Friday, May 17, 2024, took their boldest step yet, unveiling a nationwide plan to buy up some of the vast housing stock languishing on the market. (Qilai Shen/The New York Times)

site_title: Platform worker protections tabled in Parliament under new Bill
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Bill to provide protections for platform workers, including Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions, work injury insurance, and a legal framework for representation. The Bill aims to address the gaps faced by ride-hailing and food delivery workers in housing and retirement adequacy, work injury compensation, and legal representation. The move is seen as an important milestone for platform workers, who are currently deemed self-employed persons (SEPs) and lack basic job protections.

images.alt_text: MOM said that creating a class of “platform workers” distinct from employees would make it easier to understand the legal protections available.

site_title: Adani Enterprises to return to equity market with US$1 billion share sale: sources
summary: Adani Enterprises is set to return to the equity market with a $1 billion share sale by mid-September, marking its second attempt at raising funds this year after a failed $2.5 billion sale in February. The company scrapped the original sale after US-based Hindenburg Research accused the Adani group of improper use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation. Adani has denied any wrongdoing and plans to raise funds through a Qualified Institutional Placement (QIP) process.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the facade of its Corporate House on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave//File Photo

site_title: S-E Asia’s startup ecosystem continues to brave funding drought
summary: South-east Asia's startup ecosystem is facing a prolonged funding drought, with venture capital firms struggling to raise money for attractive startups. The situation worsened in the first half of 2024, with funding declining 65% to $1.6 billion, a significant drop from $4.5 billion in the same period last year. Founders are becoming more selective about investors, prioritizing strategic fit and value-add over brand name. The lack of exits has also led to a decrease in fund deployment for venture capital firms, with profitability now being a key metric for investors. A total of 78% of VC funds in Asia-Pacific took over 19 months to reach their target sum in the first quarter of 2024.

site_title: Malaysia sets up chip-design hub to boost semiconductor industry
summary: Malaysia establishes a chip-design hub in Selangor state to boost its semiconductor industry, aiming to improve its chip-design capabilities and move away from testing and packing. The hub, in partnership with Cadence Design Systems and Arm Holdings, is part of the country's efforts to increase its role in the global supply chain and double its exports to RM1.2 trillion by 2030, making it the sixth-largest chip exporter in the world. The move is seen as a strategic response to tensions between the US and China, with Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli stating that the nation wants to see more data centres using chips designed by Malaysians.

images.alt_text: Rafizi Ramli, vice-president of the People's Justice Party, speaks during a live Facebook feed at the Invoke Space offices in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, April 18, 2017. Photographer: Charles Pertwee/Bloomberg

site_title: Sembcorp H1 profit up 2% to S$540 million on absence of loss from discontinued operation
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 2% increase in net profit to S$540 million for the first half of 2024, driven by the absence of a S$78 million loss from a discontinued operation. Earnings per share rose to S$0.303, up from S$0.2971 the previous year. Revenue fell 12% to S$3.2 billion, mainly due to lower contributions from the gas and renewables segments. The company expects earnings to be fairly stable in the full year, with a focus on growing its renewables portfolio and investing in low-carbon industrial parks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, SIA, Keppel, Japfa
summary: Singaporean stocks saw notable developments on Thursday, August 1, 2024. UOB's net profit rose 1% to S$1.43 billion due to double-digit fee income growth and lower credit allowances. SIA reported a 38.5% drop in net profit to S$451.7 million in the first quarter, while Keppel's net profit increased 7% to S$513 million. Japfa reversed into the black with a net profit of US$51.7 million for the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of United Overseas Bank (UOB) in Singapore May 3, 2023. REUTERS/Caroline Chia/File Photo

site_title: The hottest item at the Olympics is a chocolate muffin
summary: Norwegian swimmer Henrik Christiansen has made a viral sensation on TikTok by raving about the chocolate muffins at the Paris 2024 Olympic Village. The rich treats, with their lava centers and chocolate chunks, have become his go-to breakfast option, providing much-needed calories for his intense training sessions. Christiansen, a three-time Olympian, credits the muffins for fueling his performance, and their popularity has inspired other athletes and food creators. The Olympic Village's boulangerie serves over 2,000 pastry items daily, with the chocolate muffins being a highlight of French cuisine at the Games.

images.alt_text: In an undated photo, Norwegian swimmer Henrik Christiansen poses with chocolate muffins at the Olympic Village dining hall, in Paris. Christiansen has become the unofficial ‘Olympic Muffin Man’ on TikTok. site_title: Cheapest Korean fine dining, oppa chef at Onmi
summary: Onmi, a Singaporean eatery, has introduced a new 10-course tasting menu at S$118, led by chef Jaewoo Ahn, a former sous chef at Michelin-starred Eatanic Garden in Seoul. Ahn's menu offers novel flavors, such as a cold perilla tea and creamy pine nut porridge, and a deconstructed samgye-tang or Korean ginseng chicken broth. The meal features a mix of traditional Korean dishes and modern twists, including buckwheat noodles, grilled beef short rib, and burdock ice cream. With its affordable price and high-quality cuisine, Onmi is a standout in Singapore's dining scene.
